If you're looking for a little conversation, sit outside as the inside can get quite noisy when the bands start to play.I'm usually good with a pint (0.5l) of the draught pale lager, which is light and goes down easy. If you're feeling a little full, they have them in 0.3l mugs as well (which are so cute!) or if you're thirsty, go for the 1l! The dunkel/dark version is quite good as well if you like it a little stronger tasting.For bar snacks, go for the german sausages, and they do a pretty good calamari too.One day perhaps I'll make it to eating in the restaurant itself!

You must of course be German to invite Chinese in Singapore in a Bavarian restaurant, and my colleagues are. The Paulaner is definitely not easy to reach with public transportation, so taking a cab is about the only feasible option. There is a microbrewery inside and the beer is actually quite good. Other than that, the food is almost more than the real thing: the pork legs are twice the size of those in Germany, and even my Zürcher Geschnetzeltes (difficult to find anything not Gerrman on the menu!) was made with bacon. Beer prices are reputedly the highest in Singapore. Service was very friendly. And the interior? Guess how it looks?

Ok, I haven't reviewed TAP because everybody else seems to have already.  I really don't feel like they need me to bolster their already soaring cred with my humble review, but anyway, here are my two mites...As mentioned in my other reviews, the craft beer scene in Singapore is at its most delicate and vulnerable, with hawkers of craft, tentatively putting out new shoots into the beer-naive firmament of Singapore's drink atmosphere.   With more than a few customers genuinely inquiring what an India Pale Ale is, it is a gentle time for those venturing into the market to deliver craft beers to thirsty or curious Singaporeans. I have always given 5-star ratings to those who are brave enough to venture out into the harsh unforgiving and often times brutal arena that is F&B in Singapore armed with little more than a burning desire to bring you what they believe to be good to eat and drink.  They absolutely deserve all the feeble help my timid Yelp can give them!Ok, so TAP...lTAP is brought to you by the same folks that brought you Thirsty, the lovable  neighborhood bottle shop that carried a very good collection of American craft beers which when they first started ran afoul of my taste buds when I got a six pack of "old" Blue Moon.  The stock is certainly a lot fresher than it used to be and besides being a good thing in and of itself, is also a fair indicator of just how much more Singaporeans are interested in and therefore more willing to fork over serious money for craft beer. This is a fairly recent thing and a very good thing for food and drink in Singapore.  Sit at the bar at TAP, or visit Thirsty or The Great Beer Experiment or Druggist and you'll hear more than a fair share of requests for IPAs, something that I have some mixed feelings about. While I am happy that my fellow Singaporeans are exploring the wide and wondrous world of beer and venturing outside their comfort zones of the national-brand lagers like Heineken, Carlsberg, and Tiger, I am a concerned that the IPA is going the way of single origin beans in Singapore, being smothered by that miasma of hipness and being slowly and smugly co-opted as a symbol of sophistication by hipsters.  I suppose I really can't knock anything that keeps those kegs actively rotating, and the last thing anybody wants is a beer yenta sitting next to them at the bar...so I'll shut up and sip my beer.As mentioned before, the beers at TAP are disproportionately well-represented by American craft breweries like Stone, Modern Times, Lost Coast and occasionally Mike Hess.  This being Singapore, the key is to capture the attention of walk-ins as there are no "regulars" to speak of, customers that come back regularly for the same thing, so TAP keeps the lineup interesting and it keeps changing.   At the time of this writing, they just hosted a UK takeover with some very decent ales, some of my personal favourites being the Pale Fire by Pressure Drop, Fourpure's IPA, Cali by Tiny Rebel, Bibble by Wild Beer, Pompelmocello by Siren and the very gravid, very ponderous Tsar Generation 4 by one of my all time favourite UK breweries, Buxton.As I think I mentioned in my review of NickelDime, it is a very nice coincidence that all these places that have ales on tap in Singapore are carving out their individual niches, so you can get some of the most highly rated beers from all over the world in a very small space.  Anytime you have that kind of varietal density, it's a good thing, a happy event, a righteous happenstance.

Ah!!!!! Craft brew on tap from San Diego and Portland!!! I can't freakin believe it.They have most the good beers made by Modern Times. Anytime I need a good IPA west coast IPA from tap...this is the place to go.Gentlemen, do take note that this place is also in the shopping areas in the city hall area, so man a great way to past the time on your next shopping trip with the lady. The food was only so so....but who cares!!!! You come here for beer and beer you will have!Had great conversation with the workers, not only super knowledgeable and true beerheads, they also knew a lot about the industry so some nice bar conversations..I will be making frequent trips to this place

Pros: Decent California craft beer selection. Selection of beer was primarily Californian, with the exception of Maui brewing co. selection due to Singapore craft beer week. Cons: $sgd 14 beer during happy hour.Lack of attentiveness to customers; waited 10 minutes before finally giving in and asking for another beer. Not acceptable when there is four employees working and we are the only ones sitting at the bar. Staff was not knowledgable with the exception of maybe the owner. Singapore has many options when it comes to beer and this establishment just doesn't stand out.

Here for the beer? Then you're looking for the right place! Wide selection of beers to choose from, and  at affordable prices!They're having a promotion for the whole of march; $10 for all beers, and house wines. Here for the food? Would recommend looking elsewhere; mostly finger food that have been microwaved. Go early cause it gets crowded

Just moved to SG from the beer havens of Chico, California (home of Sierra Nevada) and the San Francisco Bay Area. I've found a few great craft beer places here so far, but none have matched the service we ultimately got at Tap last night (to be fair, I've not yet tried Smith Street, but it's on my list). The bartenders, especially Thomas, are laid-back but pretty attentive, full of expertise and great tips for beer choices, and happy to recommend local beer events, etc.I especially like that they cluster a handful of different beers from each of a handful of breweries rather than just a random assortment of single brews from all over the place; so, for Modern Times (San Diego), you can try their version of 4-5 different types of beer, from IPAs to stouts.Prices are high, but given the location, selection, and quality, that's a small price. Definitely going back, and I'd haunt them on the regular if I didn't live out near West Coast.

Fantastic selection of ales on tap ... for SD$10 !!!Lost Coast - 8-Ball Oatmeal Stout ... on tap!!'Amazing selection of IPA's. Food ... warmed-up in a microwave "cuisine" at its best. 5 star rating is for ale price & selection.

Great place for various dark beers, meads, perhaps a shade too many IPAs, occasional knockouts like the Heretic porters. Best selection in town, most of it international. Great beer munchies made in a microwave. Who needs food, anyway... They have a loyalty card system, though won't honor cards older than a month... So don't forget one in your wallet like yours truly!  An excellent no nonsense place for beer lovers. Great for an evening pint or catch up. Wish they'd update their website regularly or have emailed alerts whenever they tap a new keg. Pretty much the only place I go to now for beers. Happy to see more outlets opening up. Great deal on growlers to fill and take home for parties too... Or to drink alone while you sob that they've run out of the Heretic Chocolate Stout!

This is my favorite place in Singapore to stop for a drink.  These guys always have an outstanding selection of beers.  They will often offer a bowl of flavorful popcorn on the house.  I love that I can get a pint of something different every time I come by.  You could consider visiting during happy hours for a $3 or $4 reduction in price.

Freshly brewed Nanyang coffee and a lemon cheese bun is the best! The smell is intoxicating and the taste will delight even the most hard core coffee critics.I am already sad about not having a Toast Box back home in Seattle.Try the authentic toast with peanut butter or the coconut egg tart. Both delicious! Just like their slogan,  you will say "Toast Box....I like."

Kaya Toast is life. What is Kaya? It's like a jam made out of coconut and egg, spread between to pieces of toast. Order it as a set with eggs and coffee! That way, you can dip the toast in soft boiled eggs for a classic Singapore breakfast. We prefer Ya Kun for getting Kaya Toast just because the coffee is better there. But toast box offers this other item, toast with ham, cheese, and egg, and they flame torch the cheese. It's SO good!

I came here because it was ultra busy and wanted to see what the crowd is about. The place is very cute and coffee house like place that services light bites, drinks and desserts. It's great because it's one of few places that actually opens early...7:30am. I got the laska soup and a black tea. Both were fine for the price which was only 7.50 sgd. I wouldn't say it was anything special though. Bottom line..come for the ambience or a safe place to grab a bite or drink early in the morning. ProsIn a shopping mall in the basement so it's easy to get to Affordable Cons Food is just ok Tea is just ok

I was referred to this place by a local and it was quick, and decent in satisfying my cravings for Laksa. Next time I might venture out of the mall but for the price I am not unhappy. The coffee is strong, the Laksa filling..
Great place for quick breakfast. Sausage roll is my favorite. Kopi Peng (local iced coffee) is my favorite.

Chain serving kaya toast and traditional coffee / tea (Kopi / Teh) in Singapore. Both are pretty good but personally I prefer Yakun (another famous chain serving similar items). They also serve laksa, other bakery (cake, brownies, etc.) and other drinks (would recommend the barley drink). The venue in MBS is very convenient for a shopping break
Singaporean faves. Easy, quick, and cheap. The laksa was alarmingly delicious, and the kaya toast was simply delectable. Even the kopi is tasty!

I usually go simple at Toast Box with just kaya toast (sometimes with eggs) and a milk tea or kopi. This Toast Box near Esplanade was quite good. The seating area is pretty spacious and the aunties at the counter were soooo friendly to me, which is a step up from other Toast Boxes I've been to. As usual the kaya toast was good for a quick snack and the milk tea is always refreshing.

Toast Box is a nice stop for a break during the workday as they offer all sorts of little snacks and drinks.  The seating here is shared with other restaurants in the this "food court" area.I had the plum soda which was refreshing, but very much too sweet.  All the sweet "plum" stuff is at the bottom, so make sure you stir it up really well.  They also have kopi/coffe, Milo, barley tea, and various other hot and cold drinks.Not much else to be said about Toast Box - extremely affordable, air-conditioned, food court-type pick-me-up during the work day type of place.

I'm a fan of this place. For a food-court type of cafe in almost all the malls, this place is not pricey, it maintains a very clean and lovely image, and the food is good.The citylink location can get quite busy at lunch (though, given my observations at raffle city, not as much).  I went there at around 1pm to grab some food and there was nowhere to sit. The people who work there were extremely friendly though, and tried to get me to wait for a bit for a seat, but I opted to get the takeout anyway.Admittedly, what attracted me there in the first place was their large sign for Laksa. I realize the danger in getting laksa in a place called Toast Box, but I was not disappointed. The laksa was creamy and flavourful, and they were not stingy on the ingredients. For $4.50, that's pretty incredible. I also really wanted to try the Kaya toast there, and for $1.40 - why not? And traditional milk tea for $1? Awesome. The kaya was really really buttery though, so if i get a chance to go back, i'd request for less butter. It was delicious, nevertheless.Thumb up!

The lava egg tart is probably the best thing i have ever had.  The crust is flakey and a little sweet and when you bite into the tart the egg yolk will run out of the center of the tart so hold it close to  your mouth so you can let it drip onto your tongue  and not onto your tie.

In desperate need for a sugar hit, a cold drink, and some air conditioning after a Sunday morning of walking around we stumbled across this Toast Box which was the only thing in the area that was open. While I was initially skeptical as I knew it was a chain store, I loved the decor and was absolutely parched.The menu was extensive and I will forever regret not ordering the Milo toast. I'd already had kaya toast that morning though, so went with the banana cake. It was a generous size serve and fresh, light and fluffy. Just what I needed. I also ordered a delicious lemon and lime drink with tapioca pearls upon recommendation from the guy behind the counter. It was absolutely perfect, and easily some of the best pearls I've had which surprised me a lot!My partner ordered the kaya toast set with kopi and I felt happy with my choices. He said they were okay, but the kopi wasn't as great as we've previously had.

When I first came to Singapore, I was instantly brought here by my friends. They kept on telling me that Toast Box is like the first place to go to upon arrival. So they brought me to the branch in Suntec City. I think it was a good idea. I liked the Milo toast personally.

I believe there are 2 SBCD korean tofu house locations, one at Millenia Walk and the other at Wallich Street.  The one at Millenia Walk is a better location.My niece recommended the Assorted Soontofu which I decided to go with that. Each of us ordered the same and we all opted "Mild" for the spicy level.FOOD 4/5I really enjoyed the Assorted Soontofu. It was so delicious and the dish was loaded with Crab, prawns, squid, beef and of course tofu. It also came with rice. I wish I could get more rice so I could eat more rice with the tofu.The variety of banchan here was very limited. My only complaint was: they really need to de-vein the prawns.SERVICE 5/5Service was great! A staff also gave each of us a complimentary pan-fried fish which I politely declined. I was slightly taken aback when  the staff placed the plate of fish with the head still intact in front of me  :/ I am sure the fish was good since everyone was happily enjoying them.AMBIANCE 4/5The SBCD at Millenia Walk was huge and spacious inside. This location is next to the Promenade Station.If one still has room for coffee or dessert, I highly recommend checking out Patisserie G or Kith Café inside Millenia Walk. Who knows you may even find me there :D lol!PS. I have been thinking of the soontofu after I got home on Monday and been craving for it every day since. Planned to pick up one on the same week Friday and enjoy it while watching TV & relaxing at home :)

If u have eaten BCD Tofu in LA this place would remind you a lot of it. We tried the original Beef just have a comparison.  Got to say this is one of the better tofu soup around the island as most of the soup comes pretty watery.   Taste wise really not too bad and the side dish also pretty good.   sorry can't give a five as servuce is indeed lacking as they seem to be under staff and of course price a little off.  Aug 10th '18Back again for the same stuff unfortunately price shot up by 3 for the original Beef Soon tofu so looks like it just it the threshold of not worth it
LA galbi is a bit pricey, but its definitely my favorite! The side dishes truly show somewhat delicate features of traditional Korean food! would love to come back!

address: 7 Raffles Boulevard Level 1, Marina Square Singapore 039595 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Closed']), ('Tue', ['6:00 AM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Wed', ['6:00 AM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Thu', ['6:00 AM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Fri', ['6:00 AM - 3:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Sat', ['6:00 AM - 3:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Sun', ['Closed'])]
comment: LocationIf your taking the train its nearer to drop off at promenade station and walk towards Pan Pacific, if your driving there is a basement carpark which is so damn convinient. Pretty plush and dim setting with sofa tables by the side. For me its a great setting to just chill unwind with your date before 12am. After that its a little crazy in there at times. I have not tried the food there, all i had there was truffle fries which was addictive. If you love hip hop you have to visit this place, mattblacc spins there and they play really good stuff! There is a relatively small dance floor for you guys to flaunt your moves.The service crew there are extremely polite, enthusiastic and jovial! Drinks and food may take a awhile when its gets busy. Its not a huge establishment so be patience.Overall you have to check this place out! 4 stars!

address: 7 Raffles Boulevard Level 1, Marina Square Singapore 039595 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Closed']), ('Tue', ['6:00 AM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Wed', ['6:00 AM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Thu', ['6:00 AM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Fri', ['6:00 AM - 3:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Sat', ['6:00 AM - 3:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Sun', ['Closed'])]
comment: I was taken here by a friend to celebrate my birthday, and I think this place is grossly overpriced, with mediocre cooking skills, and soso ingredients.The supposed selling point of this place is meant to be the Matching of your sides and mains. Basically, you pick and choose what fish/pork/beef you want, with whatever veggies and sauces and add-ons. I was not impressed with my lamb chops - on the verge of well done, and the bone marrow was tasteless. Fat is decadent only when well seasoned and well-cooked. Otherwise, it is bland and uninspiring. My asparagus, was well, okay.My friends got a few sides, the duck salad and something else I can't remember. I remember them being overpriced for what they were.This place's saving grace was the ginormous parfait to share, and they put a sparkler when serving it, with a huge flourish. Great showmanship, average parfait. Towards the end of the night, the lights started to dim and the music was overpowering, presumably from the club next door. Do not take a date here, do not expect great ambience, do not eat here.

address: 7 Raffles Boulevard Level 1, Marina Square Singapore 039595 Singapore

comment: Martinis! Martinis! Martinis!  This place is awesome! I make it point to stop by here every time I am in town.  The manager and bartender are all about the customer experience! Just like home!

address: 7 Raffles Boulevard Level 1, Marina Square Singapore 039595 Singapore
opening: [('Mon', ['Closed']), ('Tue', ['6:00 AM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Wed', ['6:00 AM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Thu', ['6:00 AM - 1:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Fri', ['6:00 AM - 3:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Sat', ['6:00 AM - 3:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Sun', ['Closed'])]
comment: Attended Match for restaurant week - two options for each course - I tried them all!   Everything was great - from the host staff and ambience to the food and the wine I was impressed that the bar you escape Bang Bang from to get a real drink can serve such great food with great service - I was delighted!

A friend just took me here for duck.  I've had Peking duck a bunch of places including one that presidents go to in Washington, various spots in London etc.  this was top of the list.  And the dim sum was amazing.  I wish I knew everything he ordered.  Top knot h.
good dim sum at kai garden, marina square. the beef hor fun was delish with tender beef slices so as the bbq char siew pastry. another option for good dim sum in singapore. will be back!

We pre ordered the whole duck $88 .... a little different twist with tri color pancakes and 6 different sauces. It was all about average.. not the best, but not the worst. Had it 2 way, with noodles afterwards, noodle didn't have much taste...Service was attentive....Bill was overpriced for the 2 dishes...

Review of the new Kai Duck restaurant at Takashimaya. Understated, casual but chic atmosphere. The long menu scores high on innovation, with lots of creative dishes or classic ones with a new touch. Unfortunately- and this may be teething issue only - execution can be improved: the duck tongues are too soft, the poached rice a bit too bland, the chilled black fungus a bit too salty, the roasted duck is less good than at ImpTreas or Crystal Jade, etc. The high-on-innovation/average-on-execution comment also applies to the staff uniform: unusual but highly unlikely to win any fashion award.

Nice ambience at open sitting area with rooms available for business meeting followed by lunch.3 ladies had the following:Chilled cherry foie gras, xiao long bao, fried charcoal pork bun, honey BBQ pork (charsiew), stir fried garlic kailan and braised vermicelli with fish & dried scallops.We could not try any desserts  coz were too full.Staff were generally attentive and can understand English apart from my colloquial Mandarin/Cantonese

Kai Garden is helmed by Chef Fung Chi Keung, the one who created the colorful Xiao Long Baos at Taste Paradise. Here, other than delicious traditional Cantonese fare, you have Cantonese fusion dishes as well. I like it that Chef Fung actually thought of putting the sweet & sour pork on ice to preserve its flavour & crunchiness of the exterior. You definitely must try the crispy Peking duck, sweet & sour pork on ice & Kung Fu Tea here!

I'm pretty skeptical about marketing gimmicks such as labels like 'Top Restaurant in X" and "Best Y cuisine..". You can so imagine this cynical one rolling her eyes when she receive the invitation to taste the "Best Peking Duck in Singapore". BUT seriously, newly opened Kai Garden at Marina Square really lives up to that label. Consider me impressed with Chef-Owner and Executive Chef Fung Chi Keung's traditional Peking Duck when i tasted it. It was indeed the best that i've had. Chef Fung was previously from the Paradise Group, so you can be expecting a strong Cantonese cuisine at this 200-seater restaurant in Marina Square. So the glistening Peking Duck ($88/duck) is definitely the star here. The crispy skin was simply amazing (and i don't even really enjoy skin). The layer of fats under the naturally colored, browned crust simply renders beautifully in one's mouth. It doesn't taste too oily even.Accompanying the duck is an interesting selection of wraps- Original, Pumpkin, Green(Spinach), Bamboo Charcoal, and Beetroot.While the wraps didn't taste much of their stated ingredient, they added pretty colors, plus a great texture and balance to each bite. It's fairly thin, with just a light amount of chewiness, and it remained fairly moist even as the baskets made their rounds around the huge dining table. There are also 5 sauces that come with the dish (Duck, Black Pepper, Sesame, Seafood, or Special Mixed). Well i was happy with the regular sweet salty original duck sauce. The Double-boiled Japanese Matsutake served in Tea Pot ($38/pax) was stellar. The Matsutake is Japan's answer to the black truffle (it's very rare and unique) and it gave a sweet and earthy balance to the traditional Cantonese soup.Grouper in Lobster Soup (seasonal price) is a simple fish dish, flash cooked in a super umami Asian lobster bisque. It's rich without being too heavy. And the fish was given the TLC on the spot for that perfect doneness. I could have a whole pot of this easily. While i'm not exactly sure if serving crispy food on ice helps to maintain the crunchy texture, i enjoyed the Sweet and Sour Pork on The Rocks ($22/serving). I was afraid that the balls would be cold but thankfully they were warm still. The light crunch batter encased the juicy roughly minced pork and the sauce was balanced with the right amount of acidity and sweetness. Deep Fried Vegetarian Roll ($22) is a beautiful web of bamboo fungus that holds a juicy mix of vegetables and mushroom with tofu. The texture is amazing and the layers picked up the delicious pumpkin and chicken stock which was an intense reduction that i couldn't stop spooning. But other than that, the filling was pretty standard. If the bao skin were any indication the standard of their Kai Garden's dimsum, i would be here every weekend for brunch. Or supper if it's available every night. The Pan Fried Charcoal Pork Bun ($6.80 for 3pcs) is actually a xiao long bao in disguise. First the crisp crust, then the fluffy skin, and the juicy pork and broth in the center of it all. -slow clap- tears of joy- The meal concludes perfectly with the Chilled Fresh Coconut Puree ($6.80). This is such a great dessert! I would come back just for desserts alone. Kai Garden definitely has my vote for Best Peking Duck in town and I'm looking forward to sampling their Dimsum as well. For all you know, they may bag the Best Dimsum in Singapore title too.
Delicious peking duck with different sauces and variety of wraps.abalone was good.try the fried fish skins with salted egg yolk

Ok, after almost a decade of searching for Hong Kong quality yum cha / dim sum in Singapore a colleague recommended Kai Garden, and it was insanely good. Cornered away in Marina Square, this non-description looking Chinese Restaurant actually has some good views over Marina Bay and lots of natural light. We worked our way through the classics, siu mai, har gao, char siu (kurobuta), chive dumplings, xia long bao, char siu pau, cheong fan (excuse all my spelling). Everything that came out was as good as I've had anywhere in the world. Service was also great, my daughter was really cold so a waitress brought her out a blanket without us even asking. Very sweet. We were actually discussing going back the next day. Stop reading and go book this place now!

We celebrated our anniversary in this beautiful Italian restaurant with great views overlooking the iconic Marina Bay Sands! We had reserved an outdoor table for the occasion & was happy with the seating. The staff were were friendly! We had a welcome snacks of Chef's choice which was lovely. For the meals we opted for Ala Carte & had their recommended red wine for the night. For appetizers I chose the Polipo- The Pan seared octopus & my hubby had Uovo- Crispy organic egg! Both were delicious & very tasty. For our main course, I opted for Mantova's Risotto, which had the perfect flavor & the truffle made it so yummy. My hubby had Carbonara which they agreed to replace the meat with chicken! It was the best carbonara he ever had in Singapore! We were very satisfied with our choices! For dessert, we had ordered Tiramisu which was very different to taste than what I have had my entire life, so this was something I didn't enjoy at all! It was very sweet of them to serve us complimentary dessert for our anniversary- a red velvet cake & it was amazing! The service was bit slow as I felt there was only one waiter serving for all guests seated outside! We also received 15% discount for using our city credit card.. which was very nice! Overall we loved our experience & will be back soon.

Recently I have brought my mother to lunch at the restaurant which was located by the pool side. There was indoor air con and outdoor alfresco dining. We decided on indoor as it was pretty hot that day. We were showed to a table with a nice view of the pool. Although it was week day, it was quite a crowd at the pool. There was lunch set (S$38++/2 course, S$46++/3 course, S$54++/4 course)  for week day. After placing our order, we were served water, crusty bread and butter. The bread was soft and pillowy.Orecchiette alla NorcinaSignature Umbria's pork sausage ragout, spinach, pecorino Although simple looking, it was quite tasty.RisottoSpecial selection Acquerello rice, mushroom ragout, truffle scentIt smell quite nice when served. The rice was savoury and well cooked. BarramundiSeared Barramundi filletCrustacean soup, sautéed vegetables The fish was firm and juicy.PolloOrganic chicken roulade, charred kale, pearl onion mustard seed and mushroom ragoutThe meat was quite tender. Quite a heavy serving.Panna CottaVanilla panna cotta, berry coulis, berry spongeThe custard was smooth and milky, without too sweet.We ended the meal with coffee.For a quiet week day, the restaurant attracted quite fair bit of crowd for lunch.

Excellent place for brunch. Great Italian food and very attentive service. Price is reasonable by Singapore standards and you get a lot of choice in the food. Very good ambience as well with pool side views and the impressive MBS in the background. Located in the Mandarin Oriental hotel.Solid 4.5 stars!

Casual relax environment on a Sunday evening.  Host is friendly and welcoming.  Gone through 3 lovely appetizers and they were nicely presented and tasted wonderful. The mains were equally good.  The disappointment was the desserts were mostly sorbet.  All in all a good place for causal Italian.

We have been going to Dolce Vita every year for our anniversary since arriving to Singapore.  I am Italian and miss my Italian food very much and have always been so impressed with how fantastic the food tastes.  The ambiance is fantastic and the service is phenomenal.

Good things never come cheap and I have to agree that it's for a valid reason. Priced too low and it'll be flooded with all the bargain hunters. A usual spot for my girlfriend and I, both of us enjoy the starter of freshly baked bread with olives a lot. We go through the loaves so fast that we end up being too full and having to go with  the lighter dishes like  pasta  instead. My favourite has to be the osso bucco, one of the best I've had so far and I find myself ordering it over and over again on return visits. Coming in a close second for me and first for her would be the beef tenderloin with foie gras. The place in general is quiet, and we like it that way. Dinner conversations are always a joy to have without having to scream to hear one another. We've heard that brunch here is good as well but have yet to try it so far.

THE BEST OF THE BEST!Since I can remember my parents would always tell me about how we would go to Ruth's Chris Steak House when we lived in Washington D.C. As we moved back to Europe there was no such thing as a Ruth's Chris Steak House and the restaurant became a story that my parents would tell us when we would talk about the best steak houses. While I planned my trip to Singapore with my family, I thought to myself, could it be that there is one in Singapore? I knew that they had opened one in Hong Kong and were opening a couple throughout Asia. To my surprise, I was right! In 2012 (I think) it had opened in Singapore. Without hesitation I made us a reservation. This place that I had heard so much about but couldn't remember from when I was small. I would discover it at last! Discover the steaks that melt on your tongue, the impeccable service, etc, etc... As our trip approached, I have to admit that I was becoming nervous. Could it really live up to those high standards I had put up in my head? Would I be inevitably disappointed?On the 3rd day of our stay in Singapore, the day had come. I will never forget walking in to the restaurant and being greeted by the Maitre D. Maybe it was because this place had become something so special to me that I thought it was the perfect restaurant and overall best dining experience of my life, but you can't deny that everything is simply perfect. From the steak to the service to the wine and even to the beautiful decor! Everything was just as I had imagined it. I don't want to spoil the experience as it is something everyone should see for themselves. Myself and my mother had the NY strip, my dad had the Rib-eye. I would recommend both of these options but it really depends on personal preference. A glass of red wine is a must for me and I would definitely suggest to take the "Roasted Brussels Sprouts" or "Lobster Mac And Cheese" for sides. I can't recommend this place enough! Yes, the prices are high but you won't be disappointed! I don't know when I will return to a Ruth's Chris Steak House the next time as I live in London but I am already looking forward to it.

1 of my favorite steakhouse in singapore for usda beef. Service is excellent everytime. Staff are friendly, attentive, and ask each time what they can do for you. Food arrives very fast and the taste is excellent. Ruth's chris offers medium rare plus that is a tad rarer than medium rare compared to the usual medium rare or medium. Steak is cooked juuuust right and they all come out warm on a hotplate. Some steaks will be cold by the time u're halfway through it. I've had the 340g & 450g usda rib eyes and each bite was beefy, tender, juicy & flavourful. The mac & cheese has a crunchy crispy topping that seperates it from the usual mac & cheese. Dessert portions are large but they are also very tasty. Even if one is feeling full, dessert still finds a way to be eaten and enjoyed as a nice finishing touch to the meal. The restaurant seats & table are spacious & comfortable. Always a joy to dine here!

Good American steak house in Singapore. We're here many times already and never got bored. Today we had lunch and ordered some soup, baked potato, mushrooms, and salads, besides the steak itself. Very good and satisfying. Love the ambiance too. Always good service here.

I've been to many Ruth's Chris Steakhouse's in throughout the US over the years so I have become accustomed to the unique and great flavors.  Tonight, I didn't have the same experience.  I'm not sure whether it's because the steaks are shipped in across the world or different preparation techniques but it's just not worthy to be called a Ruth's Chris steak. My party had three steaks and we all agreed this wasn't a Ruth's Chris experience. To the credit of the management they were very concerned that we didn't eat our steaks, offered to prepare others, and made some adjustments to the check.

My dad was talking about some Chris Ruth steak.. and I was all like "????? but it can't be as awesome as Bedrock Bar & Grill's steak, dad." So he decided to prove me wrong and drag my brother and I to the place.. and the first thing I noticed was.. it's not Chris Ruth.. it's called Ruth's Chris. Secondly, it turned out to be quite a dressy place.. which I, in my jeans and tee-shirt, feel a little bit out of sorts.. as the location of this place is within the hotel. Thankfully, the waiters were kind enough to not judge. We ordered a variety of dishes, Caesar Salad (delicious), lambchops (not bad), roast potatoes and mashed potatoes side dish (I am addicted to their roast potatoes, a must try!) and of course, their steak. We had 3 plates of it.. in medium well. Firstly, the steak was served on a sizzling white plate. Yes, you heard me right, it was served on a ceramic white plate that is hot. That was interesting. Secondly, the color of the steak.. perfectly grilled. When we cut it, it was exactly like what we asked for. Medium well. Not too tough, not too bloody. Just nice. Thirdly, it tasted lovely, even without any condiments. So my dad was right, Ruth's Chris's steaks are good! The ambience of the place is akin to that of Lawry's sans the french maids prancing about with trolleys doing their twinkly dance with the spinning salad bowl. It's quiet, a good place to have a good chat with friends or your significant other. As the place is quite pricey, it is a good place to go to for a special occasion. I must say this place is definitely one of my to go places for steak in future. Do give it a try if you have the money or if you are simply craving for a good steak.

When I first heard that Ruth's Chris is gonna open a Singaporean branch, I jumped with joy. I went to Ruth's Chris a few times before when I was in the US and it was one of my favorite steakhouses.Before even biting into the steak, I was already pleased with how it looks like. Perfectly charred, served with that classic butter on top of a sizzling plate. I ordered the ribeye and my brother & his friend had the T-Bone for 2. Both were extremely good and a perfect representation of good ol' American style steak. It had to be mentioned though that the T-Bone beef was actually Australian.I was sad though, when I heard that they didn't serve shoestring potatoes. It was my favorite side dish in Ruth's Chris SF and on that note, if there is any letdown in this place, it is the side dishes. They were very mediocre and didn't do justice to the main dish.There was a slight difference between the Singapore branch and the US branch, but I won't fault them for it. (I'll post the pictures) I'd still give this place a 5 star for serving the best good ol' fashioned cowboy steak in this part of the world.

The set lunch was good value, I feel .. $35 for a Wagyu burger w/ fries. I guess u could call the meat patty "juicy" as all the moisture went thru my buns (the burger - lower bun). Fries were hot & delicious - salt level was just right albeit a little on the high side. Ordered a Moscato "sparkling wine" to go with my meal (I know, it's a dessert sweet wine - but I was thrown off by the "sparkling wine" tag in the wine list). Pricey at $23 & served in a tiny glass (almost like a champagne flute). This wad not hood value, and yes I know it's how F&B establishments make money.Service was spotty. 1/2 the waiters were aloof & could not be bothered. We were 2/3 way thru our meal when our waiter came up to us, asked "how many coffees & teas" (yes, he helpfully informed us it came with our set lunch). Seriously .. It wasn't even 3pm yet, & a real fine dining restaurant would NOT hurry their customers thru their meal.The other 1/2 were friendly & warm. Entertained our very active little toddler who was getting restless during our lunch.I'm not sure I would return; perhaps for lunch but most likely not for dinner. Unless someone else was paying ;)

This is my favourite steak and wine place in Singapore.   You absolutely feel catered to with fantastic food.  You pay for it but it is worth every bit of it.  Have gone to many in the USA and this one is no different.

I just went to have a steak and a salad alone by myself, but the service was really nice through out the stay. I had a talk with the waiter and spent nice time. Caesar salad was quite good, much better than the room service one at the same hotel. And the steak!! I had a prime rib with medium rare, it was great!! Wish I was able to stay longer...

I really loved my dinner at Ruth's Chris, and my mates concur as well. The food was faultless, and I loved the traditional style of Ruth's Chris' steaks; unadorned save for salt, pepper, and a simple glaze of American butter. No sauces, herbs or seasoning to distract from the meat, so the quality of the meat is highlighted in its pure form, which I understand can be a little uninspiring for some diners. But one man's meat is another man's poison, so what's boring to others can also be construed as classic, and I like my stuff classic anyway.Service was gracious, if a bit spotty (our water glasses weren't refilled automatically).All in all, this is definitely going down as one of 2016's best eats. We had:1) New Orleans-styled Barbecued Shrimp ($35): a must-try, we actually ordered more bread to mop up that lovely spiced garlicky white wine and butter sauce.2) USDA Prime Ribeye ($85 for 12-ounce): a perfect medium-well. The corn-fed meat had ample heft, and imbued with a tantalizing char. Be sure to go down a cooked-level coz it'll continue cooking at the table3) USDA New York Strip ($85 for 12-ounce): fuller-bodied flavour than the ribeye, but just as sumptuous and robust.4) USDA Filet ($90 for 11-ounce): a leaner cut but incredibly tender and luscious.There are a good number of sides to break up the monotony of steak, and we liked:5) Sauteed Spinach ($20): clean, delicate, and simply fried with garlic.6) Potato Au Gratin ($20): laden with cream and burnished with cheddar melt. Rustic, old-school and hearty

When I first heard that Ruth's Chris is gonna open a Singaporean branch, I jumped with joy. I went to Ruth's Chris a few times before when I was in the US and it was one of my favorite steakhouses.Before even biting into the steak, I was already pleased with how it looks like. Perfectly charred, served with that classic butter on top of a sizzling plate. I ordered the ribeye and my brother & his friend had the T-Bone for 2. Both were extremely good and a perfect representation of good ol' American style steak. It had to be mentioned though that the T-Bone beef was actually Australian.I was sad though, when I heard that they didn't serve shoestring potatoes. It was my favorite side dish in Ruth's Chris SF and on that note, if there is any letdown in this place, it is the side dishes. They were very mediocre and didn't do justice to the main dish.There was a slight difference between the Singapore branch and the US branch, but I won't fault them for it. (I'll post the pictures) I'd still give this place a 5 star for serving the best good ol' fashioned cowboy steak in this part of the world.

I love Ruth's Chris and always eat in the restaurant whenever I visit a city that has one. My favorite is the one in Beverly hills. The Singapore outlet is ok, but I miss the US Prime T-Bone, which they don't serve in Singapore due to some import regulations against US beef with bones, and the shoestring potatoes.

I first heard about Ruth's Chris Steakhouse when I was reading a Tom Clancy novel and the way the steaks were described made me hunger for them all this while (7years). Now that they've finally arrived in Singapore, I've got another trusted and reliable joint to satisfy my meat cravings. It's definitely not cheap, but to compare it with Morton's (its closest competitor), I'd have to say that what you're paying for at Ruth's is almost equal to or even better than what you get at Morton's. Taste wise, I've got to say that its surpassed my wildest dreams and is exactly as how I expected it to be. Portions are huge and yet they've managed to prepare it perfectly. Definitely a must try for meat lovers.

Been trying waffles everywhere-they are all by Dora Keiki. What I expected was the usual green batter, with the red bean paste like the one I tasted at Woodlands MRT. It's quite different since they're all under random different names-prices as well as the availability of spreads differ as well.This was a mix between the usual green batter and white batter, so it was crispy yet soft and fluffy. Is this is legendary golden ratio? I was amazed. What made it stand out the most was the red bean filling. You'd expect it to be the usual red bean paste, but nope! The lady scooped out literal red beans-you could count them as they rolled happily on my waffle. Wew! Must try @ $1.60, Esplanade xchange

address: #02-205 Marina Sq 6 Raffles Boulevard Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: ive been here many times for their lor mee which is well loved by my mum and i. its not like the usual dark sauce lor mee, this is the 'heng hua' style of mee. no review needed. go try it and let it speak for itself.today i decided to try other dishes other than my usual order of lor mee.1. fried eggplant with floss.  srsly. you cant go wrong w anything w floss. 2. fried yam with duck. this was okay for me, not wow'ed by it. it was nice, not too oily and e dipping sauce gives it a bit more omph. 3. pig intestine. this is a 'must try' for intestines lover.  this is 9 layers of intestines rolled into one. 9 layers of goodness! it is served with a candlelight warmer to keep it warm. do not take too long to finish this dish as the longer its on the warmer, the tougher it gets. mmmMmmmm4. fried bun w shredded meat. dont worry about dirtying your hands on this one, it comes with plastic gloves for you to use to hold the fried bun. how thoughtful of them :) shredded pieces of meat and strips of onions is so flavourful, makes you want to go for more. if you like 'heng hua' cuisine, this is the place to go to.

address: #02-205 Marina Sq 6 Raffles Boulevard Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: I was really excited to try Putien but was pretty disappointed with the vegetarian options. The tofu dish that doesn't have meat is cooked with meat broth. The taro that has no meat has fish sauce. The options were very limited for me unfortunately. The food that I ordered was just ok. The concept of the ice bitter melon was cool but nothing to write home about. Hope they'll make some adjustments to better accommodate vegetarians!

address: #02-205 Marina Sq 6 Raffles Boulevard Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: So it looks like most people that end up posting here on Yelp are Americans since it doesn't seem to be too popular with the native people in Singapore. We walked in here add more able to get seated for lunch for a work lunch. My host ordered all of the food and it was very tasty although it was completely different that anything that I had expected. She ordered some nice pork buns that you put a little glove on your hand and load up that was very tasty. Also a duck dish that was baked into a pastry that is really nice as well. Over all really good place

address: #02-205 Marina Sq 6 Raffles Boulevard Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: I ordered the "100 second" stewed yellow croaker along with the boiled prawns as an appetizer. The croaker was great and prepared in a nice ginger broth. The croaker was cooked just right and the fish fell right off the bone. I also enjoyed the prawns as well.

address: #02-205 Marina Sq 6 Raffles Boulevard Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: Fourth time in Singapore. As a Shanghainese, I think this is the best Chinese food in Singapore.

address: #02-205 Marina Sq 6 Raffles Boulevard Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: One star Michelin. Good, but not great. Some of the dishes (fried yam) were bland, but the side spicy sauce saved them. Others (duck  and yam cakes) were quite good. Friendly service. Glad I went.

Came here to try crabs in Singapore.   Ordered 3 types: chilli, black pepper and salty egg.  We loved salty egg the best.  Cash onlyOpen late beyond midnight Open air hawker center by the river With fans

address: 8 Raffles Avenue Esplanade Mall, Makansutra Gluttonbay Singapore 039802 Singapore
comment: If you are in town a must try filipino treat! Sisig and kilawin Tuna! Best We always make sure we visit and eat this two items in menu. We also tried the Grilled Tuna belly too ... Which is good too! Inexpensive menu and very delicious! Will be back here whenever we will be in Singapore.

With a Michelin star under its belt, you'll find fancy upscale dim sum.  After sitting down (and having the staff put the napkins on our laps), my dad looked at us and asked, "where's the paper to write down our order?".  Like I said, upscale - so don't expect the usual bustle or self-service of a normal dim sum restaurant.We ordered some of the usual dim sum dishes, har gao, soup dumplings etc.  The food was delicate, and expertly prepared.  Expensive yes, but this is really the kind of restaurant you'd go for a special occasion.We also ordered a unique noodle dish - fried fish noodles, which was my favorite.  The noodles are actually made with fish (and presumably some starch to keep it together)!  Had great bounce to the texture, which was surprising.Upscale dim sum isn't exactly my cup of tea, as I'd rather prefer the hustle and bustle of dim sum, but it was one of those experiences that you just have to try once!

A+ for the service but the food was only ok for this type of restaurant.  This is for the Dim Sum... maybe the regular entrees might be betterThe decor is nice and upscale but doesn't stand out much.  The plateware is amazing though.  They bring out plates of different colors with each dish and to be honest that was a very cool experience in itself.  We got the har gow, siu mai, fried dumplings, glutinous pastry and goose liver fried rice.  The fried rice was great but the rest were above average....but that's kind of like the minimum expected from a restaurant like this.  I've had noticeably better in Toronto and Hong Kong.  For two people id recommend maybe 4 dim sum dishes and a rice or noodle.  For a city with this many amazing restaurants I find it hard to recommend.

Chinese fine dining at its most underwhelming.We ordered the Lily set menu. The Pork was succulent and incredible, but thats where the excitement ended. The Scallop was nothing special. The soup was dull and uncompelling. The Sea Perch lacked the flakey joy you expect and the single solitary prawn sat next to the noodles, carbing you up to ensure you didn't leave hungry.The meal was just fine - and at this price point, it should have been amazing.

Little glitches here and there but overall a rather pleasant experience.  Service overall was attentive or at least u can tell the young Jedi was under training so made quiet a few mistakes.   Big one not observing the speed the guests were consuming the food.   Small ones were spilling the soy sauce while placing the food, his clothes had soy sauce stain, not topping up tea and also asking questions meant for another table.   Food wise, suckling pig bettet at Wah Lok.  Take away dish was the soup in coconut and dessert. The rest was good.   overall a wonderful evening and yes complimentary parking!!

Located in the ritz hotel in Singapore is this gold mine that brings me back to reality.  My trip to Singapore in search of new menus left me wondering whether iI know what is good and what is so so.  Most dishes were amazing but some were too fried or starchy.  Having dinner at Summer Pavilion brings me back to understanding why I like trying food so much.  Their dishes were delicious, artful and definitely will bring you back to knowing what is good food in case you lost your way.  The Peking duck was amazing but then again every dish we ordered was amazing.  So if you lost your way when you're traveling.  Come back to home, come to Summer Parvillion.

Great food and service.Starter: Long bean.Deep fried lobster roll, prawn paste & breaded vermicelli - superb, crispy, light & not oily.Deep fried crab - didn't like the cheesy taste. Otherwise, it was good.Sautéed Chinese cabbage with shredded pork meat in claypot.Smoked duck (half) with Chinese tea leaves - good taste, crispy skin, perfect sauce (not too sweet or saltish).Poached rice, lobster meat.Dry ah balling (black sesame paste inside, served warm) - Super good and not so hot that it will burn your tongue.

I had the Tasting Menu here for a Sunday lunch. It was comprised of 6 courses: (1) Australian abalone, (2) Chicken Soup in a coconut, (3) Wagyu Beef cubes, (4) A small Lobster with asparagus, (5) Grouper with rice in broth, & (6) a dessert of hot sago pudding & crunch bar. Every course was absolutely fabulous. The Chinese Executive Chef Cheung Siu Kong stopped by my table to see how I liked the meal. The dining experience here was outstanding in all respects. They certainly deserve the Michelin star that they have earned.

The ambience is serene; the corridor leading to the private dining rooms looks as elegant as a palace's. The Cantonese dishes are among the best you can find in Singapore - nothing flamboyant or very innovative, just extremely refined, served on beautiful porcelain. Service is efficient yet unobtrusive. If prices were lower, I would go anytime I would like to have Cantonese food. Choice destination for entertaining valued guests.

Another Michelin star restaurant in the Ritz Hotel.  We didn't have reservations but they accommodated us most likely because we were staying in the hotel.  Amazing food, anything you order will be astonishing!
Decent Chinese food. The skills of the chefs are good, but the real key to this restaurant is the quality of the ingredients. I had better Chinese food, but seldom made with such quality ingredients.

fantastic meal - great ambience, good food - at this classic chinese institution at the ritz-carlton. this was a treat for the mum on her birthday - and we had a great time; I love sitting down in an old-school, luxurious place eating dainty little bits of fatty dim sum.the food here strikes me as being classic but-not-really, very exquisite and rather well made - and very much in line with what I expect from a chinese restaurant inside a hotel: good service, food that's interesting but still familiar, and a peaceful ambience.we did a fair bit of their smallish menu - and it was all pretty good. the food at my favourite paradise pavilion is a little more modern-interesting and might be tastier - but there's just something about sitting in a hotel-housed chinese restaurant that has all the pomp and luxuriance you just don't get in a stand-alone place.I certainly had no qualms about the bill when it arrived, service was polite and our tea cups constantly filled - and the mum had a good time. much worth a visit, especially for a bit of old-school chinese posh.

We stayed at the hotel so wanted to enjoy this restaurant. We assumed it would be significantly better than what we find in Gearhart, Oregon. It was. we got a several course lunch with dim sum. I am not a connoisseur of Cantonese food though we have friends who are. The four dim sum items included a couple that were new to us and a couple that seemed quite ordinary. We had birds nest soup, not a regular item where I go. The fried rice was abundant but not particularly flavorful. The vegetables were ok and we'll prepared. The tea was very nice. Service was good enough. We were the last lunch table seated that day which meant our server was distracted with other duties when we wanted to order and when it was time to serve our food. Still, the four of us enjoyed our lunch.

The dim sum here is not on par with the other 5-star dim sum places but nevertheless you still good quality and tasty food. The ambiance is ideal for Sunday morning brunches. Relax atmosphere and the excellent service staffs more than make up for the 4-star dim sums.

address: 6 Raffles Boulevard #02-106A/106B, Marina Square Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: A comforting and satisfying meal! The restaurant wasn't too crowded on a weekday lunch-though I really wonder why, given it's great (value for money) food! Their lunch sets offer up to $4 off popular mains. What is really attractive is their free flow appetiser bar. I came expecting the usual mundane appetisers like pickles and soup, but was greatly surprised (and spoilt for choice!) by the spread which included salad, braised pork with egg, udon, sweet potato fries, takoyaki, chicken karage and more! What makes this even more special is their above-average standard of food. The takoyaki was flavourful and filled with octopus-even better than some takoyaki specialized stores :) there were clams in the chawanmushi and the chicken was nicely flavoured with soy garlic. A really satisfying meal! I'll be back for more :))

address: 6 Raffles Boulevard #02-106A/106B, Marina Square Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: Definitely a great deal for the price - with whichever main you order, you can get free flow appetizers. The selection is impressive! There's corn tofu (flavorful but need to get used to the texture), takoyaki, cheese fondue, soba, fried pumpkin, fried sweet potato.. and if you add $2.90, you get free flow drinks and soft serve! I was very pleased to enjoy some hot green tea. That said, the mentaiko carbonara definitely needs some work. Very faint mentaiko flavor and both my friend and I needed some salt and pepper to flavor our pasta. It's probably good if you don't like salty food. I must applaud the quality service at Hifumi (usually rare in SG); the server was genuinely interested in the quality of the dish and asked politely if my friend also agreed that the dish was not salty enough. If I'm in the mood for a big meal, I'll be interested to be back to try the hot pot or other rice dishes!

address: 6 Raffles Boulevard #02-106A/106B, Marina Square Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: Nice food, affordable price with free flow of appetizer. Just top up SGD2.90 for free flow of drinks.  Nice place to hang out with friends.

address: 6 Raffles Boulevard #02-106A/106B, Marina Square Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: Entering a restaurant with a name that doesn't sound very inviting must be a first for me! However the experience was a overall pleasant one and the concept is slightly altered than the usual ala carte set meals of most jap restaurants. What's special about this place is that there is an appetizer buffet as long as you order any set meal. (Actually everything on the menu is a set meal). Top up a little more to get free flow drinks. The appetizer buffet was better than I expected. Consisting of some vegetables, sweet potatoes, chawanmushi, and even soba! It will give you enough taste-utility of a Japanese meal even with not-too-big a price tag. I ordered a curry pork katsu rice and my partner ordered a beef suki yaki. The former serves a good size junky juicy piece of pork with a nice blend of curry sauce that has the slight mix of Indian curry that I've never tasted in a Japanese curry. The result, is good. The latter is a sweet soup with enough beef to make you finish your rice before you can finish the beef. Pictures speaks better than words and their concept of having a appetizer buffet seems to be paying off with consumers as you see a decent queue outside. All prices here are ++.

rest_name: Jia Xiang Sarawak Kuching Kolo Mee
address: 6 Raffles Boulevard #02-220A Marina Square Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: Ordered the original.. #1.. they use lard in the soup! No wonder it tastes sooooo damn gd!!! But I loved it!!! Reminds me of a place in Melbourne where lard us used as well. It's a bit $$ for SG standards but I love it all the same. 2 thumbs up for taste (although bad for u)!! :) and service was great. Staff noticed I finished my soup and asked if I wanted more.. no charge! He could tell I loved the noodles. I could only manage an open palm queens wave with my head down slurping a mouthful of noodles.

rest_name: Jia Xiang Sarawak Kuching Kolo Mee
address: 6 Raffles Boulevard #02-220A Marina Square Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: #2 was a decent bowl of noodles with char siew (skipped this), wanton, prawns and vegetables ($6.90). Noodles were decently springy, but the prawns didn't taste fresh. It was served very quickly. 3 stars.

rest_name: Jia Xiang Sarawak Kuching Kolo Mee
address: 6 Raffles Boulevard #02-220A Marina Square Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: My friend took me here to eat what she termed 'high class wanton noodle'. It's located in a nook of Marina Square and is furnished in the old-style kopitiam manner.I had myself the recommended Jia Xiang Mee for $6.40, which is about twice what you might pay in a hawker centre for similar sort of noodle. The food was served pretty quickly, quite a fair portion of springy 'QQ' noodles with minced pork, char siew and veggies, along with a bowl of soup with 2 prawns and 3 wantons.The noodle texture was as QQ as they're famous for, the char siew lean enough and tasty, though the soup could have been tastier in my opinion. Prawns were an unusual addition, but given the price you're paying, probably a necessary addition.My friend had their other recommended dish, the fish soup, which was quite a large portion and included quite thick and yummy slices of fish, more prawns and veggie. As above, wish the soup was tastier, though I suspect this might actually mean its not filled with MSG.

rest_name: Jia Xiang Sarawak Kuching Kolo Mee
address: 6 Raffles Boulevard #02-220A Marina Square Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: Jia Xiang has expanded quite a bit from it's first days with only one outlet. Now it has outlets in Vivo City , Marina Square and Marina Bay Sands as well as a few other places. Actually I quite like this Kolo Mee.  I always order the Fish Fillet Kolo Mee... standard!I know it's not the best noodle option but I do love the fired fish on top of wanton-mee style noodles, instead of the usual char siew.My only complaint is that it is perhaps that the dish is a little to the salty side.

rest_name: Jia Xiang Sarawak Kuching Kolo Mee
address: 6 Raffles Boulevard #02-220A Marina Square Singapore 039594 Singapore
comment: Good kolo mee is hard to find in Singapore and one of the those that I've tried, Jia Xiang is definitely one of the closest you can get. What I really enjoy is the the QQ of the noodles, that are very springy, and the seasoning of the dish as a whole, makes the noodles tasty by itself. Throw in the minced pork, char siwe and abalone, and the dish is completed. The trick is to have the noodles dry, not soup as it will affect the taste. While I enjoy the noodles, the portions here tend to be on the small side, so paying $10 for a bowl of noodles that doesn't really fill me up, doesn't make a lot of sense. Nonetheless, when the craving for Kolo Mee strikes, I'll definitely find myself here!

One of my girlfriends suggested to meet here for lunch. I had a hard time finding this place. So this restaurant is located outside Millenia Walk, across from Conrad Centennial and next to Rakuzen.FOOD 4/5I ordered the Yakiniku set  which came with a yakiniku don, a soup , a tiny piece of tofu and a small dish of cabbage. The portion of the set was generous, though I found the beef a bit bland (maybe the chef forgot to season with salt). I had to add a few drops of soy sauce twice.AMBIENCE 5/5I like the ambience. It was not too noisy. Like the décor too! SERVICE 5/5Our server was polite and attentive. She came refilling our water a couple of times. Overall it was not bad a place to grab lunch. Pricing is on the higher end but I guess you get what you pay for. The ingredients are of high quality.  It would be a solid 5 star restaurant if the meat was tastier for me.

Exquisite food but overpriced. Choice of standard to high quality meats/fish - obvious difference in quality which is reflected in the price. The wagyu beef tongue and tuna were divine. The standard beef skewers in comparison were kinda gross...

Great food here at reasonable price.  Was pleasantly surprised by it as it was one of the few restaurants where we could get a table immediately.  Wagyu Don was excellent and the sashimi special was good value (you get the special price even if you order green tea).  Definitely would recommend to anyone.  Barley in the rice was a nice touch also.

There are very few, if any, restaurants in Singapore that make you feel so out of place. In this case, it's a VERY VERY good thing. Coming to SanDaime Bunji feels like your almost in Japan. Not only are there a TON of Japanese patrons during the weekday lunch hour, but if seated inside, more likely or not you'll have to take your shoes off to dine.I frequent Japanese restaurants, at least once or twice a week. Despite this, I could not recognize any of the dishes on the menu. These dishes are truly different. The big draw at this restaurant is the weekly rotating lunch set at $9++. On the day I went, I had a beautifully marinated fish served (teriyaki I believe) with an Ox tongue/Wintery miso soup and daikon radish soup and nutty barley rice. Like, I said it's DIFFERENT.If you are adventurous and go in with an open mind, this is the Japanese restaurant to go to. I guess that's what makes this restaurant a truly AUTHENTIC FIND!

Okay, I can't claim to be an expert on Japanese food from Sendai, but I can tell you that every dish I tried here was excellent. I didn't do the ordering, so I can't tell you what the exact dishes are, but etched on my mind is the beef tongue!  How can something so sinfully good actually be healthy?Well, apparently, tongue is a tender, lean piece of meat, full of the flavour, with almost no fat, just pure muscle. Have to have more!Did I mention the beef tongue?

Pity this restaurant's standard has dropped tremendously. Came here during dinner time. Ramen soup is diluted unlike its richness in the past (I.e. Beef bone ramen) which used to be its greatest attraction. The beef bone ramen tastes very much like a Chinese noodle soup with a Japanese twist. Wouldn't say it's bad either, just that the standard has dropped. Even the side dishes for the additional $8 set, are now cold and smaller in portion as if it was been left outside for some time. Chawanmushi had a funny taste to it too. Ordered a Saba mackerel fish as well, ain't warm, pretty cold and oil tasted bitter. Fish was chewy and unfresh. Was pretty disappointed as i've always had high regards for this restaurant especially for its authenticity. Maybe the Chef has changed? Also, it took really Long for the order to arrive (20 mins for a simple mackerel set dish without rice), and when it did, they weren't warm. Had difficulty calling out to the waitresses (several times) which was very unlike the crew in the past, they were very efficient. Pity the restaurant's overall standard has dropped a great deal.

Surprised I'm the first review. Great option if you work near Millenia Walk. Indoors was full when I arrived around 12 so we sat outside as the weather has been mild. Daily lunch set special is a steal at SG11. Given the service, setup and decent food I'd recommend it if you're looking for lunch in the area. I'd classify this place as Japanese Fusion not classic Japanese.
Excellent sashimi dinner special at 19.95. Have to order a drink to get special price...just not water, can be a cup of green tea.

This is an interesting Italian/American hybrid restaurant. I got the seafood risotto, and it was very filling considering the deceptively small size. I could barely finish it, and I usually think sit-down restaurants in Singapore don't provide enough food. I thoroughly enjoyed the risotto, and it was $20, which is reasonable compared to other restaurants.

My husband and I stopped in here for a drink to kill some time before a massage we had scheduled. I ordered the aloe lychee French soda which was fizzy and had a fresh lychee as garnish. My husband ordered a root beer float which he decided as yummy in his tummy. Has free wifi.

The food is ok, but the staff quality varies a lot. We have been coming to this place regularly for lunch due to its proximity to our office. Watch out for a indianwaiter without his name tag. Not only did he take the orders at the slowest pace in the history of restaurants' services, he refused to customised our orders (we wanted to order extra pasta on the side, but he said it wasn't possible, which is clearly not true as we had done it before. Furthermore, one of my colleagues kindly asked if he could change his order. To his dismay, he refused profusely again, insisting that he has recorded that order. Come at your own risk.

Some friends invited me for lunch at Collins. They love this place because of the quality of food and the value for money meals this place provides. Most main courses are around $14 to $15+, but with a current lunch promotion that gives you a starter and a choice of a drink or dessert, this gives extremely good value for money. And the quality of food is good too. Large portions that really fill you up. I'll be back again.

Sugar fiends can satisfy their cravings with any of the beautifully crafted cakes and pastries Patisserie G has to offer. A classic lineup of espresso drinks and a small menu of savory items are available as well. Chef extraordinaire- Gwen Lim, born and raised in Singapore, paid homage to her heritage by offering innovative and contemporary forward confections with Asian infused flavors.  Among the hits are the Lychee Rose Cheesecakes with Lychee jelly and a crumble base. The lychee jelly added a nice texture and flavor to the creamy yet light cheesecake. Simply delicious! The flat white with a subtle bitterness was a sophisticated pairing and balanced out the sweetness quite well. The in-store seating provides a quiet oasis while the additional seating in the center of the Millenia Walk Mall is great for people watching. With an outstanding service, delicious indulgences and a chic vibe makes this place worth visiting.

Almost a year after my first visit to Patisserie G, I found myself here again, twice in fact since I arrived in Singapore 6 days ago. So what holds the attraction to this place for me? Clearly, my darling girlfriend working at Millenia Tower is one big factor. Then it comes to: FOOD 5/5I love their cakes! Not only they looked esthetically pleasing, they tasted good too. I just had a cake named "Poison Apple". It looked like an apple. It was so pretty. I told my friend I would either be Snow White or the evil Queen. But she agreed since I had to eat the "Poison Apple" then I would be Snow White then. I hope the seven dwarves would appear if I fell on the floor, and my prince would eventually show up. Right!! ;P Anyhoo, this "Poison Apple" tasted good, inside was a mix of cake and the center reminded me of apple pie. The other cake I had tried recently was the Lychee Rose Cheesecake. I recommended that cake too. Even though it was a cheesecake, it was not too heavy. The Mango & Pear iced tea was refreshing. I had the same during my last two visits. AMBIENCE 5/5I love the openness of Patisserie G. I particularly like the outside seatings.SERVICE 5/5The staffs were as always friendly and helpful. Now I am already thinking what cake should I try next? :D

Quiet setting on late Sunday morning, great music!  Latte's are rich and well made, almond croissant was large and tasty.  Ordered scrambled eggs with mushroom and chose the croissant instead of the fluffy toast.  Got 1 out of 3 right, it has eggs and they are scrambled, but no mushrooms and got the toast.  I returned the plate, 5 min later they got 2 out of 3 right; added the mushroom but not the croissant, reminded me of Henry Ford's saying "you can have a car with any color as long as it's black".  I have to say the eggs were moist well made, and the mushrooms were good too, not your average button mushrooms, they had a bite to them.  By then l decided that the toast soldiers are good enough to have, never mind the croissant.  Only thing is, you can't dip the soldiers in scrambled egg, like you do in fried eggs.  Toast eaten!  Third latté had the right effect. It's all good.

Love how the place is quiet and peaceful-great to chill even on a weekend. By the vibes alone, I would consider this place a gem I'd want to keep to myself for the alone times c:Had their Tropical cake ($8.50) and a flat white ($5.50). Not usually a fan of these type of cakes (see the photo) but this is hands down the best I've ever had. Mango passion mousse, banana marmalade, chocolate sponge, coconut chantilly and a butter crumble base.  The flavours came together in a harmonious fashion-simple texture, yet layered and intriguing. The flat white is not bad too-above average, considering how it focuses on it's bakes. Will definitely be back!

Never tried the sweets here but came numerous times for their croque Monsieur! It has the perfect brioche bread, topped with the perfect bechamel sauce and melty Gruyere cheese and ham....it is EXACTLY what a croque Monsieur should be. I also love their simple ham and cheese croissant but I am into something lighter and their scrambled egg is also done the way I like it - very runny and creamy.They have recently expanded their menu and expanded their seating area to outside the store. More choices yeah! Prices are not cheap but you do get quality. Coffee is good too.For the price, I only wish it is not self-serve.

In a little nook of a rather quiet mall, Millenia Walk is a lovely little gem of a cafe. They get the small things right and that's what keeps me coming back. Decor is in light, natural wood colors. Relaxed music in the background. Polite service. Water and newspaper for your free taking and reading. Perfect setup to chill, relax, grab a bite with a friend or colleague. They manage to keep it simple when it comes to the menu. For savory, eggs cocotte/scrambled and gourmet sandwiches. All of 7 sandwiches to choose from. Not a problem as they make them very well. My fav is the Parma ham, mushroom relish, arugula and Gruyere. Accompanied with crisps. Yummy to the last bite. Not a big connoisseur of coffee. I only know when it tastes good. And to me this is good, especially with the desserts they have. Again, not a mind boggling vast selection but what they make, they make well. My only sticking point these days is that it gets pricey to have these types of lovely dining experiences. Fine if you make oodles of dough but for many it's out of reach. =(Very much recommended!

Was around the area and felt like having a coffee. I was torn between Kith next door and Patisserie G. Both were just as crowded so I looked at the cakes they had on display. Kith's cakes were larger and richer, and i felt I wasn't really that hungry. So I chose Patisserie G. The cakes were smaller, but had this artisinal look to them. The apple crumble and cappuccino I ordered were pretty good. I wish they offered me the option of having a warm Apple crumble though. The cappuccino was delightful. Nice foam and a nutty aftertaste. Would come here again if I'm around the area again.

Patisserie G is the Crown Jewel of Millenia Walk. It's an ultra modern French cafe that plays feel good songs. Coffee and Pastries are definitely their strong suit. Their coffee selections are extensive ranging from: double expresso, to double macchiato to Cappuccino and Flat white. I understand they source all their coffee beans from local artisan roasters, liberty coffee. I would say Patisserie G's coffee edges out it's neighbor Commune upstairs. I find the cappuccino here tastier, the latte art more detailed, and the coffee having more of a subtle finish (which I prefer).The pastries, albeit on the expensive side, are Classic French favorites: macaroons, cheese cakes, chocolate mousse, lemon cakes, strawberry cakes, etc. I'm not a Pastry expert so I won't elaborate more than I have to, but they are of very high quality, among the highest on the red dot, especially among those offered to the regular consumer outside of high prices restaurant establishments.Overall, I'm a big fan of Patisserie G. However, I will ding this pastry shop one-star for removing "Everyone Loves Us Yelp" sticker. This is a very special accolade that few local establishments get globally. Yes, some yelpers may give tough reviews, but overall the Yelp Community in SG are huge fans of Patisserie G, especially me.

Love the pastries here. The chocolate sea salt cookies are an exact match to the Pierre Herme chocolate sea salt cookies - decadently chocolatey with the zing of salt to keep things happening. They also do a lovely crumbly buttery salted egg yolk cookie for Chinese New Year. The chocolate eclair is also very decent - some places have their eclairs sitting in the display cases slowly drying into cardboard crumbliness. But Patisserie G's eclair is fresh enough that the choux has a crisp shell and light interior. Helps too that the cream filling is usually richly flavoured. They've done well enough over the years to expand to additional seating outside the shop. I love their morning breakfast offerings - croque monsieur, buttery croissants and lightly brewed coffee.  Good place to hang out, chill over a cuppa and a nicely made sweet.

Revisited the possibly most French local patisserie shop in Singapore to try its not-so-new cakes that were launched during my absence in SG. Gone was my favourite Douceur. Along the way, we had the Eggs En Cocotte with Bacon ($16), a French dish that hasn't seem to rise to much popularity for brunch in Singapore yet. The savoury custard was well-seasoned and wiggly, speedily demolished with the soldiers of fragrant toasted brioche. Meantime, the Creamy Scramble Eggs ($15/add on with smoked salmon $3) might not be as grandiose as the soft luscious yellow clouds served at Bills, but was a heart-warming delight to go with its reputable croissant. Yes, I've had it previously with my dark chocolate drink and it still stays VERY delicious. The Lemon Cheesecake ($9) exhibits great character, distinguishing itself from the usual baked cheesecake with a livid lemon curd in the centre and a reliable chocolate biscuit base instead of the occasionally cranky graham crust. The Hazelnut Opera ($8.50) was particularly iffy; unquestionably tri-textures of the hazelnut ganache, coffee sponge and chocolate ganache, but the hazelnut tones weren't pronounced. The Nouvelle G ($9), a 73%-63% dark chocolate spaceship lookalike that had a delicate sandy yet crispy chocolate feuilletine which was finer than any of the feuilletine here. But the star was the Coconut Choux Tart ($9), a pretty revolutionary piece that focused on the coconut-flavoured Carribean rum. Nothing much to speak in terms of coconut accents, but the beloved textures of all the components; chantily cream, (empty) choux puff, salted caramel sauce and Creme brûlée custard tart is enough to make this gateaux a highly saleable one.

I would go for 4.5 if there was an option. But hey I will give the cafe some space so they can push themselves to even higher level! My all-time favourites are THE G SPOT and BOMBE CERISE, and also maybe the LEMON TART (tanginess that cleanses your palette and balances with the sweetness). Their cakes are delish and also pretty to look at. G Spot would appeal to dark chocolate lovers, and BOMBE CERISE is just smooth with a good punch from the Kirsh-Soaked Cherries and crunchy-chewy base. Not forgetting the minimal deco which makes the whole experience even more insta worthy,

back here again wanting to try e eclair but alas! I was distracted with e pastries and ordered a chocolate gnut instead.1. Flat white - good coffee but nope I still didn't get my 3D coffee art. sigh2. chocolate gnut - $4 - price is kinda steep for a mini bite size pastry. I have no idea what it is but it kinda tasted like a mini donut hybrid with croissant (cronut) good amount of chocolate cream with every bite but e price ... e price... e price $$$$$3. ham + cheese croissant - $5 this was just OK, wished it came warm but it was kinda cold when i had it.I srsly have to try that eclair next time - looks nomilicious

I love to come here especially in the early mornings when its just me and the baristas. They are uber friendly and the latte art is really endearing. Love the chillout environment where I can get reading done.I always buy more coffee just to see what interesting things they can draw for me. The desserts are pretty and delectable. Sometimes just too pretty that I wouldnt want to stick the fork in. G spot is the dessert I'd recommend for all chocolate lovers like me.
