Recommend this place for people who just wanna have some me-time and enjoy a good cuppa (or two or three) If you ever do, invite me along as well.... :p

Patisserie G is located in the Marina Walk shopping center.  I was looking for some non-Singaporean coffee aka "kopi", and Yelp led me to Patisserie G.  It's more of a "fancy" French cafe and it is definitely reflected by its prices.  A simple iced black coffee cost me $5 SGD.  I guess that's not bad, given the ridiculous prices that Starbucks charges in Singapore.  Still, my coffee was just okay for $5... and not even an extra large size at that, which would have been nice :)Plenty of seating to go around.  The place wasn't very busy even in the morning... maybe because its located in the middle of the mall?Worth a try, but even if I lived here I wouldn't be a regular.

great little cakes at this popular cakery in millenia walk - so popular, in fact, that they've now expanded twice their original size. and for good reason, I think - if the cakes I had were anything to go by, they know their desserts.I finally managed to catch this place when it wasn't maniacally filled with sweet tooths (like mine) - probably because it was about 5 minutes before they closed the cashier. it's very good cake, so it's going to be an easy review: two cakes - a chocolate dome, and a opera-style one (sorry for the lack of titles, but hey, that's what photos are for!)both were surprisingly well done (surprising for hype doesn't always translate to skill) - neat clean layers, crispy pâte feuilletée or biscuit layers playing contrast to the soft, not-too-sweet chocolate mousse/ ganache layers, and prettily shiny glazes to top everything off.I like that there's a good mix of chocolate and other-than options - which span the spectrum from cheesecake to eclair. but these two were plenty lovely, good portions for a post-dinner treat, and very much worth ordering again.service is young but helpful and smiley, and the space is scandinavian white-and-wood and beautiful - clean, neat lines and pretty little desserts that aren't cheap but plenty satisfying, this place is a good one for some post-meal (or actual meal, why not) indulgence.

Allow me to preface this review by saying that I didn't order dessert! I know, I know, I basically broke the cardinal rule of this establishment, but allow me to explain. I came and held one of my CMYE* Office Hours here around 2 PM on a weekday, and I was amazed at how busy it was. It seems to be a quite popular mid-day hangout for the nearby office workers. I hadn't eaten all day, so I ordered a ham and cheese croissant. To be honest, it wasn't mindblowing, but it took away my hunger pangs. I also had a flat white which tasted perfectly fine to me. :)Everyone else seemed to be enjoying their desserts and coffee, so I'd definitely come back and give those a try sometime!--*CMYE stands for "Community Manager Yelp Event", which are casual meet ups hosted by yours truly. :) Office Hours are also when I answer any questions you have about Yelp. Check the Events Page to see what I have coming up next!

Saw the croque Monsieur which was my original thought, ordered the full breakfast instead. Sausage egg bacon, all good, salad and brioche didn't go well with the traditional food. Coffee was good, no decaf. Plate was cold, to help with the salad, therefore the egg and bacon were warm. Will go back later and try a cake.

The baristas' skill at creating elaborate designs out of milk foam is testament to how seriously the owner of Patisserie G takes her craft. Ms Gwen Lim identifies her target consumers as "a niche group of people who understand French pastry and are discerning about good-quality French products", namely the "well-travelled" Singaporean. Mm not the humblest way to plug her pâtisserie, but must say she really knows how to appeal to the yuppie psyche.Lemon Cheesecake, $9.00 - One forkful of the cheesecake should be enough to convince you that these cakes are worth good money. The filling is zesty and creamy without being too heavy on the palate, and flecked with crushed vanilla beans. The biscuit crust is actually crispy (!!) and tastes slightly singed, but went pretty well with the citrus filling and the strip of candied lemon peel. There's this thin gelatinous cover on the cake which I find odd, but its mostly tasteless and adds glossiness to the cake so meh, I'll live with it.Triomphe, $8.50 - Named after a historical monument, the Triomphe sported a lustrous toffee-brown coat that made it resemble a giant piece of Werther's candy. This baby was calling out my name so I decided I had to eat him. The caramel mousse was malty, ever-so-slightly burnt and, to sum it up: just divine. Within the cake there are a couple layers of soft hazelnut sponge, but the mousse was the friggin' star of the show. If it were up to me, I'd add a praline base or something crunchy at the bottom to provide some contrast in texture, but I'm sure the chef is better than I am at knowing which ingredients go together. In any case, the magical mousse is reason enough to justify repeated visits to Patisserie G.Flat White, $5.50 - The coffee selection here is proof that Patisserie G isn't going to bend over backwards for pedestrian crowds. Our respective requests for a mocha and a skinny latte were met with an apologetic "We don't do those here." from the waitress taking our orders at the counter. Embarrassed by my wimpyness, I manned up and got a flat white. Patisserie G gets its blends from artisan roasters Liberty Coffee (specifically the Speakeasy brew), which should please coffee aficionados. My flat white was nutty and robust.I watched in slack-jawed wonder as one of the baristas artfully crafted the smiling face of a bear on another customer's latte, then scowled in displeasure at the very unelaborate heart on the surface of my flat white. I'll be back, and I'll be sure to request for a bear on my coffee.

The pastries are good but the coffee is a hit or miss. The double macchiato was super sour while I'm guessing the piccolo latte's milk helped to neutralize the acidity. Pastries are good but pricey but I don't mind that. However, having an inedible piece of paper of their logo on the cake is a faux pas to me.

Chic japanese themed cafe located in Millenia Walk. Not a typical place that I would head to for a cup of cuppa. Heard and saw pictures of the 3d latte art totally made me want to check it out myself. Coffee beans are from local roastery Liberty Coffee was definitely a plus! Be sure to try out the desserts from the Cordon Bleu pastry chef Gwen Lim who has apparently worked under Pierre Herme himself! Pretty Awesome!
The quiche is amazing and cute cafe latte delicious. If I lived in Singapore I would visit all the time!!!

The Salted Caramel macaron was rather salty for a liking. The Milk Chocolate White Miso macaron started out rather sweet and milky but then the salty taste kicked in after that. The Lychee Rose is probably the better macaron I have ever eaten. It is sweet with very noticeable taste of lychee and rose. For someone who likes sweet stuffs, this fits perfectly into the picture. The Salted Hazelnut macaron is also very nice. The hazelnut taste was very distinct and was less salty.

Had a lovely skinny latte and tasted a bit of a coconut choux tart, which didn't look that inviting but turned out to be delicious. They tend to run out of items (e.g. Croque Monsieur) by later in the day so the early bird catches the worm...

WOW!  The hot chocolate was remarkable, I might just has well have been drinking a chocolate creme soup.  I've never had anything so amazing.  Amazing, good word to describe the desserts as well.  I tried the G-spot, an amazing chocolate mousse creation and another which was a creme broulette dessert.  The tea was excellent as well.  I highly recommend checking this place out.  Walk past the Starbucks and into PatisserieG instead!  You won't be disappointed.

Visited the place on Sunday for brunch. Compared to its next door crowded buffet restaurant, the place was surprisingly quiet with just 4 other tables of couple. We were showed to a roomy booth table, where the staff pulled out the table for us to be seated. Looked through the menu, we decided on the 3-course Sunday Lunch Set Menu (S$98++).After placing order, we were served its signature Onion Bread and butter. The huge bun was pipping hot and fluffy.For AppetizerBaked Five Onion Soup (ala carte price S$29++)It was served in a small cup with melted cheese toast on top. The soup was more salty side but great to dip the bread with.Chopped House Salad (ala carte price S$28++)It may not looked much, but the flavours were great. Just take of note of the strong flavoured goat cheese.For Entree8.5oz Filet Mignon with Asparagus and Mashed Potatoes (ala carte price S$101++/ 8oz)Went with the staff's recommendation of medium rare. Opt to serve with mustard and brown sauce, plus sour cream for the mash on the side. The meat was done just right without too raw or too tough. The mash was delicious with bits of potato in it.Center-Cut Prime Ribeye (Topup S$30++) (ala carte price S$118++/ 16oz)Went with the staff's recommendation of medium. The meat serving was double of the filet mignon.  Opt to serve with brown sauce, plus sour cream for the mash on the side. The meat was done just right without too raw or too tough. The texture was smoother compared to the filet mignon, but the serving was too huge for a female like me. The end part was a tab too chewy than preferred.For DessertMorton's Legendary Hot Chocolate Cake (Topup S$10++) (ala carte price S$36++)The molten chocolate cake was served hot, topped with raspberries and a scoop of vanilla ice cream by the side. Soft crumbling crust, encasing the hot molten chocolate inside. Sinfully rich pairing with the cold ice cream.Key Lime Pie (ala carte price S$26++)Served with a slice of lime and a pile of whipped cream.I was too full to have a mouth of it. The staff kindly packed it up for takeaway.

Morton's is one of my happy places, I was more than thrilled that my friends agreed to go there for my birthday.The whole night was just perfect, Morton's in Singapore can definitely keep up with the branches in the US. The steaks and seafood are just on point, they are perfectly cooked and of very good quality.The cocktails are also comparable to those in the US, unlike in most Singaporean bars & restaurants it is not a watered down jobbie, it is a full strength Martini. The wine we had was excellent (but $$$!).Another nice touch is that they had (like in the US) the menu personalized and offered a complimentary souffle plus a printed out picture for me to take home. In general, the service was very good throughout the night.Morton's complimented the great company of my friends perfectly, I felt so spoiled and happy. The only downside was the price: it is certainly not cheap and is still more expensive than their US counterparts but it is well worth it in my opinion. Will go back if another special occassion comes up.

My first visit at Morton's steakhouse was an extremely good experience!Planned a birthday celebration for a big boy, and started off dinner with pre dinner drinks by Morton's bar in the evening. Morton's bar happy hour every evening from 5pm - 7pm, with free flow steak sliders with any drinks purchased, and selected martinis at $15.95.I ordered a chocolate mortini and the big boy for himself a cosmopolitan. The chocolate mortini taste fabulous with a thick layer of chocolate which settles at the bottom of the martini glass. We also helped ourselves with a couple of steak sliders (2 mouthfuls worth) which are so succulent and good!We moved on to dinner at the restaurant.We love the setting and service of the restaurant, private yet intimate, and dark romantic and comfortable set up. We had sufficient introduction and great service from the staff who made us feel comfortable throughout our whole dining experience.We ordered a chilled Morton's Prime Ocean Platter, a 12oz centre cut filet mignon (add enhancement of a slab of black truffle butter), and button mushroom only (as recommended by the waitress) for sharing. The sweet gesture by the chef, separate the 12oz filet mignon to 2 equal portions for us. (Look at it on a cost saving perspective..)Received a complimentary small soufflé for the birthday boy, and a lovely birthday song by the staff. To sum up the night, the staff helped us take and developed a photo for souvenir.Concluded that Morton's is not only known for its steak, the ocean platter is also fresh and worth the mention! Steak is perfectly medium rare by the chef, and it should not go without a good glass of red wine.We had a great dining experience with good food, drinks and service at the restaurant and will definitely pop by again in future!

Order- 1/2 doz oyster in their shells, 6 oz center cut filet mignon and I sampled the center cut ribeye (all steaks done medium rare). We had the lava cake as dessert.The colour on all steaks were nice and I personally felt the portion size of the ribeye was huge! Still, it was a good night out - good quality steak but I'm not certain it's the best steak I could get for the price it commands.

I am not ashamed to say that this is my first time at Morton's Steakhouse, despite their legendary status among my beef-oholic friends. Their price tag is also equally legendary.Excited yet apprehensive about the quality of the steak and the size of the hole it will burn in my pocket, I accepted my partner's invitation to have dinner with him at Morton's.A few things sorely lacking in most F&B establishments in Singapore is the quality of service provided. At Morton's, you can expect the best, personalised service ever (Well, comparable to Black Swan, I would say).Stepping foot into Mandarin Oriental (Morton's is at Level 4), I gave 2 thumbs up to the antiquated-like settings with deep maroon and brass finishing. Somehow in my mind's eye, I always have this vision that good steakhouses will have these kind of furnishings. Anyway, I digress.The two waitresses greeted me with a warm smile and without hesitation I mentioned that my friend is already inside. To which, they confirmed my friend's name and one of them walked me to my table. The self-independent woman in me wanted to decline for her to walk me to my table but she was walking too purposefully for me to stop her. I spotted my partner in one the booths and he gave me a mischievous smile. We reached the table and next thing I knew, the waitress pull out the table with effortless Herculean strength to let me in. Wow. I guess this is part of their service to diners who sit at the booths which I feel was adequate for one person to slide in, slowly.Having checked out their menu online, I was still undecided on what to order so we decided to seek the recommendations of our waiter. He gamely and cheerfully recommended me a Center-Cut Fillet Mignon 8oz as he felt that the 12oz onwards would be too huge for me - if only he knew of my appetite for beef, having ate 2 Jack's Place steak in one sitting! For my partner, he recommended the Chilean Seabass Fillet a La Nage. We ordered the cream spinach after our waiter commented that the sauteed spinach and mushrooms are meh.The crowd was picking up by that time and I was impressed when our food came in record time. Verdict:1. Center-Cut Fillet Mignon - I was singing praises with every gentle slice of beef that I savoured - "Wow, very soft, melts in your mouth. This is good." - to the point my partner was highly amused. The 8oz would be more than sufficient to most ladies, but not to me. Almost to the point where I was tempted to order another one! Served simply on a white plate, the steak oozed flavourful spoonfuls of beef juice!2. Creamed Spinach -  The dish looks overwhelming at first sight but it goes well with my steak as I had no sides on my plate. The delicious butter-filled aroma that it exudes is simply appetizing. Though it is 'creamed', it is light and easy on the palette.3. Chilean Seabass Fillet a La Nage -  Fresh, that's one word to describe the fish. The portion is somewhat larger then what most steakhouses would serve but we are not complaining. The sauce may seem a bit too light for those who are used to creamy, buttery sauce but I feel that it acts as an excellent foil to bring out the freshness of the fish. 4. Key Lime Pie - This tops my list as the best ever, dethroning the Key Lime Pie at PS Cafe. Light and tangy with just the right amount of sweetness, this is a good choice for a desert. Best savoured with after-dinner tea (without milk).The manager stopped by our table to chat and check on our satisfaction and though I usually dislike chatting with the staff during my meal, I was infected by his good sense of humor and charm.Would I return again? Hell, yes! On special occasions though..Service: 5/5Humor of staff 6/5Food: 5/5Price: 3/5 (only because it would burn a huge hole in your pocket if you start craving for the Fillet Mignon 8oz every two weeks!)

Everyone is just so friendly at mandarin oriental. That's why I love staying at this hotel everywhere I go. Staff at mortons too are just as proper and sweet. Their cocktails at happy hour too just make that smile bigger on your face. Free steak sarnies too from 5-7pm. You know how a medium rare steak is so juicy? A slice of that is sandwiched by two soft buns and slathered in a horseradish cream. Oh so gooood!!! The chocotinis are the best in town too. Those steak sandwiches and one cocktail will fill you up too. Writing this review just makes me wish for Monday happy hour to come :p

Disappointing. The sommelier was great and recommended a Ruffino Chianti that was medium bodied and paired well with the fillet. That said, the rest of the dinner was very disappointing. The steamed asparagus was flavorless, as was the Hollandaise sauce which accompanied it. When we asked what type of cheese was in the au gratin potatoes (we adore smoked Gouda), we were told "American,"  which is not a real cheese, but a processed cheese "food."  We ordered the filet mignon done "medium" and it was beautifully tender, but sadly underdone. As it was Valentines Day, and our anniversary, we were told that we would be receiving a dessert "on the house."  Instead of a traditional chocolate dessert, we were presented with a "lemon soufflé." It was tasteless and was more like an egg-white breakfast omelette than a dessert soufflé. Overall a disappointing meal.

This place is very expensive. $98 for 6 ounce filet. My friend ordered a Filet Medium and it was served Rare. We asked the server to cook it some more and when the steak was brought back out it was still rare. I have never had this experience at a fine dining steakhouse. Appetizers and salad were great. We ordered the shrimp tacos, oysters, and mozzarella wrapped in prosciutto. Overall,  I would not recommend this restaurant they were playing loudly Justin Beiber  and pop's greatest hits. Not my kind of ambiance for a fine dining restaurant.

My steak- medium rare was perfectly cooked, I was impressed because it was so good. We ordered tuna tacos to share as our appetizer and they were delicious too. I think my mouth just gave my stomach a high five.  Oh, and the service was excellente

Visit umakemehungry website for more detailsNestled in the heart of Marina Bay area, Mandarin Oriental housed a legendary steakhouse, Morton's. It is located at 4th storey of the hotel, just opposite one of the popular buffet lines, Melt-The World Cafe.The exterior of Morton's was a classic looking American steakhouse with wood panels as its background and its reputable name shining brightly under the warm orange lightings.  Dining in Morton was really a good experience with its elegant interiors and service was impeccable with special needs well attended. Furthermore they were quite detailed with little actions well taken care of and make us felt close to heart.We were presented with a hand decorated birthday card with our photo instantly printed which was a pleasant surprise to the birthday guy, making the event a memorable one in Morton's !Overall, everything was good. My only gripe was that Photography was a challenge as the place was dimly lit. Nevertheless, this had create a very good atmosphere especially for special occassions. I would highly recommend this place if one is seeking for a good steak dinner, service and ambience.

Morton's used to serve some of the best steaks in town at a mid-to-high end price point. The food is still good and service is very good by Singapore standards, but perhaps not as good as before since Lawry's took over. Had lunch recently during a conference, which may or may not explain our experience. Even with a very full house, we got hot cups of lobster bisque and good bread (though we had to ask for it). Our sirloin steaks came at the right doneness but everyone had quite different sized cuts, which is strange for a restaurant that I used to think was very consistent. I would also have liked a bit more charring on my steak but that tends to be done best on a filet mignon. We had cheesecakes for dessert and as always, there were no complaints there.I am willing to give Morton's the benefit of doubt as this restaurant has historically been a great experience at dinner. Will be back sometime to see if things have really changed.

Morton's is a steakhouse from USA that is really famous for the kind of service that they deliver to customers. Think the service from there have definitely been built up in the Singapore chain. When we walked into this particular restaurant, we were served immediately and brought to our seats in a jiffy. A waitress then came to our table and presented to us the different cuts of beef which was an eye opener.The menu was then passed to us and we decided to order the new York cut and ribeye steak which did not disappoint us at all. We tried the molten chocolate cake as well which was pretty normal, not really glorious or anything was hoping for the wow factor.One thing that we should not have tried is the Caesar salad, with only grated parmesan cheese and croutons on it and really over priced. I have had better Caesar salads with bacon bits and eggs topped on top of the vegetables. Overall a good experience if you know what to order from the start.

This is my go to place for steak in Singapore. There is a consistency to the food quality and service standards offered at Morton's. I guess every individual would have their own experiences but I personally have never had a bad meal at Morton's before. Their crab cakes and chocolate lava cakes are also my absolute favourites! Dining at Morton's has become an annual tradition for birthdays and anniversaries. I've tried other steakhouses such as Cut, Chris Ruth, Wooloomooloo etc. some were pretty good as well but so far none comes close to Morton's in my opinion. Its good value for money.Also try getting in the bar during happy hour for the martini and free flow mini steak sandwiches!

Morton's is a good choice for a leisure meal and happy hour drinks. It proved to be consistent in service, pricing & quality.In terms of the actual steakhouse function of it I have to say that Morton's is a good 'run of the mill' chain restaurant for the better and the evil. The better being the aforementioned pro arguments: I never had bad service here, I never had bad food here and I find the prices to be reasonable for a good steak. The negative part of any larger scale chain restaurant is that it is generic, not outside the box. Meaning Morton's won't give you the unique experience as Cut would do however it is within a totally different price bracket so not fair to judge it by that.A solid 4 star establishment!

I have been very fortunate to make a stop in Morton's at the Oriental whenever I am in Singapore (which has been about once a year for the past 10 years), and each time has been great. The Vibe is exactly how a Morton's should be and the people who work their are awesome.After eating here (this was my first time to a Morton's), I figured I would visit the locations in San Francisco and San Jose, but was completely let down. Maybe the Morton's in the USA should take a lesson from this location on how to offer good service. Anyways, You guys rock!!

We usually come here for the happy hour where martinis go for a song (relatively) and there's free flow of steak sandwiches to go around. However we decided to check it out properly this time. Love the onion bread. The steaks are great although the portions are ginormous! The crabcakes are to die for and so is the chocolate lava cake.Intimate and cosy. Good place for a celebratory dinner.

Singapore sadly doesnt have great steakhouses, only good ones.If you're used to Lugar's in Brooklyn or Goodmans/Hawksmoore in London, you'll be  disappointed with Mortons.But given the few other options on this island, Morton's is worth going to. Its expensive, and somewhat dark inside. The steak is good.

Steaks make me happy, and when I know I'm headed to Morton's, my heart leaps.Begin either at The Bar at Morton's perched midway up the winding stairway with $12 Martinis or head straight to the restaurant for appetisers. The complimentary onion bread is quite something, I can never have enough of it. But you must leave space for the crab cake. We usually order it to share (begrudgingly) but if budget is not an issue, do yourself a favour and have one on your own. I listen obligatorily to the server's repertoire as they roll the meat cart around, explaining and pointing to the various cuts in a well-rehearsed manner, and managing to stifle a giggle when they pick up the lobster with its claws flailing about. However, when it comes to the steak selection, I only have eyes for the marbled US aged black angus ribeye ($97, moderately huge, we ordered one to split).   Morton's always gets medium exactly right, so no ribeyes of mine ever go to waste, and the marbling means I get delicious melting fat to go along with well-seared, pink-in-the-middle king of all steaks. Add a side of asparagus if you must have your vegetables.Looking for an excuse to go back again! Reservations are a must.

We asked for medium ... But after about 45 mins the steaks came and both were overdone. One was salty. Not sure why. There must be big issues. Waiting staff were apologetic and offered to refund the of the steaks (SGD99++ each). They tried hard to make it up. But we came to this overpriced restaurant for good steak, not apologies, and didn't get it. So FAIL. I have had better steaks in a lot of cheaper places. This was supposed to be a special night out and they messed it up. If you pretend to be a quality steakhouse learn how to cook a steak.

It used to be good. The last visit in Nov 2012 saw many changes to the staff and food quality/presentation and size. Had food poisoning after eating oysters on half shells. The double porterhouse tastes different too. Won't be visiting it for a long time.

Being from the US and actually having an aversion to chain restaurants I should have known better than to attempt to visit this establishment.  While guests of the Mandarin Oriental, we had made dinner reservations at another restaurant in the hotel and wanted to grab a drink at the Morton's Bar prior to dinner.  Huge mistake.  The way their staff made me feel was probably the way Julia Roberts character in Pretty Woman felt when she tried to purchase clothing on Rodeo Drive, and I look/act nothing like a trashy hooker.  If you want to feel snubbed or treated with disrespect you should definitely go to the Morton's Bar, they are exceptional at that. Cheers.
Never done the bar, but inside everything else is done right. Service, food, and ambiance.

Morton's in Singapore. In a word it's awful. Meat is frozen and long ago. You have to saw it to cut a slice. Tomatoes are almost white. Tea is in the tea bags:) And for that torture an astonishing price. Do not do a mistake, do not go to a steakhouse in Singapore. It's stupid.

Feels like the real deal compared to the US.  The meat in my opinion falls a bit short, but that's more or less because of the laws around dry-aged, bone in meat not allowed for in Singapore.  Australian beef just does not compare.  Never tried the happy hour.  Only have heard good things.

I booked dinner at Morton's at the Mandarin Oriental as a special treat for my son and daughter in law, who I was visiting in Singapore. Unfortunately their service was slow and inattentive and the food was way below par for their exorbitant prices.  I ordered mine medium rare and it was well done and once they finally slapped our plates on the table they forgot about us. I reluctantly paid the bill but will never eat at a Morton's restaurant again. There are many way better and reasonably priced restaurants in Singapore!

I saw a picture of a grilled squid online and couldn't resist trying it on my recent trip to Singapore. The squid was tender and delicious, and the environment was authentic, relaxed, and perfect. My friend tried the tuna hand rolls and remarked to me that they were the best he'd ever had, and overall we had a great time.Tomo Izakaya is definitely a memorable experience, especially if you're interested in going outside your comfort zone and trying new food!

No hostess to seat people in crowded Clarke Quay. Watched several dozen people walk out due to lack of service. Finally got our order. At the end of meal I had to interrupt server and cook from arguing to pay the bill. He then tried to argue with me. Food was average, service was non-existent. Would never recommend.

Ate here because of convenience. Ordered a tonkatsu bento that comes with unlimited rice and miso soup, salmon sashimi along with Japanese starters. While eating the salmon sashimi, there was a piece of hair sticking out from the wasabi. It was curly... I wanted to throw up. I flagged the waitress down and told her what I found. When she came back with the bento box, it was the same exact box that she had taken and she just put a new bowl of salmon sashimi. Talk about sanitary... I did not get an apology along with my "new" bento box. Wouldn't recommend this place. Food is mediocre.

(3 stars, but giving it 2 to compensate for the over-ratings from the other reviews)Contrary to the other reviews, I beg to differ with regards to the food quality.Food quality-wise, it's the average izakaya fare. Grilled, fried and some sushi/sashimi items to pick from on the menu. I passed on the sushi when the fish didn't look too fresh. The grilled squid was previously frozen before getting tossed on the grill, and was rather chewy. The udon was generally run of the mill. The only saving grace is the stewed pork rib.This is a place to get cheap beers, hang out and watch the world go by at the Esplanade. Service is good, and there's a variety of items on the menu. It's a notch above the regular strip-mall sushi joint. However, if you're looking for great Japanese food, this isn't the place.

My husband and I stumbled upon this sushi establishment late one night after arriving from a long flight and finding most other places closed for the evening.  We ordered our usual nigiri and sashimi and were delighted to find that the waitress recommended different types of soy sauce for each dish.  The fish melted in your mouth.  The quality was unbelievable.  The value for money was really so much better than expected.  It's now a regular place for us when we're in SG.
One of our favourite place for Japanese. We especially love the tomo Caesar salad and the soba. The maki and temaki are pretty good. We enjoy the laid back atmosphere and the good service
Just sushi nothing special over price the only good thing is the location ramen was very taste less

I decided to stop by this place with my wife after work. During a return flight to Singapore on one of the famous budget airlines, I discovered an article that listed establishments to grab cheap beer in Singapore. Now, most of us know that Singapore is an incredibly expensive place to drink alcohol. That's a fact that many of us have to live with. Well, this article stated that Tomo Izakaya had $5 beers and cheap Japanese eats. It was pretty much a must visit after reading about $5 beers. Finding this place was easy. It's close to the Esplanade, and in a great part of town, close to the river with a great view of Marina Bay and the CBD. We took a seat and really enjoyed their décor and setting. We ordered a couple of $5 Japanese beers and few bites which included 1) bacon scallop skewers 2) cold soba noodles 3) sushi roll 4) Seafood salad 5) chicken karage. The only thing that stood out was the skewers. Everything else was not memorable. We'd probably return for the $5 beers, but we don't plan on grabbing more food here. 3 stars for the cheap beer and the attentive service.

My friends and I were looking for a nice outdoor dining area and eventually ended up at Esplanade. Izakaya Tomo serves Japanese cuisine, and I'd say that you will have to try their grilled food items when you get here. We ordered the soft shell crab maki, unagi maki, bacon-wrapped vegetables, grilled squid, grilled beef, and grilled mackerel - we ended up paying about $23 per person in a party of four.Izakaya's unagi maki takes the prize, hands down. The unagi simply melts in your mouth as you bite through the firm and fresh rice ball to reach the center. The unagi is also not overly oily or slimy, so those worried about that will have less reason to hesitate ordering this dish. The soft shell crab is crispy and relatively salty (as should be expected), but not remarkable. I also wondered how difficult it would be to ruin bacon-wrapped vegetables: in any case, I loved Izakaya's version. The bacon fats are grilled nicely, with pepper bits decorating the meat at the surface.The grilled squid was a little tough and could have spent more time in the heat, but I had nothing to complain about the mackerel: thin-crisp skin combined with the succulent white flesh of the fish, tinged with freshly-squeezed lemon zest. You also can taste the smoked flavours as you savour every bite. The grilled beef - my friends concurred - was done just right: sinewy but not tough, with the temperature wavering between medium-rare and medium.Ultimately, I'd say they do their grilled food very well; and the ambience is unbeatable. The cool breeze from the waters nearby, live music in the distance, and open space so that you don't need to compete for elbow room while dining.

Tomo Izakaya at Esplanade Mall is a hidden gem. The location makes for quiet dining (sorta) with a slightly more sophisticated crowd and relaxing ambience. Gyu Tataki ($13) is the beef version of sashimi. Lightly seared on the outside then marinated with lemon, vinegar and soy sauce after, it was served with pounded ginger and spring onions on top of the rare meat. Very big slices of beef which really worked our jaws. There is none of that bloodiness or heaviness of the red meat. Oishi.Skewers were next. Who could say no to BBQ bacon wrapped anything? The smokiness of the fatty pork flavored the succulent and sweet hotate chunks ($10), giving each bite a burst of juices and flavors.Shitake Mentai Cheese ($7) is a must order. The woody and juicy shitake goes perfectly with the crackling bacon and the mentaiko cream was simply the icing on the cake.The Tonkujyou Chirashi ($36) is really the highlight of the meal. The special chirashi is worth every bit of that 36 bucks even though it's a small bowl. Tomo is very generous with the fresh sashimi. The fatty toro was creamy with fats and extremely well marbled. There was so much uni and salmon roe to go around that we had to finish all the vinegar rice (which was delicious on its own too). One of the best chirashi bowls in town and reasonably priced.For reviews and more, visit my blog.
Never packed, great food! Makes for a real decent, dignified dining experience. The sashimi was also decently delectable for an izakaya place. All other barbecued-based dishes were also lovely. A go!

address: 9 Raffles Boulevard #02-06, Millenia Walk Singapore 039596 Singapore
comment: Not clear why this place has poor reviews the ramen noodles I had were delicious. And it's open late and has a vegetarian friendly version.

address: 9 Raffles Boulevard #02-06, Millenia Walk Singapore 039596 Singapore
comment: This is an almost 5 star rating review.So came here after my first Milksha voyage at Suntec. I was really wandering about at the huge and confusing Suntec area. Eventually I surrendered and fell back on my familiar grounds, Millenia Walk.I have a friend who kept suggesting we meet at Uma Uma but somehow we made it to everywhere else except here. So I thought why don't I try it here even w/o her.SERVICE 5/5Staff greeted me upon entering and basically let me choose whichever table I like. That was wonderful. No problem with the service! FOOD 5/5Uma Uma Ramen (without the spicy miso) - An excellent Tonkotsu ramen!! Egg was perfectly cooked to what it should be. The broth was thick. So I read, Uma Uma serves the Hakata-styled ramen and It was established in Fukuoka in 1953.The Chicken kaarage was one of the best I tasted in recent times and I had a lot of chicken kaarage.So what made me took out one point? Read further...AMBIENCE 4/5The décor reminded me of a Izakaya. I really love the ambience. However, that chair I was sitting on was the devil. It was really uncomfortable and not long after the meal, my back was hurting :( Despite of that, I would still come to Uma Uma noodles if I get the chance.

address: 9 Raffles Boulevard #02-06, Millenia Walk Singapore 039596 Singapore
comment: Recently the ramen chain has expanded to a second outlet in the newly open Japanese street in Millenia Walk. Besides the usual ramen dishes, it also offers yakitori at night. As chinese new year is coming, the restaurant is offering a new ramen called Yusheng Ramen from 18 Jan to 22 Feb 2016.Yusheng Ramen ($14++)Cucmber, radish, carrot shredded omelette, seaweed, red ginger, spring onion, sesame seeds, salmon & tuna chunks, fried gyoza skin and hakata ramenThe dish was served cold and dry, without the usual soup in it. It looked quite colorful with the different toppings on top. Remember to toss the dish before eating. Felt that it was quite difficult to toss as the shredded vegetables tended to stick together. It was a cold and refreshing dish. The top potion was a bit dry and flavourful, whereas the bottom was quite flavourful with strong sesame oil taste as the dressing was quite watery and tended to stay at the bottom.Overall the food was not bad but the choices was quite limited during the day. More choices as yakitori and cocktails were available at night. Service was not bad with iced water refilled regularly.

address: 9 Raffles Boulevard #02-06, Millenia Walk Singapore 039596 Singapore
comment: Great service and delicious ramen. I got the spicy broth without chasiu, but added corn. My husband got the signature uma uma with double chasiu (since we had them add mine in his). Both delicious!

address: 9 Raffles Boulevard #02-06, Millenia Walk Singapore 039596 Singapore
comment: Stumbled upon this place while checking out a row of Japanese restaurants. The place is small and we didn't want to sit at the bar area or outdoors. Luckily, we got a table quite soon, maybe because it was still early. There was a national day set promotion which seemed quite value for money. A normal ramen alone costs $15++ at the minimum while the promotion had a ramen, char siu bun, green tea ice cream with red beans and green tea for $20++. I had the prawn ramen which reminded me of prawn bisque. The soup was more like gravy but the thick flavor more than compensated for it. The char siu bun had small dried shrimps which was a nice surprise. When we paid, the waitress even asked if we liked the food. Overall positive experience in terms of the taste and service!

address: 9 Raffles Boulevard #02-06, Millenia Walk Singapore 039596 Singapore
comment: Missing the open air Fukuoka yatais and smoky izakayas in Nagoya, we headed to Uma Uma at its latest location on the Japanese Food Street at Millenia Walk. Here, we kicked back with grilled Yakitori and Kushikatsu,  cocktails and drinks by Horse's Mouth and Hakata-styled ramen from Uma Uma Ramen.It really felt like we walked into a Hakata izakaya at Uma Uma, with its slightly crampish seating, long bar/ramen counter and warm Japanese hospitality. Orders were placed swiftly, so that the a la minute sticks with homemade sauces (created by Head Chef, Shota Kaneko) would arrive quickly.  Ingredients are imported twice weekly from Japan and the quality is best presented through grilling. My favorite Yakitori sticks are the Tsukune (chicken balls with soft bone) which was juicy with some crunch! All resolve to eat healthy will obliterate with a stick (or 2) of that crispy and sweet grilled chicken skin! How did i resist this for so long?! The Butabura (Pork Belly) and chicken thigh were a tad dry-ish and bland for my liking. And obviously I'm not a fan the bland soft bone. All Yakitori sticks are priced between $2 - 3 each.From the bar bites, do not miss the fried Brussels Sprouts ($10) with a salty sweet sauce. This is possibly the 'healthiest' dish at Uma Uma. Loved those browned crispy edges. The Eihire (stingray fins) ($10) are best eaten hot. They tastes exactly like grilled cuttlefish but sweeter.The Kushikatsu (串揚げ) selection is quite small currently. While the batter is sufficiently light and not overly greasy, I always felt it's a waste of the ingredients when they are deep fried. Wouldn't the freshly imported Japan scallops have died in vain? Well thankfully they remained fairly decent after frying. I much preferred the Pork Loin with the Tonkatsu sauce though I must say it's a bit tougher. All Kushikatsu sticks are sold from $2 - 5 each.Now this is the star of Uma Uma actually- the Chasiu Don ($5) with an additional Onsen Tamago ($1.50). Love love love the wonderfully charred and buttery chasiu with soy! This portion is perfect for the ladies and for the guys too, since you could always have other sides to go with! This is also available at the other outlets, even at Horse's Mouth (it's $10 there though).For something heartier to go with the meat skewers, pick from the list of ramen. I'd go with the Mazesoba, a Japanese spin on the local dry ba chor mee (minced pork noodles). They use a Hokkaido type of curly yellow noodles (which was a bit too alkaline IMO) topped with spring onions, bamboo shoots, leeks, chili oil and onsen egg. You should definitely top up or add on a side of the wonderfully charred chasiu! I found the Uma Uma Ramen ($14) to be too bland, oily, and overcooked for my liking. The Bushi Tonkotsu Ramen ($16) fared better with the smoky bonito flakes Tonkotsu soup but that's my preference. The good guys behind Horse's Mouth have crafted a special drinks menu for Uma Uma, featuring Sakes chosen from small and private breweries in Japan, classic cocktails, premium whiskys and beers so there is something for everyone.

address: 3 Temasek Blvd #B1A-144, Tower 1 Suntec City Mall Singapore 038983 Singapore
comment: Finally!!  A 100% Muslim Owned Vietnamese Kiosk/Food Vendor which offers Banh Mi that I like!  Thank you for opening one, and for that I cannot thank you enough!!  Though it can be messy eating those Baguette...  The Grilled Beef slices though some was fatty bits, the flavor combinations and how the Beef was marinated I like...  That was what I had and ordered from my recent trip at Banh You Banh Mi!In Banh You Banh Mi Menu, they offer Beef, Chicken and Vegetarian dishes which includes Salad Bowls if you are into that route.  From my understanding, Banh You Banh Mi has been opened since August/September ish...  Oh well...  The Secret is out!!  From their Social Media accounts and I found out about this tiny Food Vendor or Kiosk from the Local Food Journalist a few weeks ago after reading her article in the Local Newspaper.There is only like 4 seats to enjoy your purchase else, outside the Main Walkway or Public areas, there are several standing tables too...  Banh You Banh Mi is indeed tricky to find... it is located just across the Beverage Vendor who sells Teh Tarik I think.Banh You Banh Mi offers Summer Spring Rolls.  That would definitely be my next order!  When the first time I was here, ONLY Cash transactions is available since they are working out their kinks.  Will update and definitely returning when I am at Suntec!  See you soon Banh You Banh Mi!  See you soon!

address: 1 Beach Rd #01-22/23 Raffles Hotel Singapore 189673 Singapore
comment: Came here for dinner on a Sunday night and was surprised to see that it wasn't crowded!! Nevertheless, the food was exceptional and I would definitely want to come back to try breakfast, lunch, and afternoon tea.FOOD: (HIGHLY RECOMMEND)- SEAWEED & WASABI FRIES (Appetizer): The seasoning of the seaweed, pepper, and hints of wasabi make these fries (which are similarly shaped to Mcdonalds fries) seem so sophisticated and inventive. Definitely enjoyed thiss!! Portion wise it was very generous and easily made the three of us full.- HALIA CHILLI CRAB SPAGHETTI: One of their signature dishesss and it was absolutely delicious! At first I was worried that the sauce would be too heavy but it wasn't at all. And they certainly didn't skimp on the crab bits!!- HALIBUT EN PAPILLOTE: Another signature dish which I really enjoyed! My favorite was the buttery soup-like sauce the halibut, broccoli, and mushrooms were soaked in. It definitely helped add some flavor to the unseasoned halibut. The dish also is accompanied with aioli sauce for you to dip the halibut in!! As well as rice and cucumbers which seemed very japanesy like.*When you order two chili crab spaghetti, they give you two Singapore SlingsOverall, a really great experience. Not to mention, the service was really good and I really like the decor of the restaurant.

address: 1 Beach Rd #01-22/23 Raffles Hotel Singapore 189673 Singapore
comment: This cafe offers a good selection of food ranging from breakfast, lunch and dinner. The price is not as expensive as one would expect since its based at one of the most expensive hotels in Singapore. I had the pancakes which is definitely worth the deal. Portion was big and it was tasty. Will definitely return to try out the other dishes. Decent restaurant that offers good ambiance even for large groups both inside and outside of it.

address: 1 Beach Rd #01-22/23 Raffles Hotel Singapore 189673 Singapore
comment: so disappointing. food, service and value were far below what should have been at such an iconic locationthere was no one dining there when we got there at 6:30pm. that should have been a warning. our waitress barely spoke english. if this was a hawker market food stall, sure, that's to be expected. but in the Raffles Hotel?!?! my colleague ordered a cosmopolitan drink which was one of their specialty drinks and she had no idea what we were talking about. we had to point to it on the menuclearly nothing was prepared to order. the apps came immediately and main courses a few minutes after. we both ordered the cheesy seafood dish (I don't remember the name). cheese and seafood is usually high-risk and this was no exception. no dessert, we both wanted to get out of there, but the price was way too high. with so many choices around Raffles Hotel, including Boat Quay which is just  few minute walk, I will never come here again

address: 1 Beach Rd #01-22/23 Raffles Hotel Singapore 189673 Singapore
comment: Very nicely done food. The chilli crab spaghetti is spicy and delicious. Even my picky mother approved. And it's a great lazy way to eat chilli crab. The fries with the truffle aoili and spicy mayo is good - we cleaned out the truffle aoili. I like the pulled duck salad concept with the cold soba but they could have had a lighter hand with the sesame oil seasoning. Their brunch menu had a lovely pancake which my friend's kid scarfed down. Service is fairly attentive and place is relatively kids' friendly

address: 1 Beach Rd #01-22/23 Raffles Hotel Singapore 189673 Singapore
comment: We went here for lunch which was really good. The 'lunch espress' serves a great wagyu salad, a delicious truffle-egg on toast, ánd a proper chocolate desert with coffee. ($25) other options are available, like soup and tagliatelle.My girlfriend had the fried squid which was to die for, really that alone is worth the visit. The signature chili crab spaghettini was nice and plenty.Most noticeable was the service! We were served by a lovely lady called Kengar, who advised us on the food, and kept making sure everything was satisfactory. We haven't been served this good anywhere in Singapore yet.So overall definitely a great place to visit!

address: 1 Beach Rd #01-22/23 Raffles Hotel Singapore 189673 Singapore
comment: The iconic Raffles Hotel has finally gotten itself a decent restaurant for brunch with The Halia coming under its roof. Afternoon tea at the Tiffin Room is one thing but ladies of leisure still need their morning coffee run and eggs of course! And what better place to do it than at the urban, casual-chic sister of the award winning restaurant. I much preferred the indoor space which has a bit more privacy as compared to the alfresco bar area. Plus the Singapore weather is not meant for dining outdoors, even with ceiling fans. Give me my ac please.Weekend brunch starts at 11am. The selection is extensive with both the Brunch Specials and the Main Menu available for the picking. I've been in quite a bread mood recently and the Assorted Bread & Pastries ($12) really appealed to the tummy. The croissant was delightful and i love that they serve clotted cream with the basket.The Pancake with bacon, maple butter, fresh strawberries & puree ($12) was one of my favorite dish. I always get overwhelmed after eating a piece of pancake but Halia's rendition had me going on and on. I like the slightly buttery batter which was fluffy and the thin flaky bacon was an interesting complement to the dish. If you're more the traditional English Breakfast sort, you'd do well with the Grilled breakfast with any style eggs ($23). What's interesting was the sweetened bacon which was thick and juicy. The scrambled eggs had this interesting layered texture and i like that it was runny but not too creamy. I'm getting hooked on buttery eggs.  I'm not so much of a fan of the White bean Iberico chorizo leek stew ($16) but if you like gumbo and the starchiness of such a stew for brunch, then this would be it. The stew was  rich and starchy with a tinge of sourness from the smoked chipotle sauce. The Celeriac "Lasagna" ($12) is an interesting signature with crunchy thin sheets of pasta. I thought i was munching on vegetables. This was accompanied with mushrooms, thyme, baby spinach, lemon and Madeira cream. Another signature is the Halia Chili Crab Spaghettini ($25). Piquant spicy finish that is typically Asian. The flavor of ginger was rather strong but it gave the dish a fresh note. I could also taste the sweetness of the crab meat. If only they would use a thicker pasta. The Sous Vide Baharat Chicken Leg ($28) was very tender and flavorful. It also had that smoky taste which was well complemented with the sweet butternut squash puree. I was intrigued by the crispy thin skin which had the texture of a baked potato skin. Served with a ginger, coriander and pepper salsa. I like how Halia caters to vegetarian eaters with their innovative dishes. The Mushroom, Lentil & Walnut Bake ($24) was absolutely delicious and even this meat eater was sold. It was nutty, cheesy, savory and sweet with the fennel seed cream and sun dried tomato. I would order this again.As you can tell, the Halia offers a wide variety for brunch and i found it quite perfect for group gatherings. Enjoy!

address: 1 Beach Rd #01-22/23 Raffles Hotel Singapore 189673 Singapore
comment: Halia is AWESOME. Service is excellent and prices are fair for what it's worth ($50-60 pp with no alcohol, although we did order bottled water).Do order the cod fish.1 star off because the foie gras salad was bordering on saccharine.. had it been infused with different flavors I would probably have been more excited.

address: 1 Beach Rd #01-22/23 Raffles Hotel Singapore 189673 Singapore
comment: Ok so this isn't going to be the sunshiny review everyone seems to give Halia. I want to love the place - I mean, I really love the Botanic Gardens. I think what we have here in Singapore are some of the most beautiful - and I've been to many around the world. So, back to the review. Despite my genuine desire to enjoy Halia (over the years I've come back occasionally - each time telling myself not to bother after the dining experience), this last time was no different. Service was warm and helpful, and that was probably the only positive thing. My husband and I ordered a potato and leek soup, burger, and 62' egg on brioche (which sounded so sexy but was anything but). 15 mins after our mains arrived, the soup came -  it was brown, and tasted watered down and nothing like leek or potato. When we asked to return it, we were told it's homemade and definitely leek and potato. We said erm no.The mains, despite the wonderful descriptions on the menu, were underwhelming at best. Fries were anemic (you know, when they don't spend enough one in the deep fryer), beef patty dry (wagyu? Really?), and my egg dish was lackluster. It as as if the chef was rushing off somewhere. So I get that it's a lovely place in the loveliest of gardens. And like most food joints in attractions (or airports), you know people will come regardless. But for the prices Halia commands, I'd have loved if they had a wee bit more pride about the food.

address: 1 Beach Rd #01-22/23 Raffles Hotel Singapore 189673 Singapore
comment: I like this place and have eaten here several times. The service is attentive, informal and really good. In terms of decor, it's a but dark (I guess that's in keeping with the Colonial feel of the Raffles complex) with heavy timber furniture, but it has windows all around to break up the mood a bit. The chef's soup is good, as is the bread basket. I particularly enjoy the Grilled Chicken Salad. Cocktails are good too. I'd come back again, no problem at all. Thanks.

address: 1 Beach Rd #01-22/23 Raffles Hotel Singapore 189673 Singapore
comment: really good food at this second branch of the halia-of-botanics at the wonderfully colonial raffles hotel. this place was impressive - and while it wasn't cheap, I dare say it was rather well worth it. friendly service, a quiet corner of the hotel, and retro furnishings (very appropriately so, and hence not too hipster) - and good food plus reasonable prices: I think this beats many of my recent gastroventures clear out the water. fine dining without poncy starched-up nonsense.the chef's soup of the day was a great start - a lightly truffled bowl of cauliflower puree. our middle courses carried the momentum of the great start: we were very pleasantly surprised by the beautifully arranged plates of cured kingfish and sous vide chicken leg. the flavors were intense but complementary; and the chicken might be one of the best executions of poultry I've had in a while. the skin was well-seasoned, the butternut squash a sweet counternote to the savoury dish - and really a feast for the eyes.their desserts were also really good. that makes it a winner from starter to fin - something that happens too infrequently. the sticky toffee was good - warm, with a slight drizzle of caramel sauce and topped with creamy vanilla-bean ice cream.the ginger nougat parfait was very interesting. almost like a room-temperatureish semifreddo, with a stick of puff pastry and grilled pineapple. it really is a lovely space - it might feel a little cramped if full house, but otherwise quiet and very cosy on a sunday. service was well-paced and unobtrusive, and so many things on the menu that I want to return to. one of the best meals I've had recently, from start to finish. wholly and unconditionally recommended.

address: 1 Beach Rd #01-22/23 Raffles Hotel Singapore 189673 Singapore
