Where is the responsible service of alcohol? I paid for a bottle, but that seems irresponsible when you are selling 2L beer towers, cocktails and other alcoholic beverages. The free wifi had a weak signal and apps wouldn't load quickly or stay connected. Our meal came to $71.70. It was over priced for average food and below average service. When we went to pay, the girl looked at us continued what she was doing and then left the counter. She came back, we got our bill and paid for it, (no how was your meal? Or any other general chatter or conversation) and then she walked away. I waiting for my change. We weren't sure if she was coming back or if she thought it was a tip. After awhile she came back and handed our change to us and walked off. I'd recommend spending your money else where along Clark Quay, there's many other places.

Even after a couple of days of traveling thru Asia and yearning for a burger, we found it a disappointment.  Ordered medium , it arrived extra well done with no flavor.  Service was slow and not friendly.  Beware, soft drink refills are $5. Not the right representation of this brand.  Great location that could use an improvement.

We'd never been to a hooters before and thought we'd give it a go. Great location and great aircon. Service isn't too bad. The place was clean and inviting. Food portions area good size and were tasty enough. Hooters is a great affordable option if you are after some western food in Singapore. I had the chicken strips the first time we visited and an All The Way burger the second time. Both were basic but yummy enough and hit the spot after a lot by day exploring Singapore.

Poor terrible bad service! Waited for 15 minutes before someone came and asked for a drink order. This is not your typical hooters not to much hoot going on at this location if you know what I mean. Better options in Clarke quay.

So, I just got my dependent's pass. (Hooray for now being a legal local resident!) To celebrate being an American in Singapore, I decided to make a beeline from the Ministry of Manpower to one of Singapore's "American concept restaurants"- Hooters. BECAUSE I'M AWESOME LIKE THAT ERMAGERD DON'T JUDGE ME.This Hooters is very well situated in Clarke Quay, and is probably tourist infested at night. Lunch in the middle of the week is pretty quiet, though. I looked through their lunch specials but I just thought they were weird. I know they have to cater to the local crowd, but a part of me thinks it's strange to order prawn spaghetti from Hooters, of all places. But if you like that stuff, you're in luck, as $10 will get you an entree, soft drink and ice cream. And if you want beer with that, it will only be an extra $5!I was craving their wings so I ordered 10 of 'em. Still as good as I remembered it. And to remind myself I'm in Singapore, I made sure to have a Tiger beer to go along with it.The girls are cute, all Asian (of course) and none of them have muffin tops. So that's cool.Hooters SG, you're a-ok in my book. :)

Fried pickles. I am seriously addicted. So many times I have walked past Hooters at Clark Quay, and each time its the same slightly sleazy and uncomfortable impression that we get from the voluptuous ladies wearing neon orange hot pants. But a friend who is one of the most demure people I know told me to give the fried pickles a try, so I finally did once as a before-beer-snack. HOOKED. Perfectly hot salty and crispy bite-sized pieces, with a juicy sliced pickle encased inside. There isn't any tangy taste like those we scrape out from our cheeseburgers, but there is still the unmistakable pickled cucumber taste. Goes perfect with an Erdinger and soccer on the TVs! Many happy and contented night has since been spent at Hooters with the boyfriend cheering for our team. Do try their Buffalo Wings too! Comes in a range of spiciness levels, but we recommend the Hot. Just don't inhale too close to the fumes, they add vinegar to the batter sauce - a potent mix!

I was walking around the area when I ran into Hooters.  It is not quite what I expected to see.  I was not sure how this American concept would take flight in Asia.  I decided to give it a try.  The inside looks like many of Hooter restaurant I have been all over the US.   The chicken wings, the staples of Hooters, were OK.  It did not remind me of home.  Service was OK but I have learned that it can be hit or miss depending on time of day, how busy it is, and how rowdy the crowd is.  I am not sure if I would go back as there other places I would rather eat at if I was this far away from home.

I had some friends take me to Hooters restaurants in the US a couple of times, and the wings were all the rage - seriously folks, people were eating them like they were just told that chicken wings would no longer exist after tomorrow.Then I came home to our sunny little island, and while Hooters had been here a while, I never had the inclination to go, but when my then boss said he'd buy us lunch there, I was quietly excited... for the wings (yes, I can be serious about my wings).We get there, and everyone gets a super affordable set lunch (12 bucks for apps, a  main and a coffee/tea), and I get... wings. People gave me the looks they reserve for smelly hobos on trains, but hey. These were Hooters wings we're talking about.Post consumption of wings, I was a little non-plussed. Them wings were wayyyy better in those US stores; perhaps I had brought home unrealistic (inflated?) expectations - I'd remembered seeing Hooters differently. Maybe the beer goggles helped.

The food is pretty much the same as any other Hooters - good beer selection, fried pickles are great, and the wings are good (although they seem to be a bit skinnier than in the US).  Speaking of skinny, there is also just a bit of a difference in the staff between the Hooters in Singapore, and one of the locations such as Atlanta, GA or other southern US states.  Must be something in the water...

Cold Beer by the riverside.  Pretty good chicken wings. Tiny orange short shorts. What's not to like?If yer looking for gourmet, this ain't the place.  Keep your expectations realistic, and you'll have a good time.

Food was ok, not good. But when I asked to swap a potato salad for French fries on a Ham&cheese sandwich I was told not possible as French fries is a side order. They are booth potatoes. One is dip fried and the other has mayo. What is the big deal? Very poor customer service on my book. Won't be coming back.

We had lunch there today. The non-local girl who served us are in shorts and sleeveless top. She was friendly and serve us with a smile. We had the lunch promotion with additional top up with S$2+ to get a tea/coffee and ice cream. Another non local girl served us, who is wearing a white tshirt with jeans, was a tad unfriendly with a little attitude. As she served our ice cream, one of the cup slip and the ice cream fall on the tray. She pick it up and put a side. Then we told her we want the ice cream to be take-away. She then left the ice cream at the counter outside the outdoor (as we were seated outside) and went to the kitchen to pick up the container. Then when she came out, I approach her and asked if she is changing the ice cream since was it fell on the tray, she replied "THE TRAY IS CLEAN". And I said, yes but it fall on the tray and it is unhygienic. She kept repeating "but the tray is CLEAN". I demand her to change 3x before she bring the ice cream into the kitchen unwillingly. First of all, she left the ice cream outdoor and went to the kitchen to pick up the container and intend to put our ice cream into the container outside is already not so right. The ice cream is melting outside while she takes her time to the kitchen and come back. 2nd she accidentally drop the ice cream, the tray may be clean, but shouldn't she change a new one since it was her fault? And how we know how clean is the tray? Excuse me, we pay for the service charge, is the way how the food should be treated?

I was out with a bunch of boys one evening and they were pretty psyched about checking Hooters out. Being the only girl and totally outnumbered, I went along. We were greeted by waitresses in low cut tops and short shorts (hence its name). They were surprisingly rude and snappy and according to my guy friends (not very hooter material).We got chicken wings, curly fries and fried pickles to share. The chicken wings are their specialty but they were nothing spectacular. They were tasty but there was no punch to it that made any of us go "wow". Their curly fries were not great either, and you can probably get the same thing frozen from the supermarket. Their fried pickles, however were pretty awesome! Its surprisingly addictive and was not as sour as I thought it would be. Overall, the food and service there is not great but if you happen to drop by hooters, do not miss out on their fried pickles!

Hot. Naked. Chicks.This was how I was taught to order buffalo wings at Hooters. What this refers to is the level of heat (hot: not that spicy lah) and the thickness of batter (naked: not very much at all). We like a mixture of wings and drumlets, but your preference might differ. That's pretty much all I eat at Hooters, really, those and the deep fried pickle chips. Strange before I ever tried one, but they really are addictive. They also do set lunches for the office crowd, but it feels a bit wrong that a place known for their wings don't put them on the set lunch menu?

In conservative Singapore a "Hooters"... this must go wrong. While other Hooters can point on the "view", this one has only the same rubbish, overprized food as any cheap, downtown Burger spot. Service is not great either. There is nothing more to say and there are better choices just few meters away

The girls aside, hooter's does serve some tasty drumlets and wings. It depends though how you like your buffalo wings. If you're a fan of the barbequed ones, this one's not for you. Hooter's wings are deep fried and lathered with a tangy buffalo sauce. You can get blue cheese dressing (my favourite) as your dip. It's pretty pricey for such wings but sometimes when you have the kind of craving that makes the corners of your mouth sweat for some spicy tangy buffalo wings, you can't go wrong with hooter's.They have set lunches that go from as low as $10 for a main course, drink and a scoop of ice-cream. But having lunch here is a vastly different ambience from having dinner in the evening. It's quieter and much less crowded, all the more to enjoy your food!

I remember coming here when I was a kid with my dad and his co workers. I was not sure how Singaporeans would take this American idea of scantly clad women in tacky orange and white uniforms. Lets be honest here...nothing is spicy as we would like it to be compared to normal Singaporean fare. If anything it is to experience beer and wings while watching sports on TV. Then, later on ask yourself, "wah lao, this is how Americans spend time watching sports? no wonder why they are so big". Just enjoy some good fried food and cold beer. Also, enjoy the ladies hitting on your and flirting as they are required to. One time I was there an a Saturday night. there was a contest involving strapping a dart board to my butt and someone tries to hit a bulls eye for free beer. Best time ever. We did not win but we did get a hula hoop contest for a free pint as consolation. Oh, those were the good old days. A big plus is the eating by the river. that is nice...
The most expencive Hooters Ive been to..Not real big hooters in singapore..Still had fun
Great fried ice-cream. Friendly service.

love their spicy wings and their oyster.  its my to go to restaurant when i visit singapore. their steak and chips r also delish. love their vodka soda also but a little expensive. overall, will go there again on our next visit :)

Din Tai Fung is tourist, expat, and family friendly.  This is hands down the best dim sum I have had while in country.  The group I was with were a combination of meat and non-meat eaters who were pleasantly surprised by the number of dim sum offerings Din Tai Fung creates.  I have been to a few dim sum restaurants in the United States and they paled in comparison to the efficiency and attentiveness of the staff here.  They even provided "bag holders" to put our back packs into so they would not be dirtied by the restaurant floor.  I will definitely come back the next time I am in Singapore.

I was told this is the place for dumps, and I can agree. Since i was dining alone, i was only able to order one type of dumplings, the XLB or soup dumplings. I do wish they offered smaller portions, so i could try more flavors! But perfect outer skin and inner soup. They also offer a few spicy seasonings to add to your liking. I think it was a little too expensive for what you get, but I guess it's because the name.ALSO: if you want a sweet, refreshing drink- get the iced roselle tea. I believe it's a type of hibiscus, but it was perfectly paired with the steamy dumplings.

I've avoided Din Tai Fung for years, wary of the wait, the prices and the hype. I was pleasantly surprised! I arrived early, so there was basically no wait. The food came quickly. The XLB were perfect -- thin skin and plenty of soup. The duck pastry was just okay. I was a little disappointed with the ambiance, which felt like a cheap Chinese restaurant from the 90s. Make sure to check your credit card receipt before you leave. As in most places in Singapore, the cashier manually enters the amount of your check into the machine. This time, she accidentally keyed in a 5 in place of a 2, overcharging me by 30 SGD, which I then had to dispute with my credit card company.
A really great place to enjoy a good dim-sum meal with a friend.A little pricey but service is really great. Very attentive staff. Great food as well.

Excellent service & delicious food. We decided to pop in for some dumplings as there was no line, a rare occupancy if you've ever been pass a Din Tai Fung. We ordered wan tans in black vinegar and chilli oil - these were filled with flavour, I think these were the best wantans I've ever had. We of course ordered xiao long Bao which were as expected, delicious. The pork baos were great too and the sui mai was beautifully presented with a shrimp on top of each one. The service was attentive. The waitresses filled up our tea after every couple of sips. I would definitely recommend this Din Tai Fung. Arriving early will save you lining up too!

I first discovered Din Tai Fung in Bellevue, Washington (US) and I really liked their dumplings and wontons. It's very hard to eat Din Tai Fung in the United States since there are like no chains, but in Singapore there were at least two in a one mile radius or so!This one is in a shopping center with multiple levels.The waitstaff mostly speaks Chinese but they can speak English too.The menu is not much different from the one in Bellevue. We got the xiao long bao and the spicy chili wontons. The xiao long bao tasted like what I expected. The chili wonton sauce looked a bit different from the ones I was expecting but they were still good!

I'm visiting Singapore from Los Angeles and had seen an advert for this restaurant a few days before, i arrived. The food looks and taste like Westernized chinese food, good but bland. The type of food almost everyone can enjoy...I forgot to mention I was charged .50 cents for a glass of tap water, even though I had ordered a coke..

Well had the off chance looking for ozone of my favorite dim sum restaurants I experienced in Taiwan.Was super happy they have multiple locations in Singapore. One was just a short walk from my hotel in China town. Located in the shopping center right near Chinatown MRT station.I placed my order for Steamed pork and vegetable dumplings, a set of 10.A set of 10 pork and shrimp shumai,Wonton pork and shrimp soup.Egg fried rice and jasmine tea.Also had a frozen mango pudding!!The service is as fast as expected. Since the cooks make the dumplings fresh for each order. The waiters bring each part of the order as they come from the kitchen. I'm glad I came on a weekday. Weekends can be a long time waiting for a seat. This chain Resturant is very popular and often has full booking.The price is average for the meal and I don't mind the price for the quality of meal I received.Totally recommend This Resturant for the Dim sum hunter!!!

I went to this Din Tai Fung twice within 6 hours...AsiaOne polled fans for favourite brands, and Banana Leaf Apolo and DIn Tai Fung made the list for 2013 Best Asian and Best Chinese respectively. stasiareport.com/premium…  Today I had 2 hours free from client obligations, so I made a dash to Banana Leaf Apolo for lunch and then stopped at this Din Tai Fung right before dinner, though not hungry at all.  I didn't order the famous juicy pork xiao long baos.  While walking back to the hotel, I felt that it would be remiss not to have eaten the xiao long baos, so rather than living with regret for the next 12 months, decided to come back at 9pm after dinner.  I could have had Din Tai Fung in Taipei two days ago at the location where Tom Cruise learned to make the juicy pork dumplings with the owner...but I was staying too far away from the city.  Here's the newspaper clipping that this DTF displayed.  yelp.com/biz_photos/din-…The fare is as expected.  The menu offerings are pretty similar to the other DTFs in Singapore.  Here, instead of a busboy or wait staff dropping off orders on the table, someone from the kitchen will come out with several tables' orders and deliver directly.  It's smart since the risk of miscommunication (orders to the wrong table, etc) would be next to nil.Service is friendly though not forgiving.  They don't call the xiao long baos "juicy pork dumplings" as they do in the states.  Simplified Chinese characters, conducive to Singapore, is my pet peeve so if you can't read, be sure to match up the item number from the menu with the item number on the order form.  A lot of the dumplings sound similar in their English descriptions but are different things entirely.When the dumplings arrived, I was disappointed in myself.  I ordered the wrong thing that cost more, compared to the xiao long baos.  I had made a special trip tonight to eat dinner #2, so I asked the waiter if I can just pay the price of the more expensive dumplings and get the XLBs instead but he said no, so looks like once the bamboo basket hits your table, the sale is final.  What to order here?Oriental Wanton with Black Vinegar and Chili Oil:  In Los Angeles, these are called "Vegetable and pork wonton in spicy sauce."  The sauce itself is the most delicious part.  Order a bowl of white rice or something and eat that sauce!Vegetable and Pork Dumplings: Looks like these also have 18 folds and a little bit of soup inside.  I used the tableside chili for additional taste.Steamed Pork and Chili Crab bun:  Just set aside S$50 and eat a real Chili Crab instead.  Last year at the DTF Marina Bay Sands, they ran out of these and I was :( not being able to try one, but turns out I was :( for nothing.Steamed Pork Dumpling: In Los Angeles, these are aptly named Juicy Pork Dumpling and these are what made Din Tai Fung famous.  Just make sure you order one of these (despite people saying these are overrated)  so you won't regret not doing it and have to come back in 6 hours to eat dinner #2 before saying goodbye to Singapore!

Giving it 4 stars because of its uniqueness and quality. The food was great but because of friends I know who have came to this restaurant I expected more than great . Anyway try the dumplings. I've had better tasting dumplings but theirs is mellow tasting and have that curiosity with it. It tasted like a lot of effort made into one dumpling. Once you bite into it expect a lot of juice from it. Also try the black sesame type dessert. Now this one was my favorite.  I won't mind recommending this restaurant to my friends. Heads up though. Prices here aren't that cheap. I paid around over $100 for four people for dinner.

I really enjoyed their starter salad. It's got bits of tau gwa, vermicelli and seaweed and their special sauce. They also have very nice xiao long bao of course. Soft skins and juicy, tasty pork fillings. In terms of lamian, I enjoyed their chill sauce tossed one. What caught me unaware was their beef brisket lamian soup, my uncle ordered that and I thought I'll just try it. Wow! The beef chunks were so soft and tasty!! The soup broth was also hearty and flavourful! Totally enjoyable!Overall awesome meal!!!

Din Tai Fung@Chinatown Point. I'm a huge fan of their original dumplings. No idea if you guys know that if you find any broken dumplings upon arrival, they will gift you another serving of dumplings (FOR FREE, YAY!).Pork cutlet fried rice is my favorite too! If you look closely, you can see that each rice is wrapped nicely with the egg scrambled in.Another recommendation is the earl grey iced tea. PLEASE, PLEASE, ORDER THIS DRINK whenever you are there. You will never regret it. Word. Really, lah! It gives your ordinary earl grey/lemon tea a very refreshing twist. I'm going to keep you in suspense here of how it looks like, because I want you to feel the same happiness as I would whenever I order this. I have never had the same drink in any other restaurants.This is the place I A-L-W-A-Y-S bring my co-workers (who mainly come from the states or Europe) here at this outlet because 1) it is near our office, and 2) less crowded. Come on, you do know that DTF is so crowded during lunch and dinner hours right? Hate the crowd? This is the SECRET place. You know I know okay!Did not give five stars because the service hasn't been that attentive. It will take a bit longer for the staff to notice you, and this has been consistent. Hence, four stars.So.... manage your expectations for the speed of service!

This was my least favorite branch of the famous dumpling chain.  The food was good and consistent with other locations, but the atmosphere and service felt flat.  There's a more robust location in the suntec center.
The steamed pork dumplings oh my god.  Divine.  I probably looked like a idiot shoving them in my mouth.  Also loved the spicy cucumber dish....was very tangy and tasty!

I once naively thought that all Din Tai Fungs were created equal.I now know better. This branch does not have the truffle xiao long bao (which is awesome and you should totally try it if you haven't).It does do everything else as you'd expect of a Din Tai Fung, and admittedly it's less crowded than most of the other branches, but not having one of my staple menu items does mean it's generally just not as good as most Din Tai Fung branches in my eyes.

I was looking forward to some great dumplings but was fairly disappointed - the chicken were flavorless and the prawn and pork only slightly better. Service was quick and we were in and out in a flash, sadly the good was nothing to write home about.

My go-to comfort spot for xiao long bao. I find this outlet to always have available spots, so there's never any of the dreaded wait as there typically are in other outlets around Singapore (and, actually, around the world if you think about it). Their fried rice is very good too, as are many other of their dishes. While you might be tempted to chomp down an entire 10 piece order of the xiao long bao, do save some space for some of their other dishes. I always find it a bit pricier than Paradise Dynasty, but it's never anything too scandalous (for Singapore, anyways). Also, while you're there, why not enjoy a nice Taiwan Beer?

The Steamed pork dumplings or xiao long baos are really fantastic here. Add some black vinegar + ginger as a condiment and they make a delicious, juicy mouthful.My office-mates either loved or hated it and those that hated it did so mainly because of the price. Their argument is that you can get as good a quality food from the hawker store nearby, and that is true. But for something different Din Tai Fung is a nice option.

I am not really a fan of Xiao long bao. but sister's bf is picky on food... a plate of duck spring roll is expensive... I can get a plate of duck for the same price but I get duck. Din Tai Fung only give me 6 tiny slice of duck.

This is a very fine burger masterfully prepared.The best meat in the world chargrilled, with cheese and without any additional fuss except for tartare sauce below and 2 brush strike of bbq sauce on top

Across from our hotel, Park Hotel, Clarke Quay. We arrived late and were looking for someplace to eat. Originally we tried to eat at what we later found out was their sister restaurant, Japanese BBQ around the corner. It was fully booked for the night. A rather small dark an intimate place with an opened kitchen in the middle. They grill over a small charcoal grill in the front of the kitchen. I started with burrata and tomatoes. It was one large piece of burrata in the middle over arugula also know as rocket. There were small cherry tomato sliced in half with a pesto sauce lightly poured on top. Very good but not as creamy as I am used to.For entrees, my wife ordered the waygu burger with red cheddar cheese. It was served with fries. GoodI had the 100 gram sirloin,Waygu beef that was sliced and melted in your mouth. Served a little arugula on the plate. Both dishes were accompanied by different home made steak sauces. Both were very good but I preferred the one fir the sirloin.Obviously a place frequented by the locals.Not inexpensive but definitely worth the price. They have a very nice wine list but I was tired so I just had a glass of Shiraz,

Masa is a premium Japanese steak house. It's owned by the same group that operates the yakiniku restaurant Yazawa just beside it. Despite that fact, previously you couldn't order dishes from each other. They recently omit this rule though, so you can enjoy the best of both world.I have to say that steak is a dish that shouldn't be too complicated, that should simply be just good beef, cooked simply to perfection. And Masa achieves just that.However, I am simply not a fan of Japanese steak. I'm a pretty heavy eater, but even for me the steak is simply too fatty & marbly. At first visit, I ordered the ribeye (my favorite cut) and I just feel so cloy ('jelat') after finishing the whole thing. I can't fault Masa for it though, because they cooked it well. It's just the kind of food that doesn't suit me.But I still visited the place a second time, because a friend gave me a tip that I should order the chateaubriand, which is a special cut of the tenderloin or something. (Google it) Normally, I would never in my wildest dream order that cut. Tenderloin is known for its tenderness, but it's lacking on marbling and fat. However, in a Japanese beef, the tenderness is retained while still possessing just the right amount of marble-ness. The result was outstanding, probably one of the best Japanese-style steaks you can have anywhere in the world.I don't usually care about price, but I have to take 1 star from Yazawa here because I think it's ridiculously expensive. The chateaubriand was just 150 or 200 grams (can't remember) and it costs $200++. You should still try it at least once in a lifetime though.

The good:  Mouth watering hamburger with tasty rice and sauce to boot. One night I got ambitious and ordered the streak, top 5 all time. Yes, that good.  Comes pre-cut so you can use chop sticks.  Comes with a small side of seasoning, but honestly speaking it doesn't need it.  Melts in your mouth.  Staff is friendly and attentive, and I think by now they recognize me but I can't tell for sure because they show everyone the same amount of attention and respect.  If you feel like drinking you can also visit Orihara Shoten next door for some top notch sake.     The bad:  Price is high, and other items on the menu are just above average.  Never had a bad dish, but I have high expectations when a premium is charged.  The ugly:  The atmosphere/decor is lacking.  It's made up of high booth seats and a private room to the side.  The kitchen is glass, but you can't really see from your seat, only when you're walking in/out.  I prefer the setup at Fat Cow, so I wish Masa would revamp to make it more open and friendly to smaller groups.  If it did, this place could be a homerun, but for now it's just a go-to for mind blowing beef.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01b Merchant Court Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: We had:Oysters juicy and fresh and good sized for $2.50Salmon (2 horizontal pieces on a stick make one order at $2.50) also juicyAji mackerel $1.50 we loved it and ordered more.Bacon cheese.. Ok for me. Nothing exciting.Lotus root - nice crunch and bite $1Sweet potato was steaming moist and small but only $1Onion a big half onion and great buy. Still had some crunch to the onion $1Banana served with hersheys chocolate syrup $1.50 a big goreng pisang sized portion as a finisher.Garlic 4 on a stick was soft like roasted garlic! Unlimited fresh cabbage to dip. Everything served crisp and hot and juicy and we found it quite satisfying if nothing fancy. But it's so much cheaper than other places with the fancy but minute toppings. But they don't serve water free, you have to buy a bottle for $5. Sake is 140ml at $9 and it's good quality for the price. Not harsh, quite smooth (we had it hot).

address: 3C River Valley Rd #01-02/03 The Cannery Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: We were surprised. This place was recommended by the concierge and when we arrived at the door we thought it was the wrong place. The downstairs was common in ambiance. The upstairs was nicer. I can't say it was upscale but the food and service were good.The menu was extensive and very descriptive which made it difficult to choose a dish they all looked great. I had the salt egg crab which was phenomenal and a lobster dish. The portions were great and the food delicious. Definitely a place to have confidence in having a good meal.

address: 3C River Valley Rd #01-02/03 The Cannery Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: Blackened Pepper Lobster was absolutely delicious.  Succulent and fresh with a spicy flair to their seasoning. I'm usually not a fan of Lobster but this restaurant knows how to prepare it right! The crab fried rice was so good. I didnt appreciate the bits of crab shell in the rice but hey, I guess that's fresh right? It didn't ruin the taste of the fried rice, I'll tell ya that, but it was just unnecessary, in my opinion. This restaurant seems popular with locals, not a touristy spot. We were definitely the only tourists here during our lunch visit. Reservations are suggested but since we walked in and they weren't as busy, we were able to get a seat. Bathrooms are not air conditioned so be prepared to leave the A/C restaurant and step in to a humid hallway leading to the single stall restrooms. Ambience is similar to typical Chinese Seafood restaurants,  there isn't anything that would make this place upscale but their seafood is definitely worth it. We were very happy with our meals. Not a cheap restaurant by any means, but the food is quite good. The rest is what it is.

address: 3C River Valley Rd #01-02/03 The Cannery Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: This Clark Quay location of Red House Seafood just recently opened it's doors.  Red House Seafood has been a local favorite since 1976.  The menu focuses on Asian seafood dishes and Singaporean flavors.  The portions are large and meant to share with the table.  This is the best spot to get the famous Singaporean Chilli Crab.  They have bottle purchases of wine and liquor, but no cocktail menu.  The wine selection is OK.  It is recommended to get a reservation.I came here with a large group and we were seated in a neat personal room in the back with a large round table that had a  Lazy Susan.  The Lazy Susan made it easy to turn and pass the dishes around the room.  We shared numerous vegetable, beef, and crab dishes amongst the group. Everything was delicious.  Cooked to perfection, and tasted fresh. I loved the steamed vegetables and the sweet buns.  Be ready to make a mess.  You are given a bib, hand wipes, and a hand bowl for a reason!  The Chilli Crab was amazing.  The servers will help you crack the crab if needed, but they also provide the utensils for you to do it yourself.  We also had the steamed and pepper crab.  The pepper crab was incredible.  I loved the pepper crab even more than the Chilli Crab. Although the Chilli Crab sauce tasted the best on the rice they served us.  The beef vegetable dish was also yummy and full of flavor.As always the prices at nice dining establishments in Singapore adds up fast.  Especially when you add the liquor costs in.  The service here was incredibly friendly and prompt.  Great dining experience with amazing food.

address: 3C River Valley Rd #01-02/03 The Cannery Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: The restaurant was located just next to the taxi stand. It looked rather small at the first floor with just about 9 tables of 4. The ground floor was mostly catered to walk in customers, where upstairs with personal room were for reservations. For lunch time, where most of the surrounding restaurants were still yet to open for business, the place was packed, especially with tourists. One could see tour guide bringing in tourists in for lunch. For lunch, the restaurant offered a limited selection of dim sum on top of the usual menu. Currently the place was having a 20% discount for dim sum. As for most Chinese restaurants in Singapore which practise charging for wet tissue and peanuts, here charged S$1.80++/ per person for hot tea(refillable) and wet tissue, and S$3++ for peanut. Lotus Leaf Glutinous Rice (S$6++/2 pieces)Small in size, but it was packed with minced meat and salted egg yolk inside. The rice was not too mushy. Nice to go with a touch of chilli sauce.Truffle Wild Mushroom Dumplings (S$6++/ 3 pieces)It smell not bad of truffle from far. The chewy skin was not too thick and inside it was packed with savoury minced mushroom.Steamed Rice Roll with Shrimp (S$7++)It tasted not bad although one wished that there was more sauce.

address: 3C River Valley Rd #01-02/03 The Cannery Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: Fair prices, decent seafood. Their black pepper crab is particularly good. A lot less-crowded than some of the more tourist-y seafood joints in SG like Nosignboard (way overrated) or Jumbo.

address: 3C River Valley Rd #01-02/03 The Cannery Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: TOP notch seafood! Be blown away by their crab dishes! Particularly enjoyed the uni with jap chae noodles! Can't wait to be back again!

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: If you're thinking that only in Japan you can satisfy your yakiniku cravings, then freight not! Yazawa is easily the number one spot in Singapore to satisfy your yakiniku cravings. Although its abit pricey, the quality of the beef easily makes up for the cost. YES, it is that worth it and YES, it is THAT good. Never did I expect to eat yakiniku of this quality in Singapore. It's just as good as the ones in Japan. Worth to go during special occasions and a definite must try.My family of 3 paid about 160 per pax for about 7 different servings of beef together with one soup and a salad. Trust me, it is not recommended that you order too much meat, as the meat is very savory and will get very 'gelat' if too much of it is eaten. Aim to order about 120-130 per pax. Food such as this is best enjoyed in smaller quantities.I highly recommend ordering the wagyu steak and at least 2 servings of it. Its easily the best dish of meat you can get there. The level of marbling on the steak is truly amazing. The words 'it literally melts in your mouth' holds very true here. The last time i had such an experience was with fatty tuna belly in Tuskiji fish market all the way in japan. Aside from that, the dish i recommend would be my personal favorite, ox tongue! The meat is both chewy and soft at the same time, giving it a unique texture which i really enjoy.

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Come for the beef, stay for the beef+  The beef. Insanely good cuts of premium Japanese beef+  Cold noodles with chicken broth, assorted pickles+  Open late, enjoy after some drinks out around Robertson-  Dark, kind of old dingy looking place-  Service not great, a few grumbles when asking for help -  At the high end price wiseWould go back, maybe twice a year? Very speciality selection for when you need that premium high end steak experience.

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Probably the awesome reviews here on Yelp set a high expectation. In short, good food (not great), horrible service, and loud ambience. The started off on the wrong foot. We got there right at the time of our reservation, we were asked to wait, and after some time we are told that because they have too many reservations they are giving us a table in their other restaurant next door (Masa) where we could order of of their menu. We go to the place next door, and again we are asked to wait. This time, slight better, because they invite us to seat at the bar to wait... The bar attendant stares at us and ignores us... Even after we greet her. Guess what we want, you genius?  Ask yourself what do people at the bar usually do... Manage to order two beers somehow. We are seated. The table setup is awkward. It's one of those typical, nice Japanese private booth. But it split in two right in the middle with a flimsy curtain, which lets you see through some and lets you hear everything happening at the other side or the table--not hard, since they are seating inches from you...The appetizers are typical Japanese, but ruined by some Chinese influence.  For example, classic Japanese chilled tofu with soy, and addition of deep fried onion on top, just to mention one. The meat is awesome, and that's the only reason to come to this place. Not cheap, definitely.  Everything, but the meat, will take ages, so be prepared...

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: The restaurant was full and we had to wait for out reserved table and were seated at Masa instead.  The seating was cramped and the ambience was bad. Felt like we had the bait and switch.  I would have left ASAP if I had to do it all over.  The bbq was good but pricy. The soup was very small.  Had the oxtail soup which was good but had almost no meat in it, just some turnips. Overall not very good experience.  Would not go back again.  My friend left before we were finished as she couldn't stand the space and slow pace.

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: So a friend brought me here because she said it was the best place to have beef.... and oh boy was she right.Just you know, this place is expensive. It's as expensive as having a meal at Cut or Mortons. But I have to say that the quality is just as good or even better. Yakiniku they call it - this was my first time having it. I ordered the Yukke to share as appetiser. Aesthetically it is an automatically eye pleaser! It's hard not to whip out your hp just to take a picture of this beauty! It's raw marinated beef with a perfect yolk in the centre. It tasted very fresh and was the gateway for more great things to come! At this point of time we started to get even more hungry! The waitress was pretty helpful and patient in explaining and recommending the different cuts for us. In the end we settled for Zabuton (short rib), Jo Kalbi, Tenderloin, and beef tongue. I'll admit it.. I enjoyed them all! I love beef. The colours of the marbling even before it's cooked is enough to send you to cloud 9! As you place it on the grill for only a few seconds, you can see how the fat bubbles off the meat and melts and cooks so evenly! BOOM. It's like heaven in your mouth. Being a guy, I also need my rice! And the rice here for 3bucks a bowl was definitely worth mentioning. Good quality indeed!The waitress will also come by quite a number of time to change your grill to a new one too! Very impressed with that! Being my first time here with really good meat, I didn't try much of the sauces as I really wanted to take in all that bovine goodness! But I can tell you that even if you used any... U really didn't need to use any of the condiments much at all! If it weren't so expensive... Id give it a full 5stars! But I can at least see why it costs so much. I think maybe I've found a new place to come to instead of the usual Cut or Mortons if I'm craving really high quality steak. Definitely not a place you'd come every other month for people like me but if you enjoy your beef or wanna impress a chick who loves beef for her birthday or a special occasion... THIS WILL NOT DISAPPOINT! HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!Oh and I just remember one slight grievance... They do tend to seem like they're rushing you out a bit the minute u finish everything and don't seem to be ordering anymore. I think they could improve a bit more on that to try to at least be a little more discreet given that I spent practically $200 per person in the span of under 90mins!

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: We came here for dinner on a sunday night, place is not too busy.  We ordered the kabuton, tongue, karubi and the pork collar.  We liked the kabuton, tongue and pork collar.

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Try the thin slice rib-shin.  You will never want to eat anything else ... ever.  Amazing.

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: ever had that inspiration to immediately start writing a review when you are still dining at a restaurant?my yakiniku yazawa experience was just that!call it first time first love.but i'm sure this place will stand the test of time in our relationship.service was really attentive and they actually anticipated your needs even before you ask for it.a pair of scissors magically appeared when they saw that we were struggling to cut them udon with fork and spoon.quick presentation of food upon ordering and quick clearing of empty plates as and when the moment presents itself.clear explanation of the different cuts also helped a lot in making informed choices. even the chef personally made the rounds to check up on us.for a yakiniku place, it sure is way less smoky than i anticipated.their top notch extraction system is key!as soon as smoke forms at the grill it gets whisked away without even reaching table level.here, smoke never gets in your eyes!the quality of meat is class indeed.the instruction of a recommended mere 5sec grilling per side is testament to how good their meats are.if looks could kill, their raw meats will at the very least get you drooling!pure and simple shio instead of tare seasoning will further maximize your enjoyment of their premium cuts.no kobe here but their wagyu is decadent enough.the japanese wagyu trumped the australian, needless to say.both very well marbled but a more intense taste from the jap.but the price of the jap is also more than double that of the oz.tongue is always a favourite of mine and here it does not disappoint.the japanese wagyu cubed superior cuts of various parts gives more bite and stronger concentration of flavours.ala carte side dishes distracts but at the same time completes your meal here.the gyuniku tataki is a real delightful combination of colour, taste, and texture.the maitake mushrooms, our token vegetable dish, are sweet with just a hint of chilli.and for some strange reason you require carbo fillers, they do a mean hot udon noodles served with stewed wagyu and also a minced wagyu beef japanese style curry rice with sunny side up.no lingering smoky smells but lingering memories remain.can't wait for our second date!:)

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Tried various wagyu and Japanese marbling cut. Not disappointed at all. Highly recommended. Will return for more.

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Great meat for the price.  Australiana wagyu is my favourite as I like a bit of the steaky taste.  Service was excellent and accommodating for kids.  Would definitely go back again.

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Waitress is very rude Typical rude singaporean Wont come back Altho meat was delicious and juicy Not worth it

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Yazawa is a Japanese yakiniku place located in Robertson Quay. It's probably my favorite yakiniku place in Singapore. They serve beef of amazing quality, and great side dishes as well.I usually start with a cold chicken ramen. It's nothing like your usual ramen. The noodles is not the usual yellow egg noodle, but it's some sort of jelly-like, chewy noodle. The broth is light, topped with sesame oil & seeds. And instead of chasiu, you have this sliced chicken thigh instead. The combination sounds weird at first, but it's very refreshing and just arouses your appetite for the beef.As said above, the beef that Yazawa serves are of the highest quality. My favorite cut is the Japanese beef shoulder. It is very rare and you should call the shop days in advance to reserve it. They also have the Australian beef version, and while it's decent, it just won't blow your brain like the Jap version. Other than that, the thick beef tongue is just wonderful.Tbh, the other beef that Yazawa serves is great, but it's just not as good as those 2 cuts I mentioned. But you won't be disappointed with the overall yakiniku experience you'll enjoy in Yazawa.

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Nice small Cute Japanese with Hibachi table grill specialising only in meat (no fish but do have vegetables). Very nice find!

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Our new favourite yakiniku joint.The meats were exquisite, even if the meat-centric menu was decidedly limited. Unlike Aburiya, Gyu Kaku or Ito-Kacho, there isn't a variety of seafood, or vegetables to break up the monotony of regular meats like beef, pork and chicken. Most meats are marinated with tare, or shio. I personally prefer tare seasoning, it's got a little more dimension than just salt & pepper.There's just 2 types of beef, all wagyu of course, of Australian breed, or the in-house proprietary brand Yazawa beef. The Australian wagyu is a little more tempered, whereas the Yazawa beef is extremely marbled. If you prefer your meats with a little more body, I suggest you take the Australian wagyu over the very rich Yazawa beef.Note that there's a 2-seatings for dinner policy, which the service staff will inform about when taking reservations, and/or also while seating u. On the upside: service was akin to a Korean-style barbecue, where u needn't bother with the grilling because the wait staff will be on hand to do so.We had:1) Edamame ($8): ridiculously expensive, but they were fat and juicy, beautifully seasoned with sea salt, and served refreshingly icy.2) Tori Momoniku ($16): bite-sized morsels of juicy chicken thigh marinated in tare sauce. Must-try.3) Mangalica Pork ($22): delicious slivers of chuck roll simply seasoned with shio (salt) & pepper so as not to detract from the natural sweetness of the meat4) Ton Toro ($16): medium-thick cuts of pork neck glazed with tare. These were so awesome, we had like 5 plates between the 3 of us. For sure a cannot-miss.5) Australian Wagyu Jo Kalbi ($28): premium chuck rib cut, steeped in tare. This had a fuller flavour, while exquisite threads of fat lent succulence.6) Yazawa Beef Misuji ($48): an exceptional precious cut at the corner of the shoulder, mostly because it was more fat than meat. This was glorious and indulgent and sinfully rich.7) Yazawa Beef Rump ($46): a smidge more delicate in marbling, so while it was decadent, it wasn't as heart-palpitatingly so

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: My summary: save up before going, and then don't cheap outIt costs a pretty penny to eat well here, but if you are going to dine here, go or the steak cuts. I mean, the slices are nice, but the steak cuts are a whole different level.

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: This is our go-to yakiniku joint when my wife and I have wagyu cravings.   The default wagyu on the menu is Australian, but if you're willing to splurge a bit they also have off-the-menu selections of Japanese wagyu (usually from Iwate). The tongue and cube steaks are good ones to try as well as the "3 second" cuts. The service staff is very helpful and knowledgeable about the cuts, which ones to order and how to cook them. In addition to the melt-in-your-mouth meats, the side dishes are also quite tasty. Our favorites were the Japanese-styled kimchi and the Yazawa (house) salad. The prices aren't cheap, but still reasonably priced given the quality of the meat that is served. All in all a good value and must try for yakiniku aficionados.

address: 11 Unity Street #01-01 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Absolutely fantastic. I loved this place. Me and my wife had a small room for ourselves where we tasted the best meat of our lives so far. thumbs up!

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-14 Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: There is no doubt about it, the Steakhouse serves one of the better steaks in Singapore. Much better value than some of the more high end Steakhouses, but giving little, if anything away in terms of quality. I have not tried their starters, nor have the group I have eaten here with ordered anything except the steak or the lamb. Good selection of steaks both in terms of cut and from USA, Australia and Ireland!  Normally more of a ribeye than a sirloin person, the Irish Grass Fed Sirloin is well worth trying, as are the Grain Fed ribeye. One of our group swears by the Tenderloin.  Sides are good quality, service is pretty good, sometimes a little brusque, but that's a trademark of Singapore service unfortunately. Carnivores should give this a try.  You won't be disappointed.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-14 Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Luckily I didn't come here on my dime. I knew it would be on the expensive side, so I was expecting an amazing steak. Maybe one of the best I've ever had (since I normally don't go to steakhouses).I was split between the Australian Wagyu Ribeye and the Filet Mignon. Since I don't normally see wagyu on menus, I decided to give it a shot. The wagyu special came with "truffle" fries and a wine or beer for $73 ($54 USD). The steak wasn't terrible, but it was on the salty side. I love anything truffle, so I was getting my hopes up on the fries. Unfortunately, these weren't house cut fries, and I couldn't taste any hint of truffle on the fries. If it didn't say it on the menu, I wouldn't have known there was truffle oil on the fries.I finished the meal off with crème brulee, which was on the "meh" side. I've definitely made better crème brulee at home.Wasn't terribly impressed with this place for the price.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-14 Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Rather pricey for the quality of food you get. Had far better steaks for that price in many other steakhouses in Singapore. Location in Clark quay means no restroom facilities, so that's a bummer. Steak knives were huge but not sharp. You'd expect better quality based on the ambience.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-14 Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: We've been there at 20:45.We waited 30 min to get the starter(beef carpaccio and it was not definitely worth to wait) And waited another 30min to get the main courses. (Just a burger and linguini)We were just about to leave before the main course and the waitress told us that they were only 3!!! which is totally unacceptable for this price level restaurants.This was also the case for 2 other tables beside us. The food was ok but very overpriced according to its quality and service provided.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-14 Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: great fillet steak and as expected at a higher prized restaurant, perfectly cooked medium rare. took it classic with butter, salt and pepper but if you wish you can also cover your great meat in blue cheese sauce as so many do. side dishes are good but nothing spectacular. wine list is good, even the house wines. had oysters as starters, also, good quality. oysters, steak with mashed potatoes and 2 glass wine plus martini = 180$

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-14 Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: We visited The Steakhouse on Chinese New Year. Our visit was not the best as the steak was cold and not prepared as requested. The spinach was also cold on delivery.My friend had the Pork Chop and it was prepared nicely as requested, but we had to wait a long time (30 minutes) for the other items to be prepared again. For a fine dining restaurant, this is not acceptable and we will not return. Our bill was $300sg and the staff did not make any adjustment for the long wait while one party was eating and the other was waiting for the food to be prepared again.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-14 Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: For a full review, please visit: urbanjourney.com/food-an…The Steakhouse delivers a sizzling, sophisticated culinary experience inside with an impressive menu of premium Australian and US Black Angus Beef and a delectable selection of seafood appetizers that have all the making of a perfect surf & turf experience. We started off with the New England Clam Chowder, which as natives of Boston, we are always skeptical of ordering outside my hometown, but Chef Manuel Gruber has an interesting take on this Boston classic, piling in a hearty portion of New Zealand mussels and bacon bits to give it a flavor all its own.When it comes to the meat, our cut is almost always the intricately marbled US Black Angus Rib-Eye cooked medium rare (closer to rare) sprinkled with a bit of salt to lock in the full flavor of the meat.  For the sides, you can't go wrong with Creamed Spinach or Grilled Green Asparagus with Bearnaise Sauce and either the Potatoes Gratin or Mashed Potatoes as welcome accompaniments.If you've saved up enough room for dessert, then we recommend diving into the White & Dark Mocca Mousse, which is a delightful set of flavors that nicely balance off the salty meat flavor from earlier. Put all that together with some friendly conversation and a couple glasses of their admirable red wine collection, and we are all but certain you will walk away satisfied, albeit quite full and a bit lighter in the wallet.
Absolutely gorgeous place. Brought my girl to celebrate her birthday and she enjoyed it .Very comfy.The food is good if you really need a mala fixing.The staff are very friendly and speaks English.

This is my new go to hotpot place. Great value, good ingredients, and very interesting soup bases! The sets for two are great value, and we didn't really find anything wrong with anything we ordered. Can't wait to bring my mum!

My family and I have been coming here a lot.What I like:1) the sets are quite varied and good value. We usually order a 2 person set and add ala carte orders on top of it.2) the fish paste here is soooo soft and tender it practically falls off the chopsticks sometimes when I'm picking it up.3) the fried beancurd skin is a MUST. I never used to eat this at steamboats but now I'm hooked and always get an additional order.4) The luncheon meat is a bit finer than other places. Is that possible??5) Help yourself to the condiment bar. There are about 20 different types to mix up yourself or follow the recommended combinations on the wall for those who need some guidance. Warning, I find the spicy chilli really spicy so I only add a little of that now.6) The mushroom stock soup. It's made from old mushrooms and really savoury.7) The rice here seems to be good quality and better than your average restaurant. Really tasty somehow with the food.8) They make their own pork balls9) There's decent air conditioning!
James and his staff are spectacular. Top notch service in a relaxed environment with absolutely amazing fresh ingredients (fish from the local market etc). You can't go wrong!
Best hotspot by far. Great broth and quality ingredients. The meat and scallops are amazing.

My husband and I came here twice while staying in a nearby hotel. Their happy hour is the best deal around and the cocktails were excellent - legitimate cocktails, both classic and unique. The atmosphere is very nice with open air dining, easy listening music, and friendly staff. The owner is always around and recognized us when we came back with a warm greeting. We will definitely be back next time we are in Singapore.

I had walked to Robertson Quay to eat at a different restaurant, one who apparently didn't have space for me. I had seen a number of people sitting outside along the river at Rosso Vino and thought the atmosphere would be nice for me too.Not wanting heavy Italian food in the heat, I chose to have the beef tenderloin. It was perfect! The meat was cooked exactly to medium and the flavor was great. Pairing that with a nice glass of rose and I had a great meal! The Tiramisu was a bit loose, it could have used more cake foundation but it was light and didn't weigh me down for the walk back downtown.The prices here were a bit high on both the food and wine but it was a nice evening all in all!

Amazing food, amazing location (basically next door to the park hotel), and amazing atmosphere. The weather in the evening is perfect. Cool breeze in the shade after a hot day. A lovely variety of Italian foods and wines. I had the lasagna and the ravioli during my stay- both were amazing.

Rosso Vino was OK. Nothing bad about this experience, and nothing outstanding.  We eat here out of convenience as our hotel was just around the corner.  We sat outside along the waterfront.  For an Italian restaurant they had an impressive gluten free menu.  Their gluten free pasta was OK.  It held form, and didn't fall apart.  I had the Bolognese Gluten Free Penne Pasta.  The flavors were bland and mediocre.

My son and I just ate here on 9/18/20 around 6:00. We were met at the entrance by a young, unsmiling woman who wordlessly led us to a table. There was no greeting except 'How many?'She took our order with no friendliness whatsoever. I never saw her crack a smile! I made the 'mistake' of asking if garlic bread was included with my entree, as most all restaurants do that.  (With a look of incredulity, she sternly said 'No, ma'am') Once we got our food, she never once came over to ask us if we needed anything or how our food was. We were ignored for the rest of the time. This meal was my treat to my son... I was actually embarrassed by our shabby treatment. We think it's great that there is no tipping in Singapore...but then there is no way to show your displeasure b/c if there WERE tipping, she would not have gotten a dime from me! I told my son that if he were not present, I would have spoken to her frankly and told her she was an embarrassment to her profession. I have embarrassed my son before by my candidness with strangers and did not want to do it on our vacation. I expect to visit Singapore again but will certainly not patronize THIS restaurant.
This is possibly the worst pizza ever. It was waaay over salted, the crust was mushy and grossly under cooked. Do not order from this restaurant.

Need more YELP reviews! I had an amazing meal. I was dining alone but I never felt alone thanks to Giri the bartender. He recommended wine, recommended a meal based on what I told him my dietary restrictions were. He chatted with me throughout my time there and was genuinely interested in learning about me. Highly recommend sitting at the bar if you're a couple or traveling alone

Finally got to try this place and it was ...disappointing!  They even got worse than the former restaurant in this same exact location, Sailors!The menu and the wine list looked good.  And the service is actually ok.  The food is the problem...  the buffalo mozzarella was a few days old.  The gnocchi alla Sorrentina were hardly fresh (the mozzarella on top looked like plastic) and the baccalà's presentation was hideous and extremely small.  For $30, at a casual dining italian restaurant, one would expect a bit more generous portions, and simple platting.Icing in the cake:  $3.50 for four slices of stale bread, which we asked once we got the mozzarella and prosciutto (the bread should just come with the dish, who eats prosciutto without break?!?)  And the waiter tried to put freshly ground pepper on pasta (gnocchi alla Sorrentina) ...come on!...well, the fact that is called Rosso Vino instead of Vino Rosso should have told me from the start that this place has nothing authentic.

After 14 days in Asia we were a little over rice and noodles and were craving a nice Italian dinner. We live in New York City and though we are not picky eaters we are used to high quality food. This place really hit the spot. It's right along the river in Robertson Quay, quiet location but quick walk into the chaos of Clark Quay. We had the eggplant appetizer, lasagna and spaghetti bolognse- all great and home made. Their bread is also made in house and delicious. Good selection of wine. The service was also great. All around would highly recommend for couples or families. Gary, one of the waiters, was also very helpful in making recommendations.Check TripAdvisor for much more reviews

I tried two of the other Italian restaurants on Robertson Quay, and Rossovino beats them hands down. Real Italians run the joint, and you can tell.  One star penalty for untoasted bread in the bruschetta, though.

Let me save you time, expectation, and money. Yes there are some European wait staff working here, I don't know if they are Italian, but the food is anything but.  What I can tell you is that the salad, pizza, and pasta were awful, simply awful, and the worst Italian dinner I've ever had in Singapore.With so many good Italian restaurants within walking distance of this place, like Ricciotti, Da Mario, Pasta Bella, well there is no reason to settle for less. We really wanted to like this place.

OMG. Came back to this place again and was again blown away by the quality of the food. I had two jumbo prawns and seafood fried rice. Outstanding!The sauce was to die for sweet and sour.  Prawns were massive and fried to perfection.

Never have I been more disappointed more than this place.  We had a party of 10 wanting to have a memorable dinner by the river with flaming drunken prawns at table side.  We were told that's available at reservation time and only told no after seating.  They will not prepare in front of us but will bring us 'similar' sans the flame so we ordered 3 appetizers and the were over cooked or so-so flavors.  So we decided to go elsewhere to finish supper,  the check was over $200 without any alcoholic beverages.  Consider you have been warned.

Great seafood at Clarke Quay.We got there about 30 mins before sun set.  Outdoor seating by the water, it could get a little warm but get to enjoy beautiful sunset and followed by night lights.Service was great! Our server was attentive, and kept coming back to clear empty plates and while he was there, he poured more glass of wine.I really enjoyed the atmosphere. We were in the Clarke Quay, one of the fun place to be in Singapore. View of sunset was amazing, and soon we were surrounded by the night lights.  Night lights reflecting in water, and got to enjoy different boats go by.Food was excellent was well. I posted pictures most of the food we had that night here, and can't pick my favorite. Everything we had was amazingly good.Note: this review sat at my draft forever, and my visit here was July 2014, and I am finally posting it.
Food - chili crab 4/5 fresh and tasty.Service - 5/5 very friendly and frequently change the dirty dishes.Price - 2/5 it is in the very high end. Overall - 3.6/5

My husband and I recently visited to try the Chili Crab and the Sambal Stingray. The chili crab comes with buns that you can get either steamed or deep fried. We chose deep fried and did not regret it at all. The food was pretty expensive but we were kind of expecting that based on other reviews. The stingray was very good but we both agree the crab was better. The seating is outside next to the river which was very nice. The only thing I didn't like was a lack of a restroom. The crab is very messy and the only place to wash your hands is a sink next to the bar.

There's nothing more I dislike than eating by myself, unless, ...... I order crab. In Singapore that translates to Chili Crab of course, and this place knows how to prepare it! I got here 40 min before closing time but they told me 'no problem'. Not cheap, (150S$ for a medium size crab and a glass of white) but hey, it's Singapore. The only thing that bothered me is the sweeping of the floors and putting all chairs around me on the tables around me, but the Chili Crab is KING!

Had an absolutely amazing meal here the other day...really large portions. We were stuffed, but loved the food so much we bought take-away seafood fried rice for our son so that he could enjoy it as well.We went at about 5:30pm to beat the crowds and got a nice table--service was pretty good, our waitress was polite and only as attentive as necessary (we can't stand wait staff who are too pushy) so that was good because it allowed us to enjoy our mean uninterrupted. The food came promptly, and was served as it was prepared, which allowed us to tuck in to one dish at a time.Instead of ordering one large meal each, we had four small dishes, which we shared. We chose one that featured sambal scallops, one that was a nicely-spiced shrimp (properly deveined, I should add!), a sumptuous squid medley, and a splendid noodle dish w/ mixed seafood. We loved the variety and felt almost guilty at all the seafood we were feasting on...we only ordered two small rice bowls, preferring to fill up on the seafood itself. :-)Here's the amazing part...the bill came to less than $100! We were gobsmacked. It goes without saying, that we'd highly recommend this place for a nice, romantic meal with a boatload of fresh, quality seafood for the money.

All the food we had was good, but the bill was staggeringly expensive... For some context, a double G&T was 28 SGD. Our party all thought the food was good, but would not return because the pricing was just outrageous for what was essentially a pretty average, to good, seafood restaurant...

Just had dinner here. We went at about 7:30pm so it wasn't crowded and the service was very prompt. We had a table by the river and the view was amazing. Now about the food. The seafood was good, just good. Nothing super special for me .We ordered a massive Chilli Crab which was presented beautifully. The Roast Duck was very large but also very dry. We ordered a plate of Ginger Beef or something that sounded like that which was all good until I spotted a strand of HAIR in my plate, mind you it was definitely not my hair. The staff were kind and often offered to change our plates, bring new napkins and what not. If you do choose to go here don't order the beef or duck just stick to the seafood.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01A, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: Great pizza--some toppings are off ...like, who would ever put meatballs on pizza, other than my American wife? :-). You can see from their brick oven from Naples that they are serious!  Consistently good service, at least at lunch in the weekends (never been here at night...)

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01A, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: Stopped in for a Singapore sling- the must have tourist drink in Singapore. I went to the Raffles hotel first where the drink originated. It was a smaller bar and drinks were $40 after taxes. I was underwhelmed and and thought I'd find a spot on the way home. They are $16 here which is still quite high per suburban American standards but it was worth it for the novelty at a breezey and shaded outdoor patio on a hot day.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01A, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: Good pizza, really good music and atmosphere. Inside and outside seating available. Limited menu, but it's all about pizza which had a variety of options.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01A, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: Visited this place and enjoyed the food as well as ambiance. The customer service was great.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01A, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: Of all the ripoff places in Singapore, this one takes the pizza!The Caprese was laughable, only 3 little pieces of store-bought mozzarella and small tomatoes... Not impressed.The pizzas couldn't be smaller and they could not be stingier with the ingredients. The Meatball pizza came with 5 tiny pieces of some sort of meat concoction at $23!!!Horrible place... and the manager? Nowhere to be found on a Saturday afternoon... and it shows! Spend your $$$ somewhere else!

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01A, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: This is probably the best pizza place in Singapore. The ambiance is awesome. The food is great. The service is truly out of the world. The staff are super friendly that's refreshing to see in Singapore. Will keep going there again and again.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01A, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: The Quattro formaggia is the best we tried of 3 different types. It's not a bad place at all. Just that we have tasted better. Prices seem reasonable especially because of the location. Service is very good.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01A, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: Next stop of my culinary trip in Singapore is this place. We ordered Margarita pizza (12"), pork meatball with tomato sauce, and the vongole pasta. The pizza is quite tasty with thin crust. The meatball is just ok but the sauce certainly helps.  The pasta needs more seasoning and bigger portion for the price they charged us.  They charges the water. I won't be coming back again.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01A, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: Was prepared to spend a decent many of money there. Was going to get 2 or 3 pizzas (all over $20 each) and some wine. Then they have the audacity to say they will charge us for Singapore tap water per person.  First time we were there they didn't seem to charge for a simple galas on tap water. We left just on principle only.  There are a number other pizza places around that treat their customers much better.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01A, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: Poor service (do I really need to repeatedly ask for water refills when the restaurant is half empty?) , average pizzas which is such a disservice to the one in NYC.The pizza tasted nothing like the one in NY- I won't be back.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01A, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: Food was actually decent except for one common denominator...everything was salty! We enjoyed the texture of the pizza except it was a little too salty. The pastas were cooked perfectly "el dente" except it was too salty. The fact that all the pasta dishes came out salty makes me suspect that maybe the pasta water was heavily salted as well as the chef having heavy hands when seasoning the food. Fix the over seasoning issue and the food should actually be quite good.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01A, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: Originally from Brooklyn, I was very excited to see Motorino arrive in Singapore, as it doesn't hurt to have another fine pizza joint.  And in terms of the pies, Motorino definitely delivers, but there are a few other parts of the dining experience that could be better.  The actual pie is 12 inches so it's good for one hungry person.  The crust is definitely amazing, and I really enjoyed the quality of ingredients.  It's a bit different from Mozza in the sense that there is more sauce, and I really enjoyed my version with sweet sausage, mozarella, and mushrooms.  What could be better?  For starters, it's very warm inside.  Even warmer than outside.  I know there is a massive oven inside, but still, it's quite uncomfortable (tip: there is a fan by one table which is where I would sit).  Secondly, it's next to the Butcher Club which apparently has a live DJ (at least on the Saturday night), so it was quite loud...not as loud as Attica, but it would be difficult to carry on a conversation.  So overall, while Motorino has some fine pies, I found it not very comfortable in terms of a restaurant.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01A, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: From New Jersey and love pizza. Usually go to Tony's for a fix. Now this will be the place.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01A, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: Just wauuuvvv! Since Sopra near Orchard Hotel closed this is the best pizza in Singapore. The dough is soft and elastic and every bite taste like a little piece of heaven! Wanted to take a picture but the I ate the pizza before the camera was ready.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-01A, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: I spent 15 years in the East Village New York near the Motorino in Manhattan and the various other authentic Neapolitan pizza places in that neighborhood. We used to eat at Motorino  fairly regularly. I've also eaten at an abundance of pizza places in Italy from childhood through to an adult with relatives.  We finally found the time to go to Motorino Singapore last night and I can report they have exactly replicated their downtown NYC location with excellent Neapolitan pizzas made with the best and freshest ingredients in a proper wood burning oven by a skilled pizzaiolo.  Clark Quay is not were I would think to go for a top quality meal out most nights, but if you want a real pizza in Singapore this is right at or near the top of the short list of places to go.

After eating here, I concluded that Little Saigon is all about the ambiance, music and location. The food was just okay. I had the beef and pork pho which was pricier than a less touristy venue while being less tasty.It is still a good time  and a good way to end up a night out
awesome live music, riverfront seating, 1945 is a very good cocktail.  there are a few vegetarian options on the menu:  stir fry noodles, spring rolls, fried yam rolls, highly recommend!
Love the river seating.  Good tasting Drinks. Not sure if our water bottles came from tap water.  It came opened.  Wish they opened them at the table.
Awesome music from the band ENT after 930! Drinks were less pricey than most bars I have been to in Singapore.
The food was too bad but the service is very slow and not importing at all. What could be an amazing place is missed by poor service. Worth a visit for a cheap chic cheerful bite to eat.

Stick around for a beer or two and grab a seat overlooking the river. It's right next to the river boat tours so you can watch people, and watch boats coming in and out.I did stick around a bit longer and went for their big sampler and fried rice. It's basically everything on their menu all on one plate. All good stuff and they give a lot of food.It's still hot even under their covered outdoor seating, but at least some of their fans still work.

Nice little place in Clarke Quay. The server was attentive and the cover band playing got everyone into the act. Ordered a few appetizers and those were fine. Drinks were a bit expensive but would've been fine if we would've made happy hour.

We were pretty hungry. Food was ok, nothing to rave about or go back to, but not disappointing either. 50% cocktails til 9pm is pretty good, but again, drinks were nothing to rave about.Minimal vegetarian options.I feel like this is the standard within the highly targeted tourist area, so if you're hungry just pick a place a go.

Really really bad cocktails!!!And one of the worst service I had in Singapore.We ordered 4 cocktails and all of us were extremely disappointed and when we dared to complain we were just given the bill...

Probably the worst cocktail that I have ever experienced. I ordered a lemon basil martini that only tasted sugar syrup and not any gin at all. Even when complaining the waitress didn't say a word and gave no response whatsoever. My friends had mojitos that also were a disaster. Do not waste your money here!
Awesome music from the band ENT after 930! Drinks were less pricey than most bars I have been to in Singapore.

Nice little place in Clarke Quay. The server was attentive and the cover band playing got everyone into the act. Ordered a few appetizers and those were fine. Drinks were a bit expensive but would've been fine if we would've made happy hour.
A tourist trap with unmaintained tap lines, stale tasting beer, and oil so rancid you can taste it.  Don't waste your time.

Food is okay. Not great. Pho a bit greasy.  Squid over cooked and rubbery. Spring rolls and green papaya salad were good.  They charge 2 SGD for a thimble of tap water...  and want another 2 for a refill. Ridiculous. Given the number of options in the area keep looking.
The food was too bad but the service is very slow and not importing at all. What could be an amazing place is missed by poor service. Worth a visit for a cheap chic cheerful bite to eat.

I don't get it. This place is a tourist trap. The view was the only nice thing. Half price happy hour with everything half price not. Many things weren't included. And my half priced drink came in a half filled glass. Appetizers were boring at best. The light fresh spring rolls were the best but the sugar prawn was made of cheap puréed something that may or may not have been prawns and the chili crab dip was just a bowl of liquid with little actual crab. The disappointment if the night was the much vaunted lemongrass beef tenderloin which was just a bunch of dry tasteless beef. No lemongrass we could discern and completely void of any redeeming value. Save your money and have a great meal at any of the hundreds of places in the streets behind Boat Quay.

This place is in Clarke Quay - that automatically puts it on the more pricey side. I went with my wife and small daughter to a friend's going away party. There is an indoor area which is open to the walking path, basically opened wide doors, and a nice verdana on the water-side. The decor is fetching with dark, blue tones with a sprinkling of Vietnamese-ness.As for the food, I recommend STAY AWAY from all soups and noodles. How you churn out mediocre pho and bun bo hue is beyond me. All else is 4/5 stars - fried rice, spring rolls, and other appetizers. Although good food, as I said it's on the pricey side.BOTTOM LINE - go for the ambiance of Clarke Quay, the food is OK but do not expect top-shelf Vietnamese fare. I've eaten better on the streets of Saigon.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-14, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
