comment: So, a New England native comes straight from Boston to live in Singapore. The first thing he notices: you can make buildings out of materials other than bricks. Several epiphanies later, he realizes that most of the pizza here is awful and exorbitantly overpriced.Relatively speaking to Singapore standards, Bella's pies are good, and though they're a bit more expensive than the average place, it's not the kind of shakedown you can expect from other spots in the area. If they're still serving the salmon pizza, I'd recommend it; original and surprisingly well done.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-14, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Along the shore of the Alexandra Canal, this establishment is steps from Clarke and Robertson Quay and has a cozy Italian restaurant feel to it. The pizza is good, with a tasty Italian crust that is reminiscent of the old world. It has a front that opens up to the canal to provide a nice ambiance. I liked it enough to come back.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-14, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: I came here because it had good reviews and was close to my hotel. I didn't order pizza, and maybe that was my problem. After looking at the menu I settled on the gnocchi, and I must admit that I had a mixed reaction to it. The flavored and presentation were very good, however I'm giving my this three stars because the gnocchi was over cooked to the point of being mush. Otherwise the space is lovely, though not set up for single diners. I hope the pizza is better than their pasta.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-14, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Ample serving of fresh mozzarella with Parma ham.  Grilled veggies fine.Pizza margarita didn't have enough basil to make it being anything other than a cheese pizza. Not terrible but ordinary

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-14, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: I am traveling solo and went for dinner. I asked to be seated outside but since I was dining single, the only option provided to me was a high top under neon lighting outside the door. Opted to sit in. Was excited based on reviews. The pizza was pretty good. I'd go back for that again. Also had the avocado and mango salad. Would not recommend. Was a pile of spinach with a few slivers of avocado and mini-cubed mango pieces. There was also ship, two to be exact that were halved. Stingy with the good stuff. So pizza and don't go alone. You won't get a decent table.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-14, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: It was very good before a change of ownership and still just about OK but food standards and service have both dropped.  Not inexpensive.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-14, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Is it the best pizza in the world?  No.  Is it the best pizza in Singapore?  Yes.  And I've tried many a pizza in Singapore.   Excellent crust.  Not too thick.  Not to thin.  Properly baked.  Very good quality ingredients.   Service --- well, it's Singapore.  Good service in Singapore has become very hard to find in the past twenty years or so.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-14, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: This is good pizza but I am not blown away by it. It is too thin for my tastes. It is like the pizza in France, or a little thicker than the pizza in Rome (but with a little worse cheese), both of which I consider inferior to pizza in Napoli. However, they may be catering to the Singaporean palette, and that would probably mean making a similar style of pizza as the early entrant Da Paolo. If this is true, they execute their efforts toward that goal very well.I am in love with Bella Pasta which is under the same ownership.The weekday lunch special is a steal. 18++ for a salad, a pizza, ice cream, and coffee or tea.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-14, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Whenever anyone tells me about a good pizza place I make it a point to check it out... and guess what? Bella Pizza wasn't only good- it was great! The margarita pizza was cheesy with just the right amount of sauce. The garlic bread was perfectly crispy and everything seemed it was made to order. Can't wait to come back to this little gem!

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-14, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Very nice pizza. Traditional taste, very nice dough and crust and a sauce that compliments rather than overpowers. When I find a nice pizza like this I usually go traditional and get classic margarita. You can't go wrong. I have been many times but always forget to review. Will check in with photos next time. Cool spot too if alone or with group of people

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-14, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Heard that this place serves one of the best pizzas in Singapore and i agree that it's a great find!PROS:-their folded pizzas are a MUST try! :)-the pizza base smells heavenly.. I believe the dough is freshly baked - could still smell the yeasty bread smell (some people may not like this)-spent just 24 dollars per person, which is pretty decent for a more upmarket restaurant (we didn't drink at the bar though)-ambience is nice, right by the riverside-service was good, waiters were very attentive and kept refilling our waterCONS:-pizza toppings they give are quite stingy though, very little meat on the italian sausage pizza we ordered, so one star off for that!-the normal pizza (ie. non-folded pizza) was a flimsy and difficult to eat - in the end i rolled them up and ate them like the folded pizza

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-14, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Tasty Italian food, reasonably priced, good service. Tried their white based pizza with salmon, short pasta with eggplant, tiramisu, and bruschetta. The first 3 were good. The bruschetta was mediocre.

address: 30 Robertson Quay #01-14, Riverside View Singapore 238251 Singapore
comment: Amazing, amazing pizza! Thin crust, gourmet toppings, extremely flavorful but not greasy. This is my favorite pizza place in Singapore thus far. MUCH better than Tomatoes, Pizza Hut or Dominoes. Too bad they don't deliver.

address: 3D River Valley Road Clarke Quay #01-11 Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: This is a nice little bar in Clarke Quay that seems to focus on the drinks more than the food. Had my heart set on fish and chips, and they were okay, but nothing to write home about. Service was prompt, surroundings are typical outdoor Clarke Quay seating. A decent place to stop for a beer or two.

I'm making it my goal to try every mexican restaurant in singapore. Ive loved mexican food as long as I can remember and really miss the taco trucks in LA.  I was pleasantly surprised after trying this place for the first time and finding some real (as close as youll get in singapore) mexican street tacos. The carnitas and el pastor are great. Their habaneros and cream salsa is also great and reminds me of a great mexican place back in LA. This one  is basically a taco stand with a much more limited menu.  If you want a bigger menu try the chimes or star vista branch.  Its a great spot for some solid food at a reasonable price.

Decent place for Mexican food in Chijmes. The outdoor alfresco seating is really good. Food is ok to decent depending on what you order. By Singapore standards decent Mexican grub, but I'm a bit spoilt from the Mexican fare I've had in the USA so it's pretty average tasting to me.

This place has gone grossly downhill. We will never eat here again! $80 for 6 tacos, a coke and a bottle of water!The Beef tacos used to come as a portion of 2 tacos as they are served anywhere else on the world, but the genius in charge of this place decided to charge $8-10 for a SINGLE taco!!! What is this owner thinking? Probably that Singaporeans are dumb enough to pay for it, but while many are, we are not. Shame on you! You lost a group of customers that will never visit or recommend your establishment again.

Literally the worst service Went here with a party of 6, everyone's food came out desperately about 15-20 min apart. They charged us for food we ordered but they didn't bring (they ran out of a dish, we ordered a substitute, but they charged us for both). They  didn't bring out the extra apps we ordered either The food is nothing special. Decent, not bad but not great. Honestly there are so many other places in the plaza even if there's a wait for something else, it's worth the wait

Great food, service and ambiance. Their signature agave tequila margarita is quite different, but gets very sweet towards the end. The location makes it lively and entertaining, if you want some quiet the indoor seating is well shielded :) Be prepared for a pricey bill though.

Señor Taco was delicious! The sizzling fajitas was excellent, some of the best chicken I've had in a while, especially after being so hungry for hours before. There is a unique layout with the bar and restaurant on the opposite sides of the sidewalk, so you can eat outside if you like and watch the live performances in the middle of Clarke Quay.

I ate here on New Year's Eve and I was disappointed with the size of my quesadilla.  My quesadilla was smaller than a taco.  The people need to realize that quesadillas must be big and cover the plate!!!  I paid 8 dollars for something smaller than a taco that I ate in only a few bites.  I feel that the food was way overpriced and they need to consider the very small portions they offer, especially for quesadillas.

Vacation trip with friends. Came to Clarke Quay late (after 10:00pm). Most food places we tried to go to stopped serving food by now. This place was still serving food though. Def one of the cheaper places around. Food was okay, def wish I had it after drinking.

Decided to try Senor Taco today. We've tried the Senor Taco on Orchard a couple of years ago and it was pretty good. We ordered our drinks then everyone disappeared. 15 to 20 minutes later a waitress came in and we were told the waitress never ordered our drinks. So we placed our order again. The Chamocelada (michelada with chamoy) was excellent, the chip and guacamole was very good. Unfortunately the tacos were not very good, the chicken taco was way too sweet, the carnitas taco very tender but bland. We're still waiting for our ceviche..

Better of the two mexican joints I've had in Singapore thus far. The Al Pastor tacos are super tasty, but alas super tiny, and pricey. They are smaller than street tacos in Mexico. Live music at 9:30pm every night though.

Perfect for people watching, food is average.It's all about the location here. Casual and hip Mexican restaurant at the heart of Clarke Quay. You can also catch the belly dancing show at the Turkish shisha bar next to it during dinner. I found the quality of food and service to be average. Coming from LA I do admit that I set a high bar for Mexican food. We ordered the chips with guacamole (probably the best dish of the meal), tacos (which were not bad but should come in smaller sizes in stead of one single huge tortilla), enchiladas, salad (which I do NOT recommend). Drinks were A-OK :)One thing I have to say about the service: They cleared our plates even when we said no... Which was a huge turn off. It is not like there were people queueing so I just didn't understand the rush.All in all it's probably worth a visit, just one though unless food quality goes up.

If I had to pick one type of food that's been difficult to find here in Singapore, it would be Mexican. In a country where great food from all walks of life is fairly easy to find, my one criticism would be trying to locate a decent Mexican joint with traditional tacos. I had a hunch that Singapore would probably not have many options for Mexican, seeing as the countries are miles apart. I knew after moving from the states that I would have to curb my Mexican cravings, which I've learned to manage since Singapore offers other great varieties of food. At one point though, I hit a wall and needed a taco fix. After searching high and low, I did manage to find a place that I can somewhat rely on now when I need a taco fix. Senor taco in Clark Quay offers decent tacos. Granted, I have had way better in my life, but again, I'm in Singapore and I knew I had to curb my expectations a bit. The beef and pork tacos are nice, and the different hot sauces they offered were quite decent. The service was nothing to brag about, but I wasn't expecting top notch service at a place like this. The only drawback was the loud music they felt they needed to blast. I enjoy my fair share of hip-hop, but I don't think you need to blast it as loud as possible on a Tuesday evening. Also, if you have kids, it might be best not to bring them here as they don't play the "clean" versions of these songs. If you don't care that your young ones are exposed to explicit lyrics, then it won't be a problem. The tacos at the Orchard location were actually tastier and the service was great there. They also didn't blast the music to the point where your ears felt like bleeding. The only drawback there is it's right behind Orchard Towers, and well, I don't really need to explain what you'll see there while dining at the location.
Fun place, right in the centre of the crowd. The best part is that they serve REAL tacos made with love. Great stuff

visited this place for dinner during my trip to Singapore.  First of all the food is highly priced and the portion size is too small. The service was slow and the waiters were not able to explain the menu properly. I ordered the beef tacos which only had two corn tortillas, sliced beef and onions. There was no other seasoning in the taco.  Even after having dinner i still felt hungry.  Wont recommend this place to anyone who is craving mexican food in Clarke Quay, Singapore.

Finding good tacos in Singapore is akin to searching for laksa in Jacksonville. Hard to find, like trying to locate Bigfoot.Señor Taco dishes up fairly average and authentic (albeit dry)  tacos. They are similar to the average taco you can get on a street corner in CA for a couple of bucks. I tried the tacos al pastor, baja fish tacos, carnitas and caramelo de filete. The corn tortillas are authentic but are a little on the dry side. Same for the marinated pork/chicken. The meat was overcooked and rather dry. However, the sauces are definitely authentic.Perusing the menu, there were also a couple of authentic-looking central Mexican dishes that looked good to try, but I didn't get the opportunity on this visit. I saw enchiladas, sopas, quesadillas. The menu is available on the website.One problem is the atmosphere, where they played mostly outdated 90s and 00s house and pop music at ear-splittingly loud levels even on an empty mid-week night...Quality and taste-wise, the tacos are okay, bordering on meh. But at around S$8/pop, I'll have to find a way to limit my taco cravings and eat something else instead...

Take away for this place is - alright.  The corn tortilla is good but not the real deal.  Service was ok accept the waitress was getting impatient to wait and kept pushing for the main.  Actually the real reason I came was to quench the craving for soft taco.  Got to say the most spicy sauce of the 3 provider was a kick :).
I checked this place out when I was overseas playing basketball and it was very good.. They have TVs and it's a waterfront setting a little bit on the pricey side but worth it.

To be clear my review doesn't necessarily reflect the quality of the food - their tacos and quesadillas are quite all right (my favorite is the steak). Unfortunately the prices are a bit high for what it is, both the food and the drinks. Sure their location in Clark Quay is convenient and the live stage along with occasional salsa inside the restaurant make this place fun but my fore mentioned favorite steak taco is $10 for a single taco and overall from my experience you need to spend $40-60 dollars, excluding drinks to get full here. The drinks are also pricy and the jug of margaritas will be $50 or so. Sure the food is good but the value is barely average.

It's interesting to see the range of reviews for Senor Taco and after pending a few hours there and trying 5 different types of tacos, I can see both the good and the bad.  First the good - they have a nice selection of different tacos including a chicharron and chile which was totally awesome.  But the winner was the fish taco - very tasty and meaty, but a little pricey at $11 per taco.  The pork belly was interesting but I would prefer smaller pieces than one slab.  The beef and chicken were smaller but there were at least 2 per order.  Drinks are weak.  The margarita on the rocks was like water.  Stick to a beer,  But come before 7:30 and most drinks are $9.90 which is nice.  The decor is cheesy.  And there is a stage for live music, which thankfully they didnt have on Sunday as the space is quite small and I can only imagine how noisy it would be.  But overall, the food exceeded expectations, the drinks did not.  But given the limited choices in Singapore for Mexican, it's definitely worth stopping by.

If you tried taco and burritos before in US or Mexico then you understand the difference between quality and style. Peoples are friendly and food is so so. You can try with corona beer to remember taste of Texas .

Just don't. No matter how drunk, how strong the craving is for mexican, or how cheap the prices look, Do Not Give In.Possibly the worst taco in all of Asia (and there are a lot of crappy mexican joints gunning for that title). Head over to the Senor Taco in Chijmes for a better experience, or pony up some cash for a Lucha Loco speciality. Whatever you do, don't fulfill your dreams of carne asada or carnitas deliciousness at this pit stop for college drunks.

Clarke Quay can be very expensive. Sometimes you want something cheap. And if you're drunk, you want something greasy. Senor Taco is open late to satisfy your craving for greasy Mexican. Tacos are authentic -- corn tortillas with meat, extra for cheese. Topped with cilantro and onions. What I like most is they bottles of sauce (chipotle sauce, guacomole sauce, super spicy, etc). Considering that guacamole is very expensive in Singapore, I just drown my tacos in the green guacamole sauce. It's not real guacamole, but it's got the taste.Tacos are $2.50-$3 SGD each, and you can order 1 for a snack or as many as you want.  A cheap way to satisfy the Mexican craving in Singapore.

I'll admit I'm a bit of a taco snob, and this place just doesn't do it for me. It's conveniently located in the middle of Clarke Quay, which is great if you just want a bite to eat while people watching, but if you're seriously in the mood for some good tacos, do yourself a favour and walk 5-10 minutes over to Super Loco over on Robertson Quay.

Señor Taco is an alfresco taqueria located in Clarke Quay. Seating is bar-like, with people perched on high-standing stools along similarly elevated tables. Upon our arrival, one of the chefs came out to take our order, and he told us about the place, including the fact that this is the first taqueria in Asia. I tend to take all such claims with a healthy pinch of salt, but I'll accept that all other Mexican outlets I have come across do tend to sell more than just tacos! Tacos were quite cheap at between $2.50 and $3.50 a taco, with fillings including grilled pork and beef. Quesadillas were also available, and cost between $4.50 and $5, depending on the fillings. I had a grilled pork taco and a beef taco, and that turned out to be too little for me. The tacos could be devoured in three bites! The pork was delicious and the beef was a little on the dry side. So I ended up ordering a vegetarian quesadilla to supplement my order, and the tortilla was nice and soft, and the cheese not too overwhelming. I also had a strawberry magarita ($20) here. You have two options: a double shot or a double double shot of tequila. Yes, that means four shots. I opted for the single double, and that in itself was pretty strong. Thanks, you've successfully added this place! Señor Taco isn't the best place I've ever had Mexican food, but it is very reasonably priced, considering I had a decent meal and drink for about $30. It's not a great place to sit if you're dying from the Singapore heat, but, if you're used to it, it's definitely a more affordable alternative compared to the neighbouring outlets.

This is a pretty good place to get a quick taco. While it's not gourmet or anything, the tacos are pretty satisfying and actually quite authentic. They use corn tortillas and not flour tortillas like many Mexican places in Singapore. They don't load the taco with mozarella cheese so it really isn't the jelat tex mex fare you get most often.I also kind of like the bar concept they have going on. You can watch your sever preparing your taco and it's fuss free and quick. Senor Taco is kind of a strange mix of tacky - Orchard Towers and LCD TVs blasting pop music - and pretty damn satisyfing tacos. Perhaps they could improve on variety but I really won't complain because they offer pretty authentic Mexican tacos in Singapore, where finding Mexican that isn't tex mex is like looking for a needle in a haystack.

I would only go on Taco Tuesday.  For regular price days - it is VERY overpriced for tacos.  The service was ok.  I ordered a White Tequila (upper quality) and was served Jose Cuervo.  Thank goodness the bar keep took it back.  The tacos were good - for paying %50 off.  Drinks are Singapore standard price, but no happy hours on taco Tuesdays it seems.  Would go again only for %50 tacos - never regular price and not for drinks.

This is easily my favourite Mexican place in Singapore.  Usually, that would not mean much but the tacos are legit and better than many places in the States and Mexico!  The margaritas and beers are of course CQ priced, but I have to come back here when I am in Singapore.  I am stunned that the guys working here remembered me from my shenanigans when I lived in Singapore.  I love their YouTube video monitor.  They even let me help pick the songs - yes I am the moron who always asks for Dizzee Rascal's Bonkers.  I do not know if they keep playing it to shut me up or to encourage my ridiculosity.  Either way, I love this place.  keep the fiesta going!

Since moving to Singapore, finding a quality taco has been a real challenge. We finally found this place and are glad we did. The tortillas are delicious and the sauces are fresh with options from medium to super spicy. Our server was friendly and provided great service. The only main drawbacks are the area- being located in Clarke Quay you have to deal with higher than usual prices and the occasional table of obnoxious people. Speaking of tables, ours was really sticky but we were so happy to have found tacos that were close to the level we were used to back home we looked past it. We will continue our search for good quality Mexican food at reasonable prices but will be happy to return there again.
Awesome only place we had in Asia with actual real tacos! I don't understand bad reviews

Solid tacos. You might find something similar 3 for a $1 on the street en el D.F., but you are in Singapore and that is 10,330 miles away (roughly). The fact that these are 4 for $20 SGD is painful, but hey, its also pretty remarkable & amazing when you think about it.
This the best place to eat authentic Mexican food in Singapore.  It's like eating in Mexico.  Specially, tourist must visit this restaurant.

The food here is affordable, we tried the Tacos al pastor which is pretty delicious. A pretty decent place to find comfort Mexican food, but not spectacular. The seating is outdoors, and has a cheery atmosphere. You have to make your orders at the cashier which is about 2 steps away from the wooden tables and chairs. They have a selection of beers available, and their tequila shots are good. When we were there, there was a promotion for $20 for a jug of long island tea if you use a certain credit card.

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: Annalakshmi is part of a temple and serves Indian buffet style cuisine. There is no set price for the meal because this place takes donation only. I think people usually donate about $5, when I donated $15 the cashier was very surprised. The food here is very good. There is a decent selection to choose from. A man was making fresh dosa (original, butter, and masala flavors) which was delicious. I thought the lassi drink (ask the server for this) and the aloo shimla were really good as well. Nothing in the buffet was super spicy which was a good thing for me because I typically don't tolerate spice that well. The only dish that I felt came a little short was the chana simla, I thought that was a bit bland. Most of the dining room will consist of Indian people. My friends were also Indian which may be why I felt the service was really great. We didn't need a reservation; we just walked in and were seated immediately. The man behind the counter was really nice to us as well.

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: Excellent food which captures the essence of South Indian cuisine. Chanced upon this place when searching for a place to eat. Interestingly they don't have a set price for their buffet style meal- it's pay what you can. Their buffet lunch consisted of typical South Indian fare and a dosa station, where you can get your customized dosa. The wait staff were really friendly and helpful, and served lassi as well. I was amazed at the type of service and would recommend anyone visiting Singapore to try out this place. Fun fact : they have restaurants in Chennai, Coimbatore and Perth as well. I'm not sure if they have the same kind of system in those places, but I would definitely check it out if I were to visit those places .

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: We were visiting Singapore and while searching for a good Indian restaurant we found this place. It was a fantastic experience and food When is the last time we heard , pay the price what you feel like after having a lunch. If some restaurant can claim such things then they have to be super confident of their  quality. This family owned business serve food as a service and not as business and their passion just reflected in the quality of food . Must visit place if you are searching for good food in Singapore

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: Average food and they charge $15 per person. Taste and quality of food not worth the money spent. Staff at front desk not friendly. Overall not a great experience, one time visit for sake of it.

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: Good vegetarian food, good ambiance. Good find. Buffet style and nicely spiced/flavourful. Feels authentic.

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: Pros: The buffet is very good with a nice variety and lots of flavor. I always enjoy it and walk away satisfied. Cons: I don't think any of the employees are happy people. They can be very weird about giving you a seat. They should wash the tablecloths; it's rather unsavory to see them flick away the food crumbs from a table then seat the next guests. Makes me wonder where else they're taking shortcuts on cleanliness. I also dislike listening to the servers snorting their snotty phlegm as they walk around the dining room.

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: We had a craving for South Indian food and this was right across the road from the hotel and hence got into this one. However the management was fairly rude - as soon as we entered an elderly lady asked us if we had reservation and since we didn't have one she gave a discourse on how we should have a reservation on weekends and that too when 50% of the restaurant was empty!! We still wanted to try the food and hence sat down..the food was just about decent. The moong dal and the potato curry was good but the rest of the food was just average. The management definitely needs some lesson on hospitality! The only good thing is that they let the customer decide the price depending on how satisfied you are.

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: Food was great. And you pay whatever you want. Must go here if you're seeking tasty vegetarian Indian food in Singapore.

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: Good experience: good food and service. They just dont have my Rasmalai. Interesting payment: pay as you wish, I hope no one abuses this

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: Excellent food, as others have said feels like home cooking. Plenty of choice, have been many times and the family always enjoy. One of our favourite places in Singapore. Never know what to pay and probably go over the odds, but quite happy with that.

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: Extremely busy place at lunch. Food is great, place is clean, buffet style, and pay what you think is fair. What more could you ask for?My opinion is that $7 for lunch is fair. This was confirmed by the indians i work with. So, i think $7 for lunch and $10 for dinner is appropo.

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: While I love the concept, the selection was very limited and the food was pretty bland. The naan was also nothing to text or post about. It also leaves a bit to be desired in the area of cleanliness. One saving grace, the mango lassi was amazing.

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: Three stars for the concept. Food is very average as its made by volunteers who have a different day job. Good for when you are in a charitable mood.

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: Lovely homemade Indian food! Feels like eating at home. :) The buffet has a lot of choice, rasam, dals, rice, sabjis, pappadams and bhajis. You can ask for buttermilk or lassi, depending on what they offer for the day. I love the concept of the restaurant as well, you pay as much as you like! I haven't seen any other restaurant doing that! Appreciate the trust!

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: Operated by the Temple of Fine Arts, Annalakshmi is an international chain of non-profit vegetarian restaurant run by volunteers. It lives by the concept of "Eat as you want, Give as you Feel", so there are no prices on the menu. Instead, patrons leave a donation of how much they think the food is worth and all the proceeds go to charity.Adorned with Indian decorations and lined with a haze of sweet smelling incense, it is obvious that the restaurant has a deep-rooted culture waiting to be revealed. Indeed, this culture is apparent from the authenticity of the dishes. The food at Annalakshmi is lovingly prepared by the volunteers and served on a buffet table. The wide array of selection incorporates flavours from North and South India, with dishes ranging from poori to oothapam and masala to dhal, amongst other gravies and sauces. With food so authentic, you can almost taste the tradition! The dishes are rotated periodically and vary within branches so that regular patrons are offered more food options.

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: Nice philosophy (not for profit restaurant that contributes to arts and charities)... we stopped in for lunch and it was pretty average... nothing exciting...  one of the dishes was spicy and tasty but the rest were pretty uninteresting...   also, the buffet food was only vaguely warm...

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: "Eat what you want, give what you feel"Yes, Annalakshmi is THAT restaurant, the one that doesn't charge but leaves it to you to offer what you wish to. It's fully staffed by volunteers, and is the culinary arts expression of the Temple of Fine Arts (TFA), an artistic and cultural organisation dedicated to serving the society through arts, music and dance. They've been around in Singapore since 1986, and I remember visiting them at the beautifully decked out Excelsior Hotel outlet, which then moved to Chinatown Point, and now Central Square. The buffet is my favourite part of dining here, with its free flow of lassi and masala chai, and the line-up usually has a great variety of dhal, masala vegetables and a curry or two. Bear in mind that it's pure vegetarian, and that it's not polite to waste the food that's been carefully and lovingly prepared by the volunteers. Always a great experience.

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: Wonderfull food and extremely friendly staff. After a long day of sigh-seeing and stuggling in hot sun, this is something we wanted. Its 7-8mins walk from clarke quay.

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: Food was spot on and would probably pay twice to three times what I paid in the states. So good - thank you and looking forward to going back!

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: I used to frequent the Annalakshmi at Chinatown Point until they moved that outlet to Central Square in Clarke Quay (not to be confused with Central Mall). Was afraid that it would be a different experience at the new outlet but my fears were unfounded! The decor remains as beautifully intricate and this outlet is definitely much brighter than the previous and also much bigger too. One of the best thing about this place is that its a pay-as-you-wish indian vegetarian restaurant - its run by volunteers and the money you pay at the end of your meal goes towards an organization that cultivates Indian arts and cultural development - it sounds like the perfect arrangement. You may wonder how they keep the business running by letting customers pay however much they like but you'd be surprised how much people can feel generous after a good meal!It has a good selection of vegetarian Indian food from rice to poori to naan to oothapam and a few types of vadai. The drinks also have a good selection, the mango lassi is one my faves and I like to end my meals with a nice hot cup of spiced masala tea. If you come on friday and weekends, it's a buffet for lunch and dinner - not a bad selection but limited to only whats on the buffet table. Come for dinner on mon to thursdays to have the best selection of food from the menu.Final verdict: One of the best feel-good restaurants- good food, good ambience and all for a good cause!

address: Blk 20, Havelock Road #01-04, Central Square Singapore 059765 Singapore
comment: I have been going to Annalakshmi for years. It is one of the best places to find Indian vegetarian food in Singapore. This place is very interesting as it is run totally by volunteers and patrons pay what they like. They either have a full buffet or ala carte and everything is fresh and very good. You can order a selection of drinks like lassi or chai masala tea. It can get pretty crowded here sometimes so it is a good idea to make a reservation. The staff are all volunteers and sometimes they can be a bit grumpy.

address: 3B River Valley Rd #01-15 The Foundry Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Good find! The good was very very good. We had the 350g Australian ribeye. Perfectly cooked and so tasty. I noticed immediately they let the beef speak for itself. It didn't have a ton of seasoning and it didn't need it. The roasted garlic added to the steak, as did the peppercorn sauce. I loved the creamed spinach. It was great. I was so mad when I went into the main room, we ate outside, and saw the beautiful aged beef. It was on the menu, but I somehow had my eye on the ribeye. Next time. The service was excellent. The server was very attentive. I liked that the manager came over to see if everything was "perfect". Overall very good. You won't go wrong here. Don't get crazy about the pricing. It's Singapore!  It is in line with most places. Sit outside and people watch. Have fun fans.

address: 3B River Valley Rd #01-15 The Foundry Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Gave 2 stars for service... waiter hovered a bit too much but was very pleasant.Steak had no flavor... consider some flavors rubs and add moisture to steaks! Top with fresh herb butters...nothing like a dollop of herb butter. Skillet sides were skimpy... fill up at least halfway, would look better.Crab cake was excellent tho and French Onion Soup was tasty. Very pricey for a steak with no flavor.

address: 3B River Valley Rd #01-15 The Foundry Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: A reasonably priced, good quality, steakhouse in Singapore. There you go, what more you need?A not insanely priced wine list? Yep. That's it.

address: Blk E 3 River Valley Rd #01-08 Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: We wanted authentic Singaporean food, and boy did we get it. 4 stars is probably a stretch here, as I was pretty grossed out by the menu. Luckily I spied the sign that warned of a $50 charge if you vomit on the premises. So needless to say I skipped out on the pig intestines and just ate some sautéed bok choy and noodles. My friends really enjoyed the chicken and rice, which looked about as authentic of a dish as you could get. Not much ambiance here. Just plop down at a table (hopefully near one of those portable air conditioners) order a few ice cold Tiger beers, and then have at the menu. Definitely the kind of place for an adventurous eater. In my defense, I ate a bunch of animal innards on my last trip to Tokyo, but vowed never again. But if that's your thing, then XiaoChenGuShi is your kind of place. Enjoy!

address: Blk E 3 River Valley Rd #01-08 Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: I came here with a local friend. It is next to Zouk and open quite late. They serve an assortment of items ranging from noodles to pig meat. We ordered two noodles along with some pig meat. The food was pretty good though small in portion, and I could see it appealing to those after a night out. I would recommend it for a quick, cheap, and satisfying bite with some local flare.

The food is pretty good, albeit on the pricey side, for the portions. Service was prompt and polite. Our server had a great sense of humour. A lovely selection of warm bread was offered as soon as we sat down. We had the pumpkin soup and burratina cheese and pesto to start. The burratina was excellent. The pumpkin soup was topped with pumpkin seeds, which added some nice crunch and texture, although the soup spoon would've been better and cheaper.For the mains, we had the ravioles du royans (ok), the haddock (pretty good), iberian ham carbonara (great) and the iberico pork secreto (excellent, melt in your mouth). Unfortunately, we didn't have space for dessert. Will definitely come back if in area
I ordered Grab food. Portions not like photo.Salmon was tasty. Octopus over cooked. Portions small. Maybe I go there and see if they just skimp when being delivered. And update review

Always greeted with a smile. Very friendly staff at Porta and hotel. Food and drinks selection is fantastic and something for everyone. The Spanish octopus is fantastic, so full of fresh flavor. Enjoy the friendship of the staff, the delicious food and drinks. Very nice place to relax either indoors or outdoors.

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: This place is great. My wife is celiac and Vietnamese cuisine is easy to eat gluten-free.The quality of the food is amazing. It is a locally owned establishment and they definitely take pride in their work. Definitely worth a stop!

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: Decent prices for good sized Banh Mi sandwiches. This place is right inside of UE square  shopping mall on the first floor. It's a small restaurant but they offer outside seating. Inside is very small but they packed 5 tables that fit 4 people. There was one table inside for a couple. It's possible to have big group.Drinks are a different story when it comes to prices. It's more than half the prices of our sandwiches. Service was ok but they had three servers that were busy.  Our food came out very slow but came out with the bread warm. All three different meats ( beef,  Pork & chicken) look the same but was actually very good with distinct flavors. I wish there was more vegetables in the sandwiches though.  I have to rate this three stars as the rest of the menu for rice and soup dishes were very expensive to me  that's why we opted for the sandwiches. Still, the banh mi sandwiches are  double the price where i'm from. Would come again if I had no choice. [24/100]

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: Whoa, waygu pho in a cast iron bowl.  Amazing.   Nice small restaurant, has an A rating too.

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: We live in Robertson Quay and this is our go to place. Reasonable prizes with good portions. Had my share of spring rolls around Singapore, so far these are the freshest and best. Good gluten free option.

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: Went for lunch after reading the positive reviews in Yelp and internet. They did not have banh mi, 1st disappointment. Ordered the raw beef pho $11.50++/ bowl, quite high price for the quality --- pho (rice noodle) was soggy/ limp (no longer translucent) and the broth was surprisingly weak in flavor, 2nd disappointment.  They have to charge $1 for water (3rd disappointment). Don't think I will go back

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: Outstanding banh mi, sullen service.We love banh mi, and think this the best we've had. Fresh, crunchy bread. Fresh, flavourful meats. Enough vegetables to nicely enhance. Lovely.Only downside was the service, which acted like they would've preferred to be left alone.

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: Stopped here on my first day in Singapore for a quick lunch . I had the fried seafood spring rolls and the BBQ chicken sandwich. Both were top notch and the homemade lemon iced tea was out of this world. I'll definitely be back before I leave.

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: My boyfriend and I stopped here for lunch in Jul when we were in Singapore. A unique design of old Vietnam. My boyfriend had BBQ pork banh mi while i had Bun thit nuong (BBQ pork cold vermicelli noodles). I like the BBQ pork taste which is very much Vietnamese authentic cuisine (just a minor thing is it was a bit salty to me). I had been trying different Vietnamese food in different countries and this place has the best Vietnamese dishes.

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave UE Square Shopping Mall Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: Yay for reasonably priced Vietnamese food and dining experiences! All the dishes you would expect are here (pho, banh mi, other noodle dishes I don't know the names of but have been assured are classic and popular) and the place had just enough people for a weekday lunch (neither annoyingly full nor awkwardly empty). You can sit inside (just a tiiiiiiiny bit cramped) or outside. My friend brought me here so you can be assured at least one Vietnamese person in Singapore approves of this place. ;)

address: 3E River Valley Road #01-07 Clarke Quay Block E Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: Bungy Bar, next to the bungy at Clarke Quay, very clever and original choice of name?? :P Though seriously, great bar, I  have had many a good night here with mates, always a good atmosphere out in the open air by the river, though add a good game of rugby, some cold beer and plenty of expats who barrack for opposing sides and this feels like that little slice of home. Prices are really reasonable, happy hour is not to be missed, and only a couple of visits and you'll be on first name basis with their friendly staff. The unexpected screams followed by the fear of flying vomit as the bungy fly's upwards can be a little annoying once you've had a few drinks if I want to look for negatives, though this is a fantastic spot to start a big night out, or catch up on some good Aussie sport.

address: 3E River Valley Road #01-07 Clarke Quay Block E Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: I'm in two minds about this place. In one sense it was a pretty decent, and somewhat grungy, pub, but in another sense it was, well, not all that impressive. Okay, the huge bungy cord sling shot next to it probably does set itself apart from your typical bar, however I'm not all that keen on being tied to a chair and thrown up into the air for little more than an adrenalin rush. The staff were nice, and the prices rather average, but other than that there wasn't anything about this place that really stood out to me.

address: 3E River Valley Road #01-07 Clarke Quay Block E Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: A great bar to chill and hang out with mates. They also take a big role in sponsoring the local sporting teams - Bedok Kings for example. Right next to the Reverse Bungy and the Swing, come and check it out.

address: 3C River Valley Road #01-07, The Cannery Singapore 179022 Singapore
comment: Never heard of lobster ramen until Singapore, so I had to check it out. To my surprise they had a nice selection of beverages: cokes and frozen kirin. I loved that they served so many things I could never find in SF. There was a queue outside but it wasn't too bad. Their complimentary spicy bean sprouts were pretty good. & The cost was the same as a standard bowl in SF. Overall, I enjoyed my meal. It's more like a 4.5/5 but I can't give half stars. The only reason it's not a 5 star, is because it was pretty heavy. When they say rich, it's rich!

address: 3C River Valley Road #01-07, The Cannery Singapore 179022 Singapore
comment: Popped in here after a riverboat and city tour that ended in Clarke Quay. Saw they were open late and I took advantage of the fact that things were very slow at the moment I wanted to go in.Ordered the rich lobster broth ramen with a seasoned egg, some extras and also  without mushrooms. I would suggest going with the standard bowl of ramen, and not getting extras unless you are still hungry or think that you're going to need them.When you walk in, there are boiled eggs on each table and they provide pickled mung beans for you to eat as a side dish. The ramen came out steaming hot, the broth was very flavorful and I was stuffed once I finished everything. I can say it's not overly salty like many places in the USA. Felt very authentic and I was glad to pay the bill when it arrived. I also tipped a few bucks and I think the server was genuinely surprised to receive anything- I think the culture here does not tip? I still did some nominal tipping where I went...felt like something right to do. They offer a lot of sides and other items you can eat here- probably nice if you had a group so you can share. Didn't drink anything but I noticed if you're thirsty there's plenty of bars and restaurants to peruse when you're here. I never made much time for nightlife this visit- but now I know this is beautiful and robust for those who want to enjoy themselves moving forward.

address: 3C River Valley Road #01-07, The Cannery Singapore 179022 Singapore
comment: The only reason I'm not giving this place five stars is because I've only been once. Seriously solid 4.5 experience. This is the perfect place for a late night supper after hitting the bars in clarke quay. The ramen has a distinctive lobster flavor, and is thick and delicious. You can customize your toppings; I highly suggest adding an egg. They cook the egg perfectly, as well as the noodles. Wavy and delicious!I'm getting hungry writing this review - a sign that it's time to head back!

address: 3C River Valley Road #01-07, The Cannery Singapore 179022 Singapore
comment: As the name suggests, this place specializes in lobster ramen! Note that they don't actually serve lobster at all, but the broth seems to taste like lobster. Overall the ramen was quite good and unique here (though not spectacular) and I had a good experience overall.Ramen:I ordered the Rich Broth Ramen with a flavoured egg. The broth was quite rich and flavourful, though more simple than I expected. You can definitely taste lobster flavour in it, which separate this place from most ramen places around. The chashu, noodles, and egg were all solid as well. If you get the Special toppings, it also comes with lobster balls, extra shashu, and seaweed.Service/Wait:We arrived at 6:20pm on a Sunday dinner and there was no queue or wait at all. For a party of 7, they seated us in our own room and the service was quite attentive and fast.Price: $$Pretty standard as far as ramen goes. The basic bowls (pretty much just noodles, chashu, and soup) were $16. With a flavoured egg, it becomes $18. And for the Special toppings, it's $20.

address: 3C River Valley Road #01-07, The Cannery Singapore 179022 Singapore
comment: There was a slight queue on Friday nite but it moved quickly. Being a member, I received free green tea soda. After ordering, helped myself to the hard boiled egg and marinated bean sprout. I was surprised to find water coming out from the hard boiled egg which I was trying to crack. Turned out there was a big black dot on the egg. I did not dare to eat and cracked another egg which did not have the same problem. I did tell the staff about it while clearing the table but received no response. Kaku High Ball (Suntory whisky with soda) ($12)Refreshing but no ball shaped ice cube :(Alcohol taste lacking.Spicy Miso Lobster broth Ramen Special ($21.90)The spicy paste had minced meat in it, not too spicy in taste. Felt that the spicy taste reduced the salty taste of the soup. The char siew could be more tender. The lobster balls were still my favourite. The wanton skin was still too thick and could not hold the filling. Need to improve on the wanton. Overall service not bad. There was bag basket for bags. Free wifi at the restaurant.

address: 3C River Valley Road #01-07, The Cannery Singapore 179022 Singapore
comment: You get free (unlimited) bean sprouts and hard boiled eggs at this place! I love adding the bean sprouts to my ramen, especially since ramen dishes tend to not feature veggies. I got the spicy miso lobster ramen special, which had a lot of goodies like lobster balls, spicy mince meat paste, and dumplings. It was pricey (over $20) but it was worth the splurge since I've never tried lobster ramen! The broth was really thick and aromatic, but got tiring after a while. If you are looking for a lighter broth option, go with the regular lobster ramen. One thing I noticed was that they use different noodles for the different broths. That was my first time seeing a ramen shop do that, and I found that incredibly thoughtful. The wait time is really annoying (I think we spent 45 mins standing outside) but at least they give you water while you wait. It's open late too so I imagine it being a great place for drunchies!!

address: 3C River Valley Road #01-07, The Cannery Singapore 179022 Singapore
comment: I went there for dinner around 7pm on Friday where there was still no queue. I ordered a rich broth ramen which is their signature with all topping, cost $21.90 and a bottle of wasabi ginger ale... I think that's only gimmick which I didn't taste any wasabi (luckyly it wasn't...)The broth is very rich with lobster sweetness but it appear to be slightly too salty to me. And I personally prefer thicker noodle but they only offer one type of noodle which is the thin type. It is 3.5 stars.. Not really motivated to go back there if I don't have to...

address: 3C River Valley Road #01-07, The Cannery Singapore 179022 Singapore
comment: With all the hype surrounding this lobster ramen, I had to try it. Popped by on a Wednesday night at about 11pm, and there was no queue. I got the lobster rich broth ramen with all the toppings, and my companion got the clear broth one. The rich broth tastes like a lobster bisque, and the clear one is very light and flavorful. There are no lobster pieces within the ramen, so don't get your hopes up. The soup is quite nice, but it get tiresome and brought down by lackluster toppings and the ramen itself. I was quite disappointed with my noodles, because I ordered the ramen to be cooked "hard", yet the ramen was soggy and mushy. I would have rather it not have any noodles. The toppings were nothing to shout about; greasy prawn balls, wantons with too little filling, a lone stalk of veggie, some chashu (possibly sous vide as it was very tender). They have free flow hard boiled eggs and bean sprouts, but nothing very much. Would I return? Probably not. I didn't finish my food.

address: 3C River Valley Road #01-07, The Cannery Singapore 179022 Singapore
comment: Ra Ra(men)... Ooh La la.It's official, Keisuke Ramen has officially taken over Singapore and has now become one of if not the number one chain of Ramen restaurants in Singapore! While I haven't been overly impressed with Tendon, their Tempura bowl restaurant, I really haven't had much to complain about their ramen restaurants. Though I haven't tried, Tonkotsu King and Orchid Hotel looks an ever popular "to-go-restaurant", their restaurant at Suntec has been good too and the Crab broth is a delight and now, Lobster King at Clarke Quay is making waves! We finally managed to bring ourselves down to Lobster King to give it a shot and we were not disappointed. Located at the heart of Clarke Quay (and right next to the soon to be re-located Zouk), Lobster King's rich lobster broth ramen has to be the ultimate hangover food. In terms of variety? Not much, with only the option of thick broth, light broth, Miso or spicy Miso. However, don't let the lack of options turn you away because what they do well is a delicious bowl of ramen. With the option of either without flavoured egg (Ajisuke Tomago), with egg or extra ingredients, we went without the egg, solely because the restaurant gives you free hard boiled eggs. YES! FREE! Oh, that and free bean sprouts as well. So we went with the trademark... Lobster Broth Ramen with Rich Creamy Broth The broth is definitely rich and definitely very tasty! Served with a good amount of Leak, a piece of torched pork, a piece of chicken and a dumpling,  this dish definitely hit the mark. The first thing we noticed was the noodles. Unlike other ramen joints, the noodle seemed different. Judging from the texture and look, we figured that it was probably a buck wheat or whole wheat mix, which works perfectly well with this broth as it allowed the broth to coat the noodle without soaking it fully, which may have made it over powering. The leak helped add balance to the dish, giving it a bit of pungent-ness to help cut the richness. The pork, which tender and juicy, got a bit lost in the dish for me, thanks to the broth but the chicken was surprisingly good. It was tender, juicy and the texture felt like it had been sous vide. The dumpling was a nice surprise.He skin tasted a little Gyoza-ish but thicker and it helped soak in the stock. The prawn they stuffed in it was nice and sweet too, bringing out the "lobster-ness" of the dish. On a side note, do note that the broth might be overpowering and salty so if an overly rich broth isn't for you, I would suggest the much lighter looking clear broth instead. Oh yes.... And please note that although the name is Lobster King, don't be disappointed when you find out that the lobster is in the broth and you don't get a fat piece of Lobster Tail in the ramen, but than again, at $14.90, I suppose that's expected. Overall, we do like it a lot. May be a little too rich to have it often but when we do crave the rich broth and can get away from the standard pork broth, we will be back!

address: 3C River Valley Road #01-07, The Cannery Singapore 179022 Singapore
comment: My first time here to try out the lobster broth.I ordered the rich broth with all sides added in for $20.90.The broth was okay, but did not really feel there's enough lobster flavour in it....taste more like crab broth.My friend ordered the same as mine & could not finish the noodle as the broth made her stomach feel very filling drinking it.The Gyoza tasted more like Chinese dumplings, not like the ones in Japan.As for the green tea cola, it's was great, which goes well with the food due to the salty flavour.Overall 3 stars.For me I still prefer the Tonkotsu King....

address: 3C River Valley Road #01-07, The Cannery Singapore 179022 Singapore
comment: For a traveler on the wrong time zone, this place was open at 3AM! for some mid night ramen. The food was great, and it was so nice to have a place to eat at such an odd hour.

address: 3C River Valley Road #01-07, The Cannery Singapore 179022 Singapore
comment: Imagine serving this to Chinese or French or Japanese grandmothers 50 years ago! HahaI reckon this dish to be a fusion of French-Japanese-Chinese influences. Ramen is first and foremost, a Japanese take on traditional Chinese "la-mian". And lobster bisque is a traditional French dish. Anyway, the coming together of these influences works quite well. Toppings of chicken, dumpling and char siu were generous. But in my opinion, the broth gets too cloyingly rich and salty after a few mouthfuls. It needed a few dashes of vinegar to enliven the heavy richness. Also, it could do without the heavy hit of MSG. After all, lobster shells should lend enough umami to the broth. I was thirsty halfway through the bowl, and so were my table mates. Keisuke ramen are such MSG-bombs. ;(It was an interesting bowl of noodles but would I have it again? Maybe, and only if there wasn't such a long queue outside.

address: 3C River Valley Road #01-07, The Cannery Singapore 179022 Singapore
comment: Soooo ono!!! Best ramen we've had in a long time!!! Open 'til 4am, score!!! Got here after the rooftop bar around 3:30a

address: 3C River Valley Road #01-07, The Cannery Singapore 179022 Singapore
comment: We had the miso lobster ramen special and the spicy miso lobster ramen special after midnight so there was no queue. The broth was very thick with almost overwhelming taste of lobster. It was perfect for dunking the free flow of cooked bean sprouts. The free flow of boiled eggs made a nice appetizer. We liked being able to customize the strength of the broth (saltiness), the amount of oil and the firmness of the noodles. The location is superb and in the thick of the nightlife in Singapore. The decor is also very nice. We think we still prefer the tonkatsu broth over the lobster broth, but if you love lobster, this is the place for you!

address: 3C River Valley Road #01-07, The Cannery Singapore 179022 Singapore
comment: I think the ramen here is pretty average, good to try it at least once though. The thick broth felt too much after awhile and it wasn't particular tasty. The texture of the ramen tasted pretty standard, nothing special. Though the place offers free flow boiled eggs and bean sprouts, it felt kind of unnecessary. Perhaps, I would opt for the light broth the next time I visit the place.

Muslim Nasi Padang. Basically Muslim mixed rice.I couldn't have stumbled upon this place since it was quite hidden. I had to ask for directions. On the 3rd floor, beside the bridge across People Park and Chinatown Point, next to the UOB ATM.The taste is authentic. The curry chicken somehow looks "overnight" but a bite tells otherwise. The sides are very surprisingly mild to the palate, not too spicy, just right. Sweet is the word.For $5.70 it is slightly pricey, but that's what we pay in town.

This. Place. Is. Amazing.Their signature collagen soup is another level, and the main reason why people queue around the shopping centre just waiting for a table here. So... it's busy, and as many have indicated, you will have to wait for a table... but don't give up! It's totally worth it.The collagen soup - Bijin Nabe - comes with the freshest of vegetables, some skewered prawns, and some mushrooms. After melting the pot for around 10 minutes, throw in your veggies for a few more and dish up. It's an experience to remember.Wash the whole thing down with a sparkling sake, and you have a meal made in heaven.5 stars, with a bullet.

Heard so many raves about the "Mei Ren Guo" or Beauty Pot, and finally got to try it out at a gathering with old friends. Was not disappointed with the delicious thick collagen broth. The set came with good portions of fresh ingredients including chicken and prawns, was particularly intrigued by the watermelon radish that gave the meal a beautiful presentation. The broth was incredible - tasty with natural flavors of the ingredients rather than seasoning, and we could really see how potently concentrated the soup was with it slowly solidifying back into its jelly form when removed from the heat source. Pity the set meal only allowed a one time top up of the soup, and additional soup would be charged more. It's understandable I guess, given probably a limited supply with a lot of work to cooking it. Not a cheap meal certainly, but an enjoyable one as a whole!
There are not lot of choice for Vegetarian and for people who eat fish! Fried sweet potato and unagi fried rice were just OK. Service was very friendly.

They don't serve the collagen soup for lunch on week days, only for dinner. On weekends, you can order it for lunch and dinner.The broth is thick and wholesome with full smell and taste of chicken. In fact, we didn't need to order anything else other than the soup and it's accompaniment. The vegetable accompanying the soup is organic and you can taste their sweetness.Besides eating, for the ladies, they perceive that they are getting a collagen infusion (hopefully to the face and not tummy) whilst they are eating. Fantastic!

When I was first introduced to the idea of collagen pudding, I assumed it was some newfangled skin treatment that "all the Hollywood stars" were obsessing over. When I learned it came from jidori chickens, and that you were meant to enjoy it by eating it, I nearly lost my breakfast. That is, until I sipped my first spoonful of this rich, creamy, formerly-gelatinous gluttony. It was love at first slurp and I'll never turn back.Known for its hotpot, Tsukada Nojo was pleasantly calm and quiet at lunchtime when they serve ramen using their same signature rich-as-all-get-out chicken collagen broth. And apparently in the same fashion as their hotpot ritual, when your soup comes out, all of the toppings are on the side and you are encouraged to taste the soup through each stage of its evolution, sampling different flavours as you drop in greens, cabbage, egg, chicken, seaweed, and yuzu rind. The organic jidori chicken was exceptionally flavourful and I could have eating about 10 more strips of it on its own... but I guess I'll have to save that for my impending "beauty pot" experience.

A tasty, healthy, and reasonably priced ($25++ per person) Japanese steamboat. How often do you get all three at the same time?? The problem is that it's just so hard to get a table here. Arrive later than 5:30pm, even on weekdays, and you'll have to wait over 45 minutes to be seated.The main draw is the steamboat, which comes with a thick and hearty chicken collagen soup base. The accompanying ingredients are fresh and of quality. They only serve chicken ramen on weekday lunches, with the same delicious soup base.Their marketing claims the soup is made from nothing but organic Japanese chickens and salt. I can believe that - it's rich but yet clean and refreshing. And tastes of chicken. And salt.They've got a cute customer loyalty programme where you get a name card describing you as their "assistant manager". You get promoted to "manager" and beyond as you visit. The rewards are decent - on the second visit, I was offered a choice of edamame or fries.They have high chairs for your toddlers, and mine just loves drinking the soup.

address: The Central 6 Eu Tong St #01-15 #02-17 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Finding a place to eat during Lunar New Year's Eve is hard enough. Finding one where food standards are still high despite the festive period is even harder. Fortunately, Fisherman's Market did not disappoint. We always wanted to give it a try after hearing good things about it. After all, its operated by a popular Japanese chain and its their first restaurant here. To our surprise, prices were the same as their usual despite the special occasion. It was also not crowded at all, leaving us plenty of elbow room to pick and choose from the wide variety of food available. The staff was reasonably friendly and efficient when clearing the tables. Besides the seafood and sashimi, there was also plenty of other dishes so much so that my parents who are picky eaters did not have a complain at all. Definitely one for seafood lovers.

address: The Central 6 Eu Tong St #01-15 #02-17 Singapore 059817 Singapore
comment: Fishermen's Market offers a delectable spread of fresh seafood. Indulge in succulent slices of tuna and salmon sashimi, work your way through the chewy octopus slices or have one s'hell of a time with the generous servings of fresh prawns and fresh oysters. If you think the sashimis are the only highlight, you are so wrong. The magic fingers of the chefs at Fishermen's Market puts out an astounding spread of over 90 dishes made from various seafood flown in from all parts of the world.You also get pizzas, soups, curries and other cooked dishes warmed in cute pots. There's something for everyone as you can hit the European palate with the Provence Style Mussles and Cheese Fondue, engage the Asian in you with the Japanese Sushi, Fried Mackeral Tatsuta Style and freshly-prepared Tempura or find your way back home with the local delicacies of the Chilli Crab and the Black Pepper Crab.The spread of all the savory food seems like an indulgence enough but really, the meal is just starting with the desserts available at Fishermen's Market. You can get a platter of fruits to cleanse the system, nip cubes of creamed cakes and Creme Brulee off the trays or just stick to the sure-win combination of fluffy white marshmallows with gooey, warm chocolate dip at the Fondue station. Food is not amazing but decent, probably suitable if you will like to treat your colleagues to a good meal after wrapping up a deal.

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave #01-22 UE Square Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: This is the newest place in UE Square, replacing an ill-fated kopitiam that had no charm at all. Eat Me immediately strikes as a simple salad bar or vegetarian restaurant, mainly because of their tagline "Lettuce satisfy you" (pun fully intended, I think). Fortunately, it's more than that.While vegetarian and vegan restaurants resort to preaching about how unhealthy, foolish and downright evil it is to eat any kind of animal product, Eat Me focuses on taste, freshness and balance. They don't eradicate meat or animal protein from their menu. Instead, they use it in sensible portions, as a complement to fresh veggies, just as your nutritionist surely told you to do. Another good thing is they emphasise the use of local and organic products. Vegetables are always fresh, and if combined with a bit of egg, duck, fish or beef, there's no way they can go wrong.Eat Me's salads are delightful, and so are their very own cold-pressed juices. The make-your-own baked potatoes look tasty, but I have to try them yet. The star for me (and for many other customers, it seems)  is the Hulk Toast: a flavourful omelette served over a thick slice of wholegrain bread with heavenly avocado, cherry tomatoes and sesame seeds. I'm not a big fan of omelettes myself, but this is fantastically well done. It has become my favourite local breakfast. Coffee is provided by the famous Sarnies. It's not the best, but it's certainly superior than what can be found at UE Square.Among the overpriced bars, franchise coffee shops and fancy places around UE Square, Eat Me shines for their healthy, honest, unpretentious and appetising food. It is truly refreshing to have a local restaurant that serves healthy food that sells itself on taste, with no need for preaching. I'm a big fan already.Curious fact: they managed to get rid of the burnt fat smell that loomed in the kopitiam that was there before. That alone is a reason to admire them.

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave #01-22 UE Square Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: Although close to Robertson Quay and it's abundance of restaurants, UE Square has been pretty much a barren wasteland.  So when I heard about this new restaurant with the interesting name I thought I'd try it.Ostensibly it's a salad place.  Which sounded good to me.  The problem was in the execution of, well, pretty much everything.  It took about fifteen minutes to get our drinks served, and another 15 to get our salads.  This despite the fact that there were only a few diners there.   The salads consisted of wilted lettuce that looked like it had gone bad a few days ago.  Veggies that were either past their peak or poorly chosen.   And flavorlessly cooked beef and chicken.   It seems the owners put too much effort into being hip hipster hippies and not enough into learning how to choose ingredients and cook them properly.To sum it up: Bad, slow service.  Terrible food.   With so many great places to eat nearby, coming here is a foolhardy mistake.Cross it off your list.  This is one place that needs to be economically Darwined out of existence.

address: 81 Clemenceau Ave #01-22 UE Square Singapore 239917 Singapore
comment: Location is amazing for this place. If you live in Robertson Quay /River Valle area, no doubt you have been clamoring for a nice place to get some good clean healthy food. Salads that make you think, hmm I guess salads are not bad after all. You may have been going home after working in the CBD area and thinking to yourself, "What I would do for a place similar to Grain Traders, or just something else other than the bar food that surrounds the area....well wait no longer true believer because "Eat Me" is here to save us all. The cafe is conveniently located in UE square, in the area where the Kopitiam used to be, and boy am I glad that this was the place to take the space over. Eat Me's tag line is "Lettuce satisfy you" (hehe) and the they do not disappoint. Once you stop giggling at some of the creative names on the menu (like "Posh Spice" and "Big Miss Steak" and finally get your food, your palates are treated to plethora of euphoric sensations. Best of all, you finish the food and you are actually full and you also do not get dragged down or feel heavy. Perfect for after working out. I've been here twice now and have tried the Daffy Duck and Big Miss steak, I'm definitely coming to try everything.The place also served breakfast! I have yet to try but they look yummy.Oh and they have also just started putting cold press juices on the menu. I had the "coconut, green apple, spinach and cucumber" juice...and yes it tastes even better than it sounds! Can't wait to come back to this place!
Got the voucher on groupon at around 26 bucks per person which makes it one of the cheapest Chinese hot pot I've ever tried in Singapore... Anyway the qualify of the food is not bad
Expensive but with good quality. I like the fish broth, the Angus beef, and all the dipping sauces. I had dinner there, not dinner buffet.

Tanyoto is one of the more expensive steamboat establishments in Singapore. They serve good quality and fresh ingredients in a calm and serene environment. Having steamboat in a hot tropical country may seem a bit strange since it is normally more enjoyable in a colder climate, but I must say that a quieter and cooler environment will make all the difference to having a great steamboat dinner in Singapore!The fish head is one of the must haves (not a fan of fish heads but my dinner companions loved it). The fish and beef slices are fresh and absolutely delicious. And they have a very good range of other ingredients that you can order. On top of the steamboat offerings, they also serve many appetizers.You have to make your own sauces at a special sauce counter at the side. They can definitely improve this by bringing the different sauce ingredients to the table and offer to mix them for you like another steamboat establishment of this price range.I did find the dinner rather enjoyable and I would definitely keep this place in mind if I am ever craving for some good quality steamboat!

Discovered this place through a supper buffet voucher I bought.  This place dish out pretty good Chinese-style (Mala) steamboat.  Don't worry if you can't stomach spicy mala broth, you can opt for their non spicy ones.  The ingredients are fresh and there is a pretty wide range of items to choose from. They also have a sauce station where you can customized your own dipping sauce for the steamboat.On the whole, I am very satisfied with the service and food here. The service here is good. Guess its supposed to be a more upclass steamboat joint. haha! The food is great but its kinda of heavy for the stomach especially since its supper. Thankfully, its not just a supper place, maybe I should go back to the restaurant during lunch or dinner.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #02-01/02, Liang Court Shopping Centre Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: I've been to Marutama Ramen in Vancouver, BC, and was VERY pleasantly surprised to find one here in Singapore!!!  The ramen offered here is different than most other Japanese ramen spots - it's not salt, soyu, miso, or pork based broth.  It's a chicken based broth, a cloudy chicken based broth.  That alone might off-putting to some people, but they should really give it a try!  We ordered the regular and spicy ramen.  As I've done in Vancouver, I tasted the broth first, then added the table side accompaniments.  Those garnishes include garlic chips, togarashi, and sesame seeds.  The ramen is just as I remembered, glad to know Marutama Ramen is consistent across oceans.  The noodles were cooked perfectly, the chicken broth had the right amount of salty flavor, the cha-shu pork also added more depth to the broth.  We added an egg to our ramen order, it was a perfectly cooked soft boiled egg, and once broken added more creaminess to the broth!  Seriously, the perfect bowl on a rainy day in Singapore!!!

address: 177 River Valley Rd #02-01/02, Liang Court Shopping Centre Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: I had dinner at Marutama tonight after several years. I ordered the regular ramen with pork. The noodles were soft, which was to my liking, but may be considered overdone for those who like theirs al dente. The broth was also a tad too salty for my liking, though I did finish most of it. There was a generous serving of spring onions, which I thought was disproportionate to the broth and noddles. Garlic, sesame and chilli powder were provided.  This are 3-4 types of ramen available, with spicy or non-spicy chicken broth options. Aside from these, they also offer some gyozas and 1-2 rice options. There is a queue during peak hours.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #02-01/02, Liang Court Shopping Centre Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Tried the Zenbu Ramen. Well balanced Ramen I would say. The amount of seaweed/spring onions with semi fatty pork is perfect for one which craving for fatty meat but in the meanwhile got it covered with vege. Chicken broth is good. Recommend the spicy version for this ramen.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #02-01/02, Liang Court Shopping Centre Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Great ramen. Small space and expect a queue especially during lunch times. This restaurant has been here for years. Go for the Marutama Special, around $19 (before GST).

address: 177 River Valley Rd #02-01/02, Liang Court Shopping Centre Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Located in town along the popular Killiney Road, you will find this Japanese ramen diner tucked in a corner.They serve quite a nice ramen with the right springiness accompanied by a hot soulful broth.We ordered a bowl each of:Karashi Ramen (spicy) $12Chicken soup based ramen was full flavored yet portioned just nice. This must be a popular order.Zenbu Ramen (all toppings) $18This was a Full Bowl of everything including a lot of ramen. If you are hungry, this boy is it.

address: 177 River Valley Rd #02-01/02, Liang Court Shopping Centre Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Had the special ramen with all toppings. Amazing pork that just melts in your mouth. Egg has a slight sour taste to it.. Wife refused to eat it though.. Good quality for the money. Recommended if you need a quick ramen fix

address: 177 River Valley Rd #02-01/02, Liang Court Shopping Centre Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: Tried this today with a mild sore throat. The fact that they use chicken base soup helped soothe my throat. The pork dish that everyone said to try was very good. we also tried the guise and egg, both delicious. I would recommend if you're looking to try chicken based soup ramen. Yummy

address: 177 River Valley Rd #02-01/02, Liang Court Shopping Centre Singapore 179030 Singapore
comment: The queues at Marutama stretches excessively on certain nights and after my experience, I just can't figure out why.Admittedly, Marutama is immensely generous with the toppings on the Ramen provided for the Liang Court Food Trail with 3 slices of Char Siu, 2 pieces of Pork Belly Kakuni, a Tamago (Boiled Flavoured Egg) and plenty of Negi (Spring Onions) and Seaweed. However, the star of the night, the ramen noodles and soup itself, was a disappointment and having tried favourites like Santouka and Nantsuttei, I feel that Marutama is just not up to par. The soup, being chicken-based, lacks the thick flavourful consistency that pork-based soups provide and doesn't pack a punch. The noodles were stringy and felt sadly like the noodles I get from instant ramen that can be purchased at Medi-ya Supermarket.Still, one thing I did enjoy, immensely, was the boiled Tamago, which is the best I have had at a local ramen place. With solid egg whites browned from soaking overnight in flavoured vinegar and a molten yolk inside, Marutama definitely puts alot of effort into a dish many cannot master and this was the star of the evening. Other toppings like Char Siu and Negi were average while the Kakuni reminded me too much of Chinese braised pork belly.For the full review and more pictures, visit voraciousappetite.wordpr…

Love this place. Mediya Japanese grocery store is the main reason why I visit this mall. There are many Japanese shops and bakeries worth checking out. The chair massages at L.C. Fu Li Hua Foot Reflexology, never disappoint. I always make sure to stop by there while shopping at Liang court. One thing to keep in mind when going there... it seems like most shops don't open until at least 11am.
