An amazing food court located on the first level of the mall. Many different options to choose from. I got the Fishball Noodle soup, which cost a flat $5.00. It was the perfect treat to fill an empty belly, on a budget! Great value with the amount provide, and several clean seating options.

I've been visiting Liang Court since I was 8. Maybe even younger. Swensen's used to be my favourite restaurant. I'd always have the Fish and Chips, my mum would have the Chef's Salad, and my dad would have the Chicken Delight. Oh. Definitely younger because I remember going there before my brother was born. So since I was 6 then. From Swensen's and Daimaru to ramen, sushi, and CREAM PUFFS, Liang Court has been a firm fixture on my list of "malls that I think of fondly". Meidi Ya in the basement has one of the best juice/smoothie selections I ever seen (they have Innocent smoothies! YUM!)And I haven't even talked about the McDonalds that's open 24 hours for the drunken bodies staggering over from Clarke Quay (yeah been there, done that more than once).Quite simply, Liang Court isn't as flashy as those new fangled malls, nor as simple as those heartland malls, but she's classy in her own way. As long as she's perched on the edge of prime drinking areas, and continues to draw in the Japanese expats, she'll be here to stay.So stay classy Liang Court, stay classy.

The first day we arrived in Singapore, we decided to have a dinner at the food court there.  The fishball noodles were surprisingly delish.  Since our apartment where we stay is basically next to it, we decided to have lunch there and we tried the fried chicken over rice and the pork belly salad.  Again the foods were delish.  The fried chicken tasted similar with Indonesian fried chicken where the chickens were marinated with mixed turmeric based sauce similar to curry.  If you're not hungry, the char su pao bun is awesome too.  They're small but the bbq pork was quite lean and seasoned well.  Yes this place have so many Japanese restaurants and 1 Italian diner.  We're planning to explore the Japanese foods here but will skip the Italian diner.  The Italian diner looked busy but by looking at the menu, I'm pretty sure the food quality is exactly like Denny's diner.  Remember to bring napkins/kleenex + water bottle (unless you want to pay) whenever you go out in Singapore.  No water fountains and the only water fountain I saw was in the National Library.

Looking for a little Japanese culture in your life? Get your quick fix here, It feels like a Japanese outpost, or maybe even a colony - a Docomo phone shop (partnered with Starhub here of course); an Okinawan restaurant; a Kinokuniya bookstore; ramen shops galore; not one, but two Tampopo food outlets - and one looks dedicated to tonkatsu (OH YUM)... and Meidi-Ya, the mother of Japanese supermarkets. I picked up everything I needed for a four-course meal once, including some tofu they made in house! YES THEY MAKE TOFU HERE. tasted amazing too.The other floors have a mix of other tenants, along with Audio House on level 3 (which has pretty amazing deals on TVs and other home appliances), but you rarely need to go up that high, everything I need is on levels 1 and B1! Yes, they're all food-related. Yes, I'm hungry as I'm writing this. but that's par for the course.

Gone where the hey day of Liang Court where Daimaru once stood. These days, the place is rather quiet but still attract its own crowd, predominately the japanese clientele.Some of their anchor tenants are meidiya, kinokuniya, tampopo restaurant groups and audio house. There are many other tenants like tanyoto, shin yeh, OM and much more. Personally, I still visit this mall pretty often as I love to shop at meidiya and nanairo as well as dine at tampopo and tanyoto.

address: 101 Upper Cross St #03-46 Peoples Park Centre Singapore 058357 Singapore
comment: My colleagues had praises for their prata so I drop in to find our.It's true!  The prata is flaky and crisp, a bite reveals the layering of the dough. That's what I like, especially for those who likes their prata "clean" without the curry or sugar. The fish curry is thick, but it brings out the tasty chewiness of the prata.I like their mutton too. Soft cubes of meaty delight. And together with the fluffy light rice, it's a pleasure to clean the plate.Definitely deserve repeated visits.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-06, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: I've been wanting to try out Shiraz for a while. It came recommended by an Iranian friend when I mentioned that we were looking for a good Mediterranean restaurant. It's a little on the pricey side, so we waited till a special occasion -- a birthday. When I called to make a reservation, the restaurant offered to have the belly dancer bring out the cake, which I thought was really nice of them. The restaurant was empty when we arrived at 7pm, but it was full by 8pm. This was a Sunday by the way. I found the menu overwhelming, despite being semi-comfortable in most Middle Eastern restaurants.  I think it was the use of Turkish names that were non-familiar -- for instance there were two eggplants dishes that were not baba ganoush on the appetizers. I think it would have been helpful to have sorted the main dishes by type of meat, and also add a short English description in the title (not in the long detailed description), but the restaurant's been around so I'm sure they know what they are doing. Part of the menu is reserved for halal food.We chickened out, and ordered a platter for 4, the vegetarian option and a lamb stew. The appetizer list was shorter, and we went with both eggplant dishes, hummus and the lamb meatballs. The appetizers were awesome, especially the bread. We had three orders of bread, and they were complimentary...although we did order 4 appetizers. I'm not sure if they eventually charge for bread. After the appetizers, we were starting to feel kind of full. Oh, we were a party of 7.The main platter was huge -- definitely more than enough food for 4 people. I think we could have just gotten the platter for our party of 7. It came with a couple of roasted tomatoes and a few slices of carrots, so it was a good idea to add the vegetarian main to our dinner. The grilled vegetables were interesting -- there were the usual bell peppers, zucchini and potatoes, and then more. Roasted celery! Roasted lotus root! They were actually really good! The meat platter was done well, but I didn't find any of the food remarkable.The belly dancer came out after 8:30pm, and started dancing in the restaurant. The arrangement of the tables made it hard to properly see her dancing. After the first song, she danced outside the restaurant at the front door for 2 more songs, which we couldn't quite see. If you're here to see the belly dancer, you're better off waiting outside.The restaurant felt a little understaffed. It took a while for them to clear the plates, and a lot longer to bring out the dishes after the belly dancer gave us the cake. However, the wait staff was very friendly. We definitely had a great time.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-06, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: This is the WORST place I've eaten in months!I want to first clarify that this review is mainly about Shiraz's small kebab wrap eatery they have across from their main restaurant.  I noticed they both share the same account, so that's why I'm writing it here. I order the Spicy Chicken Wrap and it was terrible! 1- It didn't taste like chicken.2- I couldn't taste the spiciness of the chicken... or any actual spice! #BLEND3- There were so many onions in my wrap, I thought I was eating a raw onion. I know I'm not exaggerating because my boyfriend tried it and thought the same thing. 4- After eating what it was the most horrible "kebab wrap" in history, I couldn't go to sleep because I still had that onion taste in my mouth!Do yourself a favor and run away from this place.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-06, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: Brilliant middle eastern restaurant. Top-notch food, great service, and amazing entertainment.I was here for a group (10) dinner during a work trip. A couple of my colleagues had been before and said it was good. One of them is friends with one of the dancers as well.Staff were helpful in suggesting the right options and amounts of food for 9 hungry carnivores and 1 vegetarian. A couple of their sample platters and few sides, with some nibbles of mezze and hummus before, were just right to ensure we were left fat and happy. All the food was excellently prepared and presented, with a mix of lamb, beef, and fish.Service was very quick, the wine we ordered was always topped up when needed, and we genuinely felt very well-treated.The belly dancers that are a regular part of the evening here were amazing. Their dancing had some modern moves in it, and some purists might say that these tiny Asian ladies didn't quite have substantial enough bellies for it, but it was a real crowd-pleasing show. While some of the dancing was inside, in and around each table, much of it was outside the entrance, to bring in more customers. Luckily our table was aligned perfectly with the doorway so we got to see nearly the entire show.A fun night of great food and entertainment.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-06, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: This restaurant is best avoided. Food maybe good, over priced and bad service.If you are going alone, they will refuse to give you a table and even if they give they will skip giving you bread and cheese etc. They want you out. They just want your money and out. Service is not something they know. But they will charge you 10% for service. This is something i do not get here. If you are a non drinker same treatment. What is most interesting Singapore being such a Hot place they do not even offer water. They want you to Buy water. That itself is a put off. The charge you like crazy but even tap water is not offered.My suggestion best avoided. Go to Arab Street etc to get middle eastern food. Not SHIRAZ..

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-06, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: First of I was to make a comment on another customer referring to Shiraz to another Israeli or Arab eatery. Persian food truly different than other two. Here is is my view:Pro: 1. nice location & decoration2. Good serviceCon: 1. extremely expensive: minimum price from for grill is $$37 which is about $25 (US); this 30% higher than NY with less quantity2. The portion to price is out of placeDinner for 4 (main dish plus appetizer and desert is about $70/$80 a person which is outrages.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-06, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: If you are really in for a nice middle eastern food this is not the place to go.  Service was alright though a little on the rough side.  Had waitresses that speak English but just a little hard to understand.  Also one was real eager to teach us how to eat the food and stood there looking after she was done teaching :).  Anyway the real bummer was the food.  Grill fish was dry and came with some creamy topic which was definitely not middle eastern.  The only item on the grill platter that stood out a little better was the quail.  Dinner for 3 came to 215 and that is without liqueur.  So I figure most people head there for the smokes?

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-06, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: I was looking forward to some shwarma and  delicious sauce.. instead i got some humus tasting mozzarella cheese sandwich. Shwarma with cheese a Singapore thing? Please tourist bullshit. I'm from New York and I've been to Turkey and Israel and this is the worst shwarma I've ever had. And the sauce which usually makes any meat taste better.. well this one made it worse.Anyway this cheesy wrap thing was good I guess. It just wasn't shwarma. Or even remotely middle eastern in my opinion. Sorry... try again.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-06, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: If you value the company you are with, do as the manager told our table - "don't come to a persian restaurant". He threatened to call the police when we said we did not want our mains, because the show - with speaker system you cannot yell over -must go on. Food below average too.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-06, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: I tried the Shiraz twin platter ( gives you a good array of their signature charcoal grilled kebabs) and it was absolutely fab. The meats were succulent, juicy and very tasty. And they also gave us a complimentary portion of persian flat bread with hummus, which were really good too.But enough about the food! The most memorable part of the dinner was the belly dancer, who will perform around the restaurant and between the tables. I usually find it quite awkward to watch someone perform while I eat. The food will usually distract me from half the performance and yet you have to show some decent amount of appreciation to the performer. I felt a bit strange throughout the dance (juggling the eating and appreciative smiles and nods). But from my observation, that dance definitely kept the male guests happy if they aren't already happy with the food.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-06, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: After seeing Shiraz on InsiderTV at my hotel, it looked very appetizing, and while bar hopping in Clarke Quay, I had an opportunity to give it a try.  Unfortunately, the TV version was better.  On a positive note, the quality of meat was good.  And perhaps in a kebob it would be ok.  But there are more variables with a the bread, veggies, and of course, the sauce being equally important, and unfortunately, Mezzah failed to deliver on all three.  First, the bread was all wrong, as it was paper thin - much thinner than any pita or taboon bread.  As for the veggies, there was an absence of any pickled vegetables, so you are stick with lettuce and a few tomatoes.  Boring.  Finally, you get a choice of sauces, but 1). they really skimp on the portion; and 2). they were all bland.  Plus, I like mine with lots of tahini, and that wasn't even an option.  So overall, despite being in a great location and looking good on the surface, Shiraz fails to deliver.

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-06, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: i love Shiraz... this one has late night hours so it always makes me mad when i cant get one during the lunch hours.  but last night when i went at midnight it was pretty amazing!not all of the locations have the Spicy chicken which is amazing!

address: 3A River Valley Rd #01-06, Clarke Quay Singapore 179020 Singapore
comment: The worst customer service experience in Singapore. The establishment has posted an opening time of 6:00PM; we arrived here at 6, waiting for about 15 minutes with no one attending to us, then went across to District10 because they still hadn't finished their "staff meeting". We then came back at 6:45 when they were finally done after having a couple of drinks and appetizers at District10. We ordered a Shisha and were then told we need to order 1 drink per person, which is fine because we knew that as this is the 4th time we've come here since getting to Singapore, but as we had just had drinks, we asked for a few minutes before we order something and they wouldn't let us sit until we ordered something. Furthermore, my wife was having a Starbucks which is not allowed on their premises, so I said it's fine, she'll finish it and they insisted she stand 2 meters away at the entrance of the restaurant and chug the Starbucks if she wants to enter. Mind you, we have been here 4 times in a week and we've been very good with the staff, and they've even come to recognize us so I am surprised at how poor the service is. There are MANY better places for Shisha in the town, Sahara at Boat Quay, and Dervish and a couple of other places on Arab St, maybe not as fancy, but the service is 100 times better.
If you haven't given this place 5 stars then you don't know what good food and fun is. The band was awesome. The food was great. The location is terrific. We had so much fun here, you'll love it.

Food was just okay. The sliders were not good, I would not recommend. The arrabbiata pasta with shrimp was pretty tasty. The service was great in general, but server did not check on us. Got free drinks on a Wednesday because it was "Ladies Night." Not a terrible experience, but not a "must try" in my opinion.

Had to double check website that this was the place as the stock pictures didn't match. This is on the bar/club area of Clarke quay and we were so glad we stumbled onto it. A two man band named "dirty martini " was playing..they appear to be regulars and were awesome. The ambience was very nice, pretty diverse crowd. I ordered a seafood pizza that was good, not great. My wife had a sandwich that looked really good..as is always the case if you miss happy hour in Singapore you can be prepared to be hit over the head with the prices, but the ambiance here was nice enough that you don't feel like you're being rooked.
We ordered a bowl of Sangria however it was super watered down with no hint of alcohol
Good ambience and live music on a Saturday night! Didn't eat here but one of the better happy hour menus around the Quay.

rest_name: The English House by Marco Pierre White
comment: I had the Cod Fish and Chip for lunch and fit was delicious.Triple cooking for chips is a great idea and well executed at this place.Also, the place is very interesting, would love to go back there for drinks, it reminds me of the places I enjoyed going to in London and Paris (Home House, Bob Bob Ricard, Beef Club, etc)

rest_name: The English House by Marco Pierre White
comment: The restaurant is situated in a lovely shophouse on Md Sultan Road, and is one of the most interesting restaurant interiors in Singapore. Each room has its own theme and it definitely transports you to an old English pub. They have an extensive menu (even have Dim Sums which may be a throwback to HK being an english colony earlier). We had heard good things about the fish and chips here so that was our main interest. I think it was a case of having too much expectation. The fish wasn't crispy nor was it well seasoned. The chips as well didn't have that nice fresh crunch. For the price, I felt that the quality and quantity should have been better. The starters were good though. As were the drinks. Just wish the fish and chips, being such a quintessential british dish was executed better.

rest_name: The English House by Marco Pierre White
comment: Very nice ambience and decoration, good service by friendly staffs. Ordered fish and chips since it is English House, but it was just so so. The wedges were dried and tasteless, thanks to the refreshing tartar and chili sauce, I finished the cod fish... My colleague ordered the Singapore spicy fry noodle with pork cheek. She let me tried abit of it, it was basically a sweet sauce fry koey teow (Singapore local fried flat noodle). Nothing impressive about the food, but I enjoyed the ambience very much. Hmm.. Maybe just a visit for eye opening, hard to get me go back again.

rest_name: The English House by Marco Pierre White
comment: I was invited to The English House for breakfast, an English breakfast, of course. The breakfast menu is quite extensive - ranging from the traditional English breakfast, crumpets, porridge oats to smoked haddock, though black pudding is not on the list. The toasts were done with the right crisp and brown, and needed no more than a generous spread of their home-made butter. I could be happy with just toasts and coffee but I had to try their poached egg on crushed avocado with coriander on toast, with bacon on the side. The poached egg, with a dark yellow liquid centre oozing down when cut was just delicious. The coriander was not too strong and the touch of sprinkled salt on the plate was just right. A delightful choice if one does not want a heavy breakfast.The English House is an excellent place for a meal with friends or work meetings. Though there were quite a number of patrons for an early morning Sunday meal, it has a comfortable ambience that encourages conversations. Also, an excellent service from the staff. I will be back for their lunch or dinner the next time.It's easy to miss The English House along Mohd Sultan Road but look out for the lush green entrance courtyard along the row of shophouses. .

rest_name: The English House by Marco Pierre White
comment: Absolutely Stunning, Tremendous Food and Superb Service! Best Restaurant in Singapore!! A must try!

rest_name: The English House by Marco Pierre White
comment: Nicholas is a great manager. Checked on us regularly to make sure we were getting excellent service.

Amazing and fresh sashimi available here. Sweet to the taste, with a fresh taste of sea saltiness to the bite. Fried chicken Karage was not bought and pre fried, fresh and crispy battered crust did not leave an oily sensation to the mouth. Chawamushi was ordinary, added shoyu for additional flavouring.Must try sashimi moriawase

The restaurant was located at the far end of the basement of the shopping mall. It looked like another rotating sushi restaurant at first sight until one saw the price range of the plates on the belt : from S$1.80++ to S$15.40++. Quite eye popping! Although it was a weekday lunch, the place was packed easily. There was reasonable price lunch set menu, but most were having ala carte. Hot green tea was chargeable at S$1.80++ and was refillable.Kaisen Don Set (S$33++)Served with soup & saladI was kind of surprised to see sea urchin in the dish, as I remembered that the staff who took my order, told me that sea urchin was not available and would be replaced by otoro (fatty tuna). The raw seafood was quite fresh.Mentaiko Scallop Sushi (S$6.80++)It was taken off the rotating conveyor belt. As it was black plate, it was priced S$6.80++ a plate. The rich creamy sauce on the silky juicy scallop was a match.Kaki Fried (S$8.60++)The deep fried oyster was served with mayonnaise by the side. Encased with a thin crispy crust, it was juicy inside, with juicy dipping when bite.

Love the reasonable priced very fresh sushi and sashimi like everyone else but the real star is their udon.  They serve the Kishimen flat noodle type from Nagoya and it's absolutely fantastic served in a variety of styles.  My favourite is the Tempura Udon which comes with 3 gorgeous tempura prawns.  Next time you go try the Udon for a change of pace and you won't be disappointed!
This is where I go when I'm in the mood to indulge in sushi. Love the fresh and wide range of selections they have, from tuna, salmon, hamachi, mackerel, scallops, ama ebi and more!

This was introduced to me as having really decent conveyer belt sushi and since it was close to where I live, why not? Right? Apparently, nope. Out of all the sushi I had, only the aburi salmon was decent and that was also because they had slathered so much pollock roe on to mask the taste of the sushi. The fish was definitely too cold and this blunted the taste. Some of them definitely did not seem fresh. The rice was hard and dried along the sides. I've had good sushi but then again, I've had Ikeikemaru Ryoshi. Next time I'm craving for cheap conveyer belt sushi, I'm heading back to Genki.

Fairly decent Japanese conveyor belt sushi outlet. Good selection of sashimi, with seasonal offerings. Standard sashimi rice bowl and noodle selection, and not much else. A rare find in these days of bloated menus and wacko out there sushi (by which I am definitely referring to the mediocre absurdities found at sakae, sushi tei and regrettably ichiban boshi). Food quality is decent - sashimi is fresh and not so cold as to offer an convincing impression of a meaty ice cube. Sushi rice is properly vinegared. Again, and very tragically, a rare offering these days. That said, sakuraya still holds the crown for nearly-alive sashimi freshness, at least among local sushi chains. Docking a couple stars for the surly service (yes its Singapore but still one must have standards), and the really awful iPad ordering system - truly no due consideration to us plebs who have to actually use the damn thing. UX designers, there's a business opportunity for you in designing these iPad ordering system thingies. All in, a decent place for sushi, and that's saying something considering the good selection in Liang Court (or Singapore for that matter). Will come again.

I'm not sure if it's because I went "late" or what but this place was thoroughly disappointing. I walked in at 7:30pm which i thought was not very late.I'm not a fan of conveyor belt sushi (unless I absolutely have to) so I ordered salmon aburi from the menu thinking I would get a fresh one this way. However, i'm pretty sure they just served one right off the conveyor belt anyways. The rice was tough and had dried on the sides. Gross!!!To add more, the rest of the sushi items were served with incorrect temperature (too cold) rendering nearly all of the fish tasteless. It makes me really sad when fish die and their death is wasted on sub-par meal.AND the worst part - the chawanmushi was too salty. How could they, as a japanese restaurant, mess up good ol' chawanmushi??FYI I have been here three times and the quality keeps dropping on each visit. First visit about two years ago was pleasant. Second visit, the waiter blamed me for not checking the bill before she rang up the register (Was it my job to ensure items billed are correct? How about billing the right items in the first place?). Third visit is what I described above.So based on this trend, I won't be coming back. It was not a pleasant experience for $30-40 per person price tag.

Popped by here on a weekday late afternoon for a light lunch. We had chicken karaage, sashimi platter, seaweed somen, various things from the sushi train, and tempura. My karaage was in rather large pieces and I would have preferred it in smaller pieces but that's ok. It didn't come with mayonnaise and I asked for some. I like the food here. Simple, easy, and fresh. Nothing fancy, just your usual staples here. I also like that they take Amex cards. Good place to come to, after shopping at Meidi-Ya.

I ordered mega Fuji $55, it contains sea urchin, ikura and crab meat. The sea urchin was spoil and it really smells like shit. The ikura taste very fishy too. We told the Pino cashier but she didn't do anything about it. End up we just left all the left over on the table. Well, I accidentally consumed one piece of spoil sea urchin, yes... Down to food poisoning = stomach ache and diarrhea.We also ordered a bowl of mixed sashimi and eel rice. There are a few pieces of the raw fish taste not fresh (spoil too). We don't bother to finish it. Green tea x 2Ginger ale x 1Mega Fuji (uni, ikura and crab meat)Sashimi lunch set x 1A bowl of sashimi with eel x 1Udon x 1 Oyster with ponzu x 1 Total bill $134Actually I am quite disappointed. This restaurant with such a high review in yelp yet most of their sashimi and food are not fresh. I paid 134 to got into food poisoning.
Had a great time with our family over here. It has a very wide selection of Nigiri Sushis, in fact easily the widest among the Japanese restaurants in Singapore.

so the niners failed in their quest for yet another superbowl title:(but we still need to eat lunch, right?:)marcus and carol beckoned us to join them at liang court and we obliged.so obviously we take a cab from the exchange to liang court, right?wrong, my fellow yelpers suggested we walk and walk we did!talk about working up an appetite!but this place was well worth the trudge.in fact, it would easily be the best conveyor belt sushi in town.clean, fresh, friendly.very wallet friendly without compromising on quality!i only had their fuji sushi set but based on that and what the rest had from the conveyor belt, the quality is definitely there.service was good too.prompt tea refills.smiles all round.gentle unsolicited recommendations.extra info on their offerings.and when it came to settling of the bill, no complains whatsoever when we wanted individual split billing.not your shinji for sure but also not their stratospheric prices!

Yummy fresh sushi!!! I strongly recommend the aburi salmon, the ikura and everything on the conveyor belt. Also do note that the prices of the sashimi is the same price as the sushi... and sitting by the conveyor belt is the best thing to do, if you can't control yourself and hate waiting for food to be prepared! The big eel sushi for $8 is yummy! I know $8 for one piece of sushi.... But it's so good!

This was my first time in Liang Court.  Great place to go if you're missing Japan.  Lots of Japanese stores and restaurants to choose from.We found this place on Yelp and wanted to try out a new place outside our own neighborhood.  This was tucked away in a corner of the mall next to the food market.  The sign really just looks like Ryoshi Sushi, FYOIAnyway - the food: Great value and variety of sashimi. LOVED the big bowl of miso - so different!  The fish was fresh and delicious, but there was not any creativity in it, nor was it much different than other sushi places I've been to in Singapore.  Of course, I'm a white girl that loves my California sushi, so I may not have the best palate for authentic Japanese sushi... but this felt more like a TRUE Japanese sushi experience than any other restaurant I've been to in Singapore.  No, I did not try the raw whitefish staring back at me every time it passed me on the conveyor belt, yes I did stick to mainly salmon and tuna and veggie rolls - but I'll be going back, and I just might be in the mood for raw octopus next time.

Fairly decent Japanese conveyor belt sushi outlet. Good selection of sashimi, with seasonal offerings. Standard sashimi rice bowl and noodle selection, and not much else. A rare find in these days of bloated menus and wacko out there sushi (by which I am definitely referring to the mediocre absurdities found at sakae, sushi tei and regrettably ichiban boshi). Food quality is decent - sashimi is fresh and not so cold as to offer an convincing impression of a meaty ice cube. Sushi rice is properly vinegared. Again, and very tragically, a rare offering these days. That said, sakuraya still holds the crown for nearly-alive sashimi freshness, at least among local sushi chains. Docking a couple stars for the surly service (yes its Singapore but still one must have standards), and the really awful iPad ordering system - truly no due consideration to us plebs who have to actually use the damn thing. UX designers, there's a business opportunity for you in designing these iPad ordering system thingies. All in, a decent place for sushi, and that's saying something considering the good selection in Liang Court (or Singapore for that matter). Will come again.

We could have sushi here all day and night. Salmon -aburi, -tamanegi, or just plain ol' BIG. Honmaguro akami, maguro, chutoro, ohtoro. It can go on and on.. Im not that adventurous when it comes to sushi but the variety here is quite amazing!A conveyor belt for added incentive if you can't wait for your food. Plates will range from $1.80 to $6.80. Specials and and ala carte round out their offerings. Simple, casual place where they serve good quality sushi.

I really like the aburi salmon even though I don't usually eat raw salmon. I had some raw oyster sushi on rice but I think I probably much prefer just the oyster alone as the rice does not really complement the oyster. My friends love their negitoro roll. The price is reasonable. I also tried their Sakura ebi which comes in a pair on the plate. I much prefer it cooked cos it bring out the fragrance of cooked shrimp. For 6.80, it is worth a try to see if you like it.

I ordered mega Fuji $55, it contains sea urchin, ikura and crab meat. The sea urchin was spoil and it really smells like shit. The ikura taste very fishy too. We told the Pino cashier but she didn't do anything about it. End up we just left all the left over on the table. Well, I accidentally consumed one piece of spoil sea urchin, yes... Down to food poisoning = stomach ache and diarrhea.We also ordered a bowl of mixed sashimi and eel rice. There are a few pieces of the raw fish taste not fresh (spoil too). We don't bother to finish it. Green tea x 2Ginger ale x 1Mega Fuji (uni, ikura and crab meat)Sashimi lunch set x 1A bowl of sashimi with eel x 1Udon x 1 Oyster with ponzu x 1 Total bill $134Actually I am quite disappointed. This restaurant with such a high review in yelp yet most of their sashimi and food are not fresh. I paid 134 to got into food poisoning.

When we last visited, some of the chefs were no longer there. We didn't enjoy the meal as much as than in previous visits and we felt they standards may have dropped. We'll try it again another time to give it another shot.

I fell in like with sushi here... and I don't say this frivolously.I'm not a big raw fish eater, but there was something about what I saw on the conveyor belts on my first vist that just drew me in... I'd never really enjoyed sashimi (stop judging, guys, i know it's a #firstworldproblem), always having that token piece, then feeling a little meh about it, and then I came here, and it felt like my palate was liberated, and I suddenly enjoyed it. BIZARRE. I've tried so many different kinds here now, and I don't mean tamago/inari/tuna mayo-style, but otoro, maguro, ika, aji, hamachi, and loads more I don't remember or can't pronounce. And each piece has what feels like a pinky-sized portion of rice, to a whopper of a slice of fish. It's hard not to taste the awesomeness of the fish, or see the value in what you're getting. Prices are ridiculous for this quality, and in a good way. And that's made the experience all the better!

As I've mentioned in previous reviews, my ability to eat inferior sushi in Singapore has definitely taken a hit since I returned to Japan after a long absence.I'll confess. I've never paid more than $150 per head for Japanese food. I've paid more than this for non-Japanese food but I've never been to one of these super amazeballs $400 a head sushi joints like Shini by Kanesaka or Tetsuya's or what have you. It's on the to-do list, trust me. But until then, the sushi I ate at a tiny joint called Kouraku in Nakameguro/Daikanyama area, Tokyo (check it out if you're in town) is the yardstick for any and all other sushi.So Ikeikemaru was obviously no Kouraku. But it wasn't bad, I guess. I understand that they get their sushi flown in on Tuesdays and Thursdays so maybe Sunday wasn't the best day to go. Having said this, the daimyo anago was pretty great and the salmon was competent, as was the aji.What was disappointing? The chu-toro which tasted less fresh and not as well cut, and the uni which tasted like some kind of citrus fruit.Bottom line is, this is the sort of quality you would expect while paying $50 a head for sushi in Singapore. It doesn't blow anyone's mind but it's better than many other, crappier sushi joints.By the way, for the record, I gotta say that I dig ordering directly via iPad.

Ryoshi Sushi Ikeikemaru is definitely one of my top Japanese food haunts. At least weekly visits are a must and being a loyal fan, it is no wonder that the restaurant was made one of my choices for Liang Court's Oishi Food Trail.I love Ryoshi's Iced Green Tea ($1.80, free-flow) and have also tried many of their different sushi types. This time, however, I got to taste more than just the sushi with their VERY generous meal provided in conjunction with the food trail.The set at Ryoshi consisted of Salad with Prawns, 5 pieces of Nigiri Sushi (Salmon, Tamago, Ika, Maguro and Ebi), Uni-topped Beancurd, Okura Ponzu, 6 pieces of Sashimi (2 X Salmon, 2 X Maguro, 1 X Akagai and 1 X Tako), Assorted Tempura (includes Ebi, Lotus Root, Nasu Eggplant, Okra and Tuna) and a simple Dessert.As always, the sushi and sashimi were fresh and good, especially the "Big Salmon" sushi and Maguro Sashimi which had more tender cuts than most other sushi restaurants and melted in the mouth. The Uni-topped beancurd was amazing, no doubt due to the creamy umami provided by the sea urchin gonads. What truly stood out, however, was the Assorted Tempura.The tempura batter and sauce prepared by Ryoshi Sushi is simply outstanding, converting even a friend who does not eat fried food. The sauce was so delicious I was tempted to take a spoon to it when I have regretfully finished the rest of my Tempura. Definitely a dish I would order when I next return.For many more pictures and the full review visit voraciousappetite.wordpr…

I'm confused.Do I like Ikeikemaru more? Or do I like Itacho more?Is Ikeikemaru cheaper? No... not really. My companion and I ended paying $40 each, which is a little less than what I'd probably have paid at Itacho for a similiar amount, but not by much. There were a lot of Japanese dining there though, which probably means that compared to the Taiwan-originating Itacho, the flavours are a lot more authentic (I guess? I didn't notice that.)Personally?Good sushi (I didn't try any sashimi). The various mackerel items, the seared salmon, the vinegared fish, I enjoyed it all and often ordered second helpings of each. They're definitely very generous with the fish, and the little rice is pretty tasty. Some items lost out to their counterparts at Itacho, and some were undeniably better. This place definitely does aburi much better, and all the items get a good, solid sear. And while I enjoyed  I can't shake the feeling that Ikeikemaru is a little overrated.It's not as cheap as everyone makes it out to be (in my opinion), and while it's good, solid sushi, it's also not revolutionary. I think Ikeikemaru completely blows places like Sushi Tei and Sakae Sushi out of the water, but frankly, I don't understand how those places haven't closed down to begin with. This place is a solid, reliable option for sushi, and I'll definitely be back.But is it "the best budget sushi place in town"? I can't really say yes.

Simply the best sushi I recently tried. The place has just opened and has several affordable menu with aggressive prices. I tried a 6 pieces sushi menu with salad, miso soup and green tea for 13 SGD! Very high quality and generous portions. Excellent service too.

If my guess is correct, it is the exact sushi shop from Shizuoka. The space where Ryoshi now stands used to change tenants a lot but I guess the business here is so good that it is going to stay for long. The Jizakama Rayu (fish seasoned in chilli oil) is as mild as it looks while the Fuwafuwa Tamago is creamy but bland.I guessed we were in better luck when we ordered the recommended items like the Nama Shirasu ($5.80). The overflowing amount of raw whitebait was a pleasant sight that no one would complain that it's too much. But the large piece of eel in Daimyo Anago($5.80) shown below failed to impress the eyes and the taste buds. It needs more sun-tanning.Notice the absence of raw fish? That is because we prefer to have it as plain sashimi but they did not have it. Nonetheless, this did not disappoint as their non-sushi items were actually tastier! Salmon salad ($8.60) is drizzled in bright and tangy dressing while the Fried Oysters ($6.80) are plump, juicy and cheap. The Pumpkin Croquette $4.80 was another of our hot favourite because it was not simply puréed pumpkin but also contain pumpkin bits. Served piping hot, they did require some self-discipline to not bite into them immediately but worth the wait.....

Fantastic value for quality! One of the best sushi plus really affordable prices.. Awesome :) recommended by professional foodie Chris Tan, with gd reason! Large pieces of fish w little rice. Mm. Aburi salmon was delicious! Friend loved the aburi cheese ebi. Whole anago was pretty gd (although I think itacho sushi's could give this one a run for its money, bigger slice for $6.50 as compared to $6.80 here).Lots of aburi choices, my fav!Vinegared mackerel was pretty gd. Engawa (fluke fin) was new to me but apparently a sushi standard so wanted to try it out. Texture reminded me somewhat of squid, interesting..Anyway, really good quality sushi and in all cost ~$16! Will definitely be back for more :)

Love the reasonable priced very fresh sushi and sashimi like everyone else but the real star is their udon.  They serve the Kishimen flat noodle type from Nagoya and it's absolutely fantastic served in a variety of styles.  My favourite is the Tempura Udon which comes with 3 gorgeous tempura prawns.  Next time you go try the Udon for a change of pace and you won't be disappointed!
Had a great time with our family over here. It has a very wide selection of Nigiri Sushis, in fact easily the widest among the Japanese restaurants in Singapore.

Was impressed with the selection. Kimedai! Shima Aji at a conveyor belt sushi joint? alas...it was not up to expectation. Everything tasted bleah. The fish seemed to be treated with some chemicals. tuna was inedible.Pass. You get what you pay for. Am not a sushi snob, but don't serve up sub-par fish as quality fish.

If you are looking for a slightly more authentic Japanese sushi experience than Sushi Tei or Itacho, but don't want to burn your pockets, this is a great place to go to. It's run by mostly Japanese, and on top of the usual sushi menu, served the old school conveyor belt style, they always have a ton of seasonal fish and even fresh wasabi and home-made desserts. The fish quality is pretty comparable to Itacho, but you get a lot more variety, and it makes you feel just a little closer to Japan.

Not bad authentic sushi joint in town. The good thing about this plc is they serves lotsa types of fish that are unusual which makes you feel like trying all of it. I prefer going here than itacho sushi n you'll see lotsa japanese eating in here too.

It didn't blow my face off but it was good. The service was a little off, as in I was trying to wave people down for 20 minutes to order. The tuna bowl at lunch was big enough that I shouldn't have eaten as much (or any) sushi off the conveyor belt beforehand. The tuna sashimi seemed high quality and had no visible fat. The ground tuna (if that's what it was) in the middle of the tuna bowl was remarkably delicious and succulent.

Great place for sushi without breaking the bank. Was amazed at the number of Japanese diners there, so that's always a good sign! I loved the aburi salmon, was delish! Hubby swooned over the otoro nigiri and enjoyed the oysters. With the sushi train right in front, it really is a test of your discipline and willpower! Our dinner wasn't as cheap as in the other reviews (almost $100 for the two of us and no alcohol!) but I guess that goes back to the point on discipline and willpower! Haha

Absolutely wonderful. Don't be fooled by the conveyor belt into thinking its some crappy sushi chain like Sakae Sushi and the like. No this is true authentic Japanese sushi, with Japanese staff and a Japanese sushi chef, the experience truly is authentic. The sushi itself is wonderful, fresh and generous cuts of fish. Pricing wise its extremely affordable when compared to restaurants like Tampopo upstairs.The best deal i would recommend is getting the Tempura Udon with a Sushi Set add-on. At around $15 ($9 udon, $6 add-on for sushi) its definitely worth it, especially since there's no service charge and GST (if I remember correctly). The tempura udon comes with 3 Ebi Tempura (a rarity since most places only give 1) with one of the best bowls if udons I've ever had. The soup borth for the udon is fragrant and delicious while the homemade udon is definitely different from your standard Udon as its thin rather than fat. The smooth texture of the udon with the tasty soup broth makes it one of the top Udon in Singapore.The $6.80 add-on for the sushi set is definitely one of the most value-for-money deals out there. At $6.80 you can get a mediocre plate of sushi at Sakar Sushi (:/) But here, you can a variety of seven sushi. Salmon, Tuna, Squid, Mackerel (or Sardine), Egg, Ebi (Prawn), Beancurd skin Sushi. The salmon and tuna sushi were the best I've eaten in a long time, the fish is very fresh, the cut of fish is thick and you can taste the natural sweetness of the fish. The rice is also moist and fluffy unlike another chain (Sushi Tei) The sushi is definitely one of the best around and definitely one of the cheapest around with its authentic taste, presentation and freshness of ingredients.I would definitely recommend this place to sushi lovers. Although its been only open for less than a month, its usually packed during dinner. Though there hasn't been queues yet, the restaurant is usually full house.

The price seemed really high for the Buffett like quality fish that was being offered. I expected more from a place with the reviews it received from yelp. I'm assuming that these people haven't had good sushi in their life time.

Disappointing. Firstly, I was put off by this waitress who told me to look for the sushi that I wanted from the conveyor belt instead of ordering straight from them. secondly, she was put off by the fact that I was carrying some durians which I sealed in a container, tied with a plastic bag and stored inside a paperbag. Basically there were hardly any smell detected but then I guess she must have a very sharp nose and told us not to eat the durians in the restaurant. Oh please! Why would I do that? Thirdly, the uni gunkan maki sushi was not fresh coz it taste bit bitter and sourish. However, I do like their aburi cheese ebi. Overall, pricey sushi and more suited to Japanese taste buds rather than local tastebud.

address: 3E River Valley Road, #01-05/06 Clarke Quay Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: I used to like it here despite low  reviews. They have good wine by the bottle on special. Also it's right on the river quite romantic. But the menu changed and is much more focused on Chinese seafood rather than Australian or Italian style. Also the food quality dropped.

address: 3E River Valley Road, #01-05/06 Clarke Quay Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: The most horrible dining experience I have had . The waiter had no clue of items on the menu, took out order kept us waiting for an hour and then we had to finally walk away hungry.DON'T GO HERE

address: 3E River Valley Road, #01-05/06 Clarke Quay Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: We're staying in this area and looking for something to eat late at night on a Friday evening. The whole area in general was busy and buzzing, full of young people. Really good vibe. We had fish and chips and the food was fresh and good. After our meal we walked around further and there's so many places to eat. On hind sight I would have liked to have gone to a different restaurant just to try the different local dishes. Don't get me wrong, the food was good, but their menu options I could have gotten at home.

address: 3E River Valley Road, #01-05/06 Clarke Quay Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: Visited on a Friday afternoon at 3pm. Service was great.  Ordered the house white wine and received a healthy pour for $10++.   Most places would serve a smaller amount for more money.   I also ordered the battered cod fish and chips which were fresh and nice portions.  The chips were crisp and not over cooked.  I would highly recommend the location.

address: 3E River Valley Road, #01-05/06 Clarke Quay Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: Extremely slow. Wait for our foods for more than half hour but nothing came. Within 30 mins, we asked our waitress for several times, she always responded  firmly that our foods were almost ready. Then, we angrily asked her and it turned out she forgot to order it. It ruined our Friday night:-(

address: 3E River Valley Road, #01-05/06 Clarke Quay Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: This restaurant is nothing compared to the real thing.The food is expensive (e.g. SGD16.00 for 4 prawns - each the size of my ring finger) and the texture of the seafood is murky/slimy/soft. Taste is slightly above average but nothing to talk about. Staff is rather attentive but not open to feedback and defensive upon comments. Bought Groupon Vouchers for the Lobster deal but was utterly disappointed with how it tasted (virtually no taste whatsoever) and the lobster flesh was tough. Ordered the mussels and clams but the meat was the size of a Singapore Five Cent Coin.Just terrible experience. Won't ever head back.

address: 3E River Valley Road, #01-05/06 Clarke Quay Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: Ended up at Clarke Quay on a Thursday night, and somehow Fremantle had a $5 all night happy hour going.  At 9pm, that was the best drinking deal we could find!  $5 for a Heineken is a good as you're gonna get in this area, though it didn't include the 10% + 7% taxes.  The staff did split the check, and they took my AmEx card, so no complaints here.

address: 3E River Valley Road, #01-05/06 Clarke Quay Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: Sunday lunch = $70 for two peopleI spent three years working at a seafood restaurant in Fremantle, so think I am qualified to write a review of this place. We came around 1pm on a sunny Sunday, as I have always wanted to try this. It got a fairly mediocre review from the Business Times, but then most Western restaurants do. Started with the jug of Heineken ($34.13) which is the usual Singaporean style of price gouging on beer. Moved on and ordered the Seafood Bucket ($28.25) which was well presented in a metal bucket and piled high with fried items. Unfortunately, most of it was chips, the fish was a relatively small piece and not a quality filet. The oysters were decent, but you could taste that they were either frozen or leftovers from Friday. There were also a mussel or two, some squid and I think a scallop. Disappointing because if you get this dish right, it is the perfect meal to share.Also ordered the bread basket ($8.24) and I am not sure how you can make bread taste so average, get some flavour! As you will see from flipping over the menu, this restaurant is owned locally. They have probably been to Freo on a recon mission and mimicked it here, the difference is that the seafood restaurants get really fresh items, and you do not need to drench them in batter to make them taste better. Lastly, your prices in the menu should reflect GST and service charge - anything less is cheating.

address: 3E River Valley Road, #01-05/06 Clarke Quay Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: Apart from the decor channelling the laid back, carefree vibe of Freo, Perth, there's nothing else that I really like about Fremantle Seafood Market. Their Sunday brunch menu looks more Japanese than Aussie to me with its spread of king fish Hamachi, yellow fin tuna, chilled shrimps, half-shell scallops and mussels with lemon cocktail sauce.The ingredients are fresh, and there are certain stand outs like the squid tempura and soft shell crab. But had i known it would be so Japanese-centric, with all the sashimi, I'd have skipped it and gone somewhere else instead.

address: 3E River Valley Road, #01-05/06 Clarke Quay Singapore 179024 Singapore
comment: Its a big shame that they call themselves Fremantle Seafood Market but the food there is NOTHING like seafood from Fremantle. I ordered a few things. Seafood and clam chowder, oysters kilpatrick and fish and chips (cod and john dory).The clam chowder was an ok start to dinner. The oysters were average at best. But I could not believe it when I received my fish and chips. I was practically eating batter the entire time. The fish was pathetic.Never again will I go back.

So my friend whose a local took me here thinking I'd be impressed with sorta street side dining and home cooking... Well, wrongo. Their jook was not scalding hot or even cooked enough where the grains disappear hence what porridge is all about. If I wanted watered down rice, I would ask for watered down rice. The other dishes were average Chinese fare (fried pork chop, bean curd radish, mushroom/fungus/asparagus, steam scallop w/garlic)  plated in a slightly fancier manner and smaller portions making it more chic. If put up side by side to any old hawker stand, Chao Zhou would get their Hainanese chicken ass kicked and handed to them on their white Corian counters. They still make and sell Corian???

Teochew porridge was a common food to have at home when I was young. It usually consists of pipping hot porridge, served with a few simple home-cooked dishes. Located in middle of a row of shophouses, next UE Square, there is this restaurant who offers this traditional comfort food till late at night. The place is decorated in traditional style in a modern way. Currently the restaurant is having a supper buffet promotion till end of this month, one can eat as much as you can from the displayed dishes over the counter, as well as the braised platter. The dishes available on the counter are quite a selection, ranging from the traditional salted egg, braised preserved mustard greens (Mei Cai), to shredded potato, spinach with 3 types of eggs and crispy fried smelt fish 美人魚.Porridge 白糜 ($0.70)The teochew style porridge was a watery version with the rice grains holding their shapes. It is rice cooked in a short time with a lot of water. The porridge is served half dry like a mountain, with the other half like the sea, which is unusual.Steamed Meat Ball with Porridge Water 人乡随俗 ($5.50)It is steamed meat ball, served with the water from the porridge. The steamed meat ball is stuffed with salted preserved vegetables which gives a slightly salted taste. Unusual way of serving, but feel that the meat ball is a bit too firm, and lacking of juicy bites.Braised Delights Platter 卤味拼盘 ($16.90)Duck, Pork Belly, Large Intestines, Egg, Bean Curd, Tau PokI like the juicy braised duck which is quite juicy.Cockles (Soy Sauce) 蛤（酱油）($6.90)I seldom eat cockles these day, as I don't like having overcooked version. The raw ones served here are soaked in dark soya sauce, are juicy with bites.Big Sotong 大苏东 ($6.90)The steamed squid is served cold, with salted fermented soy bean chilli sauce. The sauce is tangy and spicy with a hint of saltiness.Cold Bean Curd with Preserved Radish 菜脯拌豆腐 ($4.80)It looks such a simple dish, with just the plain bean curd topped with chopped preserved radish and spring onions, yet it is appetising to have with just plain porridge with extra crunch from the preserved radish. Never thought of that when having porridge at home.Preserved Radish Omelette 菜脯蛋 ($2.50 S, $4.50 L)I like that the simple omelette is covered with crispy surface and crunchy inside. But it gets a bit too oily after some bites. Need more plain porridge to smoothen the taste.Fragrant Minced Meat 香豉肉碎 ($4.20 S, $8.20 L)The minced meat is cooked with bean paste sauce. Slightly salty and oily, but appetising to have with just plain porridge.Mullet 黑鱼 (Seasonal Price)The fish is steamed and served with chopped preserved mustard in it, which adds additional crunch to the meaty fish. Teochew Fried Crab Balls 潮州炸蟹枣（3粒）($9.80/ 3 pieces)It does not look like balls when served. I almost want to ask if they have sweet flour sauce to dip it with. Although it looks very crispy, inside it is juicy with meaty crab meat, and crunchy ( I suspect crunchy water chestnuts). One piece is not enough. I wish I have ordered more.Crisp-fried Taro Rolls 香芋煎卷 ($2.30/ piece)There is a minimum order of 3 pieces for this item. While light and cripsy on the outside, inside it is smooth and soft with the sweetness from the yam.Sweetened Mashed Taro with Ginkgo Nuts 白果芋泥 ($3.80)It is rich and smooth, served with coconut milk. The ginkgo nuts taste a tab bitter. I would prefer to have them soaked in syrup to remove the bitter taste.I have Barley 薏米水 ($1.80) to finsih the meal with. Light and easy down the throat.Overall the food is not bad, and there is still a lot of dishes which I have not tried. I am glad to find this place that offers comfort food in the city area.

Fresh, good selection. Helpful service. Opens till 5am daily!Only problem in this area is the often limited parking by the road but thankfully it wasn't too bad Sunday at 9pm.Things we tried:1) Braised duck, tofu, pork belly and large intestines etc platter for about $16.90. The large intestines were good and tender. The amount was good for the price.2) Simple stir fry baby kailan 3) Omelet - This had a nice light crispy texture4) I like that they gave us individual saucers of chilli without asking.5) French beans with chai por - This was served up brightly green and tender. The chai por didn't look like the mass produced kind. It was quite plump and soft and not as salty.6) Bitter gourd - it was served slightly chilled but it was really tender and not that bitter. Even my dad who doesn't like cold food commented that it was good.7) Porridge was 70 cents a bowl and a bigger than average size bowl. Lots of porridge water if you like that. I gave mine to my family.Things to note:- You can ask for a bowl of "lor" sauce free like the stuff they drench the duck in.- They don't have bottled water but the girl ran next door to buy it for us and we paid cash for this separately $1.20.

Absolutely a ripoff. Bought a takeaway serving of taro with ginkgo nut dessert and was given such a MEASLY serving not even fit for a child. I could eat 10 of those and still not be full!The worst part is that the staff even explained that this is the normal serving. Wow. I was left speechless.

The best (and perhaps only?) place in Singapore  for devouring bistecca fiorentina. However, for other beef cuts (eg. tomahawk, rib eye), the pieces served at the American houses (Wolfgang, Cut, even Morton's) tend to be more flavourful. Delicious slides include purée, frites, and spinach. Too bad they don't do any bone marrow dishes anymore. Impressive list of Italian wines. Smooth service even if not extremely proactive.

After the fiasco with the reservations we decided it was only fair to give them another chance. After all the food is really good. We had for starters the scallops, octopus and ravioli. Loved the first 2 but not so much the ravioli (personal taste), the rest of my party loved it. And of course we had to have the costata. Absolutely divine, definitely as good as I remembered it to be. To end we had tiramisu and Panna cotta. The tiramisu is delicately flavored and absolutely delish. I'm not much of a Panna cotta person but it was still good. All in all I'm glad we went back. I would urge you to make reservations beforehand as it is busy.  #maneklady #manekeats

Had a very nice dinner here.  Wanted something different so we tried this place and was very happy with the food and atmosphere.  Meat and cheese board appetizer was excellent, followed with a tasty mushroom risotto for our past dish.  For the main entree had the Wagyu steak which melted in your mouth, so tender and tasty it was an excellent choice, never used one of the dipping sauces it was so good by itself. Staff was very nice and I was glad I made a reservation as the place filled up fast.  I would definitely return and recommend.

By far the best steak restaurant in Singapore. Forget Morton's and the rest. The ambience, food quality, and service were outstanding. Ambience is a casual yet trendy modern European feel - anyone would be comfortable here in a suit or khakis. Definitely a great alternative to other stuffy steakhouses. Sorry Morton's, I grew up eating your steak in Chicago but it's time to say goodbye. Now for the main event: we ordered the 1.1kg bone-in ribeye and it was heavenly. Cooked to a perfect medium rare, the meat was the definition of what a fine steak should be. They offer a selection of steak sauces on the side but please skip them and enjoy the beef directly (btw, ever wonder why every filet mignon comes with bearnaise sauce?  Because filet has NO flavor!). Side dishes were equally brilliant - mushroom risotto, mashed potatoes and creamed spinach paired nicely with the steak. Had a blended super Tuscan which brought the whole meal up a notch. The hostess, waitstaff, and bartenders are fantastic and are clearly a cut above typical Singapore restaurant staff.  My first time dining here and it certainly will not be my last - bravo!

Was roped into the 1.1kg wagyu steak at $180!!! It's not the Wolfgang of New York standard but is still pretty darn good. Still to try the new SG location. Anyways this one here at Bistecca was spot on in terms of rareness and along with its assortment of sauces salt etc ensured that every tastebud was catered for. For me I think it was just too much. Yes you can have too much of a good thing. When it's of that price and quality you really want to enjoy it. Not force to eat it cuz u spent so much on it.. lol anyhooo Bitesticca serves a pretty mean steak I would definitely return for more

Yum. Love the steak here and the phenomenal wine list. I love having a wide selection of Barolo. FYI. The burrata should be shared between four people, no less as it is just too big. Creamed spinach is dynamite.

I had looked forward to going here for quite some time, so was disappointed, unfortunately. This is based on *one visit*, so hopefully won't discourage others from trying it (as most others have positive reviews). Also, this may just be how it is in Singapore at this kind of restaurant!Food: The quality was top notch and prepared perfectly.Drinks: I only drink wine but found the selection to be good =)Service: They texted me to remind me of my upcoming reservation. I like this, except... The text also said the table would be turned over 2 hours after. I found this rude and made me rethink going. I am not a slow diner, but it is typically just me as I travel by myself a lot. I don't want to pay a lot to feel rushed.Service (continued): They sure didn't seem to be in ANY rush when I got there. Not only was the place not fully booked, I wound up waiting. A lot. On everything. I got my wine and then about 15min later, my first course (delicious). I was done with the first and waited for ~22min more before I finally waved someone down. They cleared my plate. I didn't keep track at this point, but my steak (main) finally showed up as I finished my glass of wine. I asked this person (because who knows where my wait staff went) for another. I don't like a steak without wine. Unfortunately, this took a very long time. Steak was cold by the time I got the second glass. Overall I was stuck there for over 2 hours when I didn't WANT to be.Ambience: It has a lot of promise, and this may be regional, but I found it filled with families with kids (a Sunday night) that were terribly behaved (a lot of shouting). There is not much the restaurant can do about this, however, so I try not to ding them for it but will warn others (or let parents know, hey, this is a good place for kids).So I wound up spending over 2 hours, over US$100, for a rather stressful, loud, drawn out meal in which I had to flag waitstaff down constantly. Thankfully the food was good! When I'm back in Singapore next, I will walk by and see how full it is. If they can happen to fit me in and its quiet, great.

Taking off a star. Last meal here wasn't as good as previous visits. Not sure what's happening but food seems to be dropping in quality. For the price it should be perfect every time. Steak was tough and not the quality expected.

There's actually very few places to have a decent steak in Singapore. There's a lot of places that offer some kind of slab of fairly young beef, not or little dry aged, and fried using methods that do not give the high heat required to get a good char on the meat whilst keeping the insides red or pink (like the Josper grill that has conquered all the London steakhouses). For example, the steak served at a famous 313 Somerset steakhouse is a travesty for the price, it's just flashed on a warmish pan, I can do that at home (and better; I'd actually leave the pan on the fire for several minutes before putting on the steak, so it's hot enough to char the meat, not end up with a greyish slab of depression).This you should bear in mind, because it explains the pricing. Yes, $188 for a 1.1kg steak is not cheap. Yes, the main pieces - Costata, Bistecca - are not dry aged, not significantly that I could taste anyway, but you do get the option of a 45-day aged Angus for $60. As for the cut it's pretty simple: "bistecca" is a T-bone, which is slightly less tasty and has more bone, and "costata" is a ribeye, which should be your default order at any steakhouse as it has the most flavour, although it is quite fatty (doubly so since this is a wagyu breed with plenty of marbling). The fat in the ribeye is where the flavour concentrates when you dry age the cut. T-bones are fillet and strip steak attached to a bone; both cuts are very soft and tender but lacking in flavour compared to the ribeye; considering the ribeye is cooked properly and therefore will also be tender, the tenderness of fillet However, the flame grilling method is sufficient to get the right char on the thick cut steak which qualifies Bistecca as a "decent steakhouse" in my view. It's literally a wood fire built in their kitchen, with a grill on top, and the steaks on the grill in the middle of the flame. It's a shame you have to choose between dry aged and charred crust (the Angus is 300g, too thin for a proper crust to develop) but at least both are an option. The sides are what you expect when you pay $15-25 for high end Italian in Singapore. Honestly they could serve mac and cheese from a tin and I wouldn't care, since I come here for the steak and barely touch the sides. But they are very good (I miss the lentils and sausage, if you're reading this, Bistecca chef), and could be a meal by themselves if necessary. The interior is original, thoughtful, interesting, it goes beyond the "Nordic minimalist" look that you get everywhere and where it's hard to draw a line between fast food joint and cool modernism. Cow hide on the floor, hilarious paintings on the walls. Service is prompt and knowledgeable, including knowing about how a thick cut steak will be rawer close to the bone and thus might need a bump up in doneness versus your usual. This gives the place a much friendlier and more fun feel than the "big name" steakhouses like Morton's or Cut. If you prefer the 5* hotel feel, you might not enjoy Bistecca, it's more of a quirky boutique hotel. I personally love it.What could be improved? Simple: dry-age the costata for 45 days as well (or go wild: 60 days!), and charge me extra for it (because I know how expensive storing something for months is in Singapore, especially with the humidity). I'll still buy it, because there's no alternatives except maybe a couple of items on Cut's menu. Bistecca would not, or barely, be competitive against the institutions of London or New York (like Goodman's), but it's offering enough to be THE steakhouse of reference in Singapore as far as I'm concerned. I just think it's a shame that you can source dry aged meat and you don't bother on your flagship cut. I also miss the cypresses or whatever trees were shading the front porch...

Inside an unassuming storefront,Bistecca Tuscan Steakhouse is a slick room that goes back farther than you think.  While the specialty here is steak and in particular a tomahawk with a choice between a Japanese Wagyu ribeye and an Australian Porterhouse.  We chose the Porterhouse, as it is closer to the cut I would expect in Italy.  We started with a couple of apps -   Grilled prawns wrapped with lonza with fennel and an arugula salad with prosciutto and straciatella cheese.  Both were excellent.  In addition to the steak, we also tried a couple of pasta dishes, which were actually very good - the pumpkin ravioli tasted very fresh and light.  The tagliatalle with oxtail was hearty and also excellent.  The wine list here is basically all Italian and there is a good range of choices, and the Nebbiolo wine (same grape used in Barolo) drank beautifully for under $200.  As for the steak, well, it was good, but I wasn't blown away!  It was decent but I just wasn't impressed, especially for $188. The cut had too much fat and not as flavorful as I expected.  Desserts here are solid, and we were not disappointed by the 2 classics - tiramisu and panna cotta.  So far, I am been to Bedrock and Bistecca and while both have been good, they haven't been great.  And service at both places could be improved. So while the steak was a little disappointing (and expectations were very high), the apps, pasta and dessert were all solid.

A friend took me here for dinner on a Saturday, and I would describe the experience as pleasant in general.They waive corkage here for a bottle (or three), if you buy a bottle. I don't enjoy drinking reds, so my friend bought a bottle of Chardonnay which the waiter recommended, and he brought his own bottle of red, which they decanted for him. We started the meal with a large salami platter, and pan fried scallops, which came on a bed of root salad, and crispy pancetta (just fancy bacon). The salami was better than I thought it would be, because my scallops were a disappointment! The scallops were a lot less brown than what I am used to. The salad they came with was pretty meh.... For $35 bucks, I expect a little more.I ordered a Shiga Ohmigyu Wagyu A5 steak rare, which is a Japanese full-blood Wagyu Rump (200g) at $90. My steak was perfect. If they can't cook scallops properly, rest assured they can do beef here, perfectly. My steak was juicy and full red in the middle - yum! The steak came with a plethora of sauces, but good wagyu don't need no dressing 'cept salt! Our sides for the steaks - asparagus, kipfler potatoes, french beans, were as good as sides could be. I do wish they did mashed potatoes. I do love mashed potatoes. **sad face**We ended the meal with a cheese platter and a glass of limoncello each. The cheese platter was nice, with a nice mixture of hard and soft cheeses, with sweet apple bits and preserved figs. Yum!Would I come back? Yes - if I wasn't paying, of course. This place is quite the rip-off.P.S. I like the women's' washrooms here. They have some feminine products in case you have an "emergency"!

This is a review of a dinner with a friend at Bistecca Tuscan Steakhouse.tinyurl.com/c5tnwbtThe ambiance is warm and inviting.  There is quite a bit of unique artwork on the walls.  We sat in the downstairs area.tinyurl.com/c4ql4rfThere is also at least one other seating area upstairs.tinyurl.com/cmwzhnhThe service was inconsistent.  It started off very attentive.  However, as the meal progressed, it became a food drop-off service and then waned to the point that we were left waving our hands to gain the attention of a server to order dessert and to garner the bill.The food ranged from sub-par to very good.Complimentary Bread-sticksWe quite enjoyed these simply bread-sticks and olive oil dip. tinyurl.com/d4rxus7Bruschetta al pomodoro con burrata e olio al basilico (Toasted homemade Tuscan country bread brushed with garlic, topped with crushed tomato and creamy burrata, finished with basil oil and a pinch of sea salt)I really liked this dish.  The burrata was so creamy.  The tomatoes were not overly acidic.  I did think the bread could have used a touch more crisp to fight off the moisture from the tomatoes. This is a minor complaint.  My friend  does not eat cheese.  So, I had the added bonus of getting to eat her portion of the burrata.tinyurl.com/d7ep4b3Panzanella estiva con cappesante (Roasted scallops on top of a classic Tuscan bread salad with onion, tomato and olives)First, this simply is not panzanella.  By any name though, this was an average dish.  The scallop was slightly overcooked.  The flavour of the scallop was also stronger than the delicate sweetness I prefer.tinyurl.com/cbww6qmCostata (1-1.2kg bone-in rib eye - for 2)This is what we came here for.  Actually, I came for Bistecca Fiorentina.  However, after a less than useful conversation with the server, we decided on the Costata.  I tried to discern from the server the key difference between their specific cuts (fat content, grain, flavour profile, etc...).  However, the server said they were the same for each. Next up, since we were sharing the steak, we needed it to be cooked in a manner that each of us can enjoy  I prefer medium rare on the rare side.   She prefers a more true medium rare.  I am quite ok with this.  I tried explaining to the server that we would like the steak cooked to a true medium rare.  He stated they prepare them more on the rare side of medium rare.  I explained once again.  He suggested they prepare the steak, bring it out and, if needed, they would cook some of it some more for her.  I attempted to explain that this would ruin her portion of the meat.  If returned to the fire after slicing, meat will almost instantly seize up and become tough.  After making no headway, I gave up.In the end, he brought a steak that, while not blue, was certainly more rare than medium rare.  Even with me focusing on the rarer portions, we had to assemble some slices for her  and return them for additional cooking. Yes, this meant her portions were significantly less tender than mine.All that being said, this was not the most significant issue with the steak.  There was an extreme oiliness to the steak.  This was true in texture and flavor.  It was very disappointing.tinyurl.com/c64228bSauces: salsa verde, garlic mayonnaise, Porchini mushroom, and red pepper / tomato compote There are four sauces served with the steak.  I am not sure why in serving a $180 steak they feel sauces will be required but they do provide them.  For the most part, we only took a mild interest in them.  After trying each, none really stood out as something either of us would like to add to a steak.tinyurl.com/c4qr2dpPuré di patate As whipped potatoes go, these were very good.  They were light and buttery.  For an à la carte  side, the portion was a little small.  Luckily, for me, my friend was more focused on the asparagus.tinyurl.com/cpc3cgtAsparagi grigliati con olio al limonThis asparagus was quite good.  The grill had imparted a nice flavor and brought out some of the natural sweetness of the asparagus.  It was also still very crisp. Through an unspoken agreement though, she ate most of the asparagus and I ate most of the potato puree.  tinyurl.com/bws9us3Homemade hazelnut gelato To end our meal, hhile she enjoyed a limoncello, I had a delicious scoop of hazlenut gelato.tinyurl.com/boyo8gpReceipt ($514.35)tinyurl.com/cmr5vmmOverall, there were just too many inconsistencies for me to recommend Bistecca Tuscan Steakhouse.   If they were able to deliver on the true experience of a Tuscan steakhouse, this would be a restaurant that I would visit frequently.  They did not.  If they could have delivered on a true Tuscan steak, I would probably look beyond the service, they did not.  This was simply not an experience that lived up to its lofty price-tag.

What I absolutely love about Bistecca is the signature Bistecca Fiorentina, a mammoth-sized t-bone steak that weighs in at 1-1.2kg. While they recommend it to be shared between 2 or 3 people, I find myself perfectly happy gorging on this beauty alone. Not that I don't like to share, but if I'm going to be paying $178 for it, I want to enjoy it the best I can. Its simply seasoned with salt and pepper (like how all good steaks should) and grilled over a charcoal fire that results with plenty of charring. It's served pink and juicy and in deliciously thick cuts which I find makes for fantastic chewing. If you're the type that prefers your steak well-done, I'd say give this place a miss because you'll be wasting your money. There are other sides, but since I had no room, I have to go with my dinner buddy and say that everything is pretty decent (he only got to try a tiny slice of meat).

Outrageously expensive for what you get.Came here previously for a special occasion. Ordered The Costata (1kg bone in rib-eye). Disappointingly, the waiter was unable to properly explain the differences between the Fiorentina (t-bone) and the Costata (ribeye).The meat is cooked correctly to your specifications (medium-rare), and is a decently good steak. Disclaimer, I have not had a true European Costata or Fiorentina so I had no proper comparison. However, taste and texture-wise, the meat just didn't seem to justify the outrageous cost. To note, the meat is not dry-aged, which affects the flavor. A similar quality steak could be had for much less in the US.They provided quite a selection of sauces to go along with your steak, salsa verde, porcini mushroom, mayo... but given the high quality of steak do you have to slather it with sauce? (I wouldn't)To put things in perspective, you can consider it one of the top places for steak in Singapore, but it cannot compare with steak at good places in North and South America.All in all, the final cost ended up in the 3-digit range for two people for the steak, a couple of sides and appetizers, without alcohol. It's good, but not *that* good. What's that I smell? It's not the grilled steak, it's the smoke wafting from the hole in my pocket...

Inside an unassuming storefront,Bistecca Tuscan Steakhouse is a slick room that goes back farther than you think.  While the specialty here is steak and in particular a tomahawk with a choice between a Japanese Wagyu ribeye and an Australian Porterhouse.  We chose the Porterhouse, as it is closer to the cut I would expect in Italy.  We started with a couple of apps -   Grilled prawns wrapped with lonza with fennel and an arugula salad with prosciutto and straciatella cheese.  Both were excellent.  In addition to the steak, we also tried a couple of pasta dishes, which were actually very good - the pumpkin ravioli tasted very fresh and light.  The tagliatalle with oxtail was hearty and also excellent.  The wine list here is basically all Italian and there is a good range of choices, and the Nebbiolo wine (same grape used in Barolo) drank beautifully for under $200.  As for the steak, well, it was good, but I wasn't blown away!  It was decent but I just wasn't impressed, especially for $188. The cut had too much fat and not as flavorful as I expected.  Desserts here are solid, and we were not disappointed by the 2 classics - tiramisu and panna cotta.  So far, I am been to Bedrock and Bistecca and while both have been good, they haven't been great.  And service at both places could be improved. So while the steak was a little disappointing (and expectations were very high), the apps, pasta and dessert were all solid.

Taking off a star. Last meal here wasn't as good as previous visits. Not sure what's happening but food seems to be dropping in quality. For the price it should be perfect every time. Steak was tough and not the quality expected.

Bistecca is an easy steakhouse to love and they deliver on points that count. various parts of my family have dined there and love the consistency of the food and service. I went there for dinner with my family this past Sunday to celebrate my Dad's birthday. Dad loves steak and Cantonese food and since we children had the choice for once, we picked steak. The restaurant has some outdoor seating, tables at the front and back of the ground floor and probably some upstairs. We were seated at the back section on the first floor, surrounded by very loud diners at both tables around us. I asked that we be moved to a quieter section and the waitstaff obliged quickly and painlessly.
