We had a couple of steaks (filetto, Fiorentina single cut and a Shiga Wagyu), pasta, 4 sides and two starters to share among 3 men and 2 ladies. It was just the right amount of food and some of the highlights for me were the starters - a perfectly grilled polipo and giant lump of burrata with Tuscan tomatoes. The portions were as you would expect with the relatively higher rent in Singapore compared to Tuscany, but the seafood was fresh and the tomatoes as sweet as it was off the vine. I also loved the ribeye cap and meat off the rib bone, charred crisp on the outside but left medium rare on the inside. Perfecto! The roasted Kipfler potatoes were also excellent (its like a slightly bigger version of the baby potato and a nice taught skin when cooked). Finally, our waiter was kind and discreet enough in helping us serve the birthday cake and took some pictures too. Just the kind of fuss-free evening we were looking for and I happily paid for it. Will be back again when the tummy or occasion calls!

Two years later, I have to say that it is better than in remember, but still not that impressive...  too bad!On the plus side, the meat is good (one of the best steaks in Singapore), the wine list is excellent, and the venue is cool and trendy.  The staff is a bit pushy, but whatever, it's their way...  the price is just off.  Fiorentina for two, two sides, one glass of wine and a bottle of water, for $280!  Just unreasonable for what this is.  Will probably be back in two years, to see if it has changed :-)
The service tonight is horrible. 60 minutes in and we are still waiting for our entree. It better be worth the wait.

Good stuff! The 2 of us shared the 1.1kg ribeye done medium rare, which was delightful. You could still see the marbling of the beef when you cut into it. $25 for a glass of wine ain't cheap, but there were somewhat generous with the serving size, so I guess that made up for things a little...

A couple of weeks ago we went to Morton's Steakhouse at the Mandarin and the meal was a disaster. Undaunted, we embarked on a new meat adventure at Bistecca last night. The two of us shared a 1kg waygu T-bone washed down with couple of glasses of Italian red. Service was friendly and attentive. The meat melted in our mouths as promised by the restaurant's website. My only (mildly) negative observation is the steak was too big! But we certainly got what we ordered ... and it was great.

I brought my partner to Bistecca for his birthday (he's an avid steak lover). From the very beginning, we were impressed with the restaurant. It had a relaxing, cosy ambience that can be romantic depending on who you're with. The service staff were attentive and showed outstanding knowledge of the items on their menu. The food was excellent. My partner naturally had the steak and declared that it was the best one he'd had in Singapore. It's of course a pricey place, but definitely one I'd go back to on special occasions.

For a steakhouse, the pastas were flawless. You'll be remiss if you didn't try them. That said, the steaks were a must-try, get the bone-in steaks to share if you've got at least 4 persons in your group.Service was upbeat, attentive and warm. Our water glasses were never left parched, and the wait staff sported wide grins with a twinkle in their eyes.We had:1) Coniglio ($25) - tagliatelle tossed in a full-bodied rabbit ragout, mixed mushrooms and pancetta: exquisite. I love bunnies (as you can well tell from my moniker), but wowoweewa, this was truly glorious. It's a little difficult to feel guilty when this was so awesomely good.2) Risotto al Tartufo ($35) with porcini, parmesan and generously littered with black truffle shavings: intoxicatingly delicious, creamy, and wonderfully comforting.3) Fiorentina Manzo ($188): a massive 1.1 kg wagyu-holstein T-bone, and incredibly tender and juicy. I loved its full-bodied decadence, and beautiful charring4) Asparagi ($15): perfectly grilled asparagus sticks imbued with a heady smoky aroma5) Gnocchi e Funghi ($13): a mushroom medley with chewy potato gnocchi, and tossed with butter and thyme, was unfortunately laced with parsley despite instructions to hold all said herb off. Good thing we had a parsley lover in our midst or we'd have sent it back

Given that I've had one of the best bistecca fiorentina's of my life at La Giostra in Florence, my expectations for this one were pretty high... Walking into the converted shophouse, everyone in my party was impressed with the restaurant's modern wooded interior and warm welcome which included complimentary toasted focaccia bread served with an unctuous olive oil.  To start our meal, the four of us ordered the chicken liver paté crostini & the burrata cheese with a tower of grilled eggplant & tomatoes.  The former was regrettably forgettable, and while the burrata was really creamy and a big hit with my mother, I actually prefer the burrata flown in from Italy 3 times a week at Valentino at Turf Club Road.  That one has a soft "cheese shell" which adds texture and resistance as you bite into it.Moving onto the mains, we took their recommendations and ordered: 1) the Wagyu beef parpardelle with mushrooms and saffron cheese(left) and 2) their signature steak(below). Sadly, I found that neither of them lived up to the real thing in Italy.  I was disappointed with the parpardelle whose saffron cheese seemed an unnecessary addition on the plate and just made it really salty.As for the steak, I preferred the medium rare, beautifully thick juicy pieces I devoured in Florence.  They was tastier, and the meat just looked more appetizing!  The one at Bistecca Tuscan were sinewy and a little too chewy from the tendons. Perhaps I am being picky, and biased towards the more 'filet mignon' texture of the meat served in Florence.... Nevertheless, no one will deny Bistecca Tuscan needs to work on their presentation!! Why drape a random spring onion over a messy pile of beef?That being said, the HUGE saving grace (and surprise!) of this lunch for me was their DELICIOUS homemade bombolini (or italian doughnuts and semolina fritters) served with a cup of cold cappuccino for dipping.  I don't usually touch the dark stuff, but even so, I couldn't stop slurping down the cool cappuccino liquid.  The doughnuts were soft and fluffy on the inside, with a crispy, sugary exterior that made ME want to melt into the dish.  I would go back again and again, JUST to have this dessert!Overall, I would say the pros: good ambiance, warm service, GREAT doughnuts... the cons: average steak, non-spectacular mains, expensive!  See my pictures at: thefearlessdiner.wordpre…

Nice ambiance, good service, great food. In reality, I don't think it's quite 4 stars (just shy) but alas, there is no 3.75 rating in yelp and I'm feeling generous. Went with a big work group and so we had a number of starters to share. A few of them were hit and miss, however, I would recommend the pan roasted octopus, pan fried scallops and creamy burrata. Very tasty. For the mains, we shared the Fiorentina Wagyu T-Bone and the Costata Bone-In Rib Eye (along with salads and veggies). Am glad I was seated in front of the rib-eye as it was a lot tastier than the T-bone (I would even go so far as saying the T-bone was just standard). The rib-eye on the other hand, was cooked to medium rare perfection. Very succulent, juicy and fatty. Yum. Definitely recommend this place, especially for large groups where you can get a little bit of everything.

Bistecca - Tuscan Steakhouse in Mohamed Sultan DistrictIt has become a tradition for Little Devil ('LD') and I to celebrate our special days in a Steakhouse. I celebrated mine in Wooloomooloo November last year. So this time around, after scouring the net, we decided to on Bistecca - Tuscan Steakhouse.As it was a weekday, reservation was a breeze. I actually gave them a called to inform them in advance of this special is my LD's birthday. Nestled in Mohamed Sultan buzzing row of houses, finding parking can be quite troublesome. The best part, I did not notice that Bistecca provided a Valet service on Wednesday to Saturday from 6 pm onwards. So silly me, we ended up parking in UE Square, walking quite a distance from the car park to the restaurant.We were seated on the indoor front section of the restaurant, where we can see the bar and chefs at work. The restaurant has a nice classy dark oak wooden setting, with dim lighting and leather chairs. A painting of a lady with two buffalo feature prominently in the centre of the restaurant. We were quite lucky that the manager actually look after our table, so service was great throughout the evening. To kick start this special occasion, we started with our favourite drinks, Lemon Lime and Bitters.  A drink that we fell in love with when we are in Melbourne, it is difficult to find this drink in Singapore but recently it is getting more popular and we are so glad. Following the drinks, we have our starters;  Insalata di pomodori, burrata, prosciutto e rucola (Creamy burrata cheese, sweet parma ham, Momotoro tomatoes and rocket with italian dressing -$18) & Crostini fritti di fegatini alla toscana (Lightly pan-fried Tuscan country bread topped with house made chicken liver 'pate' and fresh majoram - $15).Burrata with parma ham has become our favourite entree. As long as the burrata is fresh, nothing can go wrong with this entree. All the ingredients here are fresh combined, mixed in fresh tomatoes and balsamic vinegar it is just refreshing and appetizing. The crispy crostini create a nice complement to the smooth and creamy chicken pate.For the mains, we ordered medium rare Costata (1-1.2kg bone in rib eye of Bistecca's exclusive organic grain fed Wagyu - Holstein. Marble score 6+, aged - $178). The sides accompanying the steak are Gratin di patate ai funghi porcini (Potato gratin with porcini mushrooms - $14) & Crema di spinaci (Creamed baby spinach - $15). The sauces selection are salsa verde, garlic mayonnaise, Porchini mushroom, and red pepper / tomato compote (our ketchup) + mustards. The steak has a nice balance of meat and fats are cooked to perfection. It has a nice charred on the outside that seal the juice inside the meat, and perfect medium rare on the inside. On a first bite, it is beautifully tender and slowly melts in your mouth. Any sauce you choose will go nicely with the steak, I preferred the garlic mayonnaise and salsa verde. My secret weapon to tackle this huge steak is lemon. A little bit of lemon juice will help to cut through the fats of the meat and avoid you being overwhelmed by the fattiness. The creamy spinach is not to my liking, as it is creamy, mushy and a bit bland. However my LD enjoy it, so it is fine by me. The potato gratin has a nice texture of crispy on the outside and moist on the inside, with a nice potato and porcini flavour. After all the food, we only left a little space for dessert. So we decided on Zuppa di rabarbaro e fragole con gelato allo yougurt (Rhubarb and strawberry "soup" with natural yogurt ice-cream - $12). The staff manage to put a candle on the ice cream and it become my wife official birthday "cake". Although the rhubarb and strawberry "soup" looks like a baby food, it tasted refreshing and wonderful. It has rhubarb sweetness, strawberry sourness and the creamy yogurt ice cream just blend in nicely together. The dessert is on the house and what a way to end a nice evening. Yummyy!!Overall, dining in Bistecca was a wonderful experience. Service was great and we won't hesitate to recommend this place for steak to our friends. Price is on the upside, however you are paying for quality. We'll be back for more in the future. Saluti e arrivederci !! (Cheers & See you again!!)Food & Drink: 8.5/10Value: 8/10Service: 8.5/10Ambiance: 8.5/10*** If you want to check out the complete review with pictures, please click on my food blog. The link is on my profile page.

address: 109 North Bridge Rd #B1-01 Funan Singapore 179103 Singapore
comment: If you are a Xiao Long Bao Connoisseur, and this is the place for you! Their eight flavors Xiao long Bao is a must try.  The kimchi Xiao long Bao is also very good. We had a few other dishes - veggies, dumplings, etc. Overall not bad. The interior is okay, not super fancy but for this price level is decent. Service was at par.

address: 109 North Bridge Rd #B1-01 Funan Singapore 179103 Singapore
comment: If you like XLBs you have to give this place a try. They have interesting flavors, some better than others. But overall a pretty fun meal. I recommend the XLB sampler so you can try each one. The price was right. & The service was ok, but we came here for the XLBs so we were not bothered by the service.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Nice pub right in the middle of Clarke Quay to grab a whiskey and people watch. Interestingly enough, they have a minimum age for the interior area. To add to that, the minimum age is different for male versus female. *mind blown*Nice assortment of whiskey selection, but don't expect anything rare. Like all of the drinking establishments around Singapore, prices are going to be fairly steep for a stiff drink. Service is good and the staff kept the drinks flowing pretty well all night. They had a live band here playing pretty good cover of top 40s plus some classics. Pretty good vibes and there were a few ladies dancing, but most of the action seems to be next door at one of the adjacent clubs.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Music was very offensive, like black getto, food was small portions, whiskey butter sauce was a scoop of frozen butter.  Sticky toffee pudding was tasty but very small.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: This is my least favorite bar in Clarke Quay. The product is super expensive, the service is rude, and the menu is very limited. Only noobs go here.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Wow - Loads of fun on a Sunday night.  Lovely live music, friendly people, and good atmosphere.  The service was fast and friendly.  They kept the drinks coming.  Drinking can be expensive, but beers run about $15-$20S.  Be careful where you sit if you want to see the show and dancing.  There are several view obstructions in the bar.  Watching the crowd can be half the fun.  Get a good seat.When I was there, lots of people shared tables up front.  Even in the back, it is hard to talk.  Try sitting at the tables outside...very nice.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: I've never felt so passionate about writing a horrible post until now because I was genuinely PISSED! I frequent Paulaner and Aquanova (check them out instead, good service) a lot and decided to try something new. Tried Highlander and for the first hour, things were alright. Drinks were pricey, menu had a weird odor but these were all minor issues. The live band was great!  However, from the get-go, service was lackluster.Server served my drink without a coaster and lacked the basic service a service staff should have - enthusiasm. The last straw for me was when my boyfriend and I were made to change tables because the server's friend and her group of friends needed a table. EXCUSE ME! I was there at 9 because I wanted a table where I have a good view of the band! If i'm gonna be moved to another table due to the server's convenience, I might as well serve myself! I paid the service charge like everyone else but it's obvious that some have priority service over others. Guess we are not the 'regulars' or we don't provide enough revenue for them. Make those people pay my service charge next time, or better, your server. Never going back there as their competitors have proved to be better at service than them. Such a pity because the band, Higher Grounds, is awesome! Thank god my night ended well at Paulaner.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Not a bad place to chill and enjoy great performances. Alcohol not cheap but food is. Though not gastronomical  foods but still nice to bite with sips of alcohol. Service is rather prompt though i dont blame them for 5 minutes slower to get my drink. This bar tends to get more crowded as night throttles on.  Love the performances! Thats what we are there for. They played our favourite songs and more customers get on the dancefloor! Good atmosphere, great performance, average service and pricey food and drinks. Recommend to go actually :)

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: I liked this place, good service, food and music. We sat outside. They had some excellent champagne (Dom P or Moet) Prices are ok, and the location is interesting. I am not sure why one would go all the way to Singapore for a Scottish themed bar and restaurant, but the natives like it so, whatever. I enjoyed myself, but I was on a first date and it went well, even better later on :-)She helped me understand why the airport code for Singaporeis SIN;-0

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Ive put off this review for a loooong time because I insist on giving this place a second, third chances because i love the theme and live band thing they have going on but to be completely honest... This place has one of the worst service staff teams I have ever experienced in singapore. Time and time again I have been served by black-faced waitresses who toss menus at me and seem to have an attitude if I dare ask a question about the menu. The second time I ever came here, i ordered a dozen kamikaze shots to share with two others.. I shot six shots one after another (because they weren't strong I downed them like juice). Six shots in 15 mins should be lethal, I felt nothing. Drinks are pretty watered down if you order anything that isnt straight up.Dont get wrong though, the live band is pretty good and the manager is very sweet. But my goodness, dear waitresses please smile and be a bit more hospitable.  One star for the band and one star for the atmosphere.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Located in a pretty happening plaza in Clarke Quay. There's lots of lights and modern looking buildings in the area. I stopped by on a weekend night to go drink with some Singaporean friends.The bar was pretty busy but the hostess put us on a small table outside immediately.There's some kind of promotion going on with Guinness, but it was very confusing because a Guinness girl would come up to us and only take orders for Guinness, then relay the order to the bar. Except for that we already had a waitress so those orders were ignored and we had to go through our normal waitress again. Huh? What exactly is going on here?There was a live band, which was alright. You could see them displayed on video screens outside. I heard some other band while I was going to the restroom, but they were TERRIBLE. I'm not sure whether it was the same band or the band from the neighboring bar which had a shared bathroom.I got a ginger beer cocktail which was alright. As always, alcohol in Singapore is pricey, I think mine was somewhere right under $20. Service is slow and it's hard to grab their attention. I think there is better in Singapore!

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: My first time at Highlander. Not impressed. I'm not sure what's the standard rate for beers in Singapore during non Happy hours but $17 for a Corona on Thur night? That's pretty damn steep.There was a live band which wasnt that great. Then again, we sat outside so maybe thats why the audio wasnt good. I did like that they had a TV screen which projected the band performance indoors though :)Service was slow too. Pretty sure there are some better bars around!

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Not a bad place to chill and enjoy great performances. Alcohol not cheap but food is. Though not gastronomical  foods but still nice to bite with sips of alcohol. Service is rather prompt though i dont blame them for 5 minutes slower to get my drink. This bar tends to get more crowded as night throttles on.  Love the performances! Thats what we are there for. They played our favourite songs and more customers get on the dancefloor! Good atmosphere, great performance, average service and pricey food and drinks. Recommend to go actually :)

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Nice patio area for people watching. There's a good view of the center of Clark Quay and the water show. Service was good. The music inside was really loud- I could barely think! Menu looked good but we only drank here :) Good scotch selection. One of our group ordered a bourbon and coke but received a vodka coke. Pretty big mistake.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Came here for a late dinner and it was pretty good. Got fish and chips and a lamb shank. The fish and chips looked bought in, but was pretty edible. The lamb was pretty good.And then there's the scotch selection. It's very extensive and prices range up to very expensive. If I lived in Singapore, I would definitely go here every now and then just to try the various scotches.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: I have been to the Highlander before for drinks and found it to be a good place for an after work place to unwind. My co-worker and I decided to eat dinner there as he was in the mood for steak as he claimed to have his fill of Asian food all week. He enjoyed his steak, while  I on the otherhand decided to have salmon as I was watching my red meat intake. That was a mistake for me as the salmon was covered with some less than appealing tomato sauce. I did not complain but should have. Our waitress was nice and I didn't want her to think badly as she was fairly new employee.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Music was very offensive, like black getto, food was small portions, whiskey butter sauce was a scoop of frozen butter.  Sticky toffee pudding was tasty but very small.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Came here for drinks and live music the other night. The entire experience was meh. The drinks were expensive and the music wasn't fantastic - just radio hits delivered in a squeaky voice. The crowd was mostly made up of foreigners. I probably won't be back.

address: 3B River Valley Road #01-11 The Foundry Clarke Quay Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: I've never felt so passionate about writing a horrible post until now because I was genuinely PISSED! I frequent Paulaner and Aquanova (check them out instead, good service) a lot and decided to try something new. Tried Highlander and for the first hour, things were alright. Drinks were pricey, menu had a weird odor but these were all minor issues. The live band was great!  However, from the get-go, service was lackluster.Server served my drink without a coaster and lacked the basic service a service staff should have - enthusiasm. The last straw for me was when my boyfriend and I were made to change tables because the server's friend and her group of friends needed a table. EXCUSE ME! I was there at 9 because I wanted a table where I have a good view of the band! If i'm gonna be moved to another table due to the server's convenience, I might as well serve myself! I paid the service charge like everyone else but it's obvious that some have priority service over others. Guess we are not the 'regulars' or we don't provide enough revenue for them. Make those people pay my service charge next time, or better, your server. Never going back there as their competitors have proved to be better at service than them. Such a pity because the band, Higher Grounds, is awesome! Thank god my night ended well at Paulaner.

German food and beer in Singapore?Beer is the best I've had since I've been here.And the Happy hour prices are reasonable.Our group started with the Finger Food Platter.I Had the Veal Escalope "Vienna style" AKA Weiner Art as shown in the picture. Not quite as good as in Munich, but darn close.Also a very good location to "people watch"

If you were going in thinking that the Paulaner at Clarke Quay was identical to the older, more established one at Millennia Walk, you're going to be pleasantly surprised.First and foremost, due to space constraints, there isn't a microbrewery here. And that isn't a bad thing! While you'll find the same Paulaner classics as Millennia Walk, they'll taste subtly different. While the Original Munich Lager, the Original Munich Dark Lager and the Weissbiers feature on both menus, there're subtle differences in flavour between the ones brewed in Singapore and the ones on offer here that are imported direct from the brewery in Germany. Little differences like the water, for example, make for a different end result.My favourite beer however, isn't even on the menu at the other Paulaner. The Weissbier Dunkel, or dark wheat beer, is excellent. The darker, maltier flavour leaves an almost chocolatey after-taste, and makes an excellent companion to the food on offer.Happy Hour runs every day, from noon to 8pm, and again from midnight to closing, and there's live music on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays. The food is well prepared. Not mind blowing, but they do a good job reproducing the typical German classics. Nurnberger pork sausages were a definite win, cooked till it had that brown, crisp skin, but still juicy and nowhere near dry. The Pork Chop was also delicious, and I confess, I actually gnawed on the bone to get those last few bits of meat. It was a little pink, but I like my pork that way, though I know that some people still feel uncomfortable eating pork that's anything less than well done. (Side note: you CAN eat pork medium, or still pink, as long as you're sure of the supplier or the restaurant.)Overall even those this Paulaner doesn't have the 'glitz' of the microbrewery, I do have to say that I much prefer the broader selection of beers at this outlet. Actually looking forward to going back and trying their beer cocktails as well.

try the three or four munich and hefe beers on tap. 50% off before 10pm so drink away. However, they don't serve water here to go with the beer. Trod over to 7-11 at Liang Court for mineral water. 10% off for HSBC Revolution card too!

Maybe we were there on a bad night, but we found this restaurant unprepared to serve most of the items on the menu that we ordered, including the brie appetizer, the beef pot roast, and the trout. The pork chops that we did order were listed as being served with vegetables. In fact, what was served was pork loin and lettuce, and not particularly flavorful.On the positive side, the dunkel beer was good, the potato side dishes were savory, and the pretzels were hot and fresh.

address: 109 North Bridge Rd #04-07 Funan Mall Singapore 179097 Singapore
comment: Godmama#04-17 Funan MallPeranakan CuisineNo reservation made so we had to sit outdoors under the fans so it wasn't hot.Bummer......they ran out of their Special for the Day - otah.Descriptions of food ingredients by restaurant.Special Dish:All-Star Egg Skin Popiah - fresh prawns, stewed vegetable filling (bang kwang), lettuce, minced garlic, crispy garlic, sprouts and cucumber wrapped in a homemade egg skin crepe Me: Not bad. Very soft skin but not my favourite skin. I still prefer the one from Cozy Corner.Signature Dishes:Ayam Buah Keluak/Chicken Black Nut Stew - Classic Nonya spicy and tangy chicken stew with 3 buah keluaks infused with fresh root spices of lengkuas (blue ginger) and turmeric Me: Nothing great, so so, better buah keluak at FolkloreNonya Chap Chye - Classic Nonya mixed vegetables, bean curd skin and mushrooms braised in a rich prawn bisque.Me: Only beancurd skin and cabbage  - most uninteresting although the taste is not bad. Laziest version I have seen & eaten.Gingerflower & Lychee Sorvet - a Godmama exclusive by local creamery Apiary, topped with roasted peanut crumble and lime jelly.Me: Nice & refreshing but prefer it without the peanut crumble.Not a Signature Dish:Pulut Hitam Panna Cotta - silken coconut panna cotta served with pulut hitam (Black glutinous rice) and coconut shavings.Me: panacotta not bad but pulut hitam doesn't have much taste.Verdict:This is not going to be a restaurant I will patronise unless I'm nearby and have nothing else better to eat.Sigh! Another disappointing Peranakan meal. 2 in a day is too much!

address: 109 North Bridge Rd #04-07 Funan Mall Singapore 179097 Singapore
comment: Mediocre at best. Had high expectations for this place. The popiah was sold out. The chicken wings looked anorexic. The beef was tough to eat. The dessert, a creme brûlée, had a weird taste to it. The panna cotta was anything but. Just a bizarre selection of dishes which were not great. Better off hitting up a hawker for this food.

address: 3B River Valley Rd #01-13 Clarke Quay - The Foundry Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: I loved this place... I'm straight out of Puerto Rico...I was there last year in June....I had a marvelous time! The customer service was on par....the band that was playing that evening was great...the singer actually pointed me out as a Boricua as he was singing salsa. Kinda kool! I still wonder today if I was the first Boricua that visited this awesome establishment...

address: 3B River Valley Rd #01-13 Clarke Quay - The Foundry Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: The waitress here is the rudest person I have ever seen working in a bar. Neglecting people and speaking in a tone like you owe her something. I usually try to take it easy and to not to be hard on people who work at places like this because I understand how energy taking it can be but here I cannot let it go. Although the food and beer was good but never come here again.

address: 3B River Valley Rd #01-13 Clarke Quay - The Foundry Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: The people that work there are terribly rude. While we were there one of my friends who is pregnant was hit in the arm by the security guy, then a woman who works there (we don't know if she runs the place or not ) told my friend to get out of the bar using very offensive language.  The "rules violation" my friend committed was to step onto the stage and take a picture while it was unoccupied by the band and she didn't touch any of the musical instruments. We left the place with my friend crying, we had to call the police, and they came and filed a report.I was telling the story to one of my friends a few days later and he told me that something similar happened to one of his friends there too. They also called the police. So this is not an isolated instance.  The management of this place is terrible. I'm spreading the word so other people are aware of what is happening there.

address: 3B River Valley Rd #01-13 Clarke Quay - The Foundry Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Garbage service to go with mediocre food, got all 3 of our orders wrong, staff didn't know what they were doing. For such a foody city we expected better. If you've had actual Mexican food before then run for the hills, not that we were looking for authentic. Didn't think it was possible to screw up nachos till this experience.

address: 3B River Valley Rd #01-13 Clarke Quay - The Foundry Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Not mexican or cuban or anything like it.More of a "tex-mex with potatos"Si puedes leer este, alejate.If you like exploring asian fusion with good food.....this is the place for you.

address: 3B River Valley Rd #01-13 Clarke Quay - The Foundry Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Any NYers out there? If you miss Latino music, get your fix here. Live band and fun mixed crowd rip up the dance floor. This place and Pump Room are always guaranteed fun in Clarke Quay.

address: 3B River Valley Rd #01-13 Clarke Quay - The Foundry Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: Let me preface this review by saying I did not eat the food, I'd already eaten dinner and just came here to drink & smoke a cigar.  My main annoyance is with the ridiculous prices - everything else was fine.  I like the ambiance, the menu for drinks and cigars is decent, the service is fine (although it wasn't busy and I was the only person there for about an hour of my time).

address: 3B River Valley Rd #01-13 Clarke Quay - The Foundry Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: While this is not the worst restaurant I've ever been to, it is a far cry from "real" Cuban/Mexican food.  First of all, the menu is focused on Mexican standards, not Cuban ones.  They don't even serve Cuban sandwiches!  How can you have a Cuban restaurant and not serve Cuban sandwiches?The food and drinks are ridiculously overpriced for what you get.  I ordered chicken and mango quesadillas, which came with a selection of two "salsas or dips."  The portions were very small, to the point that it looked more like an appetizer than an entree, and both my "dips," combined, wouldn't have filled a shot glass.  My friend ordered enchiladas, which came out after I had already finished my entire entree, with no explanation whatsoever for the delay in service.  I'm pretty sure she wouldn't have been served at all if she hadn't flagged down a waiter to ask where her entree was.The food itself was very generic.  The guacamole seemed to be pureed avocados with no seasonings or texture whatsoever.  My friend said the cheese on her enchilada was basically just microwaved Velveeta.The service was also terrible.  It took forever for the servers to provide our food, provide the check, and return my credit card and receipt.  When a server overheard me complaining to my friend about the delay with my receipt (seriously, it took at least 15 minutes for them to bring it back), he simply said there was a "problem in the back" and that they'd bring it out soon.For the location and cost, I'd expect much better than tiny, flavorless Mexican dishes that don't even come out of the ktichen at the same time, and waitstaff that actually waits on their customers, rather than ignoring them entirely.  There are plenty of better options in Clarke Quay, including at least 2 other Mexican restaurants.  I'd pick either of them over Cuba Libre.

address: 3B River Valley Rd #01-13 Clarke Quay - The Foundry Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: I was hoping to be the first to yelp Cuba Libre's mojitos but alas, the lady before me has beaten me to it.The mojitos! Excellent, but the most I've ever spent on one drink at $25. Yes its huge. And good...but wow.Great place for live music and salsa. My friend was a constant fixture here years (sorry ladies! He's now gone). But great spot for ppl spying and atmosphere.

address: 3B River Valley Rd #01-13 Clarke Quay - The Foundry Singapore 179021 Singapore
comment: According to a colleague, cuba libre has the best mojitos. When asked what's the criterion for a good mojito, she said, the Mint and sugar cane first then rum aftertaste. For $24 a huge glass almost like a pitcher, you get an alcohol packed drink that guarantees highness. Ok that depends on how good a drinker are you. I guess it's quite worth the money. What's best to have with the mojito? Nachos. For 14 bucks, you get a huge pile of corn chips with a pile of beef or chicken con carne, salsa and cheese. It's awesome! Ok maybe it's the alcohol talking at the point but it is indeed better than brewerkz.So if you want an afternoon drink or to chill out after work, this is quite a good place to go.

address: 531A Upper Cross Street, Hong Lim Food Centre & Market #02-54 Singapore 051531 Singapore
comment: was early for my tennis game, so decided to look for some breakfast joint for carbo loading.located within hong lim food centre & market are little gems and this is one of them.i have always had a soft spot for lor mee.and this was my chance for a lor mee and carbo fix.i ordered the $4 version as i did not want stray coins in change.a big bowl it was indeed.for carbo, i chose the bee hoon and it came with slices of fish cake, braised pork belly and fried fish.it also came with their special ngor hiang balls and fish nuggets, both very well seasoned and nicely fried.topped it off with your choice of minced garlic, chilli paste, fresh cut chillies and/or coriander leaves.and finally the black vinegar and pepper, as you like it.now comes the important part where you need to give it a really good mix, for all the flavours to combine well together.the hearty gooey, not too starchy, mixture is now ready for your enjoyment.the good thing is that at 7ish in the morning there was no queue.

address: 11 Unity St #01-02 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: If you love your sake, this is the place in Singapore!  This is a traditional Japanese sake bar and you should expect to be surrounded by bibulous company, no less.Sato-san, the boss is also a supplier of sake to many other establishments in Singapore.  The range of sake over here is astonishing, more than even the liquor shop at Daimaru.  You can have the cheapest to the most expensive bottle here.  I know cos' I had to foot the bill for last Friday's drink - almost $500 (incl taxes) for a large bottle of  Dassai 23 Junmai Daiginjyo and 2 portions of oden (what I would call Japanese Yong Tau Foo) for pre-dinner drinks for 3.  You can also order some selected yakitori which is served from the adjacent Tori Tama restaurant.  But, go with the oden, at least that's what I assuage myself with cos' it's healthy and guilt-free.The deco is spartan by most standards in Singapore, one L shaped counter with 4 counter chairs (used to be 2) and the rest would have to stand.  Not too bad cos' if you can't stand anymore, it means it's time to call it a night!  Actually, there's a little small round table right at the back, with 3 crates which have been strapped with cushions to act as chairs.  There's also the outdoor seating which can take 10 or so.  They also serve a good range of Japanese whiskey and beers, if that's your poison.  There's also a great selection of umeshu, if that is your preference too.  We come for the sake ..... don't worry if you can't finish your bottle, they will keep it for you for your next visit.

address: 11 Unity St #01-02 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: I've been here twice, and I have been lucky enough to have been seated, both instances. Given they only have 4 seats in the whole place, I guess you should come early if you don't want to stand the whole night. Probably not a good idea to bring a first date here - this place is more suitable to come with a friend you can bitch to, especially if you are standing the entire time. Come here with a friend who can drink, leave your car keys at home, and leave happy and inebriated.Opened by a sake supplier, expect a very extensive range of sake offered here. Me and my friend are not experts when it comes to choosing sake, so we described the taste profile and our price range to the staff and they will pick something suitable for you. There are also beers on tap available (I forgot which ones); good for a refreshing pre-drink.Food! We got oden and a few other accompaniments, and you may choose a selection of robatayaki to nom on while you drink. Peanuts are free! I especially liked the oden and the grilled eihire!My only grouse is that the public toilet is in a very, VERY inaccessible location!

address: 11 Unity St #01-02 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Dropped here for a quick bite after work. Orihara is a small bar at Robertson Quay with a very extensive collection of sake, and a sizeable selection of umeshu and shochu. There're few sake tasting sets going for $30+ for three pours, but most of the sakes are only available by the bottle. I asked for a traditional umeshu and was recommended the Kakutama umeshu ($14+ per pour). Delicious! I also had the oden ($12+) which was simple and satisfying.

address: 11 Unity St #01-02 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: A friend brought me here for drinks after dinner one evening, and I was immediately drawn to the place. Large Japanese baskets are stacked outside the entrance, adding an authentic vibe. There's a standing bar indoors, and seats outside as well.There's a very impressive list of sake, as well as shochu, umeshu, beers and whiskey from all Japan. The service here is excellent. They are very attentive and knowledgeable, so don't be afraid to ask for recommendations if you're not sure what you want to order.I really enjoyed the suntory premium malts. They're smooth and crisp. There are also great little appetizers to choose from if you're feeling peckish.Price wise, it's definitely not a cheap place, but you'd be coming here for the high quality and the great service.

address: 11 Unity St #01-02 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: The good:  Love the sake selection and the staff is friendly, patient and helpful (when ordering the sake).  The water and snacks stay full, only the bottles of sake go down.  I also like the fact you get to pick your own custom cup to drink out of.  Nice touch.    The bad:  Small space, which works for and against this place.  Intimate, yes, but if it's crowded you can't get a seat and most likely you will have to sit outside (takes away from the experience).  The ugly:  Closes early and can be costly (bottles run about 50 and up).  For people on the go it's somewhat difficult to carve out time to really hangout and soak it all in.  It also gets a fair share of your typical banker dbags boasting about their latest bonus and asking for beer to make sake bombs.  The rest of the crowd is Japanese/sake lovers.

address: 11 Unity St #01-02 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: I was curious about this place at first because they've managed to make their bar look like a hole-in-wall Japanese liquor shop when all their neighbours are striving for the opposite. Turns out it's run by the people who distribute sake to lots of Japanese restaurants here in Singapore. Of course this means there's LOTS of sake.Unlike many so-called sake bars in Singapore where they have poor pickings and indifferent waitstaff, the guys here have everything -- maybe the biggest selection of retail sake in Singapore? -- and they know their shit.They also have a small range of Japanese beers: Suntory Premium, Sun Sun, Yona Yona, and Tama no Megumi Tokyo Beer. The fact that you can order yakitori from next door, as well as order the delicious hot oden from the bar all night (oden is now my drunk food of choice!), only makes me like it even more.

address: 11 Unity St #01-02 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Drunken sake nights are the best at Orihara because of the damn oden! I never stop picking at the morsels whenever I am here because the soup base is really tasty and actually pairs really well with the crisp taste of sake.Okay, that's a digression because Orihara should actually be more reputed for their extensive sake choices. It's actually quite confusing if you ask me but the staff will be more than happy to offer you a little advice. Sweet? Dry? Fruity? They will readily whip out a bottle based on your preferences. Thumbs up to the attentive staff who are always friendly despite the insane crowd they have to tend to.It does get a little (more than) crowded on Fridays so be prepared to wait for even a standing space to call your own.

address: 11 Unity St #01-02 Robertson Walk Singapore 237995 Singapore
comment: Orihara is a small Japanese bar frequented by yuppies, and is always crowded on a Friday night. I'm always here because my friends are here. There is one problem with this place - very little seating. There are newspaper clippings and print-outs that tell you how too much sitting is bad for your health - good attempt to save money on chairs? Haha.The whole Robertson Quay area is slightly inaccessible if you don't drive - a cab is your best option I suppose, though parking lots are often ample. Other than that, authentic sake, excellent oden and Japanese bar snacks means it's a place I'll probably be back (and because my friends love this place).
Is it halal??i am so craving it.. looks amazing and my czn loved it.. just would like to make sure if its hala??

Got here before the rush Workers has a smooth assembly formation to move line quickly It can't go wrong with a $5 mitchilin dish, YES average dish is approximately $5The soy sauce chicken is incredibly silky and tender, love the soy sauce.  The bbq pork is just as good It's a must try.

The world's first Michelin hawker stall! We always try to get to one Michelin restaurant each year, so why not stop here at the cheapest one?!  I never thought I'd pay under $5 USD for a Michelin meal!  They have multiple locations but we wanted to go to the original one that was awarded, inside of the Chinatown Food Complex, even though there's one right across the walkway in an air conditioned building. We lined up right before they opened and we were still about 10th in line. It took about 20 minutes to get to the front and order our food, but they do have a good system in place to keep the line under control. We chose the soy sauce chicken rice and roasted pork rice plates.  You can add extra sauce or spicy chili on the side once you get your meal. The portion is pretty generous considering we only paid a whomping $6.10 SGD!! The chicken was so tender, and the roasted pork had a perfectly crunchy outer skin and tender inner meat.

Liao Fan Hawker Chan is arguably the most hyped food stall on the planet, and I found that especially after waiting a solid forty minutes in line that the execution didn't quite add up to the hype especially given there's such strong competition in the area. Star 1: How were the service and atmosphere?I'm told the lines at Hawker Chan can easily exceed an hour, so I'll consider myself lucky that on a Saturday at lunch I only waited forty minutes. Once you're front and center, the woman working the counter is especially sweet, and you'll have you dishes in only a few minutes. Star. Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?Unable to decide between the flagship Soy Chicken Rice and the Char Siew Noodle, I opted for both, which combined were only about 6 SGD. That's insanely cheap, and some of the best value you'l find anywhere in the world. Star. Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?Honestly both these dishes were just okay, and I was surprised to find that I like the Char Siew much better than I did the Chicken Rice. Even if you don't get a full or have chicken the chicken rice is more or less bone in, which necessitates quite a bit of work while eating. From there, the white rice was just okay. The char siew was much better, but even those noodles fell a bit short. Single Star. Star 5: Would you be excited to go back?There are simply too many amazing food stalls for me to recommend the wait for Hawker Chan. No Star.

The CHEAPEST Michelin Star Meal in the world!  Only $2.80 SG for their signature soya sauce chicken rice meal.  It's good, filing and cheap!  What more can I say??Oh yes, go early.  Long lineups there.  We showed up before they opened at 1030am and there was already a long loop around lineup.  You must try this!

Biggest disappointment! We arrived at the original location to find a line of only about 10 people. Score! We ordered both the chicken and rice and chicken and noddles. $5 total, you couldn't go wrong - but it did. My First couple of bites were loaded with tiny bones. The flavors were lacking. After adding hot sauce the meal because slightly bearable, but this was one of the worst meals we've had on our trip to date - one we were the most excited about. Looking back, a majority of the reviews and articles of this hawker dated back to 2017/2018. Maybe they are past their prime, or the new ownership name changed things up? On the flip side, my husband's chicken was tender and mostly bone free - however significantly lacking flavor. Note- we arrived around 2:30 - an hour before they were closing. Not as if that should of impacted anything...

Liao Fan Hawker Chan, I salute you for serving the most affordable Michelin Star meal on the planet. I came here during brunch hours, and the line wasn't too crazy. There were probably twenty people ahead, and the wait was less than half an hour. What I ordered: SOYA CHICKEN - So delicious. This is the real deal. That sweet soy sauce flavor smothered on the chicken as well as on the rice makes you want to have wings and fly. The egg and the cucumber served on the side also complements the taste from being boring. Best of all, the price is unmatched with any other cuisines in the city for only 5 Singaporean dollars. This place is worth the trip.

I'm sure this hawker stall use to be an amazing local gem in its prime days. Signs of a red flag, when the signage says "formerly Liao Fan ....." and the original owner is not there working the stalls--is when you know something has probably changed.I thought the food was just okay. Your typical Hong Kong BBQ food, no different than something you'd get at Sam Woo back in the states. I decided to wait in line because there was a short line of about 10-12 people but the pace of the line moved like snails.  Took roughly about 30 mins to get my plate of soya sauce rice with added roasted pork.All in all, nothing to rave home about. I wouldn't recommend anyone to wait in line, even for the curious foody. Just pick another hawker stall with a small line in front of it and I'm sure you'll get the same type of HK BBQ.

Delicious! Especially the chicken with noodles. The noodles have absorbed the soy sauce which made the noodles more savoury. Chickens were smooth and tender. I didn't expect street food could have good quality of food. There was a long line up. So if interested, please go early to avoid long line ups.

When I came to Singapore, I knew I had to stop by the world's cheapest 1 Michelin Star restaurant. We got to the Chinatown complex around 9:30am but the stall didn't open until 10:30am. Then I found out that they opened an actual storefront across the street. While yelp lists that that one opens at 10am, it actually also opens at 10:30. Wanting to eat at the OG location, we went back into the Chinatown complex and waited on the line for the stall to open. We were about #5 on the line and we showed up about 45 min before opening. By the time she opened the shop, there were about 15 people waiting on the line. Once opened, the line moved fairly quickly and surprisingly orderly. They menu was pretty limited. You could order soy sauce chicken (their speciality and claim to their Michelin Star), roasted pork and bbq pork. There may have been other items but i only saw those three on this day. You can get them by themselves or with rice or egg noodles. A plate of chicken or pork over rice or noodles is $2.50 (singaporean dollar). Dirt cheap! Half a soy sauce chicken is $7 and whole is $14!! We ordered half a chicken and char siew pork over rice. The chicken was really really good. The seasoning was delicious. Not too salty or too sweet. Just the right amount of spices. It was also super tender. Next we tried the char siew pork. We thought the pork looked burnt but wanted to try it anyway. And oh my god are we glad that we did. The char siew pork was THE BEST char siew pork either one of us have ever eaten! The outer crust had a slightly charred caramelized layer that is crunchy when you bite down. The middle consists of a perfect balance of lean to fats to add tenderness and flavor. We were blown away by how good it was. I think the real star is the char siew pork and if I had to choose one, I would pick the char siew pork over the soy sauce chicken. The following day, we went back to try the store front location. The storefront prices are double what the hawker stall prices are. One plate of chicken/pork with rice or noodles is about $5. Still a huge bargain for a Michelin starred restaurant but the prices are different and I thought I should mention it. I presume the higher prices go toward the higher cost of rent for this larger location and also AC and more staff. I ordered the char siew pork over noodles this time and skipped the chicken. The portions appear slightly larger than the one we received from the hawker stall but still not a huge portion. The char siew was also not as good as the one we had across the street the day before. It wasn't as charred or caramelized. It was good but not mind blowing. If you have a chance to visit here, I'd highly recommend eating at their original hawker stall over the newer restaurant.

Perhaps the cheapest Michelin-starred meal you can get anywhere, a plate of soy sauce chicken over noodles at Hawker Chan, located in a Chinatown hawker center, costs just $2.5! The lines for this place can be massive, and we had to wait about 30 minutes on a Saturday morning. The chicken here comes with a delicious savory sauce (kind of like sa cha), and you can add on a chili dipping sauce for a bit of spice. We also tried the char siu, or Chinese barbecue pork, which was lean, sweet, and savory. The bed of white rice made for a perfect medium to soak up the sauce, and the beans on the side added some nice texture.Was it worth the price? Definitely! But I can't say that I would necessarily wait again in line just to have this a second time.

Well... I'd say my family agrees it's well deserved and true to it's reputation.... It's a rare One Star Michelin rated (2016-2018) dining icon.We had a whole soy sauce chicken noodles with Cha sil... 2 sides of rice.  Wow but wow-za!!!  Super tenter and tasty chicken.  Cha sil was good but a tiny portion.  Rice was fine.  Prices here were higher than at the original Hawker stall... However yesterday was Sunday and the stall was closed.  We've dined at the stall before and with it's lower prices and open air (hot, humid) atmosphere it's discounted accordingly.Why 5 stars?  Are you joking??? Nope... It's fabulous!

Truly the best soy sauce chicken I've eaten. We arrived at around 10:15 am on Saturday morning and found people who were congregating around a queue but had not yet started to queue. The stand opens at 10:30 am and by 10:20 people were starting to queue (the queue begins across from the stand and snakes around the other stands). I like the fact that they call customers up one by one so that you don't feel rushed or jostled while you are ordering. We got our food by 10:55 or so, so not a bad wait at all. We ordered half a chicken and one order of soy sauce chicken over rice along with a side of veggies for good measure. The chicken - even the white meat - is velvety tender and juicy which is challenging to find. The "soy sauce" sauce is the right balance of sweet and salty. I saw a number of locals getting the chicken with rice but I'm a purist and like it with rice. As we were leaving at around 11:45, the line was only a little bit longer than when we first started standing in line at 10:20 but I heard it gets unmanageable by 1 pm.

For quite the long line (I came as it was just opening on a weekday and the line was already quite long) and the fact that this place has a michelin star, I was expecting so much more.I had the chicken and rice, and honestly, the only good part about it was the chicken, and even that I felt was lacking. The chicken itself was cooked really well, and I thought it was roasted quite nicely. Unfortunately that's where the benefits end. The seasoning was quite mediocre, it tasted a little bland in some place. The rice was terrible and low quality tasting. The sauces and accompaniments taste like the typical items you can get from any other average hawker stand.The good part though, is that the price was super low. At around $2 a plate, it was a steal. But unfortunately a low price doesn't justify the wait, and I guess my expectations coming in were too high because of the Michelin Star.

Fan! Most affordable Michelin star eatery in the world. Chicken was soft and flavourful. Soya sauce is sweet and savory. Sambal and hot sauce accompanying the dish added another level of flavour. My favourite dipping sauce is sweet jalapeno vingear! Line up was surprisingly short! Highly recommend stopping by at odd hours to avoid queue. Best $4 you can spend!

Reposting my review here from the previous Yelp page that now says "closed" despite it only having a name change:This review is for the actual Liao Fan Hong Kong food stall (now known as Hawker Chan) instead of the Hawker Chan restaurant which opened after the Michelin Star was earned. Yelp is a bit confusing in that reviewers are posting reviews for both locations on multiple businesses which all have different addresses. The food stall is located on the second floor of the Chinatown Complex, which is across the street from the air conditioned sit-down restaurant. The reason I chose to eat at the stall is because the prices are cheaper and the food is "supposedly" better. Also, if I'm going to come all the way here - it's better to eat at the original right? (Especially since Hawker Chain restaurant chains are now popping up all over the world). The soya sauce chicken noodle is the dish that earned this place a Michelin Star. At the stall it is S$2.50 (super cheap for a Michelin Star meal!) I also ordered a char siew rice which was also $2.50. There are some other menu items that also looked delicious like the soya sauce chicken rice, roasted pork rice, and the chicken hor fun. Most dishes are S$3 and under. Let me start off by saying the meal was definitely good. The chicken was very tender and juicy. The noodles were cooked well. I love that they poured their delicious sauces all over my plate. Was it amazing? I'm not sure. There are a lot of other stalls in the area serving the same exact dish and most of them are also really delicious. I'm not sure what makes the chicken stand out. The char siew, however, was really good - I liked it more than the chicken.Overall, I think my expectations were too high because of this place's popularity and its star. The only reason we came here was to try the "cheapest Michelin Star meal in the world". I'm not sure if I would come here again and wait in the really long line. Comparing this place to other one Michelin Star restaurants I would give it a four star (good food at a very cheap price). Comparing this place to other Hawker stalls I would give it a five star.

The cheapest Michelin Star worldwide! Note that one restaurant in the food center is closed on mondays so you can expect a slightly longer line on mondays. The total wait until you get your food is around 30 minutes.Rice with roasted chickenThe chicken is really tasty and for S$5 you literally pay nothing for it but don't be fooled, the portion of the chicken is so little that it's more snack than a meal. Therefore I recommend to go with the half chicken!! It's a better value and the chicken tastes better as they cut it differentlyHalf roasted chicken - Just get this one! :DCoconut water - for S$3.5 you cant go wrong. Super tasty and sweet! Better than those in hawker centerVegetables - nothing special, if you feel guilty of having too much meat, this might be an option. Otherwise skip itPapaya soup - this is a dream for fobi/local Chinese people but was nothing for me (German/American asian). This is more something my parents would probably enjoy :D

Many outlets have opened since they got their Michelin Star but the original store at Smith Street still draws the crowd till this day. Still as good as before and that's why it deserves my review. Keep it up!

What in tarnation: these were the only three words that rang through my head as I sank my teeth into the food at Liao Fan Hawker Chan.I was in disbelief; an incredibly excellent MICHELIN starred meal that cost what seemed like mere pennies and peanuts.The hype here is real. Unbelievably succulent meats and flavor-packed carbohydrates at ungodly prices.I ordered the soya sauce chicken rice and the roasted pork noodle and my taste buds still haven't returned from their vacation to Deliciousville.What.In.Tarnation.WHAT IN TARNATION.

How could I say no?I heard about Hawker Chan through a friend who raved about it. I decided to go with her and storm through the crowded Chinatown to get her favorite dish. They received their award in 2017, which was the year I was there. Was I excited? Of course.Let's talk food.The chicken truly is delicious, but what makes it even more delectable is the rice and the sauce. The chicken is glazed in some sort of sauce that pretty much seeped through the soft chicken skin. Every bite, mixed with the rice is just heaven. To top it off, the pork dish is delightful too. It's the perfect consistency of fat and meat. The egg sprouts on the side just compliments the entire ensemble.Verdict? This is a true Michelin. Cheap yet delicious.

For the price, nothing can beat this delicious meal! Their famous chicken with rice is really good. I wouldn't say it changed my life, but it was one of the heartiest meals I've had. You can tell that the owner has put love and care into his craft. The flavours and textures are all well balanced. Nothing tough or out of place (all the rice cooked well).I would stick to the classic chicken and rice. The noodles were average.

Amazing chicken and soy sauce rice at a great price. Tried this for the first time today. Waited for about 30 minutes in line, which is apparently short given normal weekend circumstances. My friend and I got two chicken and soy sauce riced and a stir fried vegetable dish for only $8. The sign said this is a Michelin starred restaurant, and while it's not glamorous, it is tasty! Would recommend coming just to try it at least once. You won't regret it!

Soya Chicken rice is very delicious! And for the price of $2.50 USD/SGD it makes it even better. Although this is comparable to some of the Chicken rice spots you can obtain at hawker stalls, the building that provides a number of amenities such as bathroom and napkins makes eating here much more enjoyable.Lines aren't terrible and everyone is here to get the "world's cheapest Michelin star restaurant". Well worth the visit, I would every time I'm back in Singapore.

Had their chicken rice, chicken noodle and chashao rice today for lunch. The line was long but we waited anyway for about 20-30minites in line since it was a Michelin one star. This is what I thought of this place and food. We are visiting for 4 days, and out of so many good food in Singapore we chose this place as one of our meals. And I felt like it wasn't worth the wait and for one of the precious few meals of Singapore. It is nice that it only costs about 2 dollar each plate... but for us we were looking for something more tasty I guess? So if you're expecting a real decent and quality good taste, this is not the place. The chicken rice wasn't bad at all, but was it worth waiting so long and worth eating at a food court in china town where it was so crowded and hot? I'm not sure.... I mean... if it was exceptionally good, which I kind of hoped it to be, I would totally and happily eat at even worse environment but it just wasn't "that" good. I wish we had picked some other place where we can sit with AC and some decent food with more choices and service. I gave it a three star because the food was just okay tasting. It wasn't what I saw from the reviews at least for me personally.

Definitely a touristy spot for the hype and there's almost always a line that takes around 15 minutes. I like that the new menu lists which options have lower calories. My favorite is probably the soya chicken with egg noodle instead of rice. As famous as the soya chicken is, there is just too much bone to meat. I'd actually come back for the roasted pork rice and char siu over rice since there is a generous amount of meat  and it really hits the spot for both tasty and cheap.

Stumbled upon Hawker Chan after doing some research on food spots in Singapore. Overall, its not the typical Hawker Stall experience... as it is in a building and well kept.In terms of food, I got the standard Soya Sauce Chicken and tofu appetizer. The chicken was DELICIOUS. I live in Chinatown, NY and definitely can't get better chicken there than in Singapore. The skin on the chicken just has this texture that is unbelievable. Oily and slippery, yet hearty and firm; the chicken was delicious.Highly highly recommend this joint.Mmmm sogoooo.

As a starter, we wanted to visit the original hawker stall (which is literally across the street from the store front), but the entire complex is undergoing renovation until June 1st.   I can only speak on the storefront.It's not lost on me, or I assume anyone else that I waited in the line with, that we were all here for the same experience--critically acclaimed cheap food.  Through a bunch of youtube/news outlet click spirals, I discovered this place am glad to have had the opportunity to try the food here.  The mechanics: We got here around 1050 to discover the 335 Smith Street complex was undergoing renovation until June 1st.  Went to the storefront and the line extended to the door, but (luckily!) not outside.  You get your receipt with a number and there are a few TV screens that list your order number and when it is ready.  The restaurant takes credit card. We ordered 2 dishes: the awarded Hong Kong Soya Sauce Chicken, the Pork Char Siu/Siew. HK Soya Sauce Chicken:  Very, Very good.  The meat was mostly tender and the sauce was a right combo of savory and sweet.  A few pieces were a touch dry, but all in all, for SGD 5.50, it's worth going to for this alone and waiting. There might be better, there might be worse, but at least I have a good base to compare other versions of this dish.  My one regret is not ordering the half chicken, but perhaps on another visitPork Char Siew: HOLLLLLLLLLYYYYYYYYYYY HELLLLLLLL. Yo this was bomb.com/gov/edu.  The char siew was tender with the great ratio of meat, fat and caramelization of the outside.  If the one at the OG stall is even better, I don't know if I can handle it.  Noodles: My goodness. So good.  Some of the better noodles I had. They  enhanced the proteins we ordered;  good by itself, good in the sauce it was in, good with any combo of items I put in there.   In short, this entire bill was less than $8-9 USD for an experience that I hope to repeat in the future.  A Michelin star increases the focus on this restaurant, and I get the immediate sense that the expectations on this place are heightened.  It's cheap, it's very tasty, and if there are better versions of these items at another place or just better at this location, I hope to try it sometime soon.

Had a chance to try this place first thing in the morning and took the chance to be first in line.  Ordered the classic soya sauce chicken with rice - though I regret not getting the noodles as I hear they're great.It costs $3.80 SGD which is an epic price increase from the previously $1.80 SGD when it was in it's hawker stand vs it's own restaurant.The soya sauce chicken was really damn good and the portion size was pretty decent.  I wish I came back for seconds but had to hit up the other awesome food in Singapore.  Would come back but wouldn't wait in line and then complain about it like some of the others...

Ok so if you are visiting Singapore this is a must stop.    Come here to the original stall location if you can instead of the air conditioned restaurant location.  We tried both and this stand is much better.So we came in morning at 10am half an hour before they opened.  There was a stand and we waited behind a few other people.  Once they opened we got the full soy sauce chicken and combo cha sew over rice.Chicken was so moist and flavorful.  It was cooked and seasoned perfectly.  We also got some veggies book choy.  The price cannot be beat.Awesome food and I don't even know how they can stay in business charging so little.

I guess I understand why this place was awarded its Michelin Star. The food is genuinely delicious. For a hawker stand, it's extraordinary. But at the end of the day, it's still hawker stand food. It's simple, no frills, and served up with plastic utensils.I think the general consensus is that the food would be more impressive if there wasn't any preconception associated with the Michelin Star. But I doubt the owner is complaining.

Now this might be the most famous Hawker stall in Singapore. It was definitely on my list of must try eating well before we went there. Maybe the fame has as much to do with the fact that the Soya Chicken and rice is only slightly more than $2.00 a plate and there's a half hour line to get it? It was yummy of course but I think I actually liked Hainanese chicken rice better? Never the less this place is an icon and worth the trip. We also had the char siew with rice and I think I liked it better? You really can't  go wrong here, that's for sure.

There are 2 hawker chan's! This one is the stand in the Chinatown food court. The other one is across the street and is a sit down place with AC. After a mediocre experience with the brick and mortar store, decided to give the stand a try to see if it really is better. Waited in line foreverrr - it took about 40 min til I got to the front of the line to put in my order! Started waiting in line at about 10:20 am on a Friday. Ordered the soya chicken and rice as well as the veggie dish - both were good. Was it better than the brick and mortar store? Yes, the rice was better and not cold and hard like at the other location. Was it worth the wait? I don't think so, but glad I gave it a shot.

I came here, because of the cheap michelin star chicken (like everyone else).We ordered the signature chicken with rice, ho fun with chicken and the veggies. We spent about 10 bucks and it was delicious. If I could do it again, I would get a whole chicken and veggies. I would definitely come back, if I'm around again.

The chicken is tender, moist and just the right amount of salty, the char siu is sweet and supple, and the rice with gravy on top is just the perfect vehicle for chicken and pork. All that for S$2.80? It really has earned the right to be named the cheapest Michelin-star meal! I won't get into the merits and hype that comes with a Michelin rating, but be assured it's worth the wait. If you're going to have one meal in Singapore, I would suggest this one!
Great cantonese bbq. Award winning for Michelin one star on the soya chicken.

Cheapest Michelin star in the world! This serves HK-style roast chicken and rice. The soy sauce chicken is juicy and tender but is it thattt good? I don't think so. Definitely above average but not particularly standout. The rice is just ok as well. Although not as famous as the soy sauce chicken, they serve pretty good barbecue pork with noodle here. Would recommend getting a set with both chicken and bbq pork so you can try bothNear the original stall in Chinatown, they now open an air-conditioned restaurant nearby.

I'm gonna say this is not worth the Michelin star. It's good, but not that good.I ordered a plate of soya chicken with noodles and waited about 15 mins on a weekday. When I got the plate, my noodles were already cold, dry, and clumped together. The cut of chicken I had was the rear boney part near the chicken butt and didn't have much meat to it. I liked the spicy sauce they have on the side table and the little bit of sauce they smeared on the plate next to the noodles too. The flavor was good, but I just don't see how this beats other Cantonese options.The $5 plate is also a pretty small portion. Many people order a side of vegetables or other cuts of meats to make it a whole meal.This is definitely not something I'd go back for.

My first food hawker center on this trip cuz I wanted to try the cheapest 1-Star Michelin restaurant in the world. This is just the stand, the sit-down restaurant is across the street.Was gonna get the roast pig w/ rice cuz I'm not a huge soy sauce chicken fan. But decided to go for the chicken cuz that's their signature item. Glad I did cuz the chicken was so smooth and tasted really yummy. Super satisfying and dang cheap too.Even in the late afternoon, there was still a queue but it went really fast.

This is my first Michellin star experience and oh boy - it was definitely worth it!The line was pretty long but not as bad as you think it would be for a Michellin restaurant. This is not the original location, but one of the other brick & mortar locations.I had so many similar dishes at home - and I thought to myself, "what could possibly be so different?" The answer is a lot of things. First off is the pricing. You can get an entire meal for less than 5 USD which is a steal!!The signature dish is the Soya chicken. The chicken was extremely flavorful and the sauce is subtle. The chicken falls right off the bone and that's when you know you got some high quality meat.Next up is the triple pork platter which was basically chinese bbq pork cooked in three different ways. Honestly I like this better than the Soya chicken. It's hard to explain and put into words, but trust me it's a beautiful explosion in your mouth.

The Michelin star dish soya chicken was BOMB ! The first word out my mouth after the first bite was "WOW." I don't think I've ever had chicken so soft and juicy before. Such simple flavors but so delicious. No sauce needed at all. Dining in is rough because it's always packed. No host to seat you down, so you have to look and hunt down a table quickly. I stood at a table for like 20 min waiting for them to finish up so I can grab it for my friends and I. Food is definitely worth the wait.

It's true! This place is a MUST go to place when you're in Singapore. The price is very affordable. We ordered the famous Soya chicken and it is so good I could eat it all week long if I need to. It was worth the hour long wait.
Amazingly tasty simple meal. Highly recommend the char siu with rice, along with the soya chicken. There was a line at 11am but it was easily worth the wait. Most plates are around $3 Singaporean.

Good food, but nothing that will blow your mind. We waited in line for about 30 minutes and had the chicken and pork. The chicken was good and I liked the sauce. I actually preferred the pork. The rice was just rice, nothing special. For being a Michelin star restaurant, I expected to be wowed with the flavors, and I really wasn't. It tasted like food stall food, good, but not amazing. It is very cheap though!

How did I forget to review this spot? First taste of soya sauce chicken was a revelation- so much nuance in how the different spices/flavors came together- it is not any ordinary soya sauce chicken. Had a bit of the crispy pork as well, which was also a thumbs up. I was tempted to come here several times throughout my stay, but managed to discipline myself to try other places. But yes, I'd come back in a heartbeat.

"1 star Michelin yada yada yada..." I don't need to go on and on about the 'hype' of Hawker Chan.  I don't exactly know what it takes to get a Michelin star, but here is what I do know:- Go early (moreso...don't go at the end of day, as you risk them running out - this happened on our first attempt). On my second attempt I went on a Saturday around 11am and was pretty surprised there wasn't much of a line. This changed about an hour later when I was leaving.- Though they are famous for their soya chicken, there are so many options! I almost feel like I shouldn't write this review until I've tried more than one dish.  I had the soya chicken with rice. The dish was $3.50+and extra .50 to choose my part (I chose breast).  Waited about 15 mins (not bad).  The chicken was indeed very flavorful, as was the rice!  However in hindsight, I wold have gotten the thigh or leg. The breast was a little dry for me, and there wasn't much skin or sauce to moisten the meat.  My fault - I went by myself. If I went with others, we could have had more dishes to try out!  Rest assured, I will be coming back here again if I get to go back!
Family vacation. Delicious food. We at Chan's food twice already and today we're going again before our departure Definitely recommend Chan's dishes!

Had to check out this highly raved about chicken and rice spot. Passed by earlier in the day and was discouraged by the long line. Came back at 5p and there was barely a line! Soya chicken and rice was good, but I didn't think it was Michelin Star Ahh-maz-ing. Glad I didn't have to wait in the long line. I felt like the soy sauce flavor could have come out stronger than it did in the chicken.
The chicken and Chau Siew are both good but not something that you must have.  The service is ok and ladies distributing the food is pretty loud and rude.

I went there for lunch with my family. I went here because of the michelin starred signs. The place was nice and cozy. I ordered the seasonal vegetable which is good, half chicken was okay because i prefer to have the boneless chicken and the sauce was just okay nothing special (thats why i gave 3 stars), thai style tofu was okay, the 2 combination platter was good..CONCLUSION = RECOMMENDED!!

For the flavor and rice, I'm definitely a fan.  The price was very nice as well.Rice was nicely cooked and sauced, which is how I like it.  The chicken itself was good, but the star was the char siew pork.  It was crispy outside, with lots of flavor and just melted when you put it in your mouth.  Pork ribs weren't bad, but the ones I got were a bit jerky like, just seemed to have been cooked too long or hung to long after.Also really liked his side sauce, little bit of sweet/hot going on.  Was a bit addictive and went on everything.

Ok so if you are visiting Singapore this is a must stop.    Come here to the original stall location if you can instead of the air conditioned restaurant location.  We tried both and this stand is much better.So we came in morning at 10am half an hour before they opened.  There was a stand and we waited behind a few other people.  Once they opened we got the full soy sauce chicken and combo cha sew over rice.Chicken was so moist and flavorful.  It was cooked and seasoned perfectly.  We also got some veggies book choy.  The price cannot be beat.Awesome food and I don't even know how they can stay in business charging so little.

This is not the original location, but one of the other brick & mortar locations.I had so many similar dishes at home - and I thought to myself, "what could possibly be so different?" The answer is a lot of things. First off is the pricing. You can get an entire meal for less than 5 USD which is a steal!!The signature dish is the Soya chicken. The chicken was extremely flavorful and the sauce is subtle. The chicken falls right off the bone and that's when you know you got some high quality meat.Next up is the triple pork platter which was basically chinese bbq pork cooked in three different ways. Honestly I like this better than the Soya chicken. It's hard to explain and put into words, but trust me it's a beautiful explosion in your mouth.
