I almost feel like I shouldn't write this review until I've tried more than one dish.  I had the soya chicken with rice. The dish was $3.50+and extra .50 to choose my part (I chose breast).  Waited about 15 mins (not bad).  The chicken was indeed very flavorful, as was the rice!  However in hindsight, I wold have gotten the thigh or leg. The breast was a little dry for me, and there wasn't much skin or sauce to moisten the meat.  My fault - I went by myself. If I went with others, we could have had more dishes to try out!  Rest assured, I will be coming back here again if I get to go back!

Place is nice, line was long even though it wasn't lunch nor dinner time but was moving fast. 1 self-order kiosk & 1 actual kiosk serving the line. Food wasn't as excellent as I expected but I kinda get the idea that the sauce might be the cause of the buzz.

The Michelin star dish soya chicken was BOMB ! The first word out my mouth after the first bite was "WOW." I don't think I've ever had chicken so soft and juicy before. Such simple flavors but so delicious. No sauce needed at all. Dining in is rough because it's always packed. No host to seat you down, so you have to look and hunt down a table quickly. I stood at a table for like 20 min waiting for them to finish up so I can grab it for my friends and I. Food is definitely worth the wait.

It's true! This place is a MUST go to place when you're in Singapore. The price is very affordable. We ordered the famous Soya chicken and it is so good I could eat it all week long if I need to. It was worth the hour long wait.
Amazingly tasty simple meal. Highly recommend the char siu with rice, along with the soya chicken. There was a line at 11am but it was easily worth the wait. Most plates are around $3 Singaporean.

I'm gonna say this is not worth the Michelin star. It's good, but not that good.I ordered a plate of soya chicken with noodles and waited about 15 mins on a weekday. When I got the plate, my noodles were already cold, dry, and clumped together. The cut of chicken I had was the rear boney part near the chicken butt and didn't have much meat to it. I liked the spicy sauce they have on the side table and the little bit of sauce they smeared on the plate next to the noodles too. The flavor was good, but I just don't see how this beats other Cantonese options.The $5 plate is also a pretty small portion. Many people order a side of vegetables or other cuts of meats to make it a whole meal.This is definitely not something I'd go back for.
Great cantonese bbq. Award winning for Michelin one star on the soya chicken.

Amazing chicken and soy sauce rice at a great price. Tried this for the first time today. Waited for about 30 minutes in line, which is apparently short given normal weekend circumstances. My friend and I got two chicken and soy sauce riced and a stir fried vegetable dish for only $8. The sign said this is a Michelin starred restaurant, and while it's not glamorous, it is tasty! Would recommend coming just to try it at least once. You won't regret it!

address: Clementi Arcade 41 Sunset Way, #01-02 Singapore 597071 Singapore
comment: Nice interior, relaxed and friendly atmosphere. Great place to chill and unwind with a cup of Teh 'C' or Ice Milo. I've been here a couple times and my favorites are the chicken curry and kaya toast. The mee siam and mee rebus are wonderful too! Make sure to be early if you want the mee siam/ chicken curry though, it tends to sell out quite quickly. That's how popular it is!PS. They have great reliable free wifi.

address: Clementi Arcade 41 Sunset Way, #01-02 Singapore 597071 Singapore
comment: I think they deserve a re-rating.Food is served hot now. So I'm happy now.Laksa is not the very lemak type but still very good. I actually prefer this version.They have taken mee rebus out of the menu and replaced with with laksa on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays. Opens at 7.30 a.m. daily except when it's closed on Sundays.

address: Clementi Arcade 41 Sunset Way, #01-02 Singapore 597071 Singapore
comment: My other go-to breakfast spot just a walk away from home. Relaxing atmosphere with eclectic decor. My usual is the Nasi Lemak whenever they sell out their Mee Rebus. (must remember to go early.) The owners/staff are very friendly and chatty. Lovely family-run business vibe.

address: 31 Bukit Batok Cres #01-01, The Splendour Singapore 658070 Singapore
comment: So it isn't always the case I come across something I can call a "hidden gem". At Kotoshi Ryori, my husband and I enjoyed a great omakase dinner, where every course was prepared with careful detail and tasted delicious. As a fringe benefit, because we went in at 6pm, we had the restaurant to ourselves. Sure, the location isn't great being in an industrial park, on the bright side it is extremely accessible being right next to the expressway. Also, the restaurant isn't as small and cosy as I would wish (next time we might go perch up at the bar counter). But the food was amazing. Sashimi with delectable cuts of fish and a seared prawn that could rival a small crayfish. Pan-fried foie gras! Wagyu beef! If you are looking for an omakase dinner that won't break the bank and don't want to learn the strange ways of booking six months in advance like for some other place, this is the place to visit. Great for a slow thoughtful dinner (e.g. "what is this delicacy I am chewing on? Delicious!) maybe bring a date, or frankly, just anyone who really likes Japanese food. Service was friendly and prompt and the chef came to chat with us, so really, all you can ask of a good omakase experience. The restaurant also does budget lunches and an a-la-carte buffet lunch and dinner.Tip: if you want Alaskan King Crab to feature in your dinner, give Master Chef Albert a call 3 days ahead.

address: 31 Bukit Batok Cres #01-01, The Splendour Singapore 658070 Singapore
comment: Polite staff, traditional Japanese design,great price.and food. Will come again :-) :-)

Soon Jing Roast Meat This is one roasted meat stall which I highly recommend in Sunset Way. The roasted pork and Char Siew is ultra tasty. The owner has got the perfect formula - making sweet caramelised Char Siew, which is sweet and Savour at the same time. Their roasted pork is made with a unique marinate, roasted over a charcoal to produce a  golden brown skin, which is crispy and produces a nice crunch when you bite into it.Their roast duck is roasted to perfection with  glistering maroon skin. The duck meat is Savour with a natural sweetness encased in a layer of crispy, fragrant skin. It's even better with the sambal chilli and garlic lemon Chilli ! What impressed me is that all his roasted meat cooked from charcoal, boast of a smoky aroma that is missing in many roast meat stalls.

Its hard to find good charcoal Cantonese roasted meat, and tucked in a sleepy corner of CLEMENTI ave 4 is Hup Kee Roasted Delights.Known only to residents here, Hup Kee has one of the best roastes meat in Singapore, which will give alot of established names a run for thwir money. Their roasted pork is well marinated and succulent qith a crispy crunchy skin. Their roast duck takes me back in time, as their charcoal roasting and marinates really create a savoury smoky taste which cannot be replicated using an electric roaster. They also serve free soup which tastes awesome

This jewel of an old-style kopi tiam has been here since I first lived here in the 90s. It's been a standard fixture for residents in this area and my go-to breakfast place in the morning.I give it 5 stars not for the quality of the food (which is excellent - really, the difference is just minimal wrt other places of this sort) but for its ambience and nostalgic value for people who live in the neighborhood.
Very nice Wan ton noodles, pork rib noodles, chicken rice, duck noodle, free parking, local coffee and tea. Our usual hangout for lunch and breakfast!

To decide on what to have for dinner is always a question for us and although it may be a simple thing, it often took us quite sometime to settle for a venue. As we were driving along Upper Bukit Timah Road, we had kind of decided to have pizza but ended up visiting the Cze Char Stall by the side of it.Not every Cze Char Stall can prepare the standard items like "Yee Mee" well but I'm rather please that Hup Choon's is above average. Yee Mee had the "Wok Hei" smell, however they do have a strong lard smell which was not to my liking.Yee Mee - $4.50Xing Zhou Bee Hoon portion was generous with crab meat, bean sprouts, vegetables and eggs as the ingredients. The part we like about ordering standard items is simply because of the "Wok Hei" flavours.Xing Zhou Bee Hoon - $4.50Simply loves the home style "Cai Po" (Preserved Vegetables) Egg! It was fluffy and tasty. Best is that I can actually eat them alone without being worried that the "Cai Po" will be salty. This is something that I usually crave for as our household stove usually could not achieve such standard as we do not have strong flames in the kitchen.Cai Po Egg - $5Tasty and light on the appetite with ingredients like slice fishes, carrots, lettuce, sweet corns, tomatoes in it. If you like having soup in your meal, this would probably be good.Fish Soup - $4Overall, we concluded that the Cze Char Stall is another place that we will visit again for other Cze Char dishes.

Lovingly referred to as our "other kitchen", Hup Choon is an authentic Singaporean eatery located just off Dunearn Road, in the friendly Binjai Park neighborhood. With its Old World charm, reminiscent of the classic kopitiams of yore, HC offers some of the best Chinese fare around these parts. I don't think I've ever had anything bad on the menu, but my absolute favorites are the Prawn Paste Chicken, Salted Fish Fried Rice, Four Treasures Tofu, Cereal Prawns, and Fish Head Curry. Driving here can be somewhat of a pain as the area only offers suburban street parking, but if you get takeout (call in advance), or if you come after 8pm, chances are you'll have a less frustrating experience. Either way, the food is well worth the hassle!

Hidden along a little enclave off Dunearn Road (near King Albert Park) is Hup Choon Eating House, home of excellent cze char, and possibly the best sweet and sour pork in Singapore. If you come here on a weekend evening, expect it to be packed. It's always hustling and bustling by 7pm, so I've learnt to come much later on, where you can sit down for a nice, chilled out meal, eating beneath Parisian lamps and enjoying the cool draft that always seems to accompany this area. I have no doubt that their chef is more than capable of making every dish on the menu here taste delicious, but there are a few that I always cannot resist ordering. The sweet and sour pork is a must-have, so well-endowed in batter that each piece is so crispy; though this means that there is less meat in each piece, you hardly miss it at all. The fried butter squid has a very nice crisp batter as well, different from the crunchy kind that is used in their pork - this one is more light, perfect for seafood. I'd also get their hotplate tofu, which is as good as it gets, really. I would also ask for their recommendation of vegetables for the freshest ones, and they stir-fry it up with lots of garlic so it tastes very full-bodied.If you're craving for cze char around Bukit Timah, this is most definitely the place to be.

I guess when you put a newbie driver and a person who is very bad with directions as his co driver, things can get hairy really quick. For some reason, we took quite a long time to find this place and had to make quite a few rounds to locate this place. In all honesty, this place is really not that difficult to find. Anyway, we managed to get here at about 7pm (way past our original scheduled time at 6.30pm) and found that the place was pretty much packed. Since we had already taken the trouble to come here, we decided to suck it up and wait for a while.We ordered the grouper steamboat, fried mussels and a few other dishes. The grouper steamboat was not bad, since the fish was fresh. The mussels were pretty decent as well; quite fresh and went quite well with the chili sauce that they served.Overall, not a bad place for seafood but I guess there are better places around.

My extended family and I are big fans of Hup Choon at Binjai Park and I eat there quite frequently. Call up in advance to make reservations and order your favourite dishes or they may be gone by the time you arrive.Star dishes at Hup Choon are the 4 treasures tofu and butter squid. The former is a braised tofu dish with cuttlefish, scallops and prawns. The tofu is so soft and addictive that my friend who avoids soy-based food couldn't resist it after one bite. The seafood treasures are also fresh and combine well. I have to eat butter squid at every visit as it is irresistible. Fresh pieces of squid coated in a thin batter and fried crisp with curry leaves and chili padi, in butter. That last bit with butter makes the dish quite unhealthy but so, so tasty. I'm also a fan of the mee goreng here although it's not as popular as the headline dishes. It's fried with lots of egg, "wet" style with just enough spice. Another veg dish I like to order is the broccoli with a heavy dose of garlic. Pai kuat wong (pork ribs) is also a winner at this joint. All this with a giant glass of home made ice lemon tea to quench one's thirst.You can't eat at Hup Choon and not love the food. It's Singaporean Cantonese tze char at it's best.
Good food in a clean, cool coffee shop and reasonably priced. What's not to love. My default tze cha shop. Can be very crowded during dinner on the weekends, hence good idea to make reservations.

address: 106 Clementi Street 12 #01-52 Sunset Way Singapore 120109 Singapore
comment: Crème de la crème? Not quite. Tucked away in a little corner of Sunset Way lies Buttercake n cream, a little bistro hidden away from the business of Singapore. It is a beautiful little bistro. Cozy al fresco dining area with an even smaller, cozy indoor area. We chanced upon this restaurant while looking for something new to try around my place and with a hundred and fifty 5* ratings on their face book page (yes... 150), we thought we'd give it a go! 150 reviews can't be wrong right? Right? Wrong. Firstly, in terms of variety, Buttercake n Cream has a lot to offer. From sandwiches, to pastas, to steaks, it had a little something for everyone! Not knowing what to eat, we decided to go the "safe" root and went with pasta. While I went with the recommended Seafood Aglio Olio, the gf decided on an even safer choice..... The carbonara. Anyone who knows me knows that I love my pastas. Not only do I eat a lot of pasta but I make the very often too. Seafood Aglio Olio First impressions? It smelled fantastic. The pungent-ness of the garlic was coming through with than hint of lemon (yes, the key to a good Aglio is that little dash of lemon juice that helps elevate the garlic, gives it a good punch and adds acidity to help cut the oiliness). However, the pasta was slightly overcooked and the overall dish was pretty salty (again, this might be a preference). However, they managed to get the garlic to acidity right, which was nice. Carbonara The first warning signs to me were there. Luxuriously creamy & homemade cream sauce. Cream sauce.... 2 words that should never be used in a carbonara, essentially because a traditional carbonara has... You guessed it, no cream. I make a lot of carbonara because it's one of the few pastas that the gf really likes, so I've painstakingly experimented a lot on not only making my carbonaras as tasty as possible, but I try to make it a traditional as possible. First impression? Not very good. The dish came looking a lot more like noodles in cream soup than it did a carbonara. It was swimming in sauce. Pasta was also overcooked and it didn't help with that much sauce as it only made the Spaghetti turn even soggier. While the taste was decent, it was way too heavy thanks to all the cream and there wasn't a trace of egg flavour in it, which was disappointing. Unfortunately, we were a bit full from the mains and didn't get the chance to order their desserts or cakes. Who knows? It may be much better but we do find ourselves needing some convincing before decided to head back for cakes again one day. Overall. Average food, nice ambience but a little on the pricey side considering their location. It's a nice place to meet up with friends... if you're not overly picky about the food.

address: 106 Clementi Street 12 #01-52 Sunset Way Singapore 120109 Singapore
comment: Tried this place out for desserts because my friend raved about their chocolate lava cake. After an idyllic Sunday brunch we had nothing to do, so we decided to go there even if it is all the way at Sunset Way (we are from Bishan).The name itself suggests that it is a dessert place. There was a plethora of cakes on display at the counter and when we were there the place is rather empty. We sat outside al fresco and was amused at looking at a rat/mouse walk around the empty chairs. The desserts were pretty good. The apple crumble and chocolate lava cake are above average quality, and the vanilla ice cream had vanilla bean bits in it which means it is not just a scoop of Walls' ice cream.They also serve food, though I doubt I will purposely travel to eat there unless I am in the area.

address: 106 Clementi Street 12 #01-52 Sunset Way Singapore 120109 Singapore
comment: Business was rather brisk on the Saturday night we were there, and if not for the foresight of a friend to call in and reserve seats, we probably would have needed to wait for a long time. As seats were few, the food took a long time to be served and customers lingered after dinner, it seemed like many walk-in customers walked away, intimidated by the small crowd. Dining inside allowed us to enjoy our meal in the classy interior of the shop, although dining outside seemed rather pleasant as well, with dimly lighted lights creating a cozy, relaxed atmosphere. Food took a long time to be served, as did the drinks. As we had to repeatedly request for water, check for our drinks, mains and even desserts, and were left constantly wondering if they were too understaffed. However, when the food arrived, our previous grievances were easily forgotten in the visual treats set before us. The 3 Course Set Dinner for Two @ $49.90+ included an appetizer, a main course, one dessert (for two to share), and a drink. The Appetizers: Chef's Wild Mushroom Soup or Supreme Mexican NachosChef's Wild Mushroom Soup was creamy, contained quite a few bits of mushrooms and generally was delightful. Supreme Mexican Nachos was on the whole a rather dry appetizer to commence a meal with, and not exactly to my personal liking. The Mains: Choice of Pork Knuckle for two or 2 choice of any of the following-Char Grilled Beef Tenderloin, Dijon Norwegian Salmon, Grilled Pork Collar, Roasted BBQ Chicken LegChar Grilled Beef Tenderloin: 2 of my friends had this-one ordered a medium and the other opted for a medium-well. Medium was more tasty than the medium-well, which seemed to have been a bit too well done, robbing the meat of its sweetness and "juice". Medium was not too "bloody", easy to chew on, and definitely more savory than medium well. Grilled Pork Collar: Tasty combination of meat (and fats). The soft meat stops short of being able to simply melt in one's mouth.Dijon Norwegian Salmon: The huge serving of salmon was simply overwhelming, and if not for the fact that several chunks of it were delivered to my friends' plates, it would be quite difficult to stomach, especially with the dessert coming after the mains. Salmon was really fresh, the meat sweat. Set atop a green spinach crepe stuffed full of the greens, alternating between a mouthful of meat and a mouthful of vegetables helped eased the big piece of salmon down. For the vegetable lover, the health nut who do not want to ingest too much healthy fats (from the salmon) or the calorie conscious, starting with the delicious green spinach crepe hidden below the salmon might be a good idea.A Sweet Affair/Desserts: Baked Crumble Apple Pie or Chocolate Fondue Pot, or top up $3 for signature Warm Chocolate Pudding or Apple Rhubarb CrumbleTOP UP! to get the signature Warm Chocolate Pudding! Chocolate lovers would fall head over heals in love with the warm, molten chocolate served with vanilla ice-cream and vanilla cream on the side. Wonderful way to trigger the release of endorphin, and filling us all with the much needed euphoria ere the day/much treasured weekend ended. Baked Crumble Apple Pie was sweet, with a vanilla ice-cream atop of it. The vanilla ice-cream here is delicious, and most of us could not help commenting on how good it tasted. In short, the inconvenient trip down to Buttercake is worth it, if you have the time to spare-to find a comfortable place away from the thronging weekend crowds in more accessible places, to find parking, to wait for the drinks, mains and then desserts-and if you care much more for the company of friends  than whether the service is fantastic or not.

address: 106 Clementi Street 12 #01-64 Sunset Way Singapore 120106 Singapore
comment: Plain and egg prata were great - crispy and not too oily. There's free flow chicken and fish curry gravy to go along as well. We also had the prata goreng (out of curiousity) - turns out it's literally prata, torn into pieces, and goreng-ed like how Maggie goreng works (think mee-hoon-kuay but prata style). It's rather spicy - we didn't finish it.

address: 106 Clementi Street 12 #01-64 Sunset Way Singapore 120106 Singapore
comment: Late for morning openings - waited 7mins before they opened their doors. Waited another 30mins for food (i was the second customer, the first customer only ordered for a family of 5, 3 kids). I ordered 3 pratas too...Processed delivery orders while having customers waiting in shopCold teh tarik. Rubbery prata like eating my own car tyre.

address: 106 Clementi Street 12 #01-64 Sunset Way Singapore 120106 Singapore
comment: The great thing with this place is that it has aircon, and is opened after the nearby food court and other outlets are closed.The last order is at 11.30pm on weekdays, so if you are in the vicinity after a late night snack, this is your place.The prices are obviously higher than the next-door food court prices, but given the aircon ambience, you can't complain.  Prices are not higher than restaurants nearby.I ordered a egg and onion prata which I thought would be their specialty, but the texture turned out "crunchier" than the prata from the food court next-door.  Perhaps they like to add more flour to their prata dough to get this texture.They also made rectangular prata to be different from the usual square-ish ones.You get to scoop your own helping of the curry sauce (choice of fish or chicken).Other than pratas, they have a menu mainly of Indian dishes.Pros:Aircon ambienceOpened late relative to other food outlets in this vicinityCons:Waiting time for some dishes e.g. curry fish head took longer than a customer was toldPrata tasted average given the crunchy texture

rest_name: Xin Peng La Mian Xiao Long Bao
address: 442 Clementi Ave 3 #01-122 Bgain442 Eating House Singapore 120442 Singapore
comment: A gem hidden in a coffee shop just next to the bigger and more well-known hawker centre in Clementi. This stall makes their own dumplings and noodles. Chive lovers should definitely try their dumplings. I had the steamed ones and they certainly do not lose to those in fancier restaurants. I also tried the xiao long bao. While they are rather big and the skin is a little too thick for my liking, the taste is still great and the price is a steal!

address: 5 Ridgewood Cl Unit G2 Ridgewood Condominium Singapore 276696 Singapore
comment: My family loves this restaurant, and it's a must-go spot whenever we're all in town (all 16 of us!). We love the wing bean salad, the fried fish, the green curry, the pandan chicken wings and gai lan. But honestly, we have yet to have anything bad from the menu. The staff here is lovely, the food (and drinks) are solid and I always look forward to visiting whenever I'm visiting my parents.

address: 5 Ridgewood Cl Unit G2 Ridgewood Condominium Singapore 276696 Singapore
comment: Go to place for my Thai food cravings. Though more commercialized than eateries in Orchard Towers and Golden Mile, the cleanliness and pleasant ambiance is a huge plus over the earlier mentioned. Without fail I'll always order Tom Yum Soup noodles, which I think is value for money ($9.50), for a hearty comfort meal!

address: 5 Ridgewood Cl Unit G2 Ridgewood Condominium Singapore 276696 Singapore
comment: After moving to Singapore from Thailand I desperately searched for "authentic" Thai Food.  The big chain Thai restaurants were my only option until I stumbled by E-sarn Thai.  The Khao-Soi reminded me of Chaing Mai as well as many of the other dishes (fish cake, green curry, Pad-See-Ew, and Thai Iced Tea).  I now found my default Thai restaurant in Singapore!!

address: 5 Ridgewood Cl Unit G2 Ridgewood Condominium Singapore 276696 Singapore
comment: staff play on phone instead of taking orders. after eating thai food for 20 years, this is the worst i ever tasted. tom yum comes from a big pot, not cooked fresh. the red duck curry is just a joke as there ist only veggies and some duck - a bit less for a dish on the top30% prices in the menue. disappointed because there was no curry in the curry. it was red but had beside coconut milk taste no taste at all. a place never to go back even it is located just around tge corner... there are other and better thai restaurants in singapore, let's say, pick anyone else and it will be better

address: Blk 448 Clementi Ave 3, Clementi Hawker Centre and Market #01-14 Singapore 120448 Singapore
comment: Always good for a cold treat on a hot humid Singapore afternoon!  Entirely ok to be overwhelmed by the menu when you step up to order. Everything's good and worth a try, and you don't have to have an especially adventurous palate.  My personal favorite for said afternoon in Singapore is the ice jelly, a surprisingly nondescript name for a wonderful dessert of shaved ice over jello with fresh lime with the option to gussy it up with other interesting accoutrements.  Good pit stop for when you're exploring Clementi central.

Saviour for people in the west.. Good place for vegetarian indian food (both north and south indian) and chaats. Weekday thalis are value for money too.I think that they serve the best dosa in singapore which is paper thin, crunchy and the accompanying sambar tastes very refined. Service is good with outdoor sitting available too.

Going to an Indian vegetarian restaurant can be a problem for me because I am illiterate to the menu, especially those without diagrams. However, after the last visit and reading up a bit about the cuisine, I am feeling more at ease when dining at these places. Founded in 1965 in India, Raj landed on the Singapore island in 1988, serving Indian vegetarian food from ....North, South East West of India??? (the website says so)Before you start navigating through the menu, it is good to have some Papadam (5 at $1.80) to silence the growling stomachs. After all, everyone may also need some time to decipher the long list of food, especially when the menu at Raj is more extensive than Ananda Bhavan. So, the million-dollar question is : What to order? Well, the simplest step is to pick any items from the Dosai list. For instance, this Butter Marsala Dosai ($4.70) is a good set that will fill up any average adult. Its a typical triangular crepe filled with potatoes chunks, tomatoes cooked down to a mash. They come with the three chutneys-mint, tomato and coconut. Alternatively, go for theplain-flavoured ones like Sada Dosai ($2.90), Paper Thosai ($3.80-pic above), Garlic naan ($3.20-pic below) and choose from the array of vegetarian curry pots for dipping. The paper thosai is suitable for those who like it crisp but it is also more greasy to the touch. Ours came as shiny as a bald man's head that reflected the dining lights very well.Our first dip was Palak paneer ($10), a familiar North Indian dish that consists cubes of home-made cottage cheese immerged in rich spinach puree. It had the smoothest texture out of the 3 and received the most number of thumbs-up at the table. But it should be consumed in moderation as it was extremely savory. Alternatively, there is the Dhal Butter Fry ($7.50) which had a slightly tangy flavor imparted by the spices in the pool of simmered lentil gravy.The chef's specialty--Soya Keemar Mattar ($10), was a delectable pool of minced tofu and green peas (mattar) in an aromatic semi-solid gravy. It had a thicker consistency than the dhal butter but was less salty. The dhals were all tasty, but we underestimated the sizes of the dhals curry and still ended up with at least half a pot.In order not to contribute to the amount of food Singaporeans are wasting each year, we ordered more sada dosai and also the above Sadam Uthappam ($3.30), a thicker version of dosai. Imagine tu-tu kueh minus the filling. One experiences a sharper tang even though both Uthappam and Dosai are made from fermented batter of rice and lentils.And I am proud to say that all the food were 100% polished off at this farewell class dinner=D The slight hiccups in the service did not deter the mood as everyone chatted merrily into the night. While Indian vegetarian cuisine may not be the cup of tea for everyone, I believe it was a good cultural experience. Should you be interested to try out, Raj is a good and affordable place to begin with!

Food is good and reasonably pricedThe ambience at biopolis is better than the one at little indiaI personally like north indian here more than south indian probably because there are better places for south indian.

Starters:1) Papri Chaat - this is a cold dish with circular biscuit-like bits. Slightly sourish and very tasty.2) Samosa Chaat - another not-so cold fish with fried samosa bits and chick peas. Also sourish and very tasty tooMains:3) Aloo Gobi - my all time favourite! They do theirs well here. 4) Spinach with Cottage Cheese - smooth blend of spinach with chunks of cottage cheese. Good flavour too!5) Mushroom Curry (I forgot the name - this is very awesome! I couldn't stop eating it!!!We ordered Naans to go with the curries and their Naans are soft and fluffy. The butter and garlic ones are even more wonderful with the extra flavours on the top! Good!!!It's not cheap but a good place to bring vegetarians.

One of the best places in Singapore for North Indian cuisine. The staff was very polite and it is not very crowded too. The service was prompt and they also charge decently for it. Overall it can be a place you are looking for the night.

I was at this place for lunch, the quick lunch menu was excellent with Rajma bean curry and a tomato based potato curry. The naan was great with generous portions. I needed only one. The papdum was not crunchy cause it was laid on top of the naan. The sweet dish was great. Overall great value for money!

I went for lunch to this restaurant and we ordered a Thali set, Masala Dosai, and a Behl Puri. The food was really good but the service was horrible. We sat down and asked the waiter if we could order, he came over and the first thing I ordered was the Behl Puri - he immediately said you can't order that because it's too busy for that and then walked away. I was very shocked! They are understaffed and cannot handle a big volume of people. We finally waited another 15 minutes to flag down another waiter who did take our order including the Behl Puri. I don't recommend going here if you want a quick bite to eat for lunch. You need a long lunch break for this!

One of the better Indian joints outside the hustle and bustle of little India. Slightly more spacious, clean and a good selection of Indian vegetarian cuisines. The selection for Indian snacks is delightful, which makes me visit regularly.

If you want vegetarian comfort food in Singapore, Raj is the place. From my 40+ family man perspective, the things that make it a winner are:1) Clean and well maintained. No adverse post meal effects till date, and we have been there more than 50 times this past year2) prompt and friendly service3) child friendly- plenty of high chairs, and they provide plastic plates and spoons for kids4) diverse menu covering North and South Indian cuisine5) food is tasty and fresh, and does not use too much oil, thus obviating the need for mugs of hot tea after the meal. 6) Booze to dull the senses when the kids are acting up - this is a tad overpriced thoughOur more commonly ordered items here include dosas, idlis, Chana bhatura, Rajma, and 2 dishes we have not seen elsewhere: palak kofta - which consists of kofta made with spinach in a tomato gravyPhaldhari kofta - made from raw bananas, in the same(?) gravy - see below.For weekday lunches their South Indian thaali is quite good, although a lot of food for a middle aged tummy.The few minuses are:1) No fresh juices or lemonade2) many of their tomato based gravies taste suspiciously similar, making one wonder if they are just adding the potatoes/kofta/veggies to a ladle dished out from the same giant pot3) No South Indian curries or veggies on their dinner menu, and thaali is only available for lunch on weekdaysSolid thumbs up from me.
They burnt the special rava masala dosa and when I called the manager, he tried to con me into saying it was black pepper and seeds.
Been there many times and other than slow service sometimes have had good experience at this vegetarian only place. I would recommend to try samosa chaat and dosas.
Everything was outstanding. It was as good as the best food I had in India. It was really cheap too. Amazing.

address: Blk 448, Clementi Avenue 3 #01-41, Clementi Food Centre Singapore 120448 Singapore
comment: I normally only have fish soup when I can add milk but this was awesome without. Soup very flavorful, chili sauce was nice. Queue was worth it. Otah was really good as well.A new favourite

address: Blk 448, Clementi Avenue 3 #01-41, Clementi Food Centre Singapore 120448 Singapore
comment: Ah, fish soup. I'm normally not a fan of eating soupy stuff while I'm eating outside, but I decided to try this stall because of good reviews from my friends. Suffice to say that I was not disappointed at all: at $3 per bowl, I was treated to a relatively big bowl of rich soup that had me slurping to the last drop. Coming from a fish lover, I had no problems with the strong fishy taste of the fish meat; in fact I loved it! Each slice of fish had thoroughly absorbed the rich taste from the soup, and they had a meaty bite to them. I write about this because I've eaten substandard fish slices too many times; the fish just disintegrates and I hate that. Overall, eating this on a cold rainy day is a real treat! And on a warm day, it's just as refreshing an experience; I was always tempted to drink up every single drop of the soup.

address: 443 Clementi Ave 3 Food Pavilion Clementi Central Singapore 120443 Singapore
comment: Cheap and Good! Absolute BOMB! and I really mean a bomb if you are like me can't take the chili heat.  Bad idea to take 3 hot just one level below 4 level heat.Lots of ingredients to choose and i felt like a boy in the candy store grabbing as many things as i can fill 3 plates full.  The chef i got to say boil and fried the ingredients superbly and smell absolutely XIANG!!  the only thing is that i should be prepared to bring a huge towel as i felt like i completed a 7K run after the meal.

address: 5 Ridgewood Close Unit G6 Singapore 276696 Singapore
comment: Valle is something of a well kept secret. Tucked away at the end of the row of shops including Haato and E-Sarn at Ridgewood Close Condominium, I would not have known about it myself if a friend hadn't brought me there. Valle is a nondescript neighbourhood bar, but don't let appearances fool you. The bar is stocked with a smorgasboard of beers, ciders and ales from all over the world. I was shocked and delighted to find Paulaner Munich on tap for $12 a pint. In fact, all the drinks are priced super reasonably. You can get Rekordlig for $12 compared to the $15 you usually see it sold for at the bars in town. You can refer to this page valle.com.sg/fullmenu.ht… for the incredibly comprehensive menu. The prices listed are delivery prices (yes, they offer delivery) but I believe the prices at the bar are $1 or $2 more. Needless to say, if you're an avid beer drinker, you will really like Valle. I also like the low key and casual vibe of the place. It really is your friendly neighbourhood bar where you can hang out and with your friends while enjoying a really good beer. Sadly, I've heard that the condo management has been forcing Valle's owner to revise the closing time earlier and earlier. While they used to close at midnight, they now have to close at 10pm, I'm guessing because of residents' complaints. This is probably why Valle's happy hour ends at 6 as the owner wants to encourage people to visit in the day. I do think Valle would be a really nice spot for a quiet afternoon drink as well.

address: Blk 353 Clementi Ave 2 #01-67, Cooked Food Centre Singapore 120353 Singapore
comment: Ah Meng Delicious Food Stall is one of the few stalls that was opened during dinner hours if you have visited the small scale hawker centre in Clementi Ave 2. If not for the guy's craving, I would have gone else where as there was limited food choices for dinner.Stall is manned by a couple in the 40s with the man taking order and lady doing the cooking. If you take a look, majority of the dishes listed have prawns as their ingredients. Surprisingly they are also selling Fried Kway Teow and Crayfish Noodle.We ordered the largest fried hokkien. It had a good mixture of white bee hoon together with yellow noodles. Sotong was sliced to its thinnest that I had mistaken them as Kway Teow. Sotong was translucent, quite different from the ones we had. Fried Hokkien Noodle tasted light and did not have over powering use of prawn stock. I enjoyed the loaded amount of wetness from the dish as well as the generous use of eggs increasing a pleasant taste in it.Fried Hokkien Noodle - $3 / 4 / 5Though cooking style may not be similar to the mainstream plates of Fried Hokkien Noodle we had, ingredients used were relatively the same with beansprouts, prawns etc.Overall, it was a comforty and contented meal to someone who have been missing the dish after shifting out from clementi for a period of time.
Great laksa! Bistro version of Spice Peranakan restaurant. This is right by work so it's my go-to place for laksa, mee siam and chicken curry.. Definitely going to go back to try their other dishes!

Great chicken green curry for an unbelievable price.   Hit the right amount of spicy and sweet.  My husband enjoyed Tom Yum and the pork fried rice.  Really nice.  Have eaten here 3 times and have not been disappointed once.

An upscale modern Chinese restaurant part of the PS Cafe group, so it has that same comforting ambiance but with really pretty, colonial style decoration. The food leans towards more authentic than fusion which is refreshing for a place of this type, but is quite expensive. Would recommend the Lobster Wontons, Octopus, Crispy Shredded Duck Pancakes, the Wings and Pork Chop Hainanese Style. The drinks are also really tasty with garnishes and ingredients from all over Southeast Asia.

Part of PS Cafe so I was able to get my sticky date pudding fix. Just like PS Cafe, Chopsuey Cafe is located in Dempsey and surrounded by plenty of greenery, which have makes dining here so wonderful. Food wise, menu is a mix of Asian flavours and an array of dim sum. My friend and I ordered the starter from the blackboard which was a wonderful chargrilled octopus using charsiew sauce. The numbing pork ribs was a main we shared. It had a generous helping of fried garlic but was a tad dry.
Maybe you can only go by car.That made me even more attractive.The large table makes it the perfect restaurant for groups to eat.I like the terrace seats because we have a feeling of openness.

When I first joined the workforce (trust me, not that long ago!), takeout options were typically limited to pizza and Chinese food. So after a long workday, I sometimes find myself craving a takeout and I often end up ordering from Chopsuey Cafe. So this review is for the delivery service, not the actual restaurant - obviously the food comes from the actual restaurant but I can't comment on service or atmosphere.I am addicted to the mudcrab fried rice, I simply love it, to me it tastes exactly like how fried rice should taste like in my book. And it's wild rice, so I can pretend it's semi-healthy! The sweet and sour pork is also pretty tasty and so are most other mains I have tried. The only dish I found a tad disappointing is the prawn toasts, which is unfortunately one of my staples for a Chinese takeout.The fact that it comes in "authentic" Chinese takeout containers* is a huge plus for me. Not only are they giving me that familiar feel, I also find it is easier to eat out of when sitting in your sofa haha.I have ordered many times from them and the quality of the food is consistent. Add in the fact that they typically throw in chocolate chip cookies as a freebie and it's easy to understand why they are one of my favorite takeout places even in times when there is a wide variety of options for food delivery.*for those who have no clue what I am talking about, these containers are apparently called Oyster Pail. Google and you'll see what I mean.

Upscale modern Chinese restaurant (by same owner as PS Cafe). Food is generally good but expensive. Personal favorite is the dim sum basket which is a modern twist on the classic dim sum items (hakao, shumai, etc.). The dim sum are all creative and delicious. Other main-stay items are good as well although not particularly stand-out to be worth the price tag. Very nice ambience though. Good for chilling / meet-ups

This was hands down my favorite meal I ate during my trip to Singapore! There are a lot of good restaurants in Dempsey, but this one is definitely top dog.They serve up delicious "Asian Fusion" (Westernized Chinese) food here and absolutely phenomenal drinks. All the dishes were packed full of flavor and the best part was that they all had unique, distinct tastes. Fortunately I came here with a party of 7 and had the opportunity to try several different dishes; I can say with certainty that I enjoyed every single one. In my opinion the only negative is that this spot is quite upscale, so I would definitely only come her every now and then for special occasions, rather than dine here regularly.Favorite dishes:- Szechuan pepper chilli chicken: I expected this dish to be super spicy, but instead was quite surprised to find out it was more of a sweet 'n' spicy and tangy flavor. The chicken was nicely cooked and the sauce was just perfect. Really enjoyed this one. We also order the Tofu version of this dish for the vegetarian at the table and it was just as delicious. - Wok breath rice noodles with snapper: The noodles picked up this amazing smoky flavor from the Wok and the oyster broth was rich and delicious. The snapper was flaky and soaked in all the flavors from the broth. - Five spice lamb ribs: WOW! I have never eaten ribs that were so tender and perfectly cooked. They tasked smoky, sweet and spicy and were fall off the bone good. They do have a slightly numbing feeling though, so if you're not a fan of that sensation then stay away from this one. - Crispy duck steamed buns, White skin siew mai, Scallop crab & scallion dumplings: All three were excellent. Perfectly cooked and full of great flavor. Each were severed with a unique sauce which paired perfectly together. The drinks were also extremely good. I tried the Imperial Caipirinha, the traditional Brazilian drink. But this one had an Asian twist and was served with muddled lychee. The Old Fashioned was excellent, just the right amount of sugar and smokiness from the bourbon. The perfect drinks and flavorful dishes led to an amazing dining experience.

Food was outstanding, very unique and different.  The eggs benedict on potato rositi, mud crab fried rice and the pumpkin, coconut and shrimp soup were excellent.  The servers were very good, as well.However, the policy on table reservations is pretty strange.  When we got there with a reservation we were seated outside, but found it a bit warm so asked to move inside.  We were told to wait and they would get us a table, which they did.  However, there were several 2 tops with nice views that were empty, but we were told they were reserved.  Funny thing though, no one sat at one of them the whole time we were there.  Not sure what a reservation means, thought it meant reserved to me.  They were a bit too inflexible and not very understanding about it, typical of Singapore I'm afraid to say.It's a bit hard to get to and from without a car though.  Taxis are sporadic and where you get them is not too clear, you just have to wait till someone is dropped off it seems. Would I go back?  Maybe.

By the same people as PS Cafe, Chopsuey offers family-style Chinese food, just a little fancier. I'd say it's a little pricey for Chinese food that you can otherwise get elsewhere for half the price. However, I think it's more the concept you're paying for and sometimes, that's okay. Perfect place to go to with a bunch of girlfriends - think, Tai Tai lunch - (as opposed to having to go to a fancy white-tablecloth-tea-pouring Chinese restaurant) this place has the right amount of trendiness to it, with the same good Chinese food. Now, not quite the place to take your grandma nor the right place if you're a tourist looking for real authentic Chinese food. Like I said, everything here is family style. So it would probably be wise to go with a few people you're comfortable sharing food with. While we were here, we got the Deep Fried Whole Red Emperor Fish, Steamed Paper ShaoShing Chicken, 2 Veggie dishes and the Chili Chocolate Cake. Everything was really good. The Red Emperor Fish was filleted and deep fried to perfection (I normally don't like deep fried fish because of how dry it can get but this was not at all). The Paper ShaoShing Chicken was good too, healthy, if that's what you're into. The veggies weren't too salty or oily. And the Chili Chocolate Cake was heavenly, rich and oh-so-chocolatey. A nice addition to Dempsey Hill!
Overpriced over spicy Americanised Chinese food with an upscale decor.  Food is def unremarkable.  Ok wine selection by the bottle but not impressed with the by the glass.  Probably won't return.

Chic upscale cafe that serves Western-style Chinese food. It's not quite fusion - it's basically  Western/Americanised Chinese food, not that there's anything wrong with that but one should go with the right expectations.The honey ginger chicken which has a very sweet sauce/glaze, and the signature Chop Suey vegetables, which includes brussels sprouts and broccoli are both delicious. Had desserts on a previous visit and remembered those to be excellent too.Food's pricey, though. So get your wallet prepared for that too...Staff are great, very attentive and service is quick and up to standard.The only miss was a Sweet Pork Belly Bites starter which had a flavourful sweet glaze but the little strips of pork belly were too thin and had been cooked to petrification. Stone. Hard. When it's pork belly, that's enough to make you cry.

The food here is ok but the service is terrible!  Waiting is expected from getting a table, to being served water or taking the orders. The orders arrived slowly and in random order. Good is good however. So come here only if you have plenty of time.

This place and its food is really addicted. Since the first time i come here, till today their food is constantly good. Fusion asian chinese food, nice presentation, lovely ambience and decor, warm service. Thats why i always come back here as i miss their food frm time to time. I love most their crispy duck in a bun and goodie green juice! Yummy! Recommended!

Excellent food though the price really makes it difficult to justify. The food is quite yummy for what  it is, which is a sort of Asian fusion by way of those Western Chinese takeaways that every student becomes intimately acquainted with and takes full advantage of but never actually can taste again once they leave campus. This place is reminiscent of that but sexes it up with a strong sense of fun and style. The food is decadent, delicious and made with a well judged amount of spice, tang and yum. Whilst purists may scream bloody murder but Chop Suey is not trying to be "authentic" it's trying to class up those dishes we've come to know and love living overseas and who can really argue with such a pretty and well judged attempt at doing so.

Pro: 1. the food was very good2. The waiters and waitresses were very professional3. Beautiful setting & gardenCon:1. Price was too high to small quantity of the food2. The manager ver snappy3. Furthermore, as soon as finished the dinner the manager came and told us that she had reserved this particular table for another. It was 9:45 pm and no other customers were waiting what so ever.Very unprofessional.

Went over this weekend on a lazy Sunday evening.Let me begin with Five stars for service. The staff was top notch! The food was excellent! Shoutout to our waiter Angie who recommended the right dishes and portions sizes! We ordered steamed dim sum, crispy duck pow pockets, chilli soft shell crabs, charred chicken rice noodles, beer, juice. Total damages were 140$ as expected. The charred chicken noodles were a clear winner and other dishes were good as well My ONLY complaint was the bun with the chilly crab! Chewy and disappointing. That lost them one star. Was in a good mood so didn't bother pointing it out to the staff. I am happy to revisit and change my review if the chef promises me better buns for the chilly crab

As oxymoronic as it sounds, Chopsuey Cafe is as authentically bastardised as it gets. So judge it on its own, as a commingling of American culture and Chinese cuisine, and temper your expectations of Chinese food as you know it.Service was faultless: upbeat, efficient, and sincere. And knowledgeable about the menu enough to make excellent recommendations.We had:1) Crispy Duck Pow Pockets ($17): pillowy-soft steamed white buns jammed with sliced duck confit, pulled roasted duck, julienned vegetables, and drizzled with a tangy-sweet bean sauce: a must-try.2) Szechuan Pepper Chilli Tofu ($18): a vegetarian variant of kungpow chicken, comprised beancurd squares wok-fried with blackened dried chillis, garlic flower, pickled radish & ginger, mushrooms, long beans, and cashews in a peppery szechuan sauce. Skip this, it was middling and forgettable.3) Crispy Crackly Organic Egg with King Prawns ($18): a fuyong omelette of sorts, was laced with holy basil and chilli for a subtle heat, and drizzled with honeyed soy for extra oomph. Lovely, albeit a little oily.4) Honey Ginger Chicken ($24): ginger-marinated chicken wok-crisped and then tossed with honey, ginger root, sesame seeds, and curry leaves; reminiscent of sweet & sour pork. I can see why a Caucasian palate would like this.5) Chopsuey Chopsuey ($16): a medley of seasonal organic baby vegetables sauteed with holy basil. The smoky char was evident, as was the delectable crunch.6) Wok Breath Rice Noodles with Snapper ($26): fish hor fan dotted with silver sprouts and spinach, and drenched in a rich oyster sauce gravy. It's not the memorable hor fan I've ever had, but I liked the smoky char coming through every bite, and appreciated that the sprouts were relieved of their heads and tails properly.7) Vodka Cheng Tng Cocktail ($19): didn't like it. The sticky sweetness of the cheng tng only exacerbated the bitter edge of the vodka, instead of balancing it.

A bit on the expensive side, but definitely worth trying out. Love the ambiance at this location. A great brunch spot. I tried the smoked braised duck and omelette which was delicious. Be sure to save room for dessert. We tried the lychee tart and the chili chocolate cake topped with vanilla bean ice cream. I would order the chocolate cake again.

Went for brunch on a Sunday with a group of friends. Took more than 10minutes for them to come and take my drink order. Food was decent. Enjoyed some of the dumplings but not all. Had lamb shank with tamarind for main and it was good. It's a good place to visit if you want to enjoy an okay meal in nice restaurant with good ambiance.

Really great choice for a family dinner or couple dinner. Maybe not the best choice for children. Their menu is amazing, the crispy beef is great and their ginger chicken is also to die for. Slightly expensive but worth it for a nice dinner outing. 100% would recommend at Dempsey Hill.

I wanted to bring my son to sample the food at chop suey cafe. I had a good experience previously. The establishment i tried this time was at Dempsey. The location is very quaint. Very nice actually. The food is fusion chinese. And that's what makes it interesting. The flavors and textures are Chinese but not exactly. The chef mixed herbs and spices to make it different from traditional Chinese fare. Flavors are strong. Nothing subtle about it. The strong flavors and sauces require you to accompany the dishes with rice. The food was good and fresh, however prices was a little on the high side. Service too was good and attentive. Overall I would recommend paying a visit particularly if you what a change of typical Chinese food.

Owned by the famed PS cafe, ChoPSuey caters toward the upscale foodie who loves westernized-Chinese food. Tucked away in a quieter part of Dempsey Hill, ChoPSuey provides an ambience filled with decor circa 1920s Shanghai.
Brilliant combining Chinese and western cuisine.  Warm place with friendly staff.  Don't miss the pork buns.

address: 12 West Coast Walk #01-04/05/06, West Coast Recreation Centre Singapore 127157 Singapore
comment: My parents have been bringing us to Jack's Place at West Coast Recreation Centre for more than 10 years now, we used to come by almost every single Sunday for a family lunch! It used to be my motivation to come for my ballet class held at a centre just at the recreation centre as well - nostalgic memories were created here! While Jack's Place does have many other branches spread out all over Singapore, my favourite has always been and always will be this particular branch. The staff there have mostly been working for more than 10 years too - from the waiters to the cashiers to the managers, they pretty much watched my sister and I grow up. We just recently dropped by to celebrate my last birthday, and it was a great feeling to see the familiar faced auntie bring out my birthday cake - just like she did 7 years ago. Staff here provide excellent and heart-warming service, and they really do mean to strike up a conversation when asking if you are enjoying your meal, not just as part of the protocol service standards like some other restaurants. Food wise, be sure to try their T-Bone Steak at least once, medium well is usually perfectly done, with a slightly pink centre and juicy meats with a crispy surface. Their portions have been consistent over the many years, unlike some others that seem to be continuously shrinking! Another old favourite would be the chocolate cake, with thick layers of comforting chiffon and smooth creams, and a generous sprinkling of shaved chocolate over the top. Of course that was my birthday cake!

If you've never had a Thai-style beef noodle soup, then I have to wonder where you've been all your life!  The ubiquity of this apparently humble dish is a testament to its​ magical allure.  Thaksin has been putting out its version of this quotidian Thai staple in Singapore for quite some time now and what is unique about it is that this stall is Halal-certified, which means all of their ingredients are Halal-sourced.  All the usual adjectives apply when describing the offerings at Thaksin, and special mentions go out for the Pad Thai and the Beef Noodle Soup.  I strongly recommend the "mixed" soup which has tripe, brisket, and beef meatballs. Say "yes" to the fresh veggies and what you'll end up facing is an aromatic bowl of fresh ingredients and delicious beef bits steeping in a hearty brown broth of bones and aromatics that has been developing more and more depth in that roiling cauldron.​Thaksin is another excellent reason to visit Clementi Central and one more stop in the food crawl through this food enclave in Singapore's heartland.  This same coffeeshop also houses Hong Kong Street Chun Tat Kee, Brother's Rojak, and Tan's Tutu Kueh.  Great bang for foodie buck!

As opposed to more famous hawkers around SG, Clementi is lesser known for hawker fare but Thaksin Beef Noodles is a gem hidden within this suburban area. Quite a quirky name for a food stall and probably works well for marketing purposes, the stall also dishes out a number of Thai food which I should look to try someday. In a bowl of beef noodles, you get kway teow, generous pieces of beef with tendon, beef slices parsley all within a rich broth. You can get it in 4 sizes: "Standard" ($3.50), "Value" ($4), "Supreme" ($5) and "Super" ($6). The broth is really herbal and deep that can only come with boiling their soup for ages. The winner for this dish is having a bite of the soft rice noodles with tender beef slices and fragrant parsley. Very comforting dish you'll want to have on a rainy day.

address: Blk 20 Ghim Moh Road #01-04 Singapore 270020 Singapore
comment: Wow. $4 each for a Duck Rice set and for Duck Porridge, with a soup each.The soup - often an afterthought - was rich and delicious, clearly cooked with care and duck bone.The Duck Rice was pretty good. The rice could have been stickier, but it was still amazing and the duck meat tender.The porridge was the MVP. Stunningly well cooked porridge with incredible duck sauce, french onion and succulent duck. A total steal at $4 - well worth the Bib Gourmand, and destined for greater accolades.

address: Blk 20 Ghim Moh Road #01-04 Singapore 270020 Singapore
comment: Ghim Moh new market is big, nice and clean.  The queue on the duck stall is the longest even at 7pm. Half a braised duck, rice, tofu and chilli sauce were $20, I thought it was amazing considering how good the boneless duck and tofu was.  Really enjoyed it.June 14 2016Half a duck, no rice - still fantastic!

address: Blk 20 Ghim Moh Road #01-04 Singapore 270020 Singapore
comment: This hawker store is at Ghim Moh market. The Duck meat is soft, tender & juicy...Which I always order their breast meat.....lean meat. Their rice is cooked with dark sauce, has the right flavour. The chilli has the right taste to go with Duck rice. Put in a bit of the chilli (chicken rice chilli added with sambal) on each mouth full of rice and duck meat & it'll be delicious.

address: Blk 20 Ghim Moh Road #01-04 Singapore 270020 Singapore
comment: Yummy duck rice no fuss and quick meal do drop by and try to believe it highly recommended

address: Blk 20 Ghim Moh Road #01-04 Singapore 270020 Singapore
comment: There's a reason why people would queue 20 mins during lunchtime (assuming your boss gives you one hour lunch break :P) for this. Taste:The duck meat is tender and flavorful. I don't know how else to describe. Felt like I could never have enough. They typically give the breast meat, unless you request for other parts. The yam rice is also well cooked and fragrant. And their thick dark sauce ensures that the rice isn't too dry nor is the sauce too wet. The yam taste isn't too overwhelming, but nevertheless is enough for you to enjoy it (and not think it's just white rice that's black/brown in color) Soup provided isn't bland and the herbal taste is quite significant. And the cucumber provided is crunchy and fresh. (I'm that nitpicky)Oh, and did I mention about their chilli? Make sure you get their "mix", not just the belachan or just the chilli sauce... You've got to mix them! Quantity:The basic set meal cost $3, but I'm only satisfied with $4 - I eat relatively more. That being said, my colleagues are typically OK with the $3 meal.  Note that from $3 to $5 only the quantity of duck meat changes, but that shouldn't stop you from splurging on more duck meat. Overall:The only real price to pay for this meal is your time. Be ready to wait about 20 mins just to get your duck fix, but it's worth it!

address: Blk 20 Ghim Moh Road #01-04 Singapore 270020 Singapore
comment: It's yummy. most other people also think so. duck is good, rice is good, extras are also just as good. i like mine with lots of gravy.$3. you have absolutely nothing to loose.

address: Blk 20 Ghim Moh Road #01-04 Singapore 270020 Singapore
comment: Duck rice is the lesser known counterpart to Hainanese chicken rice but a good bowl of duck rice beats the latter. I believe Chuan Kee has a number of branches around SG, with the one at Tampinese being the first place I had it.I like their rice - A LOT. It has a yam-like flavour to it and is done just slightly moist so it pairs nicely with the tender pieces of duck and braised sauce. The duck meat here takes on the form similar to chicken rice as it is leaner and slightly smashed. The soup is another highlight to the dish - deep, herbal and flavourful. It goes so nicely with the rice and I always try to ask for seconds for the soup. This is great duck rice that beats roasted duck or chicken rice anytime.

Tze Char or Wokshops are the greasy spoon diners of Singapore.  They're unpretentious, usually located in residential neighborhoods or near commercial or industrial districts serving those of us who have to work for a living.  The menu is invariably a copy of the original document, presenting a solid foundation of a variety of noodle and rice dishes upon which classics such as sweet sour pork ribs, cereal prawns, and sometimes crab are added for breadth.Chi, prima facie, is just another tze char joint.  It is run, very efficiently, by a brother from the Mainland, there are si fu from Malaysia behind 3 burners who work the woks like rented mules, churning out a mouthwatering progression of dishes as you stand, gawk and then order.  But come here more than once and you begin to scratch the surface to find inconsistencies with your first impression.  The wok hei (I don't rightly know the right Anglo phraseology that can adequately express it's full meaning) is strong with this one.  It comes through each dish, in the first bite or sip, that fiercely independent character of flavor.  Then there are the subtle nuances, a classic dish presented in a slightly different way, off kilter, taking you by pleasant surprise.  The Yue Kuang He (moonlight hor fun) is a good example of this mischievous wok play.   An offering of flat rice noodles, beef and sprouts  co-mingling with in a hell-broth of dark sauce, fish sauce and rice wine and made a family by their brief sojourn through the si fu's wok; enticing enough already, one would think, but wait, whats's that nestled in the still steaming spawn of the wok?  A single raw egg dusted with white pepper, the yellow liquid yolk still just visible.  You are gently encouraged by the brother from the Mainland to break the runny yolk into the steaming noodles to continue "cooking" this dish.  Pure genius. Your ecstasy is made complete with your first steaming mouthful.Oh yeah.  The crab is good too...
Great place to sit and to enjoy the Singapore culture of street food ! Sadly  a little bit of fast food style. There are better places to enjoy  tasty  Chinese cuisine.

Nice dim sum place conveniently located in the Clementi Mall. One of the many Crystal Jades on the island. Since it's a franchise restaurant, there's good assurance of quality. Reasonable prices and delicate food.  We ordered shi-mai, ha-gao, and a few special items from their menu. All good!

As good as it gets with Crystal Jade.  Consistency when you walk into any outlet so you can have expectations?  What's not to like?!   Sturdy Hong Kong bistro (chaan teng) standards in decent portions, and reasonable service overall.  Decent value for money. Just the victim of being in Singapore whether there are good eats around  every corner and sometimes even when there isn't a corner...you get the picture, competition is stiff.   So while you'll never complain that the food here is "no good" you'll possibly regret not spending your calories on something better suited to your cravings and palate that day.  Choose wisely.  When you don't know what you want, Crystal Jade is always a solid choice.

The restaurant was located just after the bridge from the MRT station. The place looked empty from outside but we were showed to a table all the way to the end, next to the noisy kitchen. Being hungry, we just stick to the table.Classic Ting Zai Congee 荔湾艇仔粥  (S$9.30++)Sliced fish, cuttlefish & shredded porkThe porridge was served with crispy fried dough fritters and shredded cabbage. XO Carrot cake XO 酱炒萝卜糕 ($10.80++)Not very spicy, but I would prefer it to be more crispy.Double Boiled Pork Softbone with Watercess 西洋菜西施骨汤 (S$7.80++)The pork was very tender and the soup was flavourful.Seasonal Vegetable with Assorted Egg in Superior Broth 金银蛋浸时蔬 ($15.80++)Spinach with salted egg, century egg, and egg. Although century egg was strong in flavour, it did not overwhelmed the dish.Crispy Beancurd Cube with Salt and Pepper 黄金豆腐粒 ($7.80++)Simple dish but flavourful on its own.Washed down with Ginger Tea with Pomelo Honey 姜茶柚子蜜 ($3.10++), which I would prefer the ginger taste to be stronger.

Great place for Hong Kong style bread and pastries. From around 9pm onwards, there is a 20% discount. My favorite item is the red velvet muffin. The biscuit crumbs on top add a next texture to the fluffy muffin which is not too sweet. Other popular items are the chocolate zebra bread, carrot cake, egg tart and char siew bun.

I have never been to this branch, but have been to many other branch.The food at the franchise is pretty consistent. Quite save to drop by for a good meal.The bakery is also everywhere, pineapple bun is nice.

Honestly I expected much more from this place. The food was ok.. though over priced for the quality.. but the service was horrible. Overall the food came out meal first then appetizers.. we had to chase down our servers as they often forgot parts of our orders.. we will not be coming back.

I have been here more than a few times and the food has always been good and solid, up to par with any Crystal Jade outlet. (I am not sure why there are so many haters on HGW.) The prices at Crystal Jade seem to steadily creep up, but that is true of any establishment anywhere in Singapore these days. (I was made to ponder, "Didn't one "long" of lormaigai use to have three bundles rather than just two? Didn't most of these dimsum items use to be in the $3.xx range rather than in the $4.50-$5.50 range?" I felt a bit like the animals in Animal Farm, being told that life in Singapore is constantly getting better and cheaper, rather than more crowded and more expensive.)On our last visit (June 12th 2013) the Yangchow fried rice was a bit salty, so we let the waitress know. Hopefully it will be corrected on our next visit.

I was disappointed when Crystal Jade Kitchen closed in Jurong Point, leaving only its La Mian Xiao Long Bao outlet behind because I love the Cantonese dishes that Kitchen whips up. The next closest Kitchen to my house was thus the one at Holland Village, which wasn't the most convenient to get to so I was glad when the Clementi Mall had Crystal Jade Kitchen as one of its tenants.Crystal Jade Kitchen serves up Hong Kong noodle favorites such as dumpling noodles and stir-fried beef hor fun along with thick flavourful congee with many different ingredients. Some of my all-time favorites are the beef fried rice, the prawn congee, the stir-fried prawn hor fun and dishes like the salad sauce prawns. It's a great restaurant to go with family and friends for affordable Cantonese food that also includes some dim sum items on its menu.
Always love crystal jade, i always have dimsum here at crystal jade clementi mall. They have good variety of dimsum only missing xiau lung pau

This is better than Nandos. If you're looking for good Portuguese chicken, I'd go here instead. Apparently they're an Australian chain but there's only one in Singapore so far. I went with the family and we ordered the Bondi Burger and a whole chicken with chips and spicy rice. Chicken is fall off the bone delicious. The Original Chili sauce reminds me of the Hainan chicken rice chili sauce a little.

Australian chain known for their flame-grilled chicken with a variety of sauces.  More of a fast food style than a typical sit-down restaurant, great for a quick but good meal. Conveniently located near Holland Village MRT, just a short few minutes walk. Minimal lines, fast service, and wallet-friendly price points. Got a half chicken ($11.90) and Chicken Taça (bowl in Portuguese) ($9.90).Grilled chicken was delicious with their "legendary chilli sauce", tender and tasty, the chicken breast didn't taste bone dry. As the other review pointed out, chilli sauce was similar to the Hainanese chicken rice chilli, slightly sour and garlicky. Chicken Taça came with spiced rice, salad vege on the side, topped with chargrilled chicken tenders and sauce over it. Rice was underwhelming in its flavour profile, and Garlic sauce we chose for the Chicken Taça was disappointing, tasted more like creamy mayo with just a hint of garlic. Would skip the sides and go for the grilled chicken. They're having some promotions now, including BOGO on their Chicken Rappa. Also, they're on Burpple Beyond -- you can get 1 for 1 off Main Dishes! Use referral code "JOAN458" for 20% off your Beyond subscription :)

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-22, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: I have never been to any of its outlets before so am quite happy to find one at my door step. It was between Brotzeit and 18chefs and since we had a teenager with us, 18chefs seemed more appropriate and it was!we were greeted by the man himself at the door  (only 2nd day of opening so maybe that's why he's there) and his huge team of servers.quickly we were ushered to our table and to my surprise, the place was packed with teenagers. the vibe and music certainly fit the bill and after checking out the menu, i can see why the youngsters pack the house. teenagers receive special deals in this place, so does senior citizens and corporate friends such as ntuc and safra members - the list is quite extensive so you may want to check out their website for more information.you simply write your orders down and head to the cashier to pay. within 10 minutes you will have your order at your table. we ordered the salted egg prawn pasta and a platter with deep fried snacks such as calamari, onion rings, nuggets, chicken tenders. the only reason why we ordered this was because of the salted egg dip that comes with it. we also ordered the heart attack fried rice with strips of steak and teriyaki chicken with a side of potato apple salad.verdict for salted egg yolk flavoured dishes...the pasta has a more intense flavour than the platter dip. i would order the pasta anytime but not the platter.the heart attack fried rice reminded us of chinese gultinous rice and the accompanying sauce supposedly was made with a peanut butter base and topped with bits of sliced chilli and minced garlic. strangely the only taste i could get out of the sauce was tomato ketchup. the steak was juicy and tender so i may just order a steak dish with no fried rice the next time. i ordered the drink and ice cream combo with my main so i was given a small cup of cookie and creams ice cream at the end of my meal. yummy ice cream and a great way to end my night there.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-22, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: This restaurant was super busy on a Thursday evening. I felt a bit out of place as everyone seemed to be a student and it was quite loud, the inside felt a bit like a college canteen, mainly due to the fact that the tables are tiny and have about an inch between them. But luckily the waitress agreed to swap our seats to the outside terrace which was less crowded.We had the steak and hart attack rice for two,the steak was ok but I felt that the HA rice was just greasy with no real taste. Overall I guess the food is ok for the price point, however I feel if you are looking for a cheap steak you are better off at Astons.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-22, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: The prices here are relatively cheaper so I did not have high expectations of the quality but was pleasantly surprised. The salted egg pasta that I had was one of the better versions that I have tried so far. I like how the sauce is not watery or diluted. There was a right balance of saltiness and texture. The place can become crowded with young students and noisy groups so service standard may get stretched but I'll consider returning for a quick and satisfactory meal.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-22, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: I've been wanting to try this restaurant chain for a long time. Every time I walk by one of their outlets, the line is long and it's super busy even late at night. This outlet is newly opened and it looked like we didn't have to wait so we came here for dinner. Eighteenchefs has a positive social media presence due to their social enterprise business model. I really like their story and hope they do well, but I can't say anything good about their food. We ordered the heart attack fried rice with egg, the salted egg snack platter, and teriyaki chicken. The snack platter was a bunch of cheap deep fried foods, and not very much of it. I like deep fried food, but this was just cheap frozen stuff they threw together. The salted egg sauce did taste a little of salted egg, but it wasn't outstanding. The heart attack fried rice had a strong garlic flavor and it was fine, but isn't what I would call outstanding. I would go next door to botejyu for their garlic fried rice. The teriyaki chicken was missing teriyaki flavor, although I did taste the char of the grill. The potato and apple salad side was tasty, but it wasn't the point of the dish.I'm wondering whether the create your own dish fares better, but I don't feel particularly compelled to try this chain again. The lack of care in some of their dishes makes me think it doesn't really care beyond giving their food a nice and catchy name with a positive branding.

Was looking for a petfriendly cafe in West to bring my dog, and found this gem!My parents were really taken by this quaint place!I do recommend to try the meesiam (which may seem like a strange choice for cafe food), but the portion was really generous, & the broth was really tasty!The ondeh ondeh cake is pretty good too! The toasted coconut bits really made the cake!

Nice ambiance. Pricy quality.Lamb shank $28. Well grilled with moist insides and slight crisped on the edge. Chewy yet flavourful. I don't like the fats though it adds to the taste. I don't mind the redness.Beef Sirloin $28. Medium rare. Good balance of greens and fries. The fries is the surprise. I will remember the fries. As for the steak, it's pretty good. Nothing memorable, on the positive side.Ambiance like this on the west side neighbourhood is a nice find.

Tucked away in a corner of a residential street, I wouldn't know about the existence of this cafe if my friend didn't introduce it to me. Business is quite good during lunch time and I would guess that most customers specially make their way here. Since it's not in a mall or upscale location, I expected the prices to be lower but it was comparable to mid range restaurants. I had duck confit which was crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. I would have preferred it to come with a less creamy sauce. Portion and taste are fine so if you are tired of chain restaurants, give this a chance!

Let's start with this place is dog friendly... I was sold at woof! We went for brunch and were pleasantly surprised, the food was wonderful and moderately priced! They were super busy and the server was running and the wait time was still fairly reasonable. I read another review that suggested that this establishment is unfamiliar with salt... to be fair, we have found a majority of restaurants in Singapore under season...  most will bring you some if you ask or you can follow our idea and carry salt and pepper with you! We will definitely be returning!

When I first saw W39.. Located next to KFC... It looked so cute and bloo!!! :) i had heard great comments about their cakes so I decided to try their rainbow cake at $6.80+ it's reasonably priced even though.. Anyone who can bake will tell you that's still overpriced.. Nonetheless... The buttercream wasn't too buttery and the cake was light. The colours were pretty too :) we had a side of chicken wings which tasted and smelt just like the har jiong kai which you get at a tze char at 2 times more than what the tze char stall would charge you for.. Nonetheless I would recommend you to checkout other places for wings and you can def try their apple crumble pie :) delicious and a  generous serving with a dollop of ice cream! :)

i put off writing this review just to see if i still feel as strongly as i did, about this place, after a cooling off period.it's been more than a month now and i think it is safe to say i'm not clouded by any impulsive verbal diarrhoea.firstly, finding this place is a challenge.even for a former west sider junkie like me.fortunately, i was cabbing it and even though the taxi driver knew of the road, he still brought me on a tour of the colourfully named roads, kuning(yellow), merah(red) before arriving at puteh(white).if you are driving, your safest bet will be parking at clementi stadium.limited parking in front of w39 is available and if you do like to take a risk at parking illegally, do have a word with marcus before you do so.it was packed to the brim on an august saturday afternoon.thankfully, we secured a reservation and were seated within.decor was pleasant enough but i'm forever wary of style over substance.staff were not the most experienced but they tried.upon the recommendation of their staff and the fact the brunch menu exclaimed it as a local favourite!
