nasi lemak with roasted spice chicken leg, that was what i ordered.when it arrived, the fleeting moments of it's decent looks gave way to an inner flaw that is hard to overlook.salt or the lack thereof.yes, most times people complain about their food being overly salty but today the oldest, most ubiquitous food seasoning was missing?did someone forget about it?but not only was the coconut rice lacking in salt, the coconut milk was way watered down resulting in a tastelessly bland, overly wet and not so lemak rice.sure, you could ask for more of their homemade sambal but again that is mere window dressing.nasi lemak rice has to be palatable enough for you to eat it on it's own.next the chicken leg, best described as a powdery turmeric mess.again, did salt go AWOL?after just one bite, all you want is to wash it away with their decent coffee.mind you, their nasi lemak is priced at $12.50, so the benchmark should be set so much the higher, no?and guess what? they interestingly use nicely poached eggs for most of their dishes.but guess what, i'm not a fan of poached eggs!:(give me oily fried eggs with runny yolks, anytime, for my nasi lemak, please!seeing how i only recently scored me the maverick badge, here is a 2 star rating in hope you can score yours too!:)

was in search for the next big rainbow cake in singapore that drove (well rather by Mr SBS uncle) me here. Cakes look pretty on the shelves that screams 'eat me'. so i did. ordered the rainbow cake and red velvet. remember how many say not to be just a pretty face but have substance? sadly this place just has a pretty face when it comes to dessert and coffee. i have to admit the sponge cake used in the rainbow and red velvet cake is light and not that sweet but the cream... OMG. tooooo sweet and too much. ordered a latte to go with me cakes but sadly I had better coffee. i'm not picky with my coffee and even I can say its meh... sooo for coffee lovers I would recommend you trying something else insteadi have to admit the service here is good and attentive. they just have to up a notch on the desserts and drinks to make this a good chill out place.i can't comment on the savories for i had none of it this time but I doubt i'll ever come back and try - looking at the reviews. however, this is a good place to come once and see the pretty cakes. overall, its a good attempt at a cafe but needs more work to reach memorable. Gambatte W39!

New indie cafes and bistros are popping up around Singapore faster than ever before (oh my poor pocket), but this is actually a good thing - more options, more variety, more cool hangouts for the weekends :)Visited W39 last Saturday with some friends for a casual breakfast, and it was love at first step-in! Located at the far end of a stretch of shophouses near West Coast Road, the exterior of this cool little bistro reminded me of a summertime beach house. The decor theme is a mix of lemon yellow stripes against fresh whites and blues, full-pane glass doors and lots of windows - such a happy, inviting place, tucked just steps away from a quiet private residential neighbourhood.Indulge yourself with the shelves of magazines, little trinkets and nostalgic old-time snacks (think rabbit brand candy, and sour lemon!) as you wait for your food to be served. We were tempted by the seemingly popular Mee Siam, but somehow all ended up ordering the Hearty Breakfast or classic Eggs Ben (all great choices). The Hearty Breakfast was yummy and very well made, eggs were perfectly fried - runny on the sunny side, slightly charred on the other... the sausage and toasts were tasty, and served with arugula salad on the side. Happy patrons we were.I really love this place - service was warm, friendly and prompt. Food was good and not grossly overpriced, and it wasn't too packed for a Saturday either. Will certainly be back again :)Both indoor and outdoor seating available. Check out my photos.Oh, and they sell some baked goods such as bread loaves and cakes to-go too.

Drawn by the siren call of the Yelp Saturday Brunch Club, hordes of hungry hungry Yelpers descended on W39 for a good balance of 'ang moh' brunch options and some local choices. Now, I've have rated W39 3 stars. I enjoyed the mee siam although it was atypical (much too rich and creamy, though the poached egg was a fascinating take), and while it might not become my go-to place when I have a mee siam craving, I definitely wouldn't mind ordering it again. The Eggs Benedict was well put together, my only complaint is that it was TINY. I could have had three of 'em. The Honey Lemon was way way too sweet, but once the ice started melting, it wasn't so bad.BUT. For everyone else at the table, I could tell that W39 felt a lot more 2-starry than 3. (And if you'll refer to Jerilyn's review, you'll get further evidence why.)The Nasi Lemak that one of the other Yelpers ordered was... very underwhelming and the small size of the Hearty Breakfast, well okay it wasn't small, just not HEARTY (full caps intended). The rice for the nasi lemak was under seasoned and the paninis were awfully small. Small niggling issues here and there that really undercut the place standing out amongst the increasing number of brunchy cafes popping up in Singapore.My conclusion after our visit? An Eggs Benedict and Mee Siam are just enough to feed one, and if that's all you order, you'll have a pretty good meal.If you stray off that path that I have painstakingly cleared for you though, don't blame me when you find yourself in a minefield of mediocrity.

Have been hearing quite a bit about this place but have been feeling lazy to trek down to the West to try it out. Well, finally I did and I wasn't disappointed at all.Was a short bus ride away from Clementi or JE MRT Station. On first sight, the place reminded me of my area at Serangoon Gardens with the cafe nestled snugly among  residential houses. Was quite crowded on a rainy Sunday evening where most people were there for dinner; isn't it a testament to how good a place is if it is filled on a raining Sunday evening? The interior was filled to the brim and so was the exterior.We weren't there for dinner but vowed to try their mains the next time around as it looked so good from what we saw at our neighboring diners' tables. Ordered a chocolate cake (forgotten the exact name but have a look at my picture) and the texture was gooey, melty and is a chocolate maven's piece of heaven - a must try. The coffee wasn't the best but was passable.Loved the atmosphere! Wished I knew of this place while I was at NUS as it would definitely be on my hang-out list!
Relaxing ambient. Simple decoration. Food was quite good but seems to be in a higher price range for this kind of restaurant.
Homely with lots of wooden furniture and glass walls.  Best tiramisu with expresso to mix together.  Mee Siam tastes superb too. Awesome!

The only cafe/resturant I've found in West Coast that comes close to an Australian style coffee shop. Coffee was good and they have a decent range of meals and snacks on the menu. It has great customer service which can be hard to find in Singapore.

Heard about the crowd here on weekends so I was a little concerned about coming here on a Sunday night. The place wasn't too hard to find from the nearby bus stop (you might have parking problems if you're driving though!) and the ambience was decent. There are lots of nostalgic stuff laid all over the place which makes the overall ambience quite cosy - albeit a little forced, as another Yelper mentioned in his review. Having gone down mainly for dessert. A friend and I ordered a flat white, the crunchie hazelnut and a tiramisu to share among us. I take pride in my coffee and I can honestly say the flat white was nothing special - a little too flat (pun unintended) actually. The crunchie hazelnut and the tiramisu looked great and I thought it would at least make up for the disappointing coffee. I was wrong. The crunchie hazelnut had an overwhelming taste of fresh cream that made it far too sweet for both our tastes. The tiramisu came with a serving of espresso - which was something I had never seen before, and for good reason. Without the espresso, the tiramisu tasted entirely of marscapone. Even with the espresso poured in, it still felt pretty... off. I couldnt taste any kahlua liqour in the tiramisu with or without the espresso, which to me, sealed the deal as one of the poorest tiramisus I've had. If you want a good tiramisu, try out Kith Cafe at Park Mall - it's far better. The place was also quite noisy, so if you're looking for a quiet place to hang out with friends or loved ones, take note. I didnt try any of the food items, but the lamb ribs and wagyu burgers other people were eating looked quite appetitizing.  But then again, so were the desserts we ordered.Not coming back to this place again. At least the service here was something worth mentioning.

Came here with the Singapore Yelp Brunch Club and while I loved meeting fellow yelpers, W39 was well, ehhhh. It's 2.5 stars (but not quite 3) in my opinion. Let's just say, the concept is good but the execution just well, kinda sucked, for lack of a better word.Food: I got the Hearty Breakfast, and wasn't the least impressed (especially because I was at Arbite the weekend before, and they, they do a mean hearty breakfast - but more on that in another review!) the portions in general just seemed small all around (except for the local options) which would be fine if it tasted amazing but everything just seemed subpar. I also tried bites of the Mee Siam and the Ham & Cheese Panini. The Ham & Cheese Panini definitely tasted kind of like something I could've done myself, however, the Mee Siam was probably the best thing there in my opinion. It was hearty, with a nice sweet flavor to it. I enjoyed that the most. We also got the Honey Lemon Ice Tea which tasted like someone spilled half the jar of honey into. Did they?! Ambience: Like I said, great concept, horrible execution. They try to be "cute" with the cute nautical theme and selling old candies we grew up with but it just seems kind of copied. The seating inside is limited and pretty cramped and the service was alright. All in all, we left happy to have met everyone but not so happy with the food. Not horrible but really nothing special.
A lovely corner boutique cafe that serves good food and desserts! A lovely place for lunch and weekend pig out. Also good for small events and celebrations

W39 was just kind of average. Worth a visit if you just want a chill out spot with a nice decor. But not a place I would return to.The service was earnest and polite but quite inefficient. Granted that I did not try the food, I really cannot comment on any dish in particular. But when I checked out what the other diners were having, none of them screamed or even said 'EAT ME!!!' And the coffee was decent but really not worth the fifteen minute wait for it.But if you are bent on trying an average brunch place, it could be wise to reserve a table, as W39 was quite crowded on a Saturday afternoon.

W39 is the brainchild of 2 Eastie sisters and this cheerful blue and yellow spot is actually both a bistro and a bakery and that only means 1 thing for me-brunch.I wouldn't have gone out of my way for brunch in the West if not for an appointment in the area. Sorry westies, you're not gonna be seeing more food posts from the western part of Singers.My Mocha tasted more like regular latte. Where is ze chocolate??! Meh-ish latte at best. Very diluted. Thankfully I've lowered my expectation so I wasn't overly disappointed. Don't go expecting anything artisan.Hearty Breakfast ($13.50) is a greedy and lazy girl's best option. Well, first and foremost, it has everything. It's quite hard to screw up an American breakfast since everything is kinda outsourced. The scrambled eggs were a little overdone for my liking. The best part was the toast (i think it's brioche) with its airy texture. Salted butter would be welcomed anytime. I originally opted for a Brie Parma Ham Panini (or was it a Croque Madame) but i was tempted by the Braised Pork Cheeks Gruyere Panini (S$13) that the neighboring table ordered. The mouthwatering scent was too good that i had to change my order immediately! Boy was I glad i did!The panini was stellar with the slightly crusty shell and dense and moist center. Pork cheeks were tender and flavorful and the sandwich had a perfect meat-gravy-bread ratio. The taste of the meat was rather strong but i'm a carnivore so i don't care. Besides, it was balanced by the savory gravy and the light sweetness of the bread.If you're looking for something lighter, the assortment of cakes, breads and pastries should not disappoint (i base that on my review of their breads).

This was good. They had great white beer and crab cakes and salad. The tenderloin steak was also great, but it was too bloody when I had asked for medium. Sauce that came with the tenderloin was good. They let me substitute mashed potatoes instead of fries.
The food is decent. They have an onde-onde cake that is not bad. And prices are ok. I have never left upset but I have also never left completely wow'd by anything here either.
Great ambience! Nice food, real chill. Would recommend for a good outing with friends

it is the weekend! which means it is brunch - and here is a good place to get a decent one, even if more than a little far out. this rustic little cafe is unpretentious (pretty rare in the recent crop of cafes), and it serves up an averagely-decent brunch menu that spans american brunch classics to local delights.most of us started off on the western side of the menu - mostly average fixins' - their poached eggs are probably the most notable thing on the menu.they make an appearance in most of the breakfast dishes, and each is a neat parcel of cooked white and flowing yolk - good execution, but it might have helped more if the sauces and flavors had just as much care.the local specialties were rather a hit-and-miss. a hit with a very lemak mee siam that was served with a poached egg - you will want to eat this hot because it quickly loses its charm as it cools - and a terrible miss with the nasi lemak, which came with another one of those poached eggs. the rice had barely any flavor, the chicken impressive-looking but barely seasoned and a tad dry - this dish was pretty dismal.I also think that poached egg on the rice smacks a little of trying-too-hard - there's something to be said about the texture of a golden fried egg with a runny yolk and the texture it brings to the dish.but I got pretty lucky with my main of grilled saba (mackerel) drizzled with a sticky soy glaze on baby spinach. definitely not the sort of thing I expected in this sort of place, but nothing to complain about since it worked very well. the mackerel was oily and savory, the baby spinach crisp and green, and that glaze a sweet-savory counterpoint.it works for this place that its kitschy, in a good almost-believably-local way, without any of the pretentiousness in the hipster-hangouts we see these days. the food is decent, though not quite worth traveling for without a car - I suggest it only if driving and looking for a cute little place to sit on the weekend.

Ate here with the yelp crew and was expecting something delicious but definitely left unsatisfied and worse, hungry.  I think the restaurant does a good job with the decor and food presentation but I just wasn't impressed with the food.  We tried most of all the things on the breakfast menu and it was just eh..  Maybe bc I'm used to American brunch places that are huge and delicious (referring to NYC and LA only) but yeah.. Will not go back..
Its gotta be one of the nicest zi char in bukit timah. Cheap, fast and yummy. Must-try their signature toufu with minced pork and salted egg prawns

Our go-to butchery in Singapore, and they recently moved just across the street! the new butchery is HUGE- it has a small outdoor playground for bored kids to play outside, while the parents shop their meat goodness for the week in a two-storey building with the elevator.  Not sure if we liked the layout though- if the butchery had more of a "cozy" and "welcoming" feeling, this new place seems more like a meat factory in an industrial setting and can get a bit confusing trying to find the entrance/exit. I usually get my cut of korean samgyupsal here (pork bbq), and steak to eat for dinner. We seem to get better cuts if we come earlier, as we had slices of the most tender steak one week, then a bit chewy and forgettable meat, the next. so come early! i deducted one star for having very little selection of organic meat available for my baby.

One of our favourite places to go for a meal during the weekend. Can be hot outside and may take up to 20 minutes if you want a table inside. Staff are very friendly and the food excellent! The aged beef burger and the meatloaf are must try dishes.

New store layout is bad. As I'm writing there is a guy is asking the restaurant waitress if the store is closed. And now even another guy roaming the ground floor with a confused face. Haha Btw the "meatloaf" at the restaurant is a over sized spam that tastes like hotdog. Sheesh

When i get the opportunity to go to Huber's i feel like a little kids on Christmas morning!  Upon entering the doors you can hear the angels singing that sweet hyme of butcher greatness!!!i know that it is expensive, but this is Singapore and they have never steered us wrong.  all of the guys that have ever helped us out have been super knowledgeable and provide any advice if you ask.  i am a big fan of being able to have them cut the steak to the right size and package however you want them to.  i also love the little cafe the menu is very german but tasty.  everything that we have ever had has been great, and how can you beat wonder heve beer on tap al fresco?!

Don't eat a misteak!Now I know that the above quote rightly belongs to Philly's own Pat's King of Steaks, but I hope they'll allow me to use it to aptly describe Huber's!Although I love cows and I think they are cute and gentle, I will admit they are absolutely delicious. (But if I had to kill my own meat to survive, I'd probably turn pescatarian. :P) It makes me happy to know that there is a quality butcher here in Singapore that I can rely on when I feel like being fancy by making my own steak.The store is in a great location, as it's the first thing you see if you exit Holland Road onto Dempsey Road. As fellow reviewer Mark D. said, it's quite pristine! The store is a well lit, organized meat heaven. When you walk in, you are greeted with a ton of beef, chicken, and pork to choose from- steaks, sausages, burger patties, you name it. I also like how the employees who work the counters are always attentive and willing to help. I've bought their Australian steaks twice and enjoyed them both times. Outside of the meat, the rest of the store caters to Western tastes. They have a small section for veggies/herbs, a decent selection of cheese, along with bottled beers and other condiments. The bistro is outside, so al fresco dining is your only option. My husband and I ordered their burger with gruyere and caramelized onions. To be honest, we thought it was just okay. We actually think Go-Go Bambini (also in Dempsey) has the better burger. If you feel you've eaten some "misteaks" in Singapore, then stop by here; you won't be disappointed! :)

Amazing market and Bavarian themed al fresco dining with meat heavy, but affordable menu. Paulaner 0.5L drafts are $12 and served in a proper glass. The only drawback in the whole experience is that the bistro service takes an eternity. The staff, although pleasant, can't be bothered to come to a table more than once. So make sure you get everything ordered at the first contact because you are on your own after that. The dedicated playground next door makes for a nice family experience. Butcher closes promptly @ 19:00.

UPDATE:After being a customer of this place for quite some time, I regrettably have to amend my positive review below.I cannot recommend for anyone to eat at their Bistro, and if you do, know that it's at your own risk!Today I went there for lunch and was served RAW sausages - and I mean red and bleeding in the middle.  Serving raw meat to a visibly (8 months) pregnant woman, and then not even offering to take it off the bill, is not a place that I can recommend to anyone.I am extremely disappointed - I have emailed them and gotten no response, and the waitstaff did not seem to get how dangerous the situation was either.It's a real shame but it seems this place has gone steadily downhill, at least when it comes to their Bistro.--This is by far the best place to buy meat in Singapore!The shop recently moved to a bigger, two-storey location on the hill on Dempsey Road, with two separate car parks, and it couldn't be better!  Everything is more spread out and easier to find, and I believe they've added more variety as well - the shop also looks a lot nicer.The Butchery:The meat here has never been a disappointment.  We have gotten everything from mince, cold cuts, parma ham, chicken, sausages, burgers, kebabs, and they have all been absolutely lovely.  The price is of course on the higher side, but you know whether the meat is coming from and you pay for a very high level of quality!  Even the vegetables and herbs are of a great quality, but I do think they're ridiculously overpriced.  I would definitely recommend to buy meat here but advise to buy veggies somewhere else!The Bistro:This has gotten a huge improvement as well!  It is on the ground floor, in a bit of an alcove, with minimal indoor and mostly outdoor seating.  The cafe is all in the shade, and in a very pleasant location - there is also a convenient playground next to it, so its great for kids.  I see many families having lunch hereThe food is awesome!  I highly recommend the currywurst, which comes with a lovely sauce and very tasty little chips!  There is also a nice selection of beer.  A perfect lunch spot!Overall, I love this place.  It was a great discovery, the quality of the food is top-notch, and you know that despite the price, it will be worth it in taste and superior to anywhere else!

This is a review of a shopping trip to Huber's Butchery.I had been wanting to visit Huber's to purchase some meat for home cooking.  I had wandered in once before with some colleagues and just looked around.  I knew I would be back.The place is spotless.  They have a very wide selection of meats and can cut many things to order.tinyurl.com/cfrv5odtinyurl.com/bnrzbhktinyurl.com/d9yxhuptinyurl.com/cul7rytAll of the meats look of the highest quality.   The only real drawback is that it certainly isn't cheap.  It is the most expensive meat I've ever purchased.The staff is beyond friendly and helpful.  They were simply amazing.  They answered all of my questions.  They were friendly throughout the process.Beyond meat, the shop does sell other things to round out a meal.  They have a small selection of vegetables and fruits.  They have some sauces and condiments.  They have breads and buns.  They have a nice selection of beers.Along with some odds and ends, I purchased:1.5 kg sirloin for roasting ($90)tinyurl.com/btwc326 lb pork shoulder for making pulled pork ($67.65)tinyurl.com/cpe5bsw2 kg whole chicken for roasting ($24)tinyurl.com/cnc2l4lAll of the meats were expertly packed and wrapped.Receipt: $237.65tinyurl.com/c86voa4When prepared at home, all of the meats were as good as they looked.   Huber's is a very professionally operated butchery with a great selection of meats.  For me, it is too expensive for everyday cooking.  But for splurging here and there, it is a great luxury to have available.   As an additional note, they do offer delivery.

I heard a great hype about this place from my uncle and decided to give it a try. Yes! It was good, high quality steak matched with high quality ingredients but that was basically it. No umph, no kick! Nothing remarkable. Dont get me wrong I enjoyed the food but it was not my favourite steakhouse . However, I can't say the same with service. At first they greeted us with open arms but when they came to realise that we were to stay abit longer, they grew impatient and gave us a sour face. Other than 3 stars from me~

Stopped by here to grab our protein for the week. Whole chicken, bacon, bacon wrapped dates, sliced ham, ground beef. We're now stocked. The prices were reasonable, but on definitely on the higher end of our budget - have I mentioned how cheap I am? We sat down for a bite before starting our shopping. We didn't come soon enough to get the chicken meal. Pretty darn Paleo, minus the fries which could be easily substituted. Instead, we opted for the short rib and my oh my, was it delicious. I'd still go for the chicken next time we're there (if they have it), but if you're down for a more indulgent meal, I'd say give it a shot. We had two ciders to go with our meal. I ordered a pear cider and hubby got the lime cider. There was beverage envy, but I was pretty stingy and didn't share too much because it was so good. We'll be back. This place's meats make me seem like an amazing cook. Bacon wrapped dates with a roasted, seasoned chicken and a side of roasted cauliflower? I could win any Paleo man's heart with this meal - luckily, I already have the hubby's. :)
we drove here for just the iberico ham, swiss raw bacon & cold cuts. good selection, will be back again.butbreakfast at the bistro was unimpressive, and they don't serve tap water.

I think it should be listed as two things: butchery and bistro separately. The bistro is nice, it's a mix of European cousin, predominantly German, tastes good, the price is okay. Nothing special.The butchery is a very pretentious fancy place for people who are okay with buying ungodly expensive meat. Yeah, yeah, the butcher can cut it any way you like but for that price he really should sing and dance for you as well. The quality of meat is not better than if you just go to a regular wet market (well, hello, it's Singapore, the quality is superb anywhere) but the variety is better. So if you wanna play a really rich Julia Child and go handpick some meat for your beef bourguignon and chat with a butcher then go ahead.

The design of the new shop at 22 Dempsey Road could not be worse. There is an steady stream of customers trying to get into the store on the ground floor (where the parking lot is) but not being allowed to do so because it is an "exit." You are forced to take an unnecessarily long and indirect walk up to the second floor to enter and then take an elevator to go down one floor to get the the meat section.Customer convenience was not a consideration when they designed how to get into the store or to get around once you do get in. Absolutely crazy.

Butcheries are my favourite stores to visit, next to supermarkets. Fresh, great cuts of meat with all sorts of herbs, potatoes, tomatoes, onions to cook them with, this place is like a candy store to steaklovers - wait - like a butchery to a steaklover. Okay analogy lost, but you get my point. Feast your eyes, or have a US ribeye to devour at the al fresco bistro. Be warned though that the grill masters are rather inconsistent, sometimes a medium steak turns out exactly pink in the middle like it should be, sometimes it's brown and well done in some parts, and medium only in 20% of it. No one experience has been the same for me, but it's good enough for $28-ish, it scratches the itch without breaking the bank.They serve their steak the way purists like them, no sauce, some salt and with good shoestring fries and some greens. I've never paid much attention to anything else on the menu. I do fancy the french onion soup now and then, but it doesn't quite compare to the thick intense concoction (blanketed by gruyere cheese) that I've had in better French restaurants. Still, a bistro's a bistro, adjust expectations and you'll be a happy diner here.Note that bistro hours differ from the butchery's. Bistro's operating hours as follows:Monday: Closed Tuesday to Friday: 11.00 a.m. to 7.00 p.m.  Saturday, Sunday & public holiday: 9.30 a.m. to 7.00 p.m. Both butchery and bistro are closed on Christmas Day, New Year's Day and Lunar New Year.
If you like good meat, and if you like to cook good meat, this place is heaven. Beautiful cuts of meat all round. You can even find home cured bacon. Meat heaven. Vegetarians stay away.

Worst customer service ever.  Been trying to reach the store for days but in vain.  No one picks up the phone and no replies to email inquiries either.  If you call during non-business hours then you get a recorded message, if you call during business hours then the phone just keeps ringing until it eventually gets disconnected.

Still a great offering of fine meats, but the new location is way too big and impersonal, and the bistro isn't open in the morning when the main shop opens. Such a shame, I hate to say it but I hope that they end up having to downsize and end up going back to their deli-style roots.

One of the best lasagne I've ever had in my life, rich and packed with meat which is what most lasagne lack. I was after a beef lasagne but Huber's only had a chicken option on that day and I thought why not give it a shot. It is definitely a lighter and healthier alternative to beef, the chicken used is shredded and not minced which gives a superb texture especially with the pasta sheets and creamy cheese. I 've tried to request for the chicken lasagne recently but with no luck. Hopefully it will be available the next time I drop by. The name of the place is a dead give away but if you're looking for prime cuts of meat and their related seasoning, this is the place to go to!! From angus to wagyu, you name it, Huber's got it!

rest_name: Ban Mian Stall Jun Hang Food Court
address: Singapore Institute of Management HQ, 461 Clementi Road Block A, Level 3 Singapore 599491 Singapore
comment: This is one of my fave stalls in this Food Court - their Ban Mian options are total yummyness and every thing's so fresh here! They make their own noodles - dumplings, and I love that I can see them making all the food stuff and it's totally fresh.Apart from Ban Mian - they have dumplings, fried and non-fried (steamed) and both options are REALLY yummy. Love the fried options but since it's deep fried - I don't eat it all the time - if I could I'll have it every freakin' day!!!What I Love: Their Ban Mian is great! I've been having their Fish Ban Mian and their Dumpling Soup for a couple of years now. Their Fried Dumplings are a MUST try! Prefer them to the steamed dumplings. The flavor is great - you can taste the pork and veggies and it all just blends and really works in your mouth. They have a really comprehensive noodle options - so its great to try a different dish everyday.What I Don't Love: Lines can get long here - so watch out for those! But they are long for a reason!! ;)

rest_name: Ban Mian Stall Jun Hang Food Court
address: Singapore Institute of Management HQ, 461 Clementi Road Block A, Level 3 Singapore 599491 Singapore
comment: This has to be my favorite stall at the food court. It has great ban mian to begin with, and great broth to go along. A satisfying and simple local dish that can sustain you through the afternoon. The portions are not particularly big, but they are definitely sufficient. Although I am not a fan of tom yum, I do have friends who dig the tom yum soup base noodles over the regular ones. Another food item that I like on the menu is the dumplings. Be it the guo tie or the normal water boiled dumplings, they all taste good! Good ratio of chives and meat, and the skin not too thick as well. Great great ban mian, I must repeat.

Unexpected trip to the mall and i was looking around when something familiar caught my eye- Jajiangmyeon and jjampong. Was never a fan of jjampong but this creamy version available here changed my mind. It reminded me of creamy tom yum soup. There were different sorts of seafood in this half and i think it was a pretty generous portion. Jajiangmyeon wasn't too bad and it was a good combo as always.

Visited Tekka Center in Little India, Singapore.  Very crowded on a Sunday.  Picked this place randomly among all the stalls.  Had the chicken tikka masala was more oily and less thick sauce than I'm used to but good flavor and big portion for the price.  Naan was good but wished I had bought 2 bc needed more to compliment all the chicken.  So overall I recommend it.  There's open seating there if u want but u may need to share your table.  We got it to go and they wrap in a plastic baggie so I had to use our hotel plates to eat.  Would like to go back and try some other places as well next time.  Guess they would consider this a hawker area which basically means a food court.  Also this center is not for u if u are OCD about cleanliness.

Residents of Holland Village must be very lucky to have this restaurant in their neighbourhood. This restaurant is inside a clean and hygienic kopitiam with Hainanese-style tables and chairs, a sight you will usually not associate with any other common kopitiams in Singapore. Besides, customers can enjoy TV while eating. The kopitiam has a giant LCD TV that delivers digital DVB-T free-to-air programmes to customers, so the picture quality is very high, even for standard definition channels. More importantly, I did not expect the taste of the food here to be great, as it was my first time here a few days ago. This place specializes in local zi char and I like its sambal stingray and sambal kangkong. The sambal stingray is well-cooked. Sambal sauce is spread out evenly onto the giant piece of stingray, and it is great pleasure to chew its gristles after eating its flesh. The sambal kangkong, a famous dish in Singapore and perhaps Malaysia as well, is also well-cooked here. Unlike many places in Singapore where the flavour isn't very "original", the intensity of spiciness here is just right. Apparantly the restaurant isn't "stingy" with ingredients. The medium fried beef hor fun here has a few giant pieces of beef served together with hor fun, and they taste good. Food is rather affordable here. A plate of stingray, a plate of medium fried beef hor fun and a plate of small sambal kangkong cost S$24.00 altogether.

Beware of Cheating !!!!!After I chose the highest price $ 68 and selected the crab ! The chef changed to smaller crab yesterday !!!Shall not eat here anymore !! GO bacK to  PUNGGOL for Uncle LEONG bee hoon crab .. WORTH it !!

The best Korean restaurant we've tried in Singapore so far. Flavors were authentic and portions were reasonable. The kimbap was sold out by the time we got there (after 7:30pm). Apparently they sell out early on Saturdays. Many customers were asking about the kimbap. We will have to go back just to try it. There is a bing soo place just outside that is excellent, so save some room for dessert. It's a little out of the way for people who don't drive, but well worth the trip.

Beef bulgogi ($12.90 at lunch) - 3.75 starsThe portion was huge and I thought it was one of the best I've had in Singapore so far - the meat wasn't as fatty as at Three Meals - but it was way too salty. After dipping it in the soup to get rid of the saltiness the texture changed. I'll see if I can ask for it with less salt the next time and review it again then. The price includes rice, whereas as Three Meals the rice is $2 extra. Not much rice though - they don't give a full bowl.I definitely want to come back and try the other dishes given the relatively inexpensive prices and large portions and authentic taste. The kimchi was excellent even though I'm not a kimchi person, and I liked the seaweed side dish.

$65 sgd for a massive Korean meal. There was a queue for a reason - Excellent bulgogi, delicious kimchi jeon and kimchi fried rice. The sundubu-jigae was also served steaming hot and tasted sublime. They'll hustle you in and out, but at these prices and portion size, you won't mind.

Ming Jia is another family korean restaurant and one of my regular hunts for affordable korean food. Situated in Bukit Timah Plaza, the restaurant itself is nothing fancy, with just the bare minimum furnishings and paper signs as their menus.The food on the other hand, is truly an authentic korean fare. One of my favourite dishes is the beef bulgogi rice set. Unlike usual korean food stores that serve this on a hot plate, Ming Jia offers it as a stew in a bowl that is usually used to serve kimchi stew. The pieces of beef are left simmering in the stew, adding flavour to the thick broth. The beef is tender and a tad salty, but this is cancelled out once you eat it with the rice. Another dish is the kimchi pancake. Packed full of vegetables and chilli, the pancake is crisp on the outer ends and soft and chewy towards to centre. A special soy sauce is served together. The unique taste, somewhat like a cross between miso and soy sauce, brings out the kimchi flavour in the pancake. Don't underestimate the portion size because it is extremely filling. The good thing is you can request for a take-away box if you can't finish the dish.

Ming Jia serves simple, good Korean food. The beef dishes are consistently good, and their veggies dishes are fresh and non-greasy. Their sets are value-for-money as well. What I like best is the the fuss-free atmosphere at this unpretentious cafe. Home-style eating out at its best.

Nothing quite rocks my boat like Korean homestyle cooking. We joined our Korean friends who swear by this place as being their go-to place for homestyle comfort food. They tell me 3 Meals A Day is a Korean reality comedy cooking show but don't think it has anything to do with it. The food here is no joke.We arrived right when they pulled up their window blinds and flipped the OPEN sign. We did have a reservation for a Saturday but by the time 6:15 rolled around, every seat was already taken. Really enjoyed the kimchi as part of the banchan set. No harsh fermented taste like how kimchi can taste at other places. I think this is the first time I only went one round on the banchans because there was simply too much food.The Nakji Bokkem (stir-fried spicy octopus) came out shortly after ordering. Nakji Bokkeum is one of my favorite dish in Korean cuisine. It creates a perfect harmony out of the two things I love most - seafood and spiciness. After taking the obligatory Yelp pics from every angle, we dug in and absolutely enjoyed this spicy dish. I don't know what it is about Korean chili sauce that makes the food taste so good. It's the kind of fiery spice with a hint of sweetness. Vegetables were not overcooked and held their crispness and the octopus was nice and tender. It wasn't until we dug in deeper that we realize there was mound of noodles underneath. Yum!The Jap Chae (Korean glass noodles) was very nice. The foundation of the dish - soy sauce, garlic, and sesame oil - came through nicely. I hate dry Jap Chae because the noodles continue to absorb moisture even after cooking, but the Jap Chae here was warm and moist, and went well with the other dishes we ordered.Finally, the large order of Bossam (boiled pork) arrived and that's when I got really excited. I realized boiled pork doesn't sound very appetizing but I've been told that although it sounds like a simple dish to make, it requires some skill to make right. The dish here was flavorful and tender. One can tell that they took their time in brining the pork and removing any bad smell/taste that can accompany bossam made in a rush. The thinly sliced pork was served with both raw and parboiled veggie leaves for wrapping along with the sides of ssamjang, sliced green chilies, raw garlic and kimchi. You won't find anything to barbecue here so your clothes will be safe and sound. The service was good but could use a little more proactive attention. Will have to come back to try their fried chicken, jjigaes, and Korean sashimi. Jal meogeosseumnida!

Update 18 June 2017Beef bulgogi ($13 + $2 rice ++) - 3 starsI was craving this so I ordered it again despite the mediocre rating I gave it below. Well, I was right. The meat is too fatty.Spicy seafood and mushroom noodle soup ($13++) - 1.5 starsThis was sort of like a Korean ban mian. The soup tasted great but after a while the noodles absorbed the soup and the starch from the noodles made the soup unpleasantly thick. Not many ingredients. I'd much rather get the sundubu the next time.Service - 5 starsThey took the initiative to move us from the bar to a table once a table opened up and were generous with the banchan refills!$33 for the two dishes.Update 9 April 2017Fishcake soup ($8) - 3 starsThe soup was alright. The fishcake inside is like the one in the banchan though with 2 additional varieties. Sort of like a Korean yong tau foo/ngoh hiang-type fishcake. We ordered this and the bulgogi since we weren't that hungry. These two dishes and the banchan were enough for us.Original reviewBanchan - 2 starsVariety is decent but each dish isn't spectacular.Beef stew - 2.5 starsToo sweet!Beef bulgogi ($13) - 3 starsFlavor was okay. We shared between the 3 of us and the size was about right, though. Stir it quickly so the bottom doesn't burn.Seafood pancake ($16) - 2.75 starsKind of thick and bland without the sauce.Fishcake soup/stew ($28) - 3 starsThe fishcake was strung on the skewers. Tasted like Japanese fishcake (oden) or the fishcake you get as banchan.Persimmon punch - 0 starsThe cinnamon was way too strong even after diluting it with water! I couldn't take more than a sip.On the plus side overall it seems like they use less MSG than Kim's and Togi but more than Woorinara (I still downed a lot of water during dinner). But the dishes just weren't impressive to me. My friends love this place and much prefer it to Kim's and Woorinara. I'm still unimpressed by all the Korean places I've been to in Singapore and miss the ones in LA/Southern California.

Decently good Korean food with some hits and misses.The name of the place is based on a popular Korean reality cooking show (Samsi Sekki) of the same name. The restaurant was rather crowded on a weekend evening, which raised my expectations somewhat. The banchan (side dishes) were pretty good and I appreciated the variety. I ordered the dolsot bibimbap (mixed rice in a stone pot), fried chicken (with spicy sauce) and haemul pajeon (seafood pancake). Although rather tasty, I felt the stone pot wasn't heated thoroughly. The rice touching the bowl wasn't crisp at all. I was also left looking around for the raw egg...The fried chicken was much better, crisp batter and tender on the inside, coated with a rather spicy sauce. The seafood pancake was run of the mill, but there was nothing much else to complain about.The usual Korean fare is served here, and I feel it borders on the 3.5 star mark, but with the wallet friendly prices I think I might round it up to a 4. I'm not sure why Korean food is also rather expensive in Singapore. Thumbs up to lower prices.

Not bad for a decent dinner.I am feeling quite full and my girl wanted to try Korean food. We chanced upon this place and thought "Why not give it a go!"The Jajamyun is one of the dishes we ordered and seriously, it was one of the most flavourful dishes. The fish cake soup is a little high on the MSG though. But if you are feeling cold and wanted something soupy, good to swing by here

This is a small restaurant, so there's always a queue during meal times. The food is decent, and authentic. They are quite short staffed, got to wait for service when the restaurant is full. We ordered the daejang jigae, bbq pork, dry cold noodle and a bottle of soju, all very delicious and reminded me of the Korean food I had back in the US. Would definitely come back again.
Good Korean food.Moderately expensive though. For example, Yukgaejang (Spicy Beef Stew, comes with bowl of rice) is $18++ (or $21.06 nett).

After years of being spoilt by the Korean food in SoCal, we were hoping to find a half decent place in SIngapore. We went in with high expectations as several pictures/reviews looked good. We ordered 4 dishes - Japchae, Bulgogi, Kimchijeon, and a cabbage and beef shank stew.Japchae - I really like Japchae and have a low bar for it but the balance was totally off on this one. It was too sweet and WET (a la fried hokkien prawn noodles). Insufficient umami and balance (no pepper taste at all), and no meat in it either.Bulgogi - This was pretty bad as well. It came out with an unappetizing grey color and my first thoughts were "no sesame seeds and scallions?". I've never eaten bulgogi without sesame seeds which made me doubt the quality/authenticity of this place. It tasted as bad as it looked. The marinade was watered down and very simple, and frankly I have made better at home. Completely missed the intense sweet/salty flavor characteristic of this dish. The beef cut was super lean and tough as well and made for a terrible dish. Kimchijeon - This was passable though not great in any sense. The pajeon mix was too sticky and felt slightly undercooked. The dip was also wrong, tasted like ponzu when it should be predominantly salty and spicy. Also no green onions or sesame seeds in it again? What's with the skimping on basics?Cabbage and beef shank soup - Never had this before. Soup flavor was not bad but there was almost no meat in it, by that I mean If you pieced all the meat in the bowl together you would get about 2 fifty cent coins worth of volume. I'm ok if you don't put meat in your jjigaes but if you are going to advertise a soup with "beef shank" in the name you had better put a fair amount in. For $20 I would never order this again.Banchan - We had 6 banchan, a macaroni salad, egg omelette (somewhat like tamagoyaki), beansprouts, baby anchovies, fish cake and kimchi. None of them were really anything to shout about. In particular, Korean fishcake already has a heavy flour component compared to the local stuff, but this one tasked like 90% flour and felt like we were eating mock meat. Urgh.All in all, the food was not good for the price and I probably wouldn't come back. The fact that this place gets 4 stars on Yelp is testament to the sorry state of Korean food in Singapore.

they seriously have the most yummy kimchi tuna jjigae in Singapore! a must try if you haven't. i also love their banchans and the variety it offers. when i was there, it was the Korean fish cake, caramelized anchovies, egg rolls, ketchup hotdogs slices, kimchi and bean sprouts. i also ordered the regular gimbap and the sesame oil coated seaweed wrap really made a difference in taste! busy busy place even at 6pm. come early to avoid waiting in line.

Food was good but service is atrocious. Didn't use to be as bad before. Not only did they forget our order, they couldn't even remember what we ordered and had to ask us thrice to confirm. The waiter also told us rather curtly that side dishes are free and we should not ask for a refill when they're busy since it is a free dish. We ended up waiting 30 mins for my mom's kalguksu to come and that was after I alr finished my tofu stew. None of the crew apologized nor did the boss who was the one who took the order & forgot about it. Rather disappointed and I do not recommend this to anyone who's paying service charge. Food is decent but the service and attitude of the staff makes this restaurant not worth coming.

user_location: Farrelly Pond District, San Leandro, CA
comment: A fusion type dish with Japanese and Chinese influences .. but it works! The aromatic prawn broth was the star of this dish, having been boiled for 8 hours, and the prawn dumplings were delicious as well. Prawn lovers out there - this is a dish you will definitely enjoy! There was a line outside, but service was quick and efficient, with payment at the counter when you exit.

The waiter got our order wrong and he took away the erroneous order and made us wait ages for the right order. I feel that the service recovery was abysmal.The wrong order was simply the wrong topping, and they should have just added on the right topping and given the wrong topping to us for free, instead of inconveniencing us at lunchtime where most people have to rush back to the office, as a gesture of goodwill.The ramen itself was okay, though I would have preferred a thicker broth. I am not sure I would return as I feel the service left a bad taste in my mouth.

I tried the panama coffee and their bread and butter pudding. I have visited this store several times and always like their coffee. I have to say the Kenya is better for me than the Panama. But it is good nevertheless.  The service is great but can be a little on the slow side at busy days as today. But well, we can't rush perfection, can we?

Just what I needed today. Close, open, coffee, WiFi and pastries. Excited for them as today is opening day! I'm looking forward to trying and reviewing their upcoming menu for food, but I can attest to the coffee: smooth, rich and authentic. I look forward to future visits! Thanks Trevor for the wonderful neighborhood addition!

This place is one of our favorite go-to for lunch/dinner in CBD. Sensibly priced and consistently tasty. I appreciate places with simple and easy to understand menu, like this one!By now I think i've pretty much tried all of the dishes here.. here are some of my recommended dishes:- Beef Pho- Signature pork (Comes with rice or vermicelli but i prefer vermicelli)- Fried duck leg (MY FAVORITE! also comes with rice and vermicelli)If you are feeling hungry, go for the set lunch or dinner.Also they have Sriracha sauce here. The real deal that's made in California.
Pretty authentic pho. Starters are too fusion for my taste. Good value lunch sets. Seems there's always a crowd here which is a good sign for first timers. Staff are also friendly

address: 5 Ridgewood Close #G6 Ridgewood Condo Singapore 276696 Singapore
comment: Really good burgers and salads.  The staff are all friendly, and are really flexible with the menu, so if you are wanting something not on the menu, just ask and they will work with you.  This resulted in a delicious pork rib rack.

address: 5 Ridgewood Close #G6 Ridgewood Condo Singapore 276696 Singapore
comment: Worst experience I had in a week.Menu says the half chicken is $13, the wall says it's $16 for dine-in ($13 for take away)I did not notice it and the staff did not mention as well. When the bill came and the discrepancy is raised, the staff were not even decent about it and insist we just have to pay the $16. The whole process was plain rude and down right offensive. I would have been ok to pay the extra if they just had to be nice and apologise. Absolutely horror, do not visit this joint. Chicken is totally overrated as well.

address: 5 Ridgewood Close #G6 Ridgewood Condo Singapore 276696 Singapore
comment: This restaurant is not so good. I ordered a burger and fries for $13 and the food tastes worse than Big Mac menu from McDonalds. The burger was really simply made and small. The fries tastes like the really cheap ones which you can buy in supermarkets everywhere. Overall, the price/value ratio is very bad from my POI. The service was nice though.

Papaya salad - 3 starsHas to be the spiciest I've had in Singapore - there were way too many chili padi seeds. I couldn't finish it! Definitely asking for less spice the next time.Red ruby ($5) - 4 starsYummy large flour covered red ruby!
Great price, and their tom Kha gai (coconut soup) is incredible! Also go for the iced Thai tea, so refreshing on a hot day!

Not silver service but just great tasty food by the road. Cheap and cheerful and very authentic Thai flavours. I can see we will be eating and ordering take away a lot from here. Delicious. Our new local

So this place is basically a second kitchen for every person who lives at the College Green hostels one block away. Their student menu used to be $5, but now it ranges from $5-$7 depending if you want pork, beef, or seafood. Student Menu is reasonably priced and portioned for a student budget (no ID required, just tell them you're a student. Of course if you look..ahem..more mature... you may want to bust out your student ID). I always clean off my plate of seafood or beef pad thai. Its delicious, just savory enough, and always flavorful. Their $3 sesame chicken is also great and order it for your group of three. I've had their pad see ew, but their pad thai is still my favorite. Their mango sticky rice is also good but has this bitter taste sometimes that I can't decide if I like it or not. Tip for those at CG, call ahead and the food will be ready by the time you walk there. The place tends to get busy around 6 when the local middle schools get out. Dining is outside and they have fans out to cool you off. I've heard there is indoor seating but never seen it.
One if the best Thai restaurants around this part of town, cheap prices for students. Love their basil chicken, green curry, papaya and green mango salad and mango sticky rice.

Mediocre food (at least the chicken larb I had today), and they charge higher prices than are written on the menu. When I complained, the woman at the cash register said "it's not my fault; the owner makes me do it!"

We ordered delivery during the Covid 19 Circuit Breaker in Singapore. It was as our first time. We had a sampler of starters, the massaman curry, with vegetables, a green curry with chicken. Both curry's excellent in flavor. Favorite dish was the honey pork ribs. Papaya salad was fresh and spicy. Fried rice and pad Thai all good. One of our favorite home deliveries during CB. We do want to go and have dinner here when they open up again as the location is so beautiful. You are in the countryside.

Spotted this Royal Thai Boat Noodles & Bar everytime I pass by the roads and decided to give it a try. There are still a lot of units left vacant in the King Albert Park thus locating Royal Thai should be an easy task, moreover they are just along the main roads.We had the outdoor seats and we had a beautiful sight of the blue hours.Through their friendly servers, we learnt that this is another branch apart from the main one in Fairways Drive. The menu is extensive, they have a lot of dishes to choose and diners like us are just simply spoilt of choices.With the naturally sweet Thai Mango, this drink is a perfect cooler to beat the heat on the hot day. Love its taste, sweet and yummy with no additional coloring added.Mango Ice Blended - $5.50Starting with Appetizers, we had the usual Mango Salad. It gave us a riots of texture together with the sour and hot burning sensation from the chilli. Not to mentioned that it is fragrant with chopped peanuts as well as dried shrimps.Mango Salad - $7Boat Noodle is also one of my preferred dishes from Thai Cuisine, however not many places served them. We had the beef version and noodle was fragrant, topped with beansprouts, pork lard, spring onions for garnishing. The soup in the bowl tasted as good as one I had in Thailand. We ordered the small portion to have a try and it was satisfying.Boat Noodle Beef (Small) - $3.90Pineapple fried rice was fragrant topped with floss and fried with prawns, assorted vegetables and cashew nuts. The dish was appetizing and addictive. I would consider this as one of the better Thai Pineapple Fried Rice I had here locally.Pineapple Fried Rice (Prawns) - $9.50The grilled pork with their house sauce was not too bad. It was tender and tasty.Grilled Pork with Garlic with Royal Thai Sauce - $12.50Thinking of completing our meal with sweet thoughts, we ordered a bowl of Red Ruby Dessert for sharing. Love the crunchy chestnut wrapped in the soft translucent red jelly.Red Ruby - $4.50Meal as an overall was satisfying. Service rendered was friendly and prompt. It will be good to be back here again for some Thai Food.

address: 3155 Commonwealth Ave W #B1-34/35 Clementi Mall Singapore 129588 Singapore
comment: We have been hunting for a good, reasonably-priced Japanese ramen restaurant and I was really pleased with this place in Clementi Mall.  The menu is quite large and they have many different Japanese dishes and Japanese-inspired meals.  Definitely worth the visit for anyone missing Japanese food.

address: 3155 Commonwealth Ave W #B1-34/35 Clementi Mall Singapore 129588 Singapore
comment: I have not seen this brand of ramen before so asked my friend to try it with me. The bright lighting and colorful entrance were inviting. Service was attentive. The lunch deal was not bad and I like the overall taste. The noodles were cooked too softly though so did not seem to resemble ramen. Not the best in ramen but does the job if you need to satisfy a craving.

address: 805 Bukit Timah Rd #01-04, Sixth Avenue Centre Singapore 279883 Singapore
comment: The food here is good, but the menu/ordering system is messed up.We were given an order sheet to fill out where the items had a different order from the menu, there were items not found on the menu and the spelling for some items was different (eg Journey to the East on the menu vs Journey to the Yeast on the order sheet). The menu and order sheet were also outdated - both said the Black Truffle Mac and Cheese came with 2 sides, but the server said they didn't and both were outdated. This all confused us and made it hard to place our order. However once we had gotten this out of the way the experience here was quite positive.The Black Truffle Mac and Cheese was creamy, mushroomy and cheesy. It also had a generous portion of tasty bacon and more truffle than I'd expected. Note that this wasn't the usual cloying and one-dimensional truffle oil but the more subtle touch of shaved truffle.The Journey to the (Y)east ribs had a nice salty-sweet flavour with an umami kick. Marmite, Guinness and molasses are a good combination indeed. The meat fell off the bone and I was almost unable to transfer the ribs to another plate since they were in danger of falling off. We had the biscuit and salad with it. The biscuit was a little buttery, but Texas chicken has a better butter flavour. It was crispy and had a nice rich crumb though. The salad had slices from a very big tomato in it but it was otherwise normal.The buffalo wings were not buffalo wings. This is not an uncommon occurence in Singapore so I can't say I was too disappointed, but still it would be nice to have some menu fidelity. These wings were sweet and had a light spicy and sour edge to them. They could've been crispier too. They were served with dipping sauce which tasted slightly more like real thing but really was just a thicker version of Singapore style chili sauce. So yes you can imagine how far away from buffalo wings these were if Singapore style chili sauce was more like buffalo wing sauce than whatever these were tossed with.The Cubano sandwich tasted okay, though the bread was a bit stale and there wasn't enough pulled pork inside. The fries were crispy fluffy and the coleslaw fresh and creamy (also it was slightly sweet and served garnished with raisins - which not everyone likes).

address: 805 Bukit Timah Rd #01-04, Sixth Avenue Centre Singapore 279883 Singapore
comment: Meat n' Chill took over the space where Ribbery n Wine used to be.  Assuming the mantle of meat and vino must not have been easy, but  MNC soldiers on...I strolled in in the middle of day, literally and ordered what the wait staff felt was the house special, the one dish that would enapsulate what MNC was all about...I received reassurances that that the coffee-Kahlua ribs would not disappoint.Reassuringly, the ribs took about 20 minutes to arrive... a harbinger of good things, surely!!The ribs were hot and veritably well-seasoned and well-flavored.  They had the texture and and overall mouthfeel of ribs that had received no less than love "French-style", microwaved to perfection.  I, personally, have nothing against microwaved food, but when your selling point is slow-cooked barbecue ribs, short wave or even microwave better not be anywhere near these pork ribs.They were good and sweet and smothered in all kinds of barbecue sauce, but they did not alas, have the kiss of long hours being smoked off the bone.  This was more of a case of "looks and feels like barbecue" and less of effort in bringing you the real article.  Overall, if you really feel like getting skin-close to the authentic Southern barbecue, spend a little bit more time and and get closer to Smokey's where you'll likely get as close to a Southern style barbecue as you are likely to get in tropical Singapore.Service overall was eager and prompt.Just not really barbecue...

address: 805 Bukit Timah Rd #01-04, Sixth Avenue Centre Singapore 279883 Singapore
comment: The ambience was really chill and more importantly, cozy. The menu was well organized haha and it had a wide array of varieties. The staff were really friendly and helpful and the food was the cherry on the cake. It was savoury and tasty in every way necessary! Would especially recommend the chilli cheese fries and the chicken mains! Will definitely be back for more and it is a great place with great food for pretty much every occasion possible!

address: 805 Bukit Timah Rd #01-04, Sixth Avenue Centre Singapore 279883 Singapore
comment: My husband was craving good ol' American style BBQ ribs.  He found this place and fell in love.  The pork ribs were delicious and fall off the bone yummy....sizable portion.  The meal came with 2 sides.  Order the sweet pickled apples & onions, AMAZING.....more apples than onions.  The cold slaw and mashed potatoes were lovely too.....just not enough to satisfy the taste buds.  All in all the meal was yummy and not overly priced.  I would definitely go again.

address: 805 Bukit Timah Rd #01-04, Sixth Avenue Centre Singapore 279883 Singapore
comment: Great place with great ambience! Visited them on a thurs night. I was really puzzled why the place was quite empty. You guys are definitely missing out! The first thing that caught my eye was the cute and very nicely designed menu. Even the font of the menu is nice! :D Both the menu and the walls of the restaurant were decorated with extremely cute graffiti. I cant help but explore the place. Did I not mention that they also provide board games on the 2nd floor? Would definitely consider holding some small scale events here!Food wise, their ribs is a must try! Had their Honey Mustard Ribs as well as the Tuscan Ribs. Both were very flavourful and the meat was tender and nice. They are also not stingy with the portion. So I highly recommend this place. Very value for money! $20+++ for ribs and 2 sides!

address: 805 Bukit Timah Rd #01-04, Sixth Avenue Centre Singapore 279883 Singapore
comment: The service is really really really bad I can't emphasize enough how bad it is.They are hilariously slow that I was almost dead before the food came, and the food still haven't come yet by then.

address: 805 Bukit Timah Rd #01-04, Sixth Avenue Centre Singapore 279883 Singapore
comment: While the food is moderately decent, the location quite ideal, there are a number of issues with this place that fall well short of its potential as a top place in bukit timah. The service is generally friendly, but as has become the norm in Singapore, ignorant of the menu, wines and almost basic restaurant knowledge. The food has potential but could use an upgrade on seasoning, plating and 'wow' factor. The decor is ok but not exciting and the TV distracts way too much because it's inescapable. The air con was frankly hurricane-like. And while they tried to lower it, it figuratively froze our dishes, not to mention the kids. The food was cold before it was halfway complete. The braised beef short ribs were very tasty but almost congealed a few minutes into the meal. I had high hopes for the place but will not return. For this place to compete with Blu Kouzina and other neighbours, they will have to step up their game.

The experience at Caruso blew me away! This is one authentic Italian restaurant not to be missed!Prices may seem a little high but the taste, portions and ambience were unforgettable. Ordered a vongole pasta and it was superb. Superb white wine sauce... (Vongole is based on availability and I was quite disappointed it wasn't available on a Thursday night I came to visit) Thinking of it makes me salivate... Pizza was also superb! We ordered the mamma mia pizza. Great place for large gatherings and they will set you on the long rectangular table at the back of the restaurant. Portions were great for sharing too! There is also a good sized bar that you can have a drink on, or wait for your takeaways to enjoy the awesome dishes at home. Read of other's reviews that service is a hit and miss, but the service I experienced twice here were respectable and waters were filled promptly. Couldn't recommend enough a lovely evening here and a taste of Italy.

I am so surprised that Caruso isn't on Yelp already. But maybe that isn't a bad thing because this place is so good you'll want to keep it your little secret. I was there for dinner last week and we had the burrata which was incredible, melt in your mouth and bursting with flavour. We then had the spaghetti caruso and panzerotti tartufati, both were excellent. The pasta is handmade and the sauces are just right. Great balance of flavours, not too heavy. The house wine is good too. My review doesn't even begin to do it justice!The restaurant itself is cozy and relaxed with a neighborhood restaurant vibe that makes you feel comfortable the minute you step in. I'm already planning my next meal there.

Good food, very slow and lousy service. Quite typical for Singapore eating establishments where a 15% service charge is tacked on to the bill whether the waiter has a pulse or not.We had to ask for bread 3 times before it arrived after about 20 minutes. It's a simple request but the waiter just didn't think it was important.Prices are on the high side - over twenty bucks for entrees and everything is ala carte but you get hawker center service minus the tissue vendors.

Small little burger shop tucked away in the corner of a relatively quiet food center, owned and operated by a young local couple. They only serve 2 items: beef burger + chicken burger (uh.. sandwich?). I've never had their chicken burger, but this is definitely my go-to when I'm craving for a good cheeseburger. Soft, fluffy, well-buttered buns, juicy minced beef with their self-concocted sauce that packs a punch. Quality is always consistent and ensures 101% satisfaction in every bite.Prices are super reasonable even though the burgers are comparable to (or even better than) proper restaurants! $6 for a single cheeseburger, $8 for a double. All burgers come with fresh fries on the side. Don't be surprised if you need to wait, there's usually a queue even before they open at 11AM. Each burger is freshly made to order, which may take awhile, but it's worth it. They take pride in assembling each burger to look as perfect as this emoji: . You know those sad photos you see of expectations VS reality? You won't be disappointed here!The food center is relatively easy to get to via public transportation, a short walk from Commonwealth MRT. Alternatively, plenty of parking on site (and even free on Sundays!)Another perk of visiting this place? You're supporting a small local business in achieving their goals :) P/s: Check out their IG page @hammees_sg to confirm opening hours, they'll typically post updates if they need to close for any reason.

address: Ghim Moh Rd Market #01-06 Singapore 270020 Singapore
comment: I was hankering for a burger and noticed this place for lunch so why not?  I ordered the double cheese burger with fries.  I thought I would get a two pattie two cheese type of burger like the one at in-n-out but it turned out to be a double large pattie instead.Ok couple of good and bad things.  The pattie was definitely a fresh piece of meat that was nice and juicy.  Perhaps a little salt would make it tastier.  The bbq sauce and cheese was excellent.  The bun however ended being pretty soggy after a couple of minutes.  I recommend toasting or grilling the bun to make it a little firmer. The bun felt like it was breaking apart with every bite.  A piece of lettuce on the bottom bun will keep the juices from seeping into the bun.  The fries were pretty good but I think holding the salt and letting customers salt it to their preference would be better.In short it was a good try but can be made much better.

address: Stephan Raidy Centre #01-06, National University of Singapore Singapore 138602 Singapore
comment: Weather you call it boba or pearls or bubble tea, if you are a fan of starchy, chewey, sweet balls of boba deliciousness and are in the NUS area, you should check out Fortune Village. For $S 2.30 you get a large cup of milk tea with honey boba. I think the boba here has a really great texture- not too soft and not too hard. I also like that the tea has a strong tea flavor, and isn't really watered down. My favorite so far is the earl grey milk tea with boba. If you're really looking for a sugar rush, they also have excellent pandan waffles starting at $S 1. Waffles + Boba = happily caffeinated Malini :D

rest_name: Kian Seng Loh Mee Prawn Mee Laksa
comment: Most of the people in the Q ask for Loh Mee.I like Loh Mee, so this Q cannot be passed up. I waited about 30mins for my turn. The soup base is pretty good. Add those chilli paste and garlic, and it's magic. The yellow noodles standard, and most people would ask for a mix of Kueh Tiao or bee-hoon and yellow mee. The ngo hiang is below average, the fishcake slices is average, but the pork belly slices is heavenly. When mixed and eaten together, it's quite good. Personally, I think the Q is too long, it probably deserve half the current Q.Ma Po Loh Mee is my benchmark comparison, and I think this rates below Ma Po.

rest_name: Kian Seng Loh Mee Prawn Mee Laksa
comment: We came here following the reviews. Thanks!!  We had laksa and lor mee. It was all very tasty. The stall staff was nice and courteous.

A branch of the much more famous stall in Maxwell Food Centre. I have heard comments that the original one is loads better but I feel like the offering here is still good and without the ultra long queue. They don't have roasted chicken which I usually prefer but it's not a big deal since the steamed chicken is quite tender and the rice has the right texture and amount of flavor. Pretty value for money in general.

Couldn't wait to try it, since it was all I read and heard about. I expect the world's best chicken. What I got was, the world's rubberyest plate of yuk. The rice and broth were flavorful, not great. The chicken was cold, rubbery, and had an odd texture. I took a second bite, and it was as bad so I stopped eating it. Luckily, we happened to also get a plate of Char Kwey Teow from another stand that was the absolute best dish I've ever had!

address: 448 Clementi Ave 3 #01-08, Clementi 448 Market & Food Centre Singapore 120448 Singapore
comment: The sesame chicken is pretty good. The pork belly is memorable. The chicken is mostly pieces of wings. The sesame oil sauce and curry is already pre-prepared and when you order they cook it again in those pots. Low budget and efficient. The Dong Po pork belly is already in a pot there somewhere, and they serve according to the portion we order.Generally it's a four star plus, overall value for money and great taste!

address: Blk 448 Clementi Ave 3 #01-10 Clementi Singapore 120448 Singapore
comment: Chai Ho is another example of why Singaporeans can be justifiably proud of our hawker culture.  This is a family business.  This business only deals with a single product (ok...maybe two if you consider that they also sell bak kwa and meat floss).  The legendary lines in front of Chai Ho are certainly there because of the satay, which is what this review will be about.  For the time that they've been Chai Ho and have been a business, they've had time to tweak their product till you get what you get today.  Honestly, it hasn't changed much, the quality and the taste of Chai Ho satay has remained essentially unchanged.  It was good then, it is good now and if they continue to run things, will continue to be good.  Like all successful family hawker businesses that form the foundation of Singapore food, they know not to screw with the recipe, with what works.  The enemy of good after all is better.  It's when a cook gets a faraway look and the worm of an idea starts to sow its corruption, that good, solid, respectable food becomes so much merde.  Chai Ho is an institution because they understand the process and are confident enough in their product not to change what works and what's been bringing those lines back day after day after day.  I recommend the chicken satay, my favorite, and which usually runs out first.  The pork would be my next choice and if hungover, likely my first choice because as other reviewers have alluded to, there is belly fat...ohhh so good for a hangover.  The peanut sauce is thick and clingy, just the way I like it.  You can power it up by adding a dollop of Skippy Chunky Peanut Butter and stirring it into the hot peanut sauce.  I do this occasionally when I get Chai Ho to go.  Guests are always wondering how the peanut sauce gets so rich??!

address: Blk 448 Clementi Ave 3 #01-10 Clementi Singapore 120448 Singapore
comment: It's pretty difficult to find a satay stall where one needs to actually queue for it, but this stall is one. Nestled in the heartlands, this stall serves up one of the better satays around.The star of the show is no doubt the pork satay: it has a perfect combination of a smoky flavor and tender meat with tons of fat. You'll no doubt pile on the calories while eating this, but trust me, it's worth it. Of course, good satay must be coupled with good "satay sauce", and the peanut curry dip here is really addictive. Be sure to order more of the rice in order to enjoy every single drop of the sauce!The quality is however not that consistent; you might get more than a few sticks of burnt satays from time to time, but feel free to bring it for an exchange; they're friendly enough to do it for you.

address: Blk 448 Clementi Ave 3 #01-10 Clementi Singapore 120448 Singapore
comment: Growing up in Clementi meant that I had no idea what the fuss was about regarding this satay stall since I've munched on those sticks of meat all my life quite often thinking that it was a standard taste. It was only when I was about 17 did I realize my classmates from Hougang would travel down to Clementi Food Centre just to have this specific stall of satay. Each stick is peng kang-ed on the spot which means you get fresh meat that's piping hot from the charcoal grill. I love nothing more than the smell of a good old charcoal bbq, and one of the biggest indicators of this stall aside from the queue is the burning charcoal smell emitting from the stall. I love the pork meat the most, since each tiny piece of meat is skewered alternately with a piece of pork lard that's soft and melts in your mouth - amazing stuff! They even sell uncooked sticks of satay, which I discovered after making enquiries about catering for a birthday party. So you can basically buy raw sticks of satay and bbq them on your own at a chalet, super genius!

address: Blk 18, Toh Yi Drive #01-17 Singapore 590018 Singapore
comment: Very nice roast pork. We especially love the Shui Jiao. You can taste the real prawn in it. Try it!

5 May 2017Sizes and prices have changed.For best value just go for a large Had the a taste of the black sauce mee today and it reminds me of indo mee but more on the sweet side. Not bad if you want an occasional change in taste.

Having done well in their first outlet at Ang Mo Kio, Soi 19 Wanton Mee in Singapore has decided to open another outlet at a coffee shop just a few minutes walk from Jurong MRT.I haven't tried this before at all and decided give it a go today. I literally just finished eating and decided to give my review on this immediately - I got here about 1:15pm on a Friday afternoon and joined the queue. Took me about 10mins to receive my order? They're pretty fast as they take your order whilst you're still in the queue. I ordered the jumbo portion since I don't live anywhere near both their outlets and felt I probably wouldn't come here often anyways. Now on to the food!The portion of $6 (jumbo) is pretty huge, even for a big guy like me. Don't really need to order this size unless you're like super starving as it seems pretty generous. All you need to do is help yourself to the chilli as they serve the bowl to you. As Thai wanton mee goes, the choices of chilli are the chilli flakes or the green chillies like your usual local wanton mee. Choose either or both. The bowl of noodles comes with a small bowl of wanton soup, again the usual standard. Here's the part about the noodles.It is QQ as everyone says, quite generous with the ingredients which includes fried dumplings, charsiew and pork lard. All quite generous. The noodles I felt was a little dry and slightly clumped together. I had to pour some soup into the mix to loosen up the noodles slightly. Taste wise, I felt if they had removed the name "soi19", I wouldn't have know its Thai in any way. The Charsiew was pretty average and so were the wantons. They also add Chinese sausage slices inside. Pretty interesting. They aren't BAD by any means, just that I guess it was probably very overhyped. Do bear in mind that my only reference from Thai wanton mee is the one at Alibabar at katong called Baan by Rochor Thai. THAT wanton mee in particular tasted "Thai" to me. This one was just a VERY handsome portion of noodles with quite a variety of ingredients unlike the usual. 3.5 Stars
Sooooooooo yummy!!!! Highly recommended. Though this outlet is a bit ulu but it totally worth going. I love it! The noodles is just like the one in Bangkok. Same same taste. Very very good

address: 2 Adam Rd Food Centre Singapore 289876 Singapore
comment: I actually timed the queue, it came to 39 minutes. He will sign first "come here and what do you want" then "eat here or take away" (I was confused, hence putting it out there for future visitors). The rice was a bit soft for my taste, too salty, and with not enough coconut (but you can really smell the pandan as a result). The ikan billis was not sickening for a change. The chicken wing is a chicken wing, I mean there's not many ways to improve on a chicken wing, it's a decent wing as far as wings go. No peanuts. The sauce was the best item, sweet and with incredible scent. I could not indulge fully in the sauce due to avoiding spicy foods at the moment, which may be why I was less than enthusiastic about the whole thing, which I did not consider to be worth 39 minutes of queue (prices have bumped up too, $3.90 for the chicken set). I prefer the nasi lemaks I've had around Joo Chiat. My wife, who ate most of her sauce, thought it WAS worth it, so I'll average our ratings and give it 4*. Personally, I'll try "No. 1" next time, its queue is considerably shorter and you get peanuts with your nasi lemak.

address: 2 Adam Rd Food Centre Singapore 289876 Singapore
comment: The is the original stall behind Crave Nasi Lemak. It was a bit better than the Crave Nasi Lemaks I've had (possibly due to proper plating, and a bit cheaper too since there's no mall rent to pay) but still nothing to write home about. Got a $6 Nasi lemak set with chicken wing, otah & begadil. The quality was similar to crave.The otah was the best item - fragrant with a rich coconut flavour.
