忘不了　忘不了忘不了你的错　忘不了你的好忘不了雨中的散步　也忘不了那风里的拥抱on a cold and rainy night,this 'ancient' chinese tavern will warm your lights.secluded and romantic, in it's own right,the soft whispering music, might you like.忘不了　忘不了忘不了你的泪忘不了你的笑忘不了落叶的惆怅　也忘不了那花开的烦恼you'll probably care not their offerings of light bites,but complimentary crispy wanton skins, just might.drinks don't come cheap under dim lantern's light,but chill here you must, till the still of the night.寂寞的长巷而今斜月轻照冷落的秋千而今迎风轻摇它重覆你的叮咛一声声　忘了　忘了它低诉我的衷曲一声声　难了　难了champagne, wine, whiskey, sake, grand cru water and chinese spirits.indoors or out, the ambience delights.and a simple pre-billing touch of tea, i like.忘不了　忘不了忘不了春已尽　忘不了花已老忘不了离别的滋味　也忘不了那相思的苦恼 unforgettable, unforgettable,cannot forget that spring has ended,cannot forget that flowers have wilted,cannot forget the taste of parting,and cannot forget jiu zhuang's haunting.

This place is not the easiest to find amongst the trees and furniture shops in dempsey but it has a charm thats evident the second you open the door.  Youre greeted with period music from 1930's as you walk into a really cozy chill setting.  Ive never been to a lounge in shanghai in the 1920's but this is about what I pictured.  Its got lots of ambience, nice romantic lighting and a huge selection of wines and alcohol.  They dont serve food but give you little fried wanton skins to chew on.The only problem I have is that its really not a place youre going to sit and drink for a while because the drinks really arent cheap.  They have a great selection but the average person isnt going to throw down $40 for a glass of whiskey.  They do have cheaper options though (ranging from 18-up there). Its not all that expensive though the beer selection is limited to Tsingtao.  Its just hard to pay kudeta prices when youre not perched on top of the MBS.  Thats the only reason I didnt give it 5 stars. I really admire places that take a chance to bring personality and flavor to a spot and try and be different.  I definitely recommend this place and plan on coming back....just not in the beginning of the night.
Hidden gem...takes you to a different time.

Classy up-scale 1930s Shanghai 上海 atmosphere with several styles of music in Mandarin (Salsa, Jazz, Cha cha cha, etc.) Very interesting, and reminds me of the opening scene in Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom (1984).

[1] Portobello Fritters $12.90- We all knew good food coming before it reaches our table. All thanks to the fragrance from the truffle oil. Portobello fritters were so crispy, drizzled with truffle oil on the outside and best of all, it wasn't soaked with oil when we bite our way through it!! So good I think I could have a few servings on my own.[2] Sambal Sotong $16.90- These 2 sea creatures were presented to us in a nice char. "Almost" grilled to perfection but I thought cooking time could be a little shorter to keep the tenderness of the flesh. The flesh itself tasted slight garlicky and goes really well together with the sambal chilli.[3] Salted Egg Yolk Calamari $13.90- Salted Egg Yolk food items wasn't new to any one of us here, it has been trending for more than a year already. What made LHOD's dish stood out? Their version of salted egg yolk sauce was thick, grainy with salted egg bits and not salty. The proportions of salted egg, curry leaves and chilli were perfect where each individual ingredients did not overshine each other. Great on these breaded calamari! LHOD could consider using this sauce to create new dishes too.[4] Prawn Paste Chicken Wings (4pcs) $15.90- Look at these wings!! Chicken wings were huge and juicy within. Skin deep fried till super crispy, lightly marinated with prawn paste and a dash of herbs. A pity the marinade did not penetrate into the meat completely otherwise they would have tasted even better.[5] Drinks:[a] Iced Chocolate $7.90- My kind of drink but it wasn't chocolatey enough for me. I preferred thicker sinful ones.[b] Green Garden Fruit Fizzies $8.90[c] Pink Passion Fruit Fizzies $8.90[d] Lavender Blue Fruit Fizzies $8.90[e] Sunny Day Fruit Fizzies $8.90- These non-alcoholic thirst quenchers were more interesting. Pretty colors and interesting flavours made us couldnt make up our mind which to try first. We ordered the 4 most popular ones to try out. My favorite was the Pink Passion Fruit Fizzies. I love slight sourish drinks as it gave me more appetite to eat more!Mains:[6] Big Breakfast $16.90- For this price we paying, portion served was really generous. Scrambled egg was done pretty well, just the way I love my eggs to be. The spinach and mushrooms were a little salty but they definitely complement the bread well. Served all day![7] Seabass wif Salad $34.90- Fish meat was firm and succulent. Pretty to my eyes and tasty on my palate. The chef made the pan-fried potato balls looked like scallops, Genius! My 2nd most loved mains for the night.[8] Pork Ribs wif Salad $32.90- Whenever I order pork ribs, I'm most concerned with the tenderness of the meat and the sweetness level of the marinates. Lucky this plate didn't disappoint me. The marinates wasn't overly sweet and carried off a smokey aftertaste. The meat fell off bones easily, tender and nice.[9] Spaghetti Laksa Prawns $26.90- Tadahhhh.. My vote goes to this spaghetti laksa prawns for best dish tonight. Look at the huge prawns we were given! Very fresh and crunchy. The spaghetti texture was al dente and every mouthful you could taste the spiciness of the sauce. I love the fiery kick from the laksa sauce, but I could take something spicier. If only the sourish from the tomato base could reduce, I believe the laksa taste would outstand more. Nevertheless, this was still my top choice :)[10] Chilli Crab Bun $19.90- Who don't love crabs? Everyone on this table loved them! Chunks and chunks of generous crabmeat were made into patties and served to us in a delicious bun made in-house. Look at the Chilli crab drizzle, so generous and everything overflows! We almost licked up the plate *haha*[11] Pulled Pork Sandwich $17.90- If we compared this pulled pork sandwich with the chilli crab bun, the former crabby was so much better. Pulled pork was too dry and tough for my liking. Overall lacked the juiciness of meat which I found it a pity. Desserts:[12] Sticky Date Pudding wif Vanilla Ice Cream $13.90- Sticky date pudding was so good, we wiped it out in seconds. Every mouthful you can taste the fragrance of dates. Beware: It could get very sweet if you pair with the bananas given but we gals dun care! Whack!![13] Creme Brulee $10.90- Tofu-liked vanilla custard base was smooth and slippery, eventually disappeared after touching our tongues. The torched sugar crust gave it more flavour. I would say it's a common item which can do with or without.[14] Vanilla Bloom Pot $6.90[15] Pandan Rose Bloom Pot $6.90- These mini pots piped so beautifully with flower petals attracted us at first sight! Almost too pretty to eat them. Vanilla bloom pot tasted less sweet with a very nice milky flavour and fluffy sponge cake below. As for Pandan Rose, the frosting was too sweet although it smells good. But I couldn't finish the first mouthful. The Pandan cake below was slightly dense too. This flavour definitely for the sweet toothies only.

Little House of Dreams has been through a big revamp and now sits comfortably beside Ben & Jerry's ice cream. The decor is very pretty, chic and cosy. The warm, light colours are used for the furniture and walls. There's even a play corner for kids to hang out, while parents watch them and have some savoury mains, sides, cakes or ice cream and waffles from Ben & Jerry's. I love that you can order items from both places and dine in a single location.Sambal Sotong $16.90Beautifully plated, this was an interesting menu item that you don't normally get to see in cafes. The squid itself had a chewy texture with a characteristic earthly flavour. The squid also maintained a slightly charred aftertaste. As I'm a weakling when it comes to spicy food, I did not try the sambal sauce.Prawn Paste Chicken Wings (4 pcs) $15.90We were expecting drumlets and winglets but we were surprised to see 4 full chicken wings in a basket. On first impression, the prawn paste aroma was evident. But upon the chicken wings cooling down to  a temperature which we could consume it at, the prawn paste taste was nowhere to be found. The skin was however, superbly crispy and the meat was juicy without being oily. No need to rush to the washroom to wash your hands after consuming this chicken wings!3. Salted Egg Yolk Calamari $13.90 *Highly Recommended*I loved salted egg and I love calamari, hence this is one of my highly recommended dishes to try at Little House of dreams. The salted egg yolk sauce was creamy and yet slightly grainy and lumpy, coupled with a distinct aromatic flavour that had a mild salty-spicy aftertaste. I just couldn't stop munching on these! Even though, these calamari rings sat for awhile, during the photoshoot, despite being being soggy, the presence of the salted egg still stood out clearly.6. Ribeye Steak with Salad $39.90I usually liked my steak medium, but this was medium-well and I still liked it. The steak was juicy and tender and together with the provided steak sauce, this was a  very appetizing. The salad had little sliced baby potatoes which I felt was an interesting way to present carbs on a plate, without making the plate look cluttered with carbs.8. Pork Ribs with Salad $34.90The pork ribs were thick, meaty and succulent. The meat was tasty but just like the pulled pork, it could've been a bit more tender. The sauce was sweet and tangy and perfectly marinated deep into the meat.9. Spaghetti Laksa Prawns $26.90Simple ingredients and yet exploding with flavours.  The prawns were huge but the gradual follow up with the spicy intensity didn't allow me to taste the prawns.10. Chilli Crab Bun $19.90 *Highly Recommended*The chilli crab patty was made with real crab meat, the sauce itself wasn't spicy and kids could probably eat this too! The chilli crab bun was certainly a satisfying and enjoyable one. The bun was toasted till the ends of the bun was crisp and pillowy in the center. The chilli crab sauce topped the crab patty with a sweet and tangy taste contributing to a shiok and yummy satisfaction level.  The crab patty was also well marinated, tender, and flavourful.14. Vanilla Bloom Pot $6.90 *Highly Recommended*This was so pretty! So much effort is made by Little House of Dreams to give you the unique dessert experience. This is actually a cupcake dressed up as a potted plant. The creme on top, was alright in sweetness factor. The cupcake on the inside was on the drier side but tasted great, when combined with the creme. I'll probably be craving for this in the d18. Snickers Cheesecake $7.90 *Highly Recommended*The owners mentioned that if you like nuts, or snickers, you'll be a fan of this cheesecake. That was me and I knew immediately that I had to try this. Indeed, this cheesecake was filled with nuts, caramel, chocolate and a chocolate cookie handmade crust. The cheesecake was dense, but not overly sweet. I wasn't  expecting this to be spectacular but it sure was!19. Lavender Blue Fruit Fizzies $8.90All the fruit fizzies are ingeniously thought out. My Lavender Blue Fruit Fizzie was made with lavender and little iced cubes with real strawberries on the inside.

Little House of Dreams is a homegrown bakery and one-stop party decorations specialist that offers bespoke cakes, cookies, cake-in-a-jar, freshly baked goods, party supplies, party decorations and even party props rentals.They have experienced party stylists to create bespoke dessert tables to suit any theme and occasions such as weddings, baby showers, parties, corporate functions and photo shoots.Little House of Dreams also conduct baking workshops at their baking studios or at a location convenient for the customers. Their sister shop, Dreams and Confetti, offers a specially curated selection of party supplies, imported tableware, pretty cake stands from USA, candies, trinkets, gifts and much more.Little House of Dreams has recently launched a new savoury food menu in December 2015 which features burgers, pastas, pizzas, salads, sides and sweet treats. One noteworthy point is that the dough for the burgers, pizzas and pasta are all hand made in-house at the Little House of Dreams.REVIEWThe hot foods here are all prepared by their talented pastry chefs. As the Little House of Dreams' forte is in baking and bespoke dessert creations, we find that their savoury food items would require a little more fine tuning.Being a fairly new establishment, the Little House of Dreams has great potential for growth, with their great desserts, cosy ambience and friendly service with a personal touch, and I will be happy to return to try their new offerings.

Cute place, with pretty desserts but at relatively higher prices (well.. it is at Dempsey). We tried the lemon meringue tart, yummy but $9 a pop!! Perhaps their focus is more on their desserts, their savory menu is really lacking in quality. Service was bad too. Don't think it's worth a second visit. Came here on a Friday morning and it was relatively empty. But was surprised that service was still extremely slow. We seated ourselves, the server saw us but did not even approach us and just stood around. We asked for information regarding several things (menu, availabilities etc.), and she had to go ask someone else multiple times - she didn't seem to know what's going on. They do not have physical menus, everything is on the iPad. Our party of 4 had to squeeze together to browse a small screen. Their digital menu seems pretty poorly planned out too - they only have brunch items available on weekends and public holidays, but it was featured under their "Popular" section which didn't indicate the availability of the items. New items that were featured on their little posters were not on the iPad and, quote the server, we were supposed to "just order from the iPad", but how?Food is just ok. They arrived way too slowly... We got appetizers, salad and main dishes. The main dishes came first. We didn't understand why our main dishes came out before the appetizers, and the salad was the last to arrive.Seems like a cute place to have brunch at, and a nice place to hang after work as it seems like they have live music occasionally. But if the service was already so bad when it wasn't very crowded, can't imagine when it is.

Strange place with many apparent contradictions. Cute pink, Tiffany-blue and white décor, adjacent to a Ben&Jerry's counter - as if to appeal to an adolescent audience. Yet, the alcohol list is almost as long as the limited food menu. We didn't try the bakery goods, but the unimaginative savoury dishes range from bad to barely acceptable. For lunch, the kitchen only opens at 12:30 pm. With so many alternatives in the Dempsey area, why bother? And why do the owners wastefully put an iPad at every table, when it says "For Staff Use only". Incidentally, the staff are very friendly when they appear, but alas they are largely absent. Pricey for what it is - without the Entertainer offer, would be pretty bad value.

Located at hip Dempsey so I expected this to be pretty artas. Nice ambience although it's a bit of a walk from the car park to the main entrance of the restaurant. Service was attentive and the menu seemed interesting. Portions are tiny for the price though and the coffee was definitely disappointing for me.

My husband and I were walking around Dempsey on a Sunday, wanting to try a different place for lunch. We were in the mood for burgers, and although we heard Huber's Butchery serves some good ones, we weren't interested in eating al fresco because it was so frikken hot!Hungry and desperate for air conditioning, we spotted Go-Go Bambini and liked what we saw on the menu. In addition to burgers, they also had salads and pizzas. Walking in we were a bit confused- why are there so many children here and OMG that's a huge playground! (Then my Italian brain popped in- bambini means children... ah, I see what they did there.)I think Go-Go Bambini's concept is genius here in Singapore, and I'm surprised there aren't more places like it. It's a family friendly establishment in upscale Dempsey that allows children to run around freely in an indoor playground as the adults chow down on gourmet food offerings! Of course, they also have a children's menu, and all items from it are served on durable plastic plates and cups so nothing breaks.My husband ordered the GGB (go-go bambini) burger, which is basically a bacon cheeseburger topped with a fried egg. It's quite epic, and good if you're super hungry! I had the cheeseburger. I found it juicy and well seasoned. I also liked the fries that came with it.If I could change one thing, it would be the glass sizes for adults. They served us water in what could be a considered a big shot glass in certain bars. Since you pay when you order, the staff didn't really check on us after our food was served. We had to work to flag them down so they could refill the glasses for us.Other than that, this is a nice spot to check out. If you're single, don't let the children scare you away- the food here is worth checking out!

I like to share my first experience with my grandson at Go Go Bambini on 14/08/18. I accompanied my daughter & my baby grandson of 7 mths plus & was in the play area for Toddlers aged 3 yrs & below.Practically the place was a sorry site.There were very few thngs to play.Th drums set & other musical instruments had strings that were really short even for a 3 yrs old to play let alone a 7 mth baby.There was no pit ball  as shown on the website. I spent more than 1 hour in the area as no other toddlers were interested to play there.They came ,saw the place & ran off.I don't blame them,there was nothing of interest for hat age.  We spent an entire time to ourselves & no other toddlers of 2or 3 yrs came to play as they were all more interested in the pit ball area for older kids .I hope there will be more improvement for added useful toys & a pit ball for the younger toddlers .

According to Singaporeans, this is one of the best places to get durian!! Although on the more expensive side, the quality is undeniably worth it. The MAO SHAN WANG and KING OF KINGS were both sooo flavorful - sweet and slightly bitter. The King of Kings being slightly more bitter and drier.The stand offers seating and free water which is definitely needed to counterbalance the richness of flavor. They also provide plastic gloves for eating so your hands don't smell too much haha.

Had my first durian here. The first one I tired seemed very different from anything else I've eaten before. By the second durian I was enjoying it quite a bit. Later I tried durians from other stalls and they did not compare. These were far better. There is seating under shade and a fan on to keep cool. The staff was friendly and seemed happy to watch us all enjoy their fruit.

I've never eaten at this stall physically, but I've always had durians from this stall for as long as I can remember, my entire life.Dad always hauled a giant paper bag of durians from the trunk of his car. Word is, according to Dad, our Emeritus Senior Minister Goh gets his durians from this stall too. Because of the quality of durians from this stall, I never ate a durian from another stall, ever, because I didn't want to pay for durians, and I am not a pro like Dad at choosing durians.I remember getting a shock at the ripe old age of 23 when I first bought durians from a random stall, because I was so used to the quality of durians from this place that your usual durian just paled in comparison.This place is quite inaccessible, you should probably drive here.

It's not cheap but you absolutely get what pay for. I even saw an Indonesian matriarch waiting in her huge mercedes back seat while her grandchildren and daughter personally helped packed many many styrofoam boxes of durians and oversaw them being laminated shut in plastic with a portable laminating machine that Ah Di keeps handy..just so other rich Indonesians back home wouldn't miss out. I remember thinking..well that's her pickup from the airport guaranteed there! And yes she was so concerned, she opened the car window so she could lean out and make sure her progeny were packing it right!Ever since I broke my jaw years back and had to subsist on a diet of smashed fish and carrot porridge and painstakingly cut up ramen (brought my own scissors to Miharu)..and durian every week for several months..I've been a regular here.Because let's face it, there's not many things that you can get the full flavour of without chewing. So Miharu aside as a weekly treat, I was having durian..2 or 3 times a week.My favourites are the King of Kings (Wang Zong Wang), Red Prawn (Hong Xia) and Nai Wang (Milk King). People complain it's pricey but my tip is, ask for the durians with the small seeds. Then you're not paying for the heft of the thorny shell but for a payload of very creamy copious pure durian flesh. It may not be cheap but my family and I (and friends we bring) often remark even nowadays how good the durians are.Lovely people serving it too.
Good selection of durian most of the time and when their stock doesn't run out. It is on the expensive side though so you have to either reserve your durian or arrive during off-peak times.

it was my first time there and i was with 2 other friends. parking was no issue as there were plenty of lots surrounding the stall. tables of different sizes were readily available and free vacuum sealed cups of water were served upon arrival. the lady boss albeit friendly was not very clear in telling us what was available - she started by saying that only the king of kings durian was left for the day if we wanted only freshly opened fruit. she then proceeded to say that the ones on the left of the shelf were $10 per kilo and ones on the right were $20 per kilo. she then stressed that if we choose to start with the $20 per kilo durian, we were not allow to buy the $10 per kilo for our 2nd helping because the cheaper one will not taste as good as the expensive one so there was no point ordering it. point taken, we decided to go for the more expensive ones.shortly after we started eating our $20 per kilo king of kings durian, a group of 8 came and sat next to our table. since they were in close proximity, we could hear every word of the conversation between them and the lady boss. to our surprise, we heard the lady boss tell the group that she has red prawn durian if they don't want to eat the king of kings. Wait a minute! did i miss the arrival of the durian truck in that short 8 minutes?at that point i can't help but feel rather cheated especially when the king of kings that I'm having weren't exactly that fantastic for the price i paid - it also didn't have the small seeds like the lady boss said it had when she presented the durian to us at the table. In addition their red prawn durian was more fragrant than ours because i could actually smell it when it arrived at their table...i guess it's no surprise that i stopped eating after 3 seeds.the name of the stall is Wan Li Xiang and the contact person is Ah Di.I think for now I'll just keep Ah Seng as my friend.

Went here for family lunch on Saturday. To my surprise, the food here is surprisingly good. We ordered sausages, pizza, beef wagyu cubes, and mussels. All are terrific. Special shout out to the wagyu cubes that came with the salad. All the food were tasty and hit the right notes of my pallete But The speed at which the food is served is disappointing.. We spent 2 hours there. Not sure was there something wrong or the taste of the food needs to sacrifice time.

CM-PB or Contemporary Melting Pot & Bar lives up to its name as it offers quite a range of dishes, both western and local (fusion) as well as plenty of drinks.  They even have sushi although I haven't tried it yet.  What I have had so far has been decent, but nothing has wowed me.  I've been here 3 times with a group, as it's a fave with my office.  The thin crust pizza is always a good bet for sharing, as is the burrata and prosciutto salad.  The burger is also quite good although at $28, it seems a bit pricey and if you add an egg, then it's $32.  The tomato crab pasta however was not as good as some of the other versions I have had in this town, e.g. latteria mozzarella in Duxton.  The beer selection could also be better - Kronenbourg on draft and a few predictable choices by the bottle didn't win me over.  Overall, it's a nice setting, especially outdoors, and it's a good choice for groups, and perhaps some light bites and basic drinks.  But not really for fine dining or drinks.

Restaurant location is great- in red hot Dempsey area. Food was mediocre; our dessert (mine was date pudding) was tasteless and uninspired. The service is lame- the waitstaff really needs to go through retraining. That bunch of teenagers...wow.

I enjoy sitting al fresco on a cool evening, chilling with friends with a cold beer in hand and good live music (songs from the millennium and my era!). The food here is quite decent - the black pepper crab pasta is quite tasty though might be a bit much if you're eating it on its own. The pizza was quite decent - I liked the wagyu beef with sweet onions and mushrooms, and the calamari and chips with truffle mash also quite yummy.Food is a little bit pricier at about $25++ for mains, but I would come back here again. Free parking at Dempsey (whee!) - there's a larger carpark hidden behind if you can't get any lots at the main carpark, plus I love the ambiance of this place.

I came here looking for more bites after a meal and was tempted into their desserts as well as truffle fries calling out my name. I know it is also a popular place for their drinks (love their mojitos!) and was pleasantly surprised to see that they offer breakfast options too. Mark this down for your next Sunday dining spot.The strawberry shortcake is paired with yuzu in its execution, consisting of a scone like cake infused with yuzu and paired with a raspberry-yuzu sorbet. Very interesting combination of flavours and the sweet and fragrant notes of both fruits paired together worked for me. It's sort of like a twist to the popular strawberry-orange flavours.The truffle fries are really good, I liked that their fries were thicker but not too chunky so you have a good amount of crispy and soft potato inside. The truffle oil was really fragrant and the shaved parmesan cheese added a great salty tinge to the flavours and bite. This one is really good!I've head many more of their dishes way back when they first opened and was impressed. Will go back just to try them all again and properly document them!

I've been here twice, both times on Friday night and it was packed, so a reservation might be wise. Both times I sat outdoors and it has a casual and lively vibe (if at times it felt like it was teeming with slightly too many people). I love the mussels with Parma Ham Cream and my friends are fans of the mussels with Tom Yum. These are the two things we order whenever we go. At $30 for a big pot, we got one each and were left stuffed. There is a live band that plays music inside, and they're pretty decent, so that's a nice accompaniment to dinner. I'd say that because of the noise level and the crowd, it's the kind of place you head to with friends and not a first date.The only cons about the place is that it is slightly on the pricey side, getting a cab is a bitch if you don't drive and it's a little out of the way.Otherwise, if you're looking for somewhere laid-back on a Friday night, this might be an option.

CM-PB | Contemporary Melting-Pot Bar, I love the name of this place. It is crafty and humorous at the same time. This place is kinda like a café/bar/bistro that mainly attracts people that are looking to relax, chill out and just have a good time. This restaurant embraces the all-in-one concept, being a great place to bring family for breakfast and branch and even experiencing happy hours last until 9pm with your buddies. For the weekend breakfast, children will have free cereal. The truffle fries are another thing to definitely come for, some say there are even the closest contenders to P.S cafés.This restaurant must be tried out personally; you won't ever get the full taste just by reading reviews, viewing photos, and hearing opinions about. It is all fusion there, you get some really interesting stuff.

In 2011, I used to frequent CM-PB at least once a week. It's no longer the default hangout of my friends and I, but it still remains one of our favorite places to go to. They serve good and affordable food and drinks without being pretentious and the staff are warm and friendly. What I love most about CM-PB is that it is comfortable for any occasion. We would bring our laptops (free wifi and power plugs!) and work there all day (it's relatively quiet before dinner). It's also good for any meal. My favorite dishes include the black pepper crab aglio olio, wagyu beef chili and lobster and crab "tacos" (note: they are actually dips with nachos). Their waffles and burgers are also popular among my friends. I haven't found any item on the menu that I did not like. It's also great for after dinner drinks. I love their ginger fizz, old fashioned mojitos and lychee mojitos. The bartenders are also very obliging with drink requests. One of my favorite cocktails came out of asking for something with lychee and choya. CM-PB is also a favorite for pre-gaming nights. Umm, our favorite bartender, has given us 10 free shots on more than one of our pre-clubbing stops there. They used to have good live music too (especially when 53A was still playing there). I don't go for the live music anymore but the bands are usually enjoyable. There are huge pluses for being regulars too! CM-PB gave me a massive bag of presents when I was there on my birthday, which included speakers, skin care, a tote bag, and more. Also, CM-PB gives out free soup at around midnight.

I have been coming here for almost 5 years, where does the disappointment start this time around. I ordered the fish and chips, the menu says halibut but it's dory which I was told that it changes from season to season. The fish was oily and under cooked so I move on to the wild mushroom soup, one spoon full tells dishwater in a bowl so I send it back and now I sit here broken hearted hungry and everything else that goes with disappointment. At least the beer is cold. New mushroom soup arrived nice very nice thank god for redemption.

Another one of Dempsey's gems, CM-PB is a hip and chic joint that offers decently priced drinks and food for the young and trendy crowd. Surrounded by the lush greenery, CM-PB is a very conducive environment for short getaways from the concrete jungle that is Singapore. The all day breakfast option is decent and much better than the international and local menu and there's a live band performing during happy hours. Depending on your preference, it's much more airy to sit in the al fresco section then to remain cooped up indoors. They also have a complimentary "Soup of the Night", which is a fairly nice touch, as we found out about during our last visit there.

This is a review of a Wednesday evening dinner date at The Dempsey Brasserie.The room is modern with clean lines.  It maintains a very open and airy feel.  The lighting maintains a feeling of intimacy without resorting to pitching the room into darkness.The narrow metal framed chairs are not very comfortable.  They are a bit too form over function.   Another aspect that subtracted from the ambiance is the restaurant was almost entirely empty.  I am a fan of room slightly bustling with guests and taking in their experience.tinyurl.com/c22tfghThe did have a very nice Christmas tree.  That was quite festive.tinyurl.com/ctoquqaThe staff was courteous, professional, and attentive.  The meal flowed at a nicely managed pace.  There were no uncomortable "hey where is my server?" moments and we were not rushed by a stack of food all simultaneoulsy arriving at the table.The food ranged from good to very good.Beef Carpaccio Board (tender slices of raw beef with rocket leaves horseradish cream, and parmesan shavings) - This was a very enjoyable appetizer.  It was a simple presentation created using quality ingredients with minimal preparation.  It allowed the the core ingredients to shine through.tinyurl.com/d2zkaffMussels + Fries Singapura: (classic singapore chilli sauce, tomato, sambal belachan, egg whites) - This was a unique broth for mussels.  It certainly was a departure from the typical and sedate white wine sauce.  I thought it worked very well.  Mussels with a touch of a kick.  The mussels themselves were also quite good.  tinyurl.com/bu3y3zrThe fries were not anything special though.  The inclusion of the fried bread to dip into the broth was a welcome addition to the pomme frites experience.tinyurl.com/ca2duqxSlow braised beef short rib with truffle & porcini infused mash and roasted root vegetables -  This was her main course.  It was a very hearty meal with rich flavours.  I only had a bite or two but thought it was very good.  She seemed to enjoy it.tinyurl.com/c3oubnmSmokey pulled pork & red cabbage burger served with skinny fries and apple sauce - As she guessed, I went with the pulled pork sandwich.  Since we are half a world away from Kansas City, Memphis, the Carolinas, or Texas, I have to give this sandwich props.  It was a pretty good pulled pork sandwich.  I wish I could find buns like that for use at home.  It could use a bit more of a deep smokey flavour but that is a minor complaint.tinyurl.com/cjhn9shMacaroni and Cheese - We ordered a side of mac 'n cheese to share.  Thus far, this is the best macaroni and cheese I've had in Singapore.  It was creamy and cheesy.  The pasta still had some of it firmness.  However, it screamed for two things to take it over the top.  It could have used one additional much sharper cheese.  But what would have really elevated it would be the addition of some bacon or pancetta.tinyurl.com/cv27s76Receipt ($157.72) - We did not have any wine or other alcoholic beverages.   I do not usually comment on prices very much.  With the exception of the extremes (super cheap or super expensive), I provide information and allow people to draw their own conclusions on costs.  I did not have an issue with the overall cost of the meal.  However, a pulled pork sandwich (even a relatively good one) and a side of average fries should not cost $28.  This is basic comfort food.  They certainly did not do anything with it to upscale it to a $28 sandwich.  Once again, I did not have an issue with the overall cost of the meal or with the cost of the other dishes. tinyurl.com/cg3s6ryOverall - This was a nice meal featuring good food, professional service, and a pleasant modern space.  The food was consistent but did not reach that unforgettable level.  The experience was dampened by a nearly empty restaurant that lacked the little spark that comes from other diners enjoying their meals.

It was pretty disappointing in short.Having read about it on a few food blogs, I decided to check it out for myself. A friend and I went there for dinner one evening and we were quite impressed with the way the place looked. The indoor sitting was a little rustic, a little cool and chic with a large bar in the middle of the room. It was quite a cool night and the outdoor sitting looked really nice and romantic. It was a waste I wasn't there with the boyfriend. It would have made a pretty romantic date.The menu was a pretty pricey, but we heard that the food was good so I was pretty prepared to pay. Unfortunately, the food did not impress. I had a french onion soup for starters and duck confit for mains and we had a serving of truffle fries to share. While the french onion soup was pretty good, with a generous serving of gruyere cheese, the duck confit was a huge let down. The meat was tough and bland and the sauces on the side failed to lift its flavour and texture. The serving was pretty small too. According to my friend, I was frowning continuously as I ate. The truffle fries were nothing to shout about as I have had better ones elsewhere for a lower price. As the food was pretty bad, we decided to head elsewhere for desserts.While I was initially impressed with the looks of the restaurant, the food changed my mind entirely. It is a pretty pretentious restaurant that charges exorbitant prices for sub-standard cooking. There are many better choices in the dempsey area.

We had always walked past Dempsey Brasserie without quite knowing it was there ... we'd been to its neighbours Don Quijote, Pamplemousse and CM-PB, but had somehow missed the discreet and elegant entrance of The Dempsey Brasserie. This changed when a fellow foodie friend raved about The Dempsey Brasserie so we decided to make it our brunch destination for the weekend. Food : We were hoping for the full menu on top of the weekend brunch one, as we had heard many good things about several items on it. However, we were informed the full menu only kicked in at 330pm so we had to stick to the brunch items. We couldn't really decide what to order (mini Angus burgers? The highly recommended fish and chips? The big breakfast?) so we decided to order a few dishes to share. In the end we settled on the French onion soup, the big breakfast and the fish and chips, as well as an iced mocha and elderflower fizz to round it off. The fish and chips disappeared quickly as it was delicious and we were ravenous. We opted for truffle fries, which came crisp and golden. The fish too, was fresh and delightfully complemented by the Stella Artois batter and lemon aioli. We loved the Cumberland sausages and the superbly done bacon (perfect balance between crisp and nicely chewy), and our scrambled eggs were nicely fluffy. We also scarfed down the French onion soup with its thick Gruyere cheese and crostini ... one of the better French onion soups we've had in a while. The iced mocha too was well made, and the elderflower fizz had a refreshing zing to it.Ambience : Lovely! Like a NY style brasserie in the meatpacking district. Though we would have preferred they play jazz or something quieter instead of Robbie Williams belting about how he wanted to feel real love.Service : Wonderful! Polite, prompt and attentive.Definitely going up on my list of favourite brunch places. Will be back to try the full menu.

writing a review after only one visit may not be ideal but first impressions, as we all know, are most important.having read about them in the papers and magazines, i was indeed intrigued by what they have to offer.i choped it and was instantly gratified.for those not familiar but have been to dempsey hill, they are where pamplemousse used to stand.love the high ceiling with understated wall prints and decor.was initially given a choice of bar counter or next to the door table.chose the table but found it weird that my reservations landed me such poor options.upon verbalizing, my friend who entered the restaurant ahead of me failed to mention that we had a reservations because she, herself, was unaware, my bad.the wrong was quickly corrected, and we were shown to our correctly choped sofa seats!i love studying menus and fell in love reading theirs.interesting ideas and combinations which i believe would work IF they can execute properly.first up, uni toast, $18.3 strips of soldiers with fresh uni sitting on cheese at one end.uni was fresh but nothing mind blowing.toast needs to be crispier and served hotter.crab otak croquettes, $12, 3 pieces sitting pretty on a nicely tangy chye poh remoulade.very well fried, chunk full of crab meat with a depth of otak and spices.bak kwa mac and cheese, $20, served in a tiny casserole.maybe they use lim chee guan's bak kwa at CNY prices???too creamy sans crusty chewy cheese with no hint of truffle oil as per menu.penne a little on the hard side.bak kwa was like the hunt for red october.would recommend a no look, pass on this.quinoa, $13, was a mushy meh mess.totally bland and lacking in texture.pork bone tea, $24, a dryish version of bak kut teh.love the moreish tea smoked bone marrow bits!tasty but not quite succulent pork ribs, best tackled with fingers.did not have their must try famous duck confit but it looked rather yummy.their milo dinosaur version 2.1 dessert, $15, was a winner for us.every bite was sweet, rich and sin worthy.service was helpful, attentive and polite.a table of bloggers, obviously being treated to a meal here, were each lugging multiple DSLRs and flashily firing away like papa-paparazzis.but......i'm not your biggest fani'll not follow you until you love mepapa-paparazzi.but...... i will come back to try your must try famous duck confitpapa-paparazzi.

Arggg this is one of those places I really wanted to like. I love supporting local businesses, especially one that tries to push the boundaries of modern Singaporean cuisine. Unfortunately I have to say the fusion dishes didn't quite blow our minds and the non-fusion dishes were good. Ha!I had a work dinner at Pidgin last night with 4 colleagues and we mostly ordered off the set menu, which seemed to encapsulate most of the best hits. Before I review everything I have to say the portions are generous so I'm not sure how Aileen N concluded that they were small.For starters, I had the crab otak croquette, which smelled like otak but didn't quite capture the rich chilli and coconut flavors you'd expect in the meat itself. The accompanying sauce apparently had chye poh but for the most part, it tasted like tartar. My Aussy colleague tried the tuna tartare and he seemed ok with it for the most part.Next I attempted the roasted beetroot salad with local goat cheese. The dish kind of worked together but curiously, the beetroot slices didn't taste or feel roasted. It was basically beetroot with a big slab of mostly sainte-maure and some salad leaves on top - and somehow the flavors didn't come together very elegantly. I'm guessing the sainte-maure was quite young because it was creamy rather than chalky and not overly piquant.On to the mains, I had the prawn capellini (I guess they've downgraded it from more pricey seafood stock) and one of my colleagues had the duck confit. My colleague said the duck was excellent and the sauce was wonderfully rich. My noodles, which are supposed to be a fusion take on wanton mee, tasted..umm...like not so awesome wanton mee? I think the stock and sauce for the noodles needed to be more robust because it felt very flat, though I did like the slices of chorizo iberico and green chilli. The wantons were fat but all I could taste was the well-fried skin as opposed to the supposed tiger prawns hiding in there. Arg I really wanted to like this!At least dessert was largely pleasurable all round with everyone enjoying the milo dinosaur and kaya bread & butter pudding, though the latter did come out a little dry. Just based on my glancing through the dinner and brunch menus, I get the feeling that Pidgin has a little identity crisis. Because the mod-sin dishes aren't successfully pushing the envelope (see Wild Rocket's laksa linguine as an example of success), it's not making money on those dishes and it looks like the chef has acquiesced to the crowd with items like eggs benedict (yawn), duck confit, lamb rack and a steak (double yawn). I'm sorry if I'm being harsh here but if you want to be a mod-sin restaurant than go all the way. Also, while the servers were attentive (there were only 3 covers anyway), they could've have championed the menu a little better by asking us if we'd been to the restaurant before and explain what makes Pidgin's kitchen special. I hope Pidgin stays in business but to do that, the owners need to figure out what their selling and sell it well.

First visit there, totally not impressed with the food. Lobster capellini was so average, can't taste that it's lobster and capellini made to taste wanton is just strange. Mac and cheese bak gwa does not go too. After the 2 items, we didn't feel like trying anything else. Tiny portion, too overpriced!

Make a reservation. It's worth the wait and price given the environment, location, service and the flavors of the dishes. Just make sure you plan ahead in terms of transportation if you don't have a car. Can be a bit hard to get a ride late at night. To be 100% honest I didn't have super high expectations because having moved to Singapore form NYC, the fine dining scene in Singapore hasn't been able to compare. The ambiance and plating have always been beautiful but usually I find the flavors to be lacking and overall not worth the price. In the case of Claudine, I really enjoyed all the dishes. Even if they weren't mind blowing, they are 90% there across the board which I can't say for any other fine dining place I've been to thus far.-Mozambique langoustine: dumplings are delicious and langoustine is perfectly cooked. The soup itself though is less on the bisque side and more... buttery? It was a bit too rich to finish - Cromesquis pork trotter: delicious but be sure to eat it hot, looooove the sauce that comes with it. Has a good kick. Comes with 5-6 pieces -Vol au vent: I think everyone who comes here should get it. It is absolutely delicious and spot on with the layers of salvors. The right amount of richness and saltiness. The pastry itself was the best part, definitely eat it before it get soggy. I don't typically like sweetbread but this wasn't overly gamy / offal like. - Chou farci: recommended for 3-4 people. The pieces themselves aren't big but it is SUPER rich because of the foie gras. So be prepared - Rhum cake dessert: I was really surprised at how balanced this dessert was. The cake itself is the right level of fluffy, the whipped cream is not overly sweet, and the orange (maybe pomelo? grapefruit) adds an acidic element and great texture. It's pre-soaked in rum but not overly so. They bring out a bottle for you to add more as needed

rest_name: Yong Xiang Xing Yong Tau Foo
address: 101 Upper Cross Street #01-1084, People's Park Centre Singapore 058357 Singapore
comment: I have always wanted to try this yong tau foo but had always been deterred by the long queue. Decided finally to bite the bullet on a 3pm afternoon. They take order in Cantonese and it was almost like i was transported back in time listening to them. The line moved quickly and the impressive thing is that the very efficient staffs are able to locate and serve you your order no matter where you sit (very good face recognition algorithm) ! No self service allowed.The 10 piece hand-made Yong Tau Foo in soup were fresh, mostly memorable and a bargain eat at $4.50 although the fish balls were of the run of the millish variety.

rest_name: Yong Xiang Xing Yong Tau Foo
address: 101 Upper Cross Street #01-1084, People's Park Centre Singapore 058357 Singapore
comment: Some times when the weather is too hot, I don't like to eat at the People's Park Hawker centre as it can be quite stuffy and humid. I will head over to People's Park Centre, at the basement you will find Tang Ren Ge and also Food Summons. Two food courts directly opposite each other.You have to order a minimum of 7 pieces if you don't get noodles, it works out to be $3.50. Or if you get noodles it's 6 pieces and noodles $3.50. Either ways it is 50 cents per item. Pretty reasonable.Yong Tau Foo Dry7 items is what I normally get, although you can top up 50 cents for laksa gravy.My favourite item is their home made meatball with egg. They are so generous with the minced meat and hard boiled egg. It's amazing that this Yong Tau Foo stall can make such delicious meatballs. I always get a couple of these, and they are always placed right by the cashier.

rest_name: Yong Xiang Xing Yong Tau Foo
address: 101 Upper Cross Street #01-1084, People's Park Centre Singapore 058357 Singapore
comment: Nothing fantastic. I don't get the hype. It's $4 fixed price, just soup and those ingredients I posted, no rice and no noodles.It's a really LONG queue for nothing that out of the ordinary. Probably only for the fact that I heard they hand make their own "liao" inside the soup.Am I missing something here?

rest_name: Yong Xiang Xing Yong Tau Foo
address: 101 Upper Cross Street #01-1084, People's Park Centre Singapore 058357 Singapore
comment: Located in the heart of Chinatown, Yong Xiang Hing is every tofu lovers wet dream.There is a perpetual line of people queuing up for identical bowls of YTF (Fried tofu, Ngoh Hiang, Tofu with Minced Meat, and Fishballs) at this very stall. Think about it, this standard rubric allows the stall owner to serve his customers quickly and efficiently while specializing in 5 different types of YTF. The items that I liked the most are the ngoh hiang and the tofu with minced meat.Every bowl has 10 pieces of YTF lovingly made by a bunch of old Cantonese men; The best thing is that it only cost S$3.50! This just might be the best Yong Tau Foo in Singapore.Note: The soup has a ton of MSG

rest_name: Yong Xiang Xing Yong Tau Foo
address: 101 Upper Cross Street #01-1084, People's Park Centre Singapore 058357 Singapore
comment: My favourite yong tau foo. Of all time. Even compared to the Malaysian yong tau foo I have been eating in the last 3 years when I lived in KL (they were very good but not as good as this one).I don't understand Singaporean yong tau foo, usually. The soup tends to be so bland and water-like, the stuff too boring and tasteless. The noodles... oh don't even get started. Boring. I swear I have serious food rage when I see cocktail sausages in YTF.Yong Xiang XIng is one of those hawkers that have made it and who do something so well they only work limited hours. Between 1.30pm and 5pm everyday, though, you can have some of it. The queue is mad, always, there are no English words at all on the signboard. Just go to People's Park Centre food centre on the ground floor and look for the long queue that's at a shop with only large Chinese words on its sign.You'll probably be surprised to find that they do things very differently here. One, you cannot choose the yong tau foo pieces you want. Two, there is absolutely nothing in the YTF other than soup and YTF. Not even noodles. I honestly think you will get punched in the face by the grumpy old men here if you asked for either. They're THAT sort of grumpy perfectionists.

address: 9 Penang Rd #B1-12 Park Mall Singapore 238459 Singapore
comment: Food is amazing but the portion is small. For a group of 10, it's better to order 10 dishes (mix of regular and large sizing). Try the Deep fried sweetened pork rib (made of yam), it's tantalising and fragrant. Curry Mutton is awesome too, it tastes almost like real meat!! Another must try dish is the $5 dumpling, crispy (mushroom filling). Herbal soup is very traditionally prepared, a foreign friend of mine commented that the herbal soup is the best dish served.Restaurant is tucked at a corner of the basement, there's no crowd patronising the area at all. All the customers came in huge groups of around 10 pax (via reservation, not walk in)... surprisingly with youngsters being the majority. Pricing is on the higher side, with a plate of vegetables costing around $13.90. They serve ala carte buffet at $19.90/pax. With a good buffet variation and pricing like that, buffet is worth a try!

address: 9 Penang Rd #B1-12 Park Mall Singapore 238459 Singapore
comment: I was invited by a friend to dine at this restaurant. The place wasn't crowded on a Friday night at about 7:30pm but I was told it could be especially when there's a birthday party or during the first (初一) and fifteen (十五) day of the lunar calendar. The price is quite reasonable and the portion is decent. The dishes are like the typical Chinese cook food that you would order in other restaurants but this place is vegetarian. Each dish average about $8 with some more exotic dishes in the $15-$16 range. Their chrysanthemum tea uses actual flower and not in a tea bag like some other restaurants. They charge $8 a pot.I like the Bamboo Pitchs with kai-lan, Hong Kong style fried noodles, Hot spicy monkey head mushroom, and salad prawns roll. The restaurant also serves steam rice if you prefer over noodles or fried rice. They even have bento box style if you prefer those.Since it was a quiet evening the ambiance is nice. Locate in the basement also means it's quiet with most of the shops closed. Park Mall is not a very high "traffic" place.The servers are quite polite and prompt.

Came here for high tea on our last day in Singapore. Cute little space hidden in a strip mall-like street. Tip - you need to make a reservation online in advance. We picked English breakfast, of course - and refilled twice!! The little finger sandwiches were delicious - memorable ones were the mushroom pastry, cheese scone, egg salad on crème puff?? The quiches are nothing to write home about but fine nonetheless. The eclairs were pretty good - I've never tried so many different flavors! The salted caramel popcorn was interesting... but my favorite ones were matcha and STRAWBERRY PISTACHIO  so yum!

Checked place because of some famous food reviewers. Was planning to try before sending these "famous" eclair for birthday gift. Had their tea set:- Dark Choc & cocoa streusel, waitress claim best seller but it didn't wow me at all.- Ispahan is alright.- Yuzu Calamanzi is better among the others.- Chicken & Bacon pie is okay.- Ice Earl Grey Latte, I had better and way cheaper! $2- Matcha Latte definitely don't bother. Just go Hvala.- Ice Cappuccino is better among the others.Service: Unfriendly.
Nice I love it! But rather expensive :( price ranging from $7-$8 per piece. But yummy, treat yourself once in awhile. Aesthetically pleasing as well.

I loved the texture of the eclairs but have to say I wasn't a fan of the 4 flavours I tried. They change flavours about once a month and I'm waiting to try the matcha and the strawberry ones! We went at 4.30pm on a weekday and they were sold out of their ispahan, dark chocolate and some other flavours.Vanilla pecan (classic flavour) - 3.5 starsThe pecan flavour was too overwhelming I couldn't taste the vanilla.Kaya - 3 starsMy mom loved their homemade kaya but it had too strong a coconut milk flavour for me. But I love fresh coconut water but generally don't like coconut ice cream or coconut flavoured things other than rice.Dark chocolate with coconut cream - 3 starsSame as above - I'm just not a fan of coconut but my Mom, who loves coconut, liked this too.Pistachio - 3.5 starsThis should've been my favourite but the strawberry slices were too skimpy and the pistachio cream was a bit too heavy on its own. Would've been much better with more strawberries.Hot chocolate - 4.5 starsRich dark chocolate and I got this with less sugar and skim milk. Fantastic!Matcha latte - 3.75 starsNot too sweet (we got this with less sugar too).

L'ÉCLAIR by Sarah Michelle is the first éclair specialty store and café in Singapore. It was founded in 2014 by Sarah and Michelle, two good friends and pâtissières with a similar dream and passion. The ladies traveled across the globe to Le Cordon Bleu Paris where they spent nine months learning the art of French pastry. They then returned back to Singapore and started with pop-up stores and finally settled on a in-town location.Their interior is very glossy and shiny, with marble like decor and a simple round table as the epicentre of the store as you walk in towards to the eclair display and ordering counter.It's so hard to pick an eclair!!Behold! The holy display of eclairs. They are all so pretty and you can definitely tell alot of time went into meticulously placing all these decorations/toppings onto the eclairs. They were all neatly aligned in the display.The eclairs had toppings that helped distinguish what eclairs they were. Like the Isaphan eclair had a rose petal on it, which I felt was very cute and creative of them. As you walk down the eclair display, it's almost as if you're admiring a display of art work!Most of their eclairs are priced between $7.50-$8.50 1. Isaphan Eclair $8.50Filled with a light rose cream, embedded with fresh raspberries  and cut lychees, this is my favourite eclair! I have never tasted an eclair quite like this. The aroma of the sweet rose smell is also very pleasant and actually, due to it, I couldn't really smell anything from the other eclairs. The rose cream was subtly sweet and with the sourness from the raspberries, blended well together.2. Green Tea Eclair $8As a matcha lover, I had higher expectation of this, but then again. Real matcha isn't supposed to be sweet. The matcha cream here had a very slight matcha taste to me. The outer chocolate layer was so much sweeter that it was all that I could taste. A slight disappointment here, but this green tea eclair is on their seasonal list, so maybe it won't stay in the eclair display for long.3. Earl Grey Eclair $8Another eclair that I had high hopes for as an earl grey lover. I liked that they played fresh blueberries on top with earl grey infused chocolate. The chocolate was so yummy. The cream on the inside was infused with earl grey as well and was the perfect cream for the eclair. Now if only sarah and michelle can make a thai milk tea eclair, that would be heavenly! I needed like 5 of these, it was that good!4. Hazelnut Praline Eclair $8The hazelnut praline eclair stood out from the rest of the eclairs on display because of it's choux au craquelin top! It was filled with valrhona hazelnut cream and roasted hazelnuts. There were alot of roasted hazelnuts in this one. Any hazelnut lover would be extremely pleased with this eclair. The hazelnut cream here was one of the sweeter ones in comparison to the rest that I had tried.Eclairs!!!At L'eclair, they insist on using top quality ingredients to produce the finest tastes and flavours. Each piece is lovingly assembled by hand which are generously filled and delicately garnished with utmost precision. All of these attributes to beautifully hand made eclairs that taste just as beautiful!I can safely say that this place is probably going to be a hit with the ladies. Being how pretty these eclairs are!!!  You can also order these eclairs online whenever you have the craving. Their nearest mrt is Dhoby Ghaut, so it's not too far off for anyone to reach. Verdict : Their eclairs are not just special in appearance! They are also spectacular in taste! The eclairs are a work of art and though at $8 a pop, I feel it is worth the money!

I just dropped by to grab an eclair to go. Unfortunately I came in too late during the day (5pm) so most of their more popular flavors were already gone :(. Go early you guys!I bought the Earl Grey flavor (8sgd).  Let's talk about the presentation - it had blueberries on it. Which I thought was super random pairing with Earl Grey. Blueberries, gold dust and chocolate covered the top. Oh well - it's still pretty enough, I'll accept the blueberries. On to the taste. You have this eclair with a slightly soggy chewy outer portion and then earl grey custard like cream oozing out. It was alright. I didn't really like how soggy the pastry was. At 8 for one , I don't think I'll be returning to try anymore eclairs here.

They are celebrating their 3rd anniversary. Only knew about them after I bought the Entertainer app.Nice ambience. Quiet.Gave a box to a friend and her family. Feedback is that the fillings are amazing but the pastry is only so so. Mushroom soup was good. Not too creamy. Caesar's salad with pasta and additional chicken was just so so.

address: 68 Orchard Rd Unit #01-32/33/34C/35 Plaza Singapura Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: The much-awaited Five Guys burger from the US is here! It's definitely a good time to be in Singapore as we see a couple of international burger chains opening its outlet here in our tiny republic. Shake Shack landed in Jewel earlier this year, we then have Amsterdam based Lombardo's burger and now - Five Guys.  Five Guys is located in Plaza Singapura - ground floor facing the main road. The ordering system is pretty much hassle-free like any burger joint. You queue up (what's new, it's Singapore we queue up for everything!), walk to the counter, order and wait for your burger as the very efficient kitchen staffs do the works. While waiting, help yourself to free flow of groundnuts and a good playlist of songs ranging from rock to RnB and current top 40. I ordered the double cheeseburger with "all the way" toppings, a tiny fries, and a chocolate milkshake. While it's a satisfying meal, it doesn't come cheap. Just like Shake Shack, you can't top-up to a meal here. You order everything separately. I paid $35 for the 3 items and felt that it's on a higher side. Cheeseburger is good - juicy succulent patty, fries a tad too oily for my liking and milkshake is solid. Being a glutton myself, ordering these 3 is a mistake. It's too much. So I would recommend to order a burger and complete your meal with either fries or milkshake. Unless you're really a big eater. Overall, I wouldn't mind a meal here from time to time as the burger is good and the restaurant vibe is lively and a great place to catch up with friends and loved ones.

address: 68 Orchard Rd Unit #01-32/33/34C/35 Plaza Singapura Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: Had it in the US and remembered it was greasy and not the best burgers as opposed to Smash Burger but sadly the Singapore branch made it worst.  I called it Burger Peyek as the burger came in squashed and worst the bun was stone cold!!!  What is up with that?  The pattie itself was still good but sadly given the same amount of money i will opt for Shake Shack at the Airport :).  Seating arrangement and layout seems a little out of place too with the stocks wasting the front end space?  Anyway won't be back again that is for sure. Curiosity really choked the cat :(.

address: 68 Orchard Rd Unit #01-32/33/34C/35 Plaza Singapura Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: Decent burgers but massively overpriced for what it is. $5 for unlimited coke refills? Who even drinks that much coke? Anyway I will go back but bring my own drinks. Not bad food but not worth waiting in queue for.

address: 68 Orchard Rd Unit #01-32/33/34C/35 Plaza Singapura Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: Always a big fan of Five Guys. However, I'll jump into the issue. I've been here four times and the first three visits were wonderful. The food was cooked as ordered with all the right condiments; great tasting. The milkshake was prepare the way shakes should be. But this fourth visit was a disappointment. The shakes were as liquidly as heavy cream (we ordered three shakes and all were like that). The person behind there making the shakes on 24 Jan. 2020 at 6:30 pm should not be doing that job. Putting bbq sauce on the edge of the bun doesn't qualify as a condiment. I also asked for grilled onions and instead received raw onions. I, fortunately,  know this can be chalked up to a bad visit this go-around. But if this was new customers' experience, they may never return. Please be better and stay above the norm. This is truly a good place to eat.

address: 68 Orchard Rd Unit #01-32/33/34C/35 Plaza Singapura Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: The place is honestly very over rated, fries are better then the burgers tbh. Milkshake is way too sweet. I guess try it but i'm certainly never going back there again.

I love the idea of being able to customise your own sushi roll/salad and even the idea of having healthier options like brown rice etc. I usually go for the mega san as it is more worth it, that little bit of extra money for an extra protein like salmon or unagi. (the smaller size does not fill) Also, was being adventurous and chose to deep-fry my sushi roll which was a bad idea. the sushi roll became too greasy and it wasn't very pleasant. It is generally pretty crowded during lunch and dinner time regardless whether its the weekdays or weekends and there is limited seating available. But overall, i'd recommend this place for creative, adventurous and hungry souls !

I really enjoy the maki rolls from this place because there are quirky references to "the sushi roll" everywhere plus the ingredients are fresh and healthy (depending on what you select to go in it, of course). I mean how many places will offer to stuff your maki with items like dried cranberries, sunflower seeds, crunchy jellyfish, honey soy chicken and Yuzu Honey Vinaigrette? Hey, I think I just created a roll, albeit not one I would suggest though. See how simple that was to order a customized roll? Can't decide or in a hurry? Just pick one of their House Sushi's that they've already created for the indecisive customers. I just wished they didn't have to put each roll into those fancy boxes, especially if you're going to eat-in.Seems like such a waste. For those with nut allergies ... Beware: "Our food is prepared at a facility that uses NUT ingredients." So roll yourself outta bed and go get some!
Love the packaging and the idea! First time trying it and got the egg crepe roll with brown rice Had Unagi, asparagus, ebi roe, avocado with miso sauce Healthy and fast!

i'm lovin' itYes, I realize this is the slogan of a certain fast food chain but it describes perfectly my thoughts about Maki-san. It came with high expectations (both Yelpers as non-Yelpers recommended this place) and was a bit afraid that it would be a let down but this concept is just plain awesomeness.Is it the best sushi I ever had? Nope* but they offers good quality sushi at a decent price and the concept is fantastic. As previous reviews described, this is Sushi meets Subway and coincidently I love sushi and I am a subway fan so this restaurant was right up my alley.I am a big fan of the possibility to customize your dishes (yes I am THAT person who takes longer to order a starbucks drink than to drink it) and I am always having a hard time picking sushi as I always end up thinking: "this roll has xyz that I love but I wish it came with abc which comes in this other roll...". Maki-san solves that problem by letting you design your own roll. For eternal doubters as myself it is still a chore as it creates even more choices but it gives you a strange sense of empowerment.I went for the combo which included a mega-san, a canned drink and a snack which came in under 13 S$. My roll was super tasty (maybe because it hit all the right spots since I could pick my own ingredients ) and the snack I chose was super delicious! I would have never expected that crab stick tempura would be something I would rave about but the dough was super light & fluffy and the cheese dip which I picked for it made it a match in haven.Although I have rated it the full five stars I do have some minor points of criticism:1) it is filled with teenagers which made me feel out but a) this is not maki-sans fault; b) it might be due to the time of the day and location (film theatre on a Saturday late afternoon) and c) I might just having to accept that I am getting older...2) I like to drink a lot with my food, in the meantime I have accepted that in Singapore there is seldom a bottomless soda but since there is quite a queue it is difficult to purchase an extra drink if you want a refill so a soda fountain /a water dispenser would be welcome, or even a way to purchase another drink without having to queue in the food queue.Overall this place is amazing. I was going to start a petition: "I want Maki-San at Holland V" but I figured it would lead me to go there more than once a week  and not eat anything else anymore so I am happy for now since the Cathay is not too far away either.* in case you are wondering what for me the best sushi is: without a doubt I would pick a place in Japan. No competition possible, sushi is just so much better there.

How cool to order your sushi the way and the ingredients that you like  Love the packing and the experience. I order my salmon sushi w all the goodies that I like. Salads are also very fresh and tasty. Highly recommended.

As Halloween is coming, the outlet has come out with a new limited edition flavour of sushi roll  known as The Black Magic Roll. It costs $8.90 a roll and only available at the Cathay outlet, via mobile application and online ordering.The sushi roll is stuffed with roasted peppers, kani stick, shredded chicken, roasted pumpkin, deep fried soft shell crab and tomato based chilli sauce. The soft shell crab gives a crispy and crunchy texture, while the pumpkin gives it a sweet and buttery texture. Although the chilli sauce looks a bit dark, it actually tastes not bad giving it a sweet taste with a hint of spicy. Together it gives a explosive combination in the mouth.So don't forget to try it. It is only available from now till end of this month.
Love the concept of customizable sushi rolls, and their Mega-San set meals are really affordable. Seats are very limited so we ordered takeout and sat by the fountain to eat instead.

Every time I'm in Cathay, it always catches my eye. They have the cutest packaging--I would love to collect them all!And the food... The sushi was so good! And really worth it for the price! It's nice that it's customizable and there are a lot of options to choose from! Next time, I'm definitely trying the salad--because they look as goo as the sushi!

I love this place with a passion. Customizable sushi in beautiful packaging reminiscent of Bankaku-style boxes - what isn't there to love?Located at the foot of The Cathay, I would sneakily suggest you buy a roll and bring it to the cinema if you have the munchies. I especially love brown rice in my sushi, and this is the place to get it. I won't go into detail about what works when it comes to maki rolls, because everybody has differing tastes, and what works for me may suck for you.What I want to talk about is the speed of rolling makis. The team is inconsistent with their efficiency. Some days I get my maki super quick, some days I get it super slow. I always go about 6pm and they have the same number of staff each time I go, so I assume this is a business processes issue. Maybe they'll improve on the speed in future - this is fast food after all.P.S. They don't take credit cards. Cash is king here!

Came here on a sunday at 1130am just as they were pulling up the shutters. The biggest selling point about maki san is that you get to make your own maki.. something like subway, except with sushi-ingredients.I went with the little-san $7.90, you get to pick 1 wrap (seaweed or healthy soy +$1)1 rice  (japanese white rice or healthy brown rice)3 essentials (avocado, steamed ebi, ebiko aka prawn roe)1 sprinkle (tempura crunch)1 house sauce (japanese caesar)And you get to watch them make them in front of you, which I think the staff was abit nervous and though he placed 5 prawns in the maki, admist his fluster whilst rolling up the maki, one shrimp fell out! *the horror*I enjoyed the maki. The tempura crunch was a good choice and it was very crispy instead. The prawn roe was rather fresh and the prawns were fresh and crunchy. The brown rice was also a nice healthy touch to the maki so I rarely see japanese maki with brown rice.All in all, a good choice for a quick lunch but a little-san to me, is still too big for me to finish on my own. The Mega-san is definitely big enough to share amongst two.

Every time I'm in Cathay, it always catches my eye. They have the cutest packaging--I would love to collect them all!And the food... The sushi was so good! And really worth it for the price! It's nice that it's customizable and there are a lot of options to choose from! Next time, I'm definitely trying the salad--because they look as goo as the sushi!
Love the concept of customizable sushi rolls, and their Mega-San set meals are really affordable. Seats are very limited so we ordered takeout and sat by the fountain to eat instead.

This place is like a Subway's for sushi-- customizeable, healthy and efficient.You can either choose a pre-set option, or customize your own sushi roll or salad.If you choose the latter, this is how it works:1. You pick up an ingredients list for either a sushi roll or salad2. You check off the appropriate ingredients you want (e.g. brown/white rice, seaweed,  tempura shrimp/smoked duck/salmon sashimi, caramelized japanese sweet potatoes/asparagus/corn/carrots, wasabi mayo/caesar dressing, etc.)3. You give your order to the cashier and pay the appropriate amount4. Cashier gives you a buzzer to let you know when your order is ready5. Pick up your order when your beeper buzzesI almost always choose a brown rice option with soft shell crab tempura, avocado, sunflower seeds and a few more things. The ingredients are all fresh and healthy and the service is very friendly.If you order the sushi roll, there's this robotic contraption that cuts the sushi-- which looks really nifty.It's decorated in colorful furniture that's clearly painted Ikea furniture and works really well with the simple, artsy style of the place.Relaxing atmosphere and good for grabbing a quick bite with friends.Not the cheapest of places, but sushi never is.Thumbs up

I love the idea of being able to customise your own sushi roll/salad and even the idea of having healthier options like brown rice etc. I usually go for the mega san as it is more worth it, that little bit of extra money for an extra protein like salmon or unagi. (the smaller size does not fill) Also, was being adventurous and chose to deep-fry my sushi roll which was a bad idea. the sushi roll became too greasy and it wasn't very pleasant. It is generally pretty crowded during lunch and dinner time regardless whether its the weekdays or weekends and there is limited seating available. But overall, i'd recommend this place for creative, adventurous and hungry souls !

There are two options, a salad or sushi roll, both of which are beautifully packaged and made to order. The ingrdients in my salad were fresh and crispy, but the temperature of the chicken teriyaki was colder than the salad itself. The miso dressing paired with corn, the lemon included in the egg wrap and cream cheese and salmon roll allow me to safely say that Maki-San is a Japanese fusion restaurant/cafe. The brightly colored walls, cartoon artwork, sensitive music, and sushi rolls wrapped like a present leads me  to my final conclusion, that this restaurant is designed for young girls. I spent 30 minutes in the cafe and all the customers were female, half were wearing school uniforms. The artwork depicting angry ingredients with the slogan, "if you don't like it, take it out!" Illustrates just how customizable the menu is for picky eaters or those with diet restrictions.

address: Plaza Singapura 68 Orchard Rd, Blk 01-35 Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: I heard a lot of good stuff about this place from my friend, especially the Malaysian food. Hmm, I want to say 3.5 stars for service and 4.2 stars for food. There was a queue for my party of 1. At times I felt overlooked as well, even after being sat at the table and ringing the bell for service. They were busy on a Wednesday night, maybe short staffed? It's a good thing they have an efficient ordering system. You mark the item number on the ordering pad and press the bell when you're ready. I ordered the nasi lemak with beef rendang. It was delicious. The rice had a coconut flavor and complemented the curry very well. It was pretty good combo for the price too. I also ordered the cendol. It was also really good, great for the dessert too. I almost ordered a second. It's best to make a reservation at this place! Also use the restroom and wash your hands before because the restrooms are in the mall outside. Will come back for sure.

address: Plaza Singapura 68 Orchard Rd, Blk 01-35 Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: Never been to this outlet before although I have been to the one at Suntec City.Service here was a little slow today but at least the waitress came around to check.Char kway teow was nice. Came with a good number of prawns of a good size, bean sprouts, egg and koo chai (chives).So was the crayfish crispy kway teow with chives and green leafy vegetable. This is in gravy.Everything was served piping hot.Heard their nasi lemak is good too.Prices are reasonable. Not noisy.Reasonably good ambience. Nicer than the one at Suntec City. Char kway teow here is also better than Suntec City.

address: Plaza Singapura 68 Orchard Rd, Blk 01-35 Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: Came here under a friend's recommendation and I was surprised that the food didn't suck. Sorry, I was half expecting it to be bad since you really cant replicate hawker/ street food in a restaurant. Well, apparently they managed to do it pretty decently. I wouldnt say that the food is wow. It definitely isnt up to your best street food experience. But hey, it is decent enough for me to want to order it again.I had the hor fun with white chicken. It was pretty good (but I dont like breast meat boo). The chendol with soy milk and red bean drink was very yummy. We were served an appetizer of coffee bun which was delicious since it was freshly baked. Thumbs up!

address: Plaza Singapura 68 Orchard Rd, Blk 01-35 Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: I have heard so much about PappaRich. Although I have to confess when I first heard the name, I had honestly thought it was a new name of a bag brand or something. So yes, my colleagues brought me here for lunch at Plaza Singapura to get a first taste.I have to say I was very impressed with the service. They even have a button (like a doorbell) placed on each table if you require assistance. Famished, I ordered a rice meal. And my oh my, the serving could have lasted me the whole day. They had a big bowl-sized scoop of rice, a runny fried egg (just the way I liked it), a crispy fried chicken leg, and sambal'ed ikan bilis. Taste-wise... I can say that I have definitely tasted better. But still, I think I will give them a thumbs-up for everything. My two other colleagues ordered something noodle-y. Can't really recall what they had. Probably laksa and some vegetarian noodles. They too had enjoy their respective meals and had no complaints.One of my colleagues ordered their scrumptious coffee buns that I admit to have regretted not getting some for myself. Thing is, I can never think of my future hungery self when I am feeling fully bloated with food. Ah! Maybe next time.

address: Plaza Singapura 68 Orchard Rd, Blk 01-35 Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: I like this restaurant chain. The classics were well done - panang beef, hainan chicken, and coconut rice.Then there's a wide selection of drinks and classic Singaporean desserts too. The "The Tarik" milk tea was perfect.Efficient ordering system too (make selection on paper, then press a button for attendant).

address: Plaza Singapura 68 Orchard Rd, Blk 01-35 Singapore 238839 Singapore
comment: Having been known for its rich, affordable papa-style Malaysian dishes, Papparich now introduces their all-new Papparich Plus at Plaza Singapura and OneKM Tanjong Katong.The Kampung Fried Rice $10.90 may have humble origins but is no way short of flavours. Shreds of kangkong, julienned chicken breast, squid with a sloppy fried egg plopped and crunchy ikan bilis, the grains might not look refined but won our hearts with the arresting wok-hei aroma and well-seasoned taste. The Sweet & Sour Crab Meat with Fried Rice $11.90 is Papparich's founder, Rich Tan's interpretation of the Singapore Chilli Crab.
