comment: Excellent Thai food, service is fast but service level is just average.  Food very tasty, pricing good value

address: 27A Lorong Liput Holland Village Singapore 277738 Singapore
comment: With lines around the block, I do take-out now.. which means dining in at home with Nakhon Thai 3x a week. Yup, it's THAT good!  Wonderful staff - fast, polite; awesome tasting food.

address: 27A Lorong Liput Holland Village Singapore 277738 Singapore
comment: The reason most people; say its good is bcz its cheap..  The food was reasonable to start off now its mostly swimming in liquid but more importantly I  have never seen such obnoxious rude surly staff... someone needs to remind them that they have jobs because of customers so may be a good idea to behave sometimes.. I've been three times each time hoping it was bad luck that the staff were so awful but third time enough.. rude rude rude.

Food is decently good, as far as bar food is concerned. Music is very hit or miss...careful coming in the evenings, could be caught being serenaded to '90s tunes that weren't even good by the original singer.

Greenwitch offers something for both vegetarians and omnivores. Thus it makes a suitable casual lunch spot for co-workers and friends. Many items on their menu sound so delicious that you'll want to come back again and again. In addition there is a Daily Special to surprise you on every visit!Dishes get sold out towards the end of the day. However there usually is plenty of cookies and drinks left.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: This is for the branch at the Serene Centre. The service of the staff is not up to a good standard.  There were a few incidents that the food I ordered is prepared. However, there was no one  at the kitchen to deliver it to the customer. After waited for a very time for a simple order (there was not much customers around), I had to go to the counter asking for it. This has created an unhappy customer.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Guzman Y Gomez finally opens for business, in the west side of Singapore.During the opening, they gave out free burritos for an afternoon with a live mariachi band playing. The line was extremely long but moved rather quickly, I got my burrito in 20 minutes.It's similar to Chipotle, fast food tex-mexy type burritos and tacos. It's okay not mindblowing, but the good part is that they're consistent. (extra star for that) It's good now that they are in a convenient location outside the central business district (CBD).3-stars. Overall consistency and that free burrito bribed me into giving another 1-star.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Pulled pork mini burrito ($8.40) - 3 starsI really like that they offer mini burritos! Won't be getting the whole wheat tortilla the next time - the flavor just didn't quite fit in. The pork and beans were just okay. Not too dry, but the flavors could be better. The rice definitely has room for improvement - it could use better spices.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: I was excited with this place opened near me. I've tried them in Perth, Australia and really liked it there.Maybe it's opening pains, but it's just not the same. The ingredients aren't super fresh, and the meats were a little too salty.Those with kids beware - smoke from the nearby smokers' hangout will permeate into the al fresco dining area.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: disclaimer: i am a big fan of chipotle mexican grill!the idea of having mexican food at a stone's throw away from my abode was so exhilarating! of course i have to give it a try asap and my first impression was, "my! what a small shop front they have." their cashier counter was basically 3 steps away from the automatic glass door. the lady at the counter must have known it's not that easy to be staring at a steep menu board for long so she very quickly offered me the paper menu. I chose the spicy grilled steak with regular rice and a side of gucamole. she asked if i wanted sour cream. not being too keen about it, i replied, "just a little." she said, "sorry, we don't do just a little...it's additional 50 cents." that's when the first wave of missing Chipotle came crashing over me. i already accepted the fact I had to pay additional $2 for my guac and also they don't have corn as an ingredient in the bowl so I didn't think I want to splurge anymore for my $13 meal. Quickly i ended my order before i could do anything else stupid like ordering an additional side of churros with chocolate dip. My order was ready in less than 5 minutes and i was happy to find that they offer chipotle medium hot sauce at the condiment table; there were also sliced Jalapeño and diced red onion plus 2 other kind of sauces. It was a good 30 minutes before i could eat and the bowl stayed pretty warm in the eco friendly to-go container. Another nice touch was the melted cheese on the rice but the real saving grace was the hot sauce I picked up on the way out. the sauce really gave the other wise regular tasting bowl its kick. if you like black beans then you will be happy to know they are very generous with their beans. i ran out of rice faster than i could eat the beans. By now i am completely missing Chipotle like crazy.Thanks Guzman and Gomez for offering me a decent bowl of mexican food. it doesn't completely satisfy me but I am glad you are in my life for now.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Decent Mexican place with a variety of options. The outside seating area is prettier than the inside and the fans are enough to beat the heat. The burrito can be filling after a while so you might find it more enjoyable to have a small burrito and pair with sides like nachos. My friend opted for 2 quesadillas instead which looked rather small for a proper meal. My preference is the burrito bowl. The fish is surprisingly good- very fresh in big portions. The guacamole is also well prepared.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: No shame. Queued for the free burrito during their opening.Beef was decent and juicy. The fish, I had lacked seasoning.However, I would recommend coming back for a hearty bite.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: This is nice. Close enough to to chipotle imo. So much meat stuck on my teeth. Tonight I'm a t rex.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Always a good place to grab a quick bite. My kids enjoy it too. The frozen lemonade is too sweet and I do wish they would hv a garbage can so that people can throw away their garbage. Love the biodegradable plates & cutlery.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Yummy! Tried it for the first time and I must say I'm already a big fan. Had the pan seared barramundi burrito bowl with smoke chipotle sauce and extra guac. There is just so much flavour and spice in one bowl, which blended well together. Though the portion isn't huge, its enough to keep me satisfied. I'm glad that I'm able to find a similar version of Chipotle in Singapore!

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: No shame. Queued for the free burrito during their opening.Beef was decent and juicy. The fish, I had lacked seasoning.However, I would recommend coming back for a hearty bite.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: This is nice. Close enough to to chipotle imo. So much meat stuck on my teeth. Tonight I'm a t rex.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: I paid a visit to the new branch at Star Vista, enticed by a free burrito flyer handed out at the mrt station. But when I got there shortly after 5, I was turned away by staff saying that the promo ended at 5. No end time was indicated on the flyer and the staff  acknowledged that but still said the promo was over. Talk about false advertising! !! I told her to tell the manager that this was wrong but she casually dismissed me (the staff were having some kind of celebration and totally ignoring the customers) so I have zero confidence that she will pass my feedback. Hence I decided to post this.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: disclaimer: i am a big fan of chipotle mexican grill!the idea of having mexican food at a stone's throw away from my abode was so exhilarating! of course i have to give it a try asap and my first impression was, "my! what a small shop front they have." their cashier counter was basically 3 steps away from the automatic glass door. the lady at the counter must have known it's not that easy to be staring at a steep menu board for long so she very quickly offered me the paper menu. I chose the spicy grilled steak with regular rice and a side of gucamole. she asked if i wanted sour cream. not being too keen about it, i replied, "just a little." she said, "sorry, we don't do just a little...it's additional 50 cents." that's when the first wave of missing Chipotle came crashing over me. i already accepted the fact I had to pay additional $2 for my guac and also they don't have corn as an ingredient in the bowl so I didn't think I want to splurge anymore for my $13 meal. Quickly i ended my order before i could do anything else stupid like ordering an additional side of churros with chocolate dip. My order was ready in less than 5 minutes and i was happy to find that they offer chipotle medium hot sauce at the condiment table; there were also sliced Jalapeño and diced red onion plus 2 other kind of sauces. It was a good 30 minutes before i could eat and the bowl stayed pretty warm in the eco friendly to-go container. Another nice touch was the melted cheese on the rice but the real saving grace was the hot sauce I picked up on the way out. the sauce really gave the other wise regular tasting bowl its kick. if you like black beans then you will be happy to know they are very generous with their beans. i ran out of rice faster than i could eat the beans. By now i am completely missing Chipotle like crazy.Thanks Guzman and Gomez for offering me a decent bowl of mexican food. it doesn't completely satisfy me but I am glad you are in my life for now.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: I was excited with this place opened near me. I've tried them in Perth, Australia and really liked it there.Maybe it's opening pains, but it's just not the same. The ingredients aren't super fresh, and the meats were a little too salty.Those with kids beware - smoke from the nearby smokers' hangout will permeate into the al fresco dining area.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #01-32, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Guzman Y Gomez finally opens for business, in the west side of Singapore.During the opening, they gave out free burritos for an afternoon with a live mariachi band playing. The line was extremely long but moved rather quickly, I got my burrito in 20 minutes.It's similar to Chipotle, fast food tex-mexy type burritos and tacos. It's okay not mindblowing, but the good part is that they're consistent. (extra star for that) It's good now that they are in a convenient location outside the central business district (CBD).3-stars. Overall consistency and that free burrito bribed me into giving another 1-star.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #B1-45/46, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Cantonese place with multiple branches in Singapore. Part of the Paradise Group restaurants so you can expect their standard quality. Overall, a solid experience if you crave dim sum, typical Cantonese dishes (e.g. sweet and sour pork, stir-fried green beans, etc.) but nothing mind-blowing. A safe bet at a reasonable price.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #B1-45/46, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: I've always been a fan of canton paradise at AMK hub till it closed. This outlet (obviously) serves the same stuff, but the quality really differs. The fried prawn wrapped in bean curd skin used to be much better with the beancurd skin distinctly seen and tasted. In comparison, the dish now almost fails to differentiate itself from prawns fried in dough. The chicken feet in bean sauce also failed to pack a punch, leaving a somewhat unfresh taste in the mouth. The fried yam balls were oily and did not impress with it's mediocre filling, unlike it's previously fragrant ones. The fried bqq pork buns looked similar to that of Tim Ho Wan's, but failed at first bite when it was not crispy. The congee also tasted rather bland, like plain congee cooked separately from the ingredients, rather than their previously flavourful congees. The har gau (prawn dumpling) and siew Mai were average. Notjong impressive, but I wouldn't mind dropping by if I'm nearby especially on a weekday where there's 50% off!

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #B1-45/46, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Nothing much to write about here.  The friendly folks at Yelp HQ have made rating a brainstem function.  Canton Paradise is indeed A-Ok.There's only one thing here that's really worth trying, The crispy roast pork bun, menu item A1.  It's a play on the Hong Kong classic, Po Lo Char Siew Pau. It really is good and worth your time and effort.  The hoary exterior of this creature is a rapidly crumbling crust that melts away to reveal the light and almost barely imperceptible skin of gossamer dough, just enough of a physical presence to structurally contain the sweet, savoury offering of fatty char siew, flavoured just this side of heavenly and a hair shy of naughty, the sauce redolent of pork fat.  It's good and it shows because they always run quick and early.The roast meats are nothing short of mediocre. Very uninteresting. In my very humble opinion, I had a much better roast duck and roast pork at the Grand Park City Hall Chinese restaurant, Park Palace.  The Pork Belly Char Siew looked so promising and I've included a photo to prove it.  The meat was resistant and the fat had not been rendered, which left it rubbery.  The sauce was nice enough, but not enough to hide the fact that this nice hunk of pork had been ruined.  Shame.My default place for a respectable utility Cantonese meal remains Crystal Jade.  For a good quality meal no place beats Hua Ting.Canton Paradise is just a-ok.  It really is.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #B1-45/46, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Food is very similar to what you can find in Crystal Jade.We had wanton mee which had QQ noodles and the sauce is nice. The char siew is not bad, I prefered their wanton.My friend ordered this deep fried brinjal slices with pork floss. It sounds a little funny but it tastes amazing! Star of the meal!If not for the Groupon voucher, I may not have eaten at Canton Paradise in the first place. It was a pleasure dining experience.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #B1-45/46, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: This one of the few places that actually serves dim sum during dinner time. They do have a pretty rare item, which is the Liu Sha Bao, which most places only serve during lunch.I ordered Xiao Long Bao, Liu sha Bao, Chao Shou (wantons), braised beef noodles and Chee Cheong Fun. The prices are a little on the high side, but hey, they are a restaurant afterall.The food is above average on the whole but I must say the highlight for me was the braised beef noodles. The beef was tender and the tendon managed to get the flavors from the sauce nicely. The noodles was pretty QQ (bouncy) and chewy which is good. The broth, however to my disappointment was warm rather than hot, otherwise it would have been near perfect for me.I did notice their roast peking duck, but considering the price is 65/duck, I would rather go for London Fat Duck, unless it is really that wonderful.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #B1-45/46, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Been coming here for over a year,good service, authentic tasting Cantonese/ Hong Kong dishes and Dim Sum. The roast duck and chicken are highly recommended

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #B1-45/46, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Canton Paradise is just like any paradise or crystal jade dim sim chain you've been to. Pleasant decor, great for big groups, good service. The quality of the food is about the same. Not too shabby, but nothing that's super good. The char siew polo bun is obviously a mimic of the tim ho wan one, but is half as good. Still pretty good though. In general, if you are planning a big group outing and dim sum sounds good to you, this is not a bad choice. Just go early on Fridays for lunch, because there is usually a crowd.

address: 9 North Bouna Vista Dr #01-06/07 Singapore 138588 Singapore
comment: Casual Japanese izakaya that serves reasonable bentos for lunch and ala carte menu, happy hour and live music at night. Food is decent for the price points and there's lots of variety for different taste buds. I love the grilled ika, bara chirashi, the rice bowls are hearty and for sharing, the beef tataki with garlic chips, char siu with leeks etc.

address: 9 North Bouna Vista Dr #01-06/07 Singapore 138588 Singapore
comment: Went there for dinner with friends. Ordered some sake, an appetizer shishamo and a bara chirashi don. Sake and bara chirashi don arrives but no appetizer in sight. An hour later I ask the staff. Staff tells me it was sent to another table and that there was nothing he could do. Tells me again he would charge the other table for it and order me a new one which I would still have to pay for. I tell him no, it should be free since: 1.) He delivered my order to another table which is his mistake in the first place2.) It's already been an hour3.) Makes no sense to charge customers to pay for your mistakes. He says no still will have to charge me. So I just canceled my order and left.Don't ever go to Ikki ever again if you do not like having your ordered food sent to someone else and still get charge for it.

address: 9 North Bouna Vista Dr #01-06/07 Singapore 138588 Singapore
comment: Spots always busy after work. Went two years back and had amazing food. Stopped by for lunch the other day and wasn't the same. Still a great after work HH either way

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way #B1-03 Connexxis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: Consistent quality, friendly people and value for money.This is the best place for breakfast at Fusion.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way #B1-03 Connexxis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: Horrible coffee! Its from an automatic machine dispenser. I ordered a flat white. Watery and tastless.!

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way #B1-03 Connexxis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: All their food is TRANSFAT FREEEEEEE!!Okay, that probably didn't excite you as much as if I were to say that all their food is free, but you know, it's time to start caring for your arteries, especially if you're already past 25, like me. SIGH.Anyways, their food is delicious. Their artisan bread - meaning bread made without preservatives, is baked daily. Their sandwiches are thick and full, and are chomp-chomps tasty. If you're bored of the same-taste-every-way Subway, Hungrywich will offer you tasty freshness with more flavours.I recommend the Teriyaki chicken sandwich and the Ham & eggs sandwich. There's this Pizzawich too, that contains mozzarella cheese OM NOMS NOMS.If you work in that area, ring me up for breakfast, kidding. You MUST try the NUTELLA BANANA toasties, it will definitely make you forget all about work and countdown all the way to lunch. They also serve not-bad muffins (Winter Cherry's my fav) and not-bad coffee (DAT emergency double espresso).

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way #B1-03 Connexxis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: I love a good sandwich but I hate when they have set sandwiches and the menu doesn't tell you exactly what's in it. I ordered some turkey sandwich and the menu didn't mention anything about it being doused in honey mustard. Needless, to say I couldn't eat it. The concept is great, and the sandwich was good but I would prefer if they had a more detailed menu.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way #B1-03 Connexxis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: Toasted sandwiches where the ingredients are just right. I like their tuna sandwiches because there's not too much mayonnaise.  But...they don't give free water (they insist on you buying bottled water), and their chips are pretty expensive. They really get you on the sides and upgrading to the set meal.  Don't get me wrong, sandwiches are great. They also have biscuits which taste exactly like American home cooking. Those are buttery and can fill you up if your sandwich is not enough.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way #B1-03 Connexxis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: I recently walked by the new Hungry Wich's - 2 stores wide, brightly lit, garish and soulless flat screens showing the menu, and it no longer looks or feels the same. The neon red/pink fibre optic rotating muffin light that remained was the only comforting sight. Of course, given the expansion and new fancy equipment, everything has gone up in price. I haven't yet tried the food, so I don't know how good that is yet. But I don't think I'll try anytime soon. I'm still overcoming the grief of losing the old Hungry Wich's. Call me melodramatic, but I liked it the way it was.

address: 44 Jalan Merah Saga #01-56 Chip Bee Gardens Singapore 278116 Singapore
comment: Pretty good bakery with a variety of artisan bread selection.The croissant sandwiches here are quite good (though a bit pricey) as well.

address: 44 Jalan Merah Saga #01-56 Chip Bee Gardens Singapore 278116 Singapore
comment: Located in Dempsey this place is a bakery cum cafe. Their specialty is sourdough bread and they have a wide array of freshly baked goods on display. We tried their sourdough and soy bread which had a nice nutty flavor that went well with the sourdough taste. We also tried some meringue cookies which were average. I would definitely go back to try more of their breads.

Ambience - 4 starsNice booths and window seating.Unagi, egg and cucumber maki ($7++) - 1 starRice was mushy as with the soft shell crab maki.Soft shell crab maki ($7++) - 1 starThe crab wasn't deep fried well and the batter was soft rather than crispy. The rice was poor quality and not flavorful.Curry chicken udon - 1 starFew ingredients and the curry was bland.Overall, very unimpressed with the quality of food especially since a lot of my friends rave about the food here. I'd only go for the ambience - we stayed around and played a board game over lunch. They weren't crowded on a Sunday afternoon. It was about $35 in total.

This space appears much bigger compared to its old location at the windmill in Holland Village. The service crew is efficient and the food served is of good standard.Basically the enjoyable sushi tei experience as always. Will definitely return for more!

address: 73A Ayer Rajah Cresent #01-06, Timbre+ Singapore 139957 Singapore
comment: Tried the beef brisket spinach noodle ($5.50) today. What previous reviewers have said, plus another note. The stall now features a ridiculously addictive green chilli + lemon sambal sauce that goes GREAT with spinach noodles! This, to me, is the differentiating factor. What the previous review said about the long waiting time was not true for me. There were O(10) people in front of me and I waited in line for less than 20 minutes. (I certainly did NOT have to wait for 50 min!) Anyway, those 20 min went by in a flash because of Timbre+ free wifi.Summary: Oodles of green noodles (note: slightly salty) + flavorful, tender beef brisket + zesty kick from the chili = fantastic fare for the flavor fan! I'll be back for the wonton noodles!

address: 73A Ayer Rajah Cresent #01-06, Timbre+ Singapore 139957 Singapore
comment: For a quiet afternoon, the stall packed quite a long queue. Maybe because it was one of the cheapest stall around.Char Siew Dumpling Tomato Noodle 水饺番茄面 (S$5.50)Available at @WongKeeWantonNoodle stall in Timbre+ by @TimbreMusicFirst taste felt that the noodle was overpowered by the sour tomato 's taste. I was not a fan of tomato and was a tab put off by its taste at first. It took sometime to get used to it. The dumplings were large and chunky, packed with lots of liao.

address: 73A Ayer Rajah Cresent #01-06, Timbre+ Singapore 139957 Singapore
comment: After walking 6 rounds in Timbre+, I finally found a seat right along the passage ways of Wong Kee Wanton Noodle Queue. The seat was not really ideal as anyone who walks pass by will either rub against or hit my back.Apparently, this is one of the longest queues we have seen. We joined the long queue with about 10 pax ahead of us and I literally calculated that it took them about 5 minutes to serve a customer.Spinach Noodle with beef brisket is one of their signatures served in slightly green flat noodles. They were smooth but didn't have much of spinach flavour as usual when compared to the usual standard ones we had outside. Though the beef brisket was succulent and braised to its softness, I could not enjoy much as I felt that it was rather gamey.Beef Brisket Spinach Noodle with - $5.50Tomato noodle? What's that? Beats me as I have never seen anything like this before but this is also one of the popular dishes ordered by patrons who walked pass me. The fried and boiled wantons were placed together on the plate as the stall had ran out of soup. Instead of tossing the noodles with the usual sauces, they were replaced by tomato with common wantons mee ingredients like char siew and vegetables. Talking about that, beside having noodles already processed with tomato flavours, the sauce comes with the real tomato. The noodles, as a whole were a little dry and too tangy for my liking, also I find them quite salty.Tomato Noodle Wanton Mee - $4.50Since Timbre+ is still in its novelty stage and with news media advertising, the crowd coming in was literally non-stop. Finding of seating can be a frustration, as a whole, with such a scotching weather, the place not only needs more coolers but also requires more ventilation.

address: 73A Ayer Rajah Cresent #01-06, Timbre+ Singapore 139957 Singapore
comment: Yum! This place is popular at lunchtime, and I waited in line for about 10-15 minutes at noon on a weekday. I had the beef brisket with spinach noodles. Added dumplings for $1, but not really necessary -- the plate was plenty big by itself. The beef brisket was flavorful and plentiful. Noodle quantity very generous. Good value, good flavor, good price. What not to like?  You wouldn't go out of your way for this place, but if you want good solid food at a good price, this will satisfy your tummy.

Set in the electric Holland Village, Cha Cha Cha served up some very good Mexican food. The nachos were well done and crispy and the accompanying serving of veggies was large and wholesome. Great margaritas too.

Good location. Outdoor seating only with a few mosquitos under the table. Wasnt really authentic. Very tex-mex.The chimichanga was okay. The churros were okay but had way too much cinnamon sugar that should've been dusted off at least. Otherwise everything was just ok.Great to take friends and have a few drinks for happy hour.Service was not bad. Two were good. But another was sick, and another had strong B.O.
I really like mexican food, and its a treat to eat great mexican food. This is not a good food experience unfortunately.

So happy to see this place still here after all these years. Still the most fun TexMex place to go to in Singapore. And some say Asia too. Try the chimichangas, better than the rare few I had whilst living in the States. Found out there from a Mexican that the dish was from the south, and so not so often found in Californian joints, except the rare ones. And so of the rare ones I found, the Cha Cha Cha one is still better. Lighter flour used for the deep fried taco, having the nice deep fried flavor without the heaviness of the oil. And being able to taste the marinated beef inside with the salsa and gauc on top. Asianized Mexican food.  Mmmmm.

Yeaaaaaaaah! The service was really good. The waiters were all really helpful and patient even though we stayed for quite awhile. The food is A+ but it was kinda expensive..but then again there aren't many Mexican food places in Singapore so I guess it was reasonable. Will deffo visit again! ^^

The worst mexican food i've had thus far. Funny how the reviews claimed this is the best mexican restaurant in singapore. The taco is flavorless, the fajita, same thing. The nachos are very boring.. They just put a lot of cheese for flavor. And it's not even mexican cheese!! Everything they serve look store bought.. Probably purchased from cold storage down the street. 61$. Should have spent our $ at the hawker center down the street. What a total waste...

I gave this joint a 5 star eventhough its not one of the best mexican food i have tasted...but Cha Cha Cha is still one of the best Mexican restaurant in Singapore. I have been here too many times whenever i get a craving for mexican food and their guacamole, buritos and shredded beef tacos still hits the sweet spot. Compared to most Mexican places in Asia, Cha cha cha uses corn for their tacos and i think this really makes a difference, and some dishes like their soup and beef really taste like what i have sampled in the Coyoacan market in Mexico city.This restaurant will probably be rated as a 3 star joint if it were in the states or in Mexico....but in Singapore, its still one of the best mexican places to eat. I would recommend their shredded beef as its the most authentic tasting item on the menu.

Came here around 9 PM on a Tuesday night and found the restaurant to be surprisingly busy. This was my first time to the Holland Village area and it seemed to be buzzing, in general, and this restaurant was no different. There are tons of restaurants to choose from in the area but I was dying for Mexican food, and this seemed like the only spot in the area. The restaurant is like most others in the little thoroughfare in that it is completely open to the street. We were seated rather quickly and handed menus. The menu contains all of the tex-mex staples I was hoping for, including nachos, burritos, fajitas, and enchiladas. I ended up ordering a chimichanga and we got the chicken nachos for a starter. We also ordered a couple of jumbo margaritas. The nachos came out first and they were pleasant enough but pretty plain. They were just tortilla chips with melted cheese, shredded chicken and a few pickled jalapenos thrown on top. Then we got our margaritas, which had a really peculiar texture. I'm used to frozen margaritas having a slushy texture but these were rather thick and smoothie-like. They were really sweet and didn't have much of a tequila kick to them, unfortunately. Our mains came out and my partner and I exchanged surprised looks. I guess I'm used to TexMex places including rice and beans with the entrees automatically, but these mains were simply the dish itself... which we didn't expect. My plate had a card deck-sized chimichanga on a bed of shredded iceberg lettuce-that's it. The chimichanga was alright- definitely freshly cooked but woefully understuffed and underseasoned. There was barely any meat inside (mostly cheese and beans). It was pretty poor value for the price, honestly. With the nachos, it was enough food but after spending $100+, I would have expected a more satisfying meal. Service was pretty scant after we were seated. It took us a while to get our orders in. Though to be fair it seemed like the restaurant was definitely understaffed for how busy it was.

Meh with a capital M.The menu contained the usual (texmex) suspects: tacos, enchiladas, burritos, fajitas. I went for a "combinados" plate of enchilada + taco. The filling was dry, and so was the tortilla. Unfortunately, the flavors were not there. I wondered why there were two Mexican places right next to each other in Holland Village. Then I heard that a former partner of El Felipe's (Now El Patio) left and started Cha Cha Cha.Perhaps my prior experience living 30 mins from the border afforded me an amazing choice of Mexican food joints that simply couldn't compare to the standard of Mexican food in Singapore.It may be one of Singapore's oldest Mexican resturants, but it definitely isn't the best and had seen better days. Sorry, but I'm not impressed. I'm told that El Felipe's isn't much better either...

The food here is fine. One of the rare places in Holland Village (or probably all of Singapore) that you'll find that the population is majority expats. As an expat myself, I was badly craving Mexican cuisine one night and stumbled upon this place in a daze. The waiter was decent and seated us quickly.I ordered a chicken burrito, which was quite expensive (I have been spoiled by street food pricing.) The quality was all right. The only reason I'd come here again is if I'm in Holland Village, having a great time at Wala Wala, and realize that I desperately need a change from Southeast Asian food.

The worst mexican food i've had thus far. Funny how the reviews claimed this is the best mexican restaurant in singapore. The taco is flavorless, the fajita, same thing. The nachos are very boring.. They just put a lot of cheese for flavor. And it's not even mexican cheese!! Everything they serve look store bought.. Probably purchased from cold storage down the street. 61$. Should have spent our $ at the hawker center down the street. What a total waste...
Excellent.  Been coming here twenty years.  Crispy corn chips, cold beer.  Nice location.Best shrimp fajitas in the world, I think.
I really like mexican food, and its a treat to eat great mexican food. This is not a good food experience unfortunately.

I've walked past this place for YEARS (no seriously, I think this place has been here since the late late 90s) but never tried it. I'm not really into Mexican generally, but the date suggested Mexican, and I don't -mind- it, so why not!It was pleasantly surprising. Service was pretty friendly, quite prompt, and the food was above expectations. The guacamole with corn chips was alright. It wasn't a bad guac by any means, and it was definitely a generous serving of chips, but definitely not amazing memorable wow.My main though was wow. The fluetas (not sure if i spelled that right), which is a deep fried flour wrap stuffed with your choice of meat (I chose shredded chicken) and then served topped with sour cream, more guac, and cheese. Wow. Crispy, flavourful, and surprisingly filling, I was stuck with a craving for more the day after just based on the memory of it.My date ordered the combo, which comes with a three items (I honestly forgot what the three items were... there was a taco (soft or hard, your choice), maybe a tortilla, and something else) but it was good. Generously sized, and served with refried beans. I love refried beans, and theirs tasted as beans generally do (I've never tried Mexican or Tex-mex overseas, so I can't tell if it's how they SHOULD taste...) and overall I felt it was good value considering the price.They also let us linger and talk for quite a while, we were the last to leave and they never tried to chase us off or even hinted that we should leave. I love it when a restaurant's okay with that, and after a while we realised we were the last patrons and left with guilty grins. It's a good place. Humble I think, and not amazing, but I liked the service, I liked the food, and I'd recommend it to friends without any hesitation. That's four stars in my book!

The restaurant is brightly coloured, with warm lighting and checkered-tiled tables adding to the lively ambience. It might look a little shabby from the outside, but cast your prejudices away and you'll be in for a treat.We ordered a mango margarita for drinks, and were hardly disappointed when it arrived, threatening to overflow with mango goodness. The bowl of nachos was pretty good, but the salsa dip was average and nothing to shout about (you might want to order the nachos as mains). As for the entrees, I must commend the chef for whipping up such a potent and delicious bowl of Chilli con Carne. The jalapeno peppers packed a real punch! The soft taco was rather mild, which would appeal to those who love Mexican food but prefer a lighter touch with respect to the spices used. The portions were generous and the food was certainly of great comfort. Service was efficient. Even though we paid about $15-20 per person, we had a positive experience there and felt it was worth every dollar.

Respectfully disagreeing with the prior to posts, but this place is not worth of 4.5 stars. I mean, 4.5/5 is like, an A+ student in school right? Maybe I'm a Mexican food snob, but while passable, this is a far flung cry from real Mexican food. OK, so maybe we're in Singapore so being on the opposite side of the world I need to adjust my expectations, but I'm a man of principle. The food is passable not nothing special (hence the A-OK rating). The sauces in the fajitas or burritos aren't especially tasty, the chips are "meh", and the guac is so-so. And it's expensive to boot (well, for Singapore I guess it's average, but I'm used to cheap Mexican food). Service is a bit slow, but the location is nice enough that you can just hang out with some friends and chatting over some drinks while people watching. If you're seriously craving a Mexican fix and you're in the area, sure, go for it.

agreeable tex-mexican at this open-air restaurant in holland village. I don't have much experience with south american or mexican food - and tex-mex is probably the closest I've been (since this year).it was a reticence set off by a traumatic carbplosion of an experience with my first ever burrito: beans and rice and guac and not much meat enveloped in a thick shroud of a tortilla - nothing I cared for a repeat of. so - I came with low expectations, and while I'm pretty darn sure the food here isn't anything fantastic, it went down easily enough.it's a rustic cuisine - bright and fresh and pretty wholesome, even if the carbtravaganza bit of it still holds true. my timid-embrace-a-new-cuisine solution: (mostly) skip the carb, and get at the protein.the corn chips were pedestrian, though that salsa was something spicy, and hence addictive. the menu is split between enchiladas and burritos, quesadillas and tacos - and really, it's the best real-life application of permutation and combination I've seen in life: the trinity of rice, tortilla and meat combined in a ludicrous number or ways.the churros were possibly the best part of the meal. fresh-fried, still soft but with a good crust, these were topped with cinnamon sugar alongside ice-cream. I'm not sure what it says about me that I much prefer those rotating crullers you see on sale at american fairs and theme parks.places like this are the bane of a food review: they have passably good food - sufficient for a mild hey-check-this-place-out-if-you're-there recommendation, but nothing to render any enthusiasm or aggravation over; service is a little haphazardly absent, but helpful enough when you get it; and the place is done up open-air and without air-conditioning, pleasant enough for a bit of a loiter.my friend says it's "like fast food mexican" - and I concur. it incites just about the same level of enthusiasm those joints would - sufficiently reliable enough for a quick meal, but nothing quite enough to shout about.

When I first moved here from LA over 3 years ago I was starving for good mexican food.  There just wasnt much here.  Thankfully over the years more and more places have sprung up.  I think since more places have opened it really shows that this place just really isnt all that great. I mean if you want "mexican" food then sure. They have the usual stuff.  I just felt it tasted a little bland and never really stuck with me that much.  I never really wanted to come back here for mexican.  The service is average, the food is average and not very spicy and I just never really fell in love with it. The fact that they dont have free chips and salsa just killed it for me.  Then at least you have a reason to come here and drink. You can go next door for that so whats the point.

Not the best quality street food for ridiculous amount of money. Most of it is not even Mexican, usually a tex-mex, when you try to ask about a Mexican dish they stare at you with a blank face but it is a problem in Singapore in general, not just in this place. And I will probably never get used to the fact that they don't bring you chips with salsa first, or you have to pay for it.

Given that this is Singapore, which compared to the US means don't expect it to be cheap or have large portions, this is a respectable Mexican restaurant. The rice, beans, margaritas, chicken enchilada, and shrimp tacos were all good. You can tell that they are trying and paying attention to detail.

A Mexican in SIngapore? Do not expect high class cuisine, but a no-nonsense TexMex on a no-traffic street in Holland Village - a bustling eating area. The chicken chipotle was OK and so were the prawn fajitas. The jalapenos were from a can, but hey, who knows even avocadoes in Singapore? White wine was quite good. Service OK, prices on the high side for the quality offered. So come here rather for the atmosphere and the exotic touch..

This place feels like a Mexican restaurant should feel: not too fancy, open air, and in a festive area.  The frozen margarita had ample tequila, somewhat surprising for Singapore.  Finally, the service was outstandingly attentive without being overbearing; it was almost like being back in the US.On the negative side, neither my wife's chalupa nor my burrito really resembled anything you would find at a Mexican restaurant across the Pacific.  Additionally, the elapsed time from the second we finished giving our orders until the time the food ended up on our table could not have been more than five minutes.  I'm not saying the food was all premade, but it was either that or microwaved, or both.  That being said, it still tasted halfway decent.If you're searching for the best Mexican restaurant in Singapore, you won't find it here.  If you're searching for a decent spot to have a Margarita and chill, it hits the spot.  I almost gave it stars, but the location and atmosphere does really provide that laid back vibe.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: While the seating isn't the greatest, the coffee is outstanding and the food is delicious. Grab a table and place your order at the counter when you're ready. Eggs & toast was SG$10 which seemed reasonable (for the area). The avocado toast was an absolute mountain of avocado!I really loved my latte (for the first time in Singapore) - finally one that wasn't overly bitter. Melbourne folks continue to meet the stereotype of being coffee experts. We also had a vanilla-Nutella milkshake. I was a little surprised that it was watery like milk (instead of thick like american shakes) but it was still super tasty!Free wifi - just ask for the code.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Located at the ground of a block of private housing is this tiny cafe. The dine in area was limited. Menu was a simple clip board, some sliced cakes on the display shelf. Although it was air-con indoor, we could barely feel the air-con, so we did try to adjust the standing fan next to us.MochaThe drink was quite rich and thick, but not enough coffee taste.Carrot cakeQuite a huge silce but I would prefer it to be more moist.Dom Pedro ($18)Fresh Milk, Vanilla Ice-Cream + Black Nikka WhiskyIt looked just like another plain vanilla milkshake. In just a single taste, I could feel the heat of the alcohol down my throat. Feeling high fast. It was rather strong drink to have.Overall the drinks were great. But in the warm dine in area, one tended to feel sleepy easily.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Cute little cafe hidden away in bouna vista's industrial area. Chill ambiance and a quite little book corner gives you the perfect chill. Yummy pork hash and great all day breakfast!!

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Great coffee and good quality food. Deducting one star for the location  (quite a walk from the nearest mrt station) and one star for the price (you leave wondering if you really got what you paid for). Definitely not a place you'll pass by unless you make an intentional effort to visit it. May or may not come back

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Walked in greeted and felt welcome. Menu changed a little from some of the postings.  The eggs were great and service was fast.   I wish I had know about this place the food so much better than the hotel

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: A quaint place with a really interesting design.Perfect for a catch-up with buddies over a cup of coffee instead of hustling in town.There were books in the bathroom and a rubix cube too. HAHA

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Cool, little nook with compact seating, 9 tables and 2 benches. Industrial, 3 levels exposed which must be helping to absorb all the sound. A plus in my book compared to other places that look über cool, but once seated is a cacophony, reveberated in a too enclosed space. Becomes quite a hub of activity on a sunday morning. A mix of residences nearby, young families, partners for brunch. If u need only the caffeine fix, JM Too is across the pathway and have the new Slayers. On to the food. Simple menu, doesn't offer everything under the Suns. The small things make a difference. Like mesclun salad over iceberg lettuce, ripe avacados, fresh ciabatta. Price point are on the higher side, but I'm finding that across the island these days. Portions are ample and generous. Quality and freshness on the ingredients. You don't get a 'that's it!?' reaction when the plate is served. And lastly the coffee never misses. Very much recommended.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Jimmy Monkey came highly recommended for its coffee and that was the main reason behind my visit to this off location. The space sort of screams hipster in name, design and look of the staff. That is not necessarily a bad thing as it often can deliver some good food and beverages.The coffee was pretty good and clearly better than any random place but still not really impressive wither. If it would have been around the corner I could have visited again but not at all worth traveling this far for. Also had a decent brekkie muffin and a pasta with mushrooms. Not bad but also a bit overpriced.What was however a pleasant surprise was that the staff were friendly and helpful. Service was also smooth and fast despite the place being packed.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: If you're after some Melbourne style coffee and food, then this is the place for you. It can get fairly busy during lunch time on the weekends though.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: I've been here a few times since I discovered Jimmy Monkey. Each time for breakfast on the weekend. Grab a menu and order at the counter, then the wait staff will bring out the food. The coffee is excellent, and I love the vibe of the place. The staff is friendly and attentive. Yes, the food is a little price-y, but not too far out of range for this kind of place. My favorite so far is the hash. Just a little bit of spice and just satisfying enough for brunch.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: I googled for free-wifi AND power plugs and found this place. What's lovely about it is you can manage to comfortably get lounge seats on a weekend evening. And there's no queue, not much of a crowd throughout the night. Yes, it's QUIET. A rare gem I would say.I also really admire the fact I could drink coffee, look up and there you are, a TOILET BOWL complete with toilet paper right above my head. It's so randomly ridiculous yet genius that I LURVE IT. I even took a picture of it, go see.I ordered the banana bread pudding, - $14, and coffee. The presentation of the bread pudding was very cute, it came in a pot, on a wooden slab. Coffee was better than most cafes I've been to, and service was... Let's just say that they let you do your own thing, and they do theirs, and if both lines should intersect, colourful unicorns will bloom. Pricing is on the high side.One thing that made me feel like getting up to leave, was the glaring red neon lighting fixture, that engulfed me and my companion. It reminded me of an episode in Seinfeld (who else still watches this?!) where Kramer's entire room emitted a red glow because Kenny Rogers moved opposite his room and their crazy signboard faced his window.Check out eatlikeawhale.blogspot.sg for more pictures and reviews.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: I'll just get this out of the way first. I'm probably one of five people in the world that doesn't drink coffee. I know how to grind beans and make coffee in a french press for my mum, I love the smell of coffee brewing and when it pops up in savory food and sweets...but I just hate the taste of coffee as a drink. No matter how much milk, sugar, nothing, best beans, kona beans, any beans, my man has tried to get me to drink it and the most I've tolerated is 2 sips. The one time I drank a caramel latte in Japan because I totally misread the menu, it was really sweet and suddenly I was talking non-stop for an hour. Since this IS a coffee joint, my dude has his two cents in this review. He had a decaf black and in his words "it's wonderful. very smooth". So there.Now on to the food. We're really brunch people so we were looking for food more than coffee. When I say I'm a brunch person it's not because I like to dress up to eat a meal I can cook at home. I'm actually a hungry person, I like brunch foods and someone always wakes up too late to fire up the pan. Anyway, we had the french toast and a breakfast sandwich (can't remember the exact name) and both were pretty good.  My french toast was made of 3 thick slices of brioche sliced up, drizzled with a caramel sauce with bananas and nuts drizzled over. It was beautiful to see and a hearty portion for my rumbling tummy. Here's the problem: the egg wash wasn't soaked through the bread. Whhhhhhhhy? It would've been perfect otherwise. If there's a monkey jimmy listening - please soak the toast, turn the heat low and cook that baby.The breakfast sandwich was a standout. A generous, fluffy omelet sandwiched between avocado slices, ciabatta and a sweet-ish tomato chutney. It was brilliant, huge and I would eat it again. And again. So that's a winner right there.What didn't I like? The guys on shift probably partied until 4am and decided to bring their music to work. Bad trance music in a coffee shop is just wrong. Especially at 2pm on a Saturday. That gave me a headache and I shouldn't be getting one at a place where there's a toilet bowl watching me eat.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: At this point, I'm no longer shocked by prices in this part of town. Anywhere in one north is almost exclusively catering for ex-pats and high-income locals. Jimmy Monkey is no different. Egg's Benedict will run you a whopping $24, pancakes are $14, and the french toast is $17.They had run out of pancakes on a Sunday at noon so I went with the french toast, and added on a chocolate, peanut butter, speculoos shake for good measure. This was not a wallet-friendly brunch but I was happily surprised by how tasty everything was. The french toast comes in a healthy serving, and includes berries and crème fraîche. By the end I was actually struggling to finish my serving because everything was so sweet.I wouldn't be opposed to returning but this place is definitely a treat, and not a joint for regular meals. Seating is fairly limited, but somehow sufficient for the number of patrons. It gets a little warm, and the space does feel a little cramped. Nonetheless there are a variety of seating options depending on what you're up to.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: 4-stars only for the coffee.I normally order a flat white or cappuccino here. They have a Slayer(tm) coffee machine and do their shots right.Come here only for the coffee. For dessert, you're better off wandering over to Rochester or Star Vista.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Coffee was good, food was decent. Portions were slightly too small. Service was spotty although staff were sincere.Prices could have been slightly lower, especially given the location.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: This is one of my favorite tucked-away places to go. The coffee is flavorful & beautifully prepared with a delicious little biscotti that I can't get enough of. The food is delicious and uncomplicated. The staff is friendly and unpretentious. The atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming. Free wifi if you need it. Quirky & clever little bits all around to show you that the proprietor & his staff enjoy what they do.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: They neither serve Jimmy nor Monkeys.... But for a quant place to grab a smoothie or cup of coffee and a light bite this might be a good stop.   Tried the pulled pork sandwich on a buttered bun served with potatoes lyonnaise and also tried the tartine called "the hulk" - open face rustic bread sandwich covered in avocado and feta served on a bed of arugula.  The banana-strawberry smoothie was "nice" (says the SPG) and the mocha was delightful!

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Imagine a hipster cafe with above average prices and decidedly average food.Congratulations, you've successfully imagined Jimmy Monkey Cafe & Bar.In all seriousness, I found the food to be decent but not worth raving about or coming back for.  It seemed as though JMC&B was trying to get that Saturday morning breakfast cafe feel, like the ones that you'd find by the beach in California or Hawaii, but they fell a bit short.  If they're going to charge the prices they do, I feel there should be something special that sets them at least a little bit apart, but I didn't think there was anything that special here.Last mark against them is the lack of space.  JMC&B feels very cramped, as we were slotted into what felt like a tiny corner of a wooden shack.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: I love this place for its quaint-ness. Out of the place (a short walk from One North MRT) but convenient if you have a car.Good place to chill out on a weekend afternoon but it might be a bit crowded to get some reading done.Absolutely love the washrooms as it was decorated so beautifully with bookshelves (my absolute dream intention to my own bathroom) with books and cards!

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Espresso - this was a potent, robust and strong shot with a lingering aftertaste, but also a good balance of taste and flavours. This is not surprising - Jimmy Monkey's Ironbark blend is a combination of beans from Brazil (Cerrado), Papua New Guinea (Sigri), Columbia (Kachru), Guatamala (La Laguna) and Peru (Amazonas). There is also a Columbian single origin blend available, which works well in pourover coffee. Each bean variety contributes something unique to the shot - hints of citrus, and even some chocolate notes. Ironbark is a blend that is still evolving, and is now on it's third iteration. The experimentation has paid off, leaving a full bodied shot with a lingering aftertaste.The cappuccino that I ordered was notable for the initial strong hit of coffee flavour, complemented by smooth, light foam and finished with well executed latte art. The microbubbles in the foam add the smooth, silky mouthfeel that I look for, and is seen in quality cafes. This is where Ironbark is used to good effect - the lingering aftertaste is a strong base for a milk based drink, ensuring that the fundamental coffee character is retained.I had a Piccolo also, which is characterised by a more robust coffee taste, with the aftertaste lasting through the milk and foam. The milk complements the robust coffee flavour, smoothing it but not smothering it, creating a hybrid which retains the best characteristics of each - its just right and well executed. Their original place in the piccolo latte hall of fame post is deserved, and retained. There are also pourover, syphon and chemex coffees available. This is a good choice for anyone in the West of the island, and worth a quick trip on the MRT for coffee lovers elsewhere.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Fantastic food, great friendly staff.Coffee, sourdough, bacon, Hemmingway, even the apricot marmalade is perfect. What a great delight for sunday brunch save for it being a little expensive.One customer left 10 bucks behind accidentally and the staff ran out to return it, when he could have pretended its tips and pocketed it. Excellent place!

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: excellent bruschetta. Have had the breaky sandwich a few times before but this was a first. The cold press coffee is also nice.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: I've been hearing a lot about this coffee joint so was happy to finally have time to make it down. It is a rather quirky joint located within one-north residences. I am completely in love with the turquoise shade of its cups so it might've made me a little more biased towards my drinks. Jimmy Monkey serves coffee with a richer and bolder profile so be sure to note that when you get your cup there. I haven't gotten round to trying their food menu but it features some pastas and other mains which did look delish enough. My friend enjoyed her aglio olio. Plus, I really liked the open kitchen concept which makes the experience more wholesome, almost like stepping into the kitchen of a friend's home.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: I am writing about Jimmy Monkey Cafe & Bar as I'm still in here, sipping on my flat white and enjoying a brilliant slice of yolkless cheesecake. It is one of those hidden places in the uncharted territory of one-north. To be honest, it isn't that difficult to find and is merely a 7 minute walk from one-north MRT station if you take the right exit (exit B). The service is great and the staff are really friendly and helpful, offering me recommendations of their foods and drinks as I stared at the menu. There is also free wifi, and being hidden away from the crowd it makes a good quiet place for getting some work done on a weekday afternoon. The place has a homely, yet pretty rough industrial vibe. I can't really place it but its a gruff kind of cool. They do a good cup of flat white and the coffee has a bold full-bodied flavour that is pretty satisfying. I had a go at their new introduction to the menu, the yolkless cheesecake, and have to say that it was so goooood! It was rich without being heavy, it is almost like having the best of both worlds. Other than the fact that the place smells of fried food as they have an open concept kitchen, it is a pretty ideal cafe find!

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Checked out Jimmy Monkey Cafe and struck it off my cafe list. Finally! With it being at One-North, its really kinda difficult to get to, but actually it was quite convenient via the Circle Line and it is actually just one stop away from Holland Village! Heard some good things about this place, but was also warned that it gets really stuffy and smelly inside because they cook food inside without proper ventilation! So I approached the door with trepidation, because I really don't like greasy smells on me after I leave a food place.Luckily that didn't happen! It was actually quite empty, with a few patrons, perhaps that's why there was not much cooking. The aircon perched on the high ceiling was on a full blast.I was taking photos of the place upon walking in when the chefs and barista gamely posed for a photo (w/o me asking!). That's so cute, and funny. The cafe has a little bit of an abandoned warehouse industrial feel, yet they made it rather New York lofty as well. The decor is casual but comfortable.I was expecting a much smaller place as well, but the size was actually quite spacious with very high ceilings.Prices are ok! $4-6 for coffees, and they have alcoholic drinks too. They also do the Lazy Weekend menu. Looks quite awesome, might have to go back and try! What I hear is that they roast and sell their own coffees. Perhaps I was lucky, but the cafe was a very good experience for me. Venture forth with the warning on the smell, and hope you enjoy it as much as I do!

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: The JFDI cafe at Blk 71, Ayer Rajar Crescent, has longer been servin' up their wonderful coffees made with Jimmy Monkey's beans! Initially, I thought "Jimmy Monkey" was a supplier of coffee beans. To my surprise they are a cafe which roast their own beans (and hence name it after themselves)! A very hipster one in fact! My friend brought me there after lunch to grab a Soya latte which I was skeptical about at first. My prejudice against Soya lattes stems from the fact that their drinkers are commonly stereotyped as dieters. Refusing to be labelled as one of them, I have abstained from ordering a Soya latte... until today. My friend was raving about their Soya latte so much - how light & nutty it was... etc - that I knew I had to give it a try (at least just this once). Anyways, it was a quick-in-&-out dash not long enough for any snooty purist coffee drinker to give me the stink eye for ordering a Soya latte. So I did it. To my surprise... the Soya latte was really GOOD... even better than normal latte! I am a convert. It had a nice nutty flavor (just as my friend promised) and doesn't taste like the sweet stuff you get from Mr.Bean or at soybean packet drinks from NTUC. The Soya milk didn't overpower the coffee flavor. In fact, it tasted a lot like milk ... only less creamy (which I prefer) ... & thus help enhance the coffee ( I think). I was pleasantly surprised. The brand of Soya milk they used is called - Silk - which I am told is one of the best. Can't wait to grab a pack at the nearest cold storage on my way home.My next coffee will definitely be a Soya Latte!

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: The little brown monkey sits above you watching you enjoy your meal only leads you to wonder if he is envious of the food or merely just a guardian for the space. Whatever the case is, I hope he is envious. For the food and coffee is always excellent. For it's location, they have the concept right. A bit of fusion but casual substantial food. I really enjoy their couscous salad and homemade dips. Steak sandwich is juice and delicious as well. The coffee has always been consistently great. I trust the baristas and kitchen staffs are passionate with their food and coffee. They are always friendly and outspoken. So feel free to have a casual chat with them and feel right at home here.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Coffee is great!Food is bad and overprice. I ordered toast with mashroom and poached egg. One side of the egg tasted sour.Service is bad.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: This hidden gem makes it worthwhile to come hunting in the unknown territories of the new One North neighbourhood just for the coffee alone. I drove here with a friend. Had no idea where to park since the place is situated inside a private condo. Had to just find a space nearby. There is an open air carpark not far if  you're not lazy to walk. I love the industrial look of its interior - high ceilings with random book shelves. It's very open and spacious too. It was very quiet when we came. The staff are mostly made up of a bunch of young boys.We were only there for coffee and dessert because we've had our lunch but looking at the tempting food menu, I'm definitely coming again to try some of their food. I ordered a latte and a cheesecake. The coffee is a good hit of bold flavours. The cheesecake (and most of the desserts) were really pricey (most cost more than $6). For the price, I didn't think it was worth it, I'd rather spend more and get a good meal. But otherwise, we enjoyed just hanging out and reading some magazines, it had a somewhat homely vibe.Final verdict: Whoever Jimmy Monkey is, he'll have me swinging by again for the coffee and tempting food menu!

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: The good: It's not so much that they chose to have an open concept kitchen as it is that they had no choice and really know how to make the most of the space. Literally tiny, this spot feels spacious which leaves the customer feeling cozy and comfortable. Self serve water bottles (nicely done) and the music was decent.  Staff was friendly...in a From Dusk Till Dawn kind of way.  The bad: Every time I find a new brunch place I find myself praying that the food delivers. This time, my prayers were not answered. I ordered the eggs benedict, which we borderline inedible. Had it not been for the fact that I walked around 10 mins trying to find the place and was starving I wouldn't have eaten as much as I did. But, and there is a but, it was a matter of ingredients and not execution. The muffin was grainy and doughy, ham was thick and dry and the hollandaise was sour and sparse. The greens the put on the plate were straight from a salad packet you get at Fair Price.  The egg, surprisingly, was cooked perfectly. The person purchasing the ingredients really needs to step it up because they are ruining an otherwise capable kitchen. The ugly: Too secluded and not tasty enough for a must return. Also, the pricing is too high ($30+ for eggs benedict, OJ and latte) and there wasn't anything that stood out (including the drinks). It's a shame because the ambience was there.  I think this will remain a One-North residents hangout for now.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: its pricy but i love the ambiance. get the tea, they serve it in separates and let you do the mixing. they've also got a great selection of books. the window seat is the best!

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: I absolutely love the coffee and the laid back vibe at Jimmy Monkey. But their food is really nothing to shout about and rather over priced if I must say. Have tried a couple of their brunch options and the only thing I will re order is the bowl of muesli. Although after having said that, Jimmy Monkey is a place I will keep visiting because their coffee is just quite so amazing. And I also really love their cute blue cups (which you can actually buy!).

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Since I live in the west I was super happy to find that I now had a proper coffee place near home.It's near, but still not near enough: finding it for the first time can be a daunting task, especially if you're not too familiar with the one-north/Biopolis areas.It's located in the one-north Residence condo near Slim Barracks Rise, so it's about the same walking distance from one-north and Holland Village circle line stations. The cafe has a Melbournian vibe going for it. No surprise as it's owned and run by a guy from Melbourne who craved a slice of home. They make a big deal out of how they have a Slayer machine. I'm not that much of a coffee geek although I drink a lot of it.Their coffee is above average. And pretty strong, stronger than most others'. I know because coffee tends to have no effect on me although I drink gallons of it, but I do visibly perk up a bit from Jimmy Monkey cafe. Taste-wise they have a stronger, slightly more bitter profile to their coffee.They're probably the only coffee place to do 'serious' food, as in they have a huge food menu. Most of it is executed quite well. I wouldn't go as far as to say the food is great, but it's comforting and quite unique. They have toast soldiers, good tarts, decent desserts, savoury pastas and a lot of sandwiches. All of those things are, I feel, better than their breakfast sets. But I don't like eggs and meat for brekkie so I guess I'm not the target demographic. The pastas are quite good though.They also have Asahi and some other alcohol, but I haven't had a good time or reason to drink here. I remember them being quite affordably priced though!

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: The eggs benedict (only on the weekends) and a cappuccino (which seem bigger than the latte) is probably the best breakfast I have had in Singapore. Their coffee is impressively good.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Since I can't be in Australia for coffee, I turned up at a cafe owned by an Australian.In a corner of a quiet up-scale neighbourhood, its a bustle of people in the cafe. Seats were packed, conversations were everywhere. Thankfully there were only two of us and we managed to squeeze oursevles between groups of friends. Not much was done to conceal the walls and ceilings of the place but anyhow, that did not really matter. No, this cafe did not smell like one; no aroma of coffee.. Just very strong smells of a different types of food being cooked. The menu can be found as 3 sheets of paper stuck onto a clipboard. One page is for dinner only, while, another is weekend brunch only, the other? Drinks. Order and pay at the counter. Food is served shortly.Can I say, I absolutely love their French Toasts??? Served with some cut bananas and pistachios. Awesome. The toasts were, well-toasted and soaked in the egg/milk mix. They were slightly crusty on the outside but was very soft and moist on the inside. One thing though, unless you are a big eater, order this to share. The portion got a little too much for the stomach to handle after a while. A little too "heavy". Tried the cappuccino which was, good. Not too bitter and with the almost right proportions of coffee-milk. The friend did not like it for its strong bitter coffee taste but, I found it just right. :)Trust me, if you are looking for a place to chill with close friends, have a chat, relax... this is the place to visit. At least during the day over the weekends. I should be back to check out the night scene! :) Cheers~

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Once upon a time, a little card advertised a list of independent coffee shops on an island.  A girl picked up that card and memorized it and spent the next two years of her life visiting each coffee shop in turn.  Her last coffee shop was Jimmy Monkey Bar.It is so in the middle of nowhere. I am sure the residents and nearby laborers appreciate this coffee shop but it is just too out of the way for anyone else to get here.  I finally made the effort because I had to have a meeting near Holland V.  I was struck by the strange interior; it doesn't match the vibe of the website.  Call me crazy, but consistent branding is something I pay attention too.When I first ordered they were charging me $15 for a beet salad so I negotiated for a smaller salad at 2/3 the price and was a little happier but it still seemed expensive.  I wasn't going to argue with the iced latte.  I love it and would pay every penny for it. The coffee flavor was strong and nutty and they used the good milk.  My beet salad was fine and my friend seemed to like his banana muffin.  We sat undisturbed for two hours sipping coffee and chatting.  Sort of sad such a quiet place isn't a little closer to me; but then it wouldn't be quiet.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: I was looking forward to this place after reading the positive reviews. Unfortunately my experience was not as good. The coffee was over-roasted and every. single. item. on the daytime menu had some kind of bread or wheat in it. Even the only salad had couscous. No love for the gluten-free.

address: 9 One-North Gateway #01-51 One-North Residences Singapore 138643 Singapore
comment: Very nice! Good brunch, with options for adding sides (still annoyed with Wild Honey about that!)

PARK has got to be that one eatery in the Holland Village area I'd be willing to vouch for. The food was really pretty good and considering the above-average portions, it was pretty affordable. I didn't feel like I had wasted my money as I sometimes feel at other places with expensive good food but small portions. The service was excellent. The waitstaff were friendly, prompt with refilling our water and incredibly willing to accommodate demanding customers (I was greatly impressed with how they handled my closest friend with whom I was eating). The atmosphere was really great too - suitable for chill-out gatherings with the focus on good food and even better conversations (and not drinking to get drunk parties), dinner dates, etc. If you do decide to go with a large group, be prepared to sit outside and to wait a while. Seats are limited so do reserve your seats beforehand. My friend tried the Alfredo with Turkey Ham (with extra cream, and with linguine instead of penne) and I tried the Truffled Mac and Cheese. Both were fantastic and I recommend both. I would definitely be back for more!

Friendly  service. Cute place overlooking  small park with  resident grumpy cat that's  good for people  watching. Espresso  based drinks are satisfying  with an Aussie selection.  Flat white costs  a fiver  though. Flat white and  capp will set you back  11. More Perth than Melbourne  prices.

(P)ark is a brand new pub-bistro setup on the site of the old Holland Village carpark.  You will recognize the huge old rain tree that was in front of Starbucks.  It's still there.  It's just a part of a big grassy park now, called Holland Village Park, sited over where the carpark used to to be.  In this small park, sits (P)ark.It's a pleasant enough place and easy enough to find in Holland Village to be an awesome meeting place to hang out before heading out for dinner or more serious drinks.Holland Village has become a very neat hub for dining, spa/beauty and pubs.  Conveniently accessible via the Circle Line (Holland Village) and surrounded by bus stops.(P)ark is all steel and glass and as I alluded to in my tip, a pretty jewel box when lit up at night.  Other than the location, it holds it's own by being quite serviceable with nice outdoor seating (covered) and a reasonable drinks menu, although truth be told there are a dozen other watering holes in Holland V to choose from which have menus just as and in most cases more extensive than (P)ark's.Worth a stop by in you're in Holland V to catch the vibe of the place, and a good vibe it is too.  I love you, Holland V!  You rock!

Came here about 6pm on Friday- we were addressed as we walked up and told that they didn't currently have any available seating despite the fact that I could openly see three empty tables. Sure- maybe they were reserved... but we weren't even asked for a name. Honestly felt like we weren't "good enough" or something for them. Disgusted at the lack of service. Will not be back.
Yummy duck salad with quiona! Loved everything about it. Anqi's duck confit was really tasty too!

Had the Park Blue Cheese burger,  Stout Pork Ribs and Omega 3 Salad with the missus. Everything was excellent. The salad was especially yummy. The burger was as good as the omakase burger I had the previous week.. Except I couldn't finish the buns on this one. Ribs were very nicely marinated (in Guinness Stout no less!) and came in a very generous portion. We could barely finish everything and had a tub of fries left over. Worth a second visit to try their other items..

Consistently good coffee and good food can be found here at Park. Truffle Mac and cheese is quite good, complex cheese flavor and strong dose of truffle oil. The food in general is not too exciting in terms of concept, but what they have are well executed and delicious through Park's own interpretations. Portions are always substantial and good value for money.  My own and family favourites are the spam chips and truffle fries for sharing, omega 3 salad for some greens, the burgers- Thai chicken, vegetarian and Park burger (with the blue cheese is good!), Mac and cheese.

PARK is a nice little new gastropub in HV.  They have a pretty straight forward menu that serves up good and interesting food.  The atmosphere is nice and relaxed. The food was well made and good.  I thought it was very good actually considering it was such a casual atmosphere.  I had a seafood salad.  The dressing was a little bland but its more a matter of personal choice. I also had a chicken breast with pureed spinach that was pretty tasty.  I like that the chicken wasnt over cooked and dry.  They have a great menu and I definitely have to go back for the truffle mac and cheese.  The service was great and the staff were really friendly.  Definitely much better food than most the bars in HV.  I think its my new go to spot in HV for drinks and food.

My husband and I went to Park for the first time a few days ago with our two young daughters, and we were all happily surprised. It is rare that we can find a restaurant that fills all of our requirements, as my husband is vegan and the kids and I are vegetarian (not to mention the fact that our kids are picky eaters!). However, it was a home run for all of us! The kids loved the truffle fries and the truffle macaroni and cheese, as well as the juice; I enjoyed the fantastic caprese salad, and my husband enjoyed a grilled vegetable sandwich.
