The location is great, the wine and beer prices were reasonable and the atmosphere was very pleasant. We will definitely be back again, though we live rather far away near Bedok Reservoir. I wish they would open another location close to us! However, in the meantime, we will keep making the trip over as the food and atmosphere are worth it.
Only dined here once. Food was surprisingly good and i loved the Eiffel Tower-:)

Went to eat at this Vegetarian restaurant on a saturday and almost had no seats due to it being reserved to the max.  This was our first time there.Wife had the lunch set which by the way is 7days / week.I ordered Fritters and the lasagna.Soup of the day of Pumpkin was very good (9.5/10), though we both thought a perfect 10 score would be warranted if it was abit thicker.Fritters of eggplant and parsnip was very good as well.  Never knew parsnip could be so good ! Then came the lasagna... omg... it was very very good considering it is a vegetarian version.The chocolate cake and ice cream as some of the reviewers had mentioned was heavenly. oh, and not to mentioned our 2 kids (2.5 years and 8 months) was with us, and we really appreciated the restaurant / waiter accommodated when we found my daughter loved the soup and we asked for an additional small serving.  They were very kind to oblige.overall we want to go back again to try out other offerings... Very high potential that this will be my wife's new favorite restaurant !

Very nice dining with enjoyable ambience. The rosé was delicious bought in advance. More on that in a minute. I had the lemongrass corn fritters and moussaka both very good! Highly recommend them. They offer purchases at the time of reservation. Skip that. We order vino and dessert. They also inquire about dietary preferences! Very nice feature right? Only if it goes somewhere and some reads it. They don't. We showed up and it was like we didn't go through that trouble the staff does not seem or act like they are trained to act on that purchase or information. I had to remind them show them the receipt etc. etc. Not worthy the trouble. But what really gets them a loss or stars is them inquiry about diet which was provided as vegan and lactose intolerant and then our surprise dessert pre-purchased was tiramisu and ice cream. Both contain dairy. Really?!
Quite exorbitantly priced. Food was average in taste, nothing out of the ordinary. Good decor and ambience. Very good service and friendly staff. Personally not a repeat customer.
Ambience is good and liked the outdoor seating. Perfect for a good dinner. Portions are decent and great options for vegetarian food.

Friends recommended this place due to its location and food. Location is especially nice and quiet and not in a mall :-)The impression over the phone was a big let down thanks to an unfriendly lady taking the reservation. After we arrived at the place we were surprised by the nice interior but again the staff was not really welcoming without maybe one exception. Service is okay but nothing special .... And that's exactly what makes a restaurant different to others. Staff seemed not overly interested or charming. The mushrooms as starter were fantastic, calzone was average because of the dough. The other meals were good. Overall we enjoyed the evening thanks to the quiet atmosphere and having dinner outside a mall, but this place could be so much more with a few little improvements. We will anyway come again to try the rest of the menu. We would rate 3.5 if possible.

We used to come here (and its sister restaurant and neighbour Michelangelo) a lot when it first opened in the mid-90's, then stopped when more exciting Italian dining options became available 10 years ago. For some reasons, Original Sin has always attracted a heavily-expat clientèle. It is interesting to note that the customer mix has changed from primarily European to primarily Indian, reflecting the changing expat community in Singapore. What has not changed? First, the décor, which now looks distinctly dated, down to the stains on the bench and chairs! Secondly, the food remains delicious, although one notices changes in the menu - maybe to accommodate new customer preferences? (They now serve veggie tandoori, and moved veggie burger out of the main menu). Prices are not high (especially the set lunch which is very good value). Service is knowledgeable and competent (unlike at the outlet next door). So, I guess we would go back here again!

Great location - two minutes walk from Holland Village MRT station.Came here on a Thursday night for date night, because I felt like a vegetarian dinner.I was pleasantly surprised, despite not knowing what to expect.We had the:1. Mezze PlatterA Middle Eastern platter with a selection of dips. Hummus chick pea dip, Aromatic pumpkin and carrot, Eggplant baba ganoush, Yogurt tzatziki, served with Falafel balls and ciabatta bread. (Summaries copied from the Original Sin menu)Oh my, this platter has amazing bread, freshly baked, and the hummus/eggplant were pretty darn awesome.2. Magic Mushroombaked Portobello mushroom with ricotta cheese, spinach, pesto, topped with a tomato basil sauce and mozzarellaI wanted an additional serving of this but my companion stopped me, because he wasn't sure about the size of our mains. Boohoo.3. Spanakopitabaked ricotta, spinach, feta and filo pastry served with grilled portobello and mixed vegetable ratatouilleQuite nice, but nothing special.4. Moussakabaked layers of char-grilled eggplant, potato, tomato and lentils, infused with middle eastern spices, topped with a white sauceI didn't like this because it was filled with lentils and tasted like a completely veggie lasagna. I would not order this again.I would come back, but maybe for the starters and different mains. We didn't have dessert here because they had a very small dessert selection and 2am was right opposite... But that's a separate review.

My meal at Original Sin was very enjoyable, but other than the fact that it was vegetarian and still awesome, it wasn't particularly memorable. If I could only eat vegetarian cuisine, or was dating someone that was vegetarian, or was vegetarian once a week, I'd probably rate this place 4 stars. But since vegetarian for me is a non-existence craving (I go when I want to really change things up, when I'm feeling very jaded, or very unhealthy), that makes Original Sin just A-ok. The Beetroot salad my companion and I shared was rather underwhelming. The salad snob that she is, she found the use of iceberg lettuce vaguely disappointing (the current online menu seems to indicate this has changed; it now says spinach instead of lettuce) and overall it just wasn't a particularly memorable salad, as salads go. Beetroot does not a star make unless it's been treated special or given a good supporting cast.The mains on the other hand, were delicious. The Spanakopita and Lasagna were both hearty, flavourful, absolutely addictive, and very filling. Just typing about it now is making me crave it. And considering I started writing this review over 6 months ago, maybe it's time to revisit Original Sin. Right after I satisfy my steak craving that is.

I rarely am a fan of vegetarian restaurants, but this one is an exception. This place takes vegetarian food to a different level - all dressed up and ready for prom!We had Mezze Platter for appetizer - the baba ganoush was excellent and so were other options on the platter.For the main course we had the following -Risotto - nice and creamy and cooked perfectly.Absolut - the pasta was yummy and the vegetables were cooked well and the flavor of the sauce tied it all together!Service was a tad bit too slow for my liking but the entire experience was very good.

Chipbee garden is for the more mature holland v crowd (except for the daily scoop), people who just want to chill out and enjoy a good meal in a nice ambiance and most of them enjoy wine and italian food. Original sin perfectly suits the strip. Nice ambiance, relaxing vibes, good wine, service staff is well trained and properly dressed etc. Everything seems right... except for the food. That is just plain and boring. Even a little bit more salt would do wonders. Trying to cut back on meat myself, I hope Original Sin doesn't turn people away from dining out vegetarian. If you want to go vegetarian a better option is to order a risotto at da paolo ristorante or get a mushroom truffle pizza at da paolo pizzabar down the street.

Had lunch with co worker here. I lived in HV area and  I haven't tried this place until recently. Highly recommended for vegetarians or anyone who eats healthy to indulge in! It is pricey for what it is but yes, it is sinfully delicious!

Yay fancay veggie restaurant in Singapore!Came here for brunch with friends. I already knew it was ganna be pricey - so i was pleasantly surprised with the lunch set menu, which I thought was a really good deal.the set  (for S$27 + tax/etc. = $30 sing) gets you:1) Soup/Salad/ or healthy juice2) choice of a main - I got the hummus wrap , my friend got the tofu burger (there are like 2 or 3 more other choices i forget)3) chocolate cake & coffee (REALLY good cake...comes topped w/ vanilla ice cream and was good coffee too)Another friend ordered the Mussaka - which was really hearty.  We also got the platter of cibatta bread, hummus, babaganoush, feta cheese, falaffel, olives, etc. Overall really enjoyed the food. The menu looks great - lots of  veggie italian choices, next time i'd like to try their veggie ratatouille =)

Great little place in Holland Village. Even though it's vegetarian, it has a broad menu full of options. I had the capsicum with quinoa (and great tzasiki.) It came with olives and tomatoes and a side salad. it was all was delicious. My friend had the broccoli pesto and loved that as well. They had a nice wine list and the prices were pretty decent. They can also make items many items gluten free (but sadly not the pizzas.) It's a nice place to sit on the patio and enjoy a meal. It started to get real busy around noon so you may want to arrive early for prime seating.

If I could give this place no stars at all, I would! I don't know what kind of disgusting kitchen you guys operate in, what kind of cheap, stale produce you use or whether or not cleanliness is important to your staff, but my parents went in to eat at this place last night and BOTH of them didn't stop vomiting and going to the bathroom all night long. So much so, they had to go to the ER to get help and has to be admitted and connected to an IV drip all night and my mother has now developed a fever and is currently still admitted in the hospital! Needless to say, they are never going back there ever again and we're going to make sure that our family and friends never go there either!

Original Sin specialises in vegetarian cuisine that has Mediterranean-inspired flavours. The restaurant feels very sophisticated and posh, and can come across as a little high cuisine rather than casual dining. I was definitely impressed with the décor and the ambience, and had high expectations of the food.The party I came with was certainly not let down by either the service or the quality of the food. The portobello mushrooms (or Magic Mushrooms) were juicy and flavourful, and we could not get enough of them. The Mezze Platter was also a instant crowd favourite, with the hummus dip and eggplant being particularly mouth-watering. Having had the perfect appetiser, our entrees only continued the momentum. I doubt I had ever gushed over vegetarian food before coming to this restaurant.Do note that prices are rather steep at this restaurant: be prepared to pay above $40 per person if you intend to have an appetiser and mains for each. I'd recommend you try this once - if only to challenge your conception of vegetarian food and how tastefully it can be done.

Great vegetarian restaurant with vegan options as well in the Holland Village area.  A bit pricey compared to other places, but definitely worth it. Went there with some colleagues. I had the Strozza Preti; great combi of pasta and veggies.

I made a huge mistake by taking a seat before looking at the menu and finally realized it is a Vegetarian restaurant! Don't get me wrong, I am open to tofu burgers and all things vegetarian but I was in the mood for some meat that night. The surrounding restaurants were packed so I decided to stick it out and stay. Nothing in particular on the menu caught my eye so I just played it safe and went with a risotto. I think it was a mushroom based one. Risotto to me is like Italian porridge and if done right, it could pack quite a load of flavor. The one I had at Original Sin was a tad bit bland  or maybe it was my taste-buds that were being stubborn. Either way it just tasted like comfort food without the meat. Not much to rave about but great environment to enjoy an alfresco dinner!

It's nice to have a vegetarian restaurant in this area and Original Sin does OK. There's a nice environment and the food isn't bad, but it's not inventive or extraordinary either. The menu is mostly pizzas, pastas and salads. There's a risotto and a soup and a few good but overpriced appetizers. The food is hit or miss. I have had tasty items but the potato leek and cauliflower soup could have easily been from a can. Try it once and see for yourself but don't get over excited or you may be disappointed.

My first trip here - in 2012 - was much better than a recent visit - February 2014. Both the food and service seem to have taken a turn for the worse. I took a large group both visits and the experience for all was better in 2012. The waitstaff seemed harried recently and confused orders. The food wasn't as freshly prepared and my pasta was quite watery. I won't visit again.

It can be hard to find restaurants, especially in Asia, that understand vegetarianism, so naturally I was so excited to try Original Sin! The wait staff were fantastic - very friendly and happy to accommodate special requests. My girlfriends and I had a beautiful set lunch and the food was so delicious! Will definitely be returning.

If you love vegetarian food, this is probably one of the best places in Singapore.  We had the Meza platter as starter and then the Bosco Misto and Risotto.  All was wonderful and there is also a great winelist.  You will need a reservation on the weekend.  I am giving it only 4 starts because the menu hasn't changed much over the past few years, but hey - never change a winning team... - !

A friend told me this was her favorite restaurant in Singapore. I scheduled an evening for my team to enjoy a dinner out while there on business. Unfortunately, we were all less than impressed. The food just lacked flavor vision for the food was just lost. Even our two vegetarians weren't impressed in the least. Out of everywhere in Singapore and more specifically holland village I would try something else.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way #02-10 Fusionopolis, Connexis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: This place is a gem ..... I was introduced to this place by my Professor. We had a lunch date with the team and had a really full lunch.They serve authentic korean food at very affordable price. Love the food here and have introduced many of my friends and colleagues and the reviews are very good.I love the soup, kimchi egg and the beef is the best of all.Feel free to pop over here for lunch or dinner and if you are craving for korean food this is definitely one of the best place to patronage.I'm not sure about other places but this definitely a must go place for me.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way #02-10 Fusionopolis, Connexis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: This is one of the reasons why my colleagues and I say there's nothing to eat at Fusionopolis. I have been here twice. After the first time I said "never again" because the food arrived cold, wasn't even tasty, and the service was poor. I went a second time because I was invited for a lunch mtg (the other party paid). My initial impression was confirmed, and I really hope there will be no 3rd time. If you want to eat Korean food at Fusionopolis just go to the food court at the basement.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way #02-10 Fusionopolis, Connexis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: The place's always crowded when it rains at lunch time. It seems like many others are following me and my colleagues - to pop in for some hot and soothing Korean goodness when it's crazy cold elsewhere.We've certified it as one of the better restaurants in Fusionopolis. You won't go wrong with their hotpots, or anything chicken potato. The ingredients are fresh and generous, and thoroughly mixed with veggies. The soups are great for the stomach and soul. If you want sides, try the rice cakes - chewy pieces of boing-ness in sweet sauce.The thin and metallic chopsticks might be a little bit tricky for inexperienced users. Hold yourself to a standard of grace and not perfection, and you'll be fine.Every meal comes with a set of - usually four - free appetizers, including kimchi and crunchy anchovies. It keeps you occupied with mindless chewing, and before you've even finished half of it, main dish is served.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way #02-10 Fusionopolis, Connexis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: It was simply the worse Korean I have had, no idea how this is ranked so high. It is beyond me why even the kimchi is bad at this place..... Ordered the stew, doesn't taste like anything close to what u have had before.....

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way #02-10 Fusionopolis, Connexis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: After grabbing my Korean friend said satisfied, so I guess that's the real measuring stick, but here's my take anyway: I went with the bim bim bap with chicken (choice of beef, chicken and pork). Cold bim bim bap is fairly hard to review, I mean, it can't really blow you away and it can't really disappoint, but it was as good as bim bim bap gets I suppose. I wish it would have come with egg with a runny yolk, instead of the egg "strips" (I can't really describe it), but overall it was alright. The main difference between this Korean restaurant and the Korean stall at the food court downstairs (besides the price) is the side dishes with Korean restaurants are famous for serving to complement your meal. Today it was a spread of four dishes: eggplant, two variations of kimchi, and fried anchovies.  They also provided a seawood soup.For $10, it was a decent meal.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way #02-10 Fusionopolis, Connexis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: This place is decent, although the Korean stall at the hawker center downstairs is better I think.

address: 31 Commonwealth Cres #02-94 Commonwealth Crescent Market & Food Centre Singapore 149644 Singapore
comment: Fantastic BCM. They have Bak chor soup for keto / low carb dieters! Yay. Haha. I went with a friend, he ordered the Large BCM $4, extra liver and extra minced meat (additional). I tried his bowl of mee.. Sooo... nice... I was almost jealous... it's so flavorful, and it hits all the right note. No tomato sauce here! The owner is a young guy who converted his soul from a salary man to a hawker man. Glad that he did it. I've gone there twice now, in the dead of night. So happy I live rather close by, so this is a new go to supper place for me. They do Grab food too, but it's about $6 set meal i think... i dont know if it's worth it...... hahaha. The liver is soft and not overcooked, very well done, fish dumpling is good too. The fishball is definitely not self made la.. haha, but still average, and everything else is awesome... eclipses the meh fishball. Love love love.

address: 31 Commonwealth Cres #02-94 Commonwealth Crescent Market & Food Centre Singapore 149644 Singapore
comment: My supper fix when I'm hungry.Like their fish dumplings as an additional ingredient for my bah chor mee.They also have grab delivery which is very convenient for me as I'm staying nearby.

address: Blk 354 Clementi Ave 2 #01-259 Singapore Singapore 120354 Singapore
comment: The service here approaches restaurant quality. The menu is on the counter but there are no prices and you have to ask. The price for a standard chicken rice combined is $3.50, when separated $4.20. The price for a can of drink is $1.60.The rice is a bit sticky and the chili is quite hot so put in small quantities. The chicken is damn nice though, especially the skin, as advertised. They have a separate dining room which is nice.

address: Blk 354 Clementi Ave 2 #01-259 Singapore Singapore 120354 Singapore
comment: This place is the first chicken rice "black-shop" that i have encountered in my life... no prices on the menu, turned out that chicken rice set for 1 is a small plate of meat that costs $4 and a even smaller bowl of rice for 80 cents... all tastes mediocre. Basically its the same meal (or lesser portion ) as the typical $3 chicken rice meal at most of food court but it costs $4.80 (a 60% price mark-up).Do not be fooled by the nice newspaper marketing review advertisement that they have on the walls, those golden days are over... this place is out to maximize their margin and treat or chop customers like car-workshop carrots.Lesson learned: Always check online reviews first before trying out a new shop in SG.

address: Blk 354 Clementi Ave 2 #01-259 Singapore Singapore 120354 Singapore
comment: Worst over priced chicken rice. Chicken tastes like rubber despite the fact that I ordered the drumstick. Rice was lukewarm and lacked flavour. Never coming back and definitely would not recommend it.

address: Blk 354 Clementi Ave 2 #01-259 Singapore Singapore 120354 Singapore
comment: I've been coming here for more than 5 years. The chicken is tender and boneless. And there is also achar on the side. I love their chicken liver and gizzard dish. The sauce is just right. I also called bean sprout and the Thai style tofu. I love this place and will come back for more delicious foods. They have lots of side dishes that you can order. Overall, this place is a must try! Parking might be difficult but it depends on the timing. Enjoy!

address: Blk 354 Clementi Ave 2 #01-259 Singapore Singapore 120354 Singapore
comment: The chicken rice is very average; hidden costs include paying for the rice and the vegetable dishes are very expensive ($6 for a small-ish serving). The portions of chicken are also rather small (for $3.50 excluding rice), and the taste is nothing to rave about.

address: Blk 354 Clementi Ave 2 #01-259 Singapore Singapore 120354 Singapore
comment: This eatery is located at the end of a stretch of other coffeeshops. It's one of the few places in Singapore that whips up halal duck rice. There's chicken rice too, but we can easily get that elsewhere, so we got the duck rice here. They care enough to debone the meat for you, so there's no need to dirty your hands.  They've got lots of variety in their menu. We also ordered the deep fried tofu, kailan and  omelette to go with our duck rice. The rice was fragrant and the duck meat was tender and cooked to perfection. Plus, it didn't cost a bomb! We were contented with the meal.

address: Blk 354 Clementi Ave 2 #01-259 Singapore Singapore 120354 Singapore
comment: the chicken rice is awesome. The seafood dishes are so so... Well It is called evertop chicken rice. Heh. what I don't like about the place is that you'll need to walk up to the counter to place an order and the menu is only accessible at the counter. and the drinks is ordered separately. well, it won't stop me from eating here again but it'll be better if the management sort this out.

address: Blk 354 Clementi Ave 2 #01-259 Singapore Singapore 120354 Singapore
comment: If you're looking for halal duck rice, this is one of the few chicken rice joints that serves it. They used to be the famous halal chicken rice store at tanglin halt but have since moved to clementi. I like the range of choices in the menu, you can choose from roasted to hainanese chickens to duck. If you're in a group, you can order a bunch of dishes and share and it won't bust your budget either! My favourites off the menu are the roasted duck and/or chicken, chap chye vegetables, omelette - it's a very satisfying meal just sharing those 3 dishes. The only thing I don't enjoy sometimes is that the chicken or duck is served cold. The rice is usually hot so I guess that makes up for it? Otherwise, it's a great place for halal chicken and duck rice!Final verdict: Not always evertop in quality but good enough to come back for more!

We wanted to try this restaurant as it was recently recommended by a good friend. The restaurant is pretty non-discript and could be easily missed. Decor is simple Japanese, service is personal and very good. The menu is simple, choice is omikase only, various prices from $120 to $250. We did the $170 menu. The menu changes by season. We had the autumn menu. All the dishes were integrated with an autumn theme. The menu comprised an eclectic mix of cooked and raw dishes. A mixture of "usual" well loved Japanese dishes and many ingredients and preparations that you generally wont find in Singapore. All impeccably presented. Absolutely minimalist and beautiful. All and I mean all the food was super fresh and absolutely delicious. Mind you, there was a dish or two that was "unusual" and perhaps not to everyone's taste. To me it was great, and an extension of your culinary experience. An interesting observation is that we were the only non-Japanese at the restaurant. Maybe they know something we don't. The exec chef is Tadashi Takahashi a Tokyo born chef that has been in Singapore for over 5 years. This restaurant is highly recommended. I will probably come 4 times a year to sample the various menus. The upcoming Winter menu showcases snow crab. I can't wait.

I love this hole in the wall place. It has amazing set lunches and omakase dinners. Great service. Prices are higher than the average restaurant in Singapore but are very reasonable compared to Japanese restaurants of this quality in Singapore.

address: Blk 19 Ghim Moh Road #01-229 Singapore 270019 Singapore
comment: So what's one of the touristy things to eat while in Singapore? Chili crab of course. If you Yelp chili crab in Singapore, you'll get a handful of returns with some very good reviews. I'm by no means an expert at guiding you to find this stuff in Singapore. Fortunately, we knew a local who graciously took us out one night to get some.Master Crab aka Lucky Yu Seng...We took a cab to this spot and if you ask me how to get there, I can't even tell you because I'm a tourist from the states. All I can tell you is that it's in this open air food court attached to some high rises, next to a parking lot that has a gate arm meaning you'll probably have to pay on the way out. The place isn't fancy. Actually, it's pretty grimey. Don't expect a nice air conditioned room, bright lights, or plate and silverware made out of the finest ceramics. Hell, I would tell you to avoid the bathroom if you could especially if you're a female or if you have to drop a deuce. I twinkle standing up and I still felt a little dirty. Now, if you can look past all that like I can, you're golden.Be ready for some Sri Lankan mud crab. Sounds dirty don't it? Walk by where they keep the live crabs and you'll know see why they're called mud crabs. The key is not to order the biggest or fattest one. Ask for a smaller one and maybe a female if you're into the eggs. Young meat is tender and juicy. Like lobster, the big and older ones are chewy and long out of their prime.  Our host ordered not only the chili crab but the salty egg crab. Be ready to get down and dirty. You may even want to pack your own napkins or paper towel because the napkins on the table disintegrate the minute you lay hands on them cheap things. They do provide you with a metal bowl of water and lime to bathe your icky hands in. This will be a messy meal, I guarantee it. I can't distinguish which sauce I liked better. The chili crab wasn't as spicy as I thought it would be but the heat just lingers around and the sauce is tasty. The salt egg crab sauce is rich and fatty. I honestly will say it's a toss up between the two sauces for me. Make sure you order the little fried bread. It's a perfect pairing with the crab sauces; double/triple dip for your pleasure.Since it was right around Chinese New Year, we also had the traditional Singaporean New Year dish. It's a medley of a bunch of items from veggies, to fried wonton skins, salmon, and noodles. Our waitress blessed us with each item she threw onto the plate. Grab your chopsticks and start mixing together with your tablemates and make a big deal out of it. That's how they do it out here, so I'll follow the custom and attempt to bless myself with good fortune and luck for the New Year. I don't know the standard pricing for this stuff but for three people it came out to about $160-170 Singaporean dollars. I personally didn't think it was going to be that much and I our lovable host wouldn't let us pick up the tab. I felt bad for not eating every single crab meat and sucking the shell dry after I saw the tab. So be ready for an awesome meal but it's going to get messy and it isn't exactly cheap. I personally enjoyed the food here but I will tell you that it's pretty rich and eating it often may drive your personal check-up doctor mad.Master Crab even gave me a deck of cards for Chinese New Year on my way out. Thank you for the memorable experience Master Crab and big props to our generous host which I will call "Chef C" for showing us this spot.

address: Blk 19 Ghim Moh Road #01-229 Singapore 270019 Singapore
comment: So much crab meat. Crab is from ?Sri Lanka(i think)... imported, not local, but very tasty! Chilly crab was my favorite but salted egg was good too. It comes w Man Toh to dip the sauce. A bit messy but so good.

address: Blk 19 Ghim Moh Road #01-229 Singapore 270019 Singapore
comment: Not really sure why this place is so famous. Been here twice. The first time maybe about 2 years ago. It was not bad but it did not leave an impression. Went back again today and since I was having very much a crab eating spree for the past week, decided instead on prawns, fish, pork, tofu and vege. The fried fish and tofu was highly recommended by the waitress and came as a real disappointment. Fish is deep fried with sweet soy sauce - looks great but way it was over-fried. Tofu - again looks great - but came in a puddle of golden thick gravy which turned out to be pumpkin gravy with bits of prawns and some deep fried crispy noodles-like thing on it. Was totally not impressed and a friend didn't even bother touching it.Maybe it is just good for its crab.... Then again, didn't leave an impression on me the first time round. Don't think will be going back anytime soon...

address: Blk 19 Ghim Moh Road #01-229 Singapore 270019 Singapore
comment: I came here with a friend in September 2012. I hope it's still open! I'm pretty sure it is!There's open seating at plastic rectangular tables with plastic lawn chairs. I think you might be also able to reserve smaller tables ahead of time, but we just walked on.Anyways, we got a chili crab, along with a plate of pan fried noodles, Chinese string beans, and a bowl of rice.They give you some napkins and maybe like one wet wipe to start with. This is clearly not enough. There's also a bowl of water with a lime in it.. I think you can wash your hands in this too?The chili crab is great! It's not actually that spicy. Your hands and face and table and possibly clothes are going to be a mess after this.String beans and noodles were normal.The crab itself is kind of expensive.. I think we paid around $30 USD a person.

address: Blk 19 Ghim Moh Road #01-229 Singapore 270019 Singapore
comment: Their classic "pepper crab" was flawlessly prepared.  No frills and no thrills type decor.  Service was better than par for it's restaurant segment.  Prices on par for it's segment, but the portions were slightly above par.

address: Blk 19 Ghim Moh Road #01-229 Singapore 270019 Singapore
comment: Came here with a Mandarin speaking local friend in a big group, had a good meal at a fraction of the cost as Chili Crab elsewhere (Dempsey, etc.) Came back with two fellow ang moh friends a few weeks later and the crab was more than twice the price. Could've gone to Jumbo Seafood for that cost.Doesn't that just ruin the taste of your meal!

address: 154 West Coast Road #01-69 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: Sushi Tei isn't amazing but it is dependable and good enough. I always have the katsu udon or the katsu curry udon, which is my favourite from this place. The chawanmushi is good too!

address: 154 West Coast Road #01-69 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: Nice food. Love sashimi! But daifuku are so small and strange fruit flavor stuff. Grilled salmon loose. But waitresses interrupted many times. They can't wait to collect dishes.

address: 154 West Coast Road #01-69 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: The Sushi Tei for NUS students. I can't remember if they still have promotions for NUS students (I recall they used to have) but if they do then worth coming here if you have a NUS matriculation card. Quality of food and service standards are about the same as all other Sushi Tei's in Singapore but this place somehow does not have those long snaking lines as compared to those in perhaps Vivocity or Tampines Mall.So, if you want a Sushi Tei in the west where the queues are shorter, this is the place to go.Get the Salmon Sashimi with Sushi Tei dressing which is a good appetizer / starter or can even function as a full meal if you're not a big eater. If you like shellfish, go for the hotate miso mayo that's basically mussels baked in a cheesy-mayo sauce. Other things to try are the dragon roll, curry cutlet rice, beef sukiyaki, cawanmushi, and special unagi roll that comes with thick slabs of grilled eel

address: 154 West Coast Road #01-69 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: Good ole dependable Sushi Tei. I like this outlet as the service is great. Always the same familiar faces. A well staffed outlet. I'm always impressed by how many cooks are working behind the kitchen. I like that it's an open kitchen as well - that always keeps the cooks accountable to the diners! Food is consistently good too. No complaints at all!

address: 154 West Coast Road #01-69 West Coast Plaza Singapore 127371 Singapore
comment: I've always known Sushi Tei to be a Japanese restaurant of higher quality so i was surprised to see the outlet at West Coast not exactly living up to its reputation. When our order of pork katsu was served, we were quite taken aback by the rather charred looking dish; it was as if they refried it multiple times before serving. The manager (of all people) was the person who served the dish so she very quickly said she will bring us a new one and we were glad we asked for it. the new katsu came perfect in golden brown crust and was really delicious. The tempura looked pale and was served without the dipping sauce. When highlighted to the staff who served us, he told us that the sauce is not available. we looked at him in disbelief and he quickly muttered that he'll ask the kitchen and disappeared. soon the manager came running with our dipping sauce. I'm thankful that at least she's trying to salvage what's left of our impression of the outlet.

I have been going here every morning for quite some time, it always has been the same. Other than the fact that the food is amazing, the people who work their can be quite rude, it's rare that you get someone nice taking your order. They are famous for their crossaint but they always run out- do they not think to make more earlier? you can see the frustration in every customers face when they get told their items aren't available rudely. The service is also incredibly slow.

TBB hasn't really gotten very much love since it opened to much fanfare a few years back, and I'd just like to drop it, and this branch in the Holland Village area, some love.  I appreciate consistency because it keeps my borderline OCD from a border-crossing.  Consistency means that all I need to account for are trading hours and I know when I walk into a TBB and order a croissant, I can expect on-the-money flakiness, a bready almost dough-moist corpus, and an enveloping buttery nose.  I want and need that kind of reassurance in a world where things can turn on a tweet, and TBB has always been dependable in delivering on that promise of consistency and consistent goodness.  The Holland Village TBB at Chip Bee is no exception.   Nice that it's also located near plenty of parking at the Raffles Clinic building right behind it and within neighborly proximity to the Daily Scoop!  Hang in there Holland V TBB, it shouldn't only be banks that are dependable in an increasingly undependable world.
Kind of a nice place to just get a snack, a coffee, and do some work. Nice surprising addition to the area.
Great food and reasonable pricesAustralian Ribeye Steak $16.95, Roasted Chicken Breast $14.95 and Salmon Steak $16.95Good ambience.  Friendly staff.Owner-chef so food is prepared with passion.

The restaurant was newly opened and I was attracted by its $9.90+ lunch set menu. For a weekday lunch time, the place was packed.The lunch set was served with a side salad which lettuce and cherry tomatoes topped with sesame dressing, as well as, a glass of ice lemon tea which one felt was pretty weak in taste.For the main course, selected Chicken Thigh which was served with baked potato, bacon and melted cheese. The chicken was rather tough. Even with the brand new knife, it was still quite an effort to slice through the slightly dry meat. The meat also had its share of tendon and veins in it.  The baked potato was slightly raw on certain parts as the texture was more on the crunchy than soft enough for mash potato. Wish that the bacon was crispy but one could see its fatty part.No GST but got 10% service charge.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Link #01-03, Nexus@One North Singapore Singapore
comment: Singapore's salad scene is growing! Such a pleasure for a healthy chain to serve cold-pressed juices. The papaya and wolf berry juice was delicious; not too sweet nor too bland. Just perfect. Choose from a variety of pre-made salads or go "Made Fresh to Order." You can even design your own salad! Is this paradise for vegetarians? Come and see for yourself.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Place #01-21, Galaxis Building Singapore 138522 Singapore
comment: KATTO, which means "cut" in Japanese, was started up by two brothers. Together with a bunch of good friends of theirs, coming together to bring us quality food which they specialized in; Sashimi. Having family in fresh food trading industry, all the sashimi you see at KATTO were self-sourced and self-imported. That was why KATTO promised to serve only the top quality, freshest cuts.Apart from serving premium fish, the rice they used were from Hokkaido. Premium Hokkaido Nanatsuboshi rice that's milled in Singapore to keep the freshness. Together with 18 other grains mixed in, steamed in dashi broth, their version of white/brown rice definitely bring your palate to another level. You could choose cabbage base too, if you're not a carbo loading person.How does this Sashimi ricebox works? For $12.90, you could order 2 mains of 140gm, 2 sides and a base of 250gm grains/salad. Mains were definitely the different varieties of sashimi. As for sides, there were edamame, pickled mushrooms, seaweed salad, miso buttered baby corns, tomatoes, pickled radish, cucumbers etc.My first box was with California Unrolled, Creamy Goma Tuna, paired with 2 sides of Seaweed Salad and Mushroon on top of a mixture of white and brown rice.[1] California Unrolled (Salmon)- It felt like having a California hand roll the "naked" "undressed" version. I love how creamy this combination was. The sauce was umami. Every bite was filled with generous seafood goodness from the fresh salmon cubes and kani sticks. The crunchiness from the cucumber and the popping of roe in my mouth made every mouthful delightful! Nomnomnom..[2] Goma Tuna- Fresh Tuna cubes soaked in this rich, sesame flavour. The goma dressing was so fragrant! With toasted almonds and sesame seeds mixed in the sauce, so good, you wouldn't want to waste a single drop of it. As the base rice was a little dry, this dressing worked really well to make the grainy rice softer too. Sides:[a] Seaweed Salad- Seaweed were indeed crunchy but tasted too bland for me. Although seaweed was rich in minerals and helps in maintaining collagen in our skin, but if they don't do something to the taste, I guessed I would give it amiss on my next visit.[b] Pickled Mushrooms- Mushrooms, fungus with good source of selenium (antioxidant mineral) and protein, eating more do no harm :) And by chewing these sourish tangy mushrooms, it gave me more appetite to consume more KATTO as the vinegar clears my palate. I liked this choice of side. On my 2nd visit to KATTO, I've chosen Chicken Rice Chilli and Classic Shoyu for my rice box.[3] Chicken Rice Chilli (Salmon)- A twist of asian touch I would call this and KATTO team was really bold to make this flavour. Like how it was named, it tasted just  like our usual chicken rice chilli but with salmon cubes rather than chicken. The seasoning and spiciness wasn't too overwhelming to shadow away the glory of the fresh salmon so it was a rather interesting choice which eventually worked for me.[4] Classic Shoyu (Salmon)- Among all 4 types of sashimi which I tried, this was the most common yet safest choice. Sashimi with shoyu, a classic way of eating, this combi will never go wrong. It was light weight, but the crispy seaweed bits and sesame seeds mixed in did made the overall taste tasted better.Sides:[a] Miso Buttered Baby Corns- Lightly grilled on the surface, these baby corns were still crunchy when bite. They tasted buttery while sweet on the inside. They went really well with the chicken rice chilli salmon sashimi.[b] Pickled Mushrooms- This was my second time choosing mushrooms as one of the sides. I still love it.If you have a smaller tummy space, mini boxes were available too at $7.90 each. For a mini box, you could get 70gm sashimi, 1 side on a 250gm grains/salad base.** Dining experience at KATTO was enjoyable. My tummy was happy :) For $12.90, the portion was definitely sufficient for lunch and most importantly, a healthier choice compared to fried kway teow or roast meat rice :) I find the sashimi flavours bold yet unique. Kinda love these fusion combi that KATTO provides now and awaiting to see new flavours soon! I'm hoping for my onsen egg or maybe teriyaki chicken on the menu soon  **

address: 1 Fusionopolis Place #01-21, Galaxis Building Singapore 138522 Singapore
comment: The place was located just on top of the One North MRT station, and was packed during lunch. The main dish here is its poke bowl, available in mini and regular size.Regular Size Bowl (S$12.90)Select 1 base, 2 fish, 2 sidesTopup S$1 for an onsen eggBase - Brown sushi rice with 18 grainsFish - Creamy Goma (Tuna), California Unrolled (Salmon)Side - Miso Butter Corn , Seaweed SaladThe seaweed salad was wakame topped with goma dressing. Crunchy in texture. The corn was crunchy too.The rice was not bad, soft and moist. One could not really taste the sesame dressing in the tuna. A tab upset that the onsen egg yolk did not flow out smoothly like lava.Service was fast and queue moved swiftly.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Place #01-21, Galaxis Building Singapore 138522 Singapore
comment: Been here twice - 4* for the first time 0* for the second thus 2*. Food here is actually quite good the first time around - fresh fish / good rice and salad base - makes for a good poke bowl / filling lunch. Second time around, I got very sick / food poisoning after eating there - think was due to the fish... so will never return - giving 2* for the enjoyable first time eating there... (picture is from first visit)

address: 1 Fusionopolis Place #01-21, Galaxis Building Singapore 138522 Singapore
comment: Had the mini bowl ($7.90) with the california poke, seaweed, brown rice and coleslaw. The bowl was very flavourful and the portion is great as I was looking for a light dinner. Think its better to go earlier, perhaps lunch time as they would have more poke options.

I don't eat Indian food often, and I tend to eat a sauce-based dish with naan when I do. The two times that I have visited The Curry Hut, I departed with a wonderfully, happily filled belly - the food here is phenomenal. I am a vegetarian, and I ordered the Palak Paneer twice. I paired the dish with Cheese Naan the first time and Plain Naan the second time. (I suggest you order Plain Naan so as to fully taste and appreciate the multilayered, decadent flavor of the puree itself.) My mom ordered the Paneer Butter Masala the second time with Plain Naan, and the dish reminded us of creamily melded tomato soup, but better. I gave my experiences five stars due to three criteria: the depth, the richness, and the purity of the food. I find depth and richness to be closely related, so my review under these two guidelines may extend over to one another. As I mentioned earlier, our dishes were incredibly multilayered - I was able to taste the different spices, but only detect them in well-balanced hints, fulfilling the "richness" guideline. The dish was "deep" because it, as a whole, did not strike me as overwhelming - to me, food with depth presents the ingredients in a way that not only embodies the essence of each element but also seamlessly combines them. For example, even though the spinach is pureed in Palak Paneer, it did not seem adulterated or overpowered by the other ingredients (the cream, paneer, spices). Finally, bear with me here, my digestive system attests to the "purity" of the food. The Curry Hut mentions at the beginning of their menu how they use fresh, high quality ingredients, and how each incorporated spice plays a specific role in regulating the digestive system, and I definitely tasted the difference. I know that after eating at some restaurants, I feel bloated and heavy, but this was NOT at all the case at The Curry Hut! Especially with the thickness of the dishes we ordered, you would think that you'd feel puffy, but not here. I would feel light and internally energized. I highly, highly recommend this place to anyone who loves authentic Indian cuisine. I haven't tried the other offerings on the menu, but I'm sure they're delicious! The dishes we selected were reasonably priced and definitely worth it. The people here are also really nice and helpful, which contributed to a relaxing ambiance. Will be returning again whenever I visit Singapore - so, so, so satisfied. GREAT job!!!

Artfully presented Indian fare, in between fine dine and an uppity night in town! The food was good and so was the ambiance of being nestled in HV, and the service was quick and nifty. As an Indian, I lean towards calling this over-priced, but hey, what isn't in the HV area :) Definitely try if you are in the mood for Indian flavours while in the area.

Good food! The Papdi Chaat was one of the best in Singapore. Also tried Hyderabadi Seekh Kebab(veg) was very good as well. Tried mostly vegetarian dishes and the restaurant lived up to the reviews I saw. The one-star less is for the service. It's Super slow and difficult to get attention of the people! Recommended for good Indian food.

I used sugar app to pay for my dinner. I got a sampler plate that includes Papdi chaat, bhel puri and pakoras. It was not bad. The place is like a bar, clean and in a pedestrian street that got some westerner feelings. The flavours are towards sweeter side but are quite rare treat: Indian street snacks in a restaurant setting.
The set lunch is good value at $12+.  There weren't many people when we were there at 1+pm on a weekday.  Would go back again.

Great place for Guinness and curry... Good service and pleasant folk. We ordered Guinness and the Erdinger (so much for "British" eh?) and they made us scrambled eggs Indian style with onions and spices!

I am a huge curry fan and while doing Singapore, a good curry place was definitely on the list. With some searching, we ended up to choose Curry Hut as our place to go.To sum it up: very good quality curries with possibility to tune the vindaloo's spice level. Good service, reasonably priced.The restaurant is located in the Holland Village. It is popular shopping and dining destination for younger Singaporeans and expatriates, it is dominated by and often visited solely for its eateries and watering holes.We ordered a mix of different starters plus main courses - and ended getting a lot of food. There is a wide variety of foods that you can choose, so I can't cover all what's available. We ended up choosing chili shrimps, chicken tikka, murgh korma and oh-so-spicy Vindaloo lamb. Their tandoori is very good and the Chicken Tikka was excellent. Korma and others were ok, but missing something I can't really pinpoint. Vindaloo is their only dish where you can adjust the spiciness level to maximum (you can adjust others too, but to my understanding not to great extent). The levels are from 1 to 5 and I chose with level 4 spicy factor. I am used to lots of chili and this was a good choice for me: enough kick but still good taste. I could have gone for level 5 too, I don't think it would have been too much. But this was just ok to me. I prefer also taste in the curry ;) Vindaloo wasn't as rich in flavor I would have liked it to be, but was ok.The naan was also good. My favorite restaurant back home makes the best naans, but this gets pretty close. Service was warm and attending. The interior of the restaurant is a bit too neutral (and definitely not indian) but it didn't matter much. The name of the restaurant and the look of the place just doesn't make an appealing combo to any passer by. I would have not chosen this place if I hadn't read other reviews and feedback from other customers. But don't get alarmed, you will get good food inside!All in all, a 4+ stars in total. Two excellent curries and two ok ones. Price level was pretty average (we dined for $200 with 4 dishes and starters and three glasses of house wine).

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Both the Hazelnut Sticky Bones and the Cranberry Sticky Bones $29.90++ (Half Slab) / $45.90++ (Full Slab) were extremely delicious. If you've tasted their normal sticky bones before. Think of these as sticky bones with a hint of sweetness over the thick slab of meat. A perfect fusion of Christmas flavours on ribs indeed. I would say, I couldn't distinctively taste the hazelnut or the cranberry but they both added a sweet pleasant flavour that were done to perfection on the ribs.Crackling Pork Roast $38.90+ 1kg Pork Belly roasted & braised to deliver tender & juicy meat paired with crispy crackling skin. You can't get enough of it.I love Pork Bellies especially the ones with the least fats and with crispy skin! The pork belly was delightfully tasty with a rich and lean texture and a light sweetness. The meat was mostly tender but there was a bit of chewiness here and there where it might have dried out a little from sitting.Roast Chicken $32.90+ Juicy & plump chicken, stuffed with Rosemary, onions, celery & carrots, Served with Roasted Potatoes. (1.4kg)I didn't quite expect such a good tasting roasted chicken at Morganfield's as they are more famous for their ribs. But the chicken was so tender, it was extremely easy to eat the chicken. The meat was umami and the skin of the roasted chicken was a tad crispy!If you don't want to share the love with your friends and family. Check out Morganfield's Weekend Ribs Buffet with Free flow Sticky Bones, sides and soups, take this chance to try out all the different sauces, sides and soups. Only at $40++. Available from 11am to 4pm on weekends and public holidays. The weekends can't get any better than that.Overall : Morganfield's provides a great location for any christmas gathering, to bond over good meaty food and drinks. Definitely try their ribs in any sauce! Not to mention kids dine for free on Saturdays, Sundays and Public Holidays, for each kid below 8 years or 120cm in height with every adult's main meal.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Not Quite the Field of Dreams I Was Hoping For. Being the foodie nation that we are, we've had a slew of foreign restaurants open their doors on our tiny island over the years. Steakhouses like Outback, rotisseries like Kenny Rogers and of course restaurants specializing in good ol' BBQ ribs. For years, Tony Romas have been spear heading the rib-olution in Singapore and for years they have been doing a great job. But like all great restaurants, the key to longevity is fighting off the competition. From Smokey's to Jerry's and now, Morganfield's. Though it's opened its doors for a few years now, I haven't had the chance to try it till now and I have to say.... Sadly... That their sides are better than the ribs. Since it was Father's Day, we decided to go with the Ocean Feast ($119.90) with a couple of additional sides. Beer Battered Fish Fillets. Crispy better but they used either dory or sutchi (Although I have the feeling it's the latter), which I'm not a big fan of. It's not the tastiest fish in terms of texture or flavour. Tequila Grilled prawns were nice. Sweet, well seasoned and juicy. Of course like all prawns, don't let them then cold if not they'd turn semi-bullet on you. Grilled Sausages were fairly normal and you could get similar ones at a supermarket.Grilled corn on a cobs were nice. Sweet, well grilled. Corn bread. The star of the platter. The corn bread was sweet and very moist. Definitely a million times better than what you get at Kenny Rogers. Hickory BBQ RibsWhile the sauce was pretty good, and the meat does fall off the bone, it did feel a bit overly cooked. The area with ample fat was good while the rest felt a bit dry. Chilli Con carne (side dish) Hmmm... A little disappointed with the Chili. While it was tasty, it felt more Bolognese sauce than Con Carne with the distinctive lack of beans. Coleslaw Pretty good coleslaw and a good dish to break the meatiness of the platter. Pilaf Rice If you're a fan of Aston's tasty rice, you will LOVE the pilaf rice here. It was moist and very very good. While the food quality was average, we were pretty disappointed with the service. Forgotten drinks, sides coming a good 15 mins before the main platter and the platter itself took nearly 45 mins to arrive, it certainly wasn't a good first impression. On a whole, with a little bit of tweaking, Morganfield's could very well be the best BBQ / Sticky Ribs in Singapore but till then.....

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Was quite torn between a 3 or a 4. Decided to give 4 to help them bring up their average to 3.5, which is where they really are. The food is decent, I did enjoy the hickory bbq ribs, and their corn bread is good, an American couldn't make it any better. Servings are generous, especially if you order the family platters. And there's happy hour too. Wait, did I fail to mention that kids under 8 eat free on weekends? So they are doing quite a few things right. And budget wise, for my group of 3 adults and 4 kids, with drinks, it didn't blow a massive hole in my pocket. Worked out to less than $20 per head. It's not all bad. Which is really a shame. If they were just to improve on their service a tad, they could really jump up a few notches, and Yelpers wouldn't have to wonder whether to give them a 3 or a generous 4, but instead just brandish a 5 or a stingy 4! So Morganfield's, it's really up to you now. Give us something great, you're not far off.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Expensive place and normal foods... the steak is alright however their ribs is so so only.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: This is not your Man vs Food show. It's the Morgansfield's Christmas Platter ($149.90++) that contains more than enough meat to probably last an individual till the next Christmas. But the good thing is that you don't have to beat the clock to finish this; neither do you have to embark on a solo meat conquest as this can be shared theoretically with 4-5 pax, or realistically speaking, even 6 or more. Sourced from Spain, Morganfield's showpiece sticky bones have been updated with a seasonal festive touch by tempering it with some American Rogue Hazelnut Nectar. The result is a rich, shiny, dark brown caramelized glaze and the meat underneath has a lovely smoky quality. The best part is the slighty charred crust that has such a smooth malty taste that keeps me nibbling on the crispy edges.Bathed in a reddish hue, the Cranberry Sticky Bones didn't taste as fruity as expected but the bits of cranberry sweetened the deal. The meat turned out to be more moist than the Hazelnut beer, with bits of fat tucked incongruently between layers.I sometimes wonder why restaurants like to serve turkey and not the turkey drumsticks? These two massive Smoked Turkey legs, like a miniature monolith on the plate, has a great chewy texture that makes you want to gnaw all the way down, leaving the bone bare. But I was particularly drawn to the Ham as the mildly sweet juicy honey glaze makes the meat even more appealing to the tastebuds. There was plenty more to discover on the plate with four beautiful bouncy sausages that reclined lazily on each other. Spicy Italian, Cheese, German Pork, each has a character on its own but the Cheese sausage grabbed the attention with delectably gooey cheese spurting out at the instant cut of the knife. Non-carnivores need not avert your eyes from the plate as there are plenty of greens to balance the plate; soft caramelized onions, steamed carrots, long beans, roasted potato. The Signature cornbread, a crumbly sweet corn muffin with crusty top, fully qualifies as a delicious pre-dessert snack or maybe even as a dessert for some. Christmas or not, there is always good reason to come for Morganfield's honest-to-goodness sticky bones because the quality still stays consistent as my previous visit. And, my nostrils confirmed this as soon as the meat platter made its entrance on the table, it's great.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Oddly empty on a Sunday lunch, I thought it would be flooded due to crowd from the post-service upstairs. Only half the restaurant was filled, so pleasantly delighted that we could be seated as soon as we arrived.The ribs had been highly recommended by a few of my friends and wanted to see what the fuss is all about. Ordered the Garlic BBQ spare ribs (about SGD$24 for half slab. Full slab will be around SGD$40) - comes with sides of fries and coleslaw. The meat is really tender! Wanted to share but everytime I dig into it with my fork, only a small piece get removed - PERFECT, get the whole thing to myself heehee. Nicely charred on the top, sides and LOVE the cartilage. Chunks of it were still attached to the ribs, most restaurants will just serve the meat but this is THE GOLD. It would have been flawless if not for the copious amount of sauce slathered on the ribs - it felt like i was drinking an extremely tangy soup at times. A thin layer and additional sauce on the side would be a better presentation option imo.Also had a serving of Garden Salad - meh. Corn - meh-ish, Cornbread - not bad, crust could have been crunchier.4* for the Ribs2.5* for the rest.Not really a fan, based on Yelp's 4* description more towards A-OK at 3*.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Took the old folks for some ribs and we ordered the cranberry sticky bones. it was yummy! meat falling off the bone and it was not too sweet. the muffin is always a favorite and since we didn't order the whole Christmas set, i had to order it on the side at $3.90. sure wish it was not that pricey. something else i ordered and enjoyed was the Mexican grilled corn. had been a fan since I first ate it in New York so was quite excited to see them offering it. of course it cannot be compared but it left me satisfied somewhat. We also had the crispy golden pork belly; can't go wrong with that one. super crunchy skin! if you order the Christmas set, there's actually a huge stack of it. Go for the set if you have a huge party.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Ordered Ribeye steak. Asked the lady what medium was..agreed and explained that medium was pink in the middle not red..steak came out..rare to medium rare..sent it back..steak came back out.. part cooked medium but mostly still medium rare.Complained to head staff member..just said so sorry..will tell the cook.I could see the cooks from where I was sitting. They had no idea how to cook the steak to the right level as you need a thermometer..No discount offered like outback steakhouse who at least try to compensate.Very poor way to keep customers happy to return.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Food expensive for the portions. View is pretty nice but paying 21 dollars for a burger that takes almost 45 minutes to arrive is quite ridiculous.  Side order of fries took a while too.At 10 pm it was starting to get empty and staff were cleaning as some of us were still there which was quite rude. Getting their attention for the bill took a while and was irritating.The burger was succulent and juicy and I have no complaints but the size was ridiculous.  Won't be going back there.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: This review is 3 stars, but it is possible you will get very pissed off with their sometimes spotty service.I've eaten here a couple times for lunch, and sometimes they have a mailer that my colleague gets, for one-for-one rack of ribs. You ought to find out how to get that mailer, because it is quite value-for-money. Otherwise, it seems a little, little pricey for what you get.Service here is generally okay, but I've waited years for some water before, yet other times, they offer me extra sauce for my ribs without me asking. I came here around Xmas season once, and they had the best cranberry ribs ever. Sadly, this flavor is seasonal, so wait out. Last time I came, I had the Hickory and Tuscan ribs. Hickory, is well, hickory. Tuscan ribs felt like eating pasta sauce on top of meat, which wasn't entirely bad, but maybe a double Hickory would have been better.I like their sides - red skinned potato mash, cornbread, fries, garden veggies... Yum!

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore

And, my nostrils confirmed this as soon as the meat platter made its entrance on the table, it's great.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Oddly empty on a Sunday lunch, I thought it would be flooded due to crowd from the post-service upstairs. Only half the restaurant was filled, so pleasantly delighted that we could be seated as soon as we arrived.The ribs had been highly recommended by a few of my friends and wanted to see what the fuss is all about. Ordered the Garlic BBQ spare ribs (about SGD$24 for half slab. Full slab will be around SGD$40) - comes with sides of fries and coleslaw. The meat is really tender! Wanted to share but everytime I dig into it with my fork, only a small piece get removed - PERFECT, get the whole thing to myself heehee. Nicely charred on the top, sides and LOVE the cartilage. Chunks of it were still attached to the ribs, most restaurants will just serve the meat but this is THE GOLD. It would have been flawless if not for the copious amount of sauce slathered on the ribs - it felt like i was drinking an extremely tangy soup at times. A thin layer and additional sauce on the side would be a better presentation option imo.Also had a serving of Garden Salad - meh. Corn - meh-ish, Cornbread - not bad, crust could have been crunchier.4* for the Ribs2.5* for the rest.Not really a fan, based on Yelp's 4* description more towards A-OK at 3*.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Can't recommend. Misleadingly advertised set lunch prices, absent service, slow service. High prices.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Was here for a company luncheon, with a table for 12. The servers are nice people, ensuring you are comfortable and explaining to you the menu where needed. Food was a-ok. Their signature dishes might have better luck.I had the Silrion Steak, medium rare, value lunch set meal. The spicy gumbo soup was an instant hit, though it seemed to have taken some local flavors in the process. The main dish itself was a little but of a let down. The steak was cooked to medium rare as requested, but it seemed to have been charbroiled instead of been properly grilled. Which is rather weird for a restaurant of this establishment. Overall atmosphere was fine, not too noisy, though the mounted small TV screens showing Popeyes might not be the right choice for the crowd that comes to eat here. Might come back for a second try. Their ribs and fish&chips look a lot better than their steak and pork chops. Might have a second go before deciding whether to add this place to my fave lists.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: decent american food in the huge rock that is the star vista mall. if you're looking for a place this weekend to meet up with the large family and consume a large amount of food, this could very well be it. reasonably priced, large portions and decent cooking, this made for an enjoyable mother's day dinner - I know, I know, it's the end of the month now - and its way on our list of family-congregation-venues.it's a large restaurant with outdoor seating and a surprisinly spacious interior. it was very cosy - good for conversation but with enough visual distraction in case you've got one of those awkward families (I don't, thankfully). their specialties here are platters and ribs - both of which were adequately tasty to deserve that denotation. the ocean platter a large array of item: battered fish, a rack of ribs, grilled prawns, corn-on-the-cob and -in-the-cornbread-muffins, a couple of sausages and a pile of fries. every component was tasty and went down easily. my granddad's portion of fish and chips were rather fantastic - even better than the fillets on the platter. thick fillets of firm white fish encased in a crisp batter. the seafood basket I thought a little less impressive - still a competent rendition though.our tequila spiked chicken was very good too - tender and moist - especially the breast, and with a well-seasoned skin that the partner was happy to finish.we were told at the end - when we were stuffed beyond ourselves and had requested mercy in the form of a doggy bag - that our set came with a lava cake. piping hot - with no evil microwaving so oft inflicted on innocent, unknowing cakes - and paired with a scoop of vanilla ice cream, it was so good we found anatomical capacity we never thought we had. it may not have been the best, nor the highest standard - but it was deep, dark and not-too-sweet.and so perhaps this is the holy grail of family restaurants. a large menu to satisfy everybody, with competent cooking that's well able to deal with providing quite these many choices, and food that came hot, fast and very commendable - the staff were friendly, our large order taken accurately; it's going on a list of reliables.p.s. I've just checked the menu online, and prices seem to have risen slightly since we were there - bringing it from reasonably-priced to just-within-what-you'd-be-willing-to-pay. still a good option for family dinners though!

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: 3.5 stars for Morganfield's. The food is quite good for the price you are paying. The rib eye steak was kind of fabulous. And that is probably THE thing that will get me to return. Having said that, the noisy environment and the slow service makes me quite apprehensive to consider a return visit. A note to the management. This place is understaffed. The service staff were largely polite and friendly but they were so hard to catch. And our food took more than 30 minutes to arrive. Which is not exactly acceptable. However, the manager was rather apologetic after we made the delay known to him and made amends by offering us a free dessert. And the lava cake was actually quite yummy so appeased I am.The acoustics of this restaurant is kind of shite. The noise level was terrible. It was understandably crowded but the noise pollution was rather unbearable. Not a place for decent conversation. Just come here for the steak.

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green #02-23, The Star Vista Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: I shared the $34 rib + chicken combo with a friend. There was a LOT of food.Delicious ribs! fall off the bone tender, four giant pieces. could've done with more sauce, actually. Their tequila spiked chicken was also not bad, glad we got to try some other meat (besides ribs).Our choice of sides: Pilaf rice was good! Yum :) Steamed veges were normal, nice variety of zucchini, broccoli, sugar peas, cauliflowers, carrot slices.

This is a good place to be at 7am on your way to work.  Pour that small cup of local coffee, black as sin, down your throat and wait for your brain to wake up. You look around to find the usual regulars, construction contractors on a coffee run, executives and office drones in pressed shirts and ties just so, grim determination on every face to get through another day. Everyone is fortifying for battle.  A typical montage repeated daily in coffee shops all across Singapore.  The briyani here is decent and as 3Stars suggest, "a-okay".   The chicken is fried, although you can ask for curried chicken. There is plenty of nicely briyani'd rice and a dollop of pineapple-cucumber pickle. The curry is robust enough to make eating the curried rice alone a nice enough meal.  The chicken doesn't bring much to the meal, but adds a nice bit of substance to what is otherwise an austere offering.  At $5 a pop for the chicken briyani, you'll fill up nicely, but not be as satisfied as if you'd be if you had the same meal at Sheik's Curry at the Ayer Rajah Food Centre (see my Yelp review; shameless plug such as it is). This place is A-okay and they've been doing it for a good long while, plus it's in my own backyard, and I do like to promote and support local businesses.  They make my hood what it is and I do love my hood. Give these guys a go if you're in the neighborhood, but don't trek all the way here just to try, you have better things to do with your time.

The restaurant was located at the middle of a row of shop houses. Rather dim lighted. The restaurant offered well valued western dishes.As I was ordering through Waave mobile application, there was also a S$3 off voucher in the application too. Note that payment was made through the application too.Collar Pork Chop (S$12.80++)2 pieces served with brown sauce and 2 sides which selected Baked Potato and Seasonal Vegetables.Tender meat which sliced easily and flavourful on its own. Can do without the sauce.Orange Juice (S$3.80++)The drink was served in a light bulb shaped bottle, put in a pail of ice cubes to keep cold. Slightly sour but tasted better when colder.
Good western food option and beer near NUS campus! Daytime menu differs from evening menu. Happy Hour special for draft beer is not bad!

We decided to visit this place for lunch after finding that it was having 1-for-1 promotion with Burpple Beyond membership. The place was quiet with only 2 other tables of 2 occupied. There was also a 30% promotion for ala carte food item during lunch.Assorted Sushi and Sashimi Lunch Teishoku (S$21++)Served with miso soup, salad, and pickles.Although no rice, this looked the most value for money, especially comparing to the Chirashi bowl. Seafood was not bad.Shrimp Tempura Lunch Teishoku (S$19++)Served with miso soup, salad, and pickles.Stir Fried Beef Slices with Special Sauce (S$18++)Served with miso soup, salad, and pickles. The beef were very tiny in pieces but tasted not bad.Chirashi (S$19++)It looked quite plain when comparing to the set. No soup, salad, and pickles. The sashimi was not bad.Overall the Lunch Teishoku looked well valued for money especially it was a 1-for-1 deal.

address: Block 20 Ghim Moh Road #01-48, Ghim Moh Market Singapore 270020 Singapore
comment: So what can one say about a coffee stall in a market.....Hmmmm......It is located in a corner of Ghim Moh Hawker Centre.It sells cold drinks that you can grab yourself from a fridge.They also sell cigarettes up to a little more than S$12. OMG! How can anyone afford to smoke nowadays?I spy lime juice with sour prunes.Of course, there's the usual coffee (with condensed milk and sugar), coffee C (with evaporated milk), coffee black, coffee kow (thick), coffee pok (more diluted than usual).Normally, I would just order coffee but everyone else likes coffee C. Surprisingly, I like their coffee C as the C taste is not too strong.Best coffee in Ghim Moh Hawker Centre!

address: 2 Grange Rd #01-04, Cathay Cineleisure Orchard Singapore 229233 Singapore
comment: Offers both sushi and salad with the former being obviously more popular. The distinctive thing is that you can customize your own sushi which is served in a nicely designed rectangular paper box. Service is quick and ingredients are fresh. Besides the usual seaweed to wrap the rice, there is the option of egg crepe which tastes great! If you order the bigger option, the sushi roll is actually of similar size as the smaller option and the difference is just that more ingredients are packed in the middle. The bigger option is definitely more filling though so order according to your appetite!

address: 1 Vista Exchange Green Star Vista #01-23 Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Great authentic Nyonya restaurant owned by a Nyonya couple, serving Penang style Nyonya dishes with Thai influence.Prices are ok for us, not overly expensive but we got to enjoy very tasty Nyonya food, similar to those we had in Penang.Decor is average, service is ok, it's a small place anyway. The owner, Winston, is friendly and sometimes come out to greet customers :)

address: 15 Kent Ridge Dr #02-07 Mochtar Riady Building, National University Of Singapore Singapore 119245 Singapore
comment: I've never had poor service (although the coffee's not so strong).The pumpkin soup is killer, and spaghetti'll get you along.The prices are reasonable, the air's always on-they've got free wifi and decent background songs.Quite busy in the afternoons, but mornings are serene.Convenient to my office, Reedz is my source of caffeine!

address: 15 Kent Ridge Dr #02-07 Mochtar Riady Building, National University Of Singapore Singapore 119245 Singapore
comment: This is my favorite place to grab an americano on this part of the campus near my desk.  So it holds the pinnacle spot.  I'd try lunch here sometime if it wasn't overrun by biz-school-folk in the afternoons.

address: 15 Kent Ridge Dr #02-07 Mochtar Riady Building, National University Of Singapore Singapore 119245 Singapore
comment: I'm not sure what Reedz has to offer that the other cafes in NUS such as Starbucks don't. If you're thinking food... Yes they serve food like fish and chips, but they're really not worth the price, especially when the Business canteen or Arts canteen is just a short walk away.It's also not incredibly comfortable, after the standards set by other more prominent coffee shops.The coffee is decent, and it'll do for an afternoon of kicking back or not-so-quiet revision. But there are definitely better alternatives on campus.

address: The Star Vista #B1-08 1 Vista Green Exchange Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Good Ramen with tasteful broth.I went for the vegetarian version which had four options (white, red and black sauce)- white sauce - black garlic - Tom yam - spicy The Ramen for wholesome and quite satisfying, although I wonder if udon noodles will go better or what  But overall decent noodles

address: The Star Vista #B1-08 1 Vista Green Exchange Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: If you are heading here, the black broth ramen is what you should gun for. The black pork broth infused and garlic and I-dunno-what-makes-it-black in colour broth is really delicious. Here offers extra noodles for free as well so if you're hungry, this is the right place!The downside is some of the staffs here looks like their having a bad day. I ordered fat noodles but the noodles that came in didn't looked that fat. (more like mee kia size).

address: The Star Vista #B1-08 1 Vista Green Exchange Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: On promo now is a crab stock ramen that combines crab stock and their signature tonkotsu soup base. It's a pity that the flavour of crab shell dominates and was too sharp and strong for me. The generous topping of flower crab chunks didn't rescue the dish. There are other ramen shops in town with similar crab or lobster soup bases that are more well-balanced and flavourful.Menya Musashi outlets tend to be well located in malls and I have tried their white tonkotsu ramen on many occasions. Their soup base is rich and creamy without being cloying. But I could really do without the thirst that hits me halfway through the bowl -- a sure sign of MSG!!

address: The Star Vista #B1-08 1 Vista Green Exchange Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: smelly pork soup.I don't like giving low ratings but smelly :( not sure if it's a bad day or its their usual soup base. I love pork but this is genuinely repulsive.would rather eat Maggi mee. good thing: good sized portion

address: The Star Vista #B1-08 1 Vista Green Exchange Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: The 5x noodles is a lie. When you ask for 5x, they don't give you 5x. More like 2x or 3x.

address: The Star Vista #B1-08 1 Vista Green Exchange Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: First time I had black tsukemen ramen for dinner and it was AMAZING! Clear your doubts about black soup ramen, yes they might look unappetising at first especially for those of you who are so into white soup ramen but TRUST ME! It's so so good! I ordered the garlic one and you can taste the garlic in the soup in a good way! The noodle:Thick kind Soup:Tonkotsu garlic black soupMeat:Thick chasu (I think by far the thickest chasu I have encountered is in here, probably because of the pricey tag)

address: The Star Vista #B1-08 1 Vista Green Exchange Singapore 138617 Singapore
comment: Six of us descended on this newly opened branch at the 2nd opening day of the Star Vista situated at Buona vista MRT.  While there was a queue, it moved relatively fast.  Yet a helpful staff offered us ice water while we wait.
