In addition, menus were passed for us to make our orders.  The menu offers 3 types of broth - white, res and black, and 4 types of ramen - pork, duck, seafood and chicken.  5 of us chose the black garlic broth while another chose the white tonkatsu.  We were impressed with both the quality of food and service. What could be improved is the air-con. It was quite warm inside the small restaurant.

Heard about Fish Mart Sakuraya for years but not tried till now. And the verdict is good! The fish is fresh and even the cooked food is quality stuff. The sashimi cuts are good and fresh and oh-so-tasty! It's not cheap but if you are willing to pay a little more for quality food, then Fish Mart Sakuraya won't disappoint you.

address: NUS Kent Ridge Drive Queenstown, Singapore Singapore
comment: A decent long black a.k.a. americano coffee can be found here.  It's the first one on campus that fits my snobbish ideals.

$9.90 pints of Archipelago (local Singapore craft brewery) beer and $8 Paloma cocktails at all hours of the day? Sign me up! We decided to head over here after dinner nearby purely for the reasonable drink prices. Much to our pleasant surprise, it was ukulele Wednesday here, which meant we were greeted by a throng of patrons strumming and singing along to popular tunes whose lyrics and chords were being projected on a screen. It all made for a very fun, convivial atmosphere. I loved having live music as a background for our beers! Plus, all the other bar patrons were encouraged to sing along even if they were sans ukulele, which just added on to the classy karaoke bar atmosphere we had going. Overall, the very reasonably priced drinks, chill and unpretentious atmosphere, and convenient location (very close to the MRT stop) made this the most enjoyable bar experience we had in Singapore. It felt just like a low-key neighborhood bar we'd encounter back home in Seattle.

A good ex-pat hangout catering to mostly the English crowd. We've always had good service and the beers are always cold. The full bar at The Pit features a variety of beers on tap, including Bohemian, Tiger and Guinness.  They also have several types of bottled cider. I tried the chips, they were very good. Crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside. Prices are on the moderate side but watch out for the added service charge.Overall, a nice place to wind down your day or enjoy some after dinner conversation.

This is a short review of drinks at the Pit Restaurant & Bar.This place is tucked away at a corner at the end of Lorong Liput in Holland Village.  If you do not know the neighbourhood it can be a tad tricky to find.It has a very open and airy feel to it.  It is a decent place for after works drinks.They have a range of Archipelago micro brews on hand.  These are the only beers I have tried here.  The staff is friendly and relatively responsive.Overall, as I said earlier, this is a decent place to grab a quick drink or two.  it does have covered smoking seats.   It is a very casual and laid back place.  They have a BBQ and bar food menu but I have not eaten any of their food.

The Pit sports a laid-back vibe, like many of the bars in the area. But unlike the rest, its nestled in the more quiet part of Holland Village (near 2am), which is something really welcoming if you're just looking for a couple of drinks with friends and still want to be able to hold a proper conversation. I think its meant to be a sports bar, even though nothing was showing on the large television the day I visited. The place is also rather comfortable- even the toilets are really clean.I tend to snack alot especially when drinking, and was thus pleasantly surprised to find out that The Pit had a wide selection of 'bar food' (all deep friend and super sinful) all of which were my favourites. Lucky I had the company of friends so I took the liberty to order pretty much the two things I wanted to try: the Buffalo Wings and the Jalapeno Poppers. They tasted great. Even though the wings were deep fried, they were not apparently oily and still retained a crisp juiciness. The sauce was also fantastic (spicy enough) and was coated on the wings in the right proportion. The Jalapeno Poppers were also done right: each individual portion was not too large and is fried to perfection. Definitely my favourite bar food place in Holland Village.

Great place. Nice staff.  Nice beer.  Relaxed.  A bit pricy. Smacks are basic like hot chips and chicken wings but nice.  Red wine is not great,  very cheap and bottom if range but beers are best. Tucked away and not to busy.  Friendly customers.  Someone will always chat with you if you want.

I drink alone. So I find this place to be most comfortable. They have a good grunge/rock playlist which makes it even better. The employees Remember ur drink..  If have visited more than twice. Not a place for food critics or booze critics. Just go there & have a drink. It sure is quiet & should remain that way.

I have already been a "regular" here before I knew of Yelp, and when they were at Clementi before shifting to Commonwealth before shifting to its current location at Holland Village.The clay pot chicken rice is not just good, it's great! And the price is not too steep either! For about $5/pax, you can get a nice steaming pot of clay pot cooked over a legit charcoal oven (most food these days are cooked over gas stove), filled with salted fish, pork sausage and chicken. The plethora of flavors make this a really tasty dish (for halal customers you can also ask for the pork sausage to be removed). Rice is soft, chicken pieces are tender and the salted fish really adds a whole new dimension.Furthermore, you get to decide how much oil and black sauce to add. Usually I would add until about 90% of the rice grains are black (my stirring sucks, sadly), and oil until the grains are shiny enough. Yes, this sounds unhealthy, but once in a while dish, it's worth it!And usually, we would add some soup as a side. I recommend watercress soup.Note that the food centre is like almost entirely closed save for this stall at night, so seats are aplenty. And yes, like what the other reviewers have mentioned, call in advance to place your order, so you don't have to subject yourself to a 1.5hr wait. This is one of those stalls I would recommend to my friends, and it's also pretty accessible too!

Michelin guides are dead wrong about Asian food (even in Europe - their ratings  in Singapore are pathetic!). So, it's a surprise they found  this stall and gave it a Bib a Gourmand. For us, this is one of the best Claypot Rice eateries in town, especially if you like the rice a bit charred. The chicken, salted fish and lap chong are already plentiful, but you can add more protein, for instance the scrumptious liver lap chong. Several soup choices to lower the heat of the main dish. Make sure you call 30-60 minutes in advance, for the wait can be testing.

Completely overhyped. This is a hawker stall in the Holland Food Centre known for its claypot chicken rice. The portion is quite big so we shared with a few people.The rice lacks the nice burnt smell you would expect from a good claypot rice. The chicken and Chinese sausage were ok - nothing particularly special. Apparently it used to be better - oh well...

The thing about New Lucky claypot is that I associate it quite a bit with my childhood. I used to stay in Clementi when I was much younger and claypot rice for dinner was always a bi-weekly affair. Then I moved away and made my way back again when I was in university, only because of the proximity. Don't get me wrong, the claypot rice is actually pretty good in my opinion.  The stall still sticks to using charcoal for their cooking and this gives the final dish a nice smoky flavour. One thing I love is the little salted fish bits that they put inside the rice along with the chicken and sausage slices - there are others who think of them as nothing more than little balls of salt but I beg to differ.Part of the fun of going to New Lucky is being able to decide how much sauce goes into your dish. At the start of the meal, you are given two metal cups - one filled with dark sauce, the other with fragrant oil. And, they leave it entirely up to you how much you want to put into your rice. I have had an instance where this went horribly wrong and I ended up having to eat rich swimming in oil thanks to a friend's horrible estimation skills. So remember to leave the flavouring to someone trustworthy!

A simple dish, rice is topped with marinated chicken and Chinese sausages, cooked in a claypot over a charcoal flame which imparts it with a oh-so-good smoky flavour. The stall also sells vegetable and soup side dishes that go well with the claypot rice, making the meal more balanced.Most shops don't bother cooking over a charcoal flame these days due to the time and effort required, so this was a rare treat. Of course the downside is that it will take longer for your food to be prepared. So be wise and follow the advise of previous reviewers and call in your order in advance!

First things first: ignore the earlier advice that tells you to call 45 minutes in advance; just call at least 1.5 hours ahead and tell them what time you want the food to be ready. Food's really got the "burnt rice" taste, which is what you are here for right? Not expensive, but we could have done with more generous portions of chicken and sausages. You can top-up for that. Chicken was nice and tender. Soup was a little salty, and definitely not the best I've had.

I've been coming here since they were located in Clementi. It's one of those places that you think of and actually go to when you feel like something in particular, even if it's not great, it can always be counted on to deliver a pretty good rendition.In this case they specialize in claypot chicken rice. The taste of charcoal gives it a nice depth, which is my favourite part of any claypot rice. The soups are also quite good.Now that I know where they have moved to, I'll definitely check it out again when I crave claypot rice next.

New Lucky Claypot Rice was previously located right opposite Clementi central, but recently shifted to the Holland Food Centre, nearby Buona Vista MRT Station. I've always heard about how this claypot rice served with chicken was one of the best in Singapore, so I decided to give it a try once. While it is true that they are one of the rare stalls in Singapore still making use of charcoal to cook their rice, I don't find it to be as mind-blowing as some describe it to be. One good point however is how they add small pieces of salted fish to flavour the rice - which is not done by all stalls selling this dish. However the rice itself may or may not be too dry for my taste, and it is this inconsistency that I have a love-hate thing with. But to have it cooked for us true-blue Singaporean style with real charcoal is a great experience. Another plus point is that they serve various home-cooked soups as well. Try getting the lotus soup or black chicken soup to soothe your throat after a heaty meal like claypot rice - especially if you like the burnt rice portions like me!

address: No. 1 Fusionopolis Way  Connexis #B1-12/13 Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: I heard about the name before I've actually seen it. The name of celebrity chef Jamie Oliver to be exact. He has a restaurant in London called Fifteen, where Benny - the owner of Eighteen Chefs once worked. Fifteen employs disadvantaged youths in training to be chefs. Similarly, Eighteen Chefs also takes in ex-convicts to help them acquire working skills.The restaurant is located right at the back of the food court in Fusionopolis. You've got to walk all the way in and then you'll see the huge wall with their promotional pictures. The menu is very comprehensive, besides the usual Western food staples, there's a 'Be your own chef' category, where you can select the base, sauces, main ingredients and side ingredients to form your own meal. There are also combos and student discounts too. All in all a complete meal will set you back by slightly above $10. If you're a proud cheese lover like me, they've got DOUBLE cheese fries - none of that tiny little cheese dip patroniser you get elsewhere. Over here, the cheese is served in dollops poured over the fries in a mixture of sweet and savoury flavours.

One of the oldest restaurants in Holland Village having started out as a small street food vendor.Though the place is supposedly known for its Ipoh Hor Fun, I believe that thats overrated. The true gem at this restaurant though, is their Silky Chicken Rice that is just another name for Steamed Chicken, White Chicken or Hainanese Chicken Rice.I wouldn't recommend going for just one plate but rather a group of 2-3 people going for half a Silky White Chicken. I can say that its one of the best Hainanese Chicken Rice I've eaten, having enjoyed it from a young age the taste remains constant most of the time. (They do have their off days sometimes)The half a Silky White Chicken comes in a larger than usual portion, being served on an oval plate and covered with their signature oyster sauce (!!) Ensure that the chicken is soaked in a thick pool of oyster sauce, if its just a drizzle make sure to ask for more or it really doesn't do a dish justice. The smooth texture of the chicken skin and meat combined with the tastiness of the oyster sauce makes it one of the best chicken rice around. Of course you must make sure that every piece of chicken you eat is drenched in oyster sauce, or else you won't get to eat the unique flavour of the chicken. (In the past they always gave loads of oyster sauce, but nowadays I only seem to get it from time to time)The chicken is submerged in ice cold water to give the skin a smoo texture and keep the meat moist and tender after cooking. So don't expect a steaming hot plate of chicken but rather an ice cold (as a compliment) plate of chicken covered in delicious oyster sauce. The rice itself is also wonderfully fragrant and goes along very well with the chicken.Overall, I must say that it is one of my top favourite Chicken Rice stalls on the island over the years with the standard remaining consistent most of the time though I have been disappointed on a few of my trips there. The char siew is also great there with large thick long slices of char siew with a deliciously thick char siew sauce instead of the usual dry thin tasteless char siew that most places serve. But do not go there for the Hor Fun as you will be sorely disappointed, the chicken rice is the one to try!

Decided to try out this place for a change from Crystal Jade Kitchen at the corner. The best thing is the excellent service - fast and friendly. The noodle in my noodle soup is overcooked, and the broth too bland. A neighbouring table had clay pot rice. It's not fragrant, and there's no sign of the crispy charred rice, looks like it's not as good as the excellent version at New Lucky at nearby Holland Drive. Edible, but the food at many hawker stalls would be much better than this!

I remember this noodle joint from my childhood - flashbacks of shredded chicken hor fun with the dark viscous sauce in melamine plates. I've seen the restaurant grow from a tiny shop expanding into two shop spaces and now, its most recent reincarnation as a fast casual restaurant. Now back to a single shop space, they've done a creative job with their decor - cheap chic if you will. You get air-conditioned comfort but much of the old charm of the original place is now sanitized and gone. We ordered the two-person set to sample more. We got a plate of hor fun and a plate of noodles, soy sauce chicken and roast pork, kai lan, dumpling soup, and 2 glasses of luo han guo. Not a bad deal for $21+ considering the serving sizes of the noodles/hor fun were pretty big. The standouts were the roast pork with its crispy skin, the kai lan, and the refreshing luo han guo drinks. It's sad that the soy sauce chicken and hor fun are pretty unmemorable since it's their namesake but all in all, it's still a decent spot for lunch although you can probably find better food for your money than the once-famous "Holland V Ipoh Hor Fun."

I live around Holland V. for the longest and this place used to be small store in a coffee shop. The lone owner will only cook the noodles when you order. Most popular was the Ipoh Hor Fun either with prawn dumplings or shredded chicken. Their gravy added was superb and the sambal chilli is a must have. When business was booming, it open a shop where it is now and a few outlets too.I felt that now the gravy taste different from before they expanded. Even though, I still once in awhile patronise they shop in HV because I still like their dumplings.
highly recommend soy sauce chicken , white silky chicken , home made barleys drinks , best hot pot , best congees polite staff , clean toilet and reasonable price can buy by cards !

This was a really decent set. 8.50 and you get a chicken with noodle in a curry(dry or soup choice too). A side wonton soup that was actually really good and not just a side thought. A drink to round out the meal so decent meal altogether. This is set B. Stay away from set A which was poor.

I came here for the Silky chicken hor , fun, my favorite in the last twenty years. They also  offer sets which make ordering easier. The decor is simple and artistic, and dining can be inside the air con or alfresco.

This noodle place has been around before Holland Village got hip. I used to like it when I was younger so I either my tastebuds hadn't quite developed then or the standards have dropped over the years. Probably the latter, considering they have expanded and contracted their shop space to cater to the number of customers and right now they are occupying about 1/3 of their former area.The food is not that bad. On good days, the hor fun can be quite smooth and the sauce pretty fragrant. But I've suffered one too many plates of mediocre hor fun with diluted sauce and dry chicken slices to give this place a stamp of certainty. Think they have also tweaked the chilli sauce over the years and it's a tad too vinegary for my liking now.

I went with the Char Siew Noodles which were OK (pork was very dry). My wife had the Mushroom Soup with Noodles. Soup was a bit flat but the Mushrooms all in all pulled it back up. For a quick snack ok but if you are looking for a new culinary highlight - its not the right place. Price therefore was fair.The interior was clean and simple but welcoming. The service was good, not all too attentive but when needed, friendly and quick.

great service from a young waitress who smiles warmly even after many requests for trivial things like changing table or asking for drinks to be changed multiple times ( compared to the bad attitude coming from the other waitress who wore a grey shirt)  they really lack manpower as i only saw two waitresses....the food is ok. overall the best of all eating out experiences since last year. hopefully can be served by this young waitress next time I come with my friends.:)

address: 27 Lorong Liput Holland Village Singapore 277738 Singapore
comment: Love this place!! The Açai bowls are amazing and tastes so fresh and not too sweet at all. It's refreshing on a hot day in Singapore and the toppings include great fruits and a granola mix. I tried two different types, as can be seen in the photos. Prices are reasonable and the serving size is perfect. There's a single serve and a larger bowl size. I think I could easily eat a larger bowl, but the small individual size is perfect for a quick snack. I could see it also being a meal substitute! The location is also extremely convenient to the gardens. Not a lot of space in terms of parking and seating, but there a couple locations in town and it's a very popular place. Don't hesitate to try the Açai bowls, they are very good! There's also a small unisex restroom.

address: 27 Lorong Liput Holland Village Singapore 277738 Singapore
comment: Loved the avacado toast and hummus toast . It was a treat to my eyes and for my taste buds . I am health conscious so Project Acia relates to me . Just hope the toast or well the quantity would have been bigger . But in a nutshell love the place .

address: 27 Lorong Liput Holland Village Singapore 277738 Singapore
comment: What to write, except that it's a great nutritious and refreshing snack perfect for these Singapore days. Ingredients are super fresh and I always find the people to be pleasant. It's a must stop for me anytime I'm in holland village. If I get the craving, they also have a stall in the Takashimaya shopping center.I do like the holland v atmosphere because it's larger and more conducive for hanging out. Just an all around simple but awesome place for a good Acai bowl

address: 27 Lorong Liput Holland Village Singapore 277738 Singapore
comment: I can't comment on the açaí bowls because i never had them, but my boyfriend says they're pretty good - on par with açaí bowls we've had in LA and Australia. The shop is (dangerously) just around the corner from our apartment, so we've visited 4 days in a row. I always get the Coffee America-No smoothie, which was spot on and amazing the first time I tried it. I feel like since our first visit, the quality of the smoothie has declined on the following days (hence the 3 stars). Today's was the worst. We ordered 2 smoothies and both of them came out super watery and mine had a lot of banana chunks. Using Day 1's 5 star-quality smoothie as a reference, today and yesterday's smoothies tasted like some ingredients were missing -- eg the cacao nibs and the almond butter. I certainly hope that's not the case, because a cup of this stuff isn't  exactly cheap. I think the shop could employ some stricter standardization practices. Other than that, we love the atmosphere and overall vibe of the shop. This shouldn't take away from the high rating that their açaí bowls deserve. Maybe we'll stick to their bowls for now :)

address: 27 Lorong Liput Holland Village Singapore 277738 Singapore
comment: I love acai and this place certainly satisfies my cravings all the time!

address: 27 Lorong Liput Holland Village Singapore 277738 Singapore
comment: So happy to see this come to Singapore. We come from California where acaí bowls are a growing trend and these definitely pass the test among the family.

I've come here so often since I found out about the 1 for 1 weekday lunch special. It applies to pizzas, pastas and main courses, and is such a great deal for delicious food!! Reservations are usually required for large groups though, and if you're in a group larger than 5 you may end up seated at the upper floor where service is much slower. The food, though, is so solid. It's become my go-to Italian place in Singapore & I always try to find weekdays I could visit it during the holidays. Most recently, I had the pappardelle (Homemade Pappardelle Pasta with Oxtail ragout and Rosemary) and La Nonna signature pizza. I've also tried the main course once (ribeye I believe). Service is usually quick and glasses are always topped up quickly. My friends and I rarely have anything to complain about La Nonna. I've never come for dinner though, so can't speak to the dinner or set menus. It's such a great location that you can always head across the road after to The Daily Scoop for Ice Cream or Sunday Folks for waffles!

Food is decent, worse than on a previous visit a year or so ago, but I'd go back mainly for the ambience and fantastic 1-for-1 pasta/pizza/main offer during weekday lunches.The starter bread rolls/crackers looked pale and under-baked so I didn't even bother trying them. We shared the lobster ravioli (3.5 stars), which my friend really enjoyed, and the crabmeat linguine (3 stars). I'd had the former on a previous visit a year ago or so and it seemed like the standards have dropped. For the latter, we asked for an aglio e olio sauce instead of the tomato cream sauce it typically comes with so this review isn't of the crabmeat linguine on the menu. I'd had the dish here a year ago and thoroughly loved it but this time it was rather lackluster. Ample crabmeat, but somehow the dish wasn't very flavorful. I'll have to hunt down another place for crabmeat pasta now...I was a little annoyed that the waiter misunderstood us when we asked for the crabmeat linguine to be prepared with an olive oil sauce, brought a plain aglio e olio pasta, then said he'd have to charge us for it since they'd prepared it for us. Nice try buddy. I pointed out (nicely) that it was an error on his part and he agreed to correct the order, though he emphasized that he was making an exception. One of the other waiters who helped us out made a couple of jokes and we appreciated his friendliness! Service really depends I suppose. Other than that I adore the ambience, and we paid $15 each so I can't complain! Wasn't too crowded on a Tuesday afternoon but it's easy to make reservations. I made reservations two hours before.

The food is decent (pizzas are excellent; lobster ravioli so-so; wet risotto very wet and quite unusual but not great; forget about mediocre antipasti). However, it is satisfying, almost like meals cooked by a loving grandma who is not a fabulous chef. The place has two qualities: it is very good value (especially when special 1-for-1 offers are on), and service is exceptionally warm and friendly.

Italian restaurant in Holland Village. Good solid Italian food. Both pizza and pasta are good though not excellent. Price-wise, a bit on the high side for the quality of the food. Usually gets packed during weekday lunches when they offer good value set lunch.

Came for lunch with friends and ordered:Calamari - still the same, crispy but can do with more seasoning.Portobello - this is a starter I shared with friends. Plump mushroom grilled to perfection. Delicious!!!Squid Ink Pasta - not to be consumed on first dates!!! But since Im only out with friends, eat away!!!! Pretty tasty and ingredients were also fresh. Just wish there were more really...An enjoyable meal nevertheless as they do make very decent pastas.

How could the quality go down so drastically in such a short period of time?? The prosciutto e rucola pizza we loved so much was sad. The prosciutto was way too chewy and the arugula was wilted. The only improvement was the quick service and the fact that they opened up the 2nd floor seating. I hope this was just a miss and La Nonna is not compromising quality due to the large flux of customers during lunch hour.

Although La Nonna has been around for a while in Holland Village, I have not checked out the restaurant until earlier this year.  Homestyle causal Italian dining is brought to us by the guys who own Senso. A friend organized a lunch meet up there and since, I have been dining there for lunch when I am in that neighborhood. Well, why lunch? Coz they have an attractive promotion 1-for-1 for entrees between 12pm - 2.30pm. Alternatively, you can try their 3 course set meal with coffee/tea at $22 ++.  The lunch portions were rather generous too! I usually end up sharing with my friends as I can't finish a portion myself. The dishes that I tried and love here are Mozzarella e Parma, Carpaccio and their lasagna. Definitely great for lunch meet up.

La Nonna is an Italian restaurant in Holland Village. This place is actually pretty good and I had a pleasant experience dining here. They have an indoor and outdoor sitting area (outside is nicer). I ordered the gnocchi last time I came and it was pretty tasty and cooked well. It can be hard to find good gnocchi here in Singapore but this place was good. No problems with the service. A nice place to get Italian food in Holland Village.

decent-enough desserts at this well-known trattoria along lorong mambong. this place is known more for their well-reasonable set lunches - but that's paltry. sweets! we came here for desserts-only after lunch at al hamra; and it did us well enough, even if it was nothing too special.they have a menu of typical italian desserts - we settled on the lemon meringue tart and a pannacotta, the latter of which really is indicative of the skill of the restaurant. the tart had a great crust - buttery lemon curd (though slightly gelatinous) and sufficiently-fluffy meringue on top, and it tasted the way it ought (average food truly don't make for descriptive adjectives).that pannacotta, though - I'm still on the lookout for a great rendition. this one is a little on the stiffer side, but still creamy enough not to offend. it didn't have those beautiful black seeds though - so I'm guessing extract in this one.it's difficult to be more descriptive - but if you're skipping it all to the last line - this place is alright if you're in the area, though I wouldn't travel for it.

so sorry to give a star only .. your assam fish head is not as good as before .. too much msg :!!!quite disappointed with the herbal chicken soup plus the fried pepper beef is not fresh !! we were there last night !!:(shall not be back for a long while )

Really tasty tze char for such a reasonable price! They have all your typical family style Singaporean Chinese fare plus some really creative additions like milk powder ribs! The only downside is it's not easy to get to without a car since it's in the middle of a residential area. I managed to get 12 foreigners in 3 taxis there with just showing the drivers the address though so it's not impossible! The closest MRT station is probably Holland Village and is walkable but through a convoluted back road.
Went there once with my colleagues after work. Food came within 5 mins since we ordered. I think the food wasn't cooked on the spot but cooked in a batch. Yikes.

Neighborhood zi char (Chinese cooked dishes) in Commonwealth.  Overall Ok experience.They are known for the milk powder pork ribs which is quite good. Also had the coffee pork ribs which has a nice coffee aroma. Besides these, the other dishes - veggie / fish / meat are all "ok". They are also known for cockles  which look quite good though we didn't order ourselves so can't comment personally  Service is sub-par - they really hurried us out and turned off the light where we were sitting when we called for the bill...Overall ok food but unless you happen to be in the area, wouldn't bother going

As good as everyone says they are. I had the garlic cockles, milk powder ribs and san lao hor fun. Super good combo! All for only $20.50. I arrived before 5pm and there were already patrons having their meals. I guess they do open earlier than the stated timing. Will certainly return again to try the other dishes.

Did not expect such a bad dinner. Ordered the claypot fishhead and stir-fried vegetables with garlic. Both were disappointing. The fish head was not fresh and thus had a fishy taste to it. The vegetables were bland, and were not thoroughly cooked.

Unassuming from the looks of it but Two Chefs Eating Place serves up good dishes that betray its humble settings. Tasty tze char dishes on offer here with a couple of signature dishes. I love the cold drunken cockles served with all that soy sauce, garlic, scallion, and chilies. So simple yet so gratifying. If you're wary about cockles, then this might not be up your alley since they're served chilled but it's really good. The butter pork ribs are also quite divine. Tossed in this cereal mixture that reminds me oddly of milk powder, the ribs are tender and the butter coating gives it a sweet and savory taste. We also had the drunken prawns and the hotplate beancurd and they were both delightful dishes but by far the stars were the cockles and butter pork ribs. Not much for service but the food is good. We came late at night so no wait and it was nice and cool out. Highly recommend stopping in Two Chefs Eating Place for a late dinner with some gratifying tze char dishes.

We like to patronise this dining place from their early days in Sin Ming Industrial Estate because their food is yummy especially their fish sliced noodles & San Lo Hor Fun. We just had dinner last night & we're very disappointed that the standard of their popular dishes have dropped tremendously.  I don't know whether there is a change of Chef :(:(:(

I was quite excited when one of my ex-colleague mentioned that there is a new eating place in Rail Mall that is worth a try out. Springleaf prata is tuck in the quiet corner of the mall facing the abandoned railway tracks. I came to realize its existence recently even though it was opened since last Novemeber, serving an extensive, unique and delicious Indian Cuisine in its menu.In fact, this Halal Certified Indian food Chain has opened up one more food option to the Muslim pals staying nearby.Drinks accompany our food will be none other than Teh O Limau Ice & Rose Syrup.Teh-O-Liamau & Rose Syrup - $1.80 & $1.40Being curious with alot of unfamiliar item out of the usual Indian Cuisine Menu, we ordered the Murtaburger which name sounds like Murtabak and Burger to me.2013 Murta Burger - $7Taste was amazing and I only come to know about that this is actually a good marriage of prata with our well-liked "Ramly Burger". Ingredients include mutton patties, mayonnaise well hidden inside the usual squarish egg prata. It was a moment of joy to see plenty of my favourite sticky mozzarella cheese while tearing up the prata. Not only was it delicious,  its crispiness of the prata had make me feel delighted.Filling up part of our stomach with Maggie Goreng that looks plain and uninteresting. Taste wise, it was nothing out of the ordinary but the dish came with generous chunks of chicken cooked together with eggs, beansprouts and vegetables, couple with cucumber and chilli as appetizer on the side.Maggie Goreng with Chicken - $5$1.10 for a piece of prata? What's the market rate nowadays given for the price from a air-conditioned shop in a mall? I bet this pricing is relatively acceptable especially when its plain prata is so crispy and goes well with the curry gravy. Yummy!Plain Prata - $1.10Service and food serving speed is acceptable. With a few well known prata places in the vicinity. the stood up among the rest with their specialties. I forsee myself coming back for more.

Two Chefs standard has dropped over the years. I'm not just commenting as a random diner, but I have been here a few times a year. Their butter ribs are still a crowd pleaser, but are served cold, for the past three months I've been here. Most of their other delights, are now unfortunately not as delightful. Sauces are starchy, loads of sugar used, nothing seems like it's served hot anymore. They will try to push to you the "herbal wrapped chicken", avoid it unless you want to drown yourself in mass produced bland soup.

As good as everyone says they are. I had the garlic cockles, milk powder ribs and san lao hor fun. Super good combo! All for only $20.50. I arrived before 5pm and there were already patrons having their meals. I guess they do open earlier than the stated timing. Will certainly return again to try the other dishes.

Really tasty tze char for such a reasonable price! They have all your typical family style Singaporean Chinese fare plus some really creative additions like milk powder ribs! The only downside is it's not easy to get to without a car since it's in the middle of a residential area. I managed to get 12 foreigners in 3 taxis there with just showing the drivers the address though so it's not impossible! The closest MRT station is probably Holland Village and is walkable but through a convoluted back road.

so sorry to give a star only .. your assam fish head is not as good as before .. too much msg :!!!quite disappointed with the herbal chicken soup plus the fried pepper beef is not fresh !! we were there last night !!:(shall not be back for a long while )

Unassuming from the looks of it but Two Chefs Eating Place serves up good dishes that betray its humble settings. Tasty tze char dishes on offer here with a couple of signature dishes. I love the cold drunken cockles served with all that soy sauce, garlic, scallion, and chilies. So simple yet so gratifying. If you're wary about cockles, then this might not be up your alley since they're served chilled but it's really good. The butter pork ribs are also quite divine. Tossed in this cereal mixture that reminds me oddly of milk powder, the ribs are tender and the butter coating gives it a sweet and savory taste. We also had the drunken prawns and the hotplate beancurd and they were both delightful dishes but by far the stars were the cockles and butter pork ribs. Not much for service but the food is good. We came late at night so no wait and it was nice and cool out. Highly recommend stopping in Two Chefs Eating Place for a late dinner with some gratifying tze char dishes.

I was quite excited when one of my ex-colleague mentioned that there is a new eating place in Rail Mall that is worth a try out. Springleaf prata is tuck in the quiet corner of the mall facing the abandoned railway tracks. I came to realize its existence recently even though it was opened since last Novemeber, serving an extensive, unique and delicious Indian Cuisine in its menu.In fact, this Halal Certified Indian food Chain has opened up one more food option to the Muslim pals staying nearby.Drinks accompany our food will be none other than Teh O Limau Ice & Rose Syrup.Teh-O-Liamau & Rose Syrup - $1.80 & $1.40Being curious with alot of unfamiliar item out of the usual Indian Cuisine Menu, we ordered the Murtaburger which name sounds like Murtabak and Burger to me.2013 Murta Burger - $7Taste was amazing and I only come to know about that this is actually a good marriage of prata with our well-liked "Ramly Burger". Ingredients include mutton patties, mayonnaise well hidden inside the usual squarish egg prata. It was a moment of joy to see plenty of my favourite sticky mozzarella cheese while tearing up the prata. Not only was it delicious,  its crispiness of the prata had make me feel delighted.Filling up part of our stomach with Maggie Goreng that looks plain and uninteresting. Taste wise, it was nothing out of the ordinary but the dish came with generous chunks of chicken cooked together with eggs, beansprouts and vegetables, couple with cucumber and chilli as appetizer on the side.Maggie Goreng with Chicken - $5$1.10 for a piece of prata? What's the market rate nowadays given for the price from a air-conditioned shop in a mall? I bet this pricing is relatively acceptable especially when its plain prata is so crispy and goes well with the curry gravy. Yummy!Plain Prata - $1.10Service and food serving speed is acceptable. With a few well known prata places in the vicinity. the stood up among the rest with their specialties. I forsee myself coming back for more.
Went there once with my colleagues after work. Food came within 5 mins since we ordered. I think the food wasn't cooked on the spot but cooked in a batch. Yikes.

Neighborhood zi char (Chinese cooked dishes) in Commonwealth.  Overall Ok experience.They are known for the milk powder pork ribs which is quite good. Also had the coffee pork ribs which has a nice coffee aroma. Besides these, the other dishes - veggie / fish / meat are all "ok". They are also known for cockles  which look quite good though we didn't order ourselves so can't comment personally  Service is sub-par - they really hurried us out and turned off the light where we were sitting when we called for the bill...Overall ok food but unless you happen to be in the area, wouldn't bother going

This area in Commonwealth really does bring back the neighborhood feel and is the perfect place for a quick lunch during work! Recommended to eat at this place with a group of people!I had one dish, which was the Milk Powdered Pork Ribs with rice. I had lunch at about 1.30pm here, the place was relatively deserted. Serving time was relatively quick as well. The dish itself was quite interesting! The milk powder seems to have been fried and isn't simply just sprinkled over the pork ribs, hence you wouldn't have to worry about any moisture over coagulating the powder. The sweetness of the milk powder goes very well with the fried pork ribs. I highly recommend not to order this dish if you're having a sore throat or dislike dry dishes, because this dish really does sap the moisture out of your mouth.

Reasonably priced and decent tasting tze char. Not quite worth traveling down all the way down for it, but good choice if you are just around the corner. Ordered their signature butter pork (4/5), fuyong omelette (3/5), hor fun (2/5), mapo tofu (4/5), and stuffed you tiao (2/5). Most of which we ordered were medium size and large for hor fun. Sufficient serving for 4-5 pax. Cost about $55 for all the above.Its location is rather unique and in an old estate. Everything around feels rustic and also a lot of elderly residents hanging around. Try to get to the car park which is the same "level" as the coffee shop, it has free parking on weekends while those on the "upper" ground are chargeable. Believe they are blocking them for the residents living in the area.We were there early (545pm) on a Tuesday and ordered take out, they were prepared fairly quickly. Heard it gets really crowded later in the day.

This zhi char place is definitely one of the best I've been to. They come up with original recipes on top of making your usual zhi char fare, so there is a great variety of dishes to choose from, and they are all very well done.We ordered the usual dishes such as... kang kong - which was super spicy! The prawn paste fried chicken was tasty but nothing special in my opinion. The shrimp omelette was very tasty and flavoursom, and the deer meat with spring onions was tasty and tender. But dishes are the norm. Well cooked and tasty, but their signature dishes are something to rave about.I love cockles, but I am very particular about them. I dare say that this place serves my favourite cockles dish - served cold and drenched in an intensely flavoursome sauce made with fresh chilli padi, garlic, and chives.Instead of the normal butter pork dishes every zhi char place has, they also have a milk powder version of the dish. I know it doesn't sound great, but I found it less rich than the butter pork and a lot more palatable. It can't be too healthy, but the flavour and texture you get from the milk powder is really something else.I really enjoyed their home-made tofu with mushrooms. It had a nice thick sauce with minced meat drizzled all over it. The texture and consistency of the tofu was lovely and I couldn't get enough of it. Definitely worth coming to eat here I say! I'll be back to try their other dishes, and I'll update you all with another review then!

Have you heard about the milk powder butter pork at this place?I first got to know about this place from my colleagues who were all talking about the butter pork as if it is the best thing since Photoshop. I was intrigued, and read about it. Then finally one day I got to check it out with them! The scene of invention? Two Chefs Eating Place at 116 Commonwealth Crescent.It is a regular tze char place. According to their signboard they only rest for 2 hours from 3pm to 5pm. This place is a 10-min walk from Commonwealth MRT, but it can be quite difficult to find if you are taking a taxi. Have a map in hand if you are trying to locate this place, or go with someone who knows about it.With that special dish of milk powder butter pork which I have never seen before elsewhere. It is also always very packed during dinner time but the people are very efficient at seating everyone and serving the food, which is good. Every other dish seems average only compared to the butter pork, but pricing is on the higher side for regular tze char so be prepared. I guess there's a premium when you have a USP to bank on.

Two Chefs standard has dropped over the years. I'm not just commenting as a random diner, but I have been here a few times a year. Their butter ribs are still a crowd pleaser, but are served cold, for the past three months I've been here. Most of their other delights, are now unfortunately not as delightful. Sauces are starchy, loads of sugar used, nothing seems like it's served hot anymore. They will try to push to you the "herbal wrapped chicken", avoid it unless you want to drown yourself in mass produced bland soup.

There always seem to be a long queue and usually when that happens you can't get seated until everyone's arrived, but it's so so worth it!There are four staples that I ALWAYS get when here. Start with the cockles - even if the thought of having them raw irked me a ilttle but I love this enough to get myself a hepatitis B jab so I feel safe chomping down on these babies. What really makes it so good is the sauce with lots of garlic, so make sure you drown your cockle in it before throwing it down the deep end!My favourite is their three egg spinach, with salted, centuy and the normal egg, a dish I began to notice was in restaurants everywhere, but only after I had it here. To date I still find this the most well done, with such a yum  gravy you'd want to get rice with it. The butter pork is an absolute winner. It seems to be fried pork ribs (boneless) buried under a mountain of milk powder, yet the powder is so sweet my friend guessed that it would perhaps be condensed milk powder, if such a thing even exists? But the novelty and goodness of the powder aside, the pork ribs are fried perfectly - not too thick, not fatty, very crispy...it is best eaten hot of course.I also always get the golden mushroom beancurd, even if it has disappointed me on a few occassions. It's essentially those japanese straw mushrooms in a thick minced pork sauce, a little sweet but very full of flavour.I have genuinely never thought I'd need to try anything else.

The food isnt as good as it was before. Even the signature dishes were rather disappointing. The butter ribs were dry and the three egg spinach was bland. I think overwhelming demand has compromised standards. Servers working hard to expedite tables for waiting customers at the expense of those seated.Food is reasonably priced with nice variety though. Didnt have to wait too long for our food. Probably going early would be better.

Did not expect such a bad dinner. Ordered the claypot fishhead and stir-fried vegetables with garlic. Both were disappointing. The fish head was not fresh and thus had a fishy taste to it. The vegetables were bland, and were not thoroughly cooked.

This place, located 10 minutes from Commonwealth MRT station, is pretty accessible.  It is quite a well-known Tze-Char stall and was rather crowded when we were there one Tuesday evening.Having been featured in The Straits Times for their Drunken Cockles, we decided to give it a shot and found it quite delightful. We also had their cereal prawns, which were pretty decent. I liked that they offered the option of having the prawns de-shelled (as peeling prawns is always a great put-off to me). Their Sa Po Tofu was quite nice too, but the serving was rather small. The dish that stood out the most was also one that they were well-known for - their Butter Pork Ribs with milk powder. It was unique and pretty addictive. Overall, we had a pretty good dinner, albeit small serving portions.

We like to patronise this dining place from their early days in Sin Ming Industrial Estate because their food is yummy especially their fish sliced noodles & San Lo Hor Fun. We just had dinner last night & we're very disappointed that the standard of their popular dishes have dropped tremendously.  I don't know whether there is a change of Chef :(:(:(

rest_name: Cheng Heng Kway Chap And Braised Duck Rice
comment: Awesome braised duck! I love it. And it's often closed when I visit, sadly. The line is so long whenever I visit but it is definitely worth the wait. I still forget what days the store is closed. Because of the huge crowd, it is possible for the duck to run out. I have had it happen to my Friend. The duck is soft and tender and there's also really delicious braised pork. The egg and the tau Pok is good too. The braise sauce is very flavourful but yet the meats are still tender. Very worth it for $3! The rice sadly, is not yam rice, but is normal rice. Just get lots of sauce from the auntie! Two cute aunties working together. Delicious duck and sauce! Cheap and good deal, will be back often.

rest_name: Cheng Heng Kway Chap And Braised Duck Rice
comment: Wow! Now i know and understand what the queue is about. Luckily for me, I was the third in queue and almost wanted to leave the queue. But I stuck on as I also dunno what else to eat. What a great choice I made to stay in the queue. I ordered kway chap with:* braised egg* daupok * pork belly slices * fish cake* preserved Vege All this for $3.50!!!!The braised pork belly slices is not funny kind of nice! Super flavourful! The braised sauce is good thus the Kway chap also shiok! My only complain is that the egg's outer layer is a little tough. Other than that, I had an awesome lunch!!

come here quite often before the covid-19 lock down. service is excellent! my favorite steamed egg ( chawamushi ) is good but very little now ( down suzed ???) even salmon salad too !!! grilled beef is fresh , not complaining  sukizaki is recommended but do request the  fresh beef to be served separately!!!!!!thank youshall be back!

Rumor has it that the truffle fries are deep fried IN truffle oil...and from catching a whiff of the tantalizing basket of fries from several meters away, I am inclined to believe it! Apart from being saturated in truffle oil, the fries are well seasoned with salt and dried parsley, which brings the overall taste to a whole new level. The much raved about second generation Mac & cheese lives up to the hype as well - each glorious scoop comes fully loaded with an even spread of wild mushrooms, shell macaroni and ooey gooey CHEESE! But the highlight for me was the Buttermilk Fried Chicken; its toasty and tender insides perfectly complemented the crisp maple-drizzled exterior! It's definitely a must try for all fried chicken lovers out there! We were unfortunately unable to capitalize on any of their daily promotions, but I would recommend doing so if possible as the food is a little pricey. All in all, It's certainly a perfect place for special occasions where one can splurge and indulge without any guilt whatsoever!

El Queso Grande booked The Little Diner for my first mother's day and it was an adorable hit for us!Service, as mentioned by fellow Yelpers, was excellent, but we were also quite taken by the affordable prices and tasty food.I found the much discussed red velvet pancakes quite delicious, so delicious that it was quite beyond me to share these three little pancakes fairly...I easily took down 2/3 and hoarded the cream cheese frosting like gold... That is until the last few bites, when I slathered all the remaining frosting on quite decadently.The Mac and cheese, while not the classic southern style baked with eggs that I prefer, was satisfyingly rich and the mushroom bits were particularly delicious.The steak sandwich looked a bit rare for sampling, but the Cajun fries were tasty indeed.The only downside for me was that the bathroom area is extremely warm, clean but warm.PARTING THOUGHT: definitely a nice option for brunch!

Crab cakes ($12.50) - 4 starsExcellent flavor, but it only came with 2 bite-sized crab cakes.Shrooms burger with fried egg and caramelized onion ($22.50 + $1 + $1) - 4 starsCooked well and tasted great.Overall, the food's good but on the pricey side given the small portions. Shared the two dishes (1 appetizer and 1 main) above with my brother since we weren't too hungry and the bill came up to $43.

I want to love this place. Unfortunately the reality is not as good as imagined. I don't mind it, but it is definitely not a "I like it so much I want to keep going back" kind of place unless I live in the vicinity. Friends like the place and the food (though some said it was quite average). So maybe that skewed my expectations a little. I was there early around 615 pm and a few tables were occupied. I told the manager/owner that I was still waiting for my friend and was thus left alone after being given a menu. No offer of "Can I get you a drink first?", even though it was another 15 minutes before my friend finally arrived (bad traffic!). Left to my devices, I checked out the decor. It was the now common industrial look with grey concrete walls and functional tables and chairs. Specials were written on the board hanging on one side of wall. Each table was prettied up with flowers stuck in a jar. At least there was some attention to details. Service was prompt once my friend arrived. Another server came over and told us the specials and brought us water after we placed our order. There were a few things I want to try:- crab cakes (was told it was so-so)- risotto balls (only to order it if you love rice/risotto)- carbonara pasta (it was good, the usual item ordered by friend)- fish and chips (not too bad)- espresso bacon burger (not bad)- buttermilk fried chicken (only available on Wednesday and sometimes Thursday)- fried oreo (selected days, check their FB for availability)** As they only have 1 fryer or something, fried oreo will not be available on Wednesday when it is Buttermilk fried chicken night.**What I ordered in the end:Espresso Bacon Burger-  It was medium like I ordered, pinkish in the center and charred outside. It was a huge ball of meat which sadly fell apart once I sliced it. So I was picking up minced meat the entire meal. The espresso bacon jam just had a hint of the coffee and bacon taste, so mild that it was quite forgettable. Being a jam, it was a bit sweet but I liked it as a foil to the meat and bun. The hand cut fries were alright though looked very dark. I was expecting that as it was written in the menu that it would look dark as they were fresh. Pork chop ordered by friend was said to be good. She liked it. I had iced lemon tea which was freshly brew and sugar syrup was left on the side. I would not mind going again if I am in the area, but I would not go there specially just to dine, but maybe on a Wednesday just to try the buttermilk fried chicken.

I have been coming to Little Diner since they opened. There was once a chef, a New York, who brought a breath of fresh air to the menu. The quality of the food has since declined. Breakfast remains to be decent but I feel that it's bordering on the decline.The menu used to be interesting and imaginative. Now it's mediocre and boring. Portions are small and like other Yelpers have mentioned, it's overpriced. Never once when I came did the chef or the owners who are sometimes at the premises asked the diners if they are happy with the food.The joint is not often full. Hence instead of texting away on their phones or having a smoke, it pays to ask the customers what they thought of the food if they wish to cultivate repeat business. The staff is often very friendly and cheerful. I do miss the long hair girl with the braces. She's the sunshine of the lot. I used to recommend the Little Diner but I doubt the joint is barely keeping up its former glory. It's now just a restaurant trying to make money. Not returning.

This place has a great vibe and the staff are awesomely friendly.I went for a Saturday brunch, which means two things. Coffee, and RED VELVET PANCAKES.The coffee was aiight. The Red Velvet Pancakes... unfortunately didn't quite live up to the expectations of my friends that love this place. I can see how the pancakes would be in in theory, except when I ordered them they were a little undercooked. Undercooked pancakes taste of soggy flour/batter and really no amount of cream cheese or syrup is going to cover that up.That said, my date's Eggs Benedict was pretty good though a little on the small side portion-wise and we were left wondering if we should order more or head somewhere else. In the end we decided to head somewhere else for a burger, but funnily enough I'd stlll be very willing to try Little Diner again just because the service was so friendly.Good people and good service save any dining experience, and I think this was no different. The team there deserve a second chance!

My pan seared sea bass with kalamata olives, cherry tomatoes (6 of them) and mashed potatoes was not bad, but I recall it being somewhat oily (this is from 2 months ago). My friend loves their fried chicken, and the bits that I tried were certainly pretty good!

This is one of the best places for brunch. The food is delicious and service is good too. This was my second visit to this place in 6 weeks. Both times we had a lovely meal.The eggs are amazing no matter what you order. We tried the omelette, croque madame, poached eggs. pastas are delicious too. We tried the aglio olio and Mac and cheese. I absolutely loved the french toast and double chocolate milkshake as well.Would definitely visit again.

UHHHHHH.... First of all, the mac and cheese was overrated and considering we came here primarily for the mac and cheese we were a bit disappointed. It just felt like it was missing something and none of us (a party of four) could figure out what it was lacking. The steak sandwich and truffle fries were pretty good so that's what the stars are for. Don't order the mac and cheese... It will disappoint!

The naïveté of the interior (plaster wave meets bats!), pleasantly pleasant staff, a fun reading menu with no grammatical or spelling errors and an enthusiastic owner (we assume) gave us some reason to look forward to our meal. First sign of trouble was the plating of all the dishes. Token salads, stacked and skewered food looked like compensation of some sort and turned out to be the case.I did note some rather inspired moments on my plate. I did like the fries and the coleslaw that came with my dish, but to serve fried chicken looking and tasting burnt was quite beguiling. I even finished it. Limpid, supplier-style Oreo Cheese cake was not and remained half eaten. A friend's pork chop looked robust but was an unexpected star anise party-in-our-mouths. We were left unsure about that. His apple crumble on the other hand held no surprises, but in a good way.I suggest the owner take a long, hard look at rivals on the market and see what they deliver against what they promise. Right now the output of the kitchen can't cash the cheques. Could have been acceptable in the 90's. Not anymore, not at this price point.I would suggest to lose the gimmicks and get some basics right. Otherwise a great location for a diner. I wish them all the best and hope they keep working at it.

Decided to try out this place just up the road, and we were able to snag a reservation for their last table on Saturday night.The menu looked delicious, and we actually got to take our time and look at them, because they brought out kids menus too.  Not just any kids menu, mind you, a kid's menu glued to the back of a magna-doodle!  BRILLIANT!  Not only did the kids get to pick from smaller versions of all the good stuff on the menu, they had a toy at the table to keep them entertained until the food arrived.  We got an order of arancini or fried cheesy rice balls to tide girls over.  The only downside is it doesn't open for dinner service until 6 which is a little late for our girls, but the cheesy fried rice did the trick.  They were perfectly crispy on the outside, a little melty on the inside, but not so hot that the girls couldn't dig in right away.  Perfect!The girls shared orders of the mac n cheese and fried fish n' chips.  Warning: the mac n' cheese is a smaller version of the gorgeous grown up mac n' cheese they serve for adults.  It didn't go over quite so well with the littles, but I sat there salivating while they picked at it.  The fish and chips were perfect.  The fish had a crispy golden batter, not soggy at all, coating flaky white filets piping hot inside.  And the fries!  Skin on, small batch fried, light sprinkle of sea salt...oh, excuse me, I need to wipe the drool off my keyboard...I'd have expected no less from an Irish chef, though he labeled the dish as Boston style.The Hubs and I were both tempted by the Truffle and 'Shroom burger and were not disappointed.  Truffled aioli, cabernet and butter sauteed mushrooms, and a burger the size (and shape) of a baseball.  The bun was standard fare, but the rest was so delicious we couldn't put it down.  Nellie, our server and wife of the chef, came over and remarked how happy it made her to see us eating our burgers with our hands and really enjoying them.  I commented that I would continue being the crass American eating with my hands if it meant I could have that burger again and again.  Not sure how you eat a burger with a knife and fork, but apparently that's how it's done.  She quickly reassured us that it made her feel like she was back New York, and we continued our meal with relish.  Reasonable if small wine list by the glass, much more extensive list by the bottle and a decent selection of imported and craft beers and ciders.  My radler was light and refreshing.  Mr. tried the "Yeasty Boys" which he said reminded him of a Speakeasy, bold, very hoppy.  We were both quite pleased with the recommendations.  We finished the meal with some coffee, and Nellie surprised the girls with an early chocolate Easter egg filled with pastel M&Ms.  The M&Ms were a surprise and unfortunately a few hit the ground before K could right hers, but they were heartily enjoyed by both girls!I cannot say enough about the service in this place. Nellie was extremely personable, and very thorough with explaining which menus items I should avoid when I mentioned my lactose intolerance.  She even came back to the table concerned that the mushrooms being sauteed in butter might be an issue she hadn't considered, and was relieved when I told her it wouldn't be a problem.  She continually checked in with our table and engaged the girls.  Happily they were not the only children in the restaurant, and several more arrived while we were dining.  To have our children so welcomed at a restaurant boasting a menu & wine list suitable for a nice night out was a pleasant surprise for us. The other waitresses and staff were prompt in delivering our food as it became ready and in clearing unnecessary dishes.  They asked if we needed ketchup or mustard before we had to ask and even had multiple options.  These little details combined to make it a lovely dinner out for our entire family.  It is a great little diner pub and we will certainly be back!  I want my own order of those fish and chips!

The good: Location (for me) and throughout my meal I was attended to quite frequently, including a hi from the owner/manager. My items came out fast, which was a testament given the place was packed (98% locals, not that it matters). The bad: Not terrible, but the food wasn't great. My eggs benedict came out with 1 thin slice of ham on each, and one of the eggs wasn't cooked thoroughly. The hollandaise sauce was runny and forgettable, about the only thing holding it together was the muffin (acceptable) and the ground pepper that was sprinkled on top (table side, nice touch). My latte was tasty (hard to get that wrong) but too small. The ugly: Unfortunately, it's another Frankenstein restaurant that doesn't have it's own identity. Even the decor screams outdated (there was Halloween decorations still up almost a month after) and there were design concepts that I've seen around town. Not all is lost, but there is still much left to be desired.

If only the food looked as good as the decor. And that's why I always say that you can't judge the quality of a restaurant by its looks alone.  Touted to be one of the go-to places for brunch, we were not in luck when we decided to pay the place a visit. Perhaps it was due to the unusually large crowd that had showed up while we were there. Service was inattentive and fleeting and wait times were horribly long. We got our orders messed up at twice and they actually placed the wrong orders for us. When the food we ordered arrived, it was disappointingly lackluster and middling at best. The burger I had was all mashy and seemed a tad undercooked and my girlfriend's eggs were all runny and messy, nothing like what she had ordered. I wouldn't mind giving the place a second try, but it will be some time for us to forget the madness.

I wanted to like this place for 3 reasons:1) There are very few affordable brunch places near my home that serve mind blowing food and don't require advance reservations.2) It's called the "Little Diner"3) I saw red velvet pancakes and french toast and immediately thought of the Griddle Cafe on Sunset Blvd (yelp.com.sg/biz/griddle-…)So what happened when  I ate there on Saturday afternoon?Service was great by East Coast standards, so I guess it fits with the New York theme. We (let's call him R) certainly appreciated the server checking up on us and serving water quickly when we got seated. +1 for using those umm... jar-mug thingies that the man and I used to use in college. We ordered the red velvet pancakes and eggs benedict and well, both dishes were kind of meh. My first reaction to the pancakes was wow that's a small stack. A small, thin-looking stack of pancakes that goes in-line with the "Little" in "Little Diner" I guess. I mean that's all I can really say about a stack of pancakes I ate in about 5 mouthfuls. It had some flavor to it but certainly wasn't the rich, dessert-like, thick and fluffy pancakes I was hoping for. The cream cheese frosting was on the side and didn't really taste like cream cheese (or at least what I'd associate with say a cream cheese frosting on cupcakes) and looked kinda awkward, as was the small swivel of cream. However, I must say the side of bacon was very, very well done. Super crisp, bubbling with oil, perfect. The eggs benedict that R ordered because of the honey ham in it was a benedict in name. The muffin was kind of tough and somehow the eggs and ham and hollandaise just didn't meld together and work. We've had some really insane benedict's at  Choupinette, Rider's and the Porch cafe in Bali and this version just didn't, quite, cut it.Bottom line, I'm checking this place off as tried and visited but am unlikely to return. It reminds me of the gastropub down the road - passable food and cool decor, but not enough to make me return again and again. For the price I'm paying I'm sticking with the stalwarts in the neighborhood, even if it means more effort on my part in making reservations.

My partner and I go here when we are craving Western food. The place is owned by a Singaporean lady who lived overseas for 12 years and her Irish husband. Their burgers are very good. Nice, thick homemade patties served with fresh-cut chips. We've also tried their bunch menu which is pretty good. The service is good and everyone is always friendly. I definitely recommend this place for a casual dinner or a weekend brunch/ lunch.

rest_name: Sin Kee Famous Cantonese Chicken Rice
comment: Famous chicken rice stall near Holland Drive hawker center. The chicken here is indeed very good - juicy and tender. The only letdown is the rice, which was a bit lacking in terms of fragrance. Accompanying sauces - chili and dark soy sauce complement the chicken very well. Reasonable pricingSometimes they run out so would suggest going early

rest_name: Sin Kee Famous Cantonese Chicken Rice
comment: My 2nd time here eat their rice. 1st of all, the price is reasonable.The chicken meat was soft but more of a powdery texture which is different than the usual chicken rice meat.Now the rice is a bit grainy & not enough flavour of the authentic chicken rice.On both the meat & rice, it was not to my liking. Maybe others may like their style of the cooked chicken rice.

rest_name: Sin Kee Famous Cantonese Chicken Rice
comment: Have been eating from this coffeeshop stall a couple of times this year. The chicken is really nice, tender and delicious. Inexpensive and the service is reasonably fast although there is usually a line of customers waiting to order. 1/4 chicken with two plates of rice cost $10 SGD.

address: No 1, Fusionopolis Way #01-03Fusionopolis Connexis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: Seriously the best wraps/salad I've tasted in a long time. So glad I decided to pop by this humble joint. At first glance it looks rather ordinary (simple, no fuss, a healthy office worker take-out salad bar) ... but in reality MIND-BLOWING (& healthy too). I think the secret is the a) sauce, b) meat. 1) Big Bird $10.80- I had a wrap. Basically, turkey meat, some toppings (grape, celery, apples) mixed with roman lettuce and the secret sauce of course!The turkey meat was so soft!!! and succulent. I was hesitant to order turkey initially because its meat is usually dry but this was proved my stereotype wrong! 2) Hail Caesar $10- My friend had this. Pretty good. Taste different from the former even though it's pretty much the same ingredients. Impressive a switch of 1) sauce and 2) toppings can have so much impact on the flavor. Definitely looking forward to my next trip back!!! only sad thing is they are located near office areas, raffles place etc. Not typically places one would visit unless it's to go back to work on a weekend.

address: No 1, Fusionopolis Way #01-03Fusionopolis Connexis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: Why are good salads so expensive? Aren't veggies supposed to be the cheapest thing in the supermarket? Like that how to be healthy? That is a question I'll never have answers to.The salads at Salad Stop are awesome. Besides being perfectly healthy - no preservatives, no additional anything, no fake anything, plus freshness every day, they taste oh-so-good. It's the kind of lunch that will fill you up, despite eating mostly greens, and sustain your contentment till it's time for dinner. For some reason, I don't have the tendency to snack after having Salad Stop lunches.My favourite salad is the Tuna San. The raw tuna, the avocado, mandarin orange, the edamame seeds, they're all my beloved ingredients within one bowl - how can I not love it?Salad Stop sells yoghurt too, they come with separate flavouring such as vanilla or blueberry, and also cereal on the side. Great way to start your day. Now would they lower the prices please?

address: No 1, Fusionopolis Way #01-03Fusionopolis Connexis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: Can't give four stars mostly because of the cost. Especially when adding the meat!  Love the food and taste of the wraps and sauce however. Great, peaceful place to enjoy a meal.

address: No 1, Fusionopolis Way #01-03Fusionopolis Connexis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: Kind of obsessed with this place. I teach nearby and sometimes at fusionopolis so I'm around the area quite a bit. I discovered this little gem after teaching and was looking for a healthy lunch since I've been on a massive veggie detox (well, hoping to stay 80% of the year on this "detox"). I am so excited to have found a good salad/healthy wrap place in Singapore with crisp veggies. My favorite thing on the menu is the imitation crab wrap. I get it with a tomato wrap. The dressing, the veggies, egg, imitation crab, and toasted tomato wrap makes this such a good eat. The downside to this place is actually the price. $9 for a wrap and $10 for a salad!?! I've also tried their caesar wrap with chicken (was ok..), smoothie w/ mango (was refreshing). This location is also pretty chill and clean. The service is friendly and you definitely don't feel rushed eating here.

address: No 1, Fusionopolis Way #01-03Fusionopolis Connexis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: Yep. Expensive but dependable. The people working here tend to be really nice. The breakfast burritos are cheaper and good.

Was here for a business luncheon with 10pax. Staff/Service: Was poor at best. Staff were either looking a bit lost, or not able to multitask and prioritize what's important. Crowd was minimal as it's lunch hour. Staff took about 15mins to attend and seat us. Atmosphere: As a large group with 10pax, restaurant wasn't able to accomodate us indoor, so had no choice but to sit outdoors. Which is still quite alright, except for the occasional flies and mosquitoes. Food:The food was above average. Soup of Lobster Bisquete was exceptionally good, rich in flavor and filling. Mains like the pasta, chicken and fish were all above average as well. Pricing: Reasonable for a lunch offer. Overall: Might be better to come to this place at night, with prior reservation depending on whether you want indoor dining or outdoor dining. The outdoor decor is quite a unique concept, and seem to encourage more chillout sessions than actual meals. Will still go back to this place when important meetings and dinner arises, but definitely not for lunch on a hot or rainy day.

We came here for Valentines and it was a-ok. The atmosphere was very serene, quiet, and pristine- with abundance of seating indoors and outdoors- but the food was sub par. I've expected higher quality dishes for supposedly a 'nice' restaurant. I'd love to come here to grab a drink though on a random night. Make sure to reserve a seat for outside because that's where One Rochester's beauty lies!

address: 1 Lower Kent Ridge Rd #01-19/20 One@KentRidge Singapor 119082 Singapore
comment: Nasi Lemak fast casual chain. Solidly good nasi lemak - fragrant rice with lots of accompaniments: chicken, fish, otah, sambal, etc.Would recommend for a quick lunch

address: 1 Lower Kent Ridge Rd #01-19/20 One@KentRidge Singapor 119082 Singapore
comment: This is the franchised version of the legendary Adam Road Nasi Lemak.  What I've noticed is that there is some noticeable variation in the quality of the very same offerings at different franchise locations.  This one is pretty decent, but the rice is a little off and sometimes a little sticky.  I'm pointing this out because the loose fluffy Basmati rice is always alluded to when referencing Adam Road Nasi Lemak.   For me, it's the rice and the chili condiment which for me is almost a coulis (see my review of the mother ship at Adam Road), that really distinguishes this offering making it the "Nasi Lemak of Sultans".Actually, they've just opened for business at the time of this writing and they still have time to get the rice right...not an insurmountable challenge.Otherwise, this outlet is like all the others, offering a pretty decent approximation of what you might expect from the Adam Road source code. I would still recommend that you make the trek to Adam Road, stand in line and sample the original before assessing the quality of the offerings at any of the growing number of Crave outlets.  It's not that hard to get to...it's a 5 min stroll from the Botanic Gardens MRT station.  I highly recommend this low-hanging food pilgrimage.I do wish this CRAVE outlet at One@KentRidge all the very best!  I hope they end up doing what the two other predecessors that occupied this same space couldn't...stay in business and prosper!  Good luck, CRAVE One@KentRidge, we need you stay open!!

address: 1 Lower Kent Ridge Rd #01-19/20 One@KentRidge Singapor 119082 Singapore
comment: Mediocre lunch for a somewhat acceptable price, but if you're already on campus you can find cheaper and tastier food in many other places!

This is a well kept secret of Rochester Mall. When I cross the road from Star Vista after church, I wanted to visit this place some time ago.Finally got to visit this restaurant on a Sunday evening. Was attracted by how this place blends between the modern facade of Rochester Mall and a colonial style building at its backyard. The restaurant is a small quaint single storey building. You can choose to dine in the interior brick styled cottage, or at the outdoor alfresco area, much like the Starbucks next door. But I bet it's much more beautiful sitting outdoor from 7pm onwards with candles on your tables. It has that peaceful quiet ambience in this place. In the inside, they play jazz music or Italian sopranos. It's a perfect place for small family gatherings or a couple of friends gathering. Ok time to get on the food. If you visit this place as a couple, I strongly recommend trying Spaghetti Al Cartoccio (for 2 pax) for a start. It's an assortment of seafood and spaghetti baked in parchment with tomato sauce and basil. It may look like a simple dish but the pasta and seafood inside the parchment just brings out the flavor in a much more natural enhancing way than any MSG could. The sauce is superb and very much on par as Pasta Brava, but with a more homely touch. Portion is good for two. It's good for gatherings too as you add on more dishes. The Zuppa Alla Marinara is also a good dish to try out! A thick tomato sauce or white wine sauce with seafood. Yummy!Tagliere Mix, Saumi or Formaggi with the cheese that's specially imported from Italy. The pizzas here I heard are a favorite. The kids will love it. If you're looking for anothe romantic dinner or weekend family dinner that is peaceful, close to the nature and Italian food as authentic as it could be, you shouldn't hesitate to give this place a shot. This has to be one of my top 3 Italian restaurants in Singapore. (I only try those with a realistic price.) *wink*
They used to make very good pasta but recently something changed and now everything tastes like frozen instant pasta.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way, #02-20/21 Fusionoplis, Connexis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: Not many japanese restaurants around this area making it a natural destination for sushi lovers. I ordered the Chasu Ramen set - excellent presentation and absolutely delicious. I saw someone on the adjacent table order a Tempura Set - have to admit it looked much much better. Perhaps next time around.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way, #02-20/21 Fusionoplis, Connexis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: This is the only Japanese restaurant in Fusionopolis and we're very lucky to have it. They serve very well-presented dishes, we've been surprised a few times. On a few occasions when I was trying to act healthy, I ordered their salad. Anything with avocado or salmon is good. Their salads are fresh and crunchy, and also come with a bit of fish roe on top - so pretty. I love their cold soba. My favourite order is the tempura cold soba set. It comes with miso soup and a portion of fruits - usually watermelon and orange. The cold soba is of the perfect consistency, and the accompanying sauce is great for dipping and slurping. The sauce is clean and refreshing, it doesn't stay in your mouth like some soy sauce, it leaves your mouth with a delightful tinge.Other items like the tempura rice set (generous WOW serving of tempura) and cheesy omu rice were great too. Ramen was so-so though.And yes they serve iced water. Faith in restaurants restored.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way, #02-20/21 Fusionoplis, Connexis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: Had lunch treat from boss and he suggested Jap lunch here. I ordered the Tom yam Ramen and it was a pleasant surprise as the spices were pretty authentic. The lemongrass was pounded to release a good flavour and the Chilli was spicy enough to do the term 'Tom yam' justice. I enjoyed the soup base totally and would return with another Tom Yam fan in tow.

address: 1 Fusionopolis Way, #02-20/21 Fusionoplis, Connexis Tower Singapore 138632 Singapore
comment: I think Sushi Tei is both cheaper and better, although I suppose this place has the advantage of no line.
