I had a pretty nice experience here, stopped in for a couple of drinks after work. The service was pretty good, attentive and knowledgeable. They had nice happy hour pricing, including 15% off a bottle of wine, and then letting us keep the wine there to finish later like a liquor bottle service. We had the Mezze Platter which was nice, there were many other items on the menu that looked particularly good, but passed on them to get back for dinner at home. That will have to be planned better next time :)

So looking for a place that just has everything? People watching Outdoorsy Drinks Food Live band Check check and double check So they pretty much have everything here.. Touted as an Australian restaurant, the Aussie friendliness is definitely from their wait staff. Had the pork snail sausages and a couple of sharing platters which involved calamari - awesome, wings - Okaaay and truffle fries - I still don't get it... They still taste like fries Friends had the fish and chips and spatchcock.. Came in huge platings and portions were awesome but nothing to rave about except for their cute and cheeky waiters. Outdoors is hot and humid if there's no wind and the benches and tables feel like they haven't been sanitized in a while - the icky wood feeling Though friendly, our bill took a while to arrive when asked..we were busy plotting of running off and were counting down when they finally appeared. But who can stay mad at the cutesies who gave us the bill? Aaaawwwww. Awesome marketing, Barossa and your saving grace....

Two and a half stars, if I could give that.Food was meh and service was mixed. Some staff blur, and some friendly and cheery.Let me also explain the not-very-clearly-advertised happy hour. It's 6-8pm and you can get either a 1-for-1 half pint (a $2 savings) or if you buy a full-priced pint, you get 3 teeny tiny Lilliputian angus beef sliders.The meats were decent, but nothing to write home about. (Actually the sliders tasted the best!)Starters/bar bites: Stay away from the fried calamari, unless you like your fried calamari to have a hot, doughy batter on the outside, and a cold, stringy squid ring on the inside. In which case, go right ahead.The Mezze Platter: not great, unfortunately. It's advertised as including Jamon Iberico, and I'm not sure about you, but that sure don't look like Jamon Iberico to me. (See photo). Maybe some other jamon. Maybe proscuitto. Baba ghanoush looked unusually chunky but tasted nice. The salami was some of the least tasty salami I've had the pleasure of tasting. Boo. I like salami!So anyway, maybe a nice place for beer and sliders.

Wandering through Holland village, wanting some western food, this place is nicely situated on a corner so if you're on your own, as I was, you can watch the world go by. The menu is ok, nothing special, I had a big pork chop, it had a long poncy title that I don't remember now, which for some reason had an apricot thing on it and a minute pot of runny BBQ sauce. The fries, of course we're served before the main course - Singapore can't deliver food to your table in one go, they just don't get it. So, I sent that back, the server was really surprised that I wanted everything bought to me in one go, very strange. Anyway, they turned up with the main course, but were cold, so obviously the same ones. They were the garlic fries, so that's all I could taste for the next few hours, which is just as well because the pork was dry and bland. I had 2 small beers with that and the bill came to almost $80 which is ridiculous. I hide the steaks are better, sounds like there is love music sometimes which is nice and they have EPL on the big screen so that's OK. Service was slow and uninterested, food was bland and expensive. Worth a visit but don't expect much.

Ok let's start.... Food is good....with a friend can not eat potatoes tells waiter, please no potato with my sausages....waiter agrees....food comes... Wow that looks like potato.... Waiter says it's not potato its gratin.... We are puzzled must be a be infused gratin with no potato....we ask him to talk to the kitchen he comes back and says sorry it's potato...so much for the infused gratin... We laugh and move on... Nice place, nice food one suggestion talk to the kitchen and all will be good....

Great service from the staff, even when there was a promotion going on. Excellent steaks and amazing side dishes. Had their buffet twice when it was on offer, but would definitely have it more often even if it was for the normal price. Great choice for a celebration with friends and loved ones

address: 44 Jalan Merah Saga #01-60, Chip Bee Gardens Holland Village Singapore 278116 Singapore
comment: Pan fried barramundi ($42++=$50) - 2.5 starsToo dry and didn't taste fresh. Too expensive for the quality.Crab and lobster tortellini/ravioli ($36++) - 2.5 starsFlavor wasn't impressive I could barely taste the crab or lobster.Spaghetti with mussels ($26++) - 3 starsNot bad but the mussels were a bit tough so it's 3 stars for me.Service - 5 starsThis was the best part. The waitresses were excellent!Ambience - 4 starsMostly because it's quiet!This place is definitely overpriced without a 1-for-1 and even after I probably wouldn't go back.

address: 44 Jalan Merah Saga #01-60, Chip Bee Gardens Holland Village Singapore 278116 Singapore
comment: I've spent Friday evening there for a dinner with my partner and we've had ordered the 1kg florentine steak, rucola salad and a pizza to share. The rucola salad was full of pepper and barely any Parmesan shaved strips were added on it. The florentine steak was delivered medium - well done, even though we've had asked for medium - rare. This wasn't the big issue.We started eating and noticed that actually half of the steak is pure big chunks of fat and only half of it is meat. Not mentioning the bones, as this is standard. So, 1 kg minus the bones and minus the fats is actually maybe 300 g of meat for 120 $.We made the waitress aware of the amounts of fat, but she wasn't impressed by it and brought it back to the kitchen. The chief waitress and the cook inspected it and discussed something amongst each other and then there was no reply.As we were still hungry we went on and ordered a Pizza Napoli, red sauce with buffalo mozzarella. I for sure know that the pizza delivered wasn't buffalo mozzarella for a whopping prize of 26$. Afterwards we asked for the bill and it was brought to us by the chief waitress and we were charged the full prize for the Florentine steak. Even though she had seen the big chunks of fats and had discussed with the waitress who had picked up the dishes from our table, she insisted that she didn't know anything about it.I asked for the person in charge as I would like to discuss this, and she said she's the person in charge.I told her that I saw her looking at the plate with her colleagues and discussing it, how come she doesn't know about it!?! She went back, don't know what she discussed with her colleague again, came back and offered to give us a 15% discount of the steak. That's the best she could do. She will discuss with her vendor for the meat and will make sure that it doesn't happen again....(as it helps me anything on my experience)! I didn't want to make it a big fuzz, as it's obvious that she doesn't care about honest customer service. We paid and surely didn't want the 10$ vouchers as we are not coming back to this place again.The total bill came to 190 $.....In our opinion it's a rip off, low quality food, badly prepared with low quality ingredient, over priced and on top not honest. Don't go there, and look for alternatives....

address: 44 Jalan Merah Saga #01-60, Chip Bee Gardens Holland Village Singapore 278116 Singapore
comment: Came here for a 1-for-1 promotion and our party of 6 ordered various pastas. We had Frutti de Mare, Vongola, Rigatoni Sausage, Cacciatore and the Bromia Pizza. My friends all raved about their selections, all said very very good! I'll explain mine in more details... I'm a seafood marinara person. Default choice anywhere and theirs didn't disappoint. Fresh seafood and generous in amount too. Pasta was also cooked till al dente which has a slight Q in it. Some place cooked their pasta till it's too soft. The tomato base sauce is not from a can, and if it is, the processing that went into it is damn power then. I'll buy THAT type of can sauce any day! It's not tangy and full of the sweetness of the seafood that went into it. A hearty portion too so a girl like me with a healthy appetite is smiling to my last mouthful. Will return again to cash in the 1-for-1 deal soon!!!

address: 44 Jalan Merah Saga #01-60, Chip Bee Gardens Holland Village Singapore 278116 Singapore
comment: located in chip bee gardens, enclave of the expat and yummy-mummy, this restaurant serves up rustico italiano - a direct translation (and language massacre, my apologies) of what I fancy is rustic italian home-cooking. it's surprisingly good too, considering the lack of reviews and the empty tables we arrived to at lunchtime.we were sat quickly - word to the wise, don't do the al fresco unless you're a sun-starved foreigner: the sweltering heat isn't kind at noon - amidst our choice of table in an empty restaurant, and our orders were taken quickly. there's a lunch set, but I don't find that particularly good value given the mains are mostly meatless pastas (why? just, why?) - so stick with the à la carte.interestingly, the food is cooked up by an indian chef - not quite what you'd expect, but expertise isn't necessarily home-grown, eh? our calamari came decently well-fried and tender, though the batter was a touch greasier than I would have wanted, and tended to separate from the seafood. I would have preferred a chunkier, spicier marinara too, but that's personal preference.the mains were most surprising - both our squid ink risotto and sausage penne had a depth of flavor you might not have expected, so savory and umami-filled it almost seemed too salty (which it wasn't).they don't look like big portions, but they are wholly filling and satisfying - it's interesting to note also that there was rather more sausage than noodle in our pasta dish (which is not an often-seen phenomenon), and the risotto was supplemented rather generously with fresh squid rings and prawns.we finished with a dessert of tiramisu (what else?) - and this was a more than decent rendition, served with boozy brandied cherries and a drizzle of coffee syrup across the plate. it's also not a particularly wet tiramisu (which I might prefer, actually) - you can see that the biscuits are just soaked-enough to provide a sturdy foundation.it's not cheap - this is holland village, after all, but the prices are competitive with other in-town italian establishments. it's more than worth a visit, and a pasta per person makes for a good, decent lunch.

address: 44 Jalan Merah Saga #01-60, Chip Bee Gardens Holland Village Singapore 278116 Singapore
comment: This area of Holland V used to house some of the better Italian restaurants in Singapore. While the Italian dining scene in the country has vastly improved, the quality in this neighbourhood has gone down a lot. Risotto tartufo is soggy - avoid! Tortellini with crab and lobster - our guest left it unfinished. Raviolis - below average. The waiting staff is nice, but forgot one order. Why bother, especially when prices are above average?

address: 44 Jalan Merah Saga #01-60, Chip Bee Gardens Holland Village Singapore 278116 Singapore
comment: Lamb shank came out icy inside. Rest of meal was meh. Unacceptable really. Service was ok, nothing the service staff could do about it but the chef didnt seem too apologetic. There are many good italian places in SG, this one just does not cut it.

I tried almost every dish on the menu and everything was amazing! I love how the flavors are a new take on traditional dishes. Everything was great.Brussel sprouts: super crispy on the outside with a moist center! Just perfect. Had a bit of sweetness but cooked with bacon so extra delicious Crab potato roasti: the crab meat was well seasoned and fresh, the potatoes were crispy and the whole dish just worked!Roast duck: fantastic dish. Large bites of moist duck with crispy skinPork belly: another amazing dish. Perfectly prepared and so tender!Everything was amazing!

Borrow wine erase worry! I had the char grilled eel and low temp. egg burger as well as the 'homemade radish cake'. Who new radishes could be so good? The dishes were totally delicious.  So good, I'd love to go back and sample every item on the menu. A casual, inventive Asian eatery that serves good wine and sparkling too.  The excellent friendly service elevates this great brunch spot to standout!#singaporebrunch

We had a company set lunch comprising of sharing platter of crispy otah otah, Hainanese chicken cutlets and then mains of salad with salmon sashimi with white sesame dressing and crispy fish skin and avocado mash and then Ayam pengat with fried egg and achar. Dessert was coconut tau huay with Gula Melaka sago, honey ice cream and cookie crumble. Too much food for one pax to be honest. They could have advised our Organiser. Food was ok. Not bad but Not any extraordinary. Won't be back on my own accord when there's too many New places to check out.

The atmosphere/vibe of this restaurant is absolutely beautiful. I went there with my mother for a lunch course, but there were business lunches and friend lunches happening alongside us so it is perfect for any occasion. The dishes were explained in detailed and the staff were very professional and friendly. Absolutely loved the soup and the cute starter cones.Would definitely come back again (reasonable price too!)

Cosy restaurant, but tables are space out enough so is great for business lunches. I am not sure how to describe the meal except that it's just *right*. It doesn't go over the top or fun or seem like it's actually trying to wow you, and I wasn't really feeling much till I saw the food and took a bite. And then I paused and was like, huh this is goooood. It's really odd because the meals I enjoy most tend to be very fun or creative, but I had a lot of appreciation here in a different way. Well prepared, well executed, just right. I am not sure how else to describe the experience, but the word "right".

I was at the restaurant with Rahul (review below) and have to second everything that has been said. It is a great ambience and vibe, and the team there could was incredibly keen to ensure we had a favorable experience. Thank you Jerome and team. Desserts were incredible. I enjoyed mine more than Rahul's (I believe I had a mousse of sorts), but sharing is caring - so I shared the wealth (and the calories). Highly recommended.

An intimate fine dining restaurant with creative dishes.I expected Rhubarb to be a traditional French restaurant. I ordered the set menu for dinner paired with red wine. Overall, the dishes were surprisingly tasty! The foie gras entrée was the fish that amazed me the most. Usually in France we do not mix foie gras with fish, or we try to be minimal when it comes to foie gras. The foie gras from Rhubarb was served with Japanese radish, another type of radish, fish (estragon maybe?) and some sweet jelly. The foie gras was very tender. Pairings all of these ingredients together made the dish heavenly! The dishes in general felt like eating a work of culinary art (well, probably expected from a fine dining restaurant). As of the main, I got the Wagyu beef medium rare with melted in my mouth. It was served with an emulsion of some sort, with snails at the bottom. The snails were very soft and tasty. Don't be shy to eat snails, I promise this side will make you like them! The set menu has many dishes (1 amuse bouche, 3 entrées, 1 main and 1 desert).The restaurant offers an great atmosphere with an intimate ambiance. There were only approximately 6 tables, so you should reserve in advance. The kitchen is also open. The service was great too.Bottom line, I understand why this restaurant has a Michelin star. Food, service, atmosphere.

Rhubarb le Restarant is a must go. Every dish is beautifully presented and executed. The highlights were the bread, white onion emulsion, foie gras served with rhubarb (I really never knew that rhubarb could be so tasty!) and hay flavoured ice cream. They state that the entire table must participate in 'le menu' but the chef did not enforce that so we tried the dinner menu and some ala carte items.Besides the food, we really loved the modern decor and the small setting. I highly recommend Rhubarb le restaurant. Did I mention that it is a must go?

Another lunch at a Michelin star restaurant. This was french cuisine and we tried the prix fixe menu. Started off with an amuse bouche in the form of an onion emulsion.. what can i say, it knocked us out of the park.. the flavors were incredible. I had the beef tartare with foie grais as my appetizer which was excellent! Followed that up with Japanese mackerel with chorizo which was heavenly and finished up with farm cheese plate which was great. Would have expected a bit more finesse in terms of dessert options, hope they put that up soon! Service was impeccable. Great place to celebrate an occasion as well!

Rhubarb is a small French restaurant on Duxton Hill that would be easy to miss which would be a shame, as the kitchen produces some truly beautiful and tasty dishes.  They also have a great lunch set at a reasonable price which is an excellent way to experience the potential of the kitchen, which is what we did on a rainy afternoon.  We started with an amuse buche - hamachi in cones, which reminded me of Spago.  The appetizer of cured Japanese mackerel was stunning, as it was cured in rhubarb, it was red and reminded me of an actual rhubarb stalk.  For the main, the pork loin was quite thick yet still succulent, and the mousseline of smoked potato added a nice touch.  As petit fours are served with coffee, I opted for a cheese plate for dessert, which was perfect.  Service is excellent, and the wine list has a well-picked selection of mainly French wines including a nice number of half bottles.  Definitely an experience you won't regret and worth a splurge!

My admission was that from previous French Restaurants, where I paid over $100++ and was still hungry, I was skeptical.But to my surprise, the portion sizes, and food options were spot on.Not too many, and those, where the ingredients I couldn't consume such as dairy/grans/carbs, the staff advised that it could be removed, or served on the side.We ordered Quail and my buddy ordered a beef. I though the beef was a bit more generic, but again, I was pleasantly surprised.Smoothly smokey, woody, and flavoured. My quail was wrapped in veggies, so both birds were killed with one stone....well, nutritionally  : )Impeccable chocolate desserts, we ordered 2 varieties between us, and were just impressed with every bite.I strongly recommend this place!

We were here in April to celebrate an anniversary and were thoroughly impressed with the level of detail and thought that went into every aspect of the dinner service.This is a small restaurant, and there is a cap to the number of person per table. The kitchen is an open concept, and yet the establishment managed to maintain a calm ambience.  The food was excellent, and we enjoyed every course from the set menu. The chef (and sous chefs) came to the table to explain most of the dishes. They were flexible and innovative in meeting some requests, as one of us had a medical condition. The wait staff and front of house deserve a very special mention, they were all extremely professional, attentive, and friendly. We had such a great time, and will certainly be back.

An amazing dining experience. It starts with exceptional food that confidently boasts a merger of flavors and textures that are not typically associated with French but that's only because it reaches across genres of cuisines. Chef is innovative and passionate and enjoys his personal touch with customers as he personally brought out my entree and explained the evolution of the dish which was superb. Only 7 tables in the restaurant and they ensure that you feel special and have a memorable experience. An outstanding evening altogether. A must when you're in Singapore.
The food was outstanding and innovative.  Great complement to the level of service. A great place for a great meal with a small group or romantic dinner.

I would have to say this is probably the best Italian restaurant in Singapore. I lived across street from their original place in east coast.  It's so nice to see they haven't lost their touch. Food is amazing.  Service is spot on. Staff well versed in the menu and attentive. After being stuck in USA for 2 years with pandemic I'm so happy this place survived. If you want amazing authentic Italian in Singapore, this is the place.  Shout to Eevon for making my home coming amazing. Beautiful old style Singapore neighborhood.Must try if you want to experience how it might feel having Angels  dancing on your tongue. Order this. Garganelli all' Agnello e PecorinoGarganelli pasta in braised lamb sauce and Pecorino cheese.
Ottimo! We were taken out by some clients and the whole restaurant staff treated us well. Will definitely come back the next time I am in Singapore.

The food is excellent here.The beef carpaccio appetizer was very good, as was the pork in marsala sauce.The tiramisu is outstanding, among the best that I have ever had.However, the level of service, for a restaurant of this price range, does leave a bit to be desired.Once they bring you the food, they never return a few moments later to make sure that everything is ok, or to check on whether you need anything.I should not really complain about the service as it is slightly above the usual abysmally low level of service in the food industry for which Singapore is notorious.I challenge any Singaporean to debate me on this issue.

I was happy to choose Etna for celebration of my husband's birthday!  I asked the restaurant to bring a cake for him as surprise in advance and staff did a good job!Also, the food, atmosphere and staff's hospitality are really nice.  We had salad with mozzarella cheese, today's pizza which used lots of vegetable and looks very colorful! and lasagna.  All of them were very delicious and the portion was just well. I felt Etna can be used for various situation such as for couple, girls night out or casual business dinner with reasonable price.

Etna offers fantastic Italian food in a nice setting, for days you'd like to treat yourself. I tried the Eggplant Pizza, one of their homemade pastas, and the calamari and shared among my group of 3. I found it to be just the right amount of food for us.

Just a quick one from me for this review.The atmosphere was pretty good here. Had a nice dinner with my sister and girlfriend. Yoi could have a nice conversation and it felt cozy. So a 5/5 for atmosphere. The food was a 3.5. My sisters lamb pasta (forgotten to which type) was excellent one of the specials of the evening. I had the pizza which said ham, but when it came out it was prosciutto which was very unexpected and threw me a little as I don't generally enjoy that on pizza. My girlfriend had soft shell crab linguine which according to her wasn't great.In summary I would give it another try with different meals.

First visit to etna for dinner and I am abit undecided on this place. Had their calamari and beef carpaccio for appetisers, linguine al granchio and snapper for mains paired with merlot and sparkling. Whilst we were off to a great start with their impressive appetisers, mains were a tad disappointing. There was nothing spectacular about their al granchio and it was served up with a crab claw. I may be demanding on this but I did not foresee getting my hands dirty trying to peel the meat off the crab in a fancy Italian restaurant. Snapper was fresh with a delectable capsicum sauce but it is not something I would specially head back to a restaurant for. Their service staff were friendly but I expected more attention to details. Overall, it was good but not great. I would head back again just to try out their lunch menu and coffee though.
Amazing calzone, superb service, really nice ambiance. Best Italian food I've had outside Italy

Meh. I don't think I'll come here again. Well, maybe? From the reviews, I thought this place would be fantastic but I was not impressed. We ordered the four items: 1. Burrata di Andria con Rucola, Pomodorini Pachino e Prosciutto di Parma 2. Wrapped and baked cod (Chef's special)3. Etna Pizza4. TiramisuThe burrata was fresh and the bf really enjoyed eating it with the parma ham but I wasn't too impressed. I enjoyed the burrata at La Latteria (basically across the street) much more. The baked cod was very disappointed. It wasn't fresh and barely tasted like fish! The Etna was definitely worth it! It came with parma ham and chunks of QUALITY mozzarella cheese! The pizzas were rather big so I suggest ordering just one to share. Maybe include an appetizer and some wine? You'll be good to go! As for the tiramisu, you MUST, MUST order it! The desserts are all made in house and the tiramisu was simply divine! The only dish I would die and come back for! It was covered in crushed pistachios, but special pistachios that are grown only in three parts of the world: Sicily, Israel, and Iran. So worth it! So DELLICCIOUSSS!! Service was alright, but, seriously, that tiramisu...*sigh*

Had dinner with my co workers here. Ambiance- very cozy, warm and intimate. The tables are situated close to each other thou the pace is not packed when we went there so it didnt feel as crowded.Service- the manager (or the owner?) is very attentive and give good recommendations. Thou the wait staff can have more training over attentiveness. We waited a while before someone took our order.Food- Most of what we ordered were the specials of the day. The food is mostly for sharing. I highly recommend considering the specials of the day for great selections.Price- a bit on the pricey side. Thou the pizza is reasonably priced, the appetizer and mains are a bit pricey.Overall great experience and would recommend to give it a try

I had had dinner at a restaurant earlier and left that restaurant still hungry, which isn't a good sign for me. I wandered into Etna as it had been on my list of places to go. It was very cutesy decorated and brought back memories of my honeymoon to Italy! It was about 8pm on a Wednesday night, the place was quite busy, and I was seated promptly. I was recommended a delicious Sicilian Cabernet and the mushroom pasta, and I have no regrets! They paired very well together! The mushroom ragout was very savory, which I love, and the portion size was perfect for me. I can't wait to go back and sample more of their delicious cuisine!

Decent home style Italian place. It packs a busy crowd and you should definitely make reservation.The burrata appetizer is great. Most of the pasta were homemade. I didn't quite enjoy my pasta with truffle cream, porcini mushrooms and sausages. I usually dig anything with porcini and truffle, but the pasta is too thick for me, and the mushroom taste is overpowered. The other crab pasta was better but I prefer Valentino's version much better.Price point was very good. You get good value for money.Servings are a little on the big side so feel free to order to share. We wanted to order two appetizers to go with our two pastas and was advised by our server to just go with one appetizer. Good call as that left me with a tiny bit of stomach to have their dessert and a little cup of limoncello on the house. Woohoo.Service was great, warm and friendly. They made you feel that you are dining in a friend's home. The owner came over to ask if it was our first time here and how did we hear about them. I said YELP!

Disappointed with their level of service. Food was served more than an hour after we ordered. Orders were mixed up. Wait staff don't smile at customers. Food is priced too high but food quality is mediocre. The place is also very noisy. I tried to keep an open mind and look for good things about this restaurant, but could not find one.
Recommended! Delicious food, nice wines, great service. Couldn't ask for anything else.
Good service.  Nice atmosphere.  Very well prepared food.  Spendy, but you get what you pay for.

fantastic italian execution (not the head sort) at this packed restaurant in chinatown. reservations much required - tables run out quickly, and the place is well popular even on weekdays. it's been lauded as a great place to grab some italian and lives up to that reputation (living up to reputation seems to be a problem these days), with good service and reasonably prices.it spans that rather comfortable spectrum of cosy enough for date night but bright enough for family night, and the good food helps conversations flow.I'm not a huge fan of the mostly carb-heavy cuisine, but this side of it is right up my alley. lots of fresh seafood and ingredients simply done up and plated without too much fuss, enough to show detail and attention, but not enough that my food gets cold.it's also a fair portion size (barring the fish, which we'll talk about later), and I've realised recently how important this is for me. I've grown rather tired of poncy food in small dabs and dibs on a spartan place (unless it's truly meant to be that way - and what does that even mean?), and I want very much to feel satisfied and happy at the end of a meal.it was a meal of three starters and one main - and for good reason. the starters sounded more interesting and more creative than the mains (which were mostly plates of some seared meat-or-other), and were also cheaper (perhaps two or three starters were equivalent to one entree) - and they turned out that way too.we started with insalata mediterranea di verdure alla griglia, a warm salad of grilled grins topped with a light creamy cheese sauce and caramelized walnuts. I loved the sweet tender pumpkin with the crunchy nuts - and even though I usually eschew rich sauces, this was very tasty.and then the rather transcendental calamari alla griglia, or grilled squid coils with a lovely chop of garlic and herbs. delicious, plain delicious. seafood sweet and tender, these were salted just right and utterly fantastic.we had to round off the starters with some bruschette (it does, after all, take up a fair half page in the menu), and ended up with the etna, which had a slice each topped with chopped tomatoes, a grilled eggplant slice, parma ham and a slab of mozzarella. alright - but perhaps the most average dish we had. it was just a bit of toast with stuff, and not wholly inspiring (though the cheese was good).our nominal main was the day's special of salt-roasted fish, a slim specimen of a white type simply roasted with large grains of salt and served alongside a small salad. it was well cooked (and I don't mean doneness), with the flesh flaking off with a slight push - but it was also the most expensive dish at more-than-sixty for a slip of a fish, and not quite worth it considering what we had got as starters.it's definite that we had to finish with something sweet, and this time we had two. a tiramisu al pistacchio di bronte was a green layered rich concoction, with a very mild pistachio flavor - but at least it wasn't too sweet. a delizia al ciccolato was less interesting, and not flowy so much as moist - but it came with some delicious pistachio ice cream.I haven't mentioned service, and it was pretty good: just friendly enough without being unobtrusive, and they knew how to handle the crowds and seat people efficiently. price are very reasonable for the quality of food, though that statement holds truer for everything but the mains - and I'll be back to give some of their lauded pizzas a go.
If I could, I would eat their pistachio tiramisu every single day. The best tiramisu in Singapore. The restaurant also ignited my passion for gnocchi and other pasta.

I'd been to the one at East Coast Road before, and while the service was excellent, the food I tried was mediocre. This time around, however, it was the food that was great and the service was decent but nothing to write home about. The waitresses were nice and polite, but I didn't feel I could chat or really talk to them, which is fine, but a more casual approach would be nice. That being said, the restaurant does look a lot classier than the one in East Coast, so I guess they're catering to a different crowd who doesn't talk to service stuff much. Who knows. I had the Penne Arrabiatta ($18), which was just spicy enough and the pasta was cooked just nice in the traditional Italian al dente way. Too many places here sell out and overcook their pasta because that's what most locals prefer, so I like places like Etna and Modesto's who stick to their guns and serve it how it should be served. I also tried the Bruschetta ($8.50), which was really yummy. Bruschetta seems so simple but it's so easy to go wrong with it; Etna got it just right. I can't recall the name of the wine, but the red house pour was really good and went perfectly with the meal. By the time I was done with this, there was no room in my belly for desert, so I gave that a miss. Either way, the pasta and wine is ACE. :)

The lasagna was excellent. The pizzas are thin and crispy. The ravioli were small but good. The tiramisu was great.One downside was that they took the burrata appetizer off the menu. Another is the prices, which are high. The burrata pizza (32++) doesn't have mozzarella other than strips of burrata which are added at the end, so it is colder than a typical pizza.

Very good Italian food hidden away in a shop house on Duxton Road.  Service is always exceptional and the food is always just what it should be.  Straightforward high quality Italian dishes. I have been here 5-6 times (always for lunch) and am never dissappointed.  The weekday set lunch menu is a good bargain.  The small dining room is simple (maybe a little on the dull side) but tasteful with white table cloths and cloth napkins.  I wish they could knock out the wall between the two rooms to make it a larger more interesting dining area. The wood fired pizza oven is at the rear of the dining room in full view.  Highly recommend Etna for both food and the attentive service.
Excellent service, excellent food, friendly atmosphere. Real Italian chefs! I've been a regular for 5 years. Try their Tiramisu -- it's the best in Singapore!

Cute small trattoria! Nothing super classy, which is a good change in singapore where a lot of good restaurants seem to have a classy/chic ambiance. Etna has a very warm and  'at home' feel. I ordered the pizza con funghi e salsiccia. It was HUGE, recommend sharing it. It was soooo good too. I ordered the tiramisu for dessert and the prosciutto con melone as a starter. The owner/chef is actually italian from Florence, very friendly guy :)
Calamari- awesomeCaesar salad - excellentRavioli w/Walnuts & quatro frommage - fantastic.Even the pizza was very good.Go for sure!!

Just went for their food and wine pairing event. For 98 bucks, you get a five course meal with wine (from Sicily) pairings. I have to admit that the pairings were fabulous. The meals chosen really complimented the wines! A couple of the dishes were underwhelming, but other dishes were pretty good. Definitely a good bang for the buck!

PROS:-the famous Etna Pizza was fabulous! A real MUST try! my friends and I all loved it!-The restaurant manager took the time off to talk to us, which is quite rare, especially in Singapore.-They serve free bread with olive oil and vinegar as an appetiser, which was a plus for hungry ravens like my friends and I.-They serve mostly regular Italian dishes, but they do it well I suppose. However, I had their lasagne and I reckon the Starbucks lasagne is just as good (at half the price).-Ambience is very nice and cosy, like your typical upmarket Italian restaurant-DBS/POSB cardholders get 10% off!CONS:-Portions for the prices were quite small, especially for the meats ($30 +++)-Location is quite out-of-the-way-We were given a time-limit to eat; reservation was at 7.30pm and they told us we had to leave by 8.45pm... it's pretty pressurising :/

A nice, cosy authentic Italian restaurant (sits about 20-30 people). We had been there a couple of times but our best meal was when the Italian chef/owner was in the house :) She came out host us personally, taking our orders and making recommendations of dishes that weren't on the menu. Basically, anything she felt like making... and we loved it! I especially enjoyed the Pan fried mozzarella! It wasn't too salty/oily like the one I had at Ristorante Pietrasanta (that one was BAD. avoid at all cost.) After the meal, the chef treated us to some wonderful rosolio liqueur that she personally brought back from the motherland. There were so many flavors & they all came in beautifully colored bottles (so pretty I wanted to keep them all). Don't underestimate the rosolio liqueurs! They may come in a small shot glass but they sure pack a punch! Think of them as mini tequila shots with a much nicer taste (some fruity, others nutty). The food 1. Calamari (grilled) - Ok. I prefer my squids fried. 2. Pan fried mozzarella - LOVE IT!!!3. Prawns - LOVE IT!!! It was so fresh, sweet and juicy. Served steamed (the best way to preserve the natural sweetness of its meat). 4. Crispy pitta-like bread (with a selection of dips) - LOVE IT!!! Despite their house bread not making the cut, their pitta-like bread won me over. I could snack on these babies all day. 5. Spagetti vongole - Good. 6. Spagetti with crab meat (tomato base) - Good. Popular dish here. Almost every table orders it. They are very generous with the crab meat and rich tomato sauce. 7. Steak - Good. Soft & tender. Served with a good sauce as well. Small portion though. 8. Pistácio tiramisu cake - LOVE IT. I love Pistácio flavored desserts (most of the time) as it gives any dish a little nutty kick to it. 9. Lava cake - Good. The service: ExcellentThe ambianceYou'll feel like you are dining in your Italian's friend's dining room. All the decoration (plates with drawings on them) are from Italy. The owners have brought a piece of their Italian culture/heritage to share :)
Amazing food and service! They have lots of options for vegetarians. Their Tiramusu dessert is delicious!

Went there on a Friday night and was greeted by the jolly Italian owner. Despite not having a reservation, my partner and I managed to grab a lovely table for 2 by the window. The owner quickly regaled us with interesting facts about the daily specials, which included 2 fish dishes (sea bass and cod) and a pizza tipped with burrata. He enthusiastically educated us on the difference between run of the mill and burrata, replete with a thick Italian accent.

I have visited Etna a couple of times since a friend introduced it to me late last year. And it really never disappoints.I really like the starters and the mains that I have tried so far but I am not a fan of their desserts so I would give that a miss the next time I eat here. The burrata was great. Fresh and absolutely yummy. The etna pizza was absolutely the best pizza I had last year- great crust and crazily tasty toppings- super duper yummy mushrooms, ham and cheese. Apparently there were pistachios in the pizza but I really don't recall tasting that. The spaghetti with mullet roe was great too. And I have also tried the fettuccini with truffle cream that was also really good. I would totally recommend those dishes.  And very importantly, their portions were perfect. Not huge amounts but they will definitely leave you full. That is crucial in my books!As for desserts, I have tried their pistachio tiramisu (not spectacular) and the chocolate lava cake (the lava did not ooze out. it was just kind of hard, not at all molten as you would expect a lava cake to be). They were both not as great as their starters and mains.Their special wine pairing event that took place late last year was also really good. Most of the wines went well with the food and I was well happy with the food and drinks.Love the cosy feeling of this restaurant with its homely decor and non-pretentious and good service. And that makes the whole experience nicer. Anyway, in conclusion, Etna is highly recommended! Remember to make reservations if you want to try this during the weekend!

My favorite Italian restaurant in Singapore. The chefs come from all over Italy, so they have expertise in many styles. The price is very reasonable for the quality of the food. Most entrees are $20-$30. They always have a few fresh pasta dishes on the menu (essential for an Italian restaurant, in my book). I highly recommend the burrata appetizer. The cheese itself is very soft and creamy (essentially liquid inside) and its served with a nice rocket salad and excellent prosciutto.

A really awesome restaurant.Their service was outstanding albeit they have only 4 employes 2 waiters a chef and a manager and their food was also out of the ordinary i really recommend this restaurant even though it is a bit pricey.I have been to many high end italian restaurants but this was hands down a better experience

rest_name: Buyan Russian Haute Cuisine & Caviar Bar
comment: This is my default beer place for Duxton Hill. They usually have an interesting, if somewhat unusual, range of imported European beers and two taps.  I've never eaten as the other reviews say its hit and miss. Drinks drices are standard $12 range as anywhere else (btw, fun fact, in SG the government Alcohol tax on beer bottles amounts to only $1-1.5, its amazing how Singaporians are used to paying 150% markups on beer)!What's nice about Buyan is give dark Rye-bread chips complementary with any drinks. These salty crispy things are perfect to munch with with your dunkels.

rest_name: Buyan Russian Haute Cuisine & Caviar Bar
comment: During 2013 SG Restaurant Wk in March, Miss K. and I embarked on a Russian lunch escapade at Buyan, named after a mythical Russian island in one local fairytale. To maximize the variety, we ordered different items from the 3-course lunch($25) menu. The unique Russian black rye bread served with velvety butter that resembled mini billiard balls were signs of a good meal ahead.The first appetizer was Kharcho, a spicy Georgian lamb soup filled with rice grains and chunks of lamb. I usually do not expect much spiciness from western food but this soup had quite a robust peppery flavorThe 2nd appetizer was a classic Russian bite, Pelmeni (cold dumplings stuffed with mixed meat fillings). The unleavened dough skin made with just flour and water was indeed thick and chewy. However, the overall taste surpassed its dull presentation as the filling had a pleasant savoury taste without any strange odour.I thought the portion of the main course-Blinis with creamy chicken filling was only sufficient for kids. But unexpectedly, these traditional Russian pancakes had a sweet allure that matched perfectly with the savoury mushroom dip. The sauce was so delicious that we requested for moreThe Buckwheat kasha with Mushroom and Onion surprised us with its fine grainy texture. It tasted like a healthier version of fried rice as it is less greasy but yet extremely aromatic. Kasha generally means buckwheat but it can include cereal, mill, wheat,barley and oats.There was only one option for the dessert-Milk Kissel, a mixed of milk and raspberry jelly. Though this was not fanciful western-style plated dessert, I like its gloopy texture and the fact that it was not too rich or sweet.Fortunately, the restaurant agreed to change one of the set dessert to a dessert platter without any additional charge. Though the Milk Kissel made its appearance again, there were new faces such as the Napolean (vanilla Millefeuille with fresh berries) and the Honey Cake. Both were excellent in their own arena; especially the Honey Cake which is more similar to a crunchy Baklava than a cake. Conclusion: The $25-lunch menu may vary with the $35-dinner menu but the quality and portion of the food are similar. This was my first try at Russian cuisine, thus I had no previous reference to compare with. But we enjoyed the meal as it is easy to get used to the taste of Russian food (no particular exotique ingredients like bear paws, etc...). I would definitely return to try not the dinner, but the lunch deals at SGW, especially when there are more interesting cuisine worth trying.

rest_name: Buyan Russian Haute Cuisine & Caviar Bar
comment: Some friends had rave reviews of this place, after organizing a hen's night party here, so when I found out that they had $15 set lunches (2 courses) I found a friend and visited. Considering that their non-vegetarian mains hover around $30, this is good value--for set lunch there are three choices for mains and starters, with one vegetarian choice in each. I appreciate that they take care of their vegetarian customers, although the comment that the cabbage soup was only there for vegetarians was not very confidence-inspiring.I liked the borscht a lot more than my Olivier salad. It's kind of hard to like something that reminds me of frozen vegetables, but perhaps I just don't know Russian food. The borscht was a beautiful red, tangy, and nutty if you swirled in some sour cream. My friend's mushroom kasha had the mushrooms cut small; buckwheat is nutty, though this one had a funny aftertaste. Much improved by the addition of stroganoff gravy. For some reason I thought stroganoff was supposed to be tomato-based; in any case, plenty of beef slices, couldn't find the mushrooms. And this might be the only time I will complain that there wasn't enough mashed potato! We both paid the supplement for medovik, or honey-cake. I expected it to be like gingerbread or spice cake but this was a dry layer cake. The dessert blinis the next table had looked much more promising. Given that someone didn't have to go back to the office, my friend wanted to have a bit of vodka with his meal--something that he had had while traveling was out of stock but the waitstaff were able to recommend something similar. I was super impressed by their depth of knowledge and their passion for the vodka. I think Buyan will be an occasional curiosity for me--you won't see me back soon, until they change the set lunch menu, perhaps!

rest_name: Buyan Russian Haute Cuisine & Caviar Bar
comment: Buyan came highly recommended by some foodie friends so we thought we'd go check it out. The last time I had Russian food was prolly about 15 years ago at this cosy restaurant in Rail Mall, with a really nice owner and really commendable Russian food, but the poor chap was prolly ahead of culinary times and it shut down not long after. Since then I've had the odd borscht and dollop of caviar and blinis here and there, but not sat down to an entire Russian meal.Food : We ordered the kamchatka crab timbale with blinis which was pretty good, as was the organic quail egg done sunny side up with karat caviar. I really liked the crimean black tomato with cheese stuffing ... never had it before but it had an unusual flavor that I really took to. We followed that up with the pan seared duck magret which was also pretty yum (but then I'm partial to duck) and the halibut which was a bit on the bland and boring side. In the spirit of being all Russian purist, we went with the baba romovaya, this sponge cake dessert which was a nice end to the meal but nothing mindblowing.Ambience : All fancy with opulent chandeliers and whatnot. Bit chilly but they provide pashminas for guests so I thought that was a nice touch.Service : Well like I said, they provide pashminas for guests who are feeling the chill from the air conditioning, so that has to count for something. Generally pleasant and attentive, so no complaints there.I guess since this is the only Russian place I know, it'd be a good novelty meal type place when in the mood for something different.

rest_name: Buyan Russian Haute Cuisine & Caviar Bar
comment: Buyan, Russian fine dining and probably the only Russian  restaurant I know in Singapore.  The first thing you would probably notice is Buyan's Bar and not the fine dining restaurant which is actually located on the second floor. Buyan's bar stocks a mighty impressive alcohol collection with specially imported Russian Vodka of course, some of which were 80% alcohol by volume.  It's the bar that draws most of the attention. As for the food, I had a grilled meat platter with fish which was just alright. I don't know Russian flavors well but I am guessing it  is a whole lot of meat and Vodka or at least that is what I ordered. Overall an average experience which could have been better!

opening: [('Mon', ['Closed']), ('Tue', ['6:00 PM - 12:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Wed', ['6:00 PM - 3:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Thu', ['6:00 PM - 3:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Fri', ['6:00 PM - 3:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Sat', ['6:00 PM - 3:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Sun', ['Closed'])]
comment: This up and coming new establishment is showing growing signs,  very quickly growing signs that it desires to be the benchmark of what's good about Duxton hill.  Nestled away at a fabulous corner unit,  Life is Beautiful (LIB) is gaining traction very quickly amongst expats and locals alike,  all looking to enjoy themselves at a unique watering hole. LIB serves up a dinner menu as well,  and whilst I have heard great things about quality of food,  I have not been able to savour their delectable treats yet. Their manager is a close friend,  and he boasts aplenty of their famous butter milk fried chicken,  and if pictures are anything to go by I am sure it tastes heavenly. I did however,  have the pleasure of ending up there on Saturday night for a few drinks with friends. Once dinner time is over,  LIB bursts to life in the later part of the evenings where djs take centre stage,  and Singapore's finest talents,  sometimes guests from overseas,  control the dance floor with their signature sounds. LIB is a great place to unwind,  let your hair down, have a drink or three,  hell maybe even five,  and dance your troubles away.  There's ample seating as well if you want to rest your weary legs. They have themed nights with a wide variety of musical genres on offer depending on the day of the week. Their impartial attitude towards music is very appealing to me as a DJ. I give it 4 stars,  of course to be updated in future once I've given their food menu a try,  but their skilled bartenders and extensive selection of drinks,  along with the fantastic atmosphere and general feel of the place are worthy of a positive review. Watch out Duxton Hill,  Life is indeed Beautiful.

opening: [('Mon', ['Closed']), ('Tue', ['6:00 PM - 12:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Wed', ['6:00 PM - 3:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Thu', ['6:00 PM - 3:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Fri', ['6:00 PM - 3:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Sat', ['6:00 PM - 3:00 AM (Next day)']), ('Sun', ['Closed'])]
comment: A modest group of friends and I ended up at Life is Beautiful after not being able to get a table at another place on Duxton Hill. In fact, Life is Beautiful was the only rather empty restaurant/bar on the whole street. Despite it's cute name, maybe it's not as popular as the other places. It ended up filling up closer to 10:30pm though. The ambiance is nice and I like the variety if seating options. A glance at the haphazard drink menu left me uninterested and with a glass of water for the rest of the night. My friends didn't think the wine was very good either, so ehhh, come for the food if you must. We tried a variety of food items including the ribs, fried chicken, salad and gator meat balls. The food was surprisingly delicious and made up for my lack of interest in the drinks (I guess). They definitely have some interesting food options, and I'd highly recommend the ribs. The service was ok, although my water glass was frequently empty which I didn't like. Duxton hill is a unique little area, with a variety if other food and drink establishments around, definitely worth checking out :)

YOKOWA.... a quiet private mystery. Located at the far end of Duxton Road sits Yokowa. An intimate Japanese restaurant that opened in Nov 2016. First impressions: it's a very intimate restaurant which each section separated by blinds. Claustrophobics, don't worry. The ceiling is high, ensuring that despite being draped in, there's still a good sense of speciousness. There isn't an overload of food choices here. What they do specialize in is Kaiseki. However, if you're not sure about spending $118++ on your first visit, than give their $38++ bento meals a try (it's supposedly a lunch Benton but it is available for dinner too). Each set comes with a Miso soup, 6 side dishes and Okowa (steam Japanese glutinous rice), the pride of Yokowa. Both sets come with 3 similar side dishes (pickled vegetable, tamago yaki and braised summer vegetables). MATSU SETThe pickled vegetable were very good. I'm not usually a fan, but the ones here were not over powering the sour. It was just enough to help whet the appetite for the other dishes. Agedashi TofuThe tofu was so soft it felt like it would have melted in the mouth. Another great starter to have.Tamago YakiI was please tot surprised that the eggs were not sweet. They were perfectly cooked, giving off a nice bouncy snap with every bite and the flavors were perfect. Couldn't have asked for a better tasting Tamago. Grilled Cod This was yum. Grilled to absolute perfection, the cod had that smokiness on the outside and that juicy tenderness on the inside. I really enjoyed how they seasoned each dish minimally, ensuring that each item could be tasted the way it should be. Braised Summer Vegetables This was a surprising dish. It's served called, with the vegetable very lightly stewed (I would almost say a light poach). Plotted and carrots still had their crunch but it was the light, sweet braising liquid that really helped bring the dish together. Grilled Chicken. The chicken was very very tasty. Unfortunately, it was my fault taking my time to get to it as it had already dried out a fair bit (silly me left it till the very end). But despite being cold, dry and a little hard, the flavours were still very very good. Again, minimal seasoning to allow you to taste the chicken. OkawaOne taste of the rice and it felt like heaven. Perfectly steamed, the glutinous rice was sticky yet not overly starchy. It was very fragrant, very tasty and the Edamame and Ginko helped add an earthy umami-ness to the dish. I can see why this is their signature dish. TAKE SETBraised Eggplant. Oh my.... what has this place done to me?I've never been a fan of Eggplants and by never I mean detest it with all by life. There's something about the slimy, squishy texture that I really hate but.... I don't know what form of sorcery they used to cook it here but.... I really really liked it! Liked it so much in fact that the wife (who doesn't like Eggplant too) and I ended up fighting for the last piece. Fried breaded Salmon I know... what?!! Breaded Salmon?!?! But this was so perfectly done. The panko was so thin that it didn't take away anything from the salmon. It was lightly salted, ensuring that you don't lose any of the salmon's natural flavour. Stir Fried Beef The highlight of this bento, guaranteed. The beef slices had fantastic fat to meat ratio, ensuring that each bite gives you a little spring before it melts in your mouth. The sauce it came in was mind blowing, tasting like a very rich, stew like broth with its mixture of saltiness and sweetness. For $15+ we decided to "upgrade" our meal with a plate of sashimi and boy did it not disappoint. Every slice of fish was so fresh. The blue fin tuna had zero of the powdery texture and melts in your mouth. The salmon belly (or more like salmon fat) was so sinfully good and the Hamachi was heavenly. Firm when u bite down, nearly melting in your mouth after you bite and as the flavours mellow, you get this wonderful, fresh sweetness that lingers in your mouth Vanilla custard Pudding with fresh fruits What a way to finish up a dinner. For an additional $5+, you get a little bowl of vanilla custard pudding with fresh fruits. The Pudding was very light, very fragrant and wobbled with each touch. The acidity from the oranges, kiwis and strawberries helped break the sweetness a little, cleansing your pallet at the same time. Overall, it was a fantastic experience. The decor could be a little better, with the panels of our ceiling lamp missing. Dinner was a little on the pricier range but we were more than willing to pay for the freshness and the service.

Great spot. Best lobster roll I've ever had with a perfectly matched Singapore beer.I ordered the truffle lobster roll which was nicely done, the bread was a perfect texture and the lobster wasn't messy. It was the classiest lobster roll I've ever seen, which you never see since part of a lobster roll's character is its messiness. The fries were freshly made in-house as well.However...it is very hard to justify the $68 for that one truffle sandwich or $58 for a normal lobster roll. You really need to be in the mood for a lobster roll to come here for that price, regardless of the quality.Nevertheless, highly recommend if you are in the mood for one!
Came with my sister who booked via chope. Seemed to have good reviews and hey it's lobsters. Who can say no to lobsters?

Im not too sure i like this place or will return. There are only 3 items on the menu. We tried the 'famous' lobster roll as well as steamed lobster. While both dishes were cooked to perfection, there's just something missing that I could not describe. It's a little bit pretentious compared to the ones in London and New York that Ive tried to be honest. All 3 main dish are standard price - $48 and all come with sides of fries and salad. We paid $175 for 2 mains, a glass of white and a bottle of cider. If you've heard a lot of this place and want to try it yourself, come. But after that, it's up to you if you'll return. For me, if i cant find anything to eat around Duxton Hill, then maybe ill go in and get the lobster roll.

I have always wanted to try Pince & Pints, so the love of my life decided to make it happen for me. I tried to call to make a reservation and realized that they don't take reservations at all. Still it is good to call then u know if they have available tables and potentially avoid being disappointed with a long wait. When I called the manager, informed me that there were 2 available tables for 2. Upon arrival, there was already a couple before us, And the place was packed! There are only 3 dishes on the menu and prices are at $58++ each! Yikes! Inflation ah?! The earlier reviews stated they were $48++ before! Dishes include: 1. Whole lobster with herb and butter sauce (steamed or grilled), accompanied with fries and salad2. Lobster roll, fries (with garlic aioli), and salad3. Chilli lobster with mantou We chose to have the steamed lobster and the infamous lobster roll. The service was awesome, prompt and very professional. When the waiter learnt that we were sharing, he proactively informed us that he will tell the chef to cut the portions into 2. How thoughtful!The lobster roll meal was good but it's not great! The lobster meat that was sandwiched between a fried butter bun was thick and juicy. However, The seafood mayo used to coat the lobster meat seemed to mask the taste the true taste of the lobster. Also if you are like me where you are sharing the actual whole lobster with another person, you will begin to notice that there is a stark difference in the amount of lobster on the roll compared with the actual lobster. I am sorry if you price every dish the same and even print on your menu that every dish gives me the whole lobster, you better make me believe it. The steamed lobster was awesome though! Because it's steamed, you get to enjoy the taste of the fresh, succulent, juicy and sweet taste of the lobster. It's literally steamed to perfection, the meat was tender and you are able to pick the flesh out easily. Definitely 2 thumbs up! Just one thing to note, if you are not big on salt, do ask the waiter to inform the chef to reduce the salt on your fries or give you unsalted fries. Mine was drowned with salt this evening, which left me rather disappointed. Another must-try are their cocktails and mocktails. A lot of time, thought and effort have been placed into perfecting the taste of each one. What I like is that they use fresh juices and not some canned juice or cordial. Definitely worth the investment! Overall, we did have a good experience this evening but I won't be back in a long while. It's really too expensive!! Would I recommend this place? I agree with the other reviewers here, I would say it's ok to go if you are like me, ie, never eaten a whole lobster before. After that, it's really up to you and your wallet.

If you're a crustacean lover and lobster is all you can think about at days, you definitely have to try them out. They only have 4 main lobster dishes to choose from; Chilli Lobster, Lobster Roll, Grilled Lobster or Steam Lobster. I've tried all of them and I love them all! The lobster is of decent size and done right with a price tag that will not (really) burn a hole in your wallet. (P.s. Ask for the garlic aioli sauce.)

It may not be completely fair of me to write this review since I'm not a big fan of lobster. I was there because my wife loves the stuff and heard it was the best in town. It probably was, but I was hoping for a little variety on the menu. It was limited. They clearly focus on their strengths, since everything was heavily lobster-based. I got the least lobster-centric dish, the lobster roll. Lots of creamy lobster.So maybe I'm a bit of a d!ck for judging a place called "Pince and Pints" for having too much lobster, but one of the reasons I was so agreeable about trying the place was the promise of the "pints". Disappointing. They had exactly one beer on tap, and it was one that I wouldn't ever order. They had a few passable bottles. Passable, but utterly disappointing for a place with the freaking word "pints" in their name. False advertising.But the service was great. Good job team!

Ordered grilled lobster and lobster roll to share. Grilled lobster was smaller than anticipated, served with a decadent butter sauce. Lobster roll was the star of the night, roll itself so buttery and crunchy, which compliments the tender lobster meat thats coated in a unique mayo-like dressing. Good but not sure if will return again.

We had lunch at pince and pints. Had a whole grilled lobster and lobster roll. Both dishes were tasty, with the lobsters done just right. The bun for the lobster roll was nice and buttery, with a good helping of the lobster. Sides of corn and fries were tasty.  The dips served along with the dishes were pretty good too. However, we found the pricing to be on the steep side. So if price is not a concern, then this is a great place to go to.

On Duxton Hill there are some pretty decent wine options. This tapas place should primarily be visited for their wine list - don't get me wrong their tapas are pretty good (favorites include the pan con tomate as well as the chorizo)  as well but the main reason I come here is the wine.They have a good selection of wines by the glass. They usually have a cava from really excellent producer Agusti Toréllo by the glass as well as champagne from Delamotte (for those who do not know this is the 'sister' winery of Salon and the fifth oldest champagne house). In addition they usually also have at least 3 white, 3 red and 1 rosé wine by the glass as well. All wines are usually solid choices and while it may not be cheap it is decent value for money and it is clear they know their wines.The staff are usually very friendly and most of them are good with wine recommendations. The place can get pretty packed in the later part of the evening and pretty loud so prefer coming here pretty early.

For big eaters (guilty flush comes to my face), Sabio offers the best value in quality tapas in Singapore on Sundays!Show up early if you have a big group or pull up a couple of stools at the long bar and be prepared to stuff your little bellies with free flow hot and cold tapas for 49.90 (+20 for free flow cava and sangria).Among our favorite items on the menu are:1. Churros: crispy on the outside, creamy on the inside and served with dark chocolate sauce on the side2. Sizzling Prawns: the classic tapas dish, with flawless execution (I can personally eat two orders)3. Ham Croquettes: the plain cheese croquettes are good, but I think the ham version is even more delicious4. Oysters: nothing makes a Sunday afternoon feel more luxe than a dozen oysters paired with sparkling wine5. Pan Fried Calamares: almost as delicious as the sizzling prawns, simply done in a small colorful frying pan 6. Spanish Cheese Plate: of course, El Queso Grande loves the free flow cheese platter, manchego is his favorite cheese of allPARTING THOUGHT: bring your glutton, but leave the assholes at home... We've seen bad patrons over order and waste the delicious food!  Sabio had to start charging for wastage as a result!  Order a few tapas each round and relax and pace yourself!

2nd time here and the experience has been good. The tapas portions are generally small so 1-for-1 tapas Monday is really a great deal with a larger portion at the same price! *note: 1-for-1 tapas deal applies to the same tapas dish ordered and excludes cold cuts. The seafood hot tapas are generally flavorful except for the Octopus. There's something about the Octopus seasoning/gravy that just doesn't sit well with our palette. The scallops are a must-order in my opinion. To end off, throw in a serving of churros, served warm (and crispy), with a rich bittersweet chocolate sauce - heavenly!Seats may be hard to get as it gets later in the evening so do head down early to get a nice table.

Sabio wasn't my first choice, was out and about a while back and wanted to go to Lucha Loco but it was packed, so decided on Sabio because there were seats at the bar, and I was getting hangry.  I'm not a big tapas fan, although I do like the idea of sharing little plates, and getting an assortment of things over one big plate of the same thing, but for some reason I never really get 6-7 SOLID little plates, which was the case at Sabio.  Ordered between myself and dining companion the meatballs (a bit dry and over cooked) the calamari (greasy, and drowned in chili oil I think)  some onion quiche looking thing (didn't try that, looked a bit odd) and something else I can't remember.  They do have a good wine list, so I'll give them that, and the food came out quick.  Service was really good, but the food was just meh.  The prices were also really good, especially for Duxton, so I would def. go back for cocktails or wine, but probably not the food.

Sabio Tapas Bar is a gem hidden along the Duxton stretch. The deco at this wine bistro is most inviting, with walls decorated with eclectic motifs, a long table and many seats in various permutations. We ordered white and red sangria ($10) which did not taste too strongly of brandy, and was tasty because of an adequate amount of fruit juice and sugar. It was sweet, and tasted a bit like fruit punch with alcohol. Their wine comes from vending machines, and you can choose if you want a tasting portion, half a cup or a whole cup. They also serve a wide range of Tapas. The menu is divided into four parts: Cold Tapas ($6-19), Jamon & Chorizo ($8-25), Hot Tapas ($8-18) and desserts ($6-8). As we were there for a late night drink , we didn't try the Tapas. Would certainly pop by another day to give it a shot as the description on the menu makes the food sound glorious.
Decent place with standard tapas, live music and ok sangria. Loved the chorizo and red wine, shrimp and white wine and ham croquettes. Meatballs and patatas were average.

This place WAS open on Sunday and was amazing. We had the scallops, octopuss, garlic mushrooms and calamari hot tapas. The french bread was fresh baked and they have a wide drinks selection. A nice place to visit to get away from the orchard madness.

Amongst the many Spanish tapas bars that have sprouted up of late, Sabio remains one of my favourites.Food : The vieras en salsa de cava  (sea scallops with sparkling white wine sauce) were pretty excellent ... the sauce was really good and we couldn't help mopping it up with other tapas. The gambas pil pil (prawns in olive oil and garlic) was also pretty tasty and the embutidos mixtos, a selection of Spanish ham, sausages, and cheese was a huge hit. The patatas aioli (fried potatoes with garlic mayonnaise) was deliciously addictive though the pork with saffron was a tad on the tough side.Ambience : A great vibe for drinks and tapas ... love the decor and overall ambience. The seats at the bar were a bit cramped though, leg room was insufficient so we had to sit side waysService : Great!Sabio doesn't take reservations so advisable to go early or very late

Spanish Tapas Bar and probably the most upbeat place along Duxton Hill on Thursday night or make it every night. If you've outgrown clubbing, this is the place for you! Call it lounging or socializing, this place has a beautiful crowd every evening. People aside, Sabio is a great place to get your Sangria or the ever popular Leffe Blonde beer on tap for a very reasonable price of $8 a glass. When you're first seated, a small complimentary portion of tapas is given to you to give you a taste of things to come if you do decide to try the tapas. I only ever had one tapas dish there that was really expensive, it was the shaved Aged Corn-fed Black Iberian Pork. I can tell you for sure the complex name justifies the fantastic flavor! There is no better way to end a work week with drinks, great food and great people!

Sabio, located in the increasingly hip Duxton area, is a bar I go to when I want a cheap pint of beer when I'm hanging out in the area. A pint of Hoegaarden goes for $12, and you'll be hard pressed to find a bar in the area which serves beer at a cheaper price. Their specialty though has to be their sangria - they serve both white and red versions, with the former being especially refreshing to drink when Singapore's weather is being muggy and difficult. Sabio has a latin feel, often playing irresistible Spanish songs which leave your feet tapping unconsciously. The decor is tastefully done up with black and white wall paper. I've even brought friends from overseas there and have them remarked that the bar makes them feel like they are in Miami!One drawback about Sabio however has to be their seats. The outdoor seats are nothing more than stools, and the front half of the bar is given over to strange semi-booth like tables which force you to position yourself in an awkward spot if you wish to talk to a friend face to face. That being said though, the vibe and cheap drinks more than make up for these minor inconveniences

Since the miny tapas explosion a couple of years ago in Singapore, this place is my old faithful. Straight forward no frills tapas here, nothing fancy, just straight forward classic tapas items. That shouldn't let that put you off though, cause after numerous visits the food has always been spot on and well executed. Nothing can be more satisfying than 50g of iberico de bellota shaved off the bone in front of you while you sit at the bar. The bacalao is quite simply the best I've had in Singapore. Staff are knowledgeable about product, which is exactly what you'll need if your not familiar with Spanish tapas concepts or items.  This place wont burn a whole in your pocket either, great Spanish tapas, In a very European inspired fit out, all in the easy central location of Duxton Hill. Have been here at least 6 times, and Im sure I will be back many more.

There are many things Sabio's does right (deco, the spread of food) and can do better at (the intrusive live music, a stronger sangria) but the only really important thing is the grilled bone marrow cooked in special butter, served with bread. Far and away the best thing I've eaten all year in its delicious, decadent butteriness, coupled with a full, rich meatyness that seizes your faculties and refuses to let go. Nothing else (on the menu or otherwise) really comes close.

You should try their sojurita and beerita(?). Pretty in pictures and tasted great too. Typical girly sweet drinks. It can be shared but i didn't know so I finished it myself haha.Snacks are not to be shared among more than two coz it is small. In singapore, it is still considered reasonably priced. It could help if they had little light to read the super small printed menu. That annoyed me.
Pretty cool place .  Friendly staff and good tunes . The Happy Hour Hoegaarden was HUGEEEEEE.  Casual & none pretentious

Drury Lane Cafe was completely full and I was looking for another place to get some work done. This place looked pretty hip from the outside and it was quite empty. They sold coffee so I decided to head inside and check it out. I asked if they had free wifi and power outlets and they did! Why not. There are plenty of seats by the walls that have power outlets. Wifi isn't too bad for emails and low-bandwidth tasks. The place has a nice ambiance. The design and setting of the place is conducive to work. They play jazz music in the restaurant and the hosts are very polite. Coffee is not bad, but not amazing. I wouldn't come here for the coffee, but I would come back to work here. I ordered the kimchi panini for lunch. The side salad just had normal thousand island dressing (some you would get at a cafeteria). The panini was not bad. Kimchi was good, but it was a bit cold. I think this is how you are supposed to eat it. I wish they also had some chicken or something because it's just cheese, sauce, kimchi on bread. The dish is a bit messy, I used a bunch of napkins, gave up on using my hands to eat and just used knife and fork. Their weekly lunch specials look really good, but seeing as I'm here on a Sunday, I went for their normal menu.

Food had potential but I've had way better Korean Mexican fusion food before. Service was pretty bad, we had to wait more than an hour for our food even with reminding the server. The burritos were just drenched in cheese and did not have much flavor beyond that, and the nachos were just chips. The one positive thing is the drink specials and happy hour, or "drink buffet". If you can drink a lot you can really save with the $35 for men and $28 for women all you can drink from 6-9. The margaritas were pretty good as well. Just go here for drinks and skip the food.

It's been a long time since they've opened and I'm still unsure whether this place is called Dabang or 'don't tell mama'. I first popped by when they were less than a month old and bought myself a salted caramel ice latte. The drink was good but service was terrible, so I never went back again until recently when I was craving a sweet hot drink. There really isn't much to say. The drinks are very sweet which meant that it worked well if you like starbucks frappuccinos. The hot chocolate, ironically touted as the 'best hot chocolate or your money will be refunded', was absolutely terrible. The image is deceivingly large; it's a shot of intense chocolate. The chocolate itself wasn't bad but the viscosity of the drink reminded me of when is first tried to make hot chocolate with equal parts milk and chocolate. It was topped off with generous whipped cream (sort of like bicerin but without coffee and much thicker), which I tried a little of and then decided it wasn't worth the calories. I've never tried the food (the high price point for simple sandwiches really puts me off), so perhaps it'd be worth it after all. The service is...lackluster. It appears to be run by two Korean girls, one of whom takes orders at the counter and always appears unhappy at customers. Everything takes ages from waiting to order to waiting for the food and there's no real service involved apart from preparation of food and drinks. Given that a simple lunch can easily cost above $20 here, I wouldn't recommend this place over all the other great eateries with better service available in a the area at the same cost.
